headline: Port of Tanjung Pelepas Successfully Completes Simultaneous LNG Bunkering Operation
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Port of [TANJUNG PELEPAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1010?name=TANJUNG-PELEPAS&country=Malaysia) in Malaysia successfully conducted their first simultaneous operation of liquefied natural gas bunkering (SIMOPS). ![BANGKOK EXPRESS involved in SIMOPS operation at the Port of Tanjung Pelepas](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BANGKOK_EXPRESS_3c4b5e328a.png)*Vessel BANGKOK EXPRESS, image credit: Port of Tanjung Pelepas* This transfer involved the ship-to-ship bunkering of LNG from the bunker vessel [MT PAOLINA COSULICH ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8166410/mmsi:533132943/imo:9956836/vessel:PAOLINA_COSULICH)and the Hapag Lloyd-operated vessel [BANGKOK EXPRESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9344338/mmsi:211108330/imo:9943889/vessel:BANGKOK_EXPRESS). The initiative was conducted in collaboration with PETCO Trading Labuan Co., Ltd. (PTLCL) and Hapag-Lloyd. Simultaneous Natural gas bunkering or SIMOPS refers to the practice of conducting LNG bunkering operations alongside other port activities such as cargo handling or vessel maintenance. This reduces the time vessels spend in port, maximizing efficiency and reducing operational costs.

headline: Wallenius Wilhelmsen Completes Successful Biofuel Bunkering Trial in Japan
author: Raghib Raza
content: Wallenius Wilhelmsen has marked a key milestone in its sustainability strategy with the successful bunkering trial of Bio Bunker B24 (VLSFO Blended) in Japan. ![ TAMESIS](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/TAMESIS_17bcb43cc2.png)*Image credit: Wallenius Wilhelmsen* In the trial, [M/V TAMESIS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:307446/mmsi:257565000/imo:9191307/vessel:TAMESIS#overview) bunkered 400 metric tons of Bio Bunker B24 biofuel at the Port [YOKOHAMA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/260?name=YOKOHAMA&country=Japan), Japan. Mitsubishi Corporation Energy Co, Ltd. supplied the biofuel as a part of its strategy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and expand the availability of biofuel at major global ports. This successful bunkering operation was also made possible through a collaboration between Wallenius Wihelmsen’s Energy Sourcing team and Orcelle Accelerator taskforce. Together, they worked for two years to establish biofuel capabilities in Japan. Wallenius Wilhelmsen aims to achieve net-zero emissions by 2040 and targets cutting greenhouse emissions by 40% by 2030, using its 2022 levels as a baseline. Since 2023, the company has broadened its biofuel supply reach to ports in Korea, Singapore, Belgium, and now Japan, joining this network to support cleaner shipping.

headline: Hong Kong Advances Green Shipping with First LNG Bunkering
author: Raghib Raza
content: Hong Kong conducted its first ship-to-ship transfer operation on 14th February. This marks a significant milestone in the trajectory of Hong Kong, which is looking to transition towards green shipping. ![ZIM AQUAMARINE](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ZIM_AQUAMARINE_da713f6aac.png)*Vessel ZIM AQUAMARINE, image credit:imarinenews.com* The bunkering was carried out by the Kunlun Energy Co. Ltd., a subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation. The dual-fuel container ship [ZIM AQUAMARINE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9272689/mmsi:477025700/imo:9968097/vessel:ZIM_AQUAMARINE#overview) was the recipient of the LNG transfer, with the vessel [XIN AO PU TUO HAO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6762957/mmsi:413282560/imo:9870628/vessel:XIN_AO_PU_TUO_HAO) providing 2,200 tonnes of Ultra-low-temperature LNG. The inaugural bunkering operation was attended by high-ranking officials and representatives from Hong Kong government bodies. LNG has been recognized as a cleaner burning fuel that reduces carbon dioxide emissions by 25% and nitrogen dioxide emissions by 85% and almost completely eliminates sulfur dioxide emissions when compared to traditional marine fuels.

headline: U.S. Forces Save Crew of Sinking Iranian Cargo Ship in Arabian Gulf
author: Raghib Raza
content: The U.S. Navy and Coast Guard successfully rescued crew members from the sinking Iranian cargo vessel [SHAYESTEH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:657595/mmsi:422004700/imo:9033036/vessel:SHAYESTEH#overview) on 18th February in the Arabian Gulf. The seven rescued crew members, including two Indians and five Iranians, were safe, and no injuries were reported. ![SHAYESTEH sank in Arabian Sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SHAYESTEH_3090871b0e.png)*Cargo Vessel SHAYESTEH, image credit: US CENTCOM* The 50.3-meter-long cargo vessel, which was flying a Qatari flag while in territorial waters, developed a severe list and issued a mayday call before sinking. Upon receiving the distress call, the U.S. Navy ship and U.S. Coast Guard Cutter vessel promptly responded and assisted the crewmembers who had abandoned [SHAYESTEH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:657595/mmsi:422004700/imo:9033036/vessel:SHAYESTEH#overview). The rescued crewmembers were then taken aboard the U.S. Coast Guard Cutter vessel and received medical care. U.S. CENTCOM reported that the vessel sank. However, the circumstances leading to the sinking of the vessel are yet to be determined.

headline: “MSC Baltic III” Grounds Off Newfoundland Coast Amid Stormy Conditions
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 15th February, a Liberian-flagged container ship, [MSC BALTIC III](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:123998/mmsi:636021252/imo:9241475/vessel:MSC_BALTIC_III), ran aground after losing power in severe weather conditions. The 33,767dwt container ship, which was carrying 20 crew members, was safe, and no injuries were reported. ![MSC BALTIC III ran aground.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSC_BALTIC_III_e0eb025106.png)*Container ship MSC BALTIC III, image credit: Canadian Coast Guard* A mayday call was received by Marine Communication and Traffic Services in Port aux Basques from the container ship, which was approximately 12 nautical miles outside the entrance of Bay of Island, Newfoundland, Canada. The weather conditions were unfavorable, with winds exceeding 120 kilometers per hour and waves reaching 6 meters high. [MSC BALTIC III ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:123998/mmsi:636021252/imo:9241475/vessel:MSC_BALTIC_III) was unable to secure its anchor and subsequently ran aground in Wild Cove, west of Lark Harbour. In response, the Canadian Coast Guard dispatched the icebreaker [HENRY LARSEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:381660/mmsi:316013000/imo:8409329/vessel:HENRY_LARSEN) and a Cormorant helicopter to assist in the rescue operation. The Cormorant helicopter successfully airlifted all the crew members aboard [MSC BALTIC III](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:123998/mmsi:636021252/imo:9241475/vessel:MSC_BALTIC_III), and no injuries were reported. The cause of the power failure and the extent of structural damage are not yet known. Authorities are monitoring the containership for any potential release from the fuel tank.

headline: Bulk Carrier “Lila Incheon” Strikes Quay at Brunsbüttel Port During Berthing
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 13th February, Liberian-flagged bulk carrier [LILA INCHEON](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:689605/mmsi:636022355/imo:9571272/vessel:LILA_INCHEON#overview) allided with the quay while maneuvering to berth at the [BRUNSBUTTEL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1497?name=BRUNSBUETTEL&country=Germany) Port in Elbe River, Germany. No injuries or pollution were released in the incident. ![LILA INCHEON allided with quay at Brunsbuttel Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LILA_INCHEON_345743e283.png)*Bulk Carrier LILA INCHEON, image credit: Max Wei* According to the Brunsbuttel water police, the initial report indicated that a maneuvering error caused the bulk carrier to strike the quay, resulting in hull damage, including a hole above the waterline. However, no water ingress was reported. [LILA INCHEON](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:689605/mmsi:636022355/imo:9571272/vessel:LILA_INCHEON#overview) has been detained by the authorities for the necessary repairs and inspection to assess its seaworthiness. [LILA INCHEON](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:689605/mmsi:636022355/imo:9571272/vessel:LILA_INCHEON#overview) is a 2010-built vessel with a carrying capacity of 32,401 tonnes. It is 180.82 meters long and 30 meters wide.

headline: Explosion on Oil Tanker SEAJEWEL in Italy; Cause Remains Unclear
author: Raghib Raza
content: The oil tanker [SEAJEWEL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:728750/mmsi:229160000/imo:9388807/vessel:SEAJEWEL#overview) was rocked by explosions on 14th February as it was docked in the Italian city of Savona. An investigation into the incident is underway, and the cause of the explosion has not been ascertained yet. No injuries or pollution were reported. ![SEAJEWEL rocked by explosions in Italian water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SEAJEWEL_f4b2157f25.png)*Vessel SEAJEWEL, image credit: Claudio Ritossa* The vessel’s crew reported hearing two loud bangs, following which the hull of the vessel had a concave deformation. The port authority has stated that the crew of the vessel had halted the operation of unloading oil prior to the explosion. However, the hull of the vessel has been caved inwards; the damage is located below the waterline, and the fish kill in the area of the explosion supports the theory of an external explosive device. The Savona Coast Guard has initiated an investigation into the matter, although no official statements regarding the incident have been made yet. A diving team from the Italian Navy has been brought in for support, and the local anti-mafia department has been notified. The vessel previously loaded Russian cargo three times in 2024, and Ukrainian authorities have claimed that, at the time of the incident, it was transporting Russian oil to Europe despite sanctions.

headline: Ocean Network Express Christened its First Owned and Operated Newbuilding Vessel
author: Raghib Raza
content: For the first time in Ocean Network Express’s (ONE) history, the company christened a newbuild vessel that they own and operate. The vessel, christened the [ONE SPARKLE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9401215/mmsi:563251300/imo:9975612/vessel:ONE_SPARKLE#overview), strengthened ONE’s competitive position in the global maritime industry along with showcasing their commitment to sustainable practices. ![ONE SPARKLE christened by ONE.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ONE_SPARKLE_db3ceb93d7.png)*Vessel ONE SPARKLE, image credit: ONE* The [ONE SPARKLE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9401215/mmsi:563251300/imo:9975612/vessel:ONE_SPARKLE#overview) was built at Hyundai Heavy Industries in Ulsan, South Korea. It features an optimized hull design for increased efficiency, cutting-edge energy-saving devices, integration of smart technology on the vessel for optimizing performance, and a shore power connection for zero emissions at ports. The vessel is a Singapore-registered container carrier that has a carrying capacity of 13,800 TEUs. The vessel is also dual-fuel compatible, being capable of operating on methanol and ammonia. This also makes the vessel future-ready as it can switch to these environmentally friendly fuels if required. The [ONE SPARKLE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9401215/mmsi:563251300/imo:9975612/vessel:ONE_SPARKLE#overview) is one of a series of 20 vessels that have been placed on order by ONE in Korea and Japan. These vessels are expected to be delivered in 2025 and 2026.

headline: Canadian government Approves 35.5 million CAD Grant for Developing Shore Power Facilities
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Canadian Minister for Transport and Internal Trade announced a grant of 35.5 million CAD ($25 million) for the development of shore power facilities in the province of British Columbia in Canada. ![VANCOUVER PORT](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/VANCOUVER_PORT_54edd4a2f9.png)*VANCOUVER PORT, image credit:Graeme Waller* The funding of 35.5 million CAD overall has been provided under the Green Shipping Corridor Program, which has been founded for increasing the usage of clean energy in the infrastructure at ports and terminals. Among others, the program has the objective of investing in the establishment of shore power infrastructure in port areas to reduce emissions from idling ships. Three projects have received a total of 35.5 million CAD. First is the Greater Victoria Harbor Authority (GVHA), which will receive 22.5 million CAD to implement shore power equipment at the Ogden Point cruise terminal. The second is Seaspan Ferries, which will receive an amount of 6.14 million CAD for implementing shore power equipment at four of its terminals, namely in Delta, Nanaimo, North Saanich, and Surrey. The third and final entity to receive funding is the Vancouver Fraser Port Authority (VFPA), which will receive 6.6 million CAD for upgrading the shore power infrastructure at the Canada Place Cruise Terminal, located at the Port of [VANCOUVER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/682?name=VANCOUVER&country=Canada).

headline: Shipping costs to surge in the Mediterranean amid new regulations
author: Stephanie Duscha
content: ![ship-8263464_1280.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ship_8263464_1280_ac120676e2.jpg) Kpler analysts are forecasting a rise in shipping costs across the Mediterranean as new emissions regulations come into force. The upcoming Mediterranean Emission Control Area (ECA), set to take effect on 1 May, 2025, combined with the introduction of the FuelEU regulations, is expected to push fuel prices higher, resulting in increased freight rates throughout the region. As the shipping industry braces for these converging regulations, vessels may turn to alternative fuels, but the transition is likely to come at a cost, further driving up operational expenses for shippers. Last year, it was announced that the Mediterranean Sea will become an Emission Control Area (ECA) starting on 1 May, 2025. This means the sulphur content of fuel used on board ships must not exceed 0.1%, a significant reduction from the previous limit of 0.5%. The only exception is for ships equipped with scrubbers - exhaust gas cleaning systems (EGCS) - which ensure an equivalent reduction in sulphur oxide (SOx) emissions. Other regions, such as the Baltic Sea, North Sea, North American waters, and the U.S. Caribbean Sea, are already designated as ECAs. [![Risk & Compliance London Breakfast Briefing.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Risk_and_Compliance_London_Breakfast_Briefing_7ec2f0cd41.png)](https://www.kpler.com/event/risk-and-compliance-london-breakfast-briefing) While previous regulations, like IMO 2020, saw a smoother adaptation than initially feared, this new market for lower-sulphur bunker fuels could still create challenges, as vessels will need to secure compliant fuel supplies, such as 0.15% MGO and USLFO, with existing demand from other regions. Jean-Christophe Monfort, Senior Product Manager - Emissions at Kpler, says shipowners will be seeking alternative fuels to avoid fines: >“The timing of the Mediterranean ECA also coincides with the upcoming FuelEU regulations starting on January 1, 2025, which may trigger shipowners to consider alternative fuels like LNG or biofuels to avoid penalties. This regulatory convergence could lead some fleet owners to prioritise these cleaner fuels for Mediterranean routes, potentially reducing reliance on scrubbers as the default compliance method. But with bunker fuel costs for alternative fuels higher than regular HFO or VLSFO, trading in the region will still face increased costs.” Kpler Freight Analyst Matt Wright adds that the combination of the Mediterranean ECA and EU regulations means costs for shippers will likely increase and be passed on to the charterer, raising freight rates across Europe and the Mediterranean. >“For short-haul voyages taking place entirely within the ECA or EU, alternative fuel vessels will become increasingly popular, while scrubber-fitted ships will be favoured for longer voyages," Wright said.

headline: OOCL Welcomes New Ultra-Large Container Ship into Fleet
author: Raghib Raza
content: Hong Kong-based ocean carrier Orient Overseas Container Line has welcomed new containership OOCL ABU DHABI into its fleet. It is the eighth 24,188 TEU vessel to join the OOCL’s fleet. This vessel is 400 meters long and 61.3 meters wide, an ultra-large containership registered in Hong Kong. OOCL ABU DHABI is part of the six 24188 TEU new builds that OOCL has ordered from the Dalian COSCO KHI Ship Engineering Co. Ltd shipyard in China. Six 21,188 TEU vessels joined the OOCL fleet in 2023, OOCL Spain being the first that Nantong COSCO KHI Ship Engineering Co delivered in February 2023. For OOCL, this is the second 24000+ TEU box ship delivery as the company welcomed OOCL Valencia in January 2024, taking yard delivery from Nantong COSCO KHI Shipyard. Junguang Xiao, Director of OOCL, said that the continuous delivery of new vessels and more ships carrying the blossom logo of OOCL at sea marks the continued upgrade of OOCL’s fleet structure. He added that OOCL is committed to bringing its customers greener and better integrated end-to-end logistics services.

headline: World’s First Ship-To-Ship Bunkering of Green Methanol Completed in Ulsan
author: Raghib Raza
content: The world’s first ship-to-ship bunkering of green methanol fuel was carried out on the 16,000-ton TEU container ship “ANE MAERSK." The bunkering was performed at Ulsan Port, South Korea. The ISSC-certified green bio-methanol for the bunkering operation was supplied by OCI Global. The Ministry of Oceans and Fisheries announced the completion of the bunkering operation. The ANE MAERSK is now set to embark on its maiden voyage from Ulsan to Copenhagen, making stops at Singapore, Egypt, and Rotterdam along the way. The naming ceremony of the ANE MAERSK took place at the Ulsan port around two weeks ago. The ship was built at the HD Hyundai Heavy Industries shipyard, also located in Ulsan. This vessel is the first of a series of 18 large methanol-powered ships that are to be delivered to Maersk between 2024 and 2025. The Ministry of Oceans and Fisheries established the “Guidelines for Approval of Self-Safety Management Plan for Methanol Supply," a framework that was utilized in the bunkering operation. The ministry has been involved in two prior bunkering demonstrations in July and November of last year. The Minister for Oceans and Fisheries, Kang Do-Hyung, has stated that, due to the global goal of eliminating emissions by 2050, many international ports are competing to build infrastructure to supply sustainable marine fuels. The Ministry and the Ulsan Port Authority have stated that they will continue to upgrade the systems related to bunkering and work on establishing standard operating procedures for the supply of methanol. Additionally, they have also confirmed that they intend to collaborate with the private sector to secure the supply of sustainable marine fuel.

headline: Cook Islands-Flagged Tanker Resumes Journey After Five-Day Stranding Off Kerala Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: An asphalt/bitumen tanker, [Y L W](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5432144/mmsi:518100887/imo:9360398/vessel:Y_L_W#overview), sailing under the flag of Cook-Is, was stranded at sea for five days due to a technical issue. The vessel resumed its journey after receiving assistance from the Kerala Maritime Board’s Vizhinjam officials on 18th February. ![Y L W stranded for five days due to fuel pump malfunctioning.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Y_L_W_a4847fe803.png)*Vessel Y L W, image credit: V. Tonic* The 106.84-meter-long tanker, en route from [HALDIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/18985?name=HALDIA&country=India), India, to [SHARJAH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/103?name=SHARJAH&country=United-Arab-Emirates), UAE, was anchored 14 nautical miles off the Kerala coast near Vizhinjam, in India after its fuel pump malfunctioned. The captain of [Y L W](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5432144/mmsi:518100887/imo:9360398/vessel:Y_L_W#overview), in coordination with the Thiruvananthapuram-based shipping agency Dowins Resources, contacted the Kerala Maritime Board for assistance. In response, the Kerala Maritime Board dispatched a tugboat with a replacement fuel pump to deliver to the stranded tanker. On 17th February, at around 8 PM local time, the tug arrived with the fuel pump and was transferred to [Y L W](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5432144/mmsi:518100887/imo:9360398/vessel:Y_L_W#overview) using the tanker’s crane. After the successful repair, [Y W L](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5432144/mmsi:518100887/imo:9360398/vessel:Y_L_W#overview) continued its journey around midnight on 18th February. Y L W is a 2007-built vessel with a carrying capacity of 6,012 tonnes. Marine Traffic data indicate that the vessel is scheduled to arrive at [SHARJAH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/103?name=SHARJAH&country=United-Arab-Emirates) by 27th February.

headline: Maritime Authorities Refloated Bulk Carrier PRIMUS After Grounding Off China’s Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Liberian-flagged bulk carrier [PRIMUS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:462098/mmsi:636018306/imo:9310757/vessel:PRIMUS) successfully refloated after running aground near the entrance of Luoyuan Bay, off the southwest coast of China on 17th February. The vessel was carrying 23 crewmembers, all of whom were safely rescued. ![PRIMUS refloated after grounding off China Coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PRIMUS_f5abb75e77.png)*Vessel PRIMUS, image credit: Maxi Alonso* Following the distress call from the vessel, a rescue operation was launched, with the Fujian Maritime Safety Administration deploying a patrol vessel to manage traffic in the area. Two tug boats arrived and initiated the refloating of [PRIMUS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:462098/mmsi:636018306/imo:9310757/vessel:PRIMUS#overview). Two oil spill control vessels were also deployed as a precautionary measure. After 12 hours of coordinated efforts, the vessel refloated in the early hours of 18th February. Fujian Maritime Safety Administration reported that all the crewmembers aboard the bulk carrier were safely evacuated, and no oil spill was observed during the incident. [PRIMUS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:462098/mmsi:636018306/imo:9310757/vessel:PRIMUS#overview) is a 2006 built bulk carrier en-route from [GRESIK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2454?name=GRESIK&country=Indonesia), Indonesia to China. The vessel has a length of 177 meters, breadth of 28.4 meters and has a carrying capacity of 32,588 tonnes.

headline: Fire Aboard the Grimaldi Vessel Renders the Vessel Without Propulsion
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire broke out aboard the Grimaldi vessel [GRANDE BRASILE ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:206251/mmsi:215664000/imo:9198123/vessel:GRANDE_BRASILE)on 18th February as it was transiting the English Channel. Although the fire is reported to be contained, the vessel has lost propulsion and steering capabilities. ![Fire broke aboard vessel GRANDE BRASILE](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GRNADE_BRASILE_c773d147fc.png)*Vessel GRANDE BRASILE, image credit: Manuel Hernández* The vessel issued a distress call around 9:35 AM, which reported the fire aboard the vessel and the vessel losing steering capabilities and propulsion. The vessel was around 15 nautical miles off of Ramsgate, England, and was traveling from Antwerp, Belgium, to Le Havre, France, at the time of the incident. The UK Maritime and Coastguard Agency (UK MCA) instructed the Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI), and lifeboats were promptly dispatched to the scene. As the lifeboats arrived on site, they discovered that the 28 crew members on board were uninjured and that the fire had already been contained to one deck aboard the vessel. The crew members had also deployed the onboard fire suppression system to combat the fire. The lifeboats then returned to the station. However, a tugboat, a Dutch fixed-wing surveillance aircraft, and a French vessel with firefighting capabilities are standing by for support.

headline: COSCO Shipping Launches Methanol-Powered Vessel, Pioneering Green Shipping Innovations
author: Raghib Raza
content: COSCO Shipping named its newest vessel, the [COSCO SHIPPING YANGPU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9350933/mmsi:477000000/imo:9945899/vessel:N1071#overview), on 18th February in Yangzhou, China. The vessel is the first in a new series. ![COSCO SHIPPING YANGPU named by COSCO Shipping.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/COSCO_SHIPPING_YANGPU_666f7600fc.png)*Vessel COSCO SHIPPING YANGPU, image credit: COSCO Shipping* The vessel has a length of 366 meters, a beam of 51 meters, and a maximum loading capacity of 16,136 TEUs. The vessel is the first in a series of vessels that are being built by Cosco Shipping Heavy Industries. The vessel has been made as a product of thorough research, and the shipbuilder obtained 31 patents in relation to methanol technology during the design and construction of this vessel. This has led to the vessel possessing many salient features, such as an innovatively designed methanol tank, which allows for the vessel to complete a one-way voyage between the Far East and West Coast of America utilizing methanol only. The vessel also features an intelligent ship system and has an excellent energy utilization ratio, establishing a benchmark in the shipping industry regarding energy conservation and emission reduction. COSCO Shipping has emphasized that this affords them new possibilities for the optimization of green shipping routes.

headline: Vietnam’s Most Advanced Deep-Water Port Now Operational
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Hateco Hai Phong International Container Port (HHIT), Vietnam's newest and most advanced deep-water port, has officially commenced operations, marking a major milestone in the country's maritime sector. ![MSC AURORA welcomed at HHIT Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSC_AURORA_db460bbebd.png)*Vessel MSC AURORA, image credit: HHIT* On 6th February, the port welcomed its first commercial vessel, the [ESL DUBAI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:758672/mmsi:255915745/imo:9377573/vessel:ESL_DUBAI). Following this, the [MSC AURORA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:464207/mmsi:373069000/imo:9484481/vessel:MSC_AURORA), the largest container ship to ever make a port call at[ HAI PHONG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1725?name=HAI-PHONG&country=Vietnam) Seaport, docked on 13th February. HHIT has an area of 73 hectares and features a 900-meter-long wharf with depths between -16.8 and 18.4 meters. The port can accommodate two large container vessels with lengths of up to 400 meters simultaneously. The port is equipped with cutting-edge technology, including STS cranes, a NANIS N4 operations system, e-RTG systems, Optical Character Recognition (OCR) technology, a 5G network, and surveillance cameras. The HHIT also has an automated gate system with OCR and RFID that enhances productivity and accuracy. The arrival of [MSC AURORA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:464207/mmsi:373069000/imo:9484481/vessel:MSC_AURORA) highlights HHIT's role in global trade. The vessel is part of the CHINOOK service route directly linking Vietnam with the United States and Canada.

headline: Ceuta Becomes First Mediterranean Port to Deploy ISO-Certified Mass Flow Meters
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Port of [CEUTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/511?name=CEUTA&country=Spain) in Spain has announced the deployment of internationally certified mass flow meters beginning this month. The Port of [CEUTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/511?name=CEUTA&country=Spain) is the first port in the Mediterranean to opt for this technology and has further bolstered its position in the fuel supply industry. ![CEUTA PORT.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CEUTA_PORT_3c7410615b.png)*CEUTA PORT, Image credit: Sergio Gonzalez* The first and foremost benefit of deploying mass flow meters is the accurate measurement of the fuel being transferred despite varying temperatures, fuel grades, or sources. Such mass flow meters not only increase the operational productivity by streamlining the supply process; they also lead to enhancing the security and integrity of the fuel supplies as fuel transfers are automatically logged. The mass flow meters to be utilized in the port have been reported to be ISO 22192-certified, which will allow for real-time decisive measurements of fuel transfers. This, in turn, is expected to lead to fewer disputes between fuel suppliers and shipowners.

headline: DPA Kandla Partners with Bapu’s Shipping to Introduce Bio-Methanol Bunkering
author: Raghib Raza
content: Deendayal Port Authority (DPA) Kandla has signed an MoU for developing new bio-methanol bunkering services at [KANDLA Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/269?name=KANDLA&country=India), India. The MoU was signed on 8th February with Bapu's Shipping Jamnagar Pvt. Ltd., marking DPA's commitment to environmental sustainability and opting for alternative fuel for maritime sector. ![KANDLA Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KANDLA_Port_ef11ce6d43.png)*KANDLA Port, image credit: balwaNT singh* The collaboration formed by the MoU aims to establish a green port and promote sustainable shipping solutions. The use of bio-methanol works well for decarbonization because it is a clean-burning fuel that can be obtained from natural gas, biomass, or even captured CO2. It has a high energy rating and reduces the emissions of sulfur oxides and particulate matter compared to conventional marine fuels. [KANDLA Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/269?name=KANDLA&country=India) is located in the Kutch district of Gujarat and is one of the largest and busiest ports in India. With initiatives such as the introduction of biomethanol bunkering, the port authority seeks to spearhead green shipping in India.

headline: Cook Islands-Flagged Tanker Resumes Journey After Five-Day Stranding Off Kerala Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: An asphalt/bitumen tanker, [Y L W](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5432144/mmsi:518100887/imo:9360398/vessel:Y_L_W#overview), sailing under the flag of Cook-Is, was stranded at sea for five days due to a technical issue. The vessel resumed its journey after receiving assistance from the Kerala Maritime Board’s Vizhinjam officials on 18th February. ![Y L W stranded for five days due to fuel pump malfunctioning.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Y_L_W_a4847fe803.png)*Vessel Y L W, image credit: V. Tonic* The 106.84-meter-long tanker, en route from [HALDIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/18985?name=HALDIA&country=India), India, to [SHARJAH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/103?name=SHARJAH&country=United-Arab-Emirates), UAE, was anchored 14 nautical miles off the Kerala coast near Vizhinjam, in India after its fuel pump malfunctioned. The captain of [Y L W](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5432144/mmsi:518100887/imo:9360398/vessel:Y_L_W#overview), in coordination with the Thiruvananthapuram-based shipping agency Dowins Resources, contacted the Kerala Maritime Board for assistance. In response, the Kerala Maritime Board dispatched a tugboat with a replacement fuel pump to deliver to the stranded tanker. On 17th February, at around 8 PM local time, the tug arrived with the fuel pump and was transferred to [Y L W](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5432144/mmsi:518100887/imo:9360398/vessel:Y_L_W#overview) using the tanker’s crane. After the successful repair, [Y W L](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5432144/mmsi:518100887/imo:9360398/vessel:Y_L_W#overview) continued its journey around midnight on 18th February. Y L W is a 2007-built vessel with a carrying capacity of 6,012 tonnes. Marine Traffic data indicate that the vessel is scheduled to arrive at [SHARJAH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/103?name=SHARJAH&country=United-Arab-Emirates) by 27th February.

headline: Maritime Authorities Refloated Bulk Carrier PRIMUS After Grounding Off China’s Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Liberian-flagged bulk carrier [PRIMUS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:462098/mmsi:636018306/imo:9310757/vessel:PRIMUS) successfully refloated after running aground near the entrance of Luoyuan Bay, off the southwest coast of China on 17th February. The vessel was carrying 23 crewmembers, all of whom were safely rescued. ![PRIMUS refloated after grounding off China Coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PRIMUS_f5abb75e77.png)*Vessel PRIMUS, image credit: Maxi Alonso* Following the distress call from the vessel, a rescue operation was launched, with the Fujian Maritime Safety Administration deploying a patrol vessel to manage traffic in the area. Two tug boats arrived and initiated the refloating of [PRIMUS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:462098/mmsi:636018306/imo:9310757/vessel:PRIMUS#overview). Two oil spill control vessels were also deployed as a precautionary measure. After 12 hours of coordinated efforts, the vessel refloated in the early hours of 18th February. Fujian Maritime Safety Administration reported that all the crewmembers aboard the bulk carrier were safely evacuated, and no oil spill was observed during the incident. [PRIMUS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:462098/mmsi:636018306/imo:9310757/vessel:PRIMUS#overview) is a 2006 built bulk carrier en-route from [GRESIK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2454?name=GRESIK&country=Indonesia), Indonesia to China. The vessel has a length of 177 meters, breadth of 28.4 meters and has a carrying capacity of 32,588 tonnes.

headline: COSCO Shipping Launches Methanol-Powered Vessel, Pioneering Green Shipping Innovations
author: Raghib Raza
content: COSCO Shipping named its newest vessel, the [COSCO SHIPPING YANGPU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9350933/mmsi:477000000/imo:9945899/vessel:N1071#overview), on 18th February in Yangzhou, China. The vessel is the first in a new series. ![COSCO SHIPPING YANGPU named by COSCO Shipping.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/COSCO_SHIPPING_YANGPU_666f7600fc.png)*Vessel COSCO SHIPPING YANGPU, image credit: COSCO Shipping* The vessel has a length of 366 meters, a beam of 51 meters, and a maximum loading capacity of 16,136 TEUs. The vessel is the first in a series of vessels that are being built by Cosco Shipping Heavy Industries. The vessel has been made as a product of thorough research, and the shipbuilder obtained 31 patents in relation to methanol technology during the design and construction of this vessel. This has led to the vessel possessing many salient features, such as an innovatively designed methanol tank, which allows for the vessel to complete a one-way voyage between the Far East and West Coast of America utilizing methanol only. The vessel also features an intelligent ship system and has an excellent energy utilization ratio, establishing a benchmark in the shipping industry regarding energy conservation and emission reduction. COSCO Shipping has emphasized that this affords them new possibilities for the optimization of green shipping routes.

headline: Fire Aboard the Grimaldi Vessel Renders the Vessel Without Propulsion
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire broke out aboard the Grimaldi vessel [GRANDE BRASILE ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:206251/mmsi:215664000/imo:9198123/vessel:GRANDE_BRASILE)on 18th February as it was transiting the English Channel. Although the fire is reported to be contained, the vessel has lost propulsion and steering capabilities. ![Fire broke aboard vessel GRANDE BRASILE](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GRNADE_BRASILE_c773d147fc.png)*Vessel GRANDE BRASILE, image credit: Manuel Hernández* The vessel issued a distress call around 9:35 AM, which reported the fire aboard the vessel and the vessel losing steering capabilities and propulsion. The vessel was around 15 nautical miles off of Ramsgate, England, and was traveling from Antwerp, Belgium, to Le Havre, France, at the time of the incident. The UK Maritime and Coastguard Agency (UK MCA) instructed the Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI), and lifeboats were promptly dispatched to the scene. As the lifeboats arrived on site, they discovered that the 28 crew members on board were uninjured and that the fire had already been contained to one deck aboard the vessel. The crew members had also deployed the onboard fire suppression system to combat the fire. The lifeboats then returned to the station. However, a tugboat, a Dutch fixed-wing surveillance aircraft, and a French vessel with firefighting capabilities are standing by for support.

headline: U.S. Forces Save Crew of Sinking Iranian Cargo Ship in Arabian Gulf
author: Raghib Raza
content: The U.S. Navy and Coast Guard successfully rescued crew members from the sinking Iranian cargo vessel [SHAYESTEH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:657595/mmsi:422004700/imo:9033036/vessel:SHAYESTEH#overview) on 18th February in the Arabian Gulf. The seven rescued crew members, including two Indians and five Iranians, were safe, and no injuries were reported. ![SHAYESTEH sank in Arabian Sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SHAYESTEH_3090871b0e.png)*Cargo Vessel SHAYESTEH, image credit: US CENTCOM* The 50.3-meter-long cargo vessel, which was flying a Qatari flag while in territorial waters, developed a severe list and issued a mayday call before sinking. Upon receiving the distress call, the U.S. Navy ship and U.S. Coast Guard Cutter vessel promptly responded and assisted the crewmembers who had abandoned [SHAYESTEH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:657595/mmsi:422004700/imo:9033036/vessel:SHAYESTEH#overview). The rescued crewmembers were then taken aboard the U.S. Coast Guard Cutter vessel and received medical care. U.S. CENTCOM reported that the vessel sank. However, the circumstances leading to the sinking of the vessel are yet to be determined.

headline: Explosion on Oil Tanker SEAJEWEL in Italy; Cause Remains Unclear
author: Raghib Raza
content: The oil tanker [SEAJEWEL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:728750/mmsi:229160000/imo:9388807/vessel:SEAJEWEL#overview) was rocked by explosions on 14th February as it was docked in the Italian city of Savona. An investigation into the incident is underway, and the cause of the explosion has not been ascertained yet. No injuries or pollution were reported. ![SEAJEWEL rocked by explosions in Italian water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SEAJEWEL_f4b2157f25.png)*Vessel SEAJEWEL, image credit: Claudio Ritossa* The vessel’s crew reported hearing two loud bangs, following which the hull of the vessel had a concave deformation. The port authority has stated that the crew of the vessel had halted the operation of unloading oil prior to the explosion. However, the hull of the vessel has been caved inwards; the damage is located below the waterline, and the fish kill in the area of the explosion supports the theory of an external explosive device. The Savona Coast Guard has initiated an investigation into the matter, although no official statements regarding the incident have been made yet. A diving team from the Italian Navy has been brought in for support, and the local anti-mafia department has been notified. The vessel previously loaded Russian cargo three times in 2024, and Ukrainian authorities have claimed that, at the time of the incident, it was transporting Russian oil to Europe despite sanctions.

headline: Port of Tanjung Pelepas Successfully Completes Simultaneous LNG Bunkering Operation
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Port of [TANJUNG PELEPAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1010?name=TANJUNG-PELEPAS&country=Malaysia) in Malaysia successfully conducted their first simultaneous operation of liquefied natural gas bunkering (SIMOPS). ![BANGKOK EXPRESS involved in SIMOPS operation at the Port of Tanjung Pelepas](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BANGKOK_EXPRESS_3c4b5e328a.png)*Vessel BANGKOK EXPRESS, image credit: Port of Tanjung Pelepas* This transfer involved the ship-to-ship bunkering of LNG from the bunker vessel [MT PAOLINA COSULICH ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8166410/mmsi:533132943/imo:9956836/vessel:PAOLINA_COSULICH)and the Hapag Lloyd-operated vessel [BANGKOK EXPRESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9344338/mmsi:211108330/imo:9943889/vessel:BANGKOK_EXPRESS). The initiative was conducted in collaboration with PETCO Trading Labuan Co., Ltd. (PTLCL) and Hapag-Lloyd. Simultaneous Natural gas bunkering or SIMOPS refers to the practice of conducting LNG bunkering operations alongside other port activities such as cargo handling or vessel maintenance. This reduces the time vessels spend in port, maximizing efficiency and reducing operational costs.

headline: UK Court Sentences Crew and Shipping Company for Accident that Claimed Two Lives
author: Raghib Raza
content: A UK court sentenced the crew and the shipping company of the vessel [SCOT CARRIER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5760951/mmsi:232018267/imo:9841782/vessel:SCOT_CARRIER) for an accident that claimed two lives in 2021. The case involved the collision of the cargo vessel with a barge in a high-traffic shipping lane due to the failure of the crew to operate in a safe manner. ![SCOT CARRIER.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SCOT_CARRIER_74c8f0ccc2.png)*Vessel SCOT CARRIER, image credit: Inge Fühles* The incident, which occurred in 2021, involved the collision of the cargo vessel [SCOT CARRIER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5760951/mmsi:232018267/imo:9841782/vessel:SCOT_CARRIER) with the barge [KARIN HØEJ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3861037/mmsi:-8685844/imo:8685844/vessel:KARIN_HOEJ). This resulted in the [KARIN HØEJ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3861037/mmsi:-8685844/imo:8685844/vessel:KARIN_HOEJ) capsizing and the two crewmembers aboard perishing in the accident. The captain of the vessel was sentenced to a jail term of eight months and a payment of £25,000 ($31,500) in costs. He pled guilty to failing to prevent the collision with the [KARIN HØEJ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3861037/mmsi:-8685844/imo:8685844/vessel:KARIN_HOEJ). The court found him guilty of assigning the second officer to the bridge despite him knowing that the officer was intoxicated and distracted while on duty. Media reports indicate that the captain will have to pay a charge and serve 200 hours of community service for avoiding jail time. The shipping company, Intrada Ships Management, was found guilty of having operated their vessel in an unsafe manner. The company was fined £180,000 ($227,000) and ordered to pay costs of £500,000 ($630,000). In addition to this, the litigation costs incurred by the company in this case have been estimated to be around £1 million ($1.3 million). The court determined that the shipping company was aware of there being only one officer on watch on the bridge of their ships, which violated regulations but failed to take action.

headline: 800 kgs of Cocaine Found Stashed Aboard Hapag-Lloyd Boxship
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 15th February, the Ecuadorian Navy seized around 800 kgs of cocaine aboard the Hapag Lloyd container ship [GUAYAQUIL EXPRESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4820412/mmsi:218851000/imo:9777620/vessel:GUAYAQUIL_EXPRESS). The seizure aboard the containership was conducted following a tip-off stating ongoing trafficking operations aboard the vessel. ![Drug seized from GUAYAQUIL EXPRESS.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GUAYAQUIL_EXPRESS_29b84e3e67.png)*Drugs seized aboard conatinership GUAYAQUIL EXPRESS, image credit:X/armada_ecuador* The operation was conducted around 45 miles off of Manta, Ecuador. The [GUAYAQUIL EXPRESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4820412/mmsi:218851000/imo:9777620/vessel:GUAYAQUIL_EXPRESS) was headed from [POSORJA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/19150?name=POSORJA&country=Ecuador), Ecuador to Panama Canal. According to reports, around 25 armed individuals arrived on two speedboats and had placed the packages containing cocaine onboard. Following a tip-off of potential trafficking operations being conducted aboard the vessel, the Coast Guard and Marine Corps coordinated to intercept the vessel. The inspection of the vessel revealed packages containing cocaine. The packages have been reported to have different logos on them, suggesting the involvement of numerous criminal organizations.

headline: Wallenius Wilhelmsen Completes Successful Biofuel Bunkering Trial in Japan
author: Raghib Raza
content: Wallenius Wilhelmsen has marked a key milestone in its sustainability strategy with the successful bunkering trial of Bio Bunker B24 (VLSFO Blended) in Japan. ![ TAMESIS](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/TAMESIS_17bcb43cc2.png)*Image credit: Wallenius Wilhelmsen* In the trial, [M/V TAMESIS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:307446/mmsi:257565000/imo:9191307/vessel:TAMESIS#overview) bunkered 400 metric tons of Bio Bunker B24 biofuel at the Port [YOKOHAMA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/260?name=YOKOHAMA&country=Japan), Japan. Mitsubishi Corporation Energy Co, Ltd. supplied the biofuel as a part of its strategy to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and expand the availability of biofuel at major global ports. This successful bunkering operation was also made possible through a collaboration between Wallenius Wihelmsen’s Energy Sourcing team and Orcelle Accelerator taskforce. Together, they worked for two years to establish biofuel capabilities in Japan. Wallenius Wilhelmsen aims to achieve net-zero emissions by 2040 and targets cutting greenhouse emissions by 40% by 2030, using its 2022 levels as a baseline. Since 2023, the company has broadened its biofuel supply reach to ports in Korea, Singapore, Belgium, and now Japan, joining this network to support cleaner shipping.

headline: Hong Kong Advances Green Shipping with First LNG Bunkering
author: Raghib Raza
content: Hong Kong conducted its first ship-to-ship transfer operation on 14th February. This marks a significant milestone in the trajectory of Hong Kong, which is looking to transition towards green shipping. ![ZIM AQUAMARINE](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ZIM_AQUAMARINE_da713f6aac.png)*Vessel ZIM AQUAMARINE, image credit:imarinenews.com* The bunkering was carried out by the Kunlun Energy Co. Ltd., a subsidiary of China National Petroleum Corporation. The dual-fuel container ship [ZIM AQUAMARINE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9272689/mmsi:477025700/imo:9968097/vessel:ZIM_AQUAMARINE#overview) was the recipient of the LNG transfer, with the vessel [XIN AO PU TUO HAO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6762957/mmsi:413282560/imo:9870628/vessel:XIN_AO_PU_TUO_HAO) providing 2,200 tonnes of Ultra-low-temperature LNG. The inaugural bunkering operation was attended by high-ranking officials and representatives from Hong Kong government bodies. LNG has been recognized as a cleaner burning fuel that reduces carbon dioxide emissions by 25% and nitrogen dioxide emissions by 85% and almost completely eliminates sulfur dioxide emissions when compared to traditional marine fuels.

headline: “MSC Baltic III” Grounds Off Newfoundland Coast Amid Stormy Conditions
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 15th February, a Liberian-flagged container ship, [MSC BALTIC III](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:123998/mmsi:636021252/imo:9241475/vessel:MSC_BALTIC_III), ran aground after losing power in severe weather conditions. The 33,767dwt container ship, which was carrying 20 crew members, was safe, and no injuries were reported. ![MSC BALTIC III ran aground.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSC_BALTIC_III_e0eb025106.png)*Container ship MSC BALTIC III, image credit: Canadian Coast Guard* A mayday call was received by Marine Communication and Traffic Services in Port aux Basques from the container ship, which was approximately 12 nautical miles outside the entrance of Bay of Island, Newfoundland, Canada. The weather conditions were unfavorable, with winds exceeding 120 kilometers per hour and waves reaching 6 meters high. [MSC BALTIC III ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:123998/mmsi:636021252/imo:9241475/vessel:MSC_BALTIC_III) was unable to secure its anchor and subsequently ran aground in Wild Cove, west of Lark Harbour. In response, the Canadian Coast Guard dispatched the icebreaker [HENRY LARSEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:381660/mmsi:316013000/imo:8409329/vessel:HENRY_LARSEN) and a Cormorant helicopter to assist in the rescue operation. The Cormorant helicopter successfully airlifted all the crew members aboard [MSC BALTIC III](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:123998/mmsi:636021252/imo:9241475/vessel:MSC_BALTIC_III), and no injuries were reported. The cause of the power failure and the extent of structural damage are not yet known. Authorities are monitoring the containership for any potential release from the fuel tank.

headline: DPA Kandla Partners with Bapu’s Shipping to Introduce Bio-Methanol Bunkering
author: Raghib Raza

The MoU was signed on 8th February with Bapu's Shipping Jamnagar Pvt. Ltd., marking DPA's commitment to environmental sustainability and opting for alternative fuel for maritime sector. ![KANDLA Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KANDLA_Port_ef11ce6d43.png)*KANDLA Port, image credit: balwaNT singh* The collaboration formed by the MoU aims to establish a green port and promote sustainable shipping solutions. headline: Ferry HARAM Grounds Near Dryna Shortly After Departure
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Ro-Ro/ Passenger ship [HARAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:305152/mmsi:257211400/imo:7812529/vessel:HARAM#overview) operating between [DRYNA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/25863?name=DRYNA&country=Norway)- [BRATTVAG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/22130?name=BRATTVAG&country=Norway) Port in Norway ran aground near the Dryna ferry quay on 9th February. ![HARAM ran aground in Norwegian water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/HARAM_93293ab801.png)*Ro-Ro/ Passenger ship HARAM, Image credit:Paul Misje* The incident occurred at around 7:30 PM local time, shortly after the ship departed from [DRYNA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/25863?name=DRYNA&country=Norway). The ship, carrying 15 passengers and 4 crewmembers, unexpectedly veered 90 degrees to starboard before running aground. No casualties were reported. At 8:30 PM local time, the ship was able to refloat itself using its own engine power after shifting vehicles to the rear of the ferry. Operations Manager Anders Tosse of Torghatten Nord confirmed that the vessel was inspected for damage upon grounding, with no water ingress detected. The extent of the damage remains unclear. However, the initial reports indicate potential damage to the rudder and propeller of the ship. Divers have been deployed for detailed inspection. The ship returned to [DRYNA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/25863?name=DRYNA&country=Norway), and the remaining departures for the evening were canceled. [HARAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:305152/mmsi:257211400/imo:7812529/vessel:HARAM#overview) is a Norwegian-flagged Ro-Ro/ Passenger ship built in 1979. The ship has a carrying capacity of 769 gross tons with a length of 64.33 meters and a width of 11.46 meters.

headline: Hambantota International Port in Sri Lanka Introduces HSFO Bunkering Capabilities
author: Raghib Raza
content: The [HAMBANTOTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/20525?name=HAMBANTOTA&country=Sri-Lanka) International Port (HPI) in Sri Lanka is extending its bunkering services with its newest offering of High Sulfur Fuel Oil (HSFO). The port authorities have stated that the HSFO bunkering infrastructure is already functional and will help them serve a much larger number of vessels moving forward. ![Hambantota International Port (HPI) ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Hambantota_International_Port_HPI_513f44005f.png)*Image credit:Hambantota International Port (HPI)* The newly operational HSFO facility is reported to have a 6000 cubic meter capacity, which is accommodated in two tanks that are situated in the port. The facility has a 400 metric ton per hour pumping capacity and streamlined pipes that are directly connected to the oil jetties at the port. The introduction of this new facility is expected to be a boon for vessels that use HSFO with scrubbers, as HIP is sited in a strategic location along one of the busiest maritime routes in the world. This additional refueling stop in the routes between Europe and Asia will allow for the port to accommodate a large variety of vessels, ranging from large tankers to smaller cargo ships. The offering of the new fuel is expected to strengthen Sri Lanka’s position in the global maritime landscape and allow for the port to cater to a much larger array of vessels. The marine fuels for the port are provided by Sinopec, and the port has received its Fitness for Service (FSS) certification from the Lloyd’s Register classification society.

headline: Chinese Bulker Runs Aground in Sakhalin Peninsula in Russia in Snowstorm
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Chinese-registered bulk carrier [AN YANG 2](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:687759/mmsi:414325000/imo:9563421/vessel:AN_YANG_2), which was en route from Changzhou to Nevelsk, ran aground in the Sakhalin Peninsula in Russia due to a heavy snowstorm. The vessel is reported to be carrying environmentally hazardous material, and no rescue operation has been proposed yet. ![AN YANG 2 ran aground.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/AN_YANG_2_e70d174eba.png)*Vessel AN YANG, image credit:Instagram/salvage_and_wreck* The vessel ran aground on the southwest coast of the Russian Sakhalin Island on 8th February amid a severe snowstorm. The vessel has 20 crew members onboard and is reported to be carrying 700 tons of fuel oil, 100 tons of diesel fuel, and 1000 tons of coal. The environmentally hazardous cargo has led the authorities in Sakhalin to declare a high alert. The authorities have also stated that the situation remains critical and that no clear solutions have been proposed regarding any rescue operations due to the risk of fuel spills and navigational hazards.

headline: Tanker ‘Koala’ Suffers Engine Room Blasts, Crew Safely Evacuates
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 9th February, Crude oil tanker[ KOALA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:149641/mmsi:305262000/imo:9234642/vessel:KOALA#overview) with 130,000 tons of oil ran aground in[ UST-LUGA Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/969?name=UST-LUGA&country=Russia), Russia, after three explosions occurred in the engine room. No casualties or pollution were reported in the incident. ![KOALA suffer explosion in the engine room.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KOALA_0e41067a41.png)*Crude oil tanker, KOALA, image credit:eadaily.com* The explosions occurred in the early morning as [KOALA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:149641/mmsi:305262000/imo:9234642/vessel:KOALA#overview) was departing the port. All 24 crew members, including 4 Russians, 8 Georgians, and 12 Indonesians, evacuated the vessel and reached the pier safely. After the explosions, water entered the engine room, causing the vessel to run aground. The Governor of Leningrad labeled the explosions as "man-made incident" during engine startup, stating that the vessel remains securely moored at the pier with no risk of oil leakage. An investigation into the cause of the incident is underway. [KOALA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:149641/mmsi:305262000/imo:9234642/vessel:KOALA#overview) is a 2023-built vessel sailing under the flag of Antigua Barbuda. The ship has a length of 274.18 meters, a width of 50 meters, and a gross tonnage of 84598.

headline: Two Vessels Detained by Bangladesh Coast Guard for Illicit Fuel Transfer
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Bangladesh Coast Guard has seized a chemical tanker, [DOLPHIN 19](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:728086/mmsi:352004159/imo:9291456/vessel:DOLPHIN_19#overview), and a Bangladeshi vessel, OT Union, for participating in unauthorized fuel transfer and avoiding customs duties. ![DOLPHIN 19 and another vessel detained for illicit fuel transfer](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/DOLPHIN_19_deba1bfdc1.png)*Vessel DOLPHINE 19, image credit: Michael Brakhage* The incident occurred on 01st February when the Coast Guard found two vessels engaged in a suspect fuel transfer operation. The fuel was being transferred from OT Union to the vessel [DOLPHIN 19](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:728086/mmsi:352004159/imo:9291456/vessel:DOLPHIN_19#overview). Subsequently, the crew of both the vessels were questioned. Upon their failure to provide documents to prove the legality of the fuel transfer, the authorities seized the [DOLPHIN 19](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:728086/mmsi:352004159/imo:9291456/vessel:DOLPHIN_19#overview) and moved it to the Chittagong Outer Anchorage. The OT Union and its nine crew members remain detained in the Coast Guard’s custody. Coast guard officials stated that the 11,628 gross-ton [DOLPHIN 19](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:728086/mmsi:352004159/imo:9291456/vessel:DOLPHIN_19#overview) unlawfully received around 356 metric tonnes of fuel from OT Union between 7:00 AM and 2:00 PM. Coast guard officials have clarified that the transfer of fuel was conducted without authorization from the Chittagong Port Authority and Customs and legal proceedings following the seizure of the vessels are already underway.

headline: Immingham Green Energy Terminal Construction Greenlit by the UK Government
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Immingham Green Energy Terminal, a proposed multi-user bulk liquid green energy terminal situated at the Port of[ IMMINGHAM ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/147?name=IMMINGHAM&country=United-Kingdom)in England, has obtained approval from the UK’s secretary of state for transport. The approval, granted on the 6th February, marks a major milestone for England’s energy transition. ![IMMINGHAM Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/IMMINGHAM_Port_45fbba3eda.png)*Port IMMINGHAM, image credit: Port of Immingham* The new terminal is intended for the production of green hydrogen using ammonia as a feedstock. The facility is expected to produce 300 MW worth of hydrogen, which is then to be distributed across the filling stations throughout the UK. The plans for this green energy terminal call for the construction of a new jetty to import and export bulk liquids, and land-side processing infrastructure. The new project is being built in collaboration with Associated British Ports (ABP) and Air Products. The ammonia to be imported and converted into hydrogen is to be sourced from Air Products’ facilities in Saudi Arabia. Initial plans for the new energy terminal were submitted to the UK government by ABP in September of 2023, following which it underwent a rigorous examination involving both public and private consultations. The project was finally greenlit on 6th February. No official dates have been announced for the commencement or the completion of this project; however, the construction of the project is expected to begin in the coming months.

headline: Portugal-Flagged Cargo Vessel Encounters Two Grounding Incidents in Kiel Canal
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 5th February, a general cargo vessel, [SOMMEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7550352/mmsi:255805887/imo:9968138/vessel:SOMMEN#overview), experienced two grounding incidents while transiting the Kiel Canal, Germany. Tug assistance was deployed to aid the vessel. ![SOMMEN suffered two grounding Kiel Canal.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SOMMEN_d7eb6debd1.png)*Vessel SOMMEN, image credit: Wolfgang Berthel* The first incident occurred around 2:08 AM local time near Oldenbüttel, when the vessel traveling from [AVEIRO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2229?name=AVEIRO&country=Portugal), Portugal, suffered an electrical fault. The malfunction caused the vessel to veer off course and run aground on the southern embankment. The crew was able to make repairs, and the cargo ship continued its voyage. At around 6:05 AM local time, the vessel, while approaching Rendsburg, suffered engine failure, leading to a second grounding along the southern embankment. The authorities promptly responded to the situation and dispatched the tug Holtenau to assist the distressed vessel. By late morning, the tug had successfully refloated the vessel and towed it to a quay at Kiel for further inspection. There were no reports of injuries or pollution. On 6th February, Portugal-flagged [SOMMEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7550352/mmsi:255805887/imo:9968138/vessel:SOMMEN#overview) continued its voyage and arrived at [KOEGE Anchorage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/22644?name=KOEGE-ANCH&country=Denmark), Denmark.

headline: Containerships Scrape in Kiel Canal; No Injuries or Pollution Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: A maritime incident involving a collision between two containerships, [ESSENCE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:754855/mmsi:244238000/imo:9491496/vessel:ESSENCE) and [X PRESS MULHACEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:726427/mmsi:229630000/imo:9365960/vessel:X_PRESS_MULHACEN#overview), occurred in Kiel Canal, Germany, on 6th February. Fortunately, no injuries or pollution were reported. ![ESSENCE collided with X PRESS MULHACEN in Kiel Canal.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ESSENCE_32e9eb7e66.png)*Containership ESSENCE, image credit:Peter aus Holtenau* The accident took place at around 7:30 AM local time near the north port of Kiel, in front of the Holtenau locks amid thick fog. [ESSENCE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:754855/mmsi:244238000/imo:9491496/vessel:ESSENCE), en route from [KOTKA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/331?name=KOTKA&country=Finland), Finland to[ ROTTERDAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2036?name=ROTTERDAM&country=Netherlands), Netherlands, and[ X PRESS MULHACEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:726427/mmsi:229630000/imo:9365960/vessel:X_PRESS_MULHACEN#overview), traveling from [ROTTERDAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2036?name=ROTTERDAM&country=Netherlands) to [GDYNIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/233?name=GDYNIA&country=Poland), Poland, came into proximity while maneuvering through the locks. At the time of the incident, [X PRESS MULHACEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:726427/mmsi:229630000/imo:9365960/vessel:X_PRESS_MULHACEN#overview) was about to enter the large north chamber of the locks while [ESSENCE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:754855/mmsi:244238000/imo:9491496/vessel:ESSENCE) was exiting the south chamber. The two container ships scraped and had to temporarily halt their journeys. Following the incident, both vessels were detained, and the Kiel water police launched an investigation. After a few hours of inquiries and inspection, [ESSENCE ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:754855/mmsi:244238000/imo:9491496/vessel:ESSENCE)resumed its voyage. However, [X PRESS MULHACEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:726427/mmsi:229630000/imo:9365960/vessel:X_PRESS_MULHACEN#overview) remained detained until the evening of the same day before continuing its journey.

headline: Hapag-Lloyd Welcomes LNG Dual-Fuel Vessel BANGKOK EXPRESS
author: Raghib Raza
content: A leading global liner shipping company, Hapag-Lloyd, welcomed its new LNG dual-fuel container ship, [BANGKOK EXPRESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9344338/mmsi:211108330/imo:9943889/vessel:BANGKOK_EXPRESS#overview), on 4th February. The christening ceremony took place at the Hanwha Ocean Shipyard in South Korea. ![BANGKOK EXPRESS christened at Hanwa Ocean Shipyard.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BANGKOK_EXPRESS_d30ee8018f.png)*Vessel BANGKOK EXPRESS, image credit: Hapag-Lloyd* [BANGKOK EXPRESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9344338/mmsi:211108330/imo:9943889/vessel:BANGKOK_EXPRESS#overview) is the ninth of twelve Hapag-Lloyd’s Hamburg Express class vessels. Three more containerships are still under construction. Hapang-Lloyd stated that these newbuilds, measuring 399 meters in length and have a capacity of 23,660 TEU are the largest container ships ever to operate under the flag of Germany. Hapag-Lloyd marked the addition of [BANGKOK EXPRESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9344338/mmsi:211108330/imo:9943889/vessel:BANGKOK_EXPRESS#overview) to its fleet as its commitment to expansion and innovation in shipping. The company emphasizes sustainable shipping and aims to reduce its environmental impact. Additionally, the company is also working to achieve a climate-neutral fleet by 2045. Following the christening ceremony, [BANGKOK EXPRESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9344338/mmsi:211108330/imo:9943889/vessel:BANGKOK_EXPRESS#overview) is set to sail for its maiden voyage to [BUSAN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17351?name=BUSAN-NEW-PORT&country=Korea) Port, South Korea.

headline: Norwegian Tanker "ISFJORD" Suffers Engine Failure Near Svolvaer
author: Raghib Raza
content: A Norwegian Oil and Chemical tanker, [ISFJORD](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:263501/mmsi:257677000/imo:9190200/vessel:ISFJORD#overview), experienced an engine failure off the coast of Svolvaer, Norway, on 05th February, prompting an emergency response. ![ISFJORD suffer engine failure near Norway.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ISPJORD_b0ac0c7d73.png)*Vessel ISFJORD, image credit:Sondre M Pettersen* The Main Rescue Center deployed rescue boats from Svolvaer and Ballstad to assist in securing the vessel and towing it to shore. The rescue leader at the Main Rescue Center confirmed that the crew aboard the tanker were safe. However, onshore winds from the southeast necessitated swift action to secure the vessel. The rescue vessel Sundt Flyer and Hans Hermann Horn arrived to assist the vessel. It was reported that[ ISFJORD ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:263501/mmsi:257677000/imo:9190200/vessel:ISFJORD#overview)was safely towed to Svolvaer. [ISFJORD](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:263501/mmsi:257677000/imo:9190200/vessel:ISFJORD#overview) is a 2000-built vessel operated by LNS Spitsbergen’s subsidiary, LNS Ocean. The ship has a carrying capacity of 6,535 tonnes with an overall length of 103.46 meters and a width of 15 meters.

headline: Cargo Vessel Carrying Dangerous Cargo Seeks Refuge from Storm in Port of Vigo
author: Raghib Raza
content: The cargo vessel [HC EVA-MARIE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:363411/mmsi:305113000/imo:9369071/vessel:HC_EVA_MARIE), which was carrying munitions, sought refuge in the Port of [VIGO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/182?name=VIGO&country=Spain), Spain from the oncoming storm Herminia as some of the vessel’s containers had already broken loose due to the earlier storm Eowyn. As of now, the vessel is still docked at the port, and the process of securing the cargo safely is underway. ![HC EVA MARIE.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/HC_EVA_MARIE_639166538c.png)*Vessel HC EVA MARIE, image credit: Juergen Braker* The [HC EVA-MARIE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:363411/mmsi:305113000/imo:9369071/vessel:HC_EVA_MARIE) was en route from Jordan to Germany, carrying howitzers and their shells. Due to the storm Eowyn, the cargo aboard the vessel shifted, nine of the 96 containers aboard broke free, and some containers sustained damage. With the possibility of the vessel losing cargo in the upcoming storm, Herminia looming large, the decision was made to dock the vessel at a port. The vessel docked at the port of Vigo on 26th January and has been at the port ever since. It has been docked at the Transversal Pier at the port, which has been reserved for vessels with dangerous cargo and has been guarded by private security, the port police, and the civil guard. The first inspection of the ship was carried out on 1st February by an engineer from the shipping company, accompanied by the head of the port authority’s security division and representatives from the shipping company. The inspection revealed that the cargo was intact, and only the external structure of the containers had sustained damage. The shipping company has clarified that the shells had been dismantled as required by international shipping standards. They further added that they are drawing up a plan for securely transporting the containers from one hold of the vessel to another and isolating the damaged containers. Following this, specialized personnel are to arrive and shift the cargo from damaged to new containers prepared for the same purpose. The shipping company has insisted that at no point will the containers be offloaded onto the port.

headline: Fire Aboard the Vessel "Lowlands Diamond" Continues to Burn for the Fourth Day
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire that was first reported aboard the bulk carrier [LOWLANDS DIAMOND ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7767735/mmsi:352002669/imo:9965617/vessel:LOWLANDS_DIAMOND)on 27th January continues to burn as of the latest report. The crew of the vessel are reported to be safe, and the Port of[ ABERDEEN,](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/108?name=ABERDEEN&country=United-Kingdom) United Kingdom, has issued a statement assuring that the fire does not pose a threat to the wider community. ![LOWLAND DIAMOND caught fire berth at Aberdeen Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LOWLAND_DIAMOND_f375550de1.png)*Bulk Carrier LOWLAND DIAMOND, image credit:Frank Findler* The vessel [LOWLANDS DIAMOND](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7767735/mmsi:352002669/imo:9965617/vessel:LOWLANDS_DIAMOND) berthed at the South Harbor, Dunnottar Quay, at the port of Aberdeen on 22nd January. A fire broke out in the cargo hold of the vessel, and firefighters are engaged in combating it. Emergency services have stated that they are now emptying the cargo holds of the vessel for extinguishing the fire. Although the fire officers claimed that putting out the fire could take days more, the vessel itself and the community are safe, as the fire has been successfully isolated to one of the ship’s cargo holds.

headline: NSRI – Clifton – Wednesday, 29 January. A sailing yacht run aground.
author: Schalk Van Bosch
content: ![54294624228_faf03b0041_o.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/54294624228_faf03b0041_o_f80edab177.jpg) NSRI – STATION 2, Bakoven. STATION 3, Table Bay. NSRI – Clifton – Wednesday, 29 January. A sailing yacht run aground at Clifton 4th Beach is recovered, a second sailing yacht close to running aground self recovers to deeper water A sailing yacht run aground at Clifton 4th Beach is recovered safely, while a second sailing yacht self recovers after drifting into shallow water at Clifton 4th Beach. Luke van Riet, NSRI Bakoven duty coxswain, said: At 04h19, Wednesday, 29 January, NSRI Bakoven and NSRI Table Bay duty crews were activated following reports of a sailing yacht running aground and listing at Clifton 4th Beach. Almost immediately after the initial report it was established that all crew and passengers on two local charter sailing yachts were safe. TNPA (Transnet National ports Authority) Table Bay Port Control were alerted. NSRI Bakoven and NSRI Table Bay dispatched rescue swimmers to Clifton 4th beach, the NSRI Bakoven rescue craft Gemini Legend and the NSRI Table Bay rescue craft DHL Deliverer were launched. On arrival on the scene one sailing yacht, with 3 crew onboard, was found aground in shallow water and listing at Clifton 4th Beach. A second sailing yacht, with 5 crew onboard, that had also drifted into shallow water, had managed to motor back out to sea and was standing off in deeper water safely at anchor. It appears that both yachts were spending the night at Clifton and during the early hours of the morning, despite calm seas, but in increasing wind speeds, both vessels had dragged anchor and gently drifted towards shore. NSRI rescue swimmers were deployed onto the vessel that was listing in shallow water. The 2 passengers, females, were transferred onto NSRI Bakoven's rescue craft and transported to the second sailing yacht, further out, where they were transferred onto the second yacht safely. Telkom Maritime Radio Services and MRCC (Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre) were notified. 2 NSRI rescue swimmers were deployed to the grounded yacht where they assisted the skipper to establish a towline from the casualty yacht to the NSRI rescue craft Gemini Legend. The NSRI rescue craft gently towed the casualty yacht further out to sea. At that stage the NSRI rescue craft DHL Deliverer was arriving on the scene. It was determined that both yachts had sustained no damage and with 2 NSRI rescue swimmers remaining onboard the recovered casualty sailing yacht, both yachts were escorted to Granger Bay, by the NSRI Table Bay DHL Deliverer, where they were both berthed at their moorings and no further assistance was required.

headline: Vessel Crashes Into Pier at a Tuscan Resort Due to the Storm Herminia in Italy
author: Raghib Raza
content: The 10,000 dwt [GUANG RONG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:121929/mmsi:209306000/imo:9236133/vessel:GUANG_RONG) on 28th January veered off course and crashed into a pier at Tuscan Sea Resort, Italy. The 13 crew members abandoned the ship and are safe, and there has been no spillage or pollution reported from the vessel. ![GUANG RONG ran aground after collision in Italy.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GUANG_RONG_3eb13b60f5.png)*Vessel GUANG RONG, image credit:Guardia Costiera* The winds and waves owing to the storm Herminia in the Mediterranean caused the vessel to crash the pier at Tuscan Sea Resort. The vessel is reported to have been anchored at the [MARINA DI CARRARA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/21671?name=MARINA-DI-CARRARA-AN&country=Italy) Anchorage and partially loaded with marble debris. At around 21:00 (CET), the powerful waves and wind pushed the vessel, ploughing the anchor and driving it towards the wooden pier, which extends into the sea. The pier, which is a public access structure, was partially destroyed in the accident. The vessel [GUANG RONG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:121929/mmsi:209306000/imo:9236133/vessel:GUANG_RONG) is a Cyprus-flagged vessel that was built in 2001. The vessel is 103.8 meters long, has a beam of 25 meters, and has a gross tonnage of 5,264.

headline: Russian Nuclear Icebreaker “50 Let Pobedy” Bow Damaged After Collision
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Russian-flagged nuclear-powered icebreaker [50 LET POBEDY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:346081/mmsi:273316240/imo:9152959/vessel:50_LET_POBEDY) collided with a freighter in the Kara Sea on 26th January, leading to its bow being damaged. The vessel is reportedly seaworthy despite having suffered extensive damage to its bow on the port side. ![50 LET POBEDY collided with cargo ship.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/50_LET_POBEDY_fd763c7881.png)*Icebreaker 50 LET POBEDY, image credit: X/Anton Geraschenko* The collision occurred when the icebreaker was involved in assisting the freighter, trying to free it as it was trapped in ice.
