The identity of the freighter has not been released, but it is being conjectured to be the cargo ship [YAMAL KRECHET](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:757296/mmsi:273389860/imo:9202041/vessel:YAMAL_KRECHET#overview). The icebreaker, while navigating in tight quarters, made port-bow contact with the freighter’s port side near a cargo crane base, resulting in a significant gash above [50 LET POBEDY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:346081/mmsi:273316240/imo:9152959/vessel:50_LET_POBEDY)’s waterline. According to Atomflot, the company that operates the icebreaker, there were no injuries aboard the vessel and that the vessel remains seaworthy. The company further stated that there was no damage to the vessel’s life support systems or its reactor unit; hence, the vessel will continue its operations on the North Sea Route.

headline: MARPOL Violations Land Chief Engineer in Jail for Three Months
author: Raghib Raza
content: The chief engineer of the Liberian-flagged vessel [ASL SINGAPORE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:465883/mmsi:538011363/imo:9618678/vessel:XIN_HAI_TONG_805) was sentenced to three months in jail after he pled guilty to having violated MARPOL regulations and misleading US Coast Guard (USCG) investigators. ![ASL SINGAPORE Chief Engineer sentence three months jail.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ASL_SINGAPORE_091d85d365.png)*Vessel ASL SINGAPORE, image credit: V. Tonic* The chief engineer pleaded guilty to having discharged oily bilge water directly overboard, having maintained false records, and providing these falsified records to US Coast Guard inspectors. He was then sentenced by a US court to serve three months in jail, three years of supervised release, and a mandatory special assessment fee of $200. The vessel [ASL SINGAPORE ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:465883/mmsi:538011363/imo:9618678/vessel:XIN_HAI_TONG_805)arrived in New Orleans, USA, on 26th February 2024 and was detained after Coast Guard inspectors found MARPOL violations aboard the vessel. The USCG has stated that the oily bilge water was discharged directly using a portable pump and a flexible hose, colloquially known as a “magic pipe.” The USCG also stated that there was no attempt to run the bilge water through a filter and that they were provided with falsified information regarding the discharge of the bilge water. The chief engineer asserted that the practice of discharging unfiltered bilge water was already in place before he took the position on the vessel and that it continued while he was in service.

headline: Hong Kong-Flagged Vessel on Fire and Adrift off the Coast of Yemen After Crew Abandons Ship
author: Raghib Raza
content: The crew of the Hong Kong-flagged containership[ ASL BAUHINIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7274127/mmsi:477856700/imo:9935868/vessel:ASL_BAUHINIA) abandoned the vessel after it caught fire on the 28th of January off the coast of Yemen. The crewmembers were rescued by another passing vessel and are reported to be safe. ![ASL BAUHINIA caught fire, all crew safely rescued.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ASL_BAUHINIA_da1b83c791.png)*Containership ASL BAUHINIA, image credit: Graham Flett* The fire has been reported to have been started by an explosion; however, the cause of the explosion is yet to be ascertained. Despite the vessel catching fire around 226 kilometers off the coast of Yemen, there have yet been no reports of Houthi involvement in the incident. Maritime security firms have suggested that the cause of the fire could have been hazardous cargo. The crew, which consisted of Chinese nationals, are reported to be safe and were rescued by a passing vessel. The 2022-built vessel, owned by the Shanghai-based Asean Seas Line, was headed from [JEBEL ALI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/102?name=JEBEL-ALI&country=United-Arab-Emirates) to Aqaba via the Suez Canal. The vessel was scheduled to call on [JEDDAH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/807?name=JEDDAH&country=Saudi-Arabia) on the 29th of January. Investigations have already been opened into the incident. As of now, the vessel is adrift in the sea as plumes of black smoke emanate from it.

headline: Fire on Palau-Flagged Vessel at Samsun Port Successfully Contained
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 28th January, a fire broke out in the engine room of the Palau-flagged Ro-Ro/Passenger vessel [LIRUZE G](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:339300/mmsi:511101191/imo:7811329/vessel:FIRUZE_G). Fortunately, all the 33 crew members aboard the vessel were evacuated and reported to be safe. ![Fire contained aboard the vessel LIRUZE G.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LIRUZE_G_b9a363c8ad.png)*Ro-Ro/Passenger vessel LIRUZE G, image credit:aa.com.tr* At approximately 9:00 AM local time, the fire broke out, believed to have been caused by a generator failure. The fire ignited in the engine and generator rooms on the lower deck of the Ro-Ro vessel while it was moored at Sanayi Pier in [SAMSUN Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/788?name=SAMSUN&country=Turkey), Turkey. Upon receiving the information the fire department, police, and Provincial Disaster and Emergency Directorate (AFAD) were deployed at the scene. The firefighting efforts included 15 vehicles, 50 personnel, and two tug boats operated by the port authority and Samsun Metropolitan Municipality. The team boarded [LIRUZE G](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:339300/mmsi:511101191/imo:7811329/vessel:FIRUZE_G) and tackled the flames and after 2.5 hours of intensive effort the fire was successfully extinguished. The cooling operation started to prevent any reignition of fire, while a fire brigade stationed nearby as a precaution. Authorities reported that no crewmembers were affected by the smoke inhalation and are in good health.

headline: Bulgarian-Owned Vessel Severs Undersea Cable in the Baltic Sea in Yet Another Incident of Dragging Anchor
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Bulk carrier [VEZHEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7148754/mmsi:229659000/imo:9937270/vessel:VEZHEN#overview) was detained by Swedish authorities under suspicion of damaging an undersea cable in the Baltic Sea. The incident that occurred early on 26th January is being claimed to be yet another incident of a vessel unintentionally dragging its anchor and ending up severing an undersea cable. ![VEZHEN detained by Swedish authorities under suspicion of damaging an undersea cable.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/VEZHEN_81fbe8c566.png)*Vessel VEZHEN, image credit: Carson Last* The [VEZHEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7148754/mmsi:229659000/imo:9937270/vessel:VEZHEN#overview) is a Maltese-flagged bulk carrier owned by the Bulgarian-headquartered shipping company Navigation Maritime Bulgare. The CEO of this company, Alexander Kalchev, acknowledged the possibility of the vessel having severed the undersea cable but firmly denied any allegations of sabotage performed by the crew, claiming the act to be unintentional. He explained that as the vessel was passing through the region between Latvia and Gotland, where the undersea cable was severed, the ship was facing inclement weather and winds with speeds up to 25 meters per second. He claims that one of the anchors must have become dislodged and dragged across the ocean floor without the knowledge of the crew and ended up damaging the undersea cable. Swedish authorities have launched an investigation into this matter. The vessel [VEZHEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7148754/mmsi:229659000/imo:9937270/vessel:VEZHEN#overview) was detained quickly after the severing of the cable was identified by the authorities. This incident is the fourth of its kind in less than a year, in which a vessel has severed an undersea cable, and the operator has claimed the vessel to have accidentally dropped anchor.

headline: Engine Room Fire on Tanker KRITI CAPTAIN Contained in France
author: Raghib Raza
content: A global marine claims management and recovery services company reported that on 25th January, a fire broke out in the engine room of the oil/chemical tanker [KRITI CAPTAIN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:370380/mmsi:636021691/imo:9335147/vessel:KRITI_CAPTAIN#overview). The incident occurred when the vessel was moored at [PORT-LA-NOUVELLE Anchorage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/22997?name=PORT-LA-NOUVELLE-ANC&country=France), France. ![Fire aboard KRITI CAPTAIN.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KRITI_CAPTAIN_dac2ac64e8.png)*Vessel KRITI CAPTAIN, image credit: Michael HARTUNG* The local firefighters swiftly responded to the situation and successfully extinguished the fire. There have been no reports of injuries or significant environmental impact at this time. The vessel is remains under observation with tugboats in attendance. [KRITI CAPTAIN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:370380/mmsi:636021691/imo:9335147/vessel:KRITI_CAPTAIN#overview) is a 2007-built vessel sailing under the flag of Liberia. The vessel has an overall length of 184 meters and a breadth of 27 meters.

headline: Electric Hybrid Vessel Becomes the First to Bunker LNG at Portsmouth International Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: Brittany Ferries’ upcoming Ro-Ro passenger vessel, the [SAINT-MALO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8841600/mmsi:228457700/imo:9946336/vessel:SAINT_MALO#overview), became the first vessel to undergo LNG bunkering at the [PORTMOUTH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/107?name=PORTSMOUTH&country=United-Kingdom) International Port. ![First LNG Bunkering at Portsmouth by Saint Malo.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SAINT_MALO_80af85c542.png)*Vessel SAINT MALO, image credit:portsmouth-port.co.uk* The bunkering was conducted by the vessel [OPTIMUS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6466692/mmsi:275525000/imo:9870472/vessel:OPTIMUS), which supplied the LNG to the [SAINT MALO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8841600/mmsi:228457700/imo:9946336/vessel:SAINT_MALO#overview). The [OPTIMUS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6466692/mmsi:275525000/imo:9870472/vessel:OPTIMUS) is a bunkering barge operated by Titan Clean Fuels, and a permit was issued to perform the said bunkering at Portsmouth International Port earlier this month. This particular bunkering marks the beginning of Portsmouth International Port offering LNG bunkering services. Port officials have stated that this is an important milestone in their goal of achieving net carbon neutrality by 2030 and becoming emissions free by 2050. The [SAINT MALO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8841600/mmsi:228457700/imo:9946336/vessel:SAINT_MALO#overview) is a passenger ro-ro vessel flagged in France. It has a length of 194 metres, a beam of 32 metres, and a gross tonnage of 30,000. It is the first of two new electric hybrid vessels in Brittany’s fleet and will enter service on 12 February.

headline: Maritime Collision at Indonesian Port Involves Two Vessels, No Injuries Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: A maritime incident occurred involving the collision between a cargo vessel, [LUMOSO HARMONI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:418623/mmsi:525113007/imo:9405461/vessel:LUMOSO_HARMONI), and a bulk carrier, [PANCARAN GLORY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:314691/mmsi:525121026/imo:9382724/vessel:PANCARAN_GLORY), on 24th January. The incident took place at Muara Sampara Morosi Port, Indonesia. ![LUMOSO HARMONI collided with PANCARAN GLORY](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LUMOSO_HARMONI_92039f3099.png)*Vessel LUMOSO HARMONI, image credit:hubla.dephub.go.id* At 06:53 PM, WITA, [LUMOSO HARMONI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:418623/mmsi:525113007/imo:9405461/vessel:LUMOSO_HARMONI) reportedly struck the starboard side of the [PANCARAN GLORY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:314691/mmsi:525121026/imo:9382724/vessel:PANCARAN_GLORY) while maneuvering to dock at the jetty with the assistance of three tugboats. This affected the bulwark and bulbous bow of the cargo vessel. Fortunately, no casualties were reported. According to the initial report, the collision caused a 2.92-meter-long scratch above the waterline on [PANCARAN GLORY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:314691/mmsi:525121026/imo:9382724/vessel:PANCARAN_GLORY). The inspection team conducted a visual inspection of the upper hull. However, underwater surveys remain pending, requiring divers to assess for potential damage, such as deformation or leaks. Officials confirmed that precautionary measures have been taken to ensure the vessel's safety. An investigation is ongoing to determine the cause of the collision and establish accountability.

headline: The Escalating Threat to Undersea Cables: The Fourth Maritime Cable Incident Since November
author: Alex Stuart-Grumbar
content: _Contributing author: Dimitris Ampatzidis, Risk and Compliance Analyst at Kpler_ The **VEZHEN** ([IMO 9937270](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7148754/mmsi:229659000/imo:9937270/vessel:VEZHEN)) incident raises familiar yet increasingly urgent questions about maritime risk, intent, and accountability. Undersea cables play a critical role in global internet connectivity and energy transmission, forming the backbone of modern communication and infrastructure. Damage to these cables can have far-reaching consequences, disrupting services and exposing vulnerabilities in maritime security. A vessel slows down, deviates from its expected course, exhibits erratic movement, and soon after, a vital undersea cable is found damaged. The sequence of events follows a now well-documented pattern—one seen with Shunxing39, YI PENG 3 or EAGLE S incidents referenced in a recent [MarineTraffic article](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/maritime-news/16/general/2025/11765/commercial-vessels-a-new-form-of-hybrid-warfare). What makes this incident particularly striking is how predictable it is when compared to previous events. The combination of vessel behavior and infrastructure damage forms a worrying pattern that continues to unfold in plain sight. **Vessel Details** The Maltese-flagged VEZHEN, a Handysize bulk carrier, was en route from the Russian port of Ust Luga, loading a cargo of sulfur. Kpler’s ownership data shows the vessel is managed by Navibulgar, a major player in Bulgarian shipping and a member of BIMCO. Whilst the registered owner is a Hong Kong registered company called Hai Kuo Shipping 2015B Limited. ![CleanShot 2025-01-27 at 12.15.01.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Clean_Shot_2025_01_27_at_12_15_01_fa263ade2d.png) **Image 1:** _On January 25, 2025, at 03:20 UTC, the vessel - a 2022-built Handysize bulker, DWT 32,196 - began reducing its speed from a usual operational speed of just above 10 knots to around 7.5 knots. This reduction continued for almost a full day until 06:50 UTC on January 26, when it resumed its normal operational speed. Just before returning to her normal speed, the vessel briefly maneuvered below 3 knots, with an AIS trajectory that shows a sharp course deviation - MarineTraffic data._ This is almost identical to what was observed in the other cable cutting incidents including YI PENG 3 and NEWNEW POLAR BEAR, where vessels slowed down or altered course before undersea cables were found damaged. The location of this low-speed maneuvering is also critical. The VEZHEN was transiting an area where a fiber-optic cable between Latvia and Sweden's Gotland was later found damaged. This mirrors what happened with EAGLE S in December 2024, when Finnish authorities later recovered its damaged anchor after the vessel had passed over the Estlink 2 cable. The consistency in how these incidents unfold raises obvious questions. **Contradicting Statements** The company issued a statement claiming that the damage was due to “unfavorable hydrometeorological conditions.” (source: https://www.navbul.com/ ) However, based on MarineTraffic data, our weather data partner and AIS tracking analysis, the conditions encountered by the ship were calm to moderate, well within the normal range for the Baltic Sea during winter. - **Waves and Swells:** The ship encountered moderate swells, with periods ranging from 2.7 to 4.7 seconds and heights generally below 1 meter. This is typical for the Baltic Sea, which has smaller swells compared to open oceans due to its shallow waters. - **Wind:** Wind speeds peaked at 16 knots and decreased to 2 knots at times. These are typical conditions for the Baltic in January, with stronger winds being more notable during major storms—something not observed in this instance. - **Currents:** Current speeds ranged between 0.01 to 0.23 knots, primarily from the east to southeast. These mild currents are characteristic of the Baltic Sea. Then there’s the mechanical evidence. Photos from the scene show the ship’s anchor was broken—another element that ties this case to others (source: Reuters - [Swedish authorities board ship seized over Baltic Sea cable breach](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/swedish-authorities-board-ship-seized-over-baltic-sea-cable-breach-2025-01-27/)). The same was reported for NEWNEW POLA BEAR (source: ERR - [Photo: Chinese ship that crossed gas pipeline is missing anchor](https://news.err.ee/1609143092/photo-chinese-ship-that-crossed-gas-pipeline-is-missing-anchor)) after the Baltic connector pipeline incident and YI PENG 3 when it severed Sweden-Lithuania’s undersea cables (source: The Maritime Executive - [Suspected Sabotage Ship's Anchor Shows Signs of Extreme Damage](https://maritime-executive.com/article/suspected-sabotage-ship-s-anchor-shows-signs-of-extreme-damage)). Ships do not randomly drop or drag their anchors in these areas, let alone repeatedly break them under similar circumstances. **At what point do we stop treating these as isolated maritime mishaps?** The combination of speed reductions, erratic course deviations, known infrastructure damage, and physical anchor evidence follows a pattern too clear to ignore. While the specific causes behind each event may vary, the sequence of actions is almost identical.

headline: Stena Ro Ro Expands Fleet by Purchasing New Vessel GIUSEPPE LUCCHESI
author: Raghib Raza
content: Stena Ro-Ro revealed on 21st January that they are expanding their fleet with a new acquisition, the RoRo vessel[ GIUSEPPE LUCCCHESI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:281734/mmsi:219034351/imo:9503639/vessel:GIUSEPPE_LUCCHESI#overview). The new ship will be named the Stena Shipper after its acquisition. ![GIUSEPPE LUCCHESI](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GIUSEPPE_LUCCHESI_bbcdb8f3df.png)*Vessel GIUSEPPE LUCCHESI, image credit: Stena Ro-Ro* The RoRo vessel was built in 2012 at the Danish Odense Shipyard and was previously owned by CLDN (Compagnia Italiana di Navigazione S.p.A). The vessel will be registered in Denmark following the acquisition. The specific routes that the vessel will be employed on have not been disclosed; its addition has been described as enhancing Stena’s market presence in the Mediterranean shipping routes. The vessel is 193 meters long, 26 meters wide, and has a gross tonnage 29,429. The vessel is described as having a large cargo capacity, low fuel consumption, and providing good environmental characteristics.

headline: Update: India Invests $231 Million in Enhancing its Maritime Infrastructure
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Indian Union Minister of Ports, Shipping, and Waterways, Sarbananda Sonowal, announced a new investment worth Rs. 2000 crores (around $231.45 million) in projects that aim to enhance the capacity and efficiency of the Jawaharlal Nehru Port Authority (JNPA) also known[ NHAVA SHEVA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2713?name=NHAVA-SHEVA&country=India) Port. ![India to enhance the capacity and efficiency of the Jawaharlal Nehru Port Authority (JNPA).](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NHAVA_SHEVA_PORT_113c3bef40.png)*Image credit:pib.gov.in* The announcements involved the declaration that the JNPA has officially surpassed 10 million TEUs of capacity in January 2025. Sonowal further stated that the growth is projected to surpass 10.4 million TEUs by 2027. Other plans within the JNPA include the commissioning of a second phase of the Bharat Mumbai Container Terminal (BMCT). This new addition is expected to add a further 2.4 million TEUs of capacity to the JNPA. More auxiliary plans for the furthering of the port include the launch of a solar-powered boat, two indigenously developed tugboats, and three fire tenders, which are intended to boost the safety and operational efficiency of the port. Major memorandums of understanding were also signed in the event in the presence of the minister. The MoUs were for the development of the Vadhavan Port Project. One of these MoUs was signed with Reliance Industries for the development of a liquid water jetty and for land allocation under a public-private partnership model worth Rs. 645 crores (around $74.6 million).Another of these MoU was signed with HMM, which will handle the deployment and operation at the port. The upcoming Vadhavan Port is expected to be one of the top 10 container terminals in the world by 2040. It is expected to handle 23 million TEUs annually and will have nine container terminals.

headline: Explosion at Barcelona Port Claims One Life, Leaves Three Injured
author: Raghib Raza
content: An explosion occurred at the Port of [BARCELONA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/236?name=BARCELONA&country=Spain), Spain on 21st January. Although the explosion was quickly contained and the fire was not allowed to spread beyond the port, it led to the death of one person and three others being injured. ![Explosion at Barcelona Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BARCELONA_PORT_3fa50f8da2.png)*BARCEONA PORT, image credit:X/Catalunya Informació* The incident occurred at around 10:10 AM local time on the Energy Wharf of the port of [BARCELONA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/236?name=BARCELONA&country=Spain), where the chemicals, natural gas, and petroleum products are handled. The source of the explosion was a tanker in the facility operated by Terminales Portuarias S.L. (TEPSA), filled with methyl acetate that was undergoing maintenance. The fire was extinguished around 40 minutes after it started due to the quick response of the firefighting teams. One person was killed in the incident, and one other was grievously injured and had to be taken to a nearby hospital. Although two other people also suffered injuries. Fortunately, their injuries were not severe, and they were given medical attention at the port itself. People in companies and facilities near the port of [BARCELONA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/236?name=BARCELONA&country=Spain) were advised to stay indoors as a precaution.

headline: Ship Collision in Northern Horsburgh Waters: No Injuries or Hazards Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 21st January, a collision occurred between a bulk carrier, [SHANDONG MISSION](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6873962/mmsi:477736300/imo:9910741/vessel:SHANDONG_MISSION#overview), and a barge, TB Sinhin 5. The incident took place in northern Horsburgh, in the vicinity of Indonesian territorial waters. ![SHANDONG MISSION collided with barge in Indonesian water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SHANDONG_MISSION_edacd99d03.png)*Image credit:hubla.dephub.go.id* According to the report of Vessel Traffic System (VTS) in Batam, at around 09:46 AM local time, [SHANDONG MISSION](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6873962/mmsi:477736300/imo:9910741/vessel:SHANDONG_MISSION#overview), en route from Singapore to Australia, collided with the TB Sinhin 5, which was traveling from Port Klang to Kota Kinabalu. In the collision, [SHANDONG MISSION](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6873962/mmsi:477736300/imo:9910741/vessel:SHANDONG_MISSION#overview) sustained minor damage to its starboard bow, but there were no signs of leakage or injuries. On the other hand, TB Sinhin 5 reported damage to its portside hull, resulting in leakage and causing the barge to tilt by 10°–15°. Some of the barge's white brick cargo fell into the sea, but no hazardous materials were involved in the incident. At around 11:59 AM local time, TB Sinhin 5 diverted its route and returned to Johor with a 150-meter towing line to ensure its stability. A few minutes later, at 12:19 PM local time, the bulk carrier was deemed seaworthy and continued its voyage. Indonesian maritime authorities including VTS Batam, the Tanjung Uban PLP Base, and the Tanjung Uban Port Authority coordinated to ensure maritime safety. No injuries or hazardous material spills were reported in the incident.

headline: Cargo Vessel HAVELLAND Suffers Engine Failure in the Kiel Canal
author: Raghib Raza
content: The cargo vessel [HAVELLAND](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:204264/mmsi:255805653/imo:9499735/vessel:HAVELLAND#overview) suffered engine failure while on the westbound transit of the Kiel Canal, Germany, on 20th January. No reports of injuries or pollution from the vessel have been released. ![HAVELLAND suffered engine failure while traveling through kiel Canal.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/HAVELLAND_8649167233.png)*Vessel HAVELLAND, image credit: Malte Schwarz* The incident occurred at around 11:53 AM local time when the vessel was traveling from [SUNDSVALL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/489?name=SUNDSVALL&country=Sweden), Sweden to [HULL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/146?name=HULL&country=United-Kingdom) Port, United Kingdom. The vessel suffered an engine failure and ended up running into the southern embankment of the canal. However, the vessel managed to start one of its engines and generated enough power to pull itself free. The tugboat Parat was dispatched to aid the vessel and escort it to Rendsburg. The [HAVELLAND](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:204264/mmsi:255805653/imo:9499735/vessel:HAVELLAND#overview) is a general cargo ship that is 110.9 metres long, 16.5 metres wide, and has a gross tonnage of 4,966. It was built in 2012 and is flagged in Portugal.

headline: Cargo Vessel GREEN RIZHAO Delivered to COSCO Shipping
author: Raghib Raza
content: The cargo vessel [GREEN RIZHAO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9314322/mmsi:636023209/imo:9997919/vessel:GREEN_RIZHAO) was delivered to COSCO Shipping on 15th January. The vessel was inducted into COSCO’s fleet at a ceremony held in Dalian, China. ![GREEN RIZHAO](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GREEN_RIZHAO_03a941010c.png)*Cargo vessel GREEN RIZHAO, image credit:xindemarinenews* The 77,000-dwt vessel has a length of 225 meters and a beam of 32.2 meters. It is claimed to be a multipurpose carrier intended to transport pulp cargo, high-speed trains, wind power equipment, EVs, heavy machinery, and other oversized steel structures. The [GREEN RIZHAO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9314322/mmsi:636023209/imo:9997919/vessel:GREEN_RIZHAO) is being hailed as the first vessel in China to be built with net zero carbon emissions. The vessel underwent a carbon-neutral evaluation and has a Carbon Neutrality Certificate issued by the China Classification Society. The vessel will undertake its maiden voyage from China to Brazil, carrying wind power equipment, engineering machinery, and containers.

headline: Cargo Ship SURYANI LADJONI Suffers Leaks; Crew Rescued off Madura Island
author: Raghib Raza
content: On January 18th, the vessel [SURYANI LADJONI ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5107013/mmsi:525018464/imo:7526766/vessel:SURYANI_LADJONI)developed leaks. Initial reports indicate that no casualties resulted from the incident, and all crewmembers were rescued. ![SURYANI LADJONI listed in Indonesian water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SURYANI_LADJONI_e7d4681fd9.png)*Vessel SURYANI LADJONI, image credit:hubla.dephub.go.id* The incident occurred in the northern waters of Madura Island, Indonesia when the vessel was traveling from Banjarmasin to Surabaya. The leaks were reported to be in the keel, the starboard side, and the port side of the vessel. Due to the water intake, the ship ended up listing 25 degrees towards the port side. Upon detection of the leak, the captain of the [SURYANI LADJONI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5107013/mmsi:525018464/imo:7526766/vessel:SURYANI_LADJONI) quickly informed the vessel [PALUNG MAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4016647/mmsi:525022408/imo:9791755/vessel:PALUNG_MAS). However, the [PALUNG MAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4016647/mmsi:525022408/imo:9791755/vessel:PALUNG_MAS) faced difficulties in evacuating the crew of the distressed vessel due to adverse weather. The crew of the [SURYANI LADJONI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5107013/mmsi:525018464/imo:7526766/vessel:SURYANI_LADJONI) disembarked on life rafts and were evacuated by the[ PALUNG MAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4016647/mmsi:525022408/imo:9791755/vessel:PALUNG_MAS), which managed to maneuver closer. All crewmembers were then dropped off at the Teluk Lamong Port at around 6:00 PM WIB. An investigation has been opened into the matter, and the Directorate General of Sea Transportation is gathering information regarding the causes of the incident and potential pollution that could result from the incident.

headline: Kimbe Port in Papua New Guinea to Receive Upgrades From Australian Financing
author: Raghib Raza
content: [KIMBE Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/24888?name=KIMBE&country=Papua-New-Guinea) in Papua New Guinea is the first of five ports slated to undergo upgrades under a financial package being provided by the Australian government. The initiative by the Australian government is aimed at enhancing the broader maritime infrastructure in the country. ![KIMBE PORT to undergo upgrade.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KIMBE_PORT_2933e70c0e.png)*KIMBE PORT, image credit: PNG Ports Corporation* PNG Ports Corporation Ltd. awarded the contract to Pacific Marine Group. The construction work in Kimbe Port is to begin imminently and is scheduled to conclude by the end of 2026. The project, named the “Kimbe Port Rehabilitation and Upgrade Project,” has a funding of around PGK 260 million ($64 million) and will involve the construction of a new wharf structure after the old one is demolished and works on reinforcing existing wharf and revetment walls. The funding for the upgrades will be sourced from a portion of the PGK 1.5 billion ($370 million) being provided by the Australian government under the Australian Infrastructure Financing Facility for the Pacific (AIFFP). The AIFFP is an initiative by the Australian government launched in 2019 to enhance infrastructure in Pacific Island countries and Timor-Leste via loans and grants. The intent behind the initiative is to improve regional stability and economic prosperity.

headline: Russian Cargo Ship Tilts at Plastun Port Amid Timber Cargo Loss
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 16th January, a Russian-flagged cargo vessel, [STEPAN GEYTS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:349724/mmsi:273415040/imo:8308939/vessel:STEPAN_GEYTS#overview), tilted dangerously to starboard at the [PLASTUN Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/18118?name=PLASTUN&country=Russia), Russia. At around 2:47 PM local time, the timber cargo on the vessel's deck started sliding towards its starboard side and eventually fell overboard. ![STEPAN GEYTS near capsized at Russian port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/STEPAN_GEYTS_d0e35e5456.png)*Vessel STEPAN GEYTS, image credit:Instagram/shipspotter_hayriyay* The vessel was listed heavily due to the loss of timber cargo but regained stability after most of the timber fell into the water, leaving some hanging over the side. Some crew members escaped to the quay, fearing a capsize. No casualties were reported. [STEPAN GEYTS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:349724/mmsi:273415040/imo:8308939/vessel:STEPAN_GEYTS#overview) is a 1983-built vessel operated by Vladivostok-based Lesprom-Nakhodka JSC. The vessel has a length of 90.5 meters and a width of 152 meters.

headline: Container Ship ECO LEVANT Runs Aground in Kiel Canal, Disrupting Marine Traffic
author: Raghib Raza
content: The French-flagged container ship [ECO LEVANT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8868555/mmsi:228467900/imo:9985954/vessel:ECO_LEVANT#overview) ran aground on the northern embankment of the Kiel Canal, also known as Nord-Ostsee-Kanal Canal, on 16th January. The incident occurred near the Rüsterbergen pilot station in Germany, at around 1:00 AM local time during the vessel’s eastbound journey from Antwerp towards Kiel. ![ECO LEVANT ran aground in Kiel Canal.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ECO_LEVANT_c8da274aff.png)*Containership ECO LEVANT, image credit:lomazoma.com* The Neumünster police have reported that the accident was caused by a machine failure resulting from a technical defect in the hydraulic system. The Kiel Canal remained fully closed for hours, halting the transit of 20 vessels in both directions. The canal authority promptly responded, and a tug, the Holtenau, was mobilized to assist the vessel. At around 8:00 AM local time, the vessel was successfully refloated with the assistance of the Holtenau. The vessel was then berthed at the heavy-load port of Rendsburg-Osterrönfeld where the police boarded the vessel to conduct an investigation. . Following the hydraulic system repair, and obtaining approval from the classification society DNVGL, the vessel resumed its journey. Marine traffic data shows the [ECO LEVANT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8868555/mmsi:228467900/imo:9985954/vessel:ECO_LEVANT#overview) departed from [NORD-OSTSEE-KANAL Canal](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/21777?name=NORD-OSTSEE-KANAL&country=Germany#overview), Germany on 17th January and is scheduled to arrive in [MUUGA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/716?name=MUUGA&country=Estonia), Estonia on 19th January.

headline: Trafigura Pioneers Mixed Cargo Shipping with GREEN POWER Vessel
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 16th January, Trafigura announced the completion of the delivery of a mixed cargo of ammonia and LPG aboard the same vessel, [GREEN POWER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7472151/mmsi:563182700/imo:9927316/vessel:GREEN_POWER#overview). This venture marked a significant milestone in the maritime industry and showcased the feasibility of transporting smaller quantities of low-carbon ammonia to ports based on their demand. ![Trafigura completes ammonia and LPG co-loading shipment via GREEN POWER.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GREEN_POWER_b3c8e1053c.png)*Image credit: Trafigura* The [GREEN POWER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7472151/mmsi:563182700/imo:9927316/vessel:GREEN_POWER#overview) gas carrier was loaded in two phases. The first shipment of ammonia was loaded onto the vessel at the CF Industries’ manufacturing facility in Donaldsonville, Louisiana. The vessel then moved on to Corpus Christi where the shipment of LPG was loaded. Both products were stored in separate tanks on the vessel to prevent cross-contamination. The vessel made the journey across the Atlantic, and the cargo onboard was offloaded at separate locations. The LPG was offloaded in the Mediterranean via a ship-to-ship transfer to be used in domestic heating, and the ammonia was offloaded at [TEES ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/149?name=TEES&country=United-Kingdom)Port to be used in a fertilizer plant. The shipment was preceded by an extensive risk assessment and a comprehensive review of the regulations involved. The operation was planned between the shipowner and operator Purus, STS company International Fender Providers, and the ports involved. Patricio Norris at Trafigura stated that they regularly transport ammonia and LPG on similar vessels but have never co-loaded the vessels. He stated that co-loading the vessels will allow them to improve the economics of the operation and reduce the number of voyages as well as emissions.

headline: Philippine Navy rescues 121 Passengers from Stranded Vessel
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 14th January, the Philippine Navy rescued 121 passengers that were stranded aboard the vessel [ML J SAYANG 1](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5636457/mmsi:548000018/imo:0/vessel:ML_J_SAYANG_1) after it experienced engine failure and was left adrift. The vessel was missing for 6 days. ![ML J SAYANG 1 passengers rescued by Philippine Navy after the vessel stranded for days. ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ML_J_SAYANG_1_b4abb199f7.png)*image credit:Philippine Navy* THE [ML J SAYANG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5636457/mmsi:548000018/imo:0/vessel:ML_J_SAYANG_1) experienced engine troubles on 8th January near Pangutaran Island, Philippines. Although initial efforts to repair the engine were successful, the vessel suffered further mechanical issues, which led to it being without communication or fuel. Fishermen passing through the area spotted the stranded vessel and notified authorities. The BRP Jose Loor SR managed to locate the distressed vessel at 12:00 PM local time on 14th January. The vessel was reported to be stuck around 5.4 nautical miles off Siklangkalong Island, Tawi-Tawi. The BRP Jose Loor SR found 121 passengers aboard the stranded vessel. The passengers were in sound physical condition, although they were reported to be psychologically distressed due to the recent ordeal. They were provided with food, water, medical attention, and an internet connection to contact their families. The vessel was then towed to safety at Taja Island, Tawi Tawi. At around 5:00 PM local time, another vessel, ML Arneza, arrived, delivered additional fuel and provisions, and towed the [ML J SAYANG 1 ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5636457/mmsi:548000018/imo:0/vessel:ML_J_SAYANG_1)to its destination at Turtle Islands, Tawi Tawi.

headline: Odisha Government in India Plans Ship Recycling Hub and Two New Ports to Boost Maritime Infrastructure
author: Raghib Raza
content: The government in the state of Odisha in India is planning to establish a Rs. 4000 Crore (around $462.6 million) ship recycling hub near [PARADIP](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17379?name=PARADIP&country=India) Port, India. ![PARADIP PORT.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PARADIP_PORT_0c134eb283.png)*PARADIP PORT, image credit: Prasad Mendgule* The new ship recycling hub is to be built by the Odisha government in collaboration with Paradip Port Authority. The venture aims to create a significant center for shipbuilding and repair, greatly enhancing the region's maritime capabilities. The government is also planning to build two new ports with private entities' collaboration. The two new ports, which are planned to be built at Ichuri in North Odisha and Bahuda in South Odisha, will be designed to handle around 40 million tonnes of cargo per annum each. More distant plans from the government include the establishment of a hydrogen production facility in the state by the end of 2026.

headline: Fire Breaks Out Aboard Brazilian-Flagged Vessel in Campos Basin; Crew Successfully Rescued
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire broke out on the anchor handling vessel [BRAM FORCE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4909700/mmsi:710031020/imo:9788409/vessel:BRAM_FORCE#overview) on the night of 8th January while it was operating in the Campos Basin. After 12 hours of effort, the fire was extinguished, and fortunately, all crewmembers were successfully rescued. ![Fire broke aboard the vessel BRAM FORCE ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BRAM_FORCE_f6e326028a.png)*Vessel BRAM FORCE, image credit:radioaurora.com.br* Early reports state that the fire aboard the [BRAM FORCE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4909700/mmsi:710031020/imo:9788409/vessel:BRAM_FORCE#overview) originated in the engine room, and the cause of the fire is yet unknown. All the crewmembers were successfully rescued by a Maersk vessel while tugboats were mobilized for the firefighting effort. The Brazilian Navy later reported that after 12 hours of efforts, the fire was extinguished and that the vessel was to be towed to the Port of Açu. The Navy further stated that an administrative inquiry would be opened into the incident to discern the cause of the fire. The [BRAM FORCE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4909700/mmsi:710031020/imo:9788409/vessel:BRAM_FORCE#overview) is a Brazilian-registered anchor-handling vessel built in 2017. It has a length of 93.6 meters, a beam of 21.9 meters, and a gross tonnage of 7,539.

headline: Tanker Sinks in Singaporean Waters Near Pedra Branca; All Crew Members Safe
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Malaysian-registered Oil Products tanker [SILVER SINCERE ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:708553/mmsi:533379000/imo:8712829/vessel:SILVER_SINCERE)sank in Singaporean waters off of Pedra Branca on 12th January. Fortunately, all eight crewmembers were successfully rescued after a search and rescue effort organized by the Maritime Port Authority of Singapore (MPA). ![SILVER SINCERE sank in Singaporean water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SILVER_SINCERE_cb83743115.png)*Oil products Tanker SILVER SINCERE, image credit: Julian T* The MPA received the distress signal from the [SILVER SINCERE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:708553/mmsi:533379000/imo:8712829/vessel:SILVER_SINCERE), stating that the vessel was taking on water at around 3:40 PM (SGT), and promptly began a search and rescue operation. The MPA stated that in addition to their own vessels, vessels from the Singapore Navy and the Singapore Police Coast Guard were also deployed in the rescue operation. The good Samaritan vessel [INTAN DAYA 368](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:705283/mmsi:525023251/imo:9694713/vessel:INTAN_DAYA_368), a cargo vessel assisting the distressed vessel at the MPA’s instruction, rescued all eight crewmembers from the liferafts. The rescued crewmembers were disembarked at Batu Ampar, Indonesia, and were reported to be in good health. Following the conclusion of the search and rescue effort, the MPA deployed tugs and oil spill response teams to tend to the sunken vessel. A navigational advisory has also been posted for vessels to avoid the incident site.

headline: 18 Vietnamese Crew Rescued After Cargo Ship Sinks Southwest of Vietnam
author: Raghib Raza
content: A maritime incident occurred southwest of Vung Tau, Vietnam, involving the sinking of the Vietnamese-registered cargo vessel [DOLPHIN 18](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:737444/mmsi:574928000/imo:9216341/vessel:DOLPHIN_89) on 11th January. Fortunately, all the 18 Vietnamese crew members were safely rescued. ![NICOLAI MAERSK rescued the crewmembers of the sunken freighter.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NICOLAI_MAERSK_dfa86b806d.png)*Conatiership NICOLAI MAERSK, image credit: Hans Rosenkranz* At around 7:00 AM SGT, the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre (MRCC) operated by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) received a report from the Hong Kong-flagged container ship [NICOLAI MAERSK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:157911/mmsi:477642900/imo:9192454/vessel:NICOLAI_MAERSK) regarding the distress call from [DOLPHIN 18](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:737444/mmsi:574928000/imo:9216341/vessel:DOLPHIN_89). [DOLPHIN 18](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:737444/mmsi:574928000/imo:9216341/vessel:DOLPHIN_89) was located approximately 274 nautical miles southwest of Vung Tau, Vietnam, within the Singapore Maritime Search and Rescue Region. The MRCC responded swiftly and coordinated search and rescue efforts, issuing the navigational broadcast to alert the nearby vessels to be on the lookout and report the sighting of the distressed cargo vessel . The Vietnamese Maritime authorities were also informed about the incident. [NICOLAI MAERSK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:157911/mmsi:477642900/imo:9192454/vessel:NICOLAI_MAERSK) shortly arrived at the incident location and successfully rescued all the [DOLPHIN 18](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:737444/mmsi:574928000/imo:9216341/vessel:DOLPHIN_89) crewmembers from the lifeboats. The rescued crewmembers were reported to be safe and in good health. The containership [NICOLAI MAERSK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:157911/mmsi:477642900/imo:9192454/vessel:NICOLAI_MAERSK) en route to its next port of call at [TANJUNG PELEPAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1010?name=TANJUNG-PELEPAS&country=Malaysia), Malaysia, where it will disembark the rescued crew. The cargo vessel was confirmed to have been sunk, while MRCC Singapore issued further navigational warnings to vessels transiting the area, urging caution due to the presence of the sunken vessel.

headline: Power Failure Leaves Tanker Carrying 99,000 Tons of Oil Adrift in Baltic Sea
author: Raghib Raza
content: A Panama-flagged oil tanker, [EVENTIN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:373974/mmsi:352001758/imo:9308065/vessel:EVENTIN#overview), began drifting at low speed north of Rügen in the Baltic Sea, near Germany, due to a power failure. The vessel carrying approximately 99,000 tons of oil, became unmaneuverable on 10th January, at around 12:30 PM local time. ![EVENTIN adrift in Baltic sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/EVENTIN_1142b8fe6e.png)*Vessel EVENTIN, image credit:havariekommando.de* The Warnemunde Traffic Control Center requested Germany's Central Command for Maritime Emergencies to take charge of the situation. Promptly, multi-purpose vessel Arkona of Federal Waterways and Shipping Administration and the emergency tug Bremen Fighter were dispatched to assist the distressed vessel. Due to inclement weather, including winds of 7 Beaufort scale and waves of 2.5 meters, the rescue operation became unmanageable. Additional tugs VB Bremen and VB Luca joined the operation, and a specialized towing team of four individuals was deployed via a federal police helicopter. At around 10:50 PM local time, the towing team boarded the oil tanker and established a connection between the tanker and the tug VB Bremen. VB Luca was able to establish a connection to the stern of the vessel, and Bremen Fighter maintained a connection at the bow of the vessel. Subsequently, the three tugs successfully held the oil tanker about eight nautical miles north of Rugen. The towing convoy began relocating northeast of Cape Arkona in response to the increasingly northerly wind in the sea area. This safer position provides more open sea space to prevent [EVENTIN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:373974/mmsi:352001758/imo:9308065/vessel:EVENTIN#overview) from drifting. The vessel is to be held at this position till the winds subside. Inspections of the vessel are being carried out periodically via a sensor aircraft and so far there has been no leaks or pollution detected from the vessel. Currently, the convoy, consisting of the [EVENTIN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:373974/mmsi:352001758/imo:9308065/vessel:EVENTIN#overview) and the three tugs, is moving cautiously and is expected to reach a safer position northeast of Rugen in approximately eight hours. The tanker's 24-member crew remains safe, with no evacuation required. Authorities are continuously monitoring the situation and evaluating towing options to bring the vessel to a secure port.

headline: Port of Vancouver to Implement New Navigation Aids to Improve Safety and Efficiency
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Vancouver Fraser Port Authority is implementing new navigation aids in the eastern Burrard Inlet to enhance marine safety and efficiency for vessel movements. These aids are expected to help around 500 vessels per year calling on seven of the port’s terminals per year. ![Port of Vancouver to Implement New Navigation Aids.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Port_of_Vancouver_da69b2186d.png)*Image credit: Vancouver Fraser Port Authority* The navigation aids include two solar-powered range lights and one sector light located near Berry Point. The installation of these implements is expected to begin in January and be completed by spring this year. The new navigation aids will not only allow for improved transit capabilities; they will also make nighttime transit in the eastward direction of the second narrows. Until now, the Second Narrows waterway was the only area in the Port of [VANCOUVER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/682?name=VANCOUVER&country=Canada) where nighttime travel was restricted for safety. The introduction of these new navigational aids will improve visibility and mitigate risks associated with navigating the narrow channel at night. These aids, once installed, will be tested by the Pacific Pilotage Authority and BC Coast Pilots starting in late April before being opened for use.

headline: Bulk Carrier ALGOMA VERITY Runs Aground in Delaware River near Philadelphia
author: Raghib Raza
content: The bulk carrier [ALGOMA VERITY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:300044/mmsi:311000905/imo:9183776/vessel:ALGOMA_VERITY) ran aground near the Ben Franklin Bridge, Philadelphia, in the Delaware River on 8th January. The Coast Guard and other maritime agencies are responding to the situation, and fortunately, no injuries or pollution have been reported so far. ![ALGOMA VERITY ran aground.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ALGOMA_VERITY_a9603a5d74.png)*Bulk Carrier ALGOMA VERITY, image credit: Kyle Edwards* The [ALGOMA VERITY ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:300044/mmsi:311000905/imo:9183776/vessel:ALGOMA_VERITY)is a bulk carrier headed from the [PHILADELPHIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2817?name=PHILADELPHIA&country=USA) port to [FAIRLESS HILL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/21084?name=FAIRLESS-HILLS&country=USA), Bucks County. The vessel was carrying 45,000 tons of solar salt when the grounding occurred. The Coast Guard Sector Delaware received a report of the vessel grounding with no injuries at 6:30 PM (EST) on 8th January. An urgent marine information broadcast notice was issued warning other vessels to avoid the area. Vessels that are required to pass through the area are required to contact the Coast Guard Command Center one hour prior to their transit through the area. As of 9th January, the efforts to refloat the vessel continued, and the tugs Bart Turecamo and Annabelle Dorrothy Mo joined the effort. An investigation has been launched to determine the cause of the incident.

headline: Commercial Vessels: a new form of Hybrid Warfare?
author: Alex Stuart-Grumbar
content: On Christmas Day, the Estlink 2 power cable, a critical link between Finland and Estonia, was severed in an incident that has raised alarm across the Baltic Sea region. Just over a week later, on January 3rd, 2025, a Taiwanese communications cable was damaged in a similar fashion, this time in the Pacific. In both cases, authorities have pointed to old, Chinese-owned vessels as the primary suspects, with evidence suggesting the damage was caused by ships dragging their anchors. The events of late 2024 and early 2025 are not isolated but rather part of a larger, alarming pattern of incidents involving commercial vessels causing damage to critical undersea infrastructure. Submarine cables are critical components of global infrastructure, serving as the backbone for communication and energy transfer. They are particularly attractive targets in hybrid warfare due to their strategic importance. Submarine communication cables, handle over 95% of global internet traffic and undersea power cables play a key role in energy security, particularly in areas such as the Baltic, where countries rely heavily on cross-border power transmission. These incidents carry significant geopolitical implications, with the vessels involved linked to countries like China and Russia, both of which are expected by many commentators to be increasingly engaged in hybrid warfare tactics. The timing of these events is particularly notable from a geopolitical perspective. In the Baltic, it coincides with several Baltic states' decision to sever ties with the Russian electricity grid and integrate into the continental European energy system in February 2025. Meanwhile, Chinese Premier Xi Jinping’s New Year’s Day declaration reaffirming that China’s reunification with Taiwan is inevitable further underscores the political tensions at play. To understand the scope of this issue, here are the most prominent incidents of recent years with cable damage linked to commercial ships: Shunxing39 (3rd January 2025) The Shunxing39, a cargo ship flagged in Cameroon though owned by Jie Yang Trading Limited, a company registered in Hong Kong. The vessel is widely accused of severing a subsea communications cable part of the Trans-Pacific Express Cable System connecting Taiwan to the US west coast. Tracking data indicated the vessel dragged its anchor at the cable’s location. The vessel has since gone 'dark,' with MarineTraffic receiving no AIS signal from the vessel since the damage occurred on January 3rd. ![CleanShot 2025-01-10 at 14.58.25@2x.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Clean_Shot_2025_01_10_at_14_58_25_2x_2bd03b5b19.png) Source: Marine Traffic - The authorities now suspect that the vessel was operating under two different AIS devices and identities: its real name, Shunxing39, and a nearly identical fake name, Xingshun39. By alternating between these identities, the ship managed to create a fragmented AIS track. The Shunxing39 was out of signal at 08:49 UTC on the 3rd January, only for Xingshun39 to reappear 09.59 UTC at a location only around 10kms away. ![unnamed (1).png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/unnamed_1_ed5daf85f1.png) ![unnamed.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/unnamed_86d0612560.png) Source: MarineTraffic - the vessel Shunxing39 has been suspiciously drifting for over a month around Taiwan's north coast without loading or discharging cargo, this being far from usual for this type of vessel. **Eagle S (25th December 2024)** On Christmas Day 2024, the Eagle S, a tanker part of Russia’s ‘grey fleet*’, was detained by Finnish authorities in the Gulf of Finland. The ship is believed to have damaged both power and data cables, including the crucial Estlink 2, which links Finland and Estonia. Authorities found anchor drag marks over a distance of “dozens of kilometers” on the seafloor. ![unnamed (2).png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/unnamed_2_c5d4df65c9.png) Source: The activities of the Eagle S, have been flagged by the [Kpler’s Risk & Compliance](https://www.kpler.com/product/commodities/risk-and-compliance) tool for transporting of sanctioned cargo. **Yi Peng 3 (15th November 2024)** A month before the Eagle S incident, the Yi Peng 3, a Chinese bulk carrier, was investigated for severing two key data cables that link Sweden, Lithuania, Finland, and Germany. Investigators believe the crew deliberately dragged the ship’s anchor for approximately 100 nautical miles, cutting across vital communication and energy transmission lines. Owned by Ningbo Yipeng Shipping, the vessel had departed from Ust-Luga, Russia, carrying fertiliser. Chinese government officials refused to let a Swedish prosecutor board to inspect the vessel and question the crew with the vessel now well on the way to the Port of Fangcheng in China. ![unnamed (3).png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/unnamed_3_40ecfe0590.png) Source: Marine Traffic’s ‘Past Track’ feature shows the Yi Peng 3 already through the Suez Canal on her way to Fengcheng (ETA 29/01/2025) to discharge fertiliser cargo. **NewNew Polar Bear (25th October 2023)** In October 2023, the Chinese owned and Hong Kong flagged container ship NewNew Polar Bear was suspected of dragging its anchor across a gas pipeline and undersea cables in the Baltic. After the damage, the ship promptly continued its voyage along the Norwegian coast towards Russia's Arctic region, leaving behind a trail of damage to vital infrastructure. Chinese authorities conducted an investigation and reported the vessel did cause the damage but as a result of a strong storm. The vessel has since been trading between Russia and China. ![unnamed (4).png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/unnamed_4_292e0cd3d4.png) Source: Marine Traffic’s ‘Past Track’ feature shows the NewNew Polar Bear trading just in between Russia and China since the incident in Oct 2023. **Common Traits** The ships implicated in these incidents exhibit several recurring traits that suggest their deliberate use in hybrid operations. These vessels are typically older, ranging from 19 to 24 years, and nearing the end of their operational lifespans. These vessels are flagged under nations with lenient regulations, offering a level of oversight that makes enforcement difficult. Their ownership structures are equally concerning: three of the vessels—Shunxing39, NewNew Polar Bear, and Yi Peng 3—are tied to Chinese companies with opaque corporate setups, while the Eagle S is linked to a UAE-based firm with its registered address in a luxury Dubai hotel. These cases underscore a worrying pattern, commercial vessels seemingly being deployed for covert espionage, sabotage, and broader geopolitical ends. Finnish President Alexander Stubb remarked on the frequency of these occurrences, emphasising that they “cannot all be a coincidence or an accident.” Operationally, MarineTraffic shows these vessels behaving erratically, including extended periods of drifting, slower than usual speeds, and inconsistent routing. **Why Commercial Ships?** One major factor lies in the legal complexities surrounding maritime enforcement under international law. The United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) severely limits the ability of coastal states to act against vessels suspected of damaging undersea infrastructure. Criminal jurisdiction is restricted to cases where the offending ship is flying the flag of the coastal state or the damage is caused by one of its nationals. Beyond territorial waters, even interventions under the 1884 Paris Convention for the Protection of Submarine Cables are limited to boarding and questioning the crew, without provisions for detention or meaningful enforcement. This legal ambiguity makes old commercial ships, approaching the end of their life with opaque ownership structures, an appealing choice for hybrid warfare. Their routine presence in international waters, coupled with the difficulty of proving deliberate intent, provides a layer of plausible deniability. Furthermore, the absence of safety zones around submarine cables and pipelines in Exclusive Economic Zones (EEZs) exacerbates the issue. While some nations have experimented with domestic laws to extend protections in their EEZs, these measures remain contentious and are not universally adopted. This enforcement gap allows malicious actors to exploit the vulnerabilities of critical maritime infrastructure with minimal risk of detection or accountability. **A Wake-Up Call for Maritime Security** The detention of the Eagle S marks the first successful intervention by a Baltic Sea coastal state in response to a suspected deliberate attack on critical offshore infrastructure located beyond territorial waters. Unlike the Eagle S, the NewNew Polar Bear, Yi Peng 3, and Shunxing39 all managed to evade authorities. This highlights the stark enforcement gaps that continue to exist in the maritime domain, particularly when it comes to investigating and addressing such covert attacks on critical infrastructure. These incidents underscore a critical vulnerability in global infrastructure networks, especially undersea cables and pipelines, which are essential for energy transmission and communication. Whether due to negligence or deliberate actions, the damage caused by anchor dragging to these vital systems can lead to substantial and far-reaching disruption. The fact that these vessels, many linked to geopolitical adversaries, can operate with relative impunity—evading detection, legal action, and timely intervention—reveals deep weaknesses in both international maritime law and enforcement practices. It is clear that this growing pattern of damage poses a significant threat to national security and economic stability, signaling a pressing need for enhanced vigilance, stronger international cooperation, and more effective maritime security measures. **Tracking and Monitoring: A New Era of Detection** The rise in these incidents points to an urgent need for enhanced maritime security and international cooperation and underscores the importance of leveraging advanced fleet tracking technology combined with Risk & Compliance tools. Authorities can use AIS (Automatic Identification System) data to protect critical maritime infrastructure from emerging threats. These tools enable the creation of customisable notifications tailored to customisable areas or specific scenarios, such as unauthorised entry into sensitive zones near submarine cables or erratic vessel behaviour indicative of anchor dragging. By delivering real-time updates, these alerts provide maritime authorities or compliance teams with the actionable intelligence necessary to respond swiftly to potential risks. Beyond customisable notifications, Marine Traffic’s utility in maritime security is enhanced by Kpler’s Risk & Compliance tools. These tools allow for detailed evaluations of a vessel’s operational history, highlighting patterns of regulatory violations or affiliations with flagged entities. Such insights enable proactive risk mitigation by identifying high-risk vessels before incidents occur. The combination of AIS tracking and compliance intelligence offers an invaluable toolset for monitoring and addressing suspicious activity in a timely manner.

headline: Dockworker Strike Averted Yet Again at US Gulf and East Coast Ports
author: Raghib Raza
content: Port operators and dock workers' unions on the US East and Gulf Coasts struck a deal on 8th January, resolving a protracted labor dispute that was to lead to a strike on 15th January. The tentative agreement, which was reached after months of negotiations, is stated to have touched upon all the major demands of the dockworkers for a new six-year master contract. ![ILA.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ILA_943336c190.png)*Image credit: International Longshoremen's Association (ILA)* Specific details of the new contract have not been disclosed. However, one of the major points of contention between the International Longshoremen's Association (ILA) and the United States Maritime Alliance (USMX) was job protection from automation in ports. As a solution, a framework is being established that aims at creating more jobs while still continuing the modernization of ports. It is also anticipated that the new contract will carry over the terms of the labor wage increase that was agreed upon in the interim contract of October 2024. Both sides have agreed to temporarily operate on the current contract till all of the USMX members ratify the new contract. The new agreement is being lauded as a win-win situation that secures jobs for the ILA while supporting American consumers and businesses by ensuring the ports are capable of handling greater demand.

headline: India Announces Major Projects to Bolster Its Maritime Presence
author: Raghib Raza
content: Indian Union Minister Sarbananda Sonowal has announced significant projects that are aimed at enhancing the capacity of [KANDLA Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/269?name=KANDLA&country=India) and building a new facility for constructing Very Large Crude Carriers. The total investment in the projects is expected to be around Rs. 57,000 crores ($6.6 billion). ![India announces KANDLA PORT expansion.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KANDLA_PORT_410e6439a2.png)*KANDLA PORT, image credit: balwaNT singh* There are two key projects that were announced by the Indian government. The first is a large shipbuilding facility that is expected to build Very Large Crude Carriers with a capacity of 320,000 tonnes DWT when completed. The new facility is projected to produce 32 new vessels and repair 50 vessels per year. This new shipyard will be spread over an area of 8,000 acres and has been allotted an investment of Rs 30,000 crores ($3.5 billion). The second major project is the addition of a new terminal to the [KANDLA Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/269?name=KANDLA&country=India), which will add a capacity of 135 million tonnes per annum to the port. The new terminal will be developed outside Kandla Creek towards Tuna and will use a 6 km long waterfront. The new terminal will feature modern cargo handling equipment. This project has been allotted an investment of Rs 27,000 crores ($3.14 billion). The new initiative is expected to improve India’s maritime infrastructure and boost economic growth.

headline: Marine Fuels Supplier Monjasa Carries Out UAE’s First LNG Bunkering Operation
author: Raghib Raza
content: The marine fuel supplier Monjasa carried out the first LNG bunkering operation of the UAE and the Middle Eastern region on 4th January. Moving forward, Monjasa plans to collaborate further with authorities and expand the LNG bunkering infrastructure to better cater to the increasing number of dual-fueled vessels. ![Monjasa carried out the first LNG bunkering operation of the UAE.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/COSTA_SMERALDA_013822472f.png)*Cruise Vessel COSTA SMERALDA, image credit: Monjasa* The LNG bunkering operation was carried out by the bunker vessel [GREEN ZEEBRUGGE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4404786/mmsi:205703000/imo:9750024/vessel:GREEN_ZEEBRUGGE). Around 3,000 cubic meters of LNG were transferred from the bunker vessel to the cruise vessel [COSTA SMERALDA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6005560/mmsi:247391900/imo:9781889/vessel:COSTA_SMERALDA) at the Dubai Harbor cruise terminal B. The LNG bunker vessel [GREEN ZEEBRUGGE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4404786/mmsi:205703000/imo:9750024/vessel:GREEN_ZEEBRUGGE) was chartered by Monjasa and arrived in Dubai for the bunkering on 26th December. Following this, the vessel was inspected by the Dubai Maritime Authority & Dubai Ports Authority to ensure that the vessel, as well as the bunkering permits, were in order. Moving ahead, Monjasa plans to further expand its LNG offerings. The company has revealed their collaboration with ADNOC Logistics and Services and has chartered the [SHANDONG JUNIPER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:726661/mmsi:563574000/imo:9253222/vessel:SHANDONG_JUNIPER) from them. The [SHANDONG JUNIPER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:726661/mmsi:563574000/imo:9253222/vessel:SHANDONG_JUNIPER) is an LNG carrier that will serve as a Floating Storage Unit (FSU) for nine months starting in January.

headline: Yamna Announces Land Reservation Agreement With "Port of ACU" in Brazil for Green Ammonia Project
author: Raghib Raza
content: YamnaCo recently secured additional land at the[ PORT ACU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/19040?name=PORTO-DO-ACU&country=Brazil) for a green ammonia hub that is expected to produce around 1 million tonnes of green ammonia annually for export by 2030. ![PORT ACU.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PORT_ACU_1a1f13ed00.png)*Image credit: YamnaCo* The upcoming facility is planned to be situated within the industrial complex of the [PORT ACU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/19040?name=PORTO-DO-ACU&country=Brazil), in northeastern Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. YamnaCo had already acquired 1 square kilometer of land for the project, and with the recent agreement with the Port of Açu, it has acquired an additional 2 square kilometers. The [PORT ACU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/19040?name=PORTO-DO-ACU&country=Brazil) is a crucial hub for Brazil’s oil and gas exports and handles around 40% of the country’s oil exports. Port of Açu’s infrastructure, which includes deep-draft access and land available directly connected to the quay, was deemed to be optimal for the development of sustainable decarbonization facilities. The Green Ammonia plant aligns with the Brazilian legislative framework, which is aimed at promoting low-carbon initiatives.

headline: Bulk Carrier “Lila Incheon” Strikes Quay at Brunsbüttel Port During Berthing
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 13th February, Liberian-flagged bulk carrier [LILA INCHEON](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:689605/mmsi:636022355/imo:9571272/vessel:LILA_INCHEON#overview) allided with the quay while maneuvering to berth at the [BRUNSBUTTEL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1497?name=BRUNSBUETTEL&country=Germany) Port in Elbe River, Germany. No injuries or pollution were released in the incident. ![LILA INCHEON allided with quay at Brunsbuttel Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LILA_INCHEON_345743e283.png)*Bulk Carrier LILA INCHEON, image credit: Max Wei* According to the Brunsbuttel water police, the initial report indicated that a maneuvering error caused the bulk carrier to strike the quay, resulting in hull damage, including a hole above the waterline. However, no water ingress was reported. [LILA INCHEON](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:689605/mmsi:636022355/imo:9571272/vessel:LILA_INCHEON#overview) has been detained by the authorities for the necessary repairs and inspection to assess its seaworthiness. [LILA INCHEON](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:689605/mmsi:636022355/imo:9571272/vessel:LILA_INCHEON#overview) is a 2010-built vessel with a carrying capacity of 32,401 tonnes. It is 180.82 meters long and 30 meters wide.

headline: Navigating the Complexities of Maritime Sanctions: A January 2025 Overview
author: Dimitris Ampatzidis
content: As global sanctions frameworks continue to evolve, maritime stakeholders must adapt to the changing regulatory landscapes. This update highlights the key sanctions developments from January 2025, offering insights into emerging risks and compliance strategies. **Key Takeaways** - The **U.S. intensified sanctions on Russia and Cuba**, revoking General License 93 and issuing eight new Russia-related General Licenses (GLs), including GL 8L and GL 115A. - **A total of 183 vessels linked to Russian and Iranian oil shipments were designated**, with a focus on AIS manipulation and ship-to-ship (STS) transfers. - Russian maritime insurers **Ingosstrakh and Alfastrakhovanie were sanctioned**, along with nearly 80 entities in Russia’s LNG sector and over 30 oilfield service providers. - The **Cuba Restricted List was reinstated**, targeting entities tied to Cuba’s military and intelligence sectors. - These measures signal heightened scrutiny on maritime compliance, insurance, and shipping practices. **Market Analysis** In January 2025, U.S. sanctions policy took a decisive turn, significantly impacting maritime operations and global energy markets. The revocation of General License 93, which previously permitted transactions involving Sovcomflot vessels, underscores a strategic shift aimed at curbing Russia’s maritime influence. Concurrently, OFAC issued eight new Russia-related General Licenses, including GL 8L and GL 115A, to adjust compliance pathways ([OFAC, 2025](https://ofac.treasury.gov/recent-actions/20250110)). A total of 183 vessels, predominantly oil tankers linked to Russian and Iranian crude shipments, were designated due to their involvement in deceptive practices such as AIS manipulation and clandestine STS transfers ([U.S. Treasury, 2025](https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy2777)). This marks a clear regulatory focus on “shadow fleet” operations that have become instrumental in circumventing sanctions. Notably, Russian maritime insurers Ingosstrakh and Alfastrakhovanie were also blacklisted, intensifying risks for shipping companies reliant on these providers. This demonstrates a holistic regulatory approach, targeting not only vessels but also ownership structures, insurance providers, and smaller support vessels that facilitate operations for refineries and larger ships." The U.S. State Department expanded its sanctions scope, targeting nearly 80 entities associated with Russia’s LNG sector, including Arctic LNG 2 and officials from Rosatom ([U.S. Treasury, 2025](https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/jy2777)). Additionally, over 30 Russia-based oilfield service companies faced restrictions, directly impacting crude production and LNG export operations. The reinstatement of the Cuba Restricted List further complicates maritime logistics, particularly for entities engaged with Cuba’s military-linked enterprises ([U.S. State Department, 2025](https://www.state.gov/restoring-a-tough-u-s-cuba-policy/)). **Implications for the Shipping Industry** These sanctions impose immediate and complex challenges for maritime stakeholders. The designation of 183 vessels demands enhanced due diligence and real-time vessel tracking to mitigate the risk of inadvertent sanctions breaches. Compliance teams must swiftly update screening tools to reflect the revocation of GL 93 and adjust risk assessments for entities like Gazprom Neft, Surgutneftegas, and sanctioned insurers. Shipping companies face increased scrutiny in chartering, insurance, and supply chain operations, particularly along routes involving Russia, Iran, and Cuba. The heightened focus on deceptive shipping practices necessitates investment in advanced monitoring technologies and robust compliance frameworks. Additionally, insurers must reassess coverage policies, given the sanctions against key Russian providers, potentially leading to higher premiums and limited coverage options. ![Picture1.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture1_9d9165648e.png) **Graph 1.** _Sanctioned vessels and companies through the last five years (January 2020 to January 2025) - Kpler._ The intensification of sanctions enforcement is evident in the sharp rise in the number of sanctioned vessels and companies over the past five years. Between January 2020 and January 2025, the number of sanctioned vessels surged from approximately 380 to nearly 1,200, marking an increase of over 215%. A particularly notable acceleration occurred between mid-2022 and early 2023, where the number of sanctioned vessels jumped by roughly 200 units - a clear reflection of evolving geopolitical tensions and regulatory responses. Similarly, the number of sanctioned companies grew from around 160 in early 2020 to over 500 by January 2025, representing a 213% increase. This parallel growth in sanctioned entities underscores the expanding scope of enforcement actions, with the most pronounced spike observed in the final months of 2024, coinciding with the latest U.S. sanctions targeting Russian and Cuban-linked entities. ![Picture2.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture2_5534abee53.png) **Graph 2.** _Sanctioned vessels per top 10 flag registry through the last three years (January 2022 to January 2025) - Kpler._ The evolving sanctions landscape is clearly reflected in the growth of sanctioned vessels across the top 10 flag registries from January 2022 to January 2025. Over this three-year period, the total number of sanctioned vessels increased from approximately 180 to nearly 600, representing a staggering growth of over 230%. Russia and Iran continue to dominate the list, with Russia’s share rising sharply from around 50 vessels in early 2022 to more than 200 by January 2025, indicating a fourfold increase. Similarly, Iran’s sanctioned fleet remained consistently high, maintaining a substantial baseline throughout the period. Notably, Panama, Curacao, and Guyana have experienced significant upticks, with Panama’s sanctioned vessels growing from less than 20 in 2022 to over 80 by early 2025 - a 300% surge. Flags such as Guinea, Sao Tome and Principe, and Barbados, which had minimal presence in early 2022, show exponential increases, particularly from mid-2023 onwards. This trend suggests a regulatory pivot towards targeting vessels registered under flags of convenience—registrations in countries with lenient regulations, lower operating costs, or minimal enforcement standards, often used to obscure beneficial ownership and facilitate sanctions evasion.
