The sharpest increase occurred in the final quarter of 2024, where the total number of sanctioned vessels jumped by over 40% within just three months, underscoring the aggressive escalation in enforcement actions tied to recent geopolitical developments and regulatory shifts. ![Picture3.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture3_2352353b7b.png) **Graph 3.** _Total vessels and companies added to sanctions lists over the last twelve months (February 2024 to January 2025) - Kpler._ The enforcement momentum peaked dramatically over the last 12 months, with January 2025 alone witnessing the addition of 183 vessels and 58 companies to sanctions lists - representing month-on-month increases of 375% and 120%, respectively, compared to December 2024. This explosive growth aligns with the revocation of General License 93 and the imposition of new restrictions on Russian maritime insurers and energy-linked entities. The final quarter of 2024 also shows consistent monthly additions, averaging around 50 vessels and 20 companies, highlighting an aggressive escalation in enforcement actions. This surge underscores the need for maritime stakeholders to rapidly adapt compliance frameworks, as the sanctions landscape becomes increasingly dynamic and expansive. **Conclusion** Proactive compliance is essential in navigating the evolving sanctions landscape, where enforcement actions have surged dramatically—evidenced by a 215% increase in sanctioned vessels and over 200% growth in sanctioned companies since 2020. With regulatory focus expanding to cover deceptive shipping practices, diverse flag registries, and entities tied to high-risk jurisdictions like Russia and Iran, staying ahead requires more than reactive measures. Industry professionals must remain vigilant, continuously monitoring regulatory updates, adapting compliance frameworks, and leveraging real-time data to detect emerging risks. In this dynamic environment, informed, agile compliance strategies are not just a regulatory requirement—they are critical for safeguarding operations and maintaining business continuity. _To find out more about Kpler’s Risk & Compliance offering, visit [here](https://www.kpler.com/demos/risk-compliance-demo?utm_source=website&utm_medium=blog&utm_campaign=risk&compliance_commodities_maritime_news_demo_request)._

headline: Ocean Network Express Christened its First Owned and Operated Newbuilding Vessel
author: Raghib Raza
content: For the first time in Ocean Network Express’s (ONE) history, the company christened a newbuild vessel that they own and operate. The vessel, christened the [ONE SPARKLE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9401215/mmsi:563251300/imo:9975612/vessel:ONE_SPARKLE#overview), strengthened ONE’s competitive position in the global maritime industry along with showcasing their commitment to sustainable practices. ![ONE SPARKLE christened by ONE.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ONE_SPARKLE_db3ceb93d7.png)*Vessel ONE SPARKLE, image credit: ONE* The [ONE SPARKLE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9401215/mmsi:563251300/imo:9975612/vessel:ONE_SPARKLE#overview) was built at Hyundai Heavy Industries in Ulsan, South Korea. It features an optimized hull design for increased efficiency, cutting-edge energy-saving devices, integration of smart technology on the vessel for optimizing performance, and a shore power connection for zero emissions at ports. The vessel is a Singapore-registered container carrier that has a carrying capacity of 13,800 TEUs. The vessel is also dual-fuel compatible, being capable of operating on methanol and ammonia. This also makes the vessel future-ready as it can switch to these environmentally friendly fuels if required. The [ONE SPARKLE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9401215/mmsi:563251300/imo:9975612/vessel:ONE_SPARKLE#overview) is one of a series of 20 vessels that have been placed on order by ONE in Korea and Japan. These vessels are expected to be delivered in 2025 and 2026.

headline: Vietnam’s Most Advanced Deep-Water Port Now Operational
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Hateco Hai Phong International Container Port (HHIT), Vietnam's newest and most advanced deep-water port, has officially commenced operations, marking a major milestone in the country's maritime sector. ![MSC AURORA welcomed at HHIT Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSC_AURORA_db460bbebd.png)*Vessel MSC AURORA, image credit: HHIT* On 6th February, the port welcomed its first commercial vessel, the [ESL DUBAI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:758672/mmsi:255915745/imo:9377573/vessel:ESL_DUBAI). Following this, the [MSC AURORA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:464207/mmsi:373069000/imo:9484481/vessel:MSC_AURORA), the largest container ship to ever make a port call at[ HAI PHONG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1725?name=HAI-PHONG&country=Vietnam) Seaport, docked on 13th February. HHIT has an area of 73 hectares and features a 900-meter-long wharf with depths between -16.8 and 18.4 meters. The port can accommodate two large container vessels with lengths of up to 400 meters simultaneously. The port is equipped with cutting-edge technology, including STS cranes, a NANIS N4 operations system, e-RTG systems, Optical Character Recognition (OCR) technology, a 5G network, and surveillance cameras. The HHIT also has an automated gate system with OCR and RFID that enhances productivity and accuracy. The arrival of [MSC AURORA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:464207/mmsi:373069000/imo:9484481/vessel:MSC_AURORA) highlights HHIT's role in global trade. The vessel is part of the CHINOOK service route directly linking Vietnam with the United States and Canada.

headline: Update: US Navy Aircraft Carrier Involved in Collision with Panama-flagged Bulk Carrier
author: Raghib Raza
content: The United States Navy reported that the Nimitz-class aircraft carrier USS Harry S. Truman (CVN75) collided with Panama-flagged bulk carrier [BESIKTAS M](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:407257/mmsi:355801000/imo:9291365/vessel:BESIKTAS_M#overview). The incident occurred on 12th February, at around 11:46 PM local time, while operating in the Mediterranean Sea near the Port SAID in Egypt. ![USS Harry S. Truman collision with BESIKTAS M](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/USS_Harry_S_Truman_78d63e35a2.png)*USS Harry S. Truman, image credit: US Navy* According to the initial reports, the incident did not compromise the safety of USS Harry S. Truman. No flooding or injuries were reported. The aircraft carrier’s propulsion remained unaffected and in a stable condition. The officials have initiated an investigation into the incident. In the recent update, the US Navy released an official photo of the aircraft carrier that showcase the damage occurred in a section of the flight deck close to an aircraft elevator and an area used for observation. The US Navy has yet to released information regarding the condition of the [BESIKTAS M](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:407257/mmsi:355801000/imo:9291365/vessel:BESIKTAS_M#overview). However, a image posted on private social media account suggest that the bulk carrier sustained damage to its starboard bow and deck. The Marine Traffic data shows the vessel arrived at [PORT SAID Anchorage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/20612?name=PORT-SAID-ANCH&country=Egypt) on 13th February and departed on 14th February for [CONSTANTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/67?name=CONSTANTA&country=Romania), Romania.

headline: Canadian government Approves 35.5 million CAD Grant for Developing Shore Power Facilities
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Canadian Minister for Transport and Internal Trade announced a grant of 35.5 million CAD ($25 million) for the development of shore power facilities in the province of British Columbia in Canada. ![VANCOUVER PORT](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/VANCOUVER_PORT_54edd4a2f9.png)*VANCOUVER PORT, image credit:Graeme Waller* The funding of 35.5 million CAD overall has been provided under the Green Shipping Corridor Program, which has been founded for increasing the usage of clean energy in the infrastructure at ports and terminals. Among others, the program has the objective of investing in the establishment of shore power infrastructure in port areas to reduce emissions from idling ships. Three projects have received a total of 35.5 million CAD. First is the Greater Victoria Harbor Authority (GVHA), which will receive 22.5 million CAD to implement shore power equipment at the Ogden Point cruise terminal. The second is Seaspan Ferries, which will receive an amount of 6.14 million CAD for implementing shore power equipment at four of its terminals, namely in Delta, Nanaimo, North Saanich, and Surrey. The third and final entity to receive funding is the Vancouver Fraser Port Authority (VFPA), which will receive 6.6 million CAD for upgrading the shore power infrastructure at the Canada Place Cruise Terminal, located at the Port of [VANCOUVER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/682?name=VANCOUVER&country=Canada).

headline: Ceuta Becomes First Mediterranean Port to Deploy ISO-Certified Mass Flow Meters
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Port of [CEUTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/511?name=CEUTA&country=Spain) in Spain has announced the deployment of internationally certified mass flow meters beginning this month. The Port of [CEUTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/511?name=CEUTA&country=Spain) is the first port in the Mediterranean to opt for this technology and has further bolstered its position in the fuel supply industry. ![CEUTA PORT.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CEUTA_PORT_3c7410615b.png)*CEUTA PORT, Image credit: Sergio Gonzalez* The first and foremost benefit of deploying mass flow meters is the accurate measurement of the fuel being transferred despite varying temperatures, fuel grades, or sources. Such mass flow meters not only increase the operational productivity by streamlining the supply process; they also lead to enhancing the security and integrity of the fuel supplies as fuel transfers are automatically logged. The mass flow meters to be utilized in the port have been reported to be ISO 22192-certified, which will allow for real-time decisive measurements of fuel transfers. This, in turn, is expected to lead to fewer disputes between fuel suppliers and shipowners.

headline: CMA CGM Strengthens Green Shipping with New LNG-Powered Vessel
author: Raghib Raza
content: CMA CGM has officially named the latest addition to its fleet [CMA CGM BAALBECK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9334794/mmsi:228478900/imo:9977713/vessel:CMA_CGM_BAALBECK#overview), an 8,000 TUE Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG)- powered container ship. The addition of a containership marks a significant milestone in the company’s ongoing sustainable maritime operations. ![CMA CGM BAALBECK ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CMA_CGM_BAALBECK_e230ff4f13.png)*Containership CMA CGM BAALBECK, Image credit: CMA CGM* [CMA CGM BAALBECK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9334794/mmsi:228478900/imo:9977713/vessel:CMA_CGM_BAALBECK#overview) is sailing under the flag of France and is now set to commence operations as part of the Asia Australia Express service, enhancing connectivity and efficiency in global trade. The containership will embark on its maiden voyage on 14th February. The Marinetraffic data shows the vessel is currently moored at the [MOKPO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17605?name=MOKPO&country=Korea) Port, South Korea.

headline: Vertom Expands Fleet with Delivery of New Vessel VERTOM WILLEMIJN
author: Raghib Raza
content: International maritime services provider Vertom took delivery of the newest vessel in its fleet, the [VERTOM WILLEMIJN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9284956/mmsi:244205000/imo:9993286/vessel:VERTOM_WILLEMIJN). The vessel was delivered by the Thecla Bodewes Shipyards in Kampen, Netherlands. ![VERTOM WILLEMIJN](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/VERTOM_WILLEMIJN_c537696941.png)*Vessel VERTOM WILLEMIJN, Image credit: Vertom* The [VERTOM WILLEMIJN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9284956/mmsi:244205000/imo:9993286/vessel:VERTOM_WILLEMIJN) was launched and christened by the Thecla Bodewes Shipyards in December last year and finally joined Vertom’s fleet after completing sea trials. It is the seventh in the LABRAX series of Vertom vessels. Each of these vessels features a diesel propulsion system and four generator sets. Each of these vessels is claimed to be optimized for reducing energy consumption, greenhouse gas emissions, and maintenance costs. Each of the LABRAX class of vessels is 118.6 meters long, has a beam of 14.3 meters, and has a capacity of 329,700 cubic feet.

headline: French and Australian Authorities Bust Major Cigarette Smuggling Operation
author: Raghib Raza
content: A cargo of contraband cigarettes was seized by French customs authorities aboard the Tanzanian-flagged cargo vessel [KOKOO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:700511/mmsi:677054900/imo:9114074/vessel:JING_SHENG). The seizure was made by the Noumea Customs Authority with aid from the Australian Border Force (ABF). ![Cigarette seized aboard KOKOO.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KOKOO_fa5cc84ecc.png)*General Cargo ship KOKOO, image credit: ABF* The raid on board the [KOKOO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:700511/mmsi:677054900/imo:9114074/vessel:JING_SHENG) was conducted on 5th February when it arrived at Noumea in New Caledonia. The search by the agents yielded around 76 tonnes of contraband cigarettes retrieved from 5 containers in the vessel. The contraband has been estimated to have a value of $35 million. The Australian Border Force (ABF) has stated that the investigation and surveillance of the vessel had been ongoing for a while and that they were monitoring the suspicious route of the vessel near the Australian coast. Along with the contraband, two speedboats were also found to be stowed aboard the cargo vessel. The speedboats were found to be fitted with four 300-horsepower outboard motors. Customs authorities have clarified that this arrangement is typical for boats used in smuggling operations. Around 10,000 liters of gasoline were also found to be on the cargo vessel, presumably to fuel the speedboats. Customs agents believe that the vessel [KOKOO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:700511/mmsi:677054900/imo:9114074/vessel:JING_SHENG) probably served as a mother ship to smuggle cigarettes, with the final leg of the delivery being made using the speedboats. Authorities have also stated that the sophistication of the operation leads them to believe in the involvement of organized crime. On 7th February, the captain of the vessel was presented in a criminal court in Noumea and was sentenced to 10 months in prison and a fine of $350,000.

headline: Liberian-flagged Crude Oil Tanker Causes Fuel Spill Off Istanbul
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 11th February, Turkey’s Directorate General of Coastal Safety (KEGM) reported a fuel leakage during the bunkering operation involving crude oil tanker [JAG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:753534/mmsi:636019350/imo:9266762/vessel:JAG) and oil product tanker [GOKDENIZ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:335248/mmsi:271000903/imo:9373254/vessel:GOKDENIZ). The incident occurred at Ahırkapı Anchorage, off the coast of Istanbul. ![JAG oil spill off Istanbul coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/JAG_6a3cc3752f.png)*Crude oil tanker JAG, image credit:KEGM* During refueling, an uncontrolled fuel discharge from the Liberian-flagged crude oil tanker [JAG ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:753534/mmsi:636019350/imo:9266762/vessel:JAG)resulted in water contamination in the area. KEGM deployed multiple vessels, including KEGM-3 and KEGM-4 lifeboats, an environmental barge, and a tugboat Mehmetcik, along with a rescue specialist, to contain the marine pollution. The cleanup efforts were swiftly carried out, and the water was cleared of contamination.

headline: TUI Cruises Takes Delivery of Dual-Fueled Cruise Vessel MEIN SCHIFF RELAX in Italy
author: Raghib Raza
content: TUI Cruises welcomed the newest addition to its fleet, the [MEIN SCHIFF RELAX](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9139877/mmsi:249129000/imo:9862657/vessel:MEIN_SCHIFF_RELAX), on 7th February. The vessel was delivered by the Italian shipbuilder Fincantieri at its Monfalcone shipyard in Italy. ![MEIN SCHIFF RELAX](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MEIN_SCHIFF_RELAX_5df15bdd0c.png)*Cruise Ship MEIN SCHIFF RELAX, image credit:Fincantieri* The [MEIN SCHIFF RELAX](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9139877/mmsi:249129000/imo:9862657/vessel:MEIN_SCHIFF_RELAX) is a part of the InTUItion class that was placed on order by TUI Cruises at Fincantieri. It is reported to support dual fuel operation, being able to run on marine gas oil as well as LNG. The vessel can also take e-LNG or bio-LNG. The vessel has been designed with sustainability and operational efficiency in mind and hence has many features that reflect this. The vessel has a shore power connection, which ensures that it produces no emissions when docked, which accounts for around 40% of the vessel’s uptime. The ship is equipped with catalytic converters that are up to the Euro 6 standards and has a waste heat recovery system that can collect heat from diesel generators on board, and repurpose it. A waste treatment system on board ensures that organic waste generated aboard the vessel is converted to recyclable components through a thermal process. A sister vessel of the [MEIN SCHIFF RELAX](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9139877/mmsi:249129000/imo:9862657/vessel:MEIN_SCHIFF_RELAX) is currently under construction at Fincantieri and is to be delivered in 2026.

headline: Cargo Vessel  Runs Aground Off Norway, Sustains Damage
author: Raghib Raza
content: A global marine claims management and recovery services company reported that on 04th February, a general cargo vessel[ HAV NORDIC ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:182391/mmsi:231812000/imo:8719085/vessel:HAV_NORDIC)ran aground off Bergsoya Island, Norway. ![HAV NORDIC ran aground in Norway.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/HAV_NORDIC_f4ced6a44c.png)*Vessel HAV NORDIC, image credit: Luca Gartner* It was reported that [HAV NORDIC ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:182391/mmsi:231812000/imo:8719085/vessel:HAV_NORDIC)sustained rudder damage, experienced water ingress into the ballast tanks, and developed a port-side list. A nearby vessel remained on standby at the scene until the rescue boat arrived to assist. Later that day, [HAV NORDIC](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:182391/mmsi:231812000/imo:8719085/vessel:HAV_NORDIC) successfully refloated with the help of a rescue boat and towed it to [MJOLSTADNESET](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2750?name=MJOLSTADNESET&country=Norway), Norway. HAV NORDIC is a 1990-built vessel sailing under the flag of Faroe Is. The vessel has a carrying capacity of 3,013 tonnes, with an overall length of 74.65 meters and a width of 12.7 meters.

headline: Fire Erupts Aboard Vessel Frontenac at Fincantieri Bay Shipbuilding in Sturgeon Bay
author: Raghib Raza
content: A maritime incident involving fire occurred on 04th February aboard the vessel [FRONTENAC](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:380016/mmsi:316001834/imo:6804848/vessel:FRONTENAC) at Fincantieri Bay Shipbuilding located in Sturgeon Bay, Wisconsin, USA. ![Fire broke aboard FRONTENAC.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FRONTENAC_20918cb3d5.png)*Vessel FRONTENAC, image ctredit:doorcountydailynews.com* The incident took place while cleaning the dust container aboard the vessel. Fortunately, no injuries were reported in the incident and all the personnel were safely evacuated. Firefighters from various departments across Door County immediately responded to the incident. Minimal smoke was visible from outside, but the firefighters had to navigate through the vessel to access the source of the fire and extinguish it. After an hour of effort, the fire was successfully contained. Authorities have not disclosed the extent of any potential damage. An investigation is expected to determine the cause of the fire.

headline: Capital Ship Management Takes Delivery of Two New Cutting-Edge Vessels
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Greek shipping firm Capital Ship Management Corp announced on 4th February that they had taken delivery of two new vessels, the M/T[ AISOPOS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9289412/mmsi:241930000/imo:9987029/vessel:AISOPOS) and the M/T [AIOLOS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9309028/mmsi:241936000/imo:9987031/vessel:AIOLOS). The vessels were built by the New Times Shipbuilding in China and, following their delivery, have been registered in Greece. ![Capital Ship Management takes delivery of AISOPOS and AIOLOS](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/AISOPOS_da544fae6e.png)*Vessel AISOPOS, image credit: Capital Ship Management Corp.* The vessels are 115,621 dwt eco-type product tankers and have been bestowed with the top classification by Lloyd’s Register, namely the 100A1 notation. This notation signifies that the vessels have been held up to the highest construction and maintenance standards for enhanced safety and reliability. Lloyd’s Register has also certified the cybersecurity features of the vessel. These vessels are the first to be installed with cold ironing technology and have also been equipped with a shaft generator to improve the vessel’s efficiency and reduce emissions. The vessels are IMO Phase III compliant and can operate on LNG. In addition to these already impressive features, the vessels are also equipped with a VFD for large pumps and fans and a high-efficiency rudder.

headline: Japan-Flagged SILVER BREEZE Grounding Prompts Legal Action Against Captain
author: Raghib Raza
content: The captain of the Ro-Ro /Passenger ship [SILVER BREEZE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6634034/mmsi:431017216/imo:9919113/vessel:SILVER_BREEZE#overview) faces prosecution following its grounding in the West Harbor of Tomakomai, Hokkaido, Japan. The incident occurred on 02 July 2024; the Japan-flagged SILVER BREEZE allided with a breakwater while approaching the harbor. ![SILVER BREEZE.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SILVER_BREEZE_2fbc8b4abc.png)*Ro-Ro /Passenger ship SILVER BREEZE, image credit: KOHDA SAN* At the time, 140 passengers and crew were aboard, but no injuries and pollution were reported. However, the 8,901-ton passenger ship sustained damage to its bow. Following an investigation, the Japan Coast Guard concluded that the accident was caused by human error. The Coast Guard stated that the captain did not properly confirm the position and course of [SILVER BREEZE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6634034/mmsi:431017216/imo:9919113/vessel:SILVER_BREEZE#overview) and allegedly neglected to check the vessel’s position using radar or electronic charts. While being questioned, the captain admitted that his own mistake in steering the ship led to the accident. The Japan Coast Guard has accused the captain of [SILVER BREEZE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6634034/mmsi:431017216/imo:9919113/vessel:SILVER_BREEZE#overview) of professional negligence, citing endangerment to maritime traffic. [SILVER BREEZE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6634034/mmsi:431017216/imo:9919113/vessel:SILVER_BREEZE#overview) is a 2021-built ship with an overall length of 144.13 meters and a breadth of 23 meters.

headline: Seaspan Energy Completes their First LNG Bunkering in Canada
author: Raghib Raza
content: Seaspan Marine’s subsidiary, Seaspan Energy, has marked a major milestone by completing its first ship-to-ship LNG bunkering operation within Canada. One of Seaspan’s vessels conducted the operation on 30th January. ![SEASPAN LIONS](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SEASPAN_LIONS_dd26abc7ff.png)*SEASPAN LIONS, image credit: Seaspan Energy* The LNG bunkering operation was carried out in the Upper Harbor of the port of Vancouver by the vessel [SEASPAN LIONS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8904697/mmsi:352004315/imo:9974321/vessel:SEASPAN_LIONS#overview). The 7,861 gross ton [SEASPAN LIONS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8904697/mmsi:352004315/imo:9974321/vessel:SEASPAN_LIONS#overview) is one of two vessels within Seaspan Energy’s fleet that are set to provide LNG bunkering operations beyond the Port of[ VANCOUVER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/682?name=VANCOUVER&country=Canada). Seaspan has stated that while this is their first foray into LNG bunkering operations, they are looking to expand operations as the LNG market continues to evolve and mature. Seaspan Marie obtained their accreditation for this operation back in November of last year by the Vancouver Fraser Port Authority. With the accreditation, Seaspan Marine has been authorized to conduct ship to ship bunkering operations.

headline: Unscheduled Docking of Cargo Vessel WHITE EAGLE Sparks Fears
author: Raghib Raza
content: The cargo vessel [WHITE EAGLE ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:408100/mmsi:620999302/imo:8812930/vessel:FALCON)docked at the port of Nador, Morocco, reportedly after suffering a breakdown during navigation. The residents of the nearby towns, Beni Enzar and Melilla, have voiced their fears of the vessel possibly carrying dangerous cargo or it being related to illicit operations. ![WHITE EAGLE.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/WHITE_EAGLE_a48d2e2d03.png)*image credit:msn.com* The vessel carrying 80 containers has been attracting attention due to its unannounced presence along with the fact that the position of the vessel is not broadcasted to be in the port, leading people to conclude that the AIS signal must not be being broadcasted. Residents of the towns of Beni Enzar and Melilla, along with human rights organizations in the area, have demanded that competent authorities be responsible for providing clarifications about the sudden appearance of the vessel. Demands have also been made to confirm the safety of the region. The Grand Rif Association for Human Rights has claimed that the situation is concerning since agencies such as the National Port Agency and the Masra Maroc Company are not issuing any official communication in relation to the vessel.

headline: Ro-Ro Passenger Ship “Queen of Capilano” Involved in Collision at Bowen Island
author: Raghib Raza
content: A Canadian-flagged Ro-Ro passenger ship, [QUEEN OF CAPILANO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:379854/mmsi:316001247/imo:9008354/vessel:QUEEN_OF_CAPILANO), was involved in a collision with moored boats in the Queen Charlotte Channel on Bowen Island, Canada, on 2nd February. No injuries and pollution were reported in the incident. ![QUEEN OF CAPILANO collided with dock boats at Bowen Island Marina Dock](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/QUEEN_OF_CAPILANO_75c52d28dd.png)*Ro-Ro Passenger Ship QUEEN OF CAPILANO, image credit:nsnews.com* Shortly after departing from Bowen Island, at around 7:30 AM local time, the Ro-Ro passenger ship collided with multiple moored boats at the Bowen Island Marina Dock. The moored boats and dock structure sustained damage while the Ro-Ro passenger ship remained undamaged. [QUEEN OF CAPILANO ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:379854/mmsi:316001247/imo:9008354/vessel:QUEEN_OF_CAPILANO)continued its scheduled morning runs, completing several crossings to West Vancouver before service disruption began. The passenger ship's sailing was suspended starting at 10:15 AM local time, with service not resuming until 6:50 PM local time, resulting in the cancellation of 14 sailings. BC Ferries attributed the disruption to mechanical difficulties with the propulsion system. BC Ferries stated that it was working with the marina and vessel owners to assess damages. An investigation is ongoing into whether wind conditions, mechanical failure, or both contributed to the incident.

headline: Antigua Barbuda flagged Containership Allided at Kiel Canal Lock Amid Dense Fog
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 1st February, a containership [BERNHARD SCHEPERS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:366030/mmsi:305741000/imo:9492505/vessel:BERNHARD_SCHEPERS) traveling from [BREMERHAVEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/174?name=BREMERHAVEN&country=Germany), Germany to [KOTKA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/331?name=KOTKA&country=Finland), Finland was involved in an allision with central tail and gate niche of the new north lock of the Kiel Canal, Germany. The incident occurred while the vessel was entering the waterways eastbound transit amid dense fog. ![BERNHARD SCHEPERS allided in Kiel Canal.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BERNHARD_SCHEPERS_2d909b1109.png)*Containership BERNHARD SCHEPERS, image credit: Michael Borke* Following the allision the containership remained berthed at the lock chamber. There were no reports of injuries, damage and pollution from the vessel. However, the lock gate sustained some damage and became inoperable. Divers were promptly deployed on the same day to clear obstructions, enabling the lock gate to be closed and balanced. As a result, the Antigua Barbuda flagged vessel was able to move and continued its voyage to [KOTKA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/331?name=KOTKA&country=Finland). The new northern lock of the Kiel Canal remains closed to ship traffic and is expected to reopen on February 3 at noon. Authorities continue to assess the extent of the damage and the necessary repairs.

headline: Norwegian Oil Tanker Stuck on Rocks Near Glasøya, Safely Refloated
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 14th January, a Norway-flagged oil products tanker, [KYSTBUNKER II](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5134979/mmsi:257266000/imo:9821366/vessel:KYSTBUNKER_II#overview), ran aground near Glasøya, west of Namsos, Norway. At the time of the incident, the tanker was not transporting diesel cargo. ![KYSTBUNKER II ran aground in Norwagian water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KYSTBUNKER_II_9bb68ec2fe.png)*Vessel KYSTBUNKER II, image credit:flatangernytt.no* The vessel was en route from [RORVIK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/765?name=RORVIK&country=Norway) to [KRISTIANSUND](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/315?name=KRISTIANSUND&country=Norway), Norway when it ran aground on rocks near Glasøya. Fortunately, no damage was sustained by the tanker. The tanker remained grounded until the early morning of 15th January, when it refloated. [KYSTBUNKER II ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5134979/mmsi:257266000/imo:9821366/vessel:KYSTBUNKER_II#overview)is a 2017-built tanker with a length of 46 metres, a breadth of 10 metres, and a gross tonnage of 498.

headline: Arkas Line to Extend its Shipping Services to India
author: Raghib Raza
content: Arkas Line is set to expand its shipping services to India on 10th February this year with the beginning of the India Med Service (IMS). The new initiative is a part of the company’s efforts to improve its service offerings. ![NHAVA SHEVA PORT.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NHAVA_SHEVA_PORT_e0639f45bd.png)*NHAVA SHEVA PORT, image credit: Capt.Turboboss* The IMS Service will start with four vessels, each of which will be able to transport 2,500 to 2,800 TEUs with a weekly schedule. By June this year, an additional ship will join this service. The new service will connect the ports of [AMBARLI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17436?name=AMBARLI&country=Turkey), [EVYAP](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17802?name=EVYAP&country=Turkey), [ALIAGA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/725?name=ALIAGA&country=Turkey), [MERSIN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1687?name=MERSIN&country=Turkey), [AQABA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/3197?name=AQABA&country=Jordan), [JEDDAH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/807?name=JEDDAH&country=Saudi-Arabia), [NHAVA SHEVA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2713?name=NHAVA-SHEVA&country=India), [MUNDRA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/268?name=MUNDRA&country=India), [JEDDAH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/807?name=JEDDAH&country=Saudi-Arabia), [AQABA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/3197?name=AQABA&country=Jordan), and ALEXANDRIA. Arkas Line has stated that by targeting ports such as [MUNDRA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/268?name=MUNDRA&country=India) and [NHAVA SHEVA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2713?name=NHAVA-SHEVA&country=India), which have great rail connectivity, they will also be able to extend their services to the more inland regions of India. In order to seamlessly accommodate the new service, Arkas Line is restructuring a couple of its already existing services, such as the Great Pendulum Service (GPS), East Med Morocco Service (EMS), and Spain-East Med (SEM), to provide coverage across the Mediterranean region efficiently.

headline: Wärtsilä to Retrofit Three Vessels From Sallaum Lines for Decarbonization
author: Raghib Raza
content: Dubai-based logistics and supply chain solutions company Sallaum Lines has chosen Wartsila for supporting its decarbonization efforts and integrating advanced technology into its fleet. The retrofits will be performed on three vessels, which will enhance their performance and reduce emissions. ![Wärtsilä to Retrofit Three Vessels For Sallaum. ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Waertsilae_cd5e980bd3.png)*Image credit: Wärtsilä* The vessels[ SILVER QUEEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:758927/mmsi:352001162/imo:9427938/vessel:SILVER_QUEEN), [SILVER SKY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:712857/mmsi:352001920/imo:9448140/vessel:SILVER_SKY), and [SILVER MOON](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:712853/mmsi:353033000/imo:9448138/vessel:SILVER_MOON) are selected to be fitted with solutions. Wärtsilä will provide its EnergFlow Solution and fixed-pitch propellers for the three vessels. Together, the two retrofits are expected to improve propulsion efficiency and reduce fuel consumption. Wärtsilä took the commission to retrofit the vessels in the fourth quarter of 2024. The three vessels are each 183 meters long Pure Truck and Carriers (PCTC) capable of transporting around 4,900 cars. The PCTC vessels have been operating for around 15 years and have been chosen to keep emissions low and meet the industry’s 2050 net zero goals.

headline: "Four Plus" Tanker Seized by Venezuelan Authorities for Unauthorized Entry Under a False Flag
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 13th January, Guyana’s Department of Public Information announced that Venezuelan authorities detained the tanker [FOUR PLUS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:475472/mmsi:750101000/imo:9203930/vessel:FOUR_PLUS) for unauthorized entry into Venezuelan waters and was flying the flag of Guyana without permission. The vessel is being held for lacking the necessary permits. ![FOUR PLUS detained by Venezuela ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FOUR_PLUS_f2ba9ecb56.png)*Vessel FOUR PLUS, image credit: chun-hsi* Following the seizure, the Maritime Administration Department of Guyana reported that the tanker was not registered in Guyana and flying a false flag. The [FOUR PLUS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:475472/mmsi:750101000/imo:9203930/vessel:FOUR_PLUS) is a chemical tanker with a length of 183.2 meters, a beam of 32.2 meters, and a gross tonnage of 28,981. This case of flying a false flag is not an isolated incident; five oil tankers with ties to Syria, Iran, and Venezuela were sanctioned earlier by the US Treasury Department for false registrations. The general issue is set to be discussed, and measures to be developed against it at the 112th session of the International Maritime Organizations Legal Committee which is to be held in March this year.

headline: Traffic Resumes Across St. Mary’s River in Michigan as Grounded Cargo Ship Pulls Free
author: Raghib Raza
content: The St. Mary’s River channel had been closed off after a 497-foot cargo vessel, [HARVEST SPIRIT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:272811/mmsi:316044371/imo:9655951/vessel:HARVEST_SPIRIT#overview), ran aground following a mechanical failure on 12th January. ![HARVEST SPIRIT pulled free after running aground.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/HARVEST_SPIRIT_27e2a594f4.png)*Vessel HARVEST SPIRIT, image credit:sooleader.com* The incident occurred when the ship was traveling downstream on the St. Mary’s River on Sunday. The US Coast Guard states that the vessel ran aground at around 5:00 PM local time just off the Neebish Island Ferry Dock in Michigan. The vessel is reported to have suffered a mechanical failure and run aground, losing an anchor in the process. The vessel was carrying a cargo of canola oil and traveling from Thunder Bay to Windsor at the time of its grounding. The vessel is reported to have pulled free by itself after it regained power. At around 9:00 PM local time, the same day, the tug Wilfred M. Cohen arrived on the scene and led it to the anchorage in Mud Lake. Fortunately, no reports of injuries or pollution have been reported so far. As of 13th January, a search was being conducted for the lost anchor of the [HARVEST SPIRIT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:272811/mmsi:316044371/imo:9655951/vessel:HARVEST_SPIRIT#overview).

headline: UECC Performs First-Ever Truck-To-Ship Refueling of Biomethane in Spain
author: Raghib Raza
content: United European Car Carriers (UECC) carried out the first-ever truck-to-ship refueling of liquefied biomethane (LBM) in Spain. The event took place at the port of [VIGO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/182?name=VIGO&country=Spain), Spain and involved pumping of LBM directly from a truck to the fuel tanks of the vessel [AUTO ADVANCE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6792168/mmsi:255738000/imo:9881299/vessel:AUTO_ADVANCE#overview). ![UECC carried out the first-ever truck-to-ship refueling on vessel Auto Advance.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/UECC_a89d47bd23.png)*Image credit: UECC* The operation is a significant milestone in the widespread adoption of sustainable fuel sources in Spain. This delivery has demonstrated the viability of the approach and will allow UECC to diversify their LBM supply beyond their primary hub in Zeebrugge, Belgium, where UECC has a fuel supply agreement with Titan Clean Fuels. UECC is increasing the procurement of LBM in line with their Sail For Change initiative. The initiative involves UECC refueling five of its multi-fuel LNG Pure Car and Truck Carrier vessels with LBM. This allows for these vessels to reduce the scope 3 emissions of companies whose cars they haul.

headline: Finland Bans a Ninth Member of the Crew of the Eagle S From Leaving the Country
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 13th January, Finland placed a travel ban on a ninth member of the crew of the [EAGLE S](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:712379/mmsi:518998865/imo:9329760/vessel:EAGLE_S#overview). The EAGLE S is the vessel that has been implicated in the 25th December incident of multiple subsea cables being damaged in the Baltic Sea. ![EAGLE S ninth crew ban from traveling.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/EAGLE_S_c9cd102764.png)*Vessel EAGLE S, image credit: Hannes van Rijn* Following the incident, Finnish authorities found that the position of the [EAGLE S](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:712379/mmsi:518998865/imo:9329760/vessel:EAGLE_S#overview) coincided with the position of the subsea cable at the time of its severing. A helicopter with a police tactical team onboard was dispatched, and the vessel was ordered to divert to Finland. The vessel was then seized, its cargo arrested, and multiple crew members had travel bans placed on them. Eight of the 24 crewmembers of the vessel were already prohibited from leaving the country, and now the ban has been extended to a ninth crewmember as a part of the criminal investigation. The Finnish National Bureau of Investigation (NBI) has stated that all nine crew members have been detained for questioning. Authorities have emphasized that a travel ban is a less severe form of an arrest, which affords the suspects their immediate freedom while still allowing the authorities to keep in contact with them. The incident caused significant outages in both power and telecommunications in the Finnish infrastructure, is being suspected as sabotage. Finnish authorities have revealed that they believe that had they not redirected the vessel towards Finland at the time, the ship would have gone on to sever more cables. As of now, the Cook Islands-flagged [EAGLE S ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:712379/mmsi:518998865/imo:9329760/vessel:EAGLE_S#overview)remains detained in Finnish waters near Porvoo’s Anchorage, Finland, as law enforcement carries out their investigation.

headline: Value Maritime and ME2CC Secure Maritime Masterplan 2024 Funding for the Carbon Capture System
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Dutch-based maritime technology company Value Maritime and its partners in the Maritime Efficient and Easy Carbon Capture(ME2CC) project have announced that they have obtained funding from the Maritime Masterplan 2024 for the development and installation of a novel Carbon Capture System(CCS). The new system is planned to be installed on the LNG-powered Ro-Ro vessel [SAMSKIP KVITBJORN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1870479/mmsi:259112000/imo:9642564/vessel:SAMSKIP_KVITBJORN). ![SAMSKIP KVITBJORN.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SAMSKIP_KVITBJORN_87c80c71b0.png)*Vessel SAMSKIP KVITBJORN,image credit: Value Maritime* The new system being developed is to draw on prior successes of the group, such as the installation of a CCS on the vessel Nordica around two years ago. The end result is expected to be a CCS that has around a third of the footprint of contemporary carbon capture installations, as well as being highly modular and scalable. Announced specifications also state that the upcoming CCS will be able to use hot flue gases to generate electricity for the vessel. The carbon dioxide, thus collected by the CCS, is to be offloaded in port and transported to a land-based carbon dioxide hub. The new system is to be installed and demonstrated aboard the RO-RO vessel [SAMSKIP KVITBJORN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1870479/mmsi:259112000/imo:9642564/vessel:SAMSKIP_KVITBJORN), which travels the route from Rotterdam to Hammerfest along the Norwegian Coast.

headline: Update:Japanese-flagged Oil Product Tanker Grounded Near Esancho, Japan
author: Raghib Raza
content: A global marine claims management and recovery services company reported that on 6th January, a Japanese-flagged oil product tanker, [SANWA MARU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5729019/mmsi:431012174/imo:9847217/vessel:SANWA_MARU), ran aground. The incident occurred when the vessel was positioned east of Esancho, Japan. ![SANWA MARU ran aground.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SANWA_MARU_f8fc99dc9d.png)*Oil Product Tanker SANWA MARU,image credit: Kohda San* According to reports, initial efforts to refloat the grounded vessel did not succeed. The vessel is also reported to be carrying around 3800 tons of Kerosene as cargo and has 700 kilolitres of diesel fuel onboard. The coast guard rescued 7 of the 11 crew members onboard, the rest of them are to help clear the vessel off its grounded position. An oil slick was detected around the grounded vessel on 8th January, which extended around 1.5 miles from the ship. A substantial amount of the Kerosene and diesel fuel has been reported to have leaked from the vessel. Oil booms have been placed around the ship [SANWA MARU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5729019/mmsi:431012174/imo:9847217/vessel:SANWA_MARU#overview) , and efforts to refloat the vessel have been temporarily halted as the Coast Guard investigates the source of the leak. Salvage efforts are estimated to restart on 9th January after the source of the leak has been located. [SANWA MARU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5729019/mmsi:431012174/imo:9847217/vessel:SANWA_MARU#overview) is a 2018-built vessel with a length of 104.95 meters and a breadth of 16 meters. Marine Traffic data shows the vessel departed from [TOMAKOMAI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/21776?name=TOMAKOMAI&country=Japan), Japan, on 6th January.

headline: CMA CGM Welcomes New LNG-Powered Vessel to its Fleet
author: Raghib Raza
content: The French shipping company announced on 7th January that they had taken delivery of their newest vessel, the [CMA CGM ESCURIAL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9161272/mmsi:249237000/imo:9961374/vessel:CMA_CGM_ESCURIAL#overview). The ship is built by HD Hyundai Mipo in Ulsan, South Korea. ![CMA CGM ESCULIAR delivered to CMA CGM.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CMA_CGM_ESCULIAR_17c723c2ed.png)*Containership CMA CGM ESCULIAR, image credit: CMA CGM* The vessel departed from the Hyundai Mipo shipyard in Ulsan on 24th December and arrived at its destination in Shanghai, China, on 28th December. The ship then joined the CNC CV8 service connecting Shanghai to Ho Chi Minh, Vietnam. The [CMA CGM ESCURIAL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9161272/mmsi:249237000/imo:9961374/vessel:CMA_CGM_ESCURIAL#overview) is the 10th and last vessel in its series. All of these vessels are 204.29 meters in length and 29.6 meters in width and have a capacity of around 2000 TEUs. The vessels are reported to have improved hydrodynamic performance, and their design helps reduce fuel consumption by 15%. The series of vessels has been designed by the French shipbuilder Chantiers de l’Atlantique in collaboration with the Danish engineering firm Odense Marine Technique and the French containment systems company GTT. The [CMA CGM ESCURIAL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9161272/mmsi:249237000/imo:9961374/vessel:CMA_CGM_ESCURIAL#overview) is one of the several new ships that are being integrated into CMA CGM’s fleet. The effort is aimed at modernizing the fleet, enhancing efficiency, and ultimately reaching the company’s goal of net zero emissions by 2050.

headline: Seaboard Marine Officially Announces the Name of its Newest Vessel
author: Raghib Raza
content: Seaboard Marine announced the name of its upcoming LNG-powered vessel, the [SEABOARD VERDE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9325500/mmsi:636024823/imo:9964417/vessel:SEABOARD_VERDE). The vessel is to be delivered next month and will be the third LNG-powered vessel in Seaboard Marine’s fleet. ![SEABOARD VERDE.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SEABOARD_VERDE_300d8accf3.png)*Vessel SEABOARD VERDE, image crredit: Seaboard Marine* The Seaboard Verde is one of eight vessels that are to join Seaboard Marine’s fleet by the end of 2025. Like its sister ships of the V-Class, the Seaboard Verde will be 248 meters long and 36 meters wide. It will have 3,500 TEUs of cargo capacity and 1,000 refrigerated container plugs for the transportation of perishable cargo. Upon delivery, the Seaboard Verde will operate on key routes connecting ports in [MOIN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2991?name=MOIN&country=Costa-Rica), Costa Rica, COLON, Panama, [KINGSTON](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1430?name=KINGSTON&country=Jamaica), Jamaica, [SANTO DOMINGO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2430?name=SANTO-DOMINGO&country=Dominican-Republic), Dominican Republic, [PHILADELPHIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2817?name=PHILADELPHIA&country=USA), and [BROOKLYN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/16944?name=BROOKLYN&country=USA). The rotation in these key ports is expected to further strengthen Seaboard Marine’s logistics across the Americas.

headline: Port of Prince Rupert Welcomes Wolverine Terminals’ Marine Bunkering Services
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Port of [PRINCE RUPERT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2512?name=PRINCE-RUPERT&country=Canada) on the west coast of Canada recently welcomed Wolverine Terminals’ marine bunkering services. This new service utilizes two specially designed barges namely Wolverine Spirit 1 and Wolverine Spirit 2 for fuel delivery and will prove to be a boon for vessels arriving at the deepwater port. ![Port of Prince Rupert Welcomes Wolverine Terminals Marine Bunkering Services.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Port_of_PRINCE_RUPERT_569ea07046.png)*Port PRINCE RUPERT, image credit:Robert Allan Ltd.* These two barges are designed by Robert Allan Ltd. and are Transport Canada regulations and IMO Tier III compliant. The barges are well suited to deliver a variety of fuels, including diesel, heavy, and intermediate, among others, to deep-sea ships. Both barges feature a double hull, cargo handling capabilities such as cranes, equipment for spill prevention and recovery, and a shore power connection. The Port of [PRINCE RUPERT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2512?name=PRINCE-RUPERT&country=Canada) is also well connected via rail to source domestically produced fuels. The new bunkering service at the port will allow deep-sea-going vessels to refuel at this increasingly popular gateway to North America. The vessels need not head to Vancouver or carry extra fuel, allowing for larger vessels to save costs.

headline: Four Injured Crew Members Evacuated From the Bulk Carrier as Fire Breaks Out Aboard
author: Raghib Raza
content: Four crewmembers were rescued from the bulk carrier[ PANORIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:213733/mmsi:538008112/imo:9480930/vessel:PANORIA) as it caught fire off the coast of Taiwan on 4th January. The vessel has lost power and is being towed to the Port of [KAOHSIUNG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/190?name=KAOHSIUNG&country=Taiwan). ![Fire aboard PANORIA. ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PANORIA_d429952bff.png)*Vessel PANORIA,image credit: Andreas Muhl* A fire broke out inside the engine room of the vessel, causing it to lose power and drift. The crew of 21 aboard the vessel managed to extinguish the fire, but four of them suffered burns in the process. One of the crewmembers was grievously injured and suffered serious burns. The Coast Guard Administration (CGA) of Taiwan received the distress signal from the vessel at 5:00 PM local time in the evening on 4th January. At the time, the vessel was situated around 23 nautical miles off of Cape Eluanbi, the southernmost point of Taiwan. The CGA then promptly dispatched five vessels to rescue all crewmembers onboard. However, due to 3-4 meter high waves prevailing at the time, the injured crew members could not be rescued via a ship-to-ship transfer. A helicopter from the Ministry of National Defence arrived at the vessel’s location at around 7:00 PM local time and, airlifted the four injured crewmembers and dropped them off at the Kaohsiung airport. These crewmembers were then rushed to a nearby hospital for medical attention. The St. Kitts and Nevis-flagged tugboat, Salvage Rigger, headed to the distressed vessel at 8:00 AM local time on 5th January, and it is expected to arrive at the Port of Kaohsiung with the [PANORIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:213733/mmsi:538008112/imo:9480930/vessel:PANORIA) in tow by 6th January.

headline: Bulk Carrier Propel Fortune’s Release Allowed by Indian Court Contingent on Clearing Outstanding Dues
author: Raghib Raza
content: A court in Odisha, India, ordered the release of the Singapore-flagged bulk carrier [PROPEL FORTUNE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:465105/mmsi:563142300/imo:9500699/vessel:PROPEL_FORTUNE#overview), provided that the vessel clears outstanding dues for provisions and services at the [PARADIP PORT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17379?name=PARADIP&country=India). The vessel departed the port on 31st December after clearing its dues. ![PROPEL FORTUNE](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PROPEL_FORTUNE_21dceeabe6.png)*Vessel PROPEL FORTUNE,image credit: SSR* The vessel was arrested at the Paradip Port on 30th December 2024 at the order of the Odisha High Court as the vessel was preparing to leave. A claim was made by the ship Chandler MH Bland SL, which stated that the vessel had failed to pay dues amounting to Rs. 15,56,100 ($18,143) for supplies and provisions provided to the vessel. Despite the vessel's arrest on the 30th, they released it the next day, subject to the vessel clearing its dues. The amount is to be held by the court in an interest-bearing account till a final resolution for the litigation is reached. If the judgment goes in the favor of MH Bland SL, they would receive the amount with interest; if not, the funds would be returned to the Propel Fortune. The case is set to be reviewed further on 6th January.

headline: Fire Aboard the Ro-Ro Vessel in Denmark Claimed One Life And Two Injured
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire broke out aboard the Ro-Ro cargo vessel [GLYVURSNES](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6046/mmsi:231887000/imo:9198977/vessel:GLYVURSNES) on 02nd January while it was docked at Port of [HIRTSHAL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/553?name=HIRTSHALS&country=Denmark), Denmark. ![Fire aboard the vessel GLYVURSNES ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GLYVURSNES_b817be41af.png)*Vessel GLYVURSNES, image credit:nordjyske.dk* At around 10:02 PM (CET), a fire broke in the engine room of the vessel, causing heavy smoke, that prompted an hour-long firefighting effort by North Jutland Emergency Services to bring it under control. Tragically, a 34-year-old crew member lost his life in the incident. A 47-year-old crewmember sustained severe burns and was transferred to the hospital in Copenhagen, where he was reported to be in critical condition. A third crew member, aged 19, suffered smoke inhalation and was later in stable condition. The Police Chief of North Jutland stated that the families of the deceased and the injured have been informed. The next day, on 03rd January, the police and fire technicians were at the port and collaborated with the Danish Maritime Authority to investigate the fire incident and its cause. The Danish Maritime Authority boarded and detained the vessel for conducting inspections to assess the extent of damage and determine whether the vessel's seaworthiness had been compromised. The authorities are working closely with the Faroese Maritime Authority, as the ship is registered under their flag. The timeline for the investigations and conclusions remains unclear.

headline: Dangerous Cargo of Thousands of Tons of Explosives Arrives in Africa After Multiple Controversies
author: Raghib Raza
content: A cargo of around 20,000 tons of explosives arrived in Africa after multiple controversies during its journey. The cargo, which shipped from the Russian port of Kandalaksha on 22nd August, arrived in January. ![RUBY ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RUBY_aa237f4b05.png)*Vessel RUBY, image credit: Malcolm Cranfield* The dangerous cargo was initially loaded on the vessel [RUBY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1605/mmsi:229041000/imo:9626390/vessel:RUBY#overview), which unfortunately ran aground due to inclement weather, causing damage to the vessel’s hull and propeller. The vessel, however, was still able to sail and arrived for repairs at the port of Tromso, where it caused the first controversy due to the sheer amount of explosives that was onboard the vessel. Ammonium nitrate is the same chemical that was the cause of the infamous Beirut explosion in 2020. For context, the Beirut explosion, which is considered to be the largest non-nuclear blast in history, was caused by around 2,750 tons of ammonium nitrate, which is a fraction of the cargo of 20,000 tons being hauled on the [RUBY]( https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1605/mmsi:229041000/imo:9626390/vessel:RUBY#overview). The vessel was sent away and subsequently denied entry to ports in Norway, Lithuania, and Sweden due to the dangerous nature of its cargo. A shipyard in Lithuania was supposed to offer repairs to the vessel, but the authorities prohibited it from entering until the explosive cargo was removed. Later, the vessel was allowed to dock at the port of Great Yarmouth in the UK. While the vessel was docked in the UK, the ammonium nitrate aboard the vessel was reported to be contaminated with the ship’s fuel and seawater due to the grounding of the vessel. Thus decreasing the stability of the explosive and making it more dangerous. This contaminated cargo, which weighed around 300 tons, was then dumped into the ocean after discussions with relevant authorities in the UK at a site that offered the lowest possible environmental impact. This sparked local outrage and environmental concerns. The remaining cargo was then transferred to another vessel, the [ZIMRIDA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:458238/mmsi:314458000/imo:9380817/vessel:ZIMRIDA). [ZIMRIDA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:458238/mmsi:314458000/imo:9380817/vessel:ZIMRIDA) departed the port of Great Yarmouth for Africa on 16th December and arrived at ABIDJAN Anchorage destination on 30th December, marking an end to the panic.

headline: Vietnamese Navy Rescues Drifting Tanker in Rough Seas
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Vietnamese navy rescued the tanker [PETROLIMEX 11](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:736667/mmsi:574133000/imo:9359636/vessel:PETROLIMEX_11) on 2nd January as it was drifting uncontrollably off the coast of Khanh Hoa and towed it to safety. ![PETROLIMEX 11 adrifted in rough sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PETROLIMEX_11_bc2254f246.png)*Vessel PETROLIMEX 11, image credit:vietnamnet.vn* The vessel is reported to have suffered engine failure on 1st January while it was traveling around 20 nautical miles off of Cam Ranh Bay. This rendered the ship inoperable and caused it to drift uncontrollably. The captain of [PETROLIMEX 11](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:736667/mmsi:574133000/imo:9359636/vessel:PETROLIMEX_11) issued a distress signal seeking assistance and stated that 25 crewmembers were on board. On 2nd January, despite the challenging weather, consisting of 6 to 7 meter waves, the naval crew managed to reach the adrift vessel after several hours of attempts. Immediately upon arrival, the crew of the adrift vessel was provided with medical attention, and a towing line was established. Following this, the vessel was towed to safety at an anchorage in the Tuy Phong district of the Binh Thuan Province. The rescue mission lasted over 12 hours.

headline: Crew Member Goes Missing From Bulk Carrier While en Route to Australia
author: Raghib Raza
content: A crew member of the bulk carrier [RTM ZHENG HE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:729003/mmsi:564814000/imo:9591337/vessel:RTM_ZHENG_HE) was reported missing on 26th December as the vessel was travelling from China to Western Australia. ![RTM ZHENG HE crew missing.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RTM_ZHENG_HE_acfabe17de.png)*Vessel RTM ZHENG HE, image credit: MIHAI VARAREANU* The crewmember, a 44-year-old deck fitter, was reported missing when the vessel was near the waters of the Philippines. Following his disappearance, an extensive search and rescue effort has been launched by the Philippine Coast Guard, which has been ongoing over the week. The ship’s charterer, Rio Tinto, stated that it was conducting its own investigations as well as collaborating with the ship’s owner, Anglo Eastern, and relevant authorities for locating the missing seafarer. The search efforts have so far proven unsuccessful, and the missing person has not yet been located.

headline: Two Bulk Carriers Collide on the Yangtze River in China
author: Raghib Raza
content: A collision occurred among two bulk carriers on the Yangtze River in China on 30th December 2024. The vessels, namely the Singapore-flagged [YANGZE 22](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7458148/mmsi:563230200/imo:9958212/vessel:YANGZE_22) and the Japanese-flagged [VEGA DREAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:665445/mmsi:431860000/imo:9532094/vessel:VEGA_DREAM), collided, but fortunately, no crewmembers aboard either vessel were injured. ![YANGZE 22 collided with VEGA DREAM.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/YANGZE_22_9bc66582b6.png)*Vessel YANGZE 22, image credit: Len Weigh* The incident occurred at 10:00 PM (SGT) at night, according to the Maritime Port Authority of Singapore (MPA). Out of the two vessels, the [YANGZE 22](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7458148/mmsi:563230200/imo:9958212/vessel:YANGZE_22) suffered more severe damage, reporting to have spilled around 9 tons of fuel oil due to hull damage. As of now, the [YANGZE 22](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7458148/mmsi:563230200/imo:9958212/vessel:YANGZE_22) is at the Hengsha East Anchorage for a more thorough assessment. Fortunately, both vessels were stable post-collision, and no injuries were reported on the crew of either vessel. The Shanghai Maritime Safety Administration (MSA) has informed the Singapore MPA that the situation is well under control and that the Shanghai MSA’s vessels, along with those belonging to the ship management of the [YANGZE 22](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7458148/mmsi:563230200/imo:9958212/vessel:YANGZE_22), are currently cleaning up the oil spill.

headline: Eagle S Commercial Vessel Held by Finland, Suspected of Sabotaging the Estlink 2 Power Cable and Baltic Sea Communication Cables
author: Alex Stuart-Grumbar
content:
![image1.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image1_ca343704fe.png) On 25 December, 2024, a significant disruption occurred when the Estlink 2 power cable, a crucial link between Finland and Estonia, was severely damaged. Finnish authorities have classified the incident as a suspected case of "aggravated criminal mischief" and authorities estimate the cable may take up to seven months to repair. The investigation into the incident centers on the [Eagle S](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:712379/mmsi:518998865/imo:9329760/vessel:EAGLE_S), a commercial shipping vessel. Authorities suspect the Eagle S caused the damage by dragging its anchor along the seabed. The Eagle S has been detained by Finnish police and coast guard officials, escorted by the Finnish Border Guard’s patrol vessel Turva, and is now anchored 20km off Porkkalaniemi in Finnish territorial waters with a 3-kilometre no-fly zone imposed. This incident raises concerns over the growing use of commercial vessels for sabotage and espionage.

**Location of the Estlink2 power cable** ![image2.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image2_ccc06f9449.png) Source: [Wikipedia and OpenStreetMap](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Estlink#/map/1)

The investigation suggests that the Eagle S (IMO 9329760) played a critical role in the sabotage of the Estlink 2 power cable, given its suspicious movements before and after the damage occurred. Below is the timeline of the vessel’s actions: 10:16-11:10 UTC: Eagle S slows from 10.3 knots to 7.6 knots, a significantly slower speed than typical for this type of vessel in these weather conditions. 11:10-12:34 UTC: The vessel further decelerates and begins to drift, indicating potential issues or intentional disruption. Investigators have identified a "dragging track" thought to have been made by the anchor which detectives say is ‘’dozens of kilometers in length’’, which matches with the distance the ship travelled at speeds well below the usual minimum economical sailing speed. **Eagle S movements 25 December 2024** ![image3.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image3_5319b376df.png) !Source: MarineTraffic - shows the track the vessel took as she slowed down around the area where the underwater cables lie.!

The Eagle S is owned and operated by Caravella LLCFZ, a UAE-based company, whose office is in a business centre of a luxury hotel in Dubai, and is registered in the Cook Islands. The ship has a Deadweight Tonnage (DWT) of 74,034 and a Length Overall (LOA) of 228.6 meters. It was previously named NORSTAR INTREPID before being renamed on 22 July, 2023. In 2024, the vessel only transported Russian cargoes including gas oil, naphtha and gasoline. The Kpler terminal shows that on her current voyage she was carrying gas oil and naphtha from Ust Luga and St. Petersburg, with the vessel due to discharge in India.

**Ship-to-Ship (STS) Transfers**

Over the past 24 months, Kpler data shows the Eagle S has been involved in several high-risk STS transfers at locations including Malta Lightering area and Augusta Lightering area (see chart.) In 2024 the Eagle S only transported Russian cargoes, and has been identified as part of the Russian ‘grey fleet,’ a group of vessels reportedly used by Russia to evade shipping sanctions through deceptive practices.. Notable transfers include: **Operational risks for the Eagle S as shown in the Kpler Risk & Compliance interface** ![image4.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image4_13f18f50b8.png) Source: [Kpler Risk &Compliance tool ](https://terminal.kpler.com/map/vessel/76238/compliance)

**Sanction Risks**

The Eagle S has been involved in transporting Russian-origin goods, including gasoil, clean products, and Ultra-Low Sulfur Diesel (ULSD) from sanctioned ports such as Ust Luga, Primorsk, and Vysotsk. These activities have been flagged by the Kpler R&C tool, with significant concern raised by OFAC and the EU for potential sanction violations.
