headline: CMA CGM Unveils the LNG-Powered “Adventure,” Expands Eco-Friendly Fleet
author: Raghib Raza
content: CMA CGM officially unveiled its latest LNG-powered container ship, [CMA CGM ADVENTURE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9194183/mmsi:249210000/imo:9951575/vessel:CMA_CGM_ADVENTURE), in a naming ceremony held in South Korea. The vessel is built by the Samsung Heavy Industries Shipyard (SHI) Geoje in South Korea. ![CMA CGM ADVENTURE.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CMA_CGM_ADVENTURE_df426d39b4.png)*Containership CMA CGM ADVENTURE, image credit: CMA CGM* The [CMA CGM ADVENTURE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9194183/mmsi:249210000/imo:9951575/vessel:CMA_CGM_ADVENTURE), an 85,000 dwt container ship, is the ninth in the series of ten ships in its class. The new vessel will join CMA CGM’s LNG fleet and will operate as a part of the Chesapeake Bay Express (CBX) service, facilitating trade between Asia and North America. In November, CMA CGM took delivery of 7300 TEUs of LNG-powered [CMA CGM FORT DIAMANT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9128831/mmsi:228469700/imo:9966776/vessel:CMA_CGM_FORT_DIAMANT) from SHI. On 16th December, [FORT DIAMANT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9128831/mmsi:228469700/imo:9966776/vessel:CMA_CGM_FORT_DIAMANT) made its maiden call at the [NHAVA SHEVA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2713?name=NHAVA-SHEVA&country=India) Free Port Terminal (NSFT) in India, becoming the very first LNG-powered vessel to dock at this port.

headline: Third Aging Russian Tanker Damaged in the Black Sea
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Russian tanker [VOLGONEFT 109](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:350446/mmsi:273442960/imo:8230651/vessel:VOLGONEFT_109) suffered damage to the cargo tank. The [VOLGONEFT 109](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:350446/mmsi:273442960/imo:8230651/vessel:VOLGONEFT_109) issued a distress signal on 17th December when it was situated off the Taman peninsula, Russia. ![VOLGONEFT 109 damaged in Black sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/VOLGONEFT_109_95ceb5b231.png)*Vessel VOLGONEFT 109, image credit: Anatoly Rudkov* The vessel had a crew of 14, and fortunately, no injuries have been reported. The captain has reportedly refused evacuation and requested a different berth for the vessel. Russian federal shipping agency Rosmorrechflot has claimed that the vessel has suffered damage to its cargo tank, but the integrity of the hull has not been compromised; therefore, no leakage into the sea has occurred. Meanwhile, the fallout of the oil spill from the [VOLGONEFT 212](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:347163/mmsi:273333930/imo:0/vessel:VOLGONEFT_212), a tanker with a similar age that broke in half off the coast of Crimea on 15th December is already beginning to be felt. Emergency declarations have been made in several of the coastal areas, with reports of spilled oil washing ashore along tens of kilometers.

headline: Anemoi Marine Technologies Performs Its Largest Rotor Sail Installation on SOHAR MAX
author: Raghib Raza
content: Anemoi Marine Technologies has installed rotor sails on the 400,000 dwt Very Large Ore Carrier(VLOC) [SOHAR MAX](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:714025/mmsi:538004888/imo:9565065/vessel:SOHAR_MAX), the largest vessel yet to have rotor sails fitted. ![SOHAR MAX retrofited with rotor sail](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SOHAR_MAX_2a5b0f8864.png)*Vessel SOHAR MAX, image credit: Anemoi* The retrofit of the vessel was performed at the Cosco Zhoushan Shipyard in China and was completed in October this year. The retrofit is a joint effort by the shipowner Asyad, the charter Vale, and Anemoi Marine Technologies, a wind propulsion specialist. The massive sails are 35 metres high and 5 metres in diameter. The installation of these sails is expected to provide significant reductions in the vessel’s fuel consumption. According to estimates, the vessel is expected to consume 6% less fuel and reduce its carbon emissions by 3,000 tons per year. The[ SOHAR MAX](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:714025/mmsi:538004888/imo:9565065/vessel:SOHAR_MAX) is a 2012 VLOC registered in the Marshall Islands and built at the Rongsheng Shipyard in China. The vessel is 360 meters long and 65 meters wide and is primarily used for hauling iron ore. Brazilian mining giant Vale has announced the retrofit of another of its vessels with rotor sails. The vessel, VLOC [NSU TUBARAO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6414858/mmsi:636020134/imo:9848194/vessel:NSU_TUBARAO), will have its retrofit completed by September 2025.

headline: Patterns of Risky Shipping Activity Amid EU 15th Sanctions Package
author: Dimitris Ampatzidis
content: **Overview** On **December 16th, 2024**, the European Union published its 15th package of sanctions ([EU](https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/PDF/?uri=OJ:L_202403192)), with enforcement starting on December 17th. A key provision of this package targets **52 vessels** identified for breaching or circumventing sanctions, particularly through the transportation of restricted cargo such as crude oil and refined petroleum products. This move reflects the EU’s intensified efforts to address illicit maritime activities and uphold international compliance standards. By utilising advanced satellite imagery, artificial intelligence, and human intelligence, we have identified critical trends in how vessel operators exploit AIS systems, capitalise on operational gaps, and conduct covert cargo transfers to obscure their movements. Current data highlights persistent risks in key zones such as Ust-Luga, Primorsk, and Nakhodka, which are primary sources of restricted cargo. ![Image 17-12-24 at 1.59 PM.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Image_17_12_24_at_1_59_PM_2a14f10c48.jpg) **Image 1.** _Positions of the EU sanctioned vessels as of 17th of December, 2024 12.00 UTC - Kpler._ **Cargo Movements Linked to Sanctioned Zones** Analysis of multiple vessels revealed recurring patterns linking cargo movements to high risk ports. This includes the transport of crude oil, fuel oil, and gasoil from Russian ports such as Ust-Luga, Primorsk, and Nakhodka. Key Observations: - Urals crude and fuel oil frequently feature in cargo reports, aligning with sanctions from OFAC, OFSI, and the EU. - Extended voyages flagged for risk detection between July and October 2024 often involved high-value commodities, including LNG and ESPO crude. **Dark Ship-to-Ship Transfers** Dark STS transfers—conducted with AIS systems deliberately disabled—remain a significant area of concern. Using satellite imagery, AI, and human intelligence, we identified notable instances of such clandestine activity: - **Mianzimu**: Detected engaging in a dark STS transfer with the vessel Koala on June 1, 2024, in the Ukrainian EEZ. - **Pioneer**: Demonstrated prolonged AIS gaps and dark STS events which attracted our interest previously ([Kpler LinkedIn post](https://www.linkedin.com/posts/kpler_lng-kpler-activity-7233789053966458880-_hsd?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_desktop); [Seven LNG tankers caught in a new wave of US sanctions](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/maritime-news/16/general/2024/11445/seven-lng-tankers-caught-in-a-new-wave-of-us-sanctions); [US sanctions two LNG vessels, ratcheting up pressure on Russia’s Arctiv LNG 2 project](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/maritime-news/15/maritime-security/2024/11473/us-sanctions-two-lng-vessels-ratcheting-up-pressure-on-russi)). - **Alissa** and **Christophe De Margerie** displayed high-risk transfer patterns, such as AIS gaps and STS transfers, in regions like Kalamata, Kerch, and Murmansk. **AIS Spoofing: Masking Real Movements** AIS spoofing, a tactic involving the falsification of vessel locations, was detected through satellite monitoring and machine learning: - **Pioneer**: Noted for spoofing events between Egypt and the Barents Sea, likely to obscure actual cargo origins. - **Georgy Maslov** and **Siri**: Spoofing events, paired with suspicious draught changes, suggest deliberate efforts to avoid detection during high-risk or dark STS operations. **AIS Gaps as a Risk Indicator** Persistent AIS signal gaps often coincide with operations in sensitive zones: - **Duration**: Gaps ranged from one day to over two years, as observed with vessels such as Pioneer and Alissa. - **Notable Areas**: 1. **Oman to India**: Draught reductions during these gaps indicate unloading activities. 2. **Ukraine**: Notable draught shifts align with STS transfer activities. **Conclusion** Patterns of cargo flows, dark STS transfers, and AIS spoofing illustrate increasingly sophisticated methods for sanctions evasion. Leveraging satellite imagery, AI, and human intelligence, we are now better equipped to track and analyse these anomalies. However, the ongoing evolution of these tactics underscores the need for heightened vigilance and advanced detection tools. Stay tuned for more insights and updates, ensuring that you remain informed and compliant amidst these dynamic regulatory changes. Learn more at: [Kpler Risk & Compliance](https://www.kpler.com/product/commodities/risk-and-compliance). **Sanctioned vessels as of 17th of December** - 9299666 - 9256602 - 9273052 - 9323376 - 9737187 - 9413547 - 9296391 - 9274331 - 9274343 - 9385233 - 9826902 - 9511533 - 9341081 - 9306794 - 9292204 - 9299692 - 9413561 - 9333424 - 9412347 - 9610781 - 9299898 - 9422445 - 9421972 - 9265756 - 9271585 - 9842188 - 9511521 - 9412335 - 9316127 - 9327372 - 9436941 - 9849887 - 9276030 - 9610793 - 9577082 - 9577094 - 9522324 - 9382798 - 9354301 - 9354313 - 9235713 - 9321847 - 9513139 - 9321976 - 9291250 - 9866380 - 9341079 - 9281683 - 9953535 - 9953523 - 9953509 - 9953511

headline: EU Sanctions 52 New Vessels of Russia’s “Shadow Fleet” in Its 15th Sanctions Package
author: Raghib Raza
content: The European Union adopted its newest sanctions package on 16th December at the Foreign Affairs Council meeting. The new package adds 52 new vessels to the sanctions list that have been deemed by the EU to be supporting Russia’s war machine. ![MIANZIMU](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MIANZIMU_019f21ba16.png)*Vessel MIANZIMU, image credit: Dursun Cam* The vessels that have been sanctioned are primarily involved in circumventing the oil price cap mechanism implemented by the West, in arms deliveries, and in the transportation of stolen grain. This latest package has brought the total number of vessels sanctioned by the EU to 79. The majority of these tankers are non-EU vessels that are involved in the transport of Russian oil and in transporting arms for the Russian military. The sanctions package also targets a total of 54 individuals and 30 entities that are deemed to be bolstering Russia’s war effort. Among them, there are also entities and individuals in China and North Korea who have been deemed to be supplying Russia with dual-use materials to support Russia’s military efforts. Two senior North Korean officials and seven Chinese individuals and companies have been targeted in the latest sanctions. The purpose of the sanctions has been defined to increase the operational costs for Russia by banning them from ports in the EU and hindering them from receiving maritime services. headline: Fire Breaks Out on the Passenger Vessel “Thurgau Gold” in the Rhine
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire broke out on the passenger vessel [THURGAU GOLD](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7850690/mmsi:269057854/imo:0/vessel:THURGAU_GOLD#overview) on 16th December as it was travelling on the Rhine near the city of Speyer in Germany. No reports of injuries have been reported for the crew or the passengers. ![Fire aboard Thurgau Gold](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/THURGAU_GOLD_54ac1d0216.png)*Ferry THURGAU GOLD, image credit:swr.de* The incident happened at 3:40 AM (CET) when the fire broke out in the engine room of the vessel. The fire led to significant production of smoke, and emergency services were quickly alerted to the fire. By 6:00 AM, the firefighters and the water police brought the fire under control, but they did not fully extinguish it. However, the situation was resolved with intense efforts from the firefighters with measures such as cooling the hull from the outside due to the intense heat. The fire alarm and the emergency systems aboard the vessel worked without a hitch, and all 149 passengers and 42 crewmembers were evacuated successfully. Buses were arranged for the passengers for their return journey, and they departed by around 10:00 AM. The cause of the fire is yet unknown, and an investigation has been opened into the matter.

headline: Oil Spill Occurs at Bonny Terminal in Nigeria
author: Raghib Raza
content: An oil spill has reportedly occurred at a terminal in Nigeria. The site of the spill is a Shell Petroleum Development Company (SPDC) loading terminal situated in Bonny, Nigeria. The spill has been attributed to a ruptured pipeline. ![BONNY PORT.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BONNY_PORT_61c5d2e2c8.png)*BONNY PORT, image credit: NNPC NIGERIA* The Nigerian Maritime Administration and Safety Agency (NIMASA) reported that the oil spill occurred on 15th December, and as of the latest update, the oil has reached the shoreline. SPDC clarified that the incident at the Bonny Oil Export terminal will not affect their oil exports and stated that only one section of the three loading buoys had been isolated. SPDC has also stated that they are investigating the cause of the incident and the volume of oil that had been discharged. NIMASA has established an emergency operations center to closely monitor the situation and is closely collaborating with SPDC and other stakeholders to mitigate any potential harm and contain the spill as soon as possible.

headline: Five Dead and Dozens Still Missing at Sea in Migrant Crisis off of Greece
author: Raghib Raza
content: In four separate rescue operations conducted near Greece, around 200 migrants have been rescued, five have been found dead, and around 40 are still missing. ![BRITISH ACHIEVER and other three vessels help in rescuing migrants off Greece.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BRITISH_ACHIEVER_384c99fb4c.png)*Vessel BRITISH ACHIEVER, image credit: Hartmut Knape* The four operations were started on 13th December, and one of them is still ongoing, according to the Coast Guard. One of the rescues took place near the Greek island of Gavdos, where a boat carrying refugees sank. Thirty-nine people were rescued by the vessel [MITO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:362070/mmsi:255806508/imo:9319571/vessel:MITO#overview) in difficult weather conditions around 12 nautical miles south-west of Gavdos. Five bodies were also recovered from the sea, and by survivors’ accounts, around 40 people are still missing. Another incident involved the [BRITISH ACHIEVER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5688251/mmsi:232006300/imo:9766542/vessel:BRITISH_ACHIEVER#overview) rescuing 89 people around 28 nautical miles south off the island of Gavdos. A bit farther still, the vessel [SEABEE ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:553112/mmsi:256313000/imo:9698941/vessel:SEABEE)rescued 47 migrants around 40 nautical miles off Gavdos. And finally, the vessel [BLUE CIMENT 4](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:122525/mmsi:636020079/imo:9577288/vessel:BLUE_CIMENT_4) rescued 28 people from a boat 6 miles off Cape Tainaron, in the Greek mainland. The Coast Guard conducted extensive overnight searches in the sea with assistance from Navy helicopters and commercial vessels to locate the missing refugees. Greek government officials have cited the increasing conflicts in the Middle East as the reason for the sudden spike in the number of refugees.

headline: Wind-Induced Drift Causes Collision Between GAS SOFIA and TRIMAS FHADILA
author: Raghib Raza
content: A maritime incident involving a collision between an LPG tanker, [GAS SOFIA,](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:366145/mmsi:525701047/imo:9586679/vessel:GAS_SOFIA) and a Ro-Ro passenger ship, [TRIMAS FHADILA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5106276/mmsi:525100688/imo:9821249/vessel:TRIMAS_FHADILA), took place on 13th December at the Tanjung Sekong Anchorage, located near Merak, Indonesia. ![TRIMAS FHADILA collided with LPG Tanker.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/TRIMAS_FHADILA_26fa2e5aba.png)*Ro-Ro ship TRIMAS FHADILA, image credit: Andri Ferdiyanto* At around 7:35 PM (WIB), the tanker ship [GAS SOFIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:366145/mmsi:525701047/imo:9586679/vessel:GAS_SOFIA) reported being struck by the [TRIMAS FHADILA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5106276/mmsi:525100688/imo:9821249/vessel:TRIMAS_FHADILA) to the Vessel Traffic Service Operator (VTSO). The vessel was anchored in the Tanjung Sekong area at the time of the incident. Subsequently, the VTSO contacted [TRIMAS FHADILA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5106276/mmsi:525100688/imo:9821249/vessel:TRIMAS_FHADILA) to confirm the incident. The crew of TRIMAS FADHILA explained that while waiting for docking clearance at Pier 07, the passenger ship started drifting northward due to strong wind, which resulted in a collision with the LPG tanker. Fortunately, no casualties were reported; however, both the vessels sustained partial damage. The [GAS SOFIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:366145/mmsi:525701047/imo:9586679/vessel:GAS_SOFIA) reported a 5-10 cm dent on its bulbous bow and a 10-meter-long scratch extending aft from the point of impact. The [TRIMAS FHADILA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5106276/mmsi:525100688/imo:9821249/vessel:TRIMAS_FHADILA) reported damage to its starboard railing along with the release of its anchored chain. The [TRIMAS FHADILA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5106276/mmsi:525100688/imo:9821249/vessel:TRIMAS_FHADILA) was directed to dock temporarily to disembark its passengers safely before proceeding with further measures. An investigation has been opened into the incident.

headline: Navigating the Complexities of Maritime Sanctions: A November 2024 Overview
author: Dimitris Ampatzidis
content: **Overview** November 2024 saw robust enforcement actions from the U.S. Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) and the UK's Office of Financial Sanctions Implementation (OFSI), adding 29 vessels and 9 companies to international sanctions rosters. These measures heightened scrutiny on high-risk vessels accused of engaging in deceptive practices, signaling a continued clampdown on non-compliance across global maritime networks. Over the year leading up to November 2024, international sanctions targeting the maritime industry surged significantly, with 261 additional vessels and 98 companies listed between December 2023 and November 2024. The most notable increases were recorded among vessels flagged by Barbados (35), Russia (33), Panama (28), and Guinea (19), highlighting the broad geographical impact of these efforts. This sustained enforcement underscores the growing determination of regulatory bodies to curtail illicit activities and enhance transparency in global shipping operations. **Main Updates** November 2024 saw critical developments in sanctions impacting the maritime and shipping sectors, driven primarily by geopolitical and strategic considerations. These measures highlighted the evolving dynamics of global trade enforcement. On November 25, the United Kingdom targeted Russia's 'shadow fleet' with its most expansive sanctions package to date ([Reuters](https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/britain-imposes-biggest-sanctions-package-russian-shadow-fleet-says-lammy-2024-11-25/)). Thirty vessels allegedly circumventing restrictions on Russian oil exports were sanctioned, increasing the total number of affected tankers to 73. These measures also extended to Russian insurers AlfaStrakhovanie and VSK, challenging the validity of their coverage for vessels in UK waters. A week earlier, on November 18, the UK expanded its scope by sanctioning Iran for supplying ballistic missiles to Russia ([AP News](https://apnews.com/article/uk-iran-sanctions-supplying-russia-missiles-2a4b06b76b1157678e7b12b02c6ad2c3)). This move included asset freezes on Iranian state entities and the Russian cargo ship Port Olya-3, highlighting concerns about the escalating conflict in Ukraine. Meanwhile, the U.S. Federal Maritime Commission launched an investigation into reports that Spain denied port access to the U.S.-flagged vessels carrying military equipment to Israel ([Yahoo News](https://www.yahoo.com/news/fmc-investigating-spain-alleged-blocking-183845165.html?guccounter=1&guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAE7vAJ9nzqJ4M4YdhrpZyzKqgi8xMMwrAazRJrBUrOk-ZJOVAhwbsThJbViCwiHcdOk884wynQRmx052bKvCcORvuVOLsIfUFkDApZVTI5NPC2HWPrqUkM8T1jGLFHAH3o-EFAN6VaAkBdj3ZEcpdIHX4kIJFvZ1pmYIOCW062z9)). These actions, allegedly taken to prevent an arms escalation in the Middle East, reflect rising tensions over the use of shipping routes for strategic purposes. These sanctions highlight a month of intensified scrutiny and enforcement in maritime trade, with significant implications for vessel operators, insurers, and global commodity flows. **Analysis of Sanctioned Vessels and Companies** ![Graph1.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Graph1_0c0f474233.png) **Graph 1.** _Sanctioned vessels and companies through the years - Kpler._ ![Graph2.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Graph2_a988003db1.png) **Graph 2.** _Sanctioned vessels per top 10 flag registry through the years - Kpler._ Sanctions targeting vessels and companies within the maritime sector have seen a steady increase, reflecting heightened regulatory oversight aimed at mitigating risks in global shipping. Recent data highlights a notable diversification in the geographic distribution of sanctioned vessels, with some flag registries experiencing significant growth in 2024. In November 2024, enforcement actions added 29 vessels and 9 companies to international sanctions rosters, representing a continued effort to address high-risk maritime activities. Compared to October 2024, notable increases were observed among vessels flagged by Panama (10), Gabon (5), Russia (4), and Barbados (4). These monthly shifts illustrate the dynamic nature of enforcement priorities and the adaptive strategies employed by regulators to monitor compliance. Registries with the most significant annual growth include Barbados, Russia, Panama, and Guinea, collectively reflecting the evolving global landscape of maritime oversight. By expanding enforcement to encompass a diverse group of flag states, authorities aim to ensure accountability and compliance across the international shipping ecosystem, supporting a more secure and transparent maritime environment. Examining pre-sanction behaviours offers vital insights into the nuances of maritime risk management and underscores the importance of diligent oversight in mitigating compliance challenges. **Risk & Compliance findings before the November 2024 sanctions** Recent enforcement by OFAC and OFSI highlights the growing focus on shadow fleet activities. The Aframax-class vessel LELIA (IMO 9258870) exemplifies this trend, showcasing numerous sanction risks: - **Cargo Connections:** Since 2022, LELIA has been linked to at least one Iranian transfer (South Pars Co.) and several Russian ESPO shipments. These transactions are subject to strict regulatory scrutiny. - **AIS Activity:** Significant gaps in AIS signals were recorded twice—22 hours near the Philippines in 2023 and 29 hours near South Korea in 2024—indicating potential evasion tactics. - **High-Risk Operations:** LELIA participated in numerous ship-to-ship (STS) transfers at Kalamata Light and other zones, involving restricted or sanctioned vessels and cargo, with frequent instances of questionable AIS behavior. ![Image1.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Image1_0d488a4813.jpg) **Image 1.** _LELIA risks - Kpler._ ![Image2.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Image2_70564626eb.jpg) **Image 2.** _LELIA connections to Iranian and Russian cargo - Kpler._ LELIA's management risks stemmed from operational and structural vulnerabilities: - **Insurance Termination:** Britannia Steam Ship Insurance withdrew coverage by early 2024, leaving the vessel uninsured during high-risk periods. - **Classification Downgrade:** Bureau Veritas discontinued classification services post-sanction. - **Ownership Links:** The vessel's technical and ISM manager, Salina Ship Management, faced direct OFAC sanctions in 2024. ![Image3.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Image3_0c1ed22dd4.jpg) **Image 3.** _LELIA lack of coverage from an IGP&I member - Kpler._ Kpler’s proprietary insights highlighted several critical operational risks: - **STS Transfers:** One "dark" STS transfer was documented in March 2022 near Malaysia. LELIA's AIS was off, confirmed later via satellite imagery. - **High-Risk Port Calls:** In mid-2024, LELIA docked at Assaluyeh, Iran,, a high-risk port associated with sanctioned cargo movements. ![Image4.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Image4_02bc1b8ac8.jpg) **Image 4.** _LELIA operational risks overview - Kpler._ ![Image5.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Image5_24d89a407d.jpg) **Image 5.** _LELIA dark STS transfer - Kpler._ LELIA's pre-sanction activities underscore a broader trend where ship tracking and compliance solutions play a vital role in mitigating risks. Entities utilizing advanced systems can preemptively assess and avoid similar scenarios. Stay tuned for more insights and updates, ensuring that you remain informed and compliant amidst these dynamic regulatory changes.
