headline: Storm Splits Oil Tanker VOLGONEFT 212 in Kerch Strait, Resulting in Fatalities and Oil Spill
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Russian oil tanker [VOLGONEFT 212](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:347163/mmsi:273333930/imo:0/vessel:VOLGONEFT_212#overview) broke apart in two during a severe storm as it was traveling through the Kerch Strait. The accident has led to the death of at least one crew member, with two still missing. ![ VOLGONEFT 212 sank in rough sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/VOLGONEFT_212_f0ddf23058.png)*Vessel VOLGONEFT 212, image credit: X/ Akinci* The incident occurred early in the morning on 15th December. The bow of the tanker sank, while the stern remained afloat for a while longer before succumbing to the storm. The ship is reported to have been carrying 4,300 tons of low-grade biofuel. The vessel was reported to have 15 crew members on board, of which 12 have been rescued. Of these rescued individuals, two have been reported to be in serious medical condition. One sailor tragically lost his life in the incident, and two are still missing. The breaking apart of a vessel typically causes large quantities of cargo to get released quickly. While there are no detailed reports of environmental damage available yet, an oil spill from the vessel has been confirmed. President Vladimir Putin himself has sanctioned a working group to coordinate efforts to rescue sailors and mitigate environmental damage. The Russian Authorities have initiated a criminal investigation into the incident, spurred on by the fact that no plausible immediate explanations were given for such serious damage to the vessel. The vessel is considerably old and was built in 1969. There have been a considerable number of similar maritime disasters that involved aging vessels that could not operate in challenging environments. Incidentally, another vessel from the same operator, the [VOLGONEFT 239](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:348458/mmsi:273354600/imo:0/vessel:VOLGONEFT_239#overview), suffered damage and became adrift in the storm, eventually running aground. It was determined that the crew of 14 aboard the vessel were not in immediate danger and were left aboard the vessel till the storm subsided.

headline: India Launches New Jalvahak Scheme Promoting Inland Waterways
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Indian Government launched a new scheme named the “Jalvahak” for enhancing long-distance cargo transportation via inland waterways. On December 15th, the Indian government inaugurated the scheme, which aims to promote transportation across multiple waterways, thereby alleviating congestion on roads and rail networks. ![ Indian Government launched a new scheme Jalvahak an inland waterways](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Inland_waterways_85425cadbc.png)*Image credit:pib.gov.in* The program inaugurated fixed sailing services across key routes, such as Kolkata-Patna-Varanasi and Kolkata-Pandu (Guwahati). This service will allow for timely and reliable cargo delivery. The scheme is also heavily incentivizing early adopters by offering around 35% reimbursement of operating costs for all cargo that is transported farther than 300 kilometers. Initially, this scheme is set to be valid for 3 years. The inauguration also involved the flagging off of three cargo vessels that will mark the beginning of cargo deliveries under the new scheme. These were the MV TRISHUL, carrying cement to Guwahati; the[ MV HOMI BHABA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5757773/mmsi:419741170/imo:0/vessel:HOMI_BHABHA), carrying coal to Varanasi; and the [MV AAI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5452237/mmsi:419001319/imo:0/vessel:AAI), carrying gypsum to Patna. The new Jalvahak scheme is also intended to promote a more eco-friendly mode of transport than roadways or the Indian railways, which are the go-to methods for the majority of goods transport in India. The new Jalvahak scheme is intended to bring about significant change in the current cargo transport landscape, with more than 800 million tonne-kilometers of modal shift expected by 2027.

headline: India Averts Nationwide Dockworker Strike as Government Meets Demands
author: Raghib Raza
content: The indefinite Indian dockworker strike that was to begin on 17th December has been averted as the government accepted dockworkers' demands. The Indian government has honored its agreement with the dockworkers' union that was signed in September, leading to the conflicts being resolved and the strike being averted. ![NHAVA SHEVA PORT.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NHAVA_SHEVA_PORT_e0639f45bd.png)*NHAVA SHEVA PORT, image credit: Capt.Turboboss* The Indian dock workers' unions had threatened to go on an indefinite strike if their demands of pay revisions and productivity schemes were not implemented by 15th December. However, negotiations between the government and the workers turned out successful, with updated wage agreements and other demanded benefits being implemented. The strike would have involved around 18,000 dockworkers and impacted 12 ports across India. The Ministry of Shipping in India has directed the Indian Ports Association to enforce these revised terms and has alleviated concerns of shutdowns across Indian ports that would have severely impacted trade operations.

headline: Container Ship YM UNICORN Runs Aground at Keelung Port, Taiwan
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Yang Ming container vessel, [YM UNICORN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:653532/mmsi:416464000/imo:9462732/vessel:YM_UNICORN#overview), ran aground on 11th December as it attempted to berth at the [KEELUNG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/191?name=KEELUNG&country=Taiwan) port in Taiwan. No crewmembers of the vessel were reported to be injured. ![YM UNICORN ran aground in Taiwan water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/YM_UNICORN_24cb76780c.png)*Containership YM UNICORN,image credit: Ray Hensel* The incident took place around midnight close to a lighthouse near the Keelung port in Taiwan. The vessel had arrived from [KAOHSIUNG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/190?name=KAOHSIUNG&country=Taiwank) and was attempting to berth at the port when the accident happened. Keelung Port Traffic Control Center stated that the vessel deviated from its course near the red lighthouse in Dikou. It is still unknown why the vessel deviated from its course. The traffic control center promptly launched three tugs to assist the vessel. Personnel from the port confirmed that the vessel had run aground at 3:21 AM (CST) on 12th December. Personnel soon boarded the stranded vessel, and the pilot reported that the forepeak tank had sustained damage, leading to water ingress. Another four tugs were launched to assist the vessel, and with a joint effort, the vessel was pulled free into the water in 20 minutes. The vessel then subsequently berthed at the Keelung West No. 19 pier by 4:35 AM. An investigation into the incident has been opened. [YM UNICORN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:653532/mmsi:416464000/imo:9462732/vessel:YM_UNICORN#overview) is a Taiwanese-flagged vessel built in 2013. The vessel has a length of 333.2 meters, a width of 42.8 meters, and a capacity of 8,626 TEU.

headline: South Korea Announces a $10 Billion Investment in the Port of Busan
author: Raghib Raza
content: The South Korean Ministry of Oceans and Fisheries announced a 14 trillion KRW (around $10 billion) investment plan on 11th December to upgrade the port of [BUSAN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/793?name=BUSAN&country=Korea). This development is to be completed by 2045, and the aim of the investment has been announced to convert the port of Busan into a leading container handling hub globally. ![BUSAN PORT expansion.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BUSAN_PORT_5beb398353.png)*BUSAN PORT, image credit:Jose Baja Jr.* The new project includes the development of the new Port of[ JINHAE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/20519?name=JINHAE&country=Korea) alongside Busan. The new port will have 66 berths with a capacity to handle vessels up to 30,000 TEU. The container yard space is also to increased by 1.5 times. The port is to be operated by a single operator and is expected to handle volumes up to 6 million TEUs annually. Other goals of the monumental investment involve the creation of an overseas logistic center as well as the dedication of 362 hectares of hinterland near the Busan port. The plans also involve the creation of an eco-friendly port conversion with expected transitions to achieve 25% renewable energy by 2032 and 100% renewable energy by 2050. The energy is to be sourced by solar panels, fuel cells, and offshore wind power. Infrastructure for future green fuels such as methanol and ammonia is also to be constructed. The South Korean ministry has cited recent protectionist policies due to the US-China trading conflicts, along with the heightening geopolitical uncertainties and climate challenges for the investment. The ministry stated that such investment was necessary to maintain Busan Port’s reputation as a global trade hub.

headline: Greenpeace and Shell Settle Lawsuit Stemming From a Protest Conducted in the North Sea
author: Raghib Raza
content: Greenpeace and Shell have settled a lawsuit, with Greenpeace agreeing to pay £300,000 (approximately $383,000) to Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI) as a part of the terms. ![WHITE MARLINE .](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/WHITE_MARLINE_b249baa50c.png)*Heavy Load Carrier WHITE MARLIN, image credit: Jeff Maclean* The lawsuit was over a protest that was conducted by Greenpeace protestors at the heavy lift vessel [WHITE MARLIN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1965380/mmsi:248750000/imo:9670224/vessel:WHITE_MARLIN#overview) back in January of 2023. The ship was carrying equipment for drilling operations in the North Sea. Greenpeace protestors approached the cargo vessel via inflatable boats and climbed aboard. The protestors occupied the vessel for 13 days. The protestors had used ropes to climb aboard the Penguin FPSO platform, which was being transported on the [WHITE MARLIN ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1965380/mmsi:248750000/imo:9670224/vessel:WHITE_MARLIN#overview)to the Penguins oil and gas field near the Shetland Islands. Later, Shell reported that nothing other than a padlock had been damaged. Shell then proceeded to sue Greenpeace for a sum of $1 million in damages, stating that their protest had caused significant disruptions and had incurred costs in shipping delays. Shell further claimed that the protestors endangered the safety of the crew as well as their own. Greenpeace ended up settling with Shell for £300,000 to be paid to the Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI), a charity search and rescue service, in addition to the agreement that Greenpeace would not stage protests at four designated oil fields in the North Sea. Greenpeace has agreed to refrain from protesting at three of these sites for five years and for 10 years at the fourth site. Greenpeace co-executive director Areeba Hamid stated that Shell agreed to the settlement as the lawsuit had turned into a PR nightmare for the oil company. The case had faced significant public backlash, which made it withdraw and opt for the out-of-court settlement.

headline: Cargo Ship BBC ICELAND Crashes Into Veracruz Boardwalk As Strong Winds Batter Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: The cargo ship [BBC ICELAND](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:733368/mmsi:305657000/imo:9605906/vessel:BBC_ICELAND) collided with a boardwalk in the port of [VERACRUZ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/3070?name=VERACRUZ&country=Mexico), Mexico on Wednesday. The cause of the collision is being reported to be strong northern winds that hit the coastal area of the island of Veracruz. ![BBC ICELAND collided with a boardwalk in the port of Veracruz.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BBC_ICELAND_e32e5bb41d.png)*General cargo BBC ICELAND, image credit:plumaslibres.com.mx* The incident occurred a little before 9:00 AM (CST) on 11th December. Reports indicate that the bow ropes broke, due to which the ship started to drift, eventually ending up hitting the boardwalk due to the strong winds. The ship hit a section of the wall of Malecon, a little distance from the historic center of the city of Veracruz. Initial reports from the vessel indicate that there were no injuries among dock workers or among the crew of the vessel. Recent northern winds that have been lashing out at the island of Veracruz have had speeds of up to 107 kilometers per hour. Following the collision, the area of impact was cordoned off by the Mexican Navy. Subsequently, three tugs supported the [BBC ICELAND](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:733368/mmsi:305657000/imo:9605906/vessel:BBC_ICELAND) and prevented it from continually hitting the wall due to the winds. Four tugs then monitored and assisted the vessel in its docking at the port.

headline: Bulk Carrier 'PORTHOS' Arrested in Singapore Over $145,000 Charter Dispute
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Marshall Islands-flagged bulk carrier [PORTHOS ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:712786/mmsi:538003518/imo:9408267/vessel:PORTHOS)was arrested in Singapore on 7th December under a sheriff’s order. ![Vessel PORTHOS arrested in Singapore.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PORTHOS_43f6af12ef.png)*Bulk carrier PORTHOS, image credit: V.Tonic* The arrest was made at 3:08 PM (SGT) and executed by the Chinese charterer of the vessel, Transwind Shipping. The vessel had arrived from Chittagong, Bangladesh, at 1:50 PM (SGT) and was arrested shortly after. Reports indicate that the arrest stemmed from a dispute over a charter party agreement amounting to a total of $145,000. Court documents filed for the arrest do not specify the exact details of the charter party dispute. The [PORTHOS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:712786/mmsi:538003518/imo:9408267/vessel:PORTHOS) is a 2010-built Supramax bulk carrier that is controlled by Nicholas G. Moundreas Shipping in Singapore. The vessel is 189.9 meters long, 32.2 meters wide, and has a gross tonnage of 33,044.

headline: Fire Breaks Out on Bulk Carrier LANGELAND Docked at the Arinaga Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire broke out on the bulk carrier [LANGELAND](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8823807/mmsi:255862000/imo:9968243/vessel:LANGELAND) on 9th December as the vessel was docked at the port of [ARINAGA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2193?name=ARINAGA&country=Spain), Gran Canaria, Spain. ![LANGELAND caught fire.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LANGELAND_ef8de04b6d.png)*Vessel LANGELAND, image credit:laprovincia.es* The incident occurred around 4:30 pm (WET) when the vessel was being loaded with scrap metal. The fire reportedly started in the cargo hold, which was filled with scrap materials. Firefighters from the Gran Canaria Emergency Consortium quickly arrived on the scene, and after a protracted struggle, managed to douse the fire at 6:00 PM (WET). The bulk cargo within the vessel was reportedly covered with foam to prevent reignition. The majority of the crew evacuated the vessel, and the ship at a nearby berth was moved to a more distant berth due to the fire. Port operations were also temporarily suspended as a precaution. Eyewitness accounts indicate that smoke billowed from the vessel, which was creating visibility issues for the emergency responders. Fortunately, no reports of pollution or injuries have been reported. Local media reports indicate that the crew made an attempt to close the hatches of the vessel and deploy the vessel’s fire fighting system. However, the fire seemed to have burned the wires of the hatch’s actuation system, leading to the hatch remaining open. An investigation has been launched into the incident. [LANGELAND](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8823807/mmsi:255862000/imo:9968243/vessel:LANGELAND) is a newly built bulk carrier registered in Portugal. The vessel is 89.9 meters long, 15.5 meters wide, and has a gross tonnage of 3960.

headline: Cargo Ship Remains Stuck Off Danish Coast After Multiple Salvage Attempts
author: Raghib Raza
content: The [AMADEUS GOLD](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3635017/mmsi:244810730/imo:9479565/vessel:AMADEUS_GOLD), a general cargo ship, ran aground in the early hours of 9th December while it was on a voyage from Rotterdam to Odense, Denmark. The vessel still remains stuck despite multiple attempts to free it so far. ![AMADEUS GOLD ran aground.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/AMADEUS_GOLD_b47e862f9e.png)*General Cargo Vessel AMADEUS GOLD, image credit:ugeavisen.dk* The incident is reported to have occurred at around 2:30 AM CET in Odense Fjord in Denmark. Two subsequent salvage attempts to free the vessel have failed, with the latest attempt being made at 7:20 AM on 10th December. The first attempt to free the vessel is said to have failed due to the tugboat not being strong enough to pull the vessel free. However, even during the second attempt, the vessel refused to budge. An officer on duty at the Armed Forces Operations Center stated that the next attempt to free the vessel would be made later in the night during high tide. So far, no reports of pollution have been made. The reason for the grounding of the vessel is not yet known, and investigations are underway. The ship is also to be detained till the seaworthiness of the vessel is attested to by the flag state or the classification society.

headline: Vehicle Carrier MALAYSIA STAR Catches Fire in the Malacca Strait
author: Raghib Raza
content: The vehicle carrier [MALAYSIA STAR ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:707108/mmsi:533000996/imo:9032331/vessel:MALAYSIA_STAR#overview)caught fire as it was traveling from Port Klang to Kota Kinabalu in the Malacca Strait on 2nd December. ![Fire aboard MALAYSIA STAR.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MALAYSIA_STAR_c8977bae79.png)*Vessel MALAYSIA STAR, image credit: MMEA* The fire aboard the vessel was reported to the Malaysian Maritime Enforcement Agency (MMEA) at 8:40 AM local time (MYT). At the time, the vessel was around 9.1 miles off of Tanjung Laboh. The vessel was carrying 19 crew members, 18 of whom were Filipino and one was a Malay local. A Maritime police force boat and two Patrol boats from the MMEA were promptly sent to the scene. Fortunately, none of the crew members were harmed in the incident and were rescued successfully aboard the vessel and transferred to the patrol boats. The crewmembers were then taken to the Batu Pahat Maritime Zone Jetty. The fire is reported to have ignited near the vessel’s fuel tank, which has required intense firefighting efforts. The cause of the fire has not yet been ascertained. As of the latest reports, there has been no pollution from the vessel yet. Authorities continue to closely monitor the situation.

headline: Man Rescued from Sinking Sailboat off the Coast of Grande terre, Guadeloupe by cargo vessel VANUATU CHIEF
author: Raghib Raza
content: A 66-year-old Australian man was rescued on 2nd December from his sailboat, which had sprung a leak and was sinking. ![VANUATU CHIEF conduct rescue operation.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/VANUATU_CHIEF_5c4bf69177.png)*Cargo vessel VANUATU CHIEF, imge credit: V. Tonic* The Operational Service and Rescue Center (OSC) received a distress call from a sinking Piper sailboat at around 7:30 am local time on the morning of 2nd December. The sailboat was located off the coast of Grande Terre in the Northern Lagoon. After coordinating with the Australian Rescue Centre based in Canberra, the OSC managed to establish contact with the sailor onboard the distressed vessel. The sailor identified himself to be alone and stated that his sailboat had suffered rudder damage and had an uncontrollable leak. The OSR sent a Casa Aircraft from the Armed Forces in New Caledonia. The vessel [VANUATU CHIEF ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:728242/mmsi:564407000/imo:9614543/vessel:VANUATU_CHIEF#overview)also responded to the call for the aid of the distressed vessel. Additional support was also requested from the Gardian aircraft and a helicopter. By around 9:45 am local time, the Gardian aircraft had successfully located the sailboat and communicated with the sailor, who stated that his boat would likely sink in a few hours. By Noon, the [VANUATU CHIEF](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:728242/mmsi:564407000/imo:9614543/vessel:VANUATU_CHIEF#overview) arrived near the distressed vessel, dispatched a rescue boat, and rescued the sailor. The man was then later hoisted on the helicopter and led to Poum in North Caledonia by 2:00 pm local time.

headline: Man Goes Missing from Cruise Ship; Incident Goes Unreported Till End of Cruise
author: Raghib Raza
content: A 72-year-old American man was reported to be missing from the cruise ship, [RUBY PRINCESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:371495/mmsi:310567000/imo:9378462/vessel:RUBY_PRINCESS#overview), as it arrived from a 5-day journey from[ ENSENADA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/216?name=ENSENADA&country=Mexico), Mexico. The passenger’s absence was noticed upon the completion of the journey on 2nd December. ![A man went overboard from RUBY PRINCESS](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RUBY_PRINCESS_d4dc579078.png)*Cruise ship RUBY PRINCESS, image credit: Tony Martin* The crew of the [RUBY PRINCESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:371495/mmsi:310567000/imo:9378462/vessel:RUBY_PRINCESS#overview) realized that the passenger was missing after arriving at the port of[ SAN FRANCISCO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/94?name=SAN-FRANCISCO&country=USA) on 2nd December at 6:50 am local time. A search was initiated for the man, including several thorough searches of the ship and a comprehensive review of the CCTV footage on board, but the passenger was not found. The passenger’s identity has not been publicly released. The man was reportedly traveling alone, and it is not known when, along the five-day cruise from 27th November to 2nd December, the man went missing. The incident is being treated as a man overboard incident, and the passenger is feared to be dead. The US Coast Guard initiated a search for the man and deployed a fixed-wing aircraft. However, they suspended their search efforts by 5:30 pm local time on 2nd December. An investigation into the incident has been opened by US Customs and Border Protection.

headline: Mexico Seeking to Impose $42 per Head Immigration Tax on Cruise Passengers
author: Raghib Raza
content: A bill has been passed in the Mexican Chamber of Deputies to tax the incoming cruise passengers per head with a tax that amounts to $42. The tax was traditionally reserved for passengers that stayed for more than a week but now could be extended to cruise passengers. The new tax, if approved, is expected to take effect from 2026. ![COZUMEL PORT.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/COZUMEL_PORT_cfc1541aad.png)*COZUMEL PORT, image credit: Aloys Eijgermans* In the particular case of the ports of [COZUMEL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/280?name=COZUMEL&country=Mexico) and [COSTA MAYA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/19259?name=COSTA-MAYA&country=Mexico), there will be a $5 charge levied from passengers for tourism infrastructure and disaster prevention efforts. This will lead to a total of $47 charge per head for cruise passengers that visit these ports annually. The Mexican army is due to receive around two-thirds of the proceeds from this new tax. Since 2020, the Mexican army has been placed in charge of Mexican ports to curb the smuggling of illicit cargo. The large percentage of revenues from the tax being diverted to the army instead of being invested in tourism infrastructure is also raising concerns. The bill is already facing resistance, with the cruise industry, the Florida Caribbean Cruise Association (FCCA), and even the Mexican Association of Shipping Agents opposing the tax, asking for it to not be implemented. The FCCA has issued a public statement to Mexico stating that the cruise industries would be forced to shift away from Mexican ports should this new tax come into effect, and hence, the tax must not be allowed to come into effect. As for now, the bill has been approved by the lower house and sent for debate to the Senate. Along with the possibility of the bill failing to gather support in the Senate, there is also the possibility of the bill being vetoed by the Mexican president, Claudia Sheinbaum.

headline: Renewable Fuels Plant to be Set Up at the “Port of Riga”
author: Raghib Raza
content: A new renewable fuels plant is to be set up at the port of [RIGA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/772?name=RIGA&country=Latvia), Latvia. The new plant will be a significant hub for renewable fuel production and will be the first large-scale producer of renewable fuels in the Baltic. ![A new renewable fuels plant to be set up at Port RIGA.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RIGA_PORT_a02186144d.png)*RIGA PORT, image credit:Martins Saiters* The new plant at Port [RIGA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/772?name=RIGA&country=Latvia) will focus on the production of hydrotreated vegetable oil (HVO) and sustainable aviation fuel (SAF). Both of these fuels are expected to be in high demand in the near future. Even now, these fuels are exclusively imported in the Baltics with no significant indigenous production. The renewable fuel production plant will be located in Kundziņsala, within the Port of Riga, and will be built in partnership with Ukrainian investors. The plant will be able to take around 236,000 tons of feedstock and be able to produce 93,000 tons of HVO along with 87,000 tons of SAF. The project is estimated to cost around 120 million euros ($126 million) and is expected to be completed within 20 months. The project is expected to become a valuable asset in the future, particularly for the aviation sector, which will require 20% of its fuels to be renewable by 2030.

headline: Bulker STELLA L Ordered to be Seized for Smuggling of Subsidized Rice from India
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Deputy Chief Minister of the State of Andhra Pradesh, India ordered the seizure of the bulk carrier, [STELLA L](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:464574/mmsi:373227000/imo:9500687/vessel:STELLA_L), at the Kakinada Anchorage port on 29th November. The vessel, bound for West Africa, is being seized for its involvement in the smuggling of subsidized rice. ![STELLA L seized at Indian Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/STELLA_L_702cef7391.png)*Vessel STELLA L, image credit: Arjan Elmendorp* The vessel was identified to be involved in smuggling during a raid that was conducted at the Kakinada anchorage port. The bulker [STELLA L](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:464574/mmsi:373227000/imo:9500687/vessel:STELLA_L) was found to be loaded with around 38,000 metric tons of rice, out of which 640 metric tons were verified to be rice supplied through the Public Distribution System (PDS). The Public Distribution System is a food security initiative by the Indian government to provide food for the economically disadvantaged sections of society. PDS rice is provided at highly subsidized rates, even free of charge, to people that are in acute economic hardship.

headline: Bulk Carrier Allides with Docked General Cargo Vessel in Galapagos Islands
author: Raghib Raza
content: The bulk carrier [TRAPEZITZA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8827740/mmsi:256680000/imo:9968499/vessel:TRAPEZITZA), along with the general cargo vessel [PAOLA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:967867/mmsi:735059075/imo:5146689/vessel:PAOLA), was docked for loading on 27th November. There have been no reports of injuries to the crew of either vessel. ![Allision between TRAPEZITZA and PAOLA.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PAOLA_3c098aadc5.png)*Allision between TRAPEZITZA and PAOLA, image credit:Instagram/salvage_and_wreck* The incident occurred at the Caraguay dock in Guayaquil. The[ TRAPEZITZA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8827740/mmsi:256680000/imo:9968499/vessel:TRAPEZITZA) was departing from a nearby terminal and was headed to Matarani as it collided with the [PAOLA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:967867/mmsi:735059075/imo:5146689/vessel:PAOLA) which was docked for loading. The accident led to the bow of the [PAOLA ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:967867/mmsi:735059075/imo:5146689/vessel:PAOLA)being significantly damaged. The [TRAPEZITZA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8827740/mmsi:256680000/imo:9968499/vessel:TRAPEZITZA) is a Malta-flagged bulk carrier that was built this year. The vessel has a length of around 190 meters, a beam of 31.88 meters, and a gross tonnage of 29,173. The [PAOLA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:967867/mmsi:735059075/imo:5146689/vessel:PAOLA) is a much smaller general cargo vessel that was built in 1957 and flagged in Ecuador. It has a length of 52.1 meters, a beam of 8.64 meters, and a gross tonnage of 422. The governing council of the Galapagos, along with the Subsecratariat of ports, are adjusting maritime schedules so that the accident’s adverse effects on critical maritime routes can be minimized.

headline: Vertom Group Announces the Newest Addition to its Fleet, “VERTOM RITA”
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 1st December, the Vertom Group announced the newest addition to its fleet, the 6000 DWT short-sea vessel [VERTOM RITA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9207681/mmsi:245338000/imo:9980083/vessel:VERTOM_RITA#overview). The vessel is the first of a series of 12 vessels that are to be delivered by the Chowgule shipyards in India. ![VERTOM RITA join the Vertom fleet.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/VERTOM_RITA_d51ec413f8.png)*Vessel VERTOM RITA, image credit: VERTOM* [VERTOM RITA ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9207681/mmsi:245338000/imo:9980083/vessel:VERTOM_RITA#overview)is a 6,000 DWT diesel-electric vessel that is flagged in the Netherlands. The vessel has a length of 99 meters, a beam of 14 meters, and a gross tonnage of 3,923. The vessel’s design has been optimized for short-sea operations. The vessel incorporates the latest diesel-electric technology for its engines and is IMO Tier III compliant. The vessel is also future fuel ready, being able to be converted to methanol electric or hydrogen electric for operations. The vessel is an integral part of Vertom’s strategy to reduce its carbon intensity by 40% by 2030. The vessel will begin its service in the European short-sea market.

headline: Houthi Attacks Target Passing Vessels in the Red Sea
author: Raghib Raza
content: Houthi rebels attacked vessels passing through the Red Sea on 1st December. The vessels that faced attacks were US supply ships. ![LIBERTY GRACE.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LIBERTY_GRACE_a60b3d4892.png)*Bulk Carrier LIBERTY GRACE, image credit: Christopher R Irvine* The Houthi claimed responsibility for attacking the three US supply vessels. They claimed that they directly hit the vessels with drones and missiles. The US supply ships in question were claimed by the Houthi to be the [MAERSK SARATOGA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:732401/mmsi:369096000/imo:9289207/vessel:MAERSK_SARATOGA), the [STENA IMPECCABLE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4829596/mmsi:367054000/imo:9693020/vessel:STENA_IMPECCABLE), and the [LIBERTY GRACE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:400408/mmsi:338219000/imo:9228148/vessel:LIBERTY_GRACE). The US military confirmed the attack on three US-owned vessels that were passing through the Red Sea between 30th November to 01st December. However, the US military did not name the vessels and, contrary to the Houthi statement, claimed that the vessels were unharmed. US Central Command (CENTCOM) stated that their destroyers, USS Stockdale and the USS O’Kane, destroyed three anti-ship ballistic missiles, three drones, and an anti-ship cruise missile in defense of the three commercial vessels that were being attacked. It has not yet been revealed if the journey of these vessels was aborted on account of the attack. In a separate incident, the United Kingdom Maritime and Trade Operations (UKMTO) agency reported of an attack on 1st December around 80 miles south of Aden at 9:32 AM UTC. The UKMTO has posted a warning in the region for vessels to proceed with caution.

headline: Protests Erupt in Georgia as Demonstrators Block Access to Poti Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: Demonstrators in the Black Sea city of Poti blocked access to the country’s main commercial port [POTI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/786?name=POTI&country=Georgia), on 1st December. This unrest erupted in response to the ruling party’s announcement of suspending discussions on the country joining the EU for four years. ![POTI PORT.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/POTI_PORT_6c23c147ea.png)*PORT POTI, image credit: Sergi Petriashvili* The Port of [POTI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/786?name=POTI&country=Georgia) is the primary port of Georgia, handling around 80% of its container traffic. According to the images being circulated, protestors blocked access to at least one road to the port. The port is managed by APM Terminals, which is a subsidiary of Maersk. The controversial announcement was made on 28th November. The decision to defer the negotiations of the country joining the EU is being criticized by many as being a move away from Western alignment and democracy. Protesters accuse the ruling party of trying to build closer ties to Russia. Protesters obstructing access to the port of Poti are but a part of a much wider unrest across the nation. Protests are reported to have spread to 8 cities and towns other than the cities of Poti and Tbilisi. The police are responding to the clashing protestors with tear gas and water cannons, and more than 150 protestors have been detained across the nation.

headline: Brazilian Government Unveils New Plan for Privatization and Expansion of Ports
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Brazilian government recently announced a bold initiative for the privatization of its port sector. The new plan is expected to garner around $3 billion in private investments, leading to the upgrade of the country’s ports. ![SANTOS PORT.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SANTOS_PORT_08c00b4c22.png)*SANTOS PORT, image credit: Roberto Smera* The plan involves investments in more than 50 listed projects that would involve a collective investment of around $3 billion from the private sector. Among the upcoming events, the government plans to auction off 35 port terminals, with 22 of these auctions expected to take place before the end of 2025 and three auctions to take place in the last month of 2024 alone. Five of these leases are for the Port of[ SANTOS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/189?name=SANTOS&country=Brazil), the largest port in Brazil. In addition to this, there are also concessions to be offered for the three terminals in the port and for the navigation channel. One of the terminals, the ITG 02 at Itaguai, is slated for auction this month. In a bid to attract private investors, the Brazilian government is offering competitive lines of credit and tax rebates. The regulatory landscape for the privatization of these assets has also been streamlined, reducing the overall time of such paperwork by 3 months. Furthermore, the Merchant Marine Fund has earmarked 30% of its budget for this privatization effort of the port sector. This plan, through the modernization and expansion of the port infrastructure, is expected to boost Brazilian trade and its competitiveness in the international landscape.

headline: Greenpeace Activists Board Tanker in Protest Amidst Negotiations for UN Global Plastics Treaty
author: Raghib Raza
content: Greenpeace activists boarded the tanker [BUENA ALBA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:465868/mmsi:373933000/imo:9643972/vessel:BUENA_ALBA) on 30th November and stayed aboard for 12 hours as the vessel was scheduled to load propylene, a key ingredient in plastic production. The protest was staged as negotiations were ongoing for a UN Global Plastics Treaty that was proceeding in Busan, South Korea. ![Greenpeace activist protest boarded the tanker BUENA ALBA](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BUENA_ALBA_4fb9475b42.png)*LPG Tanker BUENA ALBA, image credit: Greenpeace* The protest was intended to persuade governments to proceed with the planned cuts in plastic production and resist pressure from the petrochemical and fossil fuel industries, which are lobbying against them. The activists launched their protest from the vessel [RAINBOW WARRIOR](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:225703/mmsi:244163000/imo:9575383/vessel:RAINBOW_WARRIOR#overview). The protestors, who hail from different countries including Mexico, Germany, and the UK, departed from the [RAINBOW WARRIOR](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:225703/mmsi:244163000/imo:9575383/vessel:RAINBOW_WARRIOR#overview) on rigid-hulled inflatable boats (RHIBs), arriving at the tanker [BUENA ALBA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:465868/mmsi:373933000/imo:9643972/vessel:BUENA_ALBA) and setting up tents on its mast. The protestors stayed on board for 12 hours, symbolically halting the process. Following the 12 hours, the protestors were arrested by the South Korean police. The negotiations too ran into a deadlock on 1st December and were postponed.

headline: General Cargo Ship SOFIA Catches Fire Following explosion; Crew Abandon Ship
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Swedish general cargo ship [SOFIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:353459/mmsi:265011000/imo:8616087/vessel:SOFIA#overview) caught fire following an explosion on 28th November off Sweden. The five crew members onboard the vessel have abandoned the ship. ![SOFIA caught fire following an explosion.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SOFIA_4bc2001e0b.png)*General cargo vessel SOFIA, image credit:Johan Trommel* The incident occurred around 9:20 pm local time, around 50 kilometers east of Bornholm Island. The crew quickly issued a distress call. The first responder was a Swedish helicopter, which arrived at the location and rescued all five crew members by around 11:00 pm local time. All crew members were transported to Kristianstad and were reported to be uninjured. Other vessels, such as the Najaden and the Absalon from the Danish navy, later joined to assist the distressed vessel. The cause of the explosion and the subsequent fire is still unknown.

headline: Container Ship JML ABADI Suffers Explosion, No Casualties Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: The container vessel [JML ABADI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:702955/mmsi:525003015/imo:9200196/vessel:JML_ABADI#overview) suffered an explosion on its starboard side main deck. Despite one crewmember going overboard into the sea, there were no casualties in the incident. ![Explosion aboard JMB ABADI.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/JMB_ABADI_46c2e1a084.png)*Containership JML ABADI, image credit: Vladimir Knyaz* The incident occurred on 28th November at around 1:00 pm Western Indonesian Time. Hydraulic repair activities were underway on the vessel, which was completed by 12:00 pm Western Indonesian Time. Following this, the vessel was headed to dock. The foreman of the vessel who was performing welding aboard the vessel fell overboard. The foreman was reportedly welding without coordinating with the other crew members. Buoys and life jackets were immediately thrown, and nearby vessels and fishing boats were contacted, who assisted in the search for the missing foreman. The victim was successfully rescued at 1:20 pm Western Indonesian Time and was immediately taken to the hospital for medical treatment. The[ JML ABADI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:702955/mmsi:525003015/imo:9200196/vessel:JML_ABADI#overview) is an Indonesian-flagged container ship built in 1998. The vessel has an overall length of 98 meters, beam of 16 meters,with a gross tonnage of 3,508.

headline: Understanding the Global Distribution of Grey and Sanctioned Fleets: November 2024 Update
author: Dimitris Ampatzidis
content: **Overview** This article reports on the Global Distribution of Grey and Sanctioned fleets throughout the month of November. While 87.4% of the world’s ships operate openly, about 10.2% are hidden or unclear in their operations, and another 2.4% are involved in breaking sanctions. Altogether, this adds up to around 3,000 ships in the “grey zone”. In the past month, these fleets have moved over 101 million barrels of oil, often using old ships over 16 years old with hidden ownership. **Current state of compliance** Quietly moving through international waters, the "shadow fleet" avoids detection by constantly altering its registration details and masking its true operations. Within 2024, 248 more ships were added to this fleet, making a total of 2,967. This is about 10.2% of the world’s commercial fleet that carries dry goods, liquids, or gas that are over 5,000 tons in weight. As of November 29, 2024, we have 13 fewer vessels than we did on October 31, due to the new sanctions enforced by the United States and United Kingdom. ![Picture1.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture1_4fac559e0d.png) **Image 1.** _The rise of the grey and sanctioned fleets, from 101 to 2,967 vessels - Kpler._ ![Picture2.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture2_1beb45d7f0.png) **Image 2.** _Global distribution of white, grey, and sanctioned fleets - Kpler._ A dominant 87.4% of the global fleet operates within the 'white' category - vessels follow standard regulations, transparent practices, and are not connected to sanctioned cargo. In contrast, 10.2% of vessels (2,967 vessels) fall into the 'grey/shadow' category, indicating potential involvement in deceptive shipping practices or sanctioned trade, while a smaller 2.4% are directly involved in sanctioned activities. ![Picture3.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture3_89f6e6ef09.png) **Image 3.** _Age distribution of grey and sanctioned fleets and their proportion relative to the total fleet - Kpler._ The "grey" or "shadow" fleet primarily comprises older vessels, with a significant portion aged 16 years or more. Specifically, ships between 16 and 20 years old constitute 8.6% of the global fleet, while those over 20 years account for 29.1%. Sanctioned vessels are particularly prevalent in the 20+ year age group. This trend indicates that older ships are more often used in both shadow and sanctioned activities, possibly because their lower market value makes them more susceptible to illicit use. Accurately identifying the age of a vessel helps to better assess the likelihood of risk associated. ![Picture4.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture4_7f6f01a556.png) **Image 4.** _November-over-October changes on age distribution of grey and sanctioned fleets - Kpler._ In November, there was a decrease in the proportion of grey fleet vessels aged 0-20 years, likely due to new sanctions targeting this segment. Overall, the proportion of sanctioned vessels has increased across all age groups, reflecting the impact of recent sanctions. ![Picture5.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture5_43ac5c6796.png) **Image 5.** _Proportion of grey and sanctioned fleets across flag states - Kpler._ Iran and Russia have the largest shares of grey or sanctioned fleets, with 91.4% and 75% of their vessels falling into these categories, respectively. In contrast, Panama, despite having the largest fleet overall, has only 12.8% of its ships involved in grey or sanctioned activities. This trend highlights potential weaknesses in how some countries enforce maritime regulations. ![Picture6.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture6_b354f672f8.png) **Image 6.** _November-over-October changes on proportion of grey and sanctioned fleets across flag states - Kpler._ November-over-October, Gabon, Liberia, and Cook Islands have removed the most grey and sanctioned ships from their registries, demonstrating efforts to mitigate growing risks. However, the Marshall Islands saw the biggest increase, with a 14.3% rise in their grey fleet and a 33.3% rise in sanctioned vessels. But these percentages are misleading since only 1.9% of their fleet falls into the grey or sanctioned categories. ![Picture7.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture7_affead222f.png) **Image 7.** _Proportion of grey and sanctioned fleets across top ISM (International Safety Management) manager countries - Kpler._ The top 10 countries with the most vessels under ISM management have no sanctioned vessels in their fleets. However, there are noticeable differences in the proportions of grey vessels among them. The United Arab Emirates leads with 20.2% grey vessels, followed by Turkey at 18.7%, and India at 9.7%. In comparison, major shipping nations like Greece and Singapore have much lower percentages, with 2.9% and 2.3%, respectively. ![Picture8.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture8_ef60c208ea.png) **Image 8.** _November-over-October changes on proportion of grey and sanctioned fleets across ISM manager countries - Kpler._ From October through November, Japan saw the largest decrease in grey vessels managed by companies based there, while Germany experienced the largest increase. However, since both countries have relatively small grey fleets compared to others, such as the UAE, these changes have a limited impact on the overall risk assessment for these regions. This variation reflects enforcement of regulatory practices among these countries. Understanding these disparities is crucial for policymakers and industry leaders aiming to enhance compliance and strengthen maritime oversight on a global scale. ![Picture9.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture9_e7ecff0e43.png) **Image 9.** _Percentage of unknown ISM manager for the grey and sanctioned fleets - Kpler._ A notable 13.4% of sanctioned vessels and 7.3% of grey fleet ships lack identifiable ISM managers responsible for their safety protocols. This absence of clear safety management undermines regulatory oversight and increases the risk of these vessels participating in deceptive or non-compliant activities. The lack of transparency not only complicates enforcement efforts but also heightens concerns about maritime safety and adherence to international regulations such as IMO’s MARPOL. ![Picture10.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture10_bbd2b978f4.png) **Image 10.** _Percentage of grey and sanctioned fleets involvement in STS with Russian cargo - Kpler._ ![Picture11.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture11_c7fe547259.png) **Image 11.** _November-over-October changes on percentage of grey and sanctioned fleet involvement in STS with Russian cargo - Kpler._ Over the past year, 20.4% of the grey fleet and 26.9% of sanctioned vessels have conducted ship-to-ship (STS) transfers involving Russian cargo. However, in November, the grey fleet decreased. This drop happened because some grey fleet tied to Russian trades was moved to the sanctions list. These high numbers indicate a heavy reliance on these fleets to transport restricted goods, helping to avoid direct bans on Russian exports. Approximately 20% or more of grey and sanctioned ships are involved in ship-to-ship transfers with Russian cargo, highlighting their pivotal role in facilitating trade activities that bypass international sanctions. ![Picture12.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture12_4d45ef6fea.png) **Image 12.** _Oil volumes and flows transported by the grey fleet in the last 30 days - Kpler._ Over the past 30 days, the grey fleet has facilitated the transport of significant volumes of oil from nations with sanctions or restrictions to various global markets. China has benefited the most, importing about 13 million barrels of oil from Russia, Iran, and Saudi Arabia. In total, China received 78 million barrels from these countries, with 17% of these imports using the grey fleet. This shows China’s reliance on this network despite international sanctions. India is also a major player, receiving about 7 million barrels of oil from Russia through the grey fleet. This is part of the 25 million barrels India imported from Russia overall. This indicates a strategic balancing act in India and China’s energy imports, utilising the grey fleet to sustain supplies while sidestepping restrictions. In the Middle East, Turkey and the United Arab Emirates have also actively participated in this trade, collectively importing around 10 million barrels using the grey fleet within November. Altogether, these trade flows highlight the grey fleet’s expansive operational scope, having moved over 101 million barrels of oil in the last 30 days. This scale of activity underscores the fleet’s role in maintaining energy trade dynamics despite international sanctions, exploiting gaps in maritime regulations to keep sanctioned oil moving. Stay tuned for more insights and updates, ensuring that you remain informed and compliant amidst these dynamic regulatory changes. Learn more at: [Kpler Risk & Compliance](https://www.kpler.com/product/commodities/risk-and-compliance). **Definition of grey fleet** A vessel shall be considered as part of the grey fleet (also referred to as the shadow fleet) if a vessel has loaded sanctioned cargo and at least one of these conditions are met: - Vessel ownership structure is opaque or unknown (ISM manager is unknown) - Vessel is not classified by an IACS classification society - Vessel is not insured by an IGP&I member - Vessel age over 20 years old - Dark activity spotted through satellite during AIS Gaps - AIS spoofing detected

headline: US Coast Guard Contains Oil Spill in San Juan, Puerto Rico
author: Raghib Raza
content: The US Coast Guard (USGC) responded to an oil spill in the Puma Energy fuel dock facility at San Juan Harbor, Puerto Rico. The incident involved the spillage of around 3,800 liters of No. 3 fuel oil that occurred during a fuel transfer operation from the Tanker [DUBAI GREEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:370695/mmsi:538010727/imo:9298674/vessel:DUBAI_GREEN) to the facility. ![DUBAI GREEN oil spill in San Juan Harbor, Puerto Rico](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/DUBAI_GREEN_692cdf0049.png)*Oil Product tanker DUBAI GREEN, image credit: Claudio Ritossa* Crewmembers aboard the vessel noticed the spreading sheen on the water, and the fuel transfer operation was immediately halted. USGC watchstanders in the San Juan sector received the oil spill report at around 7:30 PM local time on the evening of 27th November. The US Coast Guard responders arrived promptly and secured the source of the leak. They then proceeded to contain the spill within the dock area, deploying around 300 meters of boom to prevent the spread of oil to the shoreline and the surrounding areas. Following this, efforts will be concentrated on identifying any pockets of oil that have escaped the containment area. The subsequent oil cleanup efforts are being led by the Marine Spill Response Corporation (MSRC). Many other government agencies, such as the Environmental Protection Agency, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, U.S. Fish and Wildlife, and the Puerto Rico Department of Natural and Environmental Resources, are closely monitoring the situation. The USGC has posted a warning to residents and fishermen in the vicinity of the oil spill to refrain from entering the area until clean-up activities are complete. The US Coast Guard has opened an investigation into the matter.

headline: Anemoi to Install Rotor Sails on U Ming’s Very Large Ore Carrier
author: Raghib Raza
content: Wind propulsion technology company Anemoi Marine Technologies has signed an agreement with U-Ming Marine Transport Ltd. (U Ming) for the installation of four rotor sails on a Very Large Ore Carrier owned by (U Ming). The installation is expected to be completed by late 2025. ![GRAND PIONEER to be install with rotor sails.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GRAND_PIONEER_d17a2011e7.png)*Ore Carrier GRAND PIONEER, image credit: Anemoi* The vessel to have the rotor sails installed is a U Ming-owned 325,000 DWT Very Large Ore Carrier, [GRAND PIONEER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6316243/mmsi:563110200/imo:9850331/vessel:GRAND_PIONEER#overview). The new rotor sails will generate wind-powered thrust, reducing fuel expenditure and increasing efficiency. The four sails, each of which is 25 meters tall and 5 meters in diameter, will collectively reduce 10% to 12% in fuel expenditure. The reduction forecast is evaluated on routes between China, Brazil, South Africa, and Australia. Rotor sails, also known as Flettner rotors, are cylindrical structures that create a pressure differential and, hence, generate thrust. The technology has gained much traction in recent years due to the impetus towards sustainable shipping practices.

headline: Port of Holyhead Blocked by Farmers Protesting New Inheritance Tax
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Port of [HOLYHEAD](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/431?name=HOLYHEAD&country=United-Kingdom) in North Wales was blocked by farmers on 27th November. The farmers were protesting the new 20% inheritance tax that will come into effect in 2026. ![HOLYHEAD PORT](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/HOLYHEAD_PORT_2cb379a3e6.png)*HOLYHEAD Port: image credit: Pete Walker* The farmers turned up in a convoy of tractors at around 11:00 PM local time at night. The farmers then proceeded to blockade the roads to the port and stayed till 3:00 AM local time. The protest effectively blocked the entries and exits to the port and caused heavy congestion. Heavy goods vehicles stayed in queues for hours, and passengers were unable to board ferries across the Irish Sea. The traffic congestion eased at around 4:00 AM local time after the farmers dispersed at 3:00 AM local time. A slow-drive protest by farmers at the Dover Ferry port was held earlier that same day. In addition to this, around a week ago, around 10,000 farmers approached Westminster, London, en masse to express their discontentment over the new inheritance tax. Under the previous law, farms had been exempt from paying inheritance tax. However, under the upcoming law in April of 2026, an inheritance that is valued at more than 1 million pounds will be taxed at 20%. Farmers have claimed that while their farms have high valuations, they themselves make little on profit margins. Farmers contend that many of the farmers inheriting ancestral property will be forced to sell parts of their farms in order to cover the tax, thus leading to the fragmentation of the farms and a threat to the food provisions of Britain.

headline: Baltic Sea Cable Damage Linked to YI PENG 3; Sabotage Suspected
author: Raghib Raza
content: Swedish authorities found in an investigation that the Chinese-flagged merchant vessel YI PENG 3 dragging anchor for more than 100 miles was the cause of undersea optic cables being severed. As of now, the vessel [YI PENG 3](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:213234/mmsi:414270000/imo:9224984/vessel:YI_PENG_3#overview) is suspected of sabotage of two undersea optic cables in the Baltic Sea. ![YI PENG 3.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/YI_PENG_3_385495d914.png)*Bulk carrier YI PENG 3, image credit: Hans Berkenhoff* The narrative established by the investigation so far states that the vessel YI PENG 3 departed from the Russian port of Ust Luga on 15 November. Two days later, the vessel dropped anchor at around 9:00 PM local time and continued to sail with its anchor dragging across the seabed. The anchor then severed the undersea optic cable connecting Sweden and Lithuania. Following this, the vessel continued sailing for an additional 111 miles and severed yet another cable, this one connecting Finland with Germany. Investigators and industry experts have expressed their skepticism with the idea of the vessel’s crew remaining oblivious to a dragging anchor. Experts at Kpler have stated that given that weather conditions were mild and waves were within manageable height, the chances of anchor dropping accidentally are minimal. As of now the [YI PENG 3](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:213234/mmsi:414270000/imo:9224984/vessel:YI_PENG_3#overview) is anchored less than one nautical mile from the coast of Denmark in the Kattegat Strait. The naval forces of Denmark are monitoring it closely but are unable to board the vessel and interrogate the crew, stymied by geopolitics and international law. Negotiations with Chinese authorities are ongoing to allow further investigation. Swedish Prime Minister Ulf Kristersson has stated that they are not accusing the crew of the YI PENG 3 of any wrongdoing but has asserted that this is not the first time an incident of this kind has happened, and they want to investigate it further. Western officials believe that despite the vessel having a Chinese registration and being owned by a Chinese company, the incident was arranged by Russian agencies. German and Finnish foreign ministers released a joint statement on 18th November implying Russian involvement in the incident. The joint statement claimed the incident to be suspicious and Russian aggression against Ukraine to be a threat to European security. Russian spokesperson Dmitry Peskov issued a statement on 20 November disavowing any Russian involvement in the incident, stating that the accusations had no ground. Lin Jian from the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs denied any knowledge of a Chinese vessel being linked with the sabotage of undersea cables. A Chinese ministry spokesperson confirmed that they are in contact with relevant parties, including Denmark, to resolve the situation. Undersea cables are well charted and rupturing them accidentally is highly improbable. However there are fears of malicious actors purposely severing undersea cables, which are crucial to the digital infrastructure and are extremely difficult to repair. Severing of an undersea cable by a civilian vessel is not construed as an act of aggression by itself as there is no concrete evidence tying the incident to a state agenda. In 2023, Taiwanese authorities accused two Chinese vessels of severing the only two cables that supplied internet to the Taiwanese Matsu Islands. These two cables ended up being cut separately by a cargo vessel and a fishing vessel within the same day on 2 February 2023. The Taiwanese ruling Democratic Progressive Party also highlighted that there had been 27 instances from 2018 to 2023 where Chinese vessels had caused cable disruptions. Then there is the much highlighted case of the [NEWNEW POLAR BEAR ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3162/mmsi:477893800/imo:9313204/vessel:NEWNEW_POLAR_BEAR#overview)which cut two cables and a gas pipeline last year by dragging an anchor across them. Given the context of rising tensions, such incidents are being viewed as a form of hybrid warfare, a way to undermine the opponent without openly engaging in conflict.

headline: Maersk Welcomes its Newest Methanol Dual Fuel Container Vessel in Singapore
author: Raghib Raza
content: The newest addition to the Maersk fleet, the [AP MOLLER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9090689/mmsi:219677000/imo:9948803/vessel:A_P_MOLLER#overview), arrived in Singapore on the 28th of November. This is the nineth vessel in Maersk’s fleet that is capable of operating on methanol, and was named in a ceremony held by Maersk in Singapore. ![A.P.MOLLER arrived Singapore as a part of its maiden voyage from Asia to Europe.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/A_P_MOLLER_9234aa70b7.png)*Containership AP MOLLER, image credit: MAERSK* The vessel is one of 18 dual-fuel methanol container vessels on order at Hyundai Heavy Industries in Ulsan, South Korea. Seven of these vessels were inducted into the Maersk fleet in 2024, and the remaining are to be delivered by 2025. The [AP MOLLER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9090689/mmsi:219677000/imo:9948803/vessel:A_P_MOLLER#overview) is a container ship flagged in Denmark. The vessel has a length of 351 meters, a beam of 54 meters, and a gross tonnage of 172,093. The vessel can carry 16,592 containers. Maersk has highlighted that these methanol-dual fuel-powered vessels are a significant piece of their decarbonization goal of reaching net zero emissions by 2040.

headline: Former Cruise Ship “Orient Princess “ Catches Fire in Tianjin City, China
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 18th November, a fire broke out aboard the cruise vessel [ORIENT PRINCESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:949191/mmsi:-6708109/imo:6708109/vessel:ORIENT_PRINCESS#overview) in Tianjin, China. The fire has since been extinguished, and no casualties have been reported in the incident. ![Fire aboard ORIENT PRINCESS](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ORIENT_PRINCESS_bee161bf1e.png)*Vessel Orient Princess caught fire, image credit:imarinenews.com* The fire aboard the vessel reportedly broke out around 2:00 PM local time. Emergency responders quickly arrived at the scene and put out the fire by 3:00 PM. According to the management of the [ORIENT PRINCESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:949191/mmsi:-6708109/imo:6708109/vessel:ORIENT_PRINCESS#overview), the blaze was caused by sparks that ignited insulation material during ongoing renovation work on the vessel. The [ORIENT PRINCESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:949191/mmsi:-6708109/imo:6708109/vessel:ORIENT_PRINCESS#overview) was built as a cruise vessel in December of 1966 and was formerly known as "Yao Hua." However, due to legal complications, the vessel was seized by authorities in 2003. Another Chinese company subsequently took over the vessel and converted it to an accommodation vessel, mooring it permanently in Tianjin as a tourist attraction. The vessel now sports two restaurants that were built atop the former cruise vessel.

headline: Cargo Vessel WILSON CAEN Collides with Pier in the Kiel Canal
author: Raghib Raza
content: The cargo vessel [WILSON CAEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:378641/mmsi:314179000/imo:9173290/vessel:WILSON_CAEN#overview) collided with a pier in the Brunsbuttel lock system within the Kiel Canal on 18th November. The incident occurred at around 12:35 PM local time when the vessel was traveling from Naples. ![WILSON CAEN collided with Pier in the Kiel Canal.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/WILSON_CAEN_0fe01768f8.png)*Vessel WILSON CAEN, image credit: Asbjorn Aamaas* The vessel [WILSON CAEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:378641/mmsi:314179000/imo:9173290/vessel:WILSON_CAEN#overview) was loaded with 2,824 tons of bulk waste when the incident occurred. As the vessel approached the lock system, the rudder of the vessel failed, and it ended up striking the bank fortification of Pier 2. The ship sustained an 11-meter-long scrape across its portside bow, but no accounts of pollution or injuries were reported. Authorities detained the [WILSON CAEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:378641/mmsi:314179000/imo:9173290/vessel:WILSON_CAEN) for seaworthiness, following which the vessel was released at around 6:00 PM the same day. The vessel has now resumed its journey. The [WILSON CAEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:378641/mmsi:314179000/imo:9173290/vessel:WILSON_CAEN#overview) is a Barbados-flagged general cargo vessel that was built in 1998. The vessel is 99.9 meters long, 12.8 meters wide, and has a gross tonnage of 2,999.

headline: Woodchip Carrier SDM TAICANG Collides with Two Tankers Off Gresik Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: The woodchip carrier [SDM TAICANG ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7733342/mmsi:636022817/imo:9949223/vessel:SDM_TAICANG)collided with two anchored vessels near the port of Gresik on 11th November. No injuries have been reported, and none of the vessels involved have sustained significant damage. The incident occurred off the port of Gresik. The vessel [SDM TAICANG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7733342/mmsi:636022817/imo:9949223/vessel:SDM_TAICANG) reportedly suffered from a system blackout, which led to a complete loss of control. The moving vessel then collided with two tankers anchored nearby. ![SDM TAICANG collision near the port of Gresik.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SDM_TAICANG_fe3f63fa29.png)*Vessel SDM TAICANG, image credit: Instagram/maritimeuniverse* One of the tankers was damaged on the port side, and no crew were reported to be injured in the incident. The [SDM TAICANG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7733342/mmsi:636022817/imo:9949223/vessel:SDM_TAICANG) has since departed for Singapore and is expected to reach there by 20 November. The [SDM TAICANG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7733342/mmsi:636022817/imo:9949223/vessel:SDM_TAICANG) is a Liberian-flagged woodchip carrier that was built in 2023. The vessel has a length of 210 meters, a width of 37 meters, and a gross tonnage of 53,015.

headline: AAL Shipping Welcomes Newest Methanol-Ready Vessel to its fleet
author: Raghib Raza
content: Singapore-based multipurpose cargo shipping company AAL Shipping welcomed its newest methanol-ready heavy lift vessel, [AAL ANTWERP](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8908754/mmsi:255915732/imo:0/vessel:AAL_ANTWERP), to its fleet in a naming ceremony held in Guangzhou, China. The vessel can transport 90,000 tons of freight cargo. ![AAL Antwerp join the AAL Shipping fleet.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/AAL_Antwerp_cf695936be.png)*Vessel AAL Antwerp, image credit: AAL Shipping* The [AAL ANTWERP](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8908754/mmsi:255915732/imo:0/vessel:AAL_ANTWERP) is the fourth of the eight vessels in the Super B Class to be delivered to AAL. The vessel was built and then subsequently named at the CSSC Huangpu-Wenchong Shipyard in Guangzhou. It is capable of transporting 90,000 tons of freight cargo and has a heavy lift capacity of 700 tons. Three vessels of the Super B class, namely the[ AAL LIMASSOL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8575085/mmsi:210232000/imo:9958755/vessel:AAL_LIMASSOL), [AAL HAMBURG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8803308/mmsi:255915731/imo:9958767/vessel:AAL_HAMBURG), and the [AAL HOUSTON](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8880087/mmsi:255915733/imo:0/vessel:AAL_HOUSTON), have already been delivered. The newest, [AAL ANTWERP](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8908754/mmsi:255915732/imo:0/vessel:AAL_ANTWERP), will soon join these vessels in shuttling cargo between Asia, Europe, the Middle East, and America. The remaining four vessels of the Super B Class are expected to be delivered to AAL by 2026. Two of these upcoming vessels, the AAL Mumbai and the AAL Newcastle, will have an increased heavy lift capacity of 800 tons.

headline: INDAH FAJAR Suffers Severe Listing, at Sunda Kelapa Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Ministry of Transportation of Republic of Indonesia Directorate General of Sea Transport in its press release on 16th November stated that a 685-gross-ton cargo vessel, [INDAH FAJAR](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4910699/mmsi:525022019/imo:8824244/vessel:INDAH_FAJAR), ran aground while maneuvering at berth due to a shift that led to the ship's listing and water ingress. ![INDAH FAJAR listed in Indonesian water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/INDAH_FAJAR_59f29f53cf.png)*Vessel INDAH FAJAR listed in Indonesian water,image credit:hubla.dephub.go.id* The cargo vessel [INDAH FAJAR](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4910699/mmsi:525022019/imo:8824244/vessel:INDAH_FAJAR) was en route from Taremba to Port Kijang, and at the the time of the incident, the vessel was trying to shift from the Eastern new Pier to Pier 06S within the Sunda Kelapa Port. The vessel initially started to list leftwards by around 10 to 15 degrees, and despite various measures, the ship ended up being listed to the right by 10 degrees. Oil booms have been laid out around the listed vessel so as to mitigate risks of pollution. The cargo is being offloaded from the vessel so as to stabilize it.

headline: Navigating the Complexities of Maritime Sanctions: An October 2024 Overview
author: Dimitris Ampatzidis
content: **Overview** October 2024 marked a surge in maritime sanctions as regulatory bodies like OFAC and OFSI expanded their sanctions lists, with 33 and 20 vessels respectively, intensifying scrutiny on high-risk vessels engaged in potentially deceptive practices. This collective action marked a year-on-year surge, with an increase of 242 vessels added to international sanctions rosters. The most significant growth was noted among vessels flagged by Russia (33), Panama (30), Comoros (11), and Guyana (9). **Main Updates** In late October, the G7 reinforced its stance on addressing the evasion of Russian oil sanctions, which directly impacts maritime shipping and the transport of energy commodities ([The Guardian, 2024](https://www.theguardian.com/world/2024/oct/26/g7-vows-to-clamp-down-on-russias-oil-sanctions-evasion); [UK Government, 2024](https://www.gov.uk/government/news/uk-strikes-at-the-heart-of-russian-energy-revenues-funding-putins-war?utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=govuk-notifications-topic&utm_source=13aad6c3-cde5-4ffa-bb5c-ff999f5948bd&utm_content=immediately)). The updated guidance aims to prevent deceptive practices, such as misreporting cargo origins and ship-to-ship transfers, which circumvent Russian crude price caps ([G7, 2024](https://assets.publishing.service.gov.uk/media/6709446c92bb81fcdbe7b732/G7_Updated_Guidance_for_Industry_-_Preventing_Russian_Export_Control_and_Sanctions_Evasion.pdf)). The UK government has strengthened these measures by introducing new restrictions specifically targeting Russia's revenue generation through maritime routes ([UK Government, 2024](https://www.gov.uk/government/news/uk-strikes-at-the-heart-of-russian-energy-revenues-funding-putins-war?utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=govuk-notifications-topic&utm_source=13aad6c3-cde5-4ffa-bb5c-ff999f5948bd&utm_content=immediately)). These sanctions target UK shipping services, such as insurance and reinsurance, to hinder the transport of Russian liquefied natural gas (LNG). Compliance teams within the shipping industry now face the challenge of ensuring that their operations align with these newly expanded restrictions, which include more rigorous checks on vessel activities and ownership details to prevent indirect support of sanctioned entities ([Mayer Brown, 2024](https://www.mayerbrown.com/en/insights/publications/2024/11/russia-ukraine-sanctions-update-month-of-october)). **Analysis of Sanctioned Vessels and Companies** ![Sanctioned vessels and companies through the years.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Sanctioned_vessels_and_companies_through_the_years_027a9fe29a.png) **Graph 1.** _Sanctioned vessels and companies through the years - Kpler._ ![Sanctioned vessels per top 10 flag registry through the years.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Sanctioned_vessels_per_top_10_flag_registry_through_the_years_ca00970c6b.png) **Graph 2.** _Sanctioned vessels per top 10 flag registry through the years - Kpler._ In October 2024, sanctions in the shipping industry increased sharply, mainly focusing on vessels rather than the companies managing them. More than 50 new vessels were added to the sanctions list, raising the total from just over 900 at the beginning of the month to nearly 1,000. Meanwhile, the number of sanctioned companies stayed about the same, nearing 400, without the same sharp increase seen in vessels. This difference shows that authorities are focusing on stopping certain vessel operations instead of targeting the companies behind them. Overall, October 2024 stands out as a month of intensified sanctions, with a clear focus on vessels involved in high-risk trading activities. Examining pre-sanction behaviours offers vital insights into the nuances of maritime risk management and underscores the importance of diligent oversight in mitigating compliance challenges. **Risk & Compliance findings before the October 2024 sanctions** The crude oil tanker LUNA PRIME serves as a useful example, as it showed activities that raised compliance concerns before sanctions were applied. This case shows the challenges of assessing risks in maritime operations, especially when dealing with sanctioned or restricted cargo, possible tampering with AIS, and engaging in high-risk STS transfers. ![LUNE PRIME risks .jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LUNE_PRIME_risks_029926e5c9.jpg) **Image 1.** _LUNA PRIME risks - Kpler._ LUNA PRIME exhibited multiple risks even before recent sanctions were applied. The biggest concerns include direct links to sanctioned cargo from Iran and Venezuela (HS 270900), which were mostly transported through ship-to-ship (STS) transfers. Additionally, the vessel has a pattern of frequent and long AIS signal gaps, sometimes lasting over twenty hours. ![LUNA PRIME connections to Iranian cargo.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LUNA_PRIME_connections_to_Iranian_cargo_f62e5129f1.jpg) **Image 2.** _LUNA PRIME connections to Iranian cargo - Kpler._ In addition to the operational patterns we discussed earlier, the vessel has an interesting and concerning Port State Control history from the Paris and Tokyo MOUs. It has undergone multiple inspections, resulting in over five deficiencies and one detention for three days in Qingdao, China, back in 2022. This poor performance highlights the safety and security issues the vessel is dealing with. Notably, the responsibility for addressing these issues lies with the ISM manager, RUNFENG SHIPMANAGEMENT CO LTD, whose oversight is crucial to maintaining compliance and ensuring vessel safety. ![LUNA PRIME concerning performance on PSC .jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LUNA_PRIME_concerning_performance_on_PSC_47b570641b.jpg) **Image 3.** _LUNA PRIME concerning performance on PSC - Kpler._ The vessel's operational history raises significant concerns: - AIS Gaps: Since 2022, there have been at least 17 high-risk AIS (Automatic Identification System) gaps exceeding 20 hours each. Some of these gaps coincide with reported changes in the vessel's draught, suggesting potential undisclosed loading or unloading activities. - High-Risk STS Transfers: In 2022, the vessel was involved in four high-risk ship-to-ship (STS) transfers, transporting sanctioned cargo from Iran and Venezuela. - Dark STS Transfers: In 2023 and 2024, three "dark" STS transfers were identified, during which the vessel's AIS signal was deliberately turned off to conceal its activities. These covert operations were detected using satellite imagery, machine learning algorithms, and human intelligence, underscoring the vessel's attempts to evade monitoring. These patterns indicate deliberate efforts to obscure the vessel's operations, posing significant safety, security, and compliance risks. Such actions, including recurrent AIS gaps and 'dark' STS transfers, suggest intentional evasion tactics. ![LUNA PRIME operational risks overview.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LUNA_PRIME_operational_risks_overview_1e50592586.jpg) **Image 4.** _LUNA PRIME operational risks overview - Kpler._ ![LUNA PRIME dark STS transfers.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LUNA_PRIME_dark_STS_transfers_ce61841173.jpg) **Image 5.** _LUNA PRIME dark STS transfers - Kpler._ In conclusion, these findings reveal substantial operational risks, including multiple AIS signal gaps, sanctioned cargo transfers, and deliberate 'dark' activities to evade detection. These trends reveal significant gaps in transparency and adherence to global safety and compliance norms. As regulatory pressures escalate, companies must proactively audit operational histories and develop compliance frameworks that integrate real-time monitoring technologies. This approach is essential to mitigate the substantial legal and reputational risks posed by association with high-risk vessels. Stay tuned for more insights and updates, ensuring that you remain informed and compliant amidst these dynamic regulatory changes.
