headline: CMA CGM takes Delivery of New LNG-Powered Vessel
author: Raghib Raza
content: CMA CGM took delivery of the newest LNG-powered vessel in its fleet, the [CMA CGM FORT DIAMANT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9128831/mmsi:228469700/imo:9966776/vessel:CMA_CGM_FORT_DIAMANT), on 18th November. This vessel was built by Samsung Heavy Industries in South Korea and is the third ship in its series. ![CMA CGM FORT DIAMANT delivered to CMA CGM.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CMA_CGM_FORT_DIAMANT_9c088817dd.png)*Vessel CMA CGM FORT DIAMANT,image credit: CMA CGM* The[ CMA CGM FORT DIAMANT ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9128831/mmsi:228469700/imo:9966776/vessel:CMA_CGM_FORT_DIAMANT)is an LNG-powered container ship registered in France. The vessel has a length of 268 meters, a beam of 43 meters, and a gross tonnage of 73,000. CMA CGM took delivery of two more vessels of the series earlier in the year. These vessels, the [CMA CGM FORT BOURBON](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8822013/mmsi:228466800/imo:9966752/vessel:CMA_CGM_FORT_BOURBON) and the[ CMA CGM FORT JAMES](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8889185/mmsi:228468900/imo:9966764/vessel:CMA_CGM_FORT_JAMES), are also LNG-powered vessels with similar capacity. The final vessel in the series is expected to be delivered to CMA CGM in January next year.

headline: Passenger Ro-Ro Vessel ANDREAS KALVOS Allies with a Quay in Greece
author: Raghib Raza
content: The passenger Ro-Ro vessel[ ANDREAS KALVOS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:207953/mmsi:237416000/imo:8500484/vessel:ANDREAS_KALVOS) allied with a quay in [SAMI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/599?name=SAMI&country=Greece), Kefalonia, Greece, on 17th November. ![ANDREAS KALVOS collided with a quay in Greece water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ANDREAS_KALVOS_f01e4d2275.png)*Ro-Ro vessel ANDREAS KALVOS, image credit: Sakis Antoniou* The [ANDREAS KALVOS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:207953/mmsi:237416000/imo:8500484/vessel:ANDREAS_KALVOS) was traveling the route between Patras and Ithaca when the incident occurred. The vessel was loaded with 157 passengers, 33 crew members, 32 cars, 3 trucks, and 3 buses at the time the vessel collided with the quay. The vessel was damaged on the starboard side of the stern. The Sami Port Department of the Kefallinia Port Authority has demanded a seaworthiness certificate of the Ro-Ro vessel before it is allowed to sail any more and has banned the vessel from sailing for the time being. All passengers are reported to be safe, and no marine pollution has been reported so far.

headline: MAERSK HALIFAX Upgraded for Methanol and Conventional Fuel Use
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Singapore-flagged [MAERSK HALIFAX ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5114854/mmsi:563030500/imo:9784271/vessel:MAERSK_HALIFAX#overview)was converted by Maersk to be methanol dual fuel capable. The conversion was performed at the Zhoushan Xinya Shipyard in China and was completed by the end of October. ![MAERSK HALIFAX converted to methanol dual fuel.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MAERSK_HALIFAX_a929885f7f.png)*Vessel MAERSK HALIFAX, image credit: MAERSK* The [MAERSK HALIFAX](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5114854/mmsi:563030500/imo:9784271/vessel:MAERSK_HALIFAX#overview) was converted to be dual fuel capable, being able to run on both methanol and conventional fuels. The conversion process took 88 days, and construction on the vessel was completed by the end of October, with the vessel sailing out of the yard on 4th November. The engine modification was carried out by MAN Energy Solutions. In addition to the engine modifications, the vessel was fitted with additional fuel tanks, a fuel preparation room, and a fuel supply system. In order to accommodate the new fuel tanks, the hull of the vessel had to be extended by 15 meters, thus increasing the overall length of the vessel to 368 meters and increasing the vessel’s capacity to 15,690 TEU. The [MAERSK HALIFAX](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5114854/mmsi:563030500/imo:9784271/vessel:MAERSK_HALIFAX#overview) is reported to have already completed its sea trials and returned to operation, serving trans-Pacific routes.

headline: Panama-flagged Ship Blocks Traffic Along the Bosphorus Strait due to Rudder Failure
author: Raghib Raza
content: The 4,607 dwt vessel [NAZAN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:335238/mmsi:371125000/imo:9373747/vessel:NAZAN), traveling from Novorossiysk, suffered a rudder failure as it was crossing the Bosphorus Strait on 17th November. The stalled vessel blocked all traffic across the strait for 4 hours. ![Vessel Nazan suffered malfunctioning while crossing the Bosphorus Strait.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NAZAN_784bd2f34f.png)*Vessel NAZAN, image credit : KEGM* The ship was traveling across the Bosphorus Strait when it suffered from engine failure around Kandili, the most treacherous part of the crossing. Authorities announced the closure of the strait at 18:42 GMT and responded quickly, dispatching the tugboats KURTARMA 7 and KURTARMA 9, which towed the vessel out of the strait. The Panama-flagged [NAZAN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:335238/mmsi:371125000/imo:9373747/vessel:NAZAN) is currently anchored at the [ISTANBUL Anchorage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/22433?name=ISTANBUL-ANCH&country=Turkey) in the Sea of Marmara.

headline: German LNG Terminal Rejects Vessel Carrying Russian LNG
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Deutsche Energy terminal in Brunsbuttel, Germany, rejected a vessel carrying Russian shipment of LNG from Yamal LNG. ![FEDOR LITKE.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FEDOR_LITKE_f9f5ab9ace.png)*Vessel FEDOR LITKE, image credit: Geir Vinnes* The incoming vessel, which is conjectured to be the [FEDOR LITKE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5062832/mmsi:212660000/imo:9768370/vessel:FEDOR_LITKE), was turned away on 14th November. The delivery was set to arrive in Brunsbuttel on 17th November. According to reports, the German ministry, via a letter, instructed the state-operated Deutsche terminal not to accept deliveries of LNG that have a Russian origin. The German government, in its letter, cited “overriding public interests” as the reason for the rejection. However, it is important to note that the Russian LNG is still imported in Germany via the German state-owned energy firm Sefe from the Arctic Russian LNG project. Russian gas still accounts for around 15% to 20% of the European supply. LNG is imported owing to longstanding contracts and then redistributed throughout the continent via the European interconnected gas network.

headline: PIL Launches Iraq Feeder Service to Strengthen Middle East Connectivity
author: Raghib Raza
content: Pacific International Lines (PIL) started a new feeder service on 15 November called the Iraq Feeder Service. The new service will connect [JEBEL ALI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/102?name=JEBEL-ALI&country=United-Arab-Emirates) Port in the UAE with [UMM QASR](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1008?name=UMM-QASR&country=Iraq) Port in Iraq. ![Kota Handal undertake a voyage to PIL's new feeder service](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KOTA_HANDAL_407954073c.png)*Vessel KOTA HANDAL, image credit: Hans Rosenkranz* The new service will offer weekly transports, and the first vessel to undertake a voyage on this route was the vessel [KOTA HANDAL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:725913/mmsi:563137700/imo:9272981/vessel:KOTA_HANDAL). The port rotation will be Jebel Ali -Umm Qasr - Jebel Ali, and the expected transit time is 2 days. PIL intends to enhance connectivity between the Middle East and the rest of PIL’s network, capitalizing on the growing demand for maritime service in the Middle East.

headline: Update: Ship Passing Through the Red Sea Reports Being Targeted by Missiles
author: Raghib Raza
content: A vessel passing through the Red Sea, at a location around 25 nautical miles off the coast of Al Mukha, Yemen, reported splashes from a missile hitting the water in the vicinity of the vessel. ![ANADOLU S.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ANADOLU_S_0d3f62ee3e.png)*Vessel ANADOLU S, image credit: Max Wei* The incident occurred on 17th November when the vessel was passing through the Red Sea near Al-Mukha, Yemen. The company security officer reported a splash from a missile hitting the waters near the vessel. According to the British maritime security agency United Kingdom Maritime Trade Operations (UKMTO), the captain of the vessel reported a second attack the next day, on 18th November, when the vessel was around 60 nautical miles southeast of Aden, Yemen. UKMTO identified the targeted vessel as [ANADOLU S](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:464790/mmsi:373312000/imo:9667758/vessel:ANADOLU_S#overview). The vessel and its crew were reported to be unharmed and heading to their next port of call. On 19th November, the Houthi Spokesperson claimed responsibility for the attack on [ANADOLU S](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:464790/mmsi:373312000/imo:9667758/vessel:ANADOLU_S#overview); however, contrary to the claims by the captain, they claim to have hit the vessel successfully. Bahrain-based Combat Task Force stated that the vessel was indeed targeted twice, but both missiles missed their target. [ANADOLU S](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:464790/mmsi:373312000/imo:9667758/vessel:ANADOLU_S#overview) is a Panamanian-flagged bulk carrier. Marine Traffic data shows that the 2014-built vessel is scheduled to arrive at [PORT QASIM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/289?name=PORT-QASIM&country=Pakistan), Pakistan, by 23rd November.

headline: Norway-flagged Bulker Carrier SPAR INDUS Runs Aground in the Gulf of Arauco, Chile
author: Raghib Raza
content: The bulk carrier [SPAR INDUS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3919456/mmsi:258775000/imo:9734991/vessel:SPAR_INDUS#overview) ran aground in the Boca Chica region of the Gulf of Arauco on the night of 13th November. The vessel ran aground around 3.5 nautical miles off of Punta Cochinos in Santa Maria Island, Chile. ![SPAR INDUS ran aground.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SPAR_INDUS_5758474fd7.png)*Vessel SPAR INDUS, image credit:diarioconcepcion.cl* The incident was promptly reported to the Maritime Governorate of Talcahuano, which deployed the patrol vessel Talcahuano to assist the grounded vessel. All the 21 crewmembers were reported to be unharmed. An inspection carried out by a group of divers revealed that there was no structural damage to the hull and there was no pollution from the vessel. The vessel refloated early on the morning of 14th November. It then dropped anchor at [CORONEL Anchorage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/22686?name=CORONEL-ANCH&country=Chile).

headline: ZeroNorth's eBDN System to Transform Bunkering Operations at Rotterdam Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: The commodities trading company Vitol and the marine technology company ZeroNorth are working with the Port of [ROTTERDAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2036?name=ROTTERDAM&country=Netherlands) to launch a trial for the use of digital bunker delivery notes in bunkering. ![ROTTERDAM PORT.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ROTTERDAM_PORT_2023cdfb47.png)*Image credit: Port of Rotterdam* During this four-week trial, the partners will carry out around three to four bunker deliveries at the port of [ROTTERDAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2036?name=ROTTERDAM&country=Netherlands) using ZeroNorth's eBDN system. The first digital bunker delivery has already been successfully completed as part of the trial. The project is expected to demonstrate the benefits of using electronic bunker delivery notes in terms of time savings during bunkering, increased operational efficiency, and more comprehensive and improved data quality. The parties intend to fully integrate the eBDN system into the port of Rotterdam's operations in time. The port of Rotterdam follows the example of Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, which was the first to mandate the use of eBDNs in buildings. The eBDN system automates processes such as documentation, which will minimize administrative burdens for the crews. The system allows for swift verification of fuel quantities purchased and reduces risks associated with human errors. In addition to this, the system will be easy to integrate with the existing workflows of suppliers and regulatory compliance systems. The initiative was developed by ZeroNorth and was launched in September last year. The eBDN system was approved by the International Maritime Organization (IMO) at the 80th session of the Marine Environment Protection Committee.

headline: Containership DALI Arrives in Fuzhou for Extensive Repairs Following Francis Scott Key Bridge Collision
author: Raghib Raza
content: The containership[ DALI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2810451/mmsi:563004200/imo:9697428/vessel:DALI) arrived at the Fuzhou Port in China on 13 November after a nearly two-month journey from [NORFOLK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/136?name=NORFOLK&country=USA), Virginia. The vessel has already undergone some repairs and is to be repaired more extensively at the Fujian Huadong Shipyard in the Luoyuan Bay Port Area. ![Dali arrived China for repair.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/DALI_VESSEL_e45d89f478.png)*Vessel DALI,image credit: Norbert Wichmann* The [DALI ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2810451/mmsi:563004200/imo:9697428/vessel:DALI)gained its infamy for colliding with the Francis Scott Key Bridge, which caused significant portions of the bridge to collapse and fall into the water. The collapse resulted in the deaths of six workers and damages of around $1.7 to $1.9 billion. The [DALI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2810451/mmsi:563004200/imo:9697428/vessel:DALI) suffered extensive damage due to a section of the bridge falling on the bow of the vessel. The repair plans include a complete replacement of the bow due to the incident. The port officials stated that it was challenging to bring the vessel properly into port due to the extensive damage to the vessel. The vessel has no functioning anchors, and much of the machinery, including the thrusters, was damaged in the accident. No timeline has been stated for the repairs of the vessel. Meanwhile, litigation against the vessel's owner and operator is still ongoing and expected to extend to mid-2026. The owner, Grace Ocean, and the operator, Synergy Marine, have invoked an 1800s admiralty law to limit their liabilities to $44 million, whereas authorities state that the admiralty law in question is obsolete and are seeking the remuneration of all damages incurred. The[ DALI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2810451/mmsi:563004200/imo:9697428/vessel:DALI) is a Singapore-flagged container ship that was built in 2015. The vessel is 299 meters long, has a beam of 48.2 meters, and has a gross tonnage of 95,128.

headline: Hole Torn in the Hull of Ro-Ro vehicle Carrier While Docking at Port Kingstown
author: Raghib Raza
content: The vessel [SPLENDID ACE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:416396/mmsi:431349000/imo:9252228/vessel:SPLENDID_ACE#overview) had a hole torn in its hull as it was docking at the cruise ship berth of Port [KINGSTOWN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/3027?name=KINGSTOWN&country=St-Vincent-Grenadines) in St. Vincent on the morning of 10th November. ![SPLENDID ACE.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SPLENDID_ACE_7e078bba98.png)*Vessel SPLENDID ACE, image credit: St.VincentTimes* The hole appeared on the starboard forward hull, just above the waterline. As of now, it is conjectured that the vessel collided with an underwater object while attempting to berth. Meanwhile, the vessel has been sufficiently offloaded so that the hole remains well above the waterline, and there is no intrusion of water in the vessel. The[ SPLENDID ACE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:416396/mmsi:431349000/imo:9252228/vessel:SPLENDID_ACE#overview) is a 2003-built Pure Truck and Car Carrier (PCTC) that is registered in Japan. The vessel is 198 meters long, 32.2 meters wide, and has a gross tonnage of 56,556.

headline: Container Ship RHINE MAERSK Diverts to Port of Tenerife After Onboard Fire Incident
author: Raghib Raza
content: The container ship [RHINE MAERSK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:755552/mmsi:219126000/imo:9456991/vessel:RHINE_MAERSK#overview) was forced to dock at the Port of [TENERIFE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1731?name=TENERIFE&country=Spain) on 10th November after a fire broke out on one of its containers. The vessel was headed from [ABIDJAN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1150?name=ABIDJAN&country=Ivory-Coast) in West Africa to [ALGECIRAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/185?name=ALGECIRAS&country=Spain) in Spain. ![A fire broke aboard RHINE MAERSK.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RHINE_MAERSK_7f597a0413.png)*Vessel RHINE MAERSK, image credit: Francisco Martín* Reports from the crew state that the fire broke out on one of its containers, which ended up spreading to other nearby containers. The crew acted promptly, and the fire was brought under control. However, to completely extinguish the fire, the vessel diverted to the nearby Port of [TENERIFE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1731?name=TENERIFE&country=Spain) . The fire was extinguished with the help of shore-based firefighters. Affected containers were injected with water, and the neighboring containers were simultaneously cooled, leading to the fire being successfully extinguished. The vessel resumed its journey after unloading the containers damaged by the fire. The [RHINE MAERSK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:755552/mmsi:219126000/imo:9456991/vessel:RHINE_MAERSK#overview) is a 2012-built, Denmark-flagged container ship. The vessel has a length of 249 meters, a beam of 37.4 meters, and a gross tonnage of 50,885.

headline: Potential Second Strike on US Ports Looms Large as Negotiations Between ILA and USMX Break Down
author: Raghib Raza
content: The ongoing negotiations between the International Longshoremen's Association (ILA) and the United States Maritime Alliance (USMX) have once again broken down. The main point of contention is the potential automation in the ports, which could lead to workers losing their jobs. ![ILA.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ILA_943336c190.png)*ILA, image credit: International Longshoremen's Association (ILA)* The last tentative agreement of the ILA and the USMX was reached after strikes on the US East and Gulf Coasts that lasted for three days. While the ILA and the USMX reached an agreement on pay raises, negotiations on other major points of contention, such as automation, were forestalled. The next deadline offered by the ILA was 15 January 2025. However, the negotiations broke down after only two days, with the ILA alleging that the USMX is pushing to use automation in ports, which will reduce the number of jobs for port workers. USMX, on the other hand, states that a measure of automation is imperative if the port is to see continued modernization. USMX insists that they are not seeking to use the kind of technology that would eliminate jobs at ports, but their focus is on increased efficiency, capacity, and worker safety. The ILA has threatened strikes again should USMX not agree to their demands by 15 January. Experts state that a strike in January would not be as devastating as there are lower volumes of cargo passing through ports at that time of year.

headline: Canadian Government Steps In, Ends Ongoing Labor Strikes At Canadian Ports
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Canadian government announced on 12th November that they were ending the ongoing strikes on major Canadian ports of [MONTREAL ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/208?name=MONTREAL&country=Canada)and [VANCOUVER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/682?name=VANCOUVER&country=Canada). Labor minister Steven MacKinnon announced that an arbitration that would be binding on both the workers and employers would be used to resolve the disputes. ![Canadian Government step in to end Port Stike.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MONTREAL_Port_52ea4a2ed0.png)*MONTRAL PORT, image credit: Marc Pingoud* The intervention involved the Canadian Industrial Relations Board stepping in and mandating the resumption of operations at the ports, along with the use of arbitration for any further negotiations. The government decision comes after negotiations between the employers and the worker's unions completely ceased. MacKinnon stated that the ongoing strikes were costing the country $932 million every day and that it was the government's responsibility to keep the economy running. This has naturally invited criticism from the workers' unions, including International Longshore and Warehouse Union Local 514 (ILWU), which has announced that it will challenge the government's decision in court. This is the second time in the last few months that the Canadian government has stepped in to resolve deadlocks between employers and workers. The last instance was the major railway lockouts in August this year.

headline: Captain Fined for Discharge of Scrubber Waste Carried Out Without his Knowledge
author: Raghib Raza
content: The captain of the vessel [SEAFORCE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2707818/mmsi:256238000/imo:9685487/vessel:SEAFORCE#overview) was fined 50,000 Euros (around $55,000) for the discharge of around one million liters of scrubber wash water off Fos-Sur-Mer in France. Despite the captain claiming that the discharge was carried out without his knowledge, the court ultimately fined him anyway, upholding that the captain was responsible for ensuring compliance. ![Captain of vessel SEAFORCE fined for scubber discharge](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SEAFORCE_8633459b61.png)*Bulk carrier SEAFORCE, image credit: Morten Weesgaard* The actual incident dates back to March 2023, when the vessel [SEAFORCE ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2707818/mmsi:256238000/imo:9685487/vessel:SEAFORCE#overview)discharged a million liters of scrubber waste in the waters of Fos-Sur-Mer, France. Such discharges have been banned in France since 1st January 2022. Initially, the charges against the captain were not as severe, having a maximum possible penalty of 4000 euros. However, at a hearing in November 2023, the prosecutor's office reclassified the offense as pollution of the territorial sea, which is a more severe offense and carries a maximum penalty of 100,000 euros. The prosecutor's office also dismissed the claim of the captain being unaware of the discharge, stating that it was the captain's responsibility to ensure compliance on board. The 66-year-old Filipino captain appeared in court in Marseilles, France, on 2nd September, where prosecutors sought a charge of 50,000 euros against him, which was upheld in the final decision pronounced in October.

headline: Ro-Ro Passenger Ship with 550 Passengers Onboard Runs Aground
author: Raghib Raza
content: The passenger Ro-Ro vessel [AGIA THEODORA ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:211120/mmsi:239619000/imo:8822155/vessel:AGIA_THEODORA)ran aground in shallow waters around four nautical miles away from Port [IGOUMENITSA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/77?name=IGOUMENITSA&country=Greece) on the night of 28th October. The ferry, which was carrying 550 passengers on board, arrived at port after a two-hour delay. ![AGIA THEODORA ran Aground.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/AGIA_THEODORA_aa4a6b825b.png)*Ro-Ro vessel AGIA THEODORA, image credit: Pieter Inpijn* The [AGIA THEODORA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:211120/mmsi:239619000/imo:8822155/vessel:AGIA_THEODORA) was traveling from [CORFU Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/76?name=CORFU&country=Greece) to [IGOUMENITSA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/77?name=IGOUMENITSA&country=Greece) Port when the incident occurred. The vessel is reported to have experienced mechanical failure when it ran aground in the shallow waters around four nautical miles northwest of the[ IGOUMENITSA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/77?name=IGOUMENITSA&country=Greece) Port. The vessel was carrying passengers and 16 crew members at the time of the incident. Fortunately, there was no threat to the safety of anyone onboard, and the weather conditions were calm. A coast guard vessel, along with two other tourist boats, were quickly on the scene. The vessel ended up refloating with the help of its own engines and was accompanied by two tugboats, three Coast Guard vessels, and a passenger ferry to the[ IGOUMENITSA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/77?name=IGOUMENITSA&country=Greece) Port.

headline: Four Nigerian Stowaways Discovered After Enduring 2000 Nautical Mile Journey on Box Ship's Rudder
author: Raghib Raza
content: Four Nigerian stowaways were discovered on the rudder of the box ship [MSC FIAMMETTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:463589/mmsi:372843000/imo:9369758/vessel:MSC_FIAMMETTA) as it arrived in Las Palmas de Gran Canaria, Canary Islands, Spain on 26th October. The stowaways are reported to be in good health despite enduring a 6-day journey spanning 2000 nautical miles. ![MSC FIAMMETTA.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSC_FIAMMETTA_b0df32e8c3.png)*Containership MSC FIAMMETTA, image credit: Frank katzer* The stowaways were discovered by dockworkers as the vessel [MSC FIAMMETTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:463589/mmsi:372843000/imo:9369758/vessel:MSC_FIAMMETTA). The dockworkers promptly alerted the authorities, and the Salvamento Maritimo launched its patrol boat, the SALVAMAR NUNKI, to retrieve the stowaways. After the stowaways were brought in for processing, they admitted that they had gotten on the vessel’s rudder as it was docked at Abidjan, Ivory Coast. Despite the perilous journey, a medical examination revealed that all the stowaways were in good health. The Spanish authorities have stated that they have begun the process of repatriating the four men. This is the typical outcome for stowaways that are discovered; however, there have been cases where they can be granted asylum, especially if there are threats to the stowaways’ safety in their home country.

headline: Oil Spill During Changi Bunkering Operation Triggers Emergency Response by MPA
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) reported a MARPOL incident off Changi, Singapore. On 28th October, at around 5:40 PM local time, an oil spill occurred during the bunkering operation between the bulk carrier [INES CORRADO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:373695/mmsi:311053600/imo:9602772/vessel:INES_CORRADO#overview) and a licensed bunker vessel. ![Oil spill during the bunkering operation at Ines Corrado.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/INES_CORRADO_71e504302d.png)*Bulk carrier, INES CORRADO, image credit: MPA* Following the accident, the bunkering operation was immediately halted. Reports indicated that approximately five tonnes of oil had overflowed into the sea. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) responded swiftly, dispatching an emergency vessel, which arrived at the site by 5:50 PM to spray dispersants and mitigate environmental impact. On 29th October, the MPA confirmed that no oil was observed in the area of the incident or along the shoreline. As a precautionary measure, the MPA deployed “Current Buster,” an advanced system that collects spilled oil from water. The system is capable of capturing oil even during high currents or in rough seas. The Malaysian authorities have also been notified to monitor the region for any visible traces of oil in the water. Following the incident, no navigational traffic was observed. The MPA will conduct an investigation into the bunkering accident. The Marine traffic data shows the Liberian-flagged vessel[ INES CORRADO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:373695/mmsi:311053600/imo:9602772/vessel:INES_CORRADO#overview) is currently at Singapore Anchorage. The laden vessel is scheduled to arrive at [TIANJIN ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/309?name=TIANJIN&country=China)Port, China, by 08th November.

headline: Houthi Forces Launch Attacks on Merchant Vessel Passing Through the Red Sea
author: Raghib Raza
content: Yemen’s Houthi Rebels launched an attack on the passing merchant vessel [MOTARO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:756363/mmsi:636016529/imo:9310290/vessel:MOTARO) on 28 October as it was passing through the Bab-el-Mandeb strait in the Red Sea. The vessel and its crew are reported to be safe and traveling to their next port of call. ![Vessel MOTARO attacked in Red Sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MOTARO_8879abefa0.png)*Vessel MOTARO, image credit: Nikos Palamaris* United Kingdom Maritime Trade Operations (UKMTO) stated that a captain of a passing vessel [MOTARO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:756363/mmsi:636016529/imo:9310290/vessel:MOTARO) had reported of an explosion occurring near the vessel at 14:35 GMT, followed by another at 15:03 GMT and a final explosion at 16:37 GMT. The vessel was reported to be safe and the crew unharmed. The Marine Traffic data shows the bulk carrier is to arrive at the port of Changjiangkou in China. This vessel has no known connections to Israel and has not docked at any Israeli port in the last three years, despite the Houthi group claiming that they only target vessels that have connections to Israel or its allies. A Houthi spokesperson claimed responsibility for the attack on 28 October. The spokesperson of Houthi militants also claimed attacks on two other vessels namely [MAERSK KOWLOON](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:151708/mmsi:636018018/imo:9290476/vessel:MAERSK_KOWLOON) and MONTREAL in the Arabian Sea. .

headline: General Cargo Ship MOLIVA, Accused of illegally Transporting Toxic Waste Returns to Albania
author: Raghib Raza
content: The general cargo vessel [MOLIVA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1014443/mmsi:271043801/imo:9454034/vessel:MOLIVA#overview), accused of transporting toxic carcinogenic waste, has returned to Albania after its departure on 4 July. Albanian prosecutors are now scheduled to sample the waste and conduct tests to ascertain if it is indeed toxic. ![Vessel MOLIVA..](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MOLIVA_468707829e.png)*Vessel MOLIVA,image credit: Sakis Antoniou* The vessel was initially due to arrive in Thailand and deliver 102 containers (around 2100 tons) of industrial waste, which was labeled as iron oxide. However, the Basel Action Network (BAN) , an organization that works to prevent the export of toxic waste from developed to developing countries, was tipped off that the containers were falsely labeled and actually contained Electric Arc Furnace Dust (EAFD). EAFD contains heavy metals that make it particularly dangerous and pose environmental risks. The vessel was blocked from docking in Thailand after receiving word from BAN and other NGOs. The vessel [MOLIVA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1014443/mmsi:271043801/imo:9454034/vessel:MOLIVA#overview) then docked in Portugal, Spain, and Italy before returning to Albania. The vessel has now dropped anchor in the waters a mile away from the port of [DURRES](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/719?name=DURRES&country=Albania) near Tirana. Albanian prosecutors have ordered the containers to be seized and stored. However, Albanian Prime Minister Edi Rama has defended the cargo, stating in parliament that iron oxide is not classified as toxic waste, implying that the containers are not falsely labeled. Jim Puckett, the head of BAN, has requested for the containers to be opened publicly, with BAN being allowed to also take a sample for independent testing. Puckett states that it is imperative for BAN to be allowed to independently test the waste for public trust in the government to be retained.

headline: Pacific International Lines Successfully Bunkers its first LNG-powered Vessel
author: Raghib Raza
content: Singaporean shipping company Pacific International Lines (PIL) successfully bunkered its first LNG-powered vessel on October 26. ![KOTA EAGLE was bunkered.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KOTA_EAGLE_fb77a5611a.png)*Containership KOTA EAGLE, image credit: PIL* The [KOTA EAGLE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8919841/mmsi:563235800/imo:9963700/vessel:KOTA_EAGLE#overview) vessel was bunkered with 8,000 cubic meters of LNG from the bunkering vessel [HAI GANG WEI LAI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6715669/mmsi:413316720/imo:9886756/vessel:HAI_GANG_WEI_LAI) in a ship-to-ship bunkering operation at the Yangshan Port in Shanghai. The [KOTA EAGLE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8919841/mmsi:563235800/imo:9963700/vessel:KOTA_EAGLE#overview) is the first LNG-powered vessel in PIL’s fleet. It is a 14,000 TEU container vessel flagged in Singapore with a gross tonnage of 136,312. The vessel is 335 meters long and 51 meters wide. It features a dual-fuel engine designed to reduce methane slip and can reduce emissions by 28% when using LNG. The LNG-powered vessel is currently on its maiden voyage and will now sail from [NINGBO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1250?name=NINGBO&country=China). [KOTA EAGLE ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8919841/mmsi:563235800/imo:9963700/vessel:KOTA_EAGLE#overview)will then depart for Latin America on PIL’s West Coast Central and South America Service 2 route. The introduction of new LNG-powered vessels in its fleet is part of PIL’s broader strategy to transition to greener shipping solutions. Two more vessels of the same series on order by PIL are currently under construction at the Jiangnan shipyard in China.

headline: Explosive-Laden MV Ruby Finds Harbor At the Port of Great Yarmouth
author: Raghib Raza
content: The [MV RUBY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1605/mmsi:229041000/imo:9626390/vessel:RUBY#overview) has finally been allowed to dock into a port after being damaged in early September. The vessel has faced scrutiny and has not been allowed to dock at ports for long due to the hazardous cargo of explosives it is carrying. The MV RUBY is set to dock at the Port of [GREAT YARMOUTH ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/134?name=GREAT-YARMOUTH&country=United-Kingdom)on 28 October. ![RUBY allowed to dock at UK Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RUBY_aa237f4b05.png)*Vessel RUBY, image credit:Malcolm Cranfield* The [MV RUBY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1605/mmsi:229041000/imo:9626390/vessel:RUBY#overview) arrived at the port of [TROMSO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/267?name=TROMSO&country=Norway) in Norway after its hull and propeller were damaged due to inclement weather. The vessel was sent away from the port due to the cargo of 20,000 tons of ammonium nitrate being transported on the vessel. The vessel then requested refuge at the port of Klaipeda but was denied. Ammonium nitrate, though having industrial uses and being an excellent fertilizer, also explodes violently when exposed to improper conditions. Around 2,750 tons of the same compound caused the infamous blast in Beirut in 2020. For context, the MV Ruby contains 20,000 tons of the compound. The vessel has been anchored at a safe distance off of Margate since September. The [MV RUBY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1605/mmsi:229041000/imo:9626390/vessel:RUBY#overview) has received permission from the UK Government and the Ministry of Transport to dock at the port of Great Yarmouth. The port’s director, Richard Goffin, has assured that the port has the capability to handle dangerous cargo, and the transshipment of such chemicals is common practice across the port group.

headline: Ro-Ro Vessel Allied with the Quay in Kalundborg, Denmark
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Ro-Ro vessel [SAMSOE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:159719/mmsi:220619000/imo:9548562/vessel:SAMSOE#overview) ended up colliding with a quay in [KALUNDBORG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/359?name=KALUNDBORG&country=Denmark), Denmark, on 26 October as it was approaching a berth. The vessel sustained minor damage, and its scheduled voyages have not been impacted. ![Ro-Ro vessel SAMSOE allided with quay.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SAMSOE_9787618a50.png)*Ro-Ro vessel SAMSOE,image credit:tv2east.dk* The ro-ro passenger vessel was arriving at [KALUNDBORG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/359?name=KALUNDBORG&country=Denmark) from Ballen when the incident occurred. As the vessel was approaching the berth, a door for debarking passengers was lowered prematurely. This led to the collision of the protruding door with the quay. This caused the door’s hinges to be damaged and almost pulled off. Following this the repairs were made. The monitoring classification society and the Danish Maritime Authority approved the vessel as suitable for sailing, and it embarked on a sail back to Ballen. No reports of injuries or pollution from the ro-ro vessel have been released. The [SAMSOE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:159719/mmsi:220619000/imo:9548562/vessel:SAMSOE#overview) is a Denmark-flagged Ro-Ro vessel that is 91 meters long and 16 meters wide. The vessel was built in 2009 and has a gross tonnage of 4,630.

headline: Tropical Storm Kristine wreaks Havoc, Beaches Two Vessels
author: Raghib Raza
content: The tropical storm Kristine significantly impacted operations in the Philippines on October 23, leading to severe weather conditions with waves of up to 6 meters in some areas. Authorities have warned vessels to remain in ports till weather conditions improve. ![LCT GOLDEN BELLA and another vessel impacted by storm Kristine](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LCT_GOLDEN_BELLA_c212e9f338.png)*Vessel, LCT GOLDEN BELLA ,image credit:sunstar.com.ph* Despite precautions, some vessels have still run aground and been damaged due to terrible weather conditions. The[ LCT ASC BIGBOY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5659622/mmsi:548111381/imo:0/vessel:LCT_ASC_BIGBOY#overview) broke its anchor chains and drifted towards the shore to the point where it was 160 feet from the coast of Barangay Sugod. The vessel was beached and was unable to free itself with the help of its engines alone. There have been early reports of the vessel leaking oil from its punctured port fuel tank. All of the 17 crewmembers are reported to be uninjured. The [LCT GOLDEN BELLA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9166169/mmsi:600010885/imo:0/vessel:LCT_GOLDEN_BELLA), a 62-meter-long vessel, experienced a similar fate as it broke free of its anchor chains and ran aground in Cebu. The vessel is now set to be inspected by divers before any attempt to refloat it is made.

headline: Navigating the Complexities of Maritime Sanctions: A September 2024 Overview
author: Dimitris Ampatzidis
content: **Main Updates** In September 2024, there were no new sanctions imposed on shipping trades or cargoes by OFAC, OFSI, the EU, or the United Nations. However, on 12 September, the UK government introduced a new directive, ["Trade, Aircraft, and Shipping Sanctions, Civil Enforcement."](https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/trade-aircraft-and-shipping-sanctions-civil-enforcement-guidance/trade-aircraft-and-shipping-sanctions-civil-enforcement-guidance) Notably, this guidance set unprecedented fines starting at £1 million and mandated proactive due diligence for vessels and shipping firms. These updated regulations highlight the growing need for advanced technologies capable of closely tracking vessel behaviour to support compliance. As shipping firms, charter companies and harbour authorities adapt to these more stringent guidelines, investing in robust tracking tools will be critical to avoid fines and sustain trust in international trade. **Analysis of Sanctioned Vessels and Companies** ![Sanctioned vessels and companies through the years.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Sanctioned_vessels_and_companies_through_the_years_36025d69ee.png) **Graph 1.** _Sanctioned vessels and companies through the years - Kpler._ ![Sanctioned vessels per top 10 flag registry through the years.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Sanctioned_vessels_per_top_10_flag_registry_through_the_years_70212e4dd7.png) **Graph 2.** _Sanctioned vessels per top 10 flag registry through the years - Kpler._ In recent years, the number of sanctioned vessels and companies has climbed sharply. Since 2017, vessels have become a particular target, with the count soaring past 900 by 2024, while sanctioned companies have increased more gradually, surpassing 300. This disparity points to vessels as a primary focus of sanctions enforcement, likely due to high-risk activities like STS transfers and AIS manipulation, often employed to circumvent sanctions. Certain flag registries have also seen pronounced increases in sanctioned vessels, with Russia and Panama leading the trend in 2024. For example, Russia saw a rise of 31 vessels, underscoring a shift towards scrutinising vessels flagged under specific nations. This trend reflects a more globalised and comprehensive approach to sanctions enforcement, urging shipping companies to remain vigilant over vessels and flag registries associated with elevated sanctions risks. Examining pre-sanction behaviours offers vital insights into the nuances of maritime risk management and underscores the importance of diligent oversight in mitigating compliance challenges. **Risk & Compliance findings before the applied sanctions** The vessel LA PEROUSE serves as a useful example, as it showed activities that raised compliance concerns before sanctions were applied. This case shows the challenges of assessing risks in maritime operations, especially when dealing with sanctioned cargo, possible tampering with AIS, and engaging in high-risk STS transfers. ![La Perouse risks.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/La_Perouse_risks_b8bd6f7e9a.jpg) **Image 1.** _LA PEROUSE risks - Kpler._ LA PEROUSE was linked to Russian LNG ([HS code: 271111](https://www.uktradeinfo.com/commodities/2711)) from the ports of Sabetta and Vysotsk in 2023, months before the sanctions came into effect. Notably, one trade of this Russian LNG took place via an STS transfer from Sabetta to Zeebrugge, Belgium. This type of operation is now being closely examined by the European Union under the 14th EU sanctions package (Dalboni & Perez-Cejuela Romero, 2024; Sutenko, 2024). ![La Perouse High Risk Trade.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/La_Perouse_High_Risk_Trade_a6f003a88d.jpg) **Image 2.** _LA PEROUSE high risk trade - Kpler._ In terms of operational risks, LA PEROUSE experienced at least five high-risk AIS gaps starting from May 2023. In four of these instances, there was a change in the vessel's draught, highlighting loading and discharge operations. During the same time, the vessel was involved in three high-risk STS transfers with the Christophe De Margerie (IMO No. 9737187). ![La Perouse High Risk AIS Gaps.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/La_Perouse_High_Risk_AIS_Gaps_acf87df870.jpg) **Image 3.** _LA PEROUSE high risk AIS gaps - Kpler._ To assess the risks associated with LA PEROUSE on Kpler before the sanctions were enforced, users could have monitored the vessel’s activities, such as its connections to Russian LNG and its participation in STS transfers. Additionally, tracking AIS gaps and draught changes could have raised early warning signs of non-compliance or riskier behaviour. By identifying these red flags in advance and cross-referencing them with evolving regulations, such as the UK’s recent sanctions guidelines, users could have avoided engaging with the vessel, thus reducing the risk of breaching sanctions. Stay tuned for more insights and updates as the year progresses, ensuring that you remain informed and compliant amidst these dynamic regulatory changes. headline: Van Oord's Cable-Laying Vessel Makes Debut by Beginning Work on Offshore Wind Farm
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Dutch maritime company Van Oord announced the debut of its latest cable-laying vessel, the [CALYPSO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7705681/mmsi:245563000/imo:9934840/vessel:CALYPSO#overview), on October 24. The vessel made its debut by laying cables for the Sofia offshore wind farm, which is around 195 km northeast of the UK. ![CALYPSO.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CALYPSO_8fbd2412e8.png)*Vessel CALYPSO,image credit: Van Oord* The [CALYPSO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7705681/mmsi:245563000/imo:9934840/vessel:CALYPSO#overview) is the second cable-laying vessel of Van Oord after the [NEXUS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1639106/mmsi:244820968/imo:9715505/vessel:NEXUS). The new cable-laying vessel has been specifically designed to meet the rapidly growing demands of the renewable energy sector. The [CALYPSO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7705681/mmsi:245563000/imo:9934840/vessel:CALYPSO#overview) is 131 meters long and 28 meters wide. The vessel is equipped with two cable carousels, each of which can carry around 8,000 tons of cable. The two-carousel arrangement allows the vessel to lay two high-voltage direct current cables simultaneously, increasing efficiency. The [CALYPSO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7705681/mmsi:245563000/imo:9934840/vessel:CALYPSO#overview) is also equipped with many other advanced sustainability features, such as hybrid engines capable of utilizing biofuels and future e-fuels, an energy management system that optimizes energy use, and a shore power connection. The vessel is also equipped with optical time-domain reflectometry (OTDR) systems that can continuously monitor cable integrity as it is being laid. The vessel made its debut by laying cables for the Sofia Offshore wind farm. The Sofia offshore wind farm has a capacity of 1.4 GW and is intended to supply a total of 1.2 million UK households once it is operational. The wind farm has been taken over by RWE, a German company, which in turn has contracted Van Oord for the monopile foundations and array cables of the project.

headline: Bulk Carrier With 85,000 Tons of Iron Ore Onboard Runs Aground
author: Raghib Raza
content: On October 23, the Singapore-flagged bulk carrier [MILDRED](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713614/mmsi:563231700/imo:9587386/vessel:MILDRED) ran aground at the entrance of the Eregli Iron and Steel Factories port in Turkey. The vessel was refloated, and following inspections, it was declared to be unharmed. ![MILDRED ran aground.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MILDRED_62be75cfd5.png)*Bulk carrier MILDRED, image credit: Graeme Waller* The vessel [MILDRED](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713614/mmsi:563231700/imo:9587386/vessel:MILDRED) was carrying 85,000 tons of iron ore when it ran aground. The fact that the vessel was heavily loaded raised concerns about its stability and potential environmental impacts. Due to the dense cargo, the vessel would have also been difficult to salvage should things have gone wrong. The vessel running aground was immediately reported to the Eregli port authority, which in turn closed off the cargo ship entrances. The vessel was then inspected by divers, and following their approval, the vessel was refloated by tugboats. The [MILDRED](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713614/mmsi:563231700/imo:9587386/vessel:MILDRED) is a 2011-built, Singapore-flagged bulk carrier. It has a length of 292 m, a beam of 45 m, and a gross tonnage of 93,733.

headline: Signs of Somali Pirates in Indian Ocean, Security Alert Issued
author: Raghib Raza
content: A warning has been posted to the vessels traversing the Indian Ocean of possible Somali pirate presence in the area. The warning was issued by the Maritime Security Centre—Horn of Africa. Furthermore, the EU Naval Force posted in the area and the EOS Risk group, a security specialist, both have stated that according to their sources, 13 armed pirates have departed from Ceel Huur in Hobyo, Somalia and are at large in the Indian Ocean. ![HUAN HANG.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/HUAN_HANG_d0f61b6f15.png)*Vessel HUAN HANG,image credit: Andry Ru* A recent notification by the UKMTO issued on 23 October also reports of the vessel [HUAN HANG 99 ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5567524/mmsi:414387000/imo:9646651/vessel:HUAN_HANG_99)being approached by five unidentified small vessels, which retreated when warning shots were fired. The [HUAN HANG 99](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5567524/mmsi:414387000/imo:9646651/vessel:HUAN_HANG_99) was near the southern coast of Aden during the incident. The experts have stated that though Somali pirate presence may return, they are unlikely to regain their former strength that they possessed a decade ago. This is due to the naval presence and anti-piracy measures that still remain in place.

headline: Search for Overboard Passenger from ALLURE OF THE SEAS Called off After 15 hours
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Passenger went overboard from ALLURE OF THE SEAS.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ALLURE_OF_THE_SEAS_22284d5bb8.png)*Cruise ship ALLURE OF THE SEAS, image credit: Andreas Reineke* The search for a 66-year-old female passenger who fell overboard from a Royal Caribbean cruise ship, [ALLURE OF THE SEAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:372814/mmsi:311020700/imo:9383948/vessel:ALLURE_OF_THE_SEAS), was called off by the Royal Bahamas Defense Force after 15 hours of searching. The passenger reportedly fell off on the night of October 22, around 17 miles off of Nassau in the Bahamas. The accident occurred on board the [ALLURE OF THE SEAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:372814/mmsi:311020700/imo:9383948/vessel:ALLURE_OF_THE_SEAS), which was on a 4-night cruise to the Bahamas that departed on October 21. The search for the passenger began as soon as the report of her falling overboard was made, at around 9:40 PM on October 22. The [ALLURE OF THE SEAS ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:372814/mmsi:311020700/imo:9383948/vessel:ALLURE_OF_THE_SEAS)quickly turned around and began the search. The Royal Bahamas Defense Force and the US Coast Guard were promptly alerted for help. Its sister vessel, the [UTOPIA OF THE SEAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8762822/mmsi:311001259/imo:9880001/vessel:UTOPIA_OF_THE_SEAS), was also in the region and quickly joined the search. The Royal Bahamas Defense Force and the USGC deployed several resources, including an HC-144 aircraft and an MH-65 helicopter, to search for the missing passenger. However, by late afternoon of the next day, the search and rescue operation having yielded no fruit, the Defense Force stopped requesting assistance from the USGC and suspended the search pending any further developments. The[ ALLURE OF THE SEAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:372814/mmsi:311020700/imo:9383948/vessel:ALLURE_OF_THE_SEAS) has resumed its journey with no change to its itinerary and is scheduled to arrive [NASSUA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/3151?name=NASSAU&country=Bahamas), Bahamas on October 24.

headline: Bulk Carrier Runs Into Canal’s Embankment in Low Visibility Conditions
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![ULTRA INFINITY.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ULTRA_INFINITY_86afc012b1.png)*Vessel ULTRA INFINITY, image credit:kn-online.de* On the morning of October 23, at around 10:00 AM local time, the bulk carrier [ULTRA INFINITY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4010445/mmsi:563094500/imo:9767481/vessel:ULTRA_INFINITY#overview), which was traveling through the Kiel Canal, Germany, struck the embankment due to low visibility conditions brought upon by thick fog. The vessel was able to free itself, and early reports indicate the vessel did not sustain grievous damage. The incident occurred as the vessel was traversing the Kiel Canal that connects Brunsbuttel and Kiel. The 98-kilometer-long canal was beset by thick fog at the time, such that visibility was reportedly reduced to around 100 m. The vessel [ULTRA INFINITY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4010445/mmsi:563094500/imo:9767481/vessel:ULTRA_INFINITY#overview), likely veering off due to low visibility, ended up hitting the embankment on the northern side. The [ULTRA INFINITY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4010445/mmsi:563094500/imo:9767481/vessel:ULTRA_INFINITY#overview) is a Singapore-flagged bulk carrier that was built in 2016. The vessel has a length of 200m, a width of 32.24m, and a gross tonnage of 34,804. The authorities blocked traffic in the canal due to the halted vessel until it was able to free itself and resume its journey to Kiel. Upon the vessel reaching the northern harbor, the tugboat came to its assistance. Initial reports confirm that none of the crewmembers were injured, and there was minimal damage to the vessel as it was traveling at a slow speed in the canal. Furthermore, there have been no reports of damage to the hull or any indication of pollution from the vessel. As of now, the vessel has dropped anchor near Holtenau, where it awaits a more thorough inspection. The water police have opened an investigation into the matter, and early reports indicate that the accident was likely due to human error.

headline: Largest Ever Suction Sail System Installation on Dutch Cargo Vessel
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Vessel EEMS TRAVELLER.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/EEMS_TRAVELLER_b11beb9420.png)*General cargo vessel EEMS TRAVELLER, image credit: bound4blue* Amasus has signed its agreement with bound4blue, under which a 22-meter wind sail is to be installed onboard the [EEMS TRAVELLER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:268836/mmsi:246498000/imo:9218234/vessel:EEMS_TRAVELLER#overview). The installation is expected to be completed by mid-2025. The [EEMS TRAVELLER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:268836/mmsi:246498000/imo:9218234/vessel:EEMS_TRAVELLER#overview) is a Netherland-flagged general cargo vessel that has a deadweight tonnage of 2,850. The vessel is to be fitted with a 22-meter eSail designed by bound4blue. The 22-meter eSail operates autonomously by monitoring conditions surrounding the vessel, increasing propulsion, and reducing emissions without any crew input. The installation is to be done at the Astander Shipyard in Santander. The [EEMS TRAVELLER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:268836/mmsi:246498000/imo:9218234/vessel:EEMS_TRAVELLER#overview) was previously fitted with two 17-meter eSails, and following positive feedback, Amasus has decided to opt for a larger sail, producing an even greater amount of wind propulsion. The installation will increase fuel efficiency and meet environmental regulations such as the EU ETS and the upcoming FuelEU Maritime Legislation.

headline: Diesel-Powered Nuclear Cargo Carrier Vessel Fitted With Wing Sail to Reduce Emissions
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![PACIFIC GREBE.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PACIFIC_GREBE_e0bd58af9a.png)*Vessel PACIFIC GREBE, image credit: Jacques Gauthier* The 4,902 dwt cargo carrier [PACIFIC GREBE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:195762/mmsi:235076847/imo:9464883/vessel:PACIFIC_GREBE), operated by Nuclear Transport Solutions (NTS), has been fitted with a retractable wing sail, allowing the vessel to tap into wind power for sailing. Sea trials for the vessel are intended to begin later this month. The [PACIFIC GREBE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:195762/mmsi:235076847/imo:9464883/vessel:PACIFIC_GREBE) is a UK-flagged diesel-powered cargo vessel that is operated by NTS and is used for hauling nuclear fuel and waste. The vessel is 104 meters long and 18 meters wide. It has been recently retrofitted with an innovative wind propulsion system called the FastRig. The FastRig is a 20-meter wing sail that is designed by Smart Green Shipping (SGS) to harness wind power for propulsion. FastRig has been shown to reduce emissions by 30% in test cases. The successful implementation of the FastRig aboard the [PACIFIC GREBE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:195762/mmsi:235076847/imo:9464883/vessel:PACIFIC_GREBE) is itself a testament to the high standards of the wing sail since the vessel is a specialist vessel carrying sensitive material such as nuclear cargo. Should the demonstration prove successful, it would greatly increase confidence among shipowners towards the effectiveness of wind-assisted technologies and pave the way for more widespread adoption. The [PACIFIC GREBE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:195762/mmsi:235076847/imo:9464883/vessel:PACIFIC_GREBE) is now set to undergo sea trials, by which SGS would obtain real-world data on fuel savings and emissions reduction. The project is also a part of the Winds of Change, a two-year plan that is funded by the UK Department of Transport and aims to deliver real-world demonstrations on projects in green maritime solutions.

headline: Grounded Cargo Vessel Successfully Refloated by Seychelles Port Authority
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![SPIL NINGSIH refloated.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SPIL_NINGSIH_39ecc6060d.png)*Containership SPIL NINGSIH, image credit: Seychelles Port Authority (SPA)* The Panamanian-flagged cargo vessel [SPIL NINGSIH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:714761/mmsi:352980780/imo:9273959/vessel:SPIL_NINGSIH) ran aground on the northern side of St. Anne Island on October 19. The vessel was successfully refloated at 1:10 AM the next day without any reported pollution or water ingress. The incident occurred on October 19 , when the vessel ran aground on the northern side of the St. Anne island. The Seychelles Port Authority (SPA) immediately enacted their emergency response protocols and dispatched an emergency team that has around 30 members. Since the vessel ended up running aground in an area that is within the St. Anne Marine Park, a protected area, it was paramount to take swift action to prevent any lasting environmental damage. Authorities were especially concerned with the size and the position of the vessel in which it had gotten stuck. Authorities stated that had the vessel turned parallel to the shore over time, it would have greatly increased the risk of pollution and hindered recovery efforts. The Seychelles Maritime Port Authority, the Seychelles Coast Guard, and the National Information Sharing Centre also arrived quickly on the scene to assist with the refloating efforts. A preliminary assessment showed that the vessel was not damaged and there was no pollution thus far. After several failed attempts to refloat the vessel, the efforts were finally successful in the rising tide at around 1:10 AM on 20 October, the next day. The vessel was then towed to the Mahe Quay in Port [VICTORIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/20023?name=PORT-VICTORIA&country=Seychelles), Seychelles and was safely docked by 5:47 PM. SPA authorities declared that the vessel indeed caused no pollution and there was no water ingress into the vessel.

headline: Russian Cargo Vessel Overturns, Four Crew Members Still Missing
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![GRIGORY LOVTSOV.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GRIGORY_LOVTSOV_39c9a236ba.png)*Vessel GRIGORY LOVTSOV, image credit: Marine Rescue Service* A Russian flagged cargo ship, the [GRIGORY LOVTSOV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3381274/mmsi:273359010/imo:8974922/vessel:GRIGORY_LOVTSOV#overview), overturned near Korsakov Port on Sakhalin Island on October 18, resulting in the loss of life of crewmembers. The incident occurred on the afternoon of October 18 while the vessel was conducting loading operations while docked at the [KORSAKOV Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/18156?name=KORSAKOV&country=Russia). After the vessel capsized, the Korsakov port authority promptly requested assistance from nearby vessels and requested four nearby vessels to divert to the region and conduct a search and rescue operation. The responding vessels included two tugboats. Reports indicate that there were seven crew members present at the time of the capsizing. When the vessel started listing heavily, three of the crewmembers were flung off the vessel into the sea. These crewmembers were later rescued in the search and rescue efforts and have reportedly suffered from hypothermia due to exposure to the cold waters. One of them was released from the hospital, while another sailor is still reported to be in a serious condition. Four remaining crewmembers were not found, and unconfirmed reports indicate that the bodies of two of these sailors have been recovered. The vessel has been towed and taken back to the port, and investigators are to assess the damage and inspect the vessel for any signs of the missing sailors. Initial investigations by the Russian Marine Rescue Service have revealed that the vessel started listing and subsequently capsized due to the improper loading of building materials on the vessel. The regional governor of the area has hinted at the possible overlooking of safety procedures during the loading of the vessel. [GRIGORY LOVTSOV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3381274/mmsi:273359010/imo:8974922/vessel:GRIGORY_LOVTSOV#overview) is 41 meters long and 9 meters wide, with a gross tonnage of 272.

headline: Cargo Ship Collision Near Hachinohe City, No casualties Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![JI ZHE 7 collided with vessel MIMITSU.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/JI_ZHE_7_2820ed9ffa.png)*Vessel JI ZHE 7,image credit: Sergei Skriabin* On the evening of 9 October, two cargo ships ended up colliding with one another near Hachinohe City, Japan. The two ships, namely the Panamanian flagged [JI ZHE 7](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7706213/mmsi:352002604/imo:8359134/vessel:SKOON_C) and the [MIMITSU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:465071/mmsi:373471000/imo:9527958/vessel:MIMITSU), were involved in the collision. The JIZHE 7 had departed from Hattaro Pier in Hachinohe City when strong winds blew the vessel back towards the pier. At around 4:00 PM, the[ JI ZHE 7 ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7706213/mmsi:352002604/imo:8359134/vessel:SKOON_C)ended up colliding with the [MIMITSU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:465071/mmsi:373471000/imo:9527958/vessel:MIMITSU), which was berthed at the Hattaro Pier at the time. There have been no oil spills or flooding reported from either of the vessels. The crews onboard both vessels are also reported to be unharmed. The Hachinohe City coast guard has opened an investigation into the matter.

headline: Update: Passing Vessel Attacked in the Red Sea Near Al Hudayah, Yemen
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Olympic Spirit attacked in the Red Sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Olympic_Spirit_bb27b53fd9.png)*Vessel OLYMPICSPIRIT, image credit: Torge Mller* On 10 October, a Liberian-flagged vessel, [OLYMPIC SPIRIT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:205246/mmsi:636022387/imo:9327097/vessel:OLYMPIC_SPIRIT), passing through the Red Sea around 70 nautical miles off the coast of Al Hudayah, Yemen, reported their vessel being targeted by successive projectiles. The incident occurred at around 12:10 AM UTC. The master of the vessel reported to the United Kingdom Maritime Trade Operations (UKMTO) that the vessel was being targeted by unknown projectiles. Around an hour later, further reports came in of the vessel being hit by a projectile and sustaining damage. However, the report also confirmed the crew being safe and there being no fires resulting from the attack. The UKMTO issued another update at 5:15 AM, reporting the vessel being targeted again and two projectiles exploding close to the vessel. The crew were again confirmed to be safe. The attacks are speculated to have been carried out using drones. The vessel is reported to have sustained light damage and is proceeding to its next port of call. In the latest update UKMTO identified the vessel to be the [OLYMPIC SPIRIT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:205246/mmsi:636022387/imo:9327097/vessel:OLYMPIC_SPIRIT). Marine Traffic data shows the tanker is currently in the Red Sea bound for [MUSCAT Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/18585?name=MUSCAT&country=Oman), Oman. The authorities have initiated an investigation into the incident in the Red Sea, and a warning has been posted to the vessels traveling in the region to proceed with caution.

headline: Ukraine Confiscates Turkey-Owned Vessel for Illegally Transporting Grain from Crimea
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![USKO MFU vessel confiscated by Turkey.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/USKO_MFU_8ff14b7080.png)*Vessel USKO MFU, image credit: Enrico Pusceddu* On 9 October, a Ukrainian court order authorized the confiscation of the vessel[ USKO MFU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:209092/mmsi:613101900/imo:7919781/vessel:USKO_MFU), which had been initially detained in July this year for transporting grain to and from occupied Crimea. The ownership of the Cameroon-flagged vessel [USKO MFU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:209092/mmsi:613101900/imo:7919781/vessel:USKO_MFU), which originally belonged to Usko Shipping of Turkey, was transferred over to the Ukrainian government. The [USKO MFU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:209092/mmsi:613101900/imo:7919781/vessel:USKO_MFU) is a 1982-built general cargo vessel. The ship has a gross tonnage of 2,654 tons and is 94 meters long and 13 meters wide. The vessel was confiscated in July this year for transporting 3000 tons of grain from Occupied Crimea to a Turkish company in November 2023. Following the detainment of the vessel, the captain and the second officer of the vessel were charged with illegally transporting goods from occupied territories in violation of both Ukrainian and international laws and are facing 5 years in prison.

headline: Six Killed and Eight Injured in Most Recent Missile Strike Near Odessa
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![SHUI SPIRIT damaged in Russia's missile attack in Ukraine.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SHUI_SPIRIT_b0be03c6d5.png)*Vessel SHUI SPIRIT,image credit: Suslov Volvodymyr* A Russian missile strike hit the port of [CHORNOMORSK ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/882?name=CHORNOMORSK&country=Ukraine)in Ukraine. The attack killed 6 people and ended up injuring 8 others. The missile attack also damaged a Panamanian-flagged container ship, [SHUI SPIRIT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:758979/mmsi:352002643/imo:9216729/vessel:SHUI_SPIRIT). The attack occurred on Wednesday, 9 October. Oleh Kiper, the regional governor of Odessa, stated that the injured people in that attack were all Ukrainian nationals and that four of them were in a serious medical condition. He further stated that this is the third such attack in the past four days. Kiper reported that the target of the missile was port infrastructure, but it ended up damaging a nearby container ship, the [SHUI SPIRIT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:758979/mmsi:352002643/imo:9216729/vessel:SHUI_SPIRIT), a pharmacy, and causing multiple fires in the area. The attack was preceded by recent strikes in the past days, including an attack on a vessel docked in the port of Pivdennyi on 6 October and an attack on a vessel at the Odessa Port on 7 October. Ukrainian authorities claim that the attacks are aimed at destabilizing the Ukrainian grain corridor and causing economic disruptions.

headline: Maersk's ALEXANDRA MAERSK Launches New Era of Green Logistics at Felixstowe Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![ALEXANDRA MAERSK christened at Felixstowe Port](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ALEXANDRA_MAERSK_971eaf0f5c.png)*Containership ALEXANDRA MAERSK, image credit: Maersk* The global shipping and logistics company Maersk celebrated the naming ceremony of the latest dual-fuel container ship, [ALEXANDRA MAERSK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8850412/mmsi:219634000/imo:9948786/vessel:ALEXANDRA_MAERSK#overview), on 09 October at [FELIXSTOWE Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/199?name=FELIXSTOWE&country=United-Kingdom), United Kingdom. The new build is the sixth in Maersk's owned fleet that can operate on methanol in both its auxiliary and main engine. This marks Maersk's strategy conversion to greener fuel alternatives. This new container ship is also the fifth in the series of eighteen dual-fuel methanol vessels ordered by Maersk. The vessels are scheduled to be handed over in 2024 and 2025. Maersk is using methanol-enabled vessels as an essential element in its strategy of reducing greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and achieving net zero emissions by 2040 across its operations. The low-emission methanol can reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 65 to 90%, depending on its feedstock and production process. Science-Based Targets initiative (STBi) has validated Maersk's decarbonisation plan in maritime shipping and other aspects of its business.

headline: Avenir LNG Charters Out its Newbuild LNG Bunker Vessel to Eni
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Avenir Aspiration chartered to Eni.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Avenir_Aspiration_4e0d765a19.png)*LNG Tanker AVENIR ASPIRATION, image credit: Avenir LNG* Avenir LNG and Eni have signed an agreement for Eni to charter the vessel[ AVENIR ASPIRATION](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6704730/mmsi:215902000/imo:9868962/vessel:AVENIR_ASPIRATION). The agreement, which was announced on 8 October, marks a significant milestone for both companies. The [AVENIR ASPIRATION](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6704730/mmsi:215902000/imo:9868962/vessel:AVENIR_ASPIRATION) is a 7,500 cubic meter LNG bunker vessel that was built in 2021 and is currently engaged in small-scale supplies and ship-to-ship bunkering services. The vessel operates for Avenir Supply and Trading, the physical LNG trading division of Avenir, and provides its services in Northwest Europe. The announced agreement with Eni is a Time Charter Party agreement, which traditionally would entail Eni chartering the vessel for a predetermined period, during which Eni would control the vessel’s operations and pay for operational costs such as fuel, port fees, and cargo handling, while Avenir would pay for the maintenance and crewing of the vessel. The charter of the vessel with Eni will begin upon the delivery of the vessel in Europe in 2025. The charter of this vessel will bring Avenir’s long-term revenue backlog, including options, to around $285 million. The agreement, which is to extend for a decade, will benefit both companies mutually. Avenir stands to benefit from the improved financials, namely the improved long-term cash flows, whereas Eni will be able to offer LNG among its bunker fuel options with the addition of this newest vessel to its fleet.

headline: Crewmembers of Polish-flagged Bulker Find Cocaine Stashed on Board their Ship
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Drugs discovered aboard JAWOR vessel.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/JAWOR_fc6efd548a.png)*Vessel JAWOR, image credit: Heinrich Nisuis* On 7 October, the crewmembers of the Polish-flagged bulk carrier [JAWOR](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:373328/mmsi:311034100/imo:9452608/vessel:JAWOR) found packets of cocaine stashed on board their own vessel. They discovered several bags containing 40 kg of cocaine each, and an investigation is underway concerning how the drugs got on board. The incident occurred on 7 October, when the vessel was anchored off the coast of Brazil, awaiting to dock at the port of Sao Luis. The crew members noticed the suspicious packages during routine operations and, upon closer investigation, surmised that it was illicit contraband. Upon the discovery of several bags of stashed drugs, the captain followed standard procedure and notified the shipping agent, who in turn notified law enforcement. The police arrived promptly on a helicopter and ended up discovering several bags wrapped in black foil, containing 40 kg of cocaine each. An investigation was subsequently opened, and the 20 crew members, consisting of Ukrainian, Polish, Bulgarian, and Romanian nationals, are awaiting interrogation. A police investigation is underway to discern if any of the crewmembers were complicit in the illicit smuggling operations. It is, however, important to note that none of the crewmembers have been taken into custody. [JAWOR](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:373328/mmsi:311034100/imo:9452608/vessel:JAWOR) had arrived in Brazil from [ROTTERDAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2036?name=ROTTERDAM&country=Netherlands) and was headed to Cartagena in Spain after picking up a shipment of cereal from the [SAO LUIS Port.](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/19050?name=SAO-LUIS&country=Brazil) The spokesman for the [JAWOR](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:373328/mmsi:311034100/imo:9452608/vessel:JAWOR) has stated that the drugs were likely planted at night, using a small craft when the vessel was in anchorage, awaiting permission to enter into the port.

headline: Cargo Ship Runs Aground in Strait Near Scottish Highlands
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![GOTLAND Vessel grounded.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GOTLAND_6de998c95c.png)*Vessel GOTLAND,image credit: RNLI* The German flagged cargo ship [GOTLAND](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:272740/mmsi:211882460/imo:9411824/vessel:GOTLAND#overview) ran aground while traversing a strait separating the Isle of Skye from the mainland at Glenelg near the Scottish Highlands. The incident occurred on 7 October. The HM Coastguard was notified at 1:15 AM, prompting them to send lifeboats from both Kyle and Portree lifeboat stations. Kyle lifeboat, the Spirit of Fred Olsen, arrived on the scene as soon as 1:30 AM. The lifeboat crew then went onboard and looked for damage to the vessel and injuries to crew members. After the subsequent arrival of the Portree lifeboat, the Stanley Watson Barker, the Spirit of Fred Olsen returned to the Kyle lifeboat station. The Portree lifeboat stood by, awaiting the high tide for the refloating of the vessel. Soon after, the emergency towing vessel arrived, and the Gotland was successfully refloated. The Gotland has now moved to anchor at Glenelg Bay. The narrow strait connecting the Isle of Skye with the Glenelg mainland, known as the Kylerhea Narrows, is notorious for strong currents. The strong currents coupled with the narrow passageway are the reason for frequent cases of vessels running aground here.

headline: Two Workers Suffer Burns in an Explosion Aboard a Russian Icebreaker Under Repair
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Explosion aboard KAPITAN KOSOLAPOV injured two workers.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KAPITAN_KOSOLAPOV_1ea203a982.png)*Vessel KAPITAN KOSOLAPOV, image credit: Oleg V.Malik* On 6 October, two workers suffered severe burns to their faces and hands as they were attempting to repair the fuel tank of the diesel icebreaker, [KAPITAN KOSOLAPOV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:351701/mmsi:273911100/imo:7406320/vessel:KAPITAN_KOSOLAPOV). The workers were rushed to the hospital and are reported to be in a stable condition. The incident occurred in the afternoon of 6 October at the Kanonersky shipyard near St. Petersburg. The two workers, later identified to be welders, were attempting to weld a leaking fuel tank when an errant spark from the welding equipment is reported to have triggered the explosion. The workers, although injured, were able to pull themselves out of the tank and seek help. The workers were subsequently rushed to the hospital. An investigation into the incident is currently underway.
