The[ KAPITAN KOSOLAPOV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:351701/mmsi:273911100/imo:7406320/vessel:KAPITAN_KOSOLAPOV) is one of three icebreakers acquired by Russia from Finland in 1976. The vessel currently operates under Rosmorport and is extensively involved in keeping the St. Petersburg port operational in the winters.

headline: Russian Missiles Target Two Civilian Vessels in Odessa Region of Ukraine
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![OPTIMA and another vessel attacked by Russia.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/OPTIMA_d1edab7b7b.png)*Vessel OPTIMA, image credit: Diaa Oustah* Two vessels in the Odessa region of Ukraine were attacked by Russian missiles on 6 October and 7 October, respectively. The attacks led to the death of one Ukrainian national, the injuring of five crew members, and damage to vessels and structures at the ports. On 6 October, a Russian airstrike targeted a grain vessel docked at the port of Pivdennyi in the Odessa region of Ukraine. The vessel was later identified as the [PARESA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:712409/mmsi:377901318/imo:9008134/vessel:HELENA#overview) and registered in St. Kitts and Nevis. Ukrainian Deputy Prime Minister Oleksiy Kuleba claimed the vessel to have arrived only hours before and was carrying around 6,000 tons of corn. Fortunately, none of the fifteen crew members onboard the vessel were injured in the incident. The very next day, on 7 October, another Russian airstrike hit the Palau-flagged Civilian vessel named [OPTIMA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5812365/mmsi:511101043/imo:9528691/vessel:OPTIMA). According to Odessa Regional Governor Oleh Kipper, the attack resulted in the death of a 60-year-old Ukrainian worker who was employed in a private cargo handling company. Kipper further stated that five crewmembers were also injured. The injured crew members are in medical care, with reports claiming four of them having sustained moderate injuries and one having sustained mild injuries. These attacks have been claimed by Ukrainian authorities to be Russia threatening food security and grain exports by repeatedly targeting grain vessels. The marked increase in attacks on vessels began after Russia withdrew from the Black Sea Grain Initiative, although Russia claims to never have targeted any civilian vessels.

headline: Bangladesh Shipping Owned Crude Oil Tanker BANGLAR SHOURABH Catches Fire: One Dead
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![BANGLAR SHOURABH caught major fire.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BANGLAR_SHOURABH_a835422a41.png)*Crude oil tanker, BANGLAR SHOURABH, image credit: ISRP* Another fatal maritime incident occurred in Bangladesh involving a major fire aboard the crude oil tanker owned by Bangladesh Shipping Corporation (BSC). On 04 October at around 12:45 AM local time, a fire broke out aboard the [BANGLAR SHOURABH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:476024/mmsi:405000025/imo:8508955/vessel:BANGLAR_SHOURABH#overview), causing the death of one crewmember. The incident took place when the state-flagged vessel was docked at the outer anchorage of [CHITTAGONG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2743?name=CHITTAGONG&country=Bangladesh) Port. Following the incident, the captain and the crewmembers of [BANGLAR SHOURABH ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:476024/mmsi:405000025/imo:8508955/vessel:BANGLAR_SHOURABH#overview)abandoned the vessel. Three specialised tugboats from the navy and four tug boats from the Coast Guard and Port Authority arrived for firefighting. After four hours of effort, the fire was brought under the control of the authorities and the firefighting team. The Inter Service Public Relations (ISPR) Bangladesh stated that one of the crew members died in the incident, and 47 crewmembers were rescued successfully. Several of the injured crew members were taken to hospital for medical treatment. ISPR reported that [BANGLAR SHOURABH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:476024/mmsi:405000025/imo:8508955/vessel:BANGLAR_SHOURABH#overview) was loaded with eleven thousand metric tons of crude oil at the time of the incident. Earlier, on 30 September, a fire broke out aboard [BANGLAR JYOTI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:476023/mmsi:405000024/imo:8508943/vessel:BANGLAR_JYOTI), resulting in an explosion in the crude oil tanker that caused the death of three crew members. Both vessels were built in 1987 and are owned by BSC.

headline: Wind-assisted propulsion installed aboard the Heavy Load Carrier, JUMBO JUBILEE
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![JUMBO JUBILEE fitted with two wind-assisted sails.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/JUMBO_JUBILEE_a1ba49b8d8.png)*Vessel JUMBO JUBILEE, image credit: Arnold Pohen* Heavy Lift and Offshore Transportation contractor Jumbo Maritime announced the installation of two mechanical sails aboard its Heavy Lift vessel, the [JUMBO JUBILEE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:267465/mmsi:246309000/imo:9371581/vessel:JUMBO_JUBILEE), on 4 October. The two wind-assisted sails are designed to alleviate the fuel requirements for the vessel. The Wind Assisted Ship Propulsion (WASP) system installed onboard is a product of the Dutch company Econowind, which specializes in harnessing wind energy for maritime uses. The company’s primary product is the VentoFoil, a foldable wind assist unit that can generate substantial thrust and reduce reliance on traditional fuel sources. Econowind stated that the[ JUMBO JUBILEE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:267465/mmsi:246309000/imo:9371581/vessel:JUMBO_JUBILEE) was the first geared vessel to have wind-assisted propulsion systems installed, commenting on the pioneering approach Jumbo has taken in the heavy lift sector. The sails aboard the [JUMBO JUBILEE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:267465/mmsi:246309000/imo:9371581/vessel:JUMBO_JUBILEE) are installed on specially designed mounts, which allow for the sails to be moved around or relocated to another vessel when additional deck space is required. These mounts were engineered by Jumbo Maritime structural engineer Estelle Bongers. In addition to wind-assisted propulsion, [JUMBO JUBILEE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:267465/mmsi:246309000/imo:9371581/vessel:JUMBO_JUBILEE) has been equipped with a number of other measures to reduce emissions and increase efficiency. These include an anti-fouling coating on the ship’s propellers, AI-powered monitoring of the ship’s hull to keep fouling in check, and an eco-control system that, depending on other factors such as wind thrust, adjusts engine power so as to increase efficiency. The [JUMBO JUBILEE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:267465/mmsi:246309000/imo:9371581/vessel:JUMBO_JUBILEE) is a 13,017 DWT vessel built in 2009 and flagged in the Netherlands. The ship has 18,130 cubic meters of storage capacity and 3,100 cubic meters of deck space. The ship has two heavy lift cranes capable of lifting 900 tons each.

headline: Vessel Carrying Ammunition Attacked by Russian Forces in Ukrainian Port Raid
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![A vessel moored at Yuzhny Port hit by Russian Missile.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/YUZHNY_Port_694cb9c3c4.png)*YUZHNY Port, image credit: Gurenko Lybov* A merchant vessel moored at the [YUZHNY Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/884?name=YUZHNY&country=Ukraine) in the Odessa region was hit by a Russian ballistic missile on 6 October. Infrared footage captured by a UAV depicting the incident has been released by Russian state media. The merchant vessel was hit by an Iskander-M type short-range ballistic missile while it was moored at the Yuzhny port. The name of the targeted vessel has not been released. However, the reporting of the event by the Russian Ministry of Defense states that the vessel was carrying military aid sent by European countries to Ukraine. The Ministry of Defense further claims that the vessel was hit by the missile at the time of unloading the ammunition, resulting in detonation and a secondary explosion. This attack is the third such attack by Russia on a merchant vessel within the period of a month and has raised concerns regarding the safety of merchant vessels involved in maritime trade in the region amidst growing hostilities.

headline: FERRINDO 5 Grounds Near Pontianak Refloated Safely After Delay
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![FERRINDO 5 ran aground in Indonesian water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FERRINDO_5_2a7190f86a.png)*Ro-Ro vessel FERRINDO 5, Image credit: Iwan Afwan* The 3,587 gross ton Ro-Ro cargo ship, [FERRINDO 5](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:704889/mmsi:525019482/imo:8702501/vessel:FERRINDO_5#overview), ran aground while it was en route to the Pontianak port on October 4 at around 6:48 PM WIB (Western Indonesian Time). The mishap of the vessel [FERRINDO 5](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:704889/mmsi:525019482/imo:8702501/vessel:FERRINDO_5#overview) was reported to the relevant authorities, and a warning was posted to the vessels traversing nearby so as for them to maintain a safe distance from the grounded vessel and avoid similar complications. The Indonesian-flagged vessel awaited the high tide to be refloated and resumed its journey once more the following morning. Following a successful refloat, the vessel resumed its journey. The Marine Traffic data shows that the 1987-built vessel [FERRINDO 5](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:704889/mmsi:525019482/imo:8702501/vessel:FERRINDO_5#overview) is partially laden and departed from [PONTIANAK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/19942?name=PONTIANAK&country=Indonesia) on 06 October.

headline: Sailing Yacht Sustains Severe Damage After Collision with Cargo Vessel
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![LOTTA vessel collided with small yacht in German water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LOTTA_72e5ae4843.png)*Image credit: DGzRS* On 3rd October, a general cargo vessel, [LOTTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:235763/mmsi:210586000/imo:9629809/vessel:ZUIDVLIET#overview), collided with a sailing yacht. The accident occurred at the Outer Elbe, around five nautical miles west- northwest of Scharhorn, a small island in the North Sea. [LOTTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:235763/mmsi:210586000/imo:9629809/vessel:ZUIDVLIET#overview), a 88.6- metre-long vessel came in contact with a 9.5-metre-long yacht under the moderate rough sea and wind conditions. In the collision the yacht sustained significant damages to its hull whereas the cargo vessel sustained minimal damage. At 6:40 AM local time, the Cuxhaven Traffic Control Center, part of the Federal Waterways and Shipping Administration, alerted the Maritime Rescue Coordination Center in Bremen, Germany about the collision. The German Sea Rescue Association (DGzRS) promptly responded to the incident and deployed two sea rescue cruisers to the scene. The general cargo vessel, [LOTTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:235763/mmsi:210586000/imo:9629809/vessel:ZUIDVLIET#overview), remained nearby at the site. A small yacht came to assist the damaged yacht, preventing it from running aground on the nearby Scharhorn reef before the rescue cruises arrived. Later, sea rescue cruisers arrived at the scene and stabilised the damaged yacht. Upon inspection of the yacht, it was discovered that the collision had caused a significant hole on the port side of the hull, just above the waterline, as well as a broken mast. When the mast broke, the sail fell into the water and draped over the hole in the hull, effectively blocking it and preventing water ingress. Fortunately, no injuries were reported. The solo sailor on the damaged yacht and the crew of [LOTTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:235763/mmsi:210586000/imo:9629809/vessel:ZUIDVLIET) were reported safe in the incident. The DGzRS towed the yacht to Cuxhaven. The Marine Traffic data shows that the Cyprus-flagged cargo vessel [LOTTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:235763/mmsi:210586000/imo:9629809/vessel:ZUIDVLIET#overview) is laden and is scheduled to arrive at [KLAIPEDA Port](lhttps://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/771?name=KLAIPEDA&country=Lithuania), Lithuania on 05 October.

headline: Two Bulk Carriers Collide in Bosphorus; Prompt Response Prevents Major Grounding
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![AYED 1 vessel collided with BUNUN ACE.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/AYED_1_866cce71af.png)*Vessel AYED 1,image credit: KEGM* On 3rd October, a maritime accident occurred involving the collision between the two bulk carriers [AYED 1 ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:418256/mmsi:671414100/imo:9281138/vessel:AYED_1)and [BUNUN ACE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:413973/mmsi:354196000/imo:9628570/vessel:BUNUN_ACE) while the vessels were navigating through the water near Pasalimani area, along the Bosphorus Strait, Turkey. The Turkey Directorate General of Coastal Safety stated that the bulk carriers collided, scraping off against each other. The pilot captain aboard the vessel [BUNUN ACE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:413973/mmsi:354196000/imo:9628570/vessel:BUNUN_ACE) along with the maneuvering support tugboat prevented the vessel from drifting off course and potentially running aground along the Uskudar coast, crowded with people. This quick action averted a more serious incident. The collision caused material damage to both the bulk carriers. No casualties were reported nor any environmental pollution was observed in the incident. Following the collision, the bulk carriers were towed safely to Istanbul Anchorage.

headline: Latest US Sanctions Target Houthi Smuggling Network
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![FRUNZE and another vessel sanctioned by US.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FRUNZE_a0a169fbc8.png)*Vessel FRUNZE, image credit: Chin-Hsi* The latest set of US sanctions from the U.S. Department of the Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) came on 2 October. The sanctions have targeted two vessels, four entities, and one Iranian operative. The Marshall Islands-based Gemini Marine Limited and its two vessels, the [IZUMO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:757440/mmsi:626466000/imo:9249324/vessel:IZUMO) and the [FRUNZE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:730763/mmsi:518998343/imo:9263643/vessel:FRUNZE), are being sanctioned. The [IZUMO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:757440/mmsi:626466000/imo:9249324/vessel:IZUMO) is a Gabon-flagged vessel that has been specifically implicated in the smuggling of Iranian oil, the proceeds from which are then in turn used to finance attacks in the Red Sea. The Crude oil tanker has been linked to the transport of oil for the company Sepehr Energy Jahan Nama Pars, which has been identified as a front for the Iranian military. This led both Izumo and its owner, Gemini Maritime Ltd., to be sanctioned. Cook Island flagged vessel [FRUNZE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:730763/mmsi:518998343/imo:9263643/vessel:FRUNZE), has been identified as an asset in which Gemini Maritime has an interest and hence has also been targeted in the sanctions. The US government claims that three of the sanctioned companies, namely Shenzhen Boyu Imports and Exports Co. Ltd., Shenzhen Jinghon Electronics Ltd. and Shenzhen Rion Technology Co. Ltd were found to be supplying components for the construction of missiles, Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) and other military equipment to the Houthis. An Iranian operative named Hasan Ahmad Hasan Muhammad al-Kuhlani has been sanctioned for coordinating the smuggling efforts.

headline: Vanuatu Flagged General Cargo Ship runs aground in Russia
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Florica vessel grounded in Russian water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FLORICA_343bccd0ac.png)*Vessel FLORICA, image credit: Titu Sorin* The General Cargo ship,[ FLORICA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:702010/mmsi:577459000/imo:8837904/vessel:FLORICA), reportedly ran aground in the Don River, in Russia’s Oblast region. The incident occurred at around 1:50 PM Moscow time on 2 October, when the vessel became stuck in a sandbar. The vessel was carrying a crew of 14 Azerbaijani citizens, all of whom are reported to be safe and uninjured following the incident. Local authorities launched two tugboats to aid in refloating the ship, and authorities have confirmed that the grounding of the vessel has not led to any traffic incidents in the area, and operations are continuing without significant delay. The [FLORICA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:702010/mmsi:577459000/imo:8837904/vessel:FLORICA) is a 2,980 gross ton vessel registered in Vanuatu and was built in 1990. The vessel is 115 m long and 13 m wide.

headline: CMA CGM Vessel Collides With Dock Following Mechanical Failure
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![CMA CGM BALBOA collided with a dock in Colombia.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CMA_CGM_BALBOA_3dfca94455.png)*Vessel CMA CGM BALBOA, image credit: Direccion General Maritima* The CMA CGM container ship, [CMA CGM BALBOA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:757920/mmsi:229528000/imo:9344655/vessel:CMA_CGM_BALBOA), collided with a dock at [BARRANQUILLA Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1476?name=BARRANQUILLA&country=Colombia), Colombia, on October 3. The collision reportedly occurred due to a mechanical failure, leading the vessel to go adrift and end up colliding with the port infrastructure. The [CMA CGM BALBOA ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:757920/mmsi:229528000/imo:9344655/vessel:CMA_CGM_BALBOA)is a 22,914-gross-ton vessel built in 2007 and registered in Malta. The containership was carrying 2,700 tons of cargo at the time of the collision. The incident occurred early in the morning of October 3, at around 4:00 AM. The ship reportedly experienced mechanical failure, causing it to go adrift and end up hitting the dock. ![CMA CGM BALBOA.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CMA_CGM_BALBOA_3225738953.png) No subsequent pollution or injuries to the crew were reported. However, it is reported that the containership sustained damage, with a punctured hull and ballast tanks. The extent of the damage to the vessel is still being assessed, depending on whether the vessel is to be dry-docked or travel to its next port for repairs.

headline: ILA Strike Ends with Compromise on Pay Raises; Automation Issues Remain Unresolved
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![US Dock workers on Strike Ends.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ILA_77dc26d544.png)*Image credit: International Longshoremen’s Association(ILA)* The strike that was launched by 45,000 workers of the International Longshoremen’s Association (ILA) on October 1 came to an end with a temporary agreement forged with the United States Maritime Alliance (USMX). Although the strike lasted only from October 1 to October 3, almost 45 containerships are currently in queue to unload cargo at the 36 ports that were shuttered in the strike. The disruption had threatened to raise prices had it continued for any longer, especially in the backdrop of Hurricane Helene, which struck the Southeastern states just as the strike began. The destruction caused by the hurricane threatened supply chains for the essential goods such as food and pharmaceuticals, prompting the Biden administration to urge the USMX to reach a deal. The new temporary agreement is to extend the master contract to 15 January, 2025, with a few compromises made on the demands of both the ILA and the USMX. The contending parties have settled for a pay raise of 62% over the course of 6 years, which is a compromise on the offers of both the ILA, which demanded a 77% raise, and the USMX, which had offered a 50% raise. With the new contract in place, both parties will return to the negotiating table again, and the striking workers will return to their jobs immediately. However, the disagreement between the ILA and the USMX was not completely resolved, as one of the major points of contention, namely automation in ports, remained unaddressed in the agreement. The Biden administration, the National Association of Manufacturers, and the National Retail Federation have lauded the efforts of both the ILA and the USMX for reaching an agreement and thwarting further economic and supply chain disruptions.

headline: Fire Contained on Ro-Ro Ship ARIBURNU Following Extensive Firefighting Operations
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Fire aboard ARIBURNU.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ARIBURNU_e3fd2d643b.png)*Ro-Ro vessel ARIBURNU, image credit: KEGM* A fire broke out aboard the Ro-Ro ship[ ARIBURNU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:335925/mmsi:271002566/imo:8850683/vessel:ARIBURNU#overview), traveling from Kumkapi to Zonguldak. After receiving the fire incident report, Turkey’s General Directorate of Coastal Safety immediately dispatched its tug boats and rescue boat to assist the distressed vessel located off the coast of Sile in the Black Sea, Turkey. A firefighting and cooling operation was launched to extinguish the fire on the 595 dwt vessel. The firefighting continued throughout the night. By the next day, the Directorate of Coastal Safety on 25 September confirmed the fire was contained, and the cooling of the vessel continued. No casualties were reported in the incident. However, the cause of the fire aboard the ARIBURNU is yet to be determined. [ARIBURNU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:335925/mmsi:271002566/imo:8850683/vessel:ARIBURNU#overview) is a 1944-built Ro-Ro vessel sailing under the Turkish flag. The 64-metre-long vessel transports vehicles, equipment, and potential passengers from the Istanbul region to Zonguldak.

headline: Port of Long Beach, Shenzhen, and South Coast AQMD Sign Green Agreement for Sustainable Development
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![PORT OF LONG BEACH.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PORT_OF_LONG_BEACH_cc1c3873a3.png)*Image credit: Port of LONG BEACH* A Memorandum of Cooperation has been signed between the [Port of LONG BEACH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2727?name=LONG-BEACH&country=USA), Hutchison Ports Yantian, the South Coast Air Quality Management District, and the North American Representative Office of Shenzhen for cooperation and collaboration on the goal of decarbonizing maritime trade and sustainable development by building a green maritime economy around the Pacific Rim. The agreement, which was signed on 22 September in Shenzhen, China, establishes a framework for sharing resources and knowledge to the end of sustainable development of the ports and decarbonizing the maritime industry. Within the agreement, the participants will endeavor to deploy clean technologies, promote sustainable infrastructure development, and promote economic development with a focus on sustainability and public health. Collaborations between the participants are to involve demonstrations involving maritime technology and programs to encourage more environmentally friendly vessels. The memorandum will also explore the possibility of a sister port agreement between the ports of Yantian and Long Beach. This would not only align with the environmental objectives of the memorandum but will also create economic advantages and operational efficiencies.

headline: Containers knocked off a FESCO Boxship in Nansha
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![VLADIVOSTOK knock off three containers after colliding with another vessel. ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/VLADIVOSTOK_ed523f0089.png)*Vessel VLADIVOSTOK, image credit: Rex Tsai* Three containers were knocked off a FESCO Boxship on 21 September in Nansha as it collided with another vessel. During the next couple of days, the containers were successfully salvaged and returned to the boxship. The accident occurred at around 9:45 PM local time. The FESCO Boxship [VLADIVOSTOK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:122178/mmsi:667001869/imo:9130145/vessel:VLADIVOSTOK#overview) was struck by another vessel when it was docked at the Phase III container terminal at the [NANSHA Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17411?name=NANSHA&country=China) and was undergoing loading and unloading operations. The vessel that struck the blow was the [DE XIN SHANG HAI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9058037/mmsi:352004491/imo:1061843/vessel:DE_XIN_SHANG_HAI), a container ship that was arriving at Nansha from Hong Kong on its maiden voyage. The impact sent three containers from the [VLADIVOSTOK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:122178/mmsi:667001869/imo:9130145/vessel:VLADIVOSTOK#overview) hurling into the water. The Guangzhou Maritime Rescue and Coordination Centre responded promptly and sent two patrol boats along with two tugboats to manage the situation. Within two hours, two of the containers were secured to the [VLADIVOSTOK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:122178/mmsi:667001869/imo:9130145/vessel:VLADIVOSTOK#overview), and the remaining container was secured by another tugboat to prevent it from drifting off. A salvage boat came by 2:45 AM, and all three containers had been successfully retrieved by 8:30 AM the next day. As of now, both the vessels involved in the collision are docked at the [NANSHA Port ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17411?name=NANSHA&country=China)and are awaiting damage assessment and further investigation.

headline: Container Ship collides With Two Others At Constanta Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![SKY LIGHT collide with vessels in Constanta Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SKY_LIGHT_f27ab92a35.png)*Containership SKY LIGHT, image credit:replicaonline.ro* The 9,616-gross-ton container vessel [SKY LIGHT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7560018/mmsi:312991000/imo:9118513/vessel:SKY_LIGHT) collided with two other vessels moored at the Constanta Port in Romania on 19 September. The[ SKY LIGHT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7560018/mmsi:312991000/imo:9118513/vessel:SKY_LIGHT) collided with two other vessels moored at the Constanta Port as it performed a berthing maneuver at Berth 52. The accident occurred at around 10:55 AM local time and caused significant material damage to the vessels involved. Fortunately, no casualties or pollution have been reported from any of the three vessels involved in the collision. The Constanta Port Authority has opened an investigation into the causes and the circumstances behind the incident. The subsequent investigations will be used to determine whether it was a technical failure, human error, or unfortunate circumstances that led to the accident. For now, the focus is primarily on assessing the material damage to the three vessels. [SKY LIGHT ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7560018/mmsi:312991000/imo:9118513/vessel:SKY_LIGHT)is a 1996-built container ship sailing under the flag of Belize. The Marine Traffic data shows the vessel departed from [AMBARLI Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17436?name=AMBARLI&country=Turkey), Turkey, on 17 September and is currently in ballast moored at the [CONSTANTA Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/67?name=CONSTANTA&country=Romania).

headline: South Korea Launches Testing of First Fully Autonomous Oceangoing Vessel
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![POS SINGAPORE autonomous oceangoing vessel, begin sea trial.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/POS_SINGAPORE_3905139603.png)*Vessel POS SINGAPORE, image credit: JUNE* The first large fully autonomous oceangoing vessel, the [POS SINGAPORE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8609910/mmsi:636023532/imo:9974773/vessel:POS_SINGAPORE#overview), began testing on 23 September, 2024. The Ministry of Trade of South Korea held a sail-away ceremony for the Liberian flagged vessel at the[ BUSAN Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/793?name=BUSAN&country=Korea), South Korea. The [POS SINGAPORE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8609910/mmsi:636023532/imo:9974773/vessel:POS_SINGAPORE#overview) is the first oceangoing vessel with level 3 autonomy, meaning the vessel can operate without a crew onboard, allowing for a high degree of automation. It has a length of 172 meters and a beam of 27 meters. The vessel is equipped with advanced navigation systems that monitor and interpret environmental conditions, ensuring safe and efficient operations. The vessel is a part of the Korea Autonomous Surface Ship (KASS) project, a $120 million project undertaken by the Korean Ministry of Ocean and Fisheries in 2020. It was built by the Hyundai Mipo Dockyard and delivered to Pan Ocean. The [POS SINGAPORE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8609910/mmsi:636023532/imo:9974773/vessel:POS_SINGAPORE#overview) is set to undergo a year of testing on routes between Korea and Southeast Asia to target the effectiveness of its automated systems, engine automation, and cybersecurity. The South Korean Ministry of Oceans and Fisheries aims to set a benchmark for the more widespread adoption of autonomous shipping technology with the data obtained from the tests of the [POS SINGAPORE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8609910/mmsi:636023532/imo:9974773/vessel:POS_SINGAPORE#overview).

headline: Cargo Carrier ASIA GLORY 6 Runs Ashore in Bima Bay, Indonesia
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![ASIA GLORY 6 ran aground in Indonesian water. ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ASIA_GLORY_6_28443d092f.png)*General Cargo vessel ASIA GLORY 6, image credit: Indonesia Directorate General of Sea Transportation* The 7748 DWT cargo carrier [ASIA GLORY 6](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:706068/mmsi:525200078/imo:9101572/vessel:ASIA_GLORY_6#overview) ran ashore in Bima Bay, off of Benteng Asakota, in the West Nusa Tenggara province of Indonesia, on 21 September. The vessel ran ashore, trying to avoid a collision with a fishing vessel. All 20 crew members aboard the vessel are reported to be safe. On the evening of 21 September, the cargo ship[ ASIA GLORY 6](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:706068/mmsi:525200078/imo:9101572/vessel:ASIA_GLORY_6#overview) was headed towards [BIMA Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/19836?name=BIMA&country=Indonesia). As the vessel entered the bay, the fishing vessel KM Sabuk Nusantara 49 approached it and was in danger of collision. The bulker veered to starboard to avoid a collision and ended up running ashore. No reports of pollution from the vessel or injuries of crewmembers have been reported. A team was promptly dispatched to the scene, and after inspection, only minor damage to the ballast tank of the bulker was found. The vessel is to be refloated at the next high tide and continue its journey to Bima port.

headline: Fishing Vessel Capsizes After Collision with Panama-flagged Bulk Carrier, 12 Rescued
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![TRANSFORMER OL collided with the fishing vessel in Vietnam water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/TRANSORMER_OL_ab95c5172f.png)*Vessel TRANSFORMER OL, image credit: Tim Barker* The 169-meter-long, 23,375-dwt bulk carrier [TRANSFORMER OL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:463477/mmsi:372789000/imo:9550216/vessel:TRANSFORMER_OL#overview) collided with the fishing vessel BV99778TS around 22 nautical miles southeast of Con Dao, Vietnam, on 19 September. The collision caused the fishing vessel to capsize and partially sink. 12 of the 14 crewmembers who were aboard the bulker have been rescued. The collision occurred when the [TRANSFORMER OL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:463477/mmsi:372789000/imo:9550216/vessel:TRANSFORMER_OL#overview) was headed from [CHITTAGONG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2743?name=CHITTAGONG&country=Bangladesh), Bangladesh, to [VUNG TAU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/22548?name=VUNG-TAU-ANCH&country=Vietnam), Vietnam. The collision caused the fishing vessel to capsize and partially submerge, sending all 14 crewmembers into the water. Nearby fishing vessels responded promptly and managed to rescue 12 of the 14 crewmembers. One of the rescued crew members is reported to have sustained serious injuries and was taken to Con Dao for treatment. The Vietnamese Coast Guard was notified, and they launched a search and rescue effort. The search continued for the next two days in inclement weather involving 7-meter high waves and strong wind. On September 21, the Coast Guard found the body of one of the missing sailors, which had been sent ashore to authorities. The last sailor still remains to be found.

headline: Harbour workers' strike on the US East Coast is imminent
author: Stephanie Duscha
content: ![New York.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/New_York_4fd811e7fd.png) The ports along the East and Gulf coasts of the USA are facing an imminent strike. Although negotiations are currently underway between the International Longshoremen's Association (ILA) and the United States Maritime Alliance (USMX), a labour strike is unlikely to be avoided. The strike by around 45,000 workers in ports from Maine to Texas would have a drastic impact on global supply traffic. As an agreement has still not been reached in the wage negotiations between the ILA and the USMX, the port authorities are preparing for a strike by port workers at the end of the contract on 30 September. The strike would therefore begin on 1 October next week. If the approximately 45,000 port employees, who handle around 60% of US shipping traffic, lay down their work, the country's busiest ports will be closed. Bethann Rooney, director of the Port Authority of [New York](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/137?name=NEW-YORK&country=USA) and New Jersey, said in a recent briefing: ‘There will be a shutdown, assuming that there's is no intervention, at midnight on Monday the 30th’ Another spokesperson emphasised that $240 billion worth of goods move through the two ports each year and that this trade supports more than 600,000 local jobs. While cruise traffic would continue, all activities involving the loading and unloading of containers would stop. Exports would be blocked so that they do not reach the ports on the East and Gulf coasts and then remain there, explained Rooney. Container ships with imports for the relevant ports would either remain at sea or at least be allowed to dock at certain points in the harbours.

headline: Firefighters Struggle To Contain Fuel Spill from Sunken Vessel in the Icelandic Fjord
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![ADOLF JENSEN.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ADOLF_JENSEN_9cce09f796.png)*Research vessel, ADOLF JENSEN,image credit: Svend Bjerge* Firefighters are engaged in containing the fuel spill from a Research vessel, [ADOLF JENSEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:389605/mmsi:331185000/imo:6708575/vessel:ADOLF_JENSEN), that sank off the coast of Greenland. The 70 dwt ship hit a reef and ran aground on the night of 18 September. The police have reported a film of oil on the surface of the water in the Nanortalik fjords. The ship was carrying around 15,000 to 20,000 liters of diesel fuel and around 1000 liters of engine oil. Although efforts are underway to contain the spill, such as pumps and floating barriers, the tides, winds, and sea currents typical of the region are making it challenging to do so. All vessels traveling through the area have been advised to travel at low speeds so as to not disturb the oil and exacerbate the condition. The police and firefighters have received additional equipment to be able to contain the spreading spill, and the Environment and Civil Protection Ministry has also requested assistance from the Arctic command of the Danish Navy to recover the leaked fuel.

headline: Protestors from Environmental Groups Block Cruise Ships from Entering Marseilles
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Aidastella and other cruise ships stopped from entering Marseilles](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/AIDASTELLA_7c6d73f3e7.png)*Passenger ship AIDASTELLA, image credit: Michael R Thom* On 21st September, around 20 activists from the environmental group Extinction Rebellion and the Marseilles-based Stop Croisières staged a protest in Marseilles, France, by blocking entry of cruise ships to the port. The 20 protestors used inflatable kayaks to blockade entrance to the port, preventing the ships from entering. The demonstration caused three cruise ships delays in their itineraries. The ship [AIDASTELLA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:281715/mmsi:247322800/imo:9601132/vessel:AIDASTELLA#overview) had to turn back at 7:00 AM and wait for two hours nearby. While two other cruise ships, the [MSC WORLD EUROPA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7129879/mmsi:256070000/imo:9837420/vessel:MSC_WORLD_EUROPA) and the [COSTA SMERALDA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6005560/mmsi:247391900/imo:9781889/vessel:COSTA_SMERALDA), had to wait offshore till 9:30 AM to dock. A ferry coming from Corsica also ended up waiting due to the blockade. The Maritime Gendarmerie, which polices French waters, ended up removing the protestors, and the port reopened at about 9:00 AM. The protest was aimed at drawing attention to the environmental issues associated with cruise tourism. Along with the environmental issues, the activists also denounced the poor working conditions for staff working onboard cruise ships.

headline: Indonesian-Flagged Cargo Vessels Involved in Major Collision
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Trita Samudra XXXV collided with another vessel.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/TIRTA_SAMUDRA_XXXV_f70a741ccd.png)*Vessel TIRTA SAMUDRA XXXV,image credit: Waldin Alfian Parhusip* The general cargo ship, [TIRTA SAMUDRA XXXV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1048259/mmsi:525020261/imo:9738296/vessel:TIRTA_SAMUDRA_XXXV), was involved in a collision with another vessel, the [BENUA 999](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7718192/mmsi:525501778/imo:8597712/vessel:BENUA_999), in the waters of Karang Jamuan, Indonesia. The accident occurred on 18 September. The collision between the two vessels occurred at 7:35 PM local time, and both vessels sustained significant damage. The [TIRTA SAMUDRA XXXV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1048259/mmsi:525020261/imo:9738296/vessel:TIRTA_SAMUDRA_XXXV) sustained damage extending from the bridge to the stern on the starboard side, whereas the [BENUA 999](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7718192/mmsi:525501778/imo:8597712/vessel:BENUA_999) forecastle was bent, and its hull was torn by 2 to 3 meters. However, damage to both vessels was above the waterline, and both vessels were afloat. Fortunately, no casualties have been reported so far in the incident. The Maritime Coast Guard Base Tanjung Perak monitored the situation with patrol ships and ensured the vessels safety in the busy area in front of Petro Port. The [TIRTA SAMUDRA XXXV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1048259/mmsi:525020261/imo:9738296/vessel:TIRTA_SAMUDRA_XXXV) is a general cargo ship with a gross tonnage of 2,272 tons. It is flagged in Indonesia and was built in 2014. The BENUA 999 is a 2015-built larger vessel with a gross tonnage of 6,339 tons. The [BENUA 999](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7718192/mmsi:525501778/imo:8597712/vessel:BENUA_999) is also flagged in Indonesia.

headline: Federal Agents Conduct Inspection of MAERSK SALTORO in Baltimore Following Court Order
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![MAERSK SALTORO investigated FBI.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MAERSK_SALTORO_396d9a2132.png)*Containership MAERSK SALTORO,image credit: Frank katzer* On the morning of Saturday, September 21, a team of US federal agents conducted an investigation aboard the ship [MAERSK SALTORO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3515951/mmsi:563062200/imo:9725706/vessel:MAERSK_SALTORO) when it was docked at the port of Baltimore. The[ MAERSK SALTORO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3515951/mmsi:563062200/imo:9725706/vessel:MAERSK_SALTORO) has the same managing company as the [DALI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2810451/mmsi:563004200/imo:9697428/vessel:DALI), the ship that caused the bridge collapse at Baltimore in March this year. Federal agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI), the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), and the Coast Guard Investigative Service (CGIS) boarded the Maersk Saltoro in the early hours of September 21. Although the FBI confirmed that the inspection was backed by a court order, they declined to comment further on whether it was related to the investigation against [DALI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2810451/mmsi:563004200/imo:9697428/vessel:DALI). Federal authorities allowed the [MAERSK SALTORO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3515951/mmsi:563062200/imo:9725706/vessel:MAERSK_SALTORO) to resume operations shortly after the inspection. The agents of the FBI and other agencies conducted a thorough investigation but did not find any immediate issues that would prevent the vessel from operating. The [DALI ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2810451/mmsi:563004200/imo:9697428/vessel:DALI)and [MAERSK SALTORO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3515951/mmsi:563062200/imo:9725706/vessel:MAERSK_SALTORO) share same design and have been built by the same shipyard in Korea. However, despite the association, the [MAERSK SALTORO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3515951/mmsi:563062200/imo:9725706/vessel:MAERSK_SALTORO) has held a spotless track record since the vessel’s delivery in 2015 and has consistently met safety and operational standards.

headline: Crew Boat WIND OF HOPE Collides with Wind Turbine at Hornsea 1 Wind Farm, No Injuries Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![wind of Hope.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/wind_of_Hope_a68460066a.png)*image credits: Plague Christian* A maritime incident occurred involving a collision between the crew boat [WIND OF HOPE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6548023/mmsi:228388900/imo:9869045/vessel:WIND_OF_HOPE) and a wind turbine at the Hornsea 1 Wind Farm in the U.K. On 19th September, at around 6:38 AM local time, the vessel allided with a wind turbine at Ørsted’s Hornsea 1 Wind Farm, located off the east coast of England. In the incident, the vessel sustained damage on the starboard side above the waterline. The base of the turbine was also reported to have been damaged to some extent. There were 26 crew members and 46 specialist personnel on board at the time of the accident, and fortunately, no one was injured. Louis Dreyfus Armateurs (LDA), the owner of [WIND OF HOPE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6548023/mmsi:228388900/imo:9869045/vessel:WIND_OF_HOPE), stated that no pollution resulted from the accident. [WIND OF HOPE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6548023/mmsi:228388900/imo:9869045/vessel:WIND_OF_HOPE) is a crew boat built in 2021, sailing under the French flag. The 83-meter-long vessel has a carrying capacity of 2,000 tonnes and a draught of 5 meters. According to MarineTraffic data, the vessel is currently moored in [Grimsby](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/148?name=GRIMSBY&country=United-Kingdom), United Kingdom, where it will undergo inspection to assess the damage and determine the scope of repairs.

headline: Missile Strike Hits ODESA Port and Cargo Ship; Governor Confirms Damage and Injuries
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Golden Lion.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GOLDEN_LION_0c733cdda5.png)*General cargo vessel Golden Lion, image credit: Yoruk Isik* The Russian missile strike damaged the Ukraine Port of[ ODESA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/124?name=ODESA&country=Ukraine) and a general cargo vessel on 20th September. Four individuals were reported to be injured in the airstrike. Regional governor Oleh Kiper stated that the debris, believed to be from an “Iskander-M missile,” was discovered after the airstrike. The missile damaged both the port and civilian buildings. The governor also noted, without specifying the name of the vessel, that an Antigua Barbuda-flagged cargo vessel was also among those that sustained damage in the attack. Marine Traffic data show the vessel [GOLDEN LION](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:344280/mmsi:305727000/imo:9363974/vessel:GOLDEN_LION#overview) was docked at the Port of Odesa on 20th September after arriving from[ VARNA Anchorage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/22483?name=VARNA-ANCH&country=Bulgaria), Bulgaria. The cargo vessel was reported to be loaded with metal products. The 6,315 dwt vessel is scheduled to arrive at [SULINA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1318?name=SULINA&country=Romania) Port, Romania, on 22nd September.

headline: Oil Tanker "ThaiLaemthong 8" Runs Aground Off Thailand Amid Rough Seas, Crew Safe
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Thai Laemthong 8.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Thai_Laemthong_8_b54ca97b15.jpg) *Image Credits: Pattayamail.com* The oil tanker [ThaiLaemthong 8](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:669842/mmsi:567070900/imo:9058581/vessel:THAILAEMTHONG_8) ran aground off the coast of Koh Kood in the Trat province of Thailand on 17th September. The local authorities were immediately alerted, and the vessel is not at risk of sinking. The vessel encountered rough weather with waves up to 2 to 3 meters on 17 September, leading to engine failure, which in turn led to the grounding of the vessel at 6:00 AM (local time). Although the vessel has sustained a hull breach, the inflow of water is not severe, and water can be pumped out faster than it can flood in. All 10 crewmembers are also reported to be safe. The vessel was carrying green oil, a kind of fuel that is used in fishing boats, particularly those that operate in coastal or inland waters. The [ThaiLaemthong 8](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:669842/mmsi:567070900/imo:9058581/vessel:THAILAEMTHONG_8) was transporting this fuel from Rayong province to support fishing operations in Trat’s border when the mishap occurred. The vessel has dropped anchor near Koh Kooh and is awaiting repairs.

headline: Explosion Onboard Cargo Vessel "BBC Vermont" Claims Crewman’s Life
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![BBC VERMONT.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BBC_VERMONT_2bbfdaebb9.jpg) *General Cargo Vessel "BBC VERMONT", image credit: Nicolai Stula* An explosion onboard the general cargo vessel [BBC Vermont](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:363621/mmsi:305160000/imo:9357236/vessel:BBC_VERMONT) is reported to have cost the life of a crewman. The explosion occurred on September 18 when the vessel was around 490 nautical miles off of the Scilly Isles of the UK. The [BBC Vermont](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:363621/mmsi:305160000/imo:9357236/vessel:BBC_VERMONT) is a 2008-built, 9625-gross-ton vessel that is flagged in Antigua and Barbuda. It is 138.5 m long and has a beam of 21 meters. The vessel was traveling towards Montoir, France, and was expected to reach its destination on 22nd September.

headline: Wärtsilä to Upgrade Engines on Six of Chevron's LNG Tankers to Reduce Methane Emissions
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Chevron.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Chevron_9e8049bf1d.png) *One of Chevron's LNG Carrier. Image Credits: wartsila* Wartsila and Chevron have announced a partnership to reduce methane emissions from Chevron’s LNG carriers. The collaboration is focused around replacing one engine on six of Chevron’s LNG tankers, mitigating methane slip from engines, and thereby reducing emissions. This conversion was announced by Wartsila in a press release on 19 September. Wartsila will be replacing its 50DF engines on six of Chevron’s ships with SG engines, which use spark ignition to begin combustion rather than diesel pilot fuel. This will lead to more efficient combustion of methane and thereby reduce methane slip. Such an effort is the first in the maritime industry and is the result of two years of collaboration between Chevron and Wartsila. The order for the conversion of the first two vessels was placed in the third quarter of 2024. LNG carriers are infamous for their carbon intensity, with the International Council on Clean Transportation claiming that these were responsible for around 82% of the marine industry’s methane emissions. Methane is a much more powerful greenhouse gas than CO2, trapping around 25–30 times more heat than CO2.

headline: US DoJ Files $100M Lawsuit Against Singapore Firms Over Deadly Bridge Collapse
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Vessel Dali refloated](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Dali_9cbec1e253.png) *Image Credits: USACE Baltimore* The US Department of Justice (DoJ) has filed a civil lawsuit seeking damages and compensation worth $100 million against two Singaporean companies, which were the owner and operator of the vessel, [Dali](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2810451/mmsi:563004200/imo:9697428/vessel:DALI). The [Dali](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2810451/mmsi:563004200/imo:9697428/vessel:DALI) is the vessel that crashed into the Francis Scott Key Bridge on March 26, 2024, leading to the collapse of the bridge into the water and causing the death of 6 people. The companies, namely Grace Ocean and Synergy Marine, have been accused by the US DoJ of keeping the [Dali](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2810451/mmsi:563004200/imo:9697428/vessel:DALI) operational despite knowing that the ship was not seaworthy. In its filing, the DoJ has outlined a series of consequent mechanical failures, including power outages, failure of safety systems, and other known issues that led to the disaster. The DoJ asserts that its investigation revealed the intentional configuration of the vessel in a way that hindered quick restoration of propulsion and steering if the ship lost power. The DoJ also claimed that the defendants were aware of vibration issues on the ship that could lead to power outages, but they neglected to take corrective measures, choosing instead to resort to temporary fixes such as welding over cracks of critical components on the ship. Furthermore, the DoJ has stated that none of the four primary means of steering a ship—the propeller, rudder, anchor, or bow thrusters—functioned when needed at the time, leading to the accident. The lawsuit by the DoJ is to recover costs incurred by different arms of the US government in removing the debris from the bridge collapse, clearing the navigation channel, and mitigating risks against pollution. In addition to this, the DoJ is also seeking punitive damages to deter other shipowners and operators from repeating these mistakes. This civil suit is one part of a larger legal landscape surrounding the tragic bridge collapse in March. The bridge itself was owned by the State of Maryland, which will be filing a similar claim against the Dali’s owner and operator for recovering the cost of the damaged bridge. Furthermore, the FBI is conducting a criminal investigation into the events of the disaster. Grace Ocean and Synergy Marine have filed a motion of their own, trying to limit the damages that can be sought from them to $44 million. However, the US Congress has deemed the 170-year-old underlying law limiting the damages of shipowners to be obsolete and is seeking to change it.

headline: Maersk Conducts Japan's First Methanol Bunkering Simulation
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Alette Maersk](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Maersk_Alette_1974111ed3.png) *Image Credits: Maersk* Maersk co-hosted Japan's first methanol bunkering simulation at the port of Yokohama on 18th September. The methanol bunkering simulation was carried out with the [Alette Maersk](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8852261/mmsi:220000001/imo:9948774/vessel:ALETTE_MAERSK), the fifth dual-fuel methanol vessel in Maersk's fleet, alongside Kokuka Sangyo's methanol tanker, Eikamaru. Maersk signed a Memorandum of Understanding with the city of Yokohama and Mitsubishi Gas Chemical back in December of 2023. The aim of the agreement was to promote the use of methanol across Japanese shipping corridors. A number of operations, including berthing, unberthing, and hose connections, were tested in the simulation. Insights gained from the simulation will be used to further the goals of developing guidelines and enhancing the methanol fuel supply chain in the country. The initiative is being supported by other stakeholders, such as the Ministries of Land, Transport, and Infrastructure, along with Tourism’s Port and Harbor Bureau. These ministries are also planning to convene a study group focused on developing methanol bunkering hubs in Japanese ports.

headline: Vietnamese-Flagged Vessel Sinks in South China Sea
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![An Bình Phát 68.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/An_Binh_Phat_68_cf065e4b35.png) *image credits: www.qrt.vn* The Vietnamese flagged vessel, [An Binh Phat 68](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9011823/mmsi:574014535/imo:0/vessel:AN_BINH_PHAT_68), sank in the South China Sea near Quang Nam province in Vietnam. The ship was carrying 4,000 tons of powdered stone and was traveling through the waters near the Quang Nam Seaport. At around 1:42 PM local time on 18th September, the Quang Nam Port Authority received a distress call from the ship, stating that the vessel had tilted 45 degrees and declared its location. Soon after, the Quang Nam port authority contacted the Regional Maritime Search and Rescue coordination center, the Quang Nam Border Command, the coast guard of the region, and neighboring agencies to conduct the search and rescue of the vessel. The captain of the vessel was advised to close all valves of the fuel tank on the vessel so as to prevent pollution. According to more recent reports on September 19, the vessel has completely sunk, and all 8 crew members have been rescued by the Vietnamese Coast Guard.

headline: Gran Canaria Beaches Shut as Three Tonnes of Oil Spill Contaminates Coastline
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Oil spill at Port Las Palmas.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/AKHISAR_42bb21db8c.png)*Cargo vessel AKHISAR, image credit: Salvamento Maritimo* The Spanish authorities have closed several beaches on the Islands of Gran Canaria after an oil spill incident happened on 04th September. Namely, La Restinga, Palos, El Barranquillo, and San Bordon Beaches were closed to the public as the oil spill approached the coast. According to the Spain Maritime Rescue organisation, Salvamento Maritimo social media post, the bunker oil spill occurred during the refuelling of vessel [AKHISAR](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:335090/mmsi:636022809/imo:9237149/vessel:AKHISAR) at the port of [LAS PALMAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/221?name=LAS-PALMAS&country=Spain), Spain. The incident caused a leak of three tonnes of IFO 180, a very low sulfur oil, in the water. The President of the Gran Canaria governing council stated that the oil leak covered an area 2.5 kilometers long and 400 meters wide and was moving towards Telde, in the south. The authorities deployed resources to monitor and control the oil spill in the sea. Drones and helicopters were in the region assisting in the cleaning operation. [AKHISAR](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:335090/mmsi:636022809/imo:9237149/vessel:AKHISAR) is a general cargo vessel sailing under Liberia's flag. According to Marine Traffic, the vessel is laden and departed from [LAS PALMAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/221?name=LAS-PALMAS&country=Spain) on 07th September and is scheduled to arrive at[ PRAIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/23016?name=PRAIA&country=Cape-Verde), Cape Verde, by 11th September.

headline: QUEEN OF NEW WESTMINSTER Undergoing Extensive Repairs After Propeller loss and Oil Spill
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Propeller of Queen of New Westminster pulled out from seabed](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Propeller_of_Queen_of_New_Westminster_92797a85eb.png)*Propeller of QUEEN OF NEW WESTMINSTER, image credit: BC Ferries* On 07 September, BC Ferries reported that they had successfully recovered the propeller of their passenger ship, [QUEEN OF NEW WESTMINSTER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:379862/mmsi:316001255/imo:6413663/vessel:QUEEN_OF_NEW_WESTMINSTER#overview). On 03 September, BC Ferries had put [QUEEN OF NEW WESTMINSTER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:379862/mmsi:316001255/imo:6413663/vessel:QUEEN_OF_NEW_WESTMINSTER#overview) out of service, citing operational problems. On the next day, divers found that the ship's propeller had sheared off from the shaft, and around 800 liters of hydraulic oil had leaked off Canada's west coast. The ferry company has stated that the oil leak had quickly dispersed in the marine environment, and no oil sheen was observed. BC Ferries and the Canadian Coast Guard Authorities are actively working together to ensure all required measures are taken to reduce the potential environmental impact. The propeller, weighing around 4.5 tonnes, was found to be half submerged in the seabed when it was pulled out on 07 September for repair. Briefing on the possible cause for propeller loss, BC Ferries stated that the preliminary visual inspections suggest structural fatigue as the reason behind shaft fracture. The ferry company has said that the repair is going to be extensive, and they plan to work on both the port and starboard propeller systems. BC Ferries has cancelled all scheduled sailing of [QUEEN OF NEW WESTMINSTER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:379862/mmsi:316001255/imo:6413663/vessel:QUEEN_OF_NEW_WESTMINSTER#overview) till 30 September and is exploring options to accommodate passengers on other vessels. [QUEEN OF NEW WESTMINSTER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:379862/mmsi:316001255/imo:6413663/vessel:QUEEN_OF_NEW_WESTMINSTER#overview) is a 1964-built Canadian-flagged passenger ship currently moored at the [TSAWWASSEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/23252?name=TSAWWASSEN&country=Canada), Canada.

headline: Bulk Carriers Collide at Chittagong Port, Authorities Confirm Minimal Damage
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![NAVIOUS CELESTIAL collided with FRIENDLY ISLANDS.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NAVIOUS_CELESTIAL_0697759ec8.png)*Bulk carrier NAVIOS CELESTIAL, image credit: Andy Ru* The Bangladesh national news media reported a collision between two bulk carriers at the outer anchorage of[ CHITTAGONG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2743?name=CHITTAGONG&country=Bangladesh) Port. On September 07, at around 2 PM local time, bulk carrier [NAVIOS CELESTIAL ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:407479/mmsi:351335000/imo:9496226/vessel:NAVIOS_CELESTIAL)anchor dragged and collided with [FRIENDLY ISLANDS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:755723/mmsi:636015708/imo:9615042/vessel:FRIENDLY_ISLANDS#overview). [NAVIOS CELESTIAL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:407479/mmsi:351335000/imo:9496226/vessel:NAVIOS_CELESTIAL) is a Panama-registered bulk carrier loaded with 44000 tons of DAP fertilizers, while Liberian-flagged bulk carrier [FRIENDLY ISLANDS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:755723/mmsi:636015708/imo:9615042/vessel:FRIENDLY_ISLANDS#overview) was carrying 27000 tons of lentils at the time of the incident. The Chittagong Port Authority (CPA) stated that the vessels sustained minor damage, with no water ingress reported. All the crewmembers aboard both vessels were safe, and no pollution was observed. The authorities have launched an investigation to determine the cause of the collision of the two bulk carriers. The CPA stated that both bulk carriers have shifted their anchor position and are currently anchored safely. The CPA Secretary informed that the local agents and the Protection & Indemnity (P&I) representing both vessels are already involved in handling the compensation and settling the legal liabilities.

headline: Containership Escapes Disaster After Engine Malfunction at Tampa Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![TYNDALL escape from major accident.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/TYNDALL_3c6a453fe7.png)*Containership TYNDALL, image credit: Patrick Deenik* A containership escaped a major disaster after experiencing an engine malfunction while arriving at the port of [TAMPA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/202?name=TAMPA&country=USA), USA, on September 05. The containership [TYNDALL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:756216/mmsi:636016321/imo:9627928/vessel:TYNDALL#overview) was boarded by the Tampa harbor pilot to direct the vessel into the port. The vessel was at the speed of 1.5 knots while approaching the dock in Tampa Bay loaded with approximately 100,000 tons of cargo. When the Liberian-flagged container ship was 200 feet from docking, the harbor pilot ordered the engine to reverse to slow the vessel. Later, the harbor pilot found that the vessel’s engine did not start reversing, and the vessel continued moving forward, posing risks to another vessel, the cargo crane, and the docking area. Immediately, the harbor pilot changed the course of the containership and called for two tugboats to bring the vessel under control. Eventually, the vessel slowed down and went past the berth, avoiding crashing into other ships and port infrastructure. The incident had been reported to the U.S. Coast Guard, and the vessel would undergo a thorough examination before getting approval for departure from the [TAMPA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/202?name=TAMPA&country=USA) port. The Marine traffic data shows that [TYNDALL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:756216/mmsi:636016321/imo:9627928/vessel:TYNDALL#overview) is currently at the [TAMPA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/202?name=TAMPA&country=USA) port and is scheduled to arrive at [PUERTO CORTES](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2472?name=PUERTO-CORTES&country=Honduras), Honduras by September 09.

headline: Offering of commercial trials begin for the first fully electric cargo vessel of Singapore
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![HYDROMOVER commenced commercial trials in Singapore.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/HYDROMOVER_2efab2890a.png)*Vessel HYDROMOVER, image credit: Yinson Greentech* Yinson Greentech commenced commercial trials on September 6 for the [HYDROMOVER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8123120/mmsi:563082550/imo:0/vessel:HYDROMOVER), which is recognized as the first fully electric cargo vessel in Singapore. The commercial trials, which will continue for the coming months, will allow for entities to charter the vessel and experience its performance firsthand. The [HYDROMOVER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8123120/mmsi:563082550/imo:0/vessel:HYDROMOVER), launched in November 2023, is an 18.5-meter-long vessel that can carry up to 25 tons. The vessel can achieve up to 12 knots and travel up to 40 nautical miles when at maximum loading capacity. The vessel is powered by swappable batteries, which can be switched when in port in a matter of minutes, allowing for a quick turnaround time. The [HYDROMOVER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8123120/mmsi:563082550/imo:0/vessel:HYDROMOVER) is claimed to reduce operational costs by up to 50%, owing to its greater energy efficiency and reduced operational costs. Yinson Greentech has announced that it has already received letters of intent from six partners that intend on chartering the [HYDROMOVER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8123120/mmsi:563082550/imo:0/vessel:HYDROMOVER) with the intent of potentially electrifying their fleets. The partners, namely Lita Ocean, DM Sea Logistics, OPL Services, RW Mainlines Services, Tian San Shipping, and Kanlian Ferry, have a combined fleet of over 200 vessels. This implies a great demand for the production of electric vessels should the partners opt for the electrification of their fleets. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore has declared that all harbor craft are to become fully electric, use B100 biofuels, or become compatible with net zero fuels such as hydrogen by 2030. These commercial trials are expected to provide crucial data regarding the feasibility, efficiency, and safety of using electric vessels in the maritime sector, bringing electric cargo ships a step closer to widespread adoption.

headline: Crude Oil Tankers Load in Libyan Ports Amid Export Suspension Over Political Dispute
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![FRONT JAGUAR arrives at Libya port amid the oil export suspension.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FRONT_JAGUAR_739155e836.png)*Crude oil tanker FRONT JAGUAR, image credit: Gary Waters* Reuters news media reported that some crude oil tankers were allowed to load oil from the Libyan Port despite an ongoing suspension to export oil in Libya. This signals the easing of the political deadlock between the warring factions in Libya, as ships are gradually being let in to load oil. According to Marine Traffic data, the crude oil tanker, [FRONT JAGUAR](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4113838/mmsi:538006772/imo:9703332/vessel:FRONT_JAGUAR), a Marshall Island flagged vessel, arrived at the [MARSA BREGA Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/19334?name=MARSA-BREGA&country=Libya), Libya on September 04 to load oil cargo. The 1,09,900 dwt oil tanker departed from the port recently and is en route to [SOUTHAMPTON](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/106?name=SOUTHAMPTON&country=United-Kingdom) Port, United Kingdom. The vessel is due to arrive there on September 14. Another oil tanker, the [KRITI SAMARIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:730064/mmsi:636017739/imo:9329409/vessel:KRITI_SAMARIA#overview) has been allowed to enter the oil export terminal of Zueitina, Libya. The vessel is scheduled to load 600,000 barrels of crude oil. Libyan oil exports have been suspended for over a week due to a political dispute involving the central bank and oil revenues. The conflict is about the rival governments exerting control over the Central bank of Libya (CBL), which is an authorized body that receives oil revenue and is responsible for paying the government salaries in Libya. On August 18, the western factions attempted to remove the 13 year tenure Governor of CBL. As retaliation, the eastern factions ordered the shutdown of oil production in Libya on August 26. Reports indicate that the two factions have reached a truce to jointly appoint the new president of the CBL by October 3. As of now, this ongoing conflict has resulted in Libya's oil output having dropped by more than half to just over 590,000 barrels per day.

headline: US sanctions two LNG vessels, ratcheting up pressure on Russia’s Arctic LNG 2 project
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![MULAN and another vessel sanctioned by US.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MULAN_90722e2353.png)*Vessel MULAN, image credit: Mrti Briedis* The US State Department on September 5 imposed sanctions on two shipping companies and two vessels that were involved in the export of LNG from the Russian Arctic LNG 2 project. The vessel LNG/C [NEW ENERGY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5169579/mmsi:511101461/imo:9324277/vessel:NEW_ENERGY) has been charged with using deceptive practices and turning off its AIS transponder while engaging in ship-to-ship transfer of LNG from the already sanctioned vessel LNG/C[ PIONEER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:376203/mmsi:511101396/imo:9256602/vessel:PIONEER#overview). Gotik Energy Shipping Co. (Gotik) and Plio Energy Cargo Shipping OPC PVT LTD (Plio Energy), which are the shipowner and the commercial manager, respectively, of the vessel LNG/C [NEW ENERGY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5169579/mmsi:511101461/imo:9324277/vessel:NEW_ENERGY), are also being sanctioned by the US government. In addition to this, the vessel LNG/C [MULAN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7950542/mmsi:511101434/imo:9864837/vessel:MULAN), managed by Pilo Energy, has been identified as Pilo Energy’s property of interest and, hence, has also been sanctioned. The ship-to-ship transfer of LNG in question took place on August 25, 2024. The US government, in its announcement, states that the LNG was sourced from the Arctic LNG 2 project and transferred onto the LNG/C [NEW ENERGY ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5169579/mmsi:511101461/imo:9324277/vessel:NEW_ENERGY)from the LNG/C Pioneer, which had already been sanctioned two days earlier on August 23. The US government is using a variety of means to hamstring the Arctic LNG 2 project before it becomes fully operational. The stern stance of the US against the Russian LNG 2 project is to prevent Russia from gaining revenue from energy exports, which the US authorities believe to be used in funding the Russian military.

headline: Titan completes its first SIMOPS bunkering in Ghent, Belgium
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Titan completes its first SIMOPS bunkering by delivering LNG to Thun Vettern ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/THUN_VETTERN_1e9b5ea600.png)*Vessel THUN VETTERN, image credit: Maik Van Der Zwan* Titan, the leading supplier of Liquefied Natural Gas (LNG) and liquefied biomethane (LBM) has completed its first SIMOPS bunkering operation in Belgium. The company successfully delivered 180 metric tons of LNG to the newbuild vessel [THUN VETTERN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8823152/mmsi:265053000/imo:9971214/vessel:THUN_VETTERN#overview). SIMOPS, an abbreviation for Simultaneous Operations in the context of LNG bunkering, is the process of fueling a vessel with LNG while simultaneously other tasks are being performed at the port or on the vessel. This increases efficiency as the bunkering time is saved, and the vessel can make a quick turnaround from the port. Titan’s [FLEXFUELLER 001](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5923521/mmsi:244041229/imo:0/vessel:FLEXFUELER_001) performed the SIMOPS bunkering, and it was the first instance of Titan delivering LNG at the Seatank terminal situated in [GHENT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/122?name=GHENT&country=Belgium), Belgium. Incidentally, this was also the first time the vessel [THUN VETTERN ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8823152/mmsi:265053000/imo:9971214/vessel:THUN_VETTERN#overview)had been bunkered in Northern Europe. Titan has stated that they regularly use their Flexfueler bunker barges for vessels in the ARA (Amsterdam-Rotterdam-Antwerp) region.

headline: Hybrid Ro-Ro Vessel CANOPEE Completes Inaugural U.S. Visit, Successfully Delivers ESM-3 Module for NASA Mission
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![CANOPEE arrive at Port Canaveral marking its first US port call.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CANOPEE_f11de6856c.png)*Ro-Ro vessel CANOPEE, image credit: Canaveral Port Authority* On September 02, [CANOPEE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7438223/mmsi:228438700/imo:9924120/vessel:CANOPEE#overview) made its inaugural U.S. port call and was welcomed at Port [CANAVERAL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/210?name=CAPE-CANAVERAL&country=USA). [CANOPEE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7438223/mmsi:228438700/imo:9924120/vessel:CANOPEE#overview) is built by ArianeGroup in 2022 and operated by Alizes. The world's first hybrid propulsion commercial Ro-Ro cargo vessel features 4 wing sails consisting of two flaps on the front and one at the rear. These sails can rotate 360 degrees to optimise the wind capture. The designer of these sails claimed that the installed sails on the vessel can produce significantly more energy than the traditional sails. Moreover, the builder of the vessel noted that these sails enable the ship to reduce fuel consumption up to 30% in every trip. The 5,491 dwt vessel is designed to transport Ariane 6 rocket parts from European Ports to French Guiana for the European Space Agency. The Ro-Ro vessel arrived at the Port of [CANAVERAL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/210?name=CAPE-CANAVERAL&country=USA) to deliver the European Service Module (ESM-3). The EMS-3 which will fly aboard NASA's Artemis III mission to the moon. The Ambassador Services International, a logistic and stevedoring company, managed the unloading of EMS-3 from the vessel and transporting it to the Kennedy Space Center. According to the Marine Traffic[ CANOPEE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7438223/mmsi:228438700/imo:9924120/vessel:CANOPEE#overview), registered under the flag of France, departed from Port[ CANAVERAL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/210?name=CAPE-CANAVERAL&country=USA) on September 04 and is scheduled to arrive at[ ANTWERP](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/117?name=ANTWERP&country=Belgium), Belgium, on September 17.

headline: ILA prepares for a potential strike from October 1 as contract expiration date approaches
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![New York Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NEW_YORK_Port_a099492cdc.png)*New York Port, image credit: Dallas Mayson* Fears of an impending strike from dockworkers in the US East Coast and Gulf Coast loom large as the negotiations between the International Longshoreman Association (ILA) union and the United States Maritime Alliance (USMX) have come to a deadlock. The ILA has begun preparations for a potential strike from October 1 if an agreement is not reached by September 30. The talks of a strike are primarily due to unresolved contract negotiations, which have been ongoing since 2022. The main points of contention are automation in ports threatening jobs, wages, retirement benefits and working conditions. Reports indicate that the ILA workers in New York and New Jersey make only around 55% of the salary of their counterparts that are in the International Longshore and Warehouse Union (ILWU) and are demanding a pay raise. The ILA insists that they will not continue working past the expiration of the current contract on September 30, should their demands not be met. With the ports in the East Coast and Gulf Coast handling around 43% of the nation's imports, a strike would already have far-reaching consequences and additional strain on the global supply chain, which is already reeling from the incidents in the Red Sea. Further worsening the situation is the fact that the holiday season is approaching along with the US presidential elections, which means increased sensitivity and a greater volume of cargo to be handled. The current labor deal impacts around 14,500 workers across 36 ports in the East Coast and Gulf Coast. A strike would potentially cause billions of dollars worth of cargo to be stranded, bring detention and demurrage charges for shippers, and cause lasting ripple effects in the supply chain that would be comparable to those caused by the Houthi attacks in the Red Sea. Experts state that for every day the strike remains, it would take four to six days more to clear the backlog that would be built. Due to the tremendous threat that such a strike would pose, many entities, such as the National Retail Federation, the Biden Administration, and US importers and exporters, are trying to persuade the ILA to resume negotiations after the [last time](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/maritime-news/21/ports/2024/11388/ila-workers-threaten-strike-on-us-east-and-gulf-coasts) negotiations broke down. However, ILA president Harold Daggett has stated that the parties are further apart than ever, especially concerning the economic conditions put down by the ILA.

headline: Grimaldi Group to offer new Ro-Ro service between Italy and Turkey
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Grimaldi Group is launching a new Ro-Ro service.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Grimaldi_2de83fe23e.png)*Grimaldi Vessel, image credit: Grimaldi Group* The Grimaldi Group is launching a new Ro-Ro service between Italy and Turkey.
