The new service is set to begin operations on September 14 and will connect the ports of [TRIESTE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/127?name=TRIESTE&country=Italy) and [AMBARLI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17436?name=AMBARLI&country=Turkey). Two of Grimaldi's most eco-friendly Ro-Ro vessels, the [ECO MALTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6698670/mmsi:247383800/imo:9859583/vessel:ECO_MALTA) and the [ECO MEDITERRANEA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7134662/mmsi:247383900/imo:9859595/vessel:ECO_MEDITERRANEA), are to be utilized on these routes, offering two weekly departures from each of the ports. These vessels, which are a part of the GG5G class, are equipped with technologies such as hybrid propulsion, lithium batteries for zero emissions in port, fuel-efficient design, and even solar panels covering 350 square meters on board. In comparison to the older generation of Ro-Ro vessels, the [ECO MALTA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6698670/mmsi:247383800/imo:9859583/vessel:ECO_MALTA) and the [ECO MEDITERRANEA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7134662/mmsi:247383900/imo:9859595/vessel:ECO_MEDITERRANEA) are twice as efficient in terms of CO2 generated per unit of cargo. The route would be of particular help to leading automobile manufacturers such as BMW, Land Rover, Kia, Hyundai, Mercedes-Benz, and others who would be able to leverage the new ro-ro service not only for the import of raw materials but for the export of finished products. The new route will satisfy the growing demand for an efficient maritime trade connection between Italy and Turkey. In addition to this, the strategic locations of Trieste, which would by extension offer access to Northern Italy and furthermore to central Europe, and that of Ambarli, which is in close proximity to Istanbul and Turkey's economic district, would significantly increase the efficiency of the existing supply chain and boost trade.

headline: Tugboat OSHIO Sinks in Singapore Waters, Singapore Authorities Launch Rescue Operation
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![OSHIO sank in Singapore water, one missing and another crewmember dead](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/OSHIO_0a8113d9c3.png)*Tugboat OSHIO, image credit: mgklingsick_aol_com* On September 04, at around 2:15 PM local time, a tugboat, [OSHIO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:725024/mmsi:563019020/imo:0/vessel:OSHIO), sank in the Eastern Anchorage, Singapore port limit. The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore in coordination with the Police Coast Guard and Singapore Civil Defence Force, launched a rescue mission for the missing crewmembers of [OSHIO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:725024/mmsi:563019020/imo:0/vessel:OSHIO#overview). [OSHIO ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:725024/mmsi:563019020/imo:0/vessel:OSHIO#overview)had two crewmembers onboard, of which one was rescued by the Police Coast Guard. MPA reported that the rescued crew was transferred to hospital, where he was later pronounced dead. The search for another missing crewmember continued. The salvage divers were activated to confirm the location of the sunken tugboat OSHIO for salvage operation. No pollution was reported in the region.

headline: Indian Coast Guard Helicopter Crashes During Evacuation Mission in Arabian Sea
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![HARI LEELA vessel injured crewmember evacuation caused a maritime incident.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/HARI_LEELA_620cf7f285.png)*Vessel HARI LEELA, image credit: Methin Mathew* The Indian Coast Guard reported a maritime incident involving the crashing of an aircraft into the Arabian Sea. On September 02, at around 11 PM local time, the Indian Coast Guard dispatched its Advanced Light Helicopter (ALH) to evacuate the injured crew member aboard the 1999-built Inland Motor tanker [HARI LEELA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:255374/mmsi:419001368/imo:9207728/vessel:HARI_LEELA). The Indian-flagged tanker was positioned approximately 30 nautical miles off the coast of Gujarat. The region was on high alert due to the approaching cyclonic weather conditions. The Marine Traffic data shows the vessel departed from [KANDLA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/269?name=KANDLA&country=India), India, on September 01. While conducting the evacuation operation, the helicopter, which had two pilots and two divers, was forced to make an emergency landing, which was described as a hard landing in the sea. Later, the helicopter sank into the water. The Indian Coast Guard launched a search and rescue operation to locate the members of the sank helicopter. One member was rescued, and the search for the remaining three is ongoing, stated the Indian Coast Guard. Indian news media reported that on September 03, two bodies were discovered from the Arabian Sea, while one member of the crashed helicopter is still missing.

headline: Cargo ship loaded with 20,000 tons of explosives docks in downtown Norway
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Ruby docks in downtown Norway loaded with explosive.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RUBY_aa237f4b05.png)*Vessel RUBY, image credit: Malcolm Cranfield* The cargo vessel [RUBY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1605/mmsi:229041000/imo:9626390/vessel:RUBY), registered in Malta, docked in Tromso harbor, Norway, after the vessel had experienced hull damage due to grounding. Concerns arose when the ship was discovered to be loaded with 20,000 tons of ammonium nitrate, a highly explosive substance. The 37,309-dwt [RUBY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1605/mmsi:229041000/imo:9626390/vessel:RUBY) was carrying the cargo from the Russian port of [KANDALAKSHA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/23929?name=KANDALAKSHA&country=Russia) to the Canary Islands. The vessel sailed out of [KANDALAKSHA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/23929?name=KANDALAKSHA&country=Russia) on August 22, and due to the ship suffering damage to its hull and propeller and facing inclement weather, it sought permission to sail to sheltered waters and arrived in [TROMSO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/267?name=TROMSO&country=Norway) on September 1. The dangerous nature of the cargo has caused multiple agencies to be involved in the resolution of this situation. These include the Norwegian police, Tromso harbor, the Directorate for Civil Protection and Emergency Planning (DSB), the Norwegian Maritime Authority, and the Norwegian Coastal Administration. The authorities have decided to have the ship relocated out of the Tromso harbor to an anchorage, although the exact destination has not been decided upon. The ship is to receive temporary repairs before being towed. Although ammonium nitrate is a great fertilizer, the chemical is most notable for its explosive properties. The chemical is usually stable under room temperature, but it can become unstable and explode under specific conditions, such as being exposed to an initiation charge or to increased heat and pressure. Unfortunately, the chemical burns when heated and produces gasses and heat, which can lead to a runaway reaction and cause an explosion. The same chemical caused the severe explosion in Beirut in 2020, when it was stored improperly alongside fireworks. For context, the Beirut explosion, which is considered to be the largest non-nuclear blast in history, was caused by around 2,750 tons of ammonium nitrate compared to the 20,000 tons onboard the [RUBY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1605/mmsi:229041000/imo:9626390/vessel:RUBY).

headline: MSC ANTONIA Loses 46 Containers Off South African Coast Amid Adverse Weather
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![MSC ANTONIA lost 46 containers in sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSC_ANTONIA_adfe866138.png)*Vessel MSC ANTONIA,image credit: Hannes Van Rijn* The South African Maritime Safety Authority (SAMSA) reported that the containership [MSC ANTONIA ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:686442/mmsi:636018660/imo:9398216/vessel:MSC_ANTONIA)lost 46 containers overboard due to adverse weather conditions. The incident occurred on August 28, when [MSC ANTONIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:686442/mmsi:636018660/imo:9398216/vessel:MSC_ANTONIA) was positioned 29 nautical miles northeast of Port St Johns, South Africa. The vessel was carrying approximately 305 containers aboard and had also sustained damages in the incident. [MSC ANTONIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:686442/mmsi:636018660/imo:9398216/vessel:MSC_ANTONIA) was en route from [COLOMBO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1272?name=COLOMBO&country=Sri-Lanka) to [NEW YORK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/137?name=NEW-YORK&country=USA). SAMSA stated that the vessel would undergo a thorough inspection and necessary repairs after arriving at [CAPE TOWN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/166?name=CAPE-TOWN&country=South-Africa) before continuing the voyage. Marine Traffic data shows that the Liberian-flagged containership departed from [COLOMBO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1272?name=COLOMBO&country=Sri-Lanka),Sri Lanka on August 15 and is currently at [CAPE TOWN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/166?name=CAPE-TOWN&country=South-Africa), South Africa. Earlier, on August 16, [CMA CGM BELEM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8829585/mmsi:256909000/imo:9938286/vessel:CMA_CGM_BELEM) also encountered adverse weather off the coast of Richard Bay and lost 99 containers in the sea. SAMSA informed that 20 containers were spotted in an aerial search on Friday last week but could not confirm that the 20 containers belong to [CMA CGM BELEM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8829585/mmsi:256909000/imo:9938286/vessel:CMA_CGM_BELEM).

headline: Samskip to retrofit LNG vessel with hydrogen-powered fuel cells
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Samskip Kvitnos to get retrofit with hydrogen-powered fuel cells](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Samskip_Kvitnos_e8ebe64d5b.png)*Ro-Ro vessel SAMSKIP KVITNOS,image credit: Samskip* Norwegian logistics provider Samskip has announced its plans to retrofit the LNG-powered vessel, [SAMSKIP KVITNOS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3455249/mmsi:259113000/imo:9642576/vessel:SAMSKIP_KVITNOS#overview), with hydrogen fuel technology developed by TECO 2030. The retrofit is to be carried out as a part of the HyEkoTank project in 2025. The HyEkoTank project is the world’s largest fuel cell retrofit project. It is a consortium of TECO 2030, Umoe, Shell, BLOM Maritime, Nav-Tech, FKAB Marine Design, Tarbit Shipping, and the Arctic University of Norway. The project provides standardized solutions for retrofits that can be adopted by a variety of seagoing and inland waterway vessels. In the partnership, TECO 2030 will provide the hydrogen fuel cells for the retrofit, and Umoe Advanced Composites will provide hydrogen storage solutions. The retrofit will ensure that the vessel remains compliant with the Fuel EU Maritime and EU ETS requirements for the remainder of its life. With regulations such as Fuel EU Maritime and EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS) incoming, shipowners like Samskip will face stricter requirements. The Kvitnos operates in a weekly multipurpose service, traveling from Rotterdam, along the Norwegian coast, to Hammerfest. Routes such as this, which pass through the Norwegian fjords, will have more stringent requirements with time. These include strict emissions monitoring, specific fuel requirements, and achieving zero emissions. Vessels below 10,000 gross tons are to reach net zero by 2026, with larger vessels having an extended deadline of achieving it by 2032.

headline: Stowaways Discovered on Bulk Carrier at Paradip Port: Authorities Probe Circumstances
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Three Ghana individuals found aboard GREAT SHENG WEN ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GREAT_SHENG_WEN_1e9763067f.png)*Bulk carrier GREAT SHENG WEN, image credit: Peter Beentjes* On August 30, three immigrants from Ghana were discovered hiding aboard the bulk carrier [GREAT SHENG WEN ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6944385/mmsi:477721700/imo:9244295/vessel:GREAT_SHENG_WEN)while the vessel was docked at the restricted area of [PARADIP PORT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17379?name=PARADIP&country=India), India. The three immigrants believed to be stowaways are under the custody of Paradip Port of Central Industrial Security Force (CISF) for investigation. The three Ghana individuals spotted aboard are not in the list of crewmembers of [GREAT SHENG WEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6944385/mmsi:477721700/imo:9244295/vessel:GREAT_SHENG_WEN). It is unclear of the exact circumstance of their boarding the vessel. The authorities have launched an investigation to determine three Ghanaian motive, their intended destination, and how and when they gained entry to the vessel. [GREAT SHENG WEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6944385/mmsi:477721700/imo:9244295/vessel:GREAT_SHENG_WEN) is a Hong Kong-flagged vessel that arrived at [PARADIP Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17379?name=PARADIP&country=India) to unload coal from [KAVKAZ Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17919?name=KAVKAZ&country=Russia), Russia. The Marine Traffic data shows the vessel is in ballast and departed from Paradip Port, India on September 01.

headline: Four seafarers abandoned aboard tugboat without pay
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Wycliffe seafarers abandoned by their shipowner without pay.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Wycliffe_9b58c8285a.png)*Tugboat WYCLIFFE, image credit: ITF* Four seafarers have been abandoned by their shipowner aboard the 60-year-old tugboat [WYCLIFFE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:452269/mmsi:577540000/imo:6605254/vessel:WYCLIFFE). The shipowner changed the flag state of the vessel to Vanuatu to evade the more stringent labor and safety regulations of the US. The seafarers hailing from Colombia, Panama, and Peru faced dire conditions during their contract aboard the ship. They are reported to have had inadequate food and water supplies and limited medical care. The ITF has undertaken the case of the seafarers and is using its resources and network to get the seafarers their due compensation. The seafarers were left abandoned at Puget Sound in Washington last week and were due to be deported back to their country before the ITF intervened. Cyrus Donato, Inspector for the ITF, condemned the actions of the shipowner, stating that the re-flagging of the vessel was a strategic move. Donato described the action as both cynical and unscrupulous, performed to increase profits and evade regulations by sacrificing seafarers. Donato explained that currently the crew is in a vulnerable position, not being under the protection of US laws; he further stated that the ITF is working to get the seafarers their complete compensation. The [WYCLIFFE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:452269/mmsi:577540000/imo:6605254/vessel:WYCLIFFE) is 40m long and 9m wide. It was built in 1965 and has had a checkered past. Previous crewmembers have been reported to have abandoned the vessel due to the safety concerns both in October 2023 and in May 2024. The vessel also lost its contract with the Washington State Ferries after a failed towing operation involving two retired ferries.

headline: Update: Red Sea incident: MV BLUE LAGOON I Targeted by Missiles; Saudi Tanker AMJAD Denies Damage
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Blue Lagoon I and another oil tanker were attacked in Red Sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BLUE_LAGOON_I_de7eea71ba.png)*Vessel MV BLUE LAGOON I, image credit: Mats Klevtorp* The United Kingdom Maritime Trade Operations reported a new attack on a merchant vessel on September 02. The crude oil tanker [MV BLUE LAGOON I](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:375114/mmsi:352002351/imo:9248447/vessel:BLUE_LAGOON_I) was struck twice by unknown projectiles while positioned 70 nautical miles northwest of Saleef, Yemen. The crewmembers of the vessel contained the damage caused by the projectiles. Later, the captain of the vessel reported a third missile explosion in proximity to the vessel. Fortunately, all the crewmembers were reported safe, and the vessel continued her voyage for the next port call. The U.S. Central Command also confirmed the attack on oil tanker [MV BLUE LAGOON I](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:375114/mmsi:352002351/imo:9248447/vessel:BLUE_LAGOON_I) in the Red Sea. The U.S. command also informed that another crude oil tanker, [AMJAD](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4829676/mmsi:403529000/imo:9779800/vessel:AMJAD#overview), was targeted by Houthis. The two vessels were hit by missiles and the Unmanned Aerial System (UAS). U.S. Central Command stated that both takers were laden. The Saudi-flagged tanker [AMJAD](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4829676/mmsi:403529000/imo:9779800/vessel:AMJAD#overview) was loaded with two million barrels of crude oil. According to Marine Traffic, the [AMJAD](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4829676/mmsi:403529000/imo:9779800/vessel:AMJAD#overview) is scheduled to arrive at [AIN SUKHNA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/25692?name=AIN-SUKHNA&country=Egypt), Egypt on September 06. Iran-backed Houthis, in their statement, claimed responsibility for targeting [MV BLUE LAGOON I ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:375114/mmsi:352002351/imo:9248447/vessel:BLUE_LAGOON_I)using multiple missiles and drones. However, as of now, the Houthis have not mentioned targeting another tanker, [AMJAD](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4829676/mmsi:403529000/imo:9779800/vessel:AMJAD#overview). In the latest update, Saudi shipping company Bahri stated that its crude oil tanker [AMJAD](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4829676/mmsi:403529000/imo:9779800/vessel:AMJAD) was not targeted and had not sustained any damage in the Red Sea.

headline: Namibian government turns away ship carrying explosives to Israel
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Kathrin not allowed to dock at Walvis Bay Port](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KATHRIN_38556f3c17.png)*Cargo vessel KATHRIN,image credit: Rico Voss* The Namibian government did not allow the ship "[MV KATHRIN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:365286/mmsi:255806285/imo:9570620/vessel:KATHRIN)" to dock at [WALVIS BAY Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1178?name=WALVIS-BAY&country=Namibia), the country's largest commercial port. The vessel was traveling from [HAIPHONG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1725?name=HAI-PHONG&country=Vietnam) in Vietnam, made a transit stop in Singapore and stopped in Namibia. The [MV KATHRIN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:365286/mmsi:255806285/imo:9570620/vessel:KATHRIN) is an 8000 DWT vessel that has a German owner. Officials from the Namibian Port Authority stated that a vessel is mandated to declare its contents if it is loaded with dangerous cargo. Upon receiving the documents submitted on August 24, authorities acted with haste to prevent the ship's scheduled docking the next day on August 25. The Namibian Justice Minister, Yvonne Dausab, stated that the ship was carrying explosive material destined for Israel and hence was not allowed to dock, as the minister claims that the country will not be complicit in what they deem as war crimes. The Namibian Police Force reported that an earlier order granting permission to the vessel to dock at the port was revoked. The police also made reports that the vessel was carrying 60 containers of TNT and six containers of hexogen explosives. A local human rights organization, the Economic and Social Justice Trust, lauded the government's efforts and stated that they were pleased that their government decided in favor of respecting international law and not being involved in genocide.

headline: MV DEBI Sale Ordered Amidst Berthing Fee Dispute
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Orissa High Court order the sale of DEBI.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/DEBI_8af2643c7a.png)*Bulk carrier DEBI, image credit: Dierk Bauer* The Orissa High Court ordered the sale of bulk carrier [DEBI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:464399/mmsi:352002464/imo:9616735/vessel:DEBI#overview), which was involved in a drug bust case last year. On November 29, 2023, [DEBI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:464399/mmsi:352002464/imo:9616735/vessel:DEBI#overview) arrived at [PARADIP Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17379?name=PARADIP&country=India) and was destined for Denmark. On December 01, 2023, the bulk carrier was seized by the customs officials of the Paradip Port after discovering 22.2 kilograms of cocaine aboard. The Orissa High Court ordered the sale of the bulk carrier not for its involvement in a drug bust case. The order came after the ship owner, Asia Pacific Shipping Company, Vietnam, failed to clear the due related to berthing charges and penalties to the Paradip International Container Terminal (PITC). In February 2024, the Orissa High Court allowed the ship to return to its owner only if the company provided a bank guarantee and an indemnity bond. Following this, the PITC charged the shipping company nearly $947,000 for overstay docking, which is around INR 79 million. The shipping company argued in court, stating that the vessel was subject to pay docking fees only upto the time before it was seized by customs officials in a drug case investigation. The company also claimed the bulk carrier had overstayed because of the authorities' investigation, which was not under their control. However, the PITC claim was found valid, and the court ordered the arrest of [DEBI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:464399/mmsi:352002464/imo:9616735/vessel:DEBI#overview) on February 23, 2024. Around five months later, on August 20, 2024, PITC came back seeking permission from the court to sell the bulk carrier [DEBI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:464399/mmsi:352002464/imo:9616735/vessel:DEBI#overview), stating the shipping company had failed to pay the bills or provide any security. PITC further noted that with time, docking fees are piling up for the vessel. Moreover, the vessel is deteriorating, and the value is decreasing day by day. The court ordered the vessel to be sold after the survey reports determined its value. The details of the [DEBI ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:464399/mmsi:352002464/imo:9616735/vessel:DEBI#overview)sale will be provided after the survey report, which is expected to be available to the court in September.

headline: Mpox case on the grain ship turns out to be a false alarm
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Mpox suspected aboard a vessel crewmember.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Mpox_ff925de051.png)*Mpox, image credit: WHO* A suspected Mpox outbreak on a grain ship has turned out to be a false alarm. Subsequent tests revealed it to be a case of chicken pox. The ship was placed in quarantine after the crew reported cyst-like lesions resembling those of Mpox on a crewmember of Indian origin. However, the results from subsequent tests run by Argentine authorities came back negative. The infection turned out to be a case of chicken pox. The ship was placed in quarantine near the port of [ROSARIO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17373?name=ROSARIO&country=Argentina), and the crewmember in particular had been isolated from the rest of the crew. The ship was arriving from Santos, Brazil, and was supposed to pick up a shipment of soy at its next stop. Argentine authorities have not disclosed the name of the ship, only revealing that the ship is flagged in Liberia. The event comes in the wake of the WHO declaring Mpox a global health emergency as a more contagious variant, the "clade 1b" strain, spread rapidly through Africa.

headline: Panama-Flagged Bulk Carrier Targeted by Explosions in Red Sea, No Damage Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![SW NORTH WIND I attacked in Red Sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SW_NORTH_WIND_I_21b061fb07.png)*Bulk carrier SW NORTH WIND I, image credit: Volker Steinbarth* The British maritime security agency, United Kingdom Maritime Trade Operations (UKMTO), reported another vessel attack in the Red Sea on August 21. The bulk carrier [SW NORTH WIND I ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:712788/mmsi:352003813/imo:9514004/vessel:SW_NORTH_WIND_I#overview)positioned 57 nautical miles south of Aden, reported five explosions close to the vessel. The bulk carrier remained undamaged and continued proceeding towards its next port call. No casualties were reported. [SW NORTH WIND I ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:712788/mmsi:352003813/imo:9514004/vessel:SW_NORTH_WIND_I#overview)is a 2009-built bulk carrier sailing under the flag of Panama. According to Marine Traffic, the partially laden vessel departed from[ SINGAPORE Anchorage ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/18812?name=SINGAPORE-ANCH&country=Singapore )on August 07 en route for [SUEZ CANAL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17181?name=SUEZ-CANAL&country=Egypt), Egypt. Currently, the vessel is out of range.

headline: Update: Red Sea Tensions Escalate:  Delta tankers Vessel Attacked Near Hodeidah, Yemen
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![SOUNION crewmember rescued.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SOUNION_5c2b9432dd.png)*Vessel SOUNION crewmemeber rescued, image credit: EUNAVFOR ASPIDES* A ship owned by the Greek Delta tankers has been attacked and disabled in a region 77 nautical miles off of Hodeidah, Yemen. This has been the third attack on a Delta Tankers vessel in the Red Sea within the span of a month. According to the security firm Vanguard, the Greek Delta tanker named [SOUNION ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:213122/mmsi:240542000/imo:9312145/vessel:SOUNION)was approached by two small vessels carrying a total of around 15 people. The two vessels exchanged small arms fire with the [SOUNION](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:213122/mmsi:240542000/imo:9312145/vessel:SOUNION) before retreating to a distance of around two miles. The [SOUNION](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:213122/mmsi:240542000/imo:9312145/vessel:SOUNION) was then hit by two unidentified projectiles, closely followed by a third, at around 5:00 AM local time, according to the master of the vessel. The crew reported smoke in the engine room following the attacks. As of now, the ship is disabled and adrift at sea. However, the operator of the vessel, Delta Tankers, has stated that the crew of 25, consisting of 2 Russians and 23 Filipinos, is unharmed and safe. They have further stated that the crew will assess the damage and resume their journey. In the latest update, the EUNAVFOR ASPIDES ship rescued the crew members aboard [SOUNION](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:213122/mmsi:240542000/imo:9312145/vessel:SOUNION#overview) and were taken to Djibouti. Currently, the vessel is at anchor and is not drifting. Although the Houthis have not officially claimed responsibility for the attack, the pattern of targeting vessels in the Red Sea aligns with that of the Houthis. The United Kingdom Maritime Trade Operations (UKMTO) and the Greek Shipping Ministry have indicated that the attack occurred in an area well known for Houthi activity, further reinforcing the possibility of Houthi involvement.

headline: Port of Rotterdam Witnesses Major Drug Busts: Over 700 kg of Cocaine Discovered in One Week
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Drug seized at Port of Rotterdam.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Drug_seizure_bd3ca9fc89.png)*Drug seizure, image credit: Openbaar Ministerie* The Netherlands officials made consecutive drug seizures in the last one week from the Port of [ROTTERDAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2036?name=ROTTERDAM&country=Netherlands). More than 700 kg of cocaine was discovered from different containers at the port and has been seized by the officials. On August 14, the Public Prosecution Service, Netherlands reported that during a routine inspection by customs officers, 514 kilograms of cocaine was found concealed in one of the containers of avocados, which arrived from Peru passing through Panama to Rotterdam. The container was heading to a company in De Lier.The police believe that the company was not involved in the drug smuggling. Another 100 kilograms of cocaine was found in a different container of avocado, which arrived at Rotterdam Port through the same route. The container was destined for a company in Ridderkerk. The company is also believed to be not connected to drug smuggling. Subsequently, on August 15, the Public Prosecution Service, Netherlands stated that the customs, during a check-in at the Port of Rotterdam, uncovered 39 kilograms of cocaine in a refrigerated container. Following this, on August 16, again, 60 kilograms of cocaine was seized from the container carrying bananas following a regular inspection conducted by customs at the Port of Rotterdam. The container carrying the fruit came from Costa Rica and was heading for a company in Zeeland, which is again presumed to be a proxy and not involved in the smuggling. 714 kilograms of cocaine had been discovered worth around $59 million. The authorities have destroyed the drugs and are investigating the drug cases.

headline: Capesize bulker retrofitted with rotor sails makes first port call in Brazil
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Camellia Dream retrofitted with Rotor sails.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CAMELLIA_DREAM_69d3b53c61.png)*CAMELLIA DREAM,image credit: MOL* A capesize bulker, the [CAMELLIA DREAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:665697/mmsi:432992000/imo:9568017/vessel:CAMELLIA_DREAM), has been retrofitted with rotor sails for improved fuel efficiency and reduced emissions. The ship’s owner, Japan-based Mitsui O.S.K. Lines (MOL), and the charterer of the ship, Brazilian mining giant Vale International, released a statement celebrating the achievement of being the first in the industry to fit a rotor sail on a capesize bulker. The vessel [CAMELLIA DREAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:665697/mmsi:432992000/imo:9568017/vessel:CAMELLIA_DREAM) is currently under a mid-term contract for Vale to transport iron ore on the Brazil-Far East trade route. MOL stated that the ship has been fitted with two Norsepower rotor sails, each having a height of 35 m and a radius of 5 m. These rotor sails, along with voyage optimization, are expected to reduce fuel consumption and subsequent emissions by 6–10%. The 207,468 DWT [CAMELLIA DREAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:665697/mmsi:432992000/imo:9568017/vessel:CAMELLIA_DREAM) is around 300 m long and has a beam of 50 m. The vessel was originally delivered 10 years ago. Following the retrofit, the vessel made its first call on its maiden voyage at the Brazilian port of [PONTA DA MADEIRA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/18858?name=PONTA-DA-MADEIRA&country=Brazil), Brazil, on August 15. Both MOL and Vale International are committed to sustainable shipping and have announced sustainability goals of their own in line with the Paris Agreement. Vale has set a goal of reducing 15% of their Scope 3 emissions by 2035, which includes their shipping arrangements. MOL has set its own goal of achieving net zero emissions by 2050 and is investing in clean energy and energy-saving technologies.

headline: Landlocked African nation of Malawi leases port in Mozambique to boost trade
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![NACALA Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NACALA_Port_abcffaf277.png)*NACALA Port,image credit: Boston Samalia* The landlocked nation of Malawi has secured leased space in a port in Mozambique for the construction and operation of a terminal. The terminal will allow Malawi to have more competitive prices on their exports and imports and improve their economy by having access to a deepwater port. The deal signed by the Presidents of both countries will see the construction and operation of the terminal in the northern port of[ NALACA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1231?name=NACALA&country=Mozambique) in Mozambique. The new terminal will bolster relations between the two countries and will synergize with many other projects that are already underway, such as the Mozambique-Malawi Regional Interconnection Project (MOMA) and the Nacala Development Corridor. The current situation, where Malawi has to turn to the access ports of [DURBAN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/452?name=DURBAN&country=South-Africa), [DAR ES SALAAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2730?name=DAR-ES-SALAAM&country=Tanzania), and [BEIRA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1228?name=BEIRA&country=Mozambique) for its imports and exports, incurs greater costs as the route to these ports is long and in poor condition. The port [NACALA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1231?name=NACALA&country=Mozambique) has seen infusions of capital not only from neighboring countries but also from the Japan International Cooperation Agency, which invested around $300 million in the port back in 2018. Due to these investments, the port has expanded rapidly to become a regional hub of maritime traffic. The new terminal will create a more cost-effective logistics framework for Malawi, improving its trade capabilities and ultimately benefiting its economy.

headline: Fire Aboard Panama-Flagged EFES Near Chennai
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Fire broke out aboard EFES.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/EFES_9ad6f32fa6.png)*Cargo vessel EFES, image credit: Arno Bruegmann* A leading marine and transmit claim company reported a fire aboard the general cargo vessel [EFES](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:204867/mmsi:370417000/imo:9197686/vessel:EFES#overview). On August 19, at around 540 nautical miles east of Chennai, in the Bay of Bengal, India, a fire broke out aboard the vessel. The Maritime Rescue Coordination Center, Chennai, had called on the vessels in the area to assist the distressed cargo vessel. Currently, the cause and nature of the fire are not known. [EFES](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:204867/mmsi:370417000/imo:9197686/vessel:EFES#overview), is a general cargo vessel sailing under the flag of Panama. The vessel's overall length is 100.55 meters, and its width is 16.6 meters. The Marine Traffic data show the vessel is partially laden and departed from[ VISAKHAPATNAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/3048?name=VISAKHAPATNAM&country=India), India, on August 17 en route to [Port KLANG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/483?name=PORT-KLANG&country=Malaysia), Malaysia. The 1999-built vessel is now out of range.

headline: Extinction Rebellion Intensifies Climate Protests Disrupting Cruise Ship and Tanker
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![ A group from Extinction Rebellion protesting against the cruise industry](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Extinction_Rebellion_1d3d88a6e6.png)*Protesters at lock gates of Amsterdam, image credit: Extinction Rebellion* Once again, a group from Extinction Rebellion appeared blocking the entrance to the Port of [AMSTERDAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1766?name=AMSTERDAM&country=Netherlands), Netherlands, protesting and preventing the cruise ship [SERENADE OF THE SEAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:374965/mmsi:311492000/imo:9228344/vessel:SERENADE_OF_THE_SEAS), and oil tanker [STEN NEPTUN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:159381/mmsi:255946000/imo:9322712/vessel:STEN_NEPTUN) from docking at the port. This incident delayed the ships entry at the port. On August 18, [SERENADE OF THE SEAS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:374965/mmsi:311492000/imo:9228344/vessel:SERENADE_OF_THE_SEAS) was prevented from entering the IJmuiden lock, near Amsterdam. The small group of protestors chained themselves to Noordersluis and Zeeslius locks, in IJmuiden. The protest is the latest in an ongoing demonstration against the cruise industry in the region, where the activists are challenging the cruise industry’s role in climate change. The protesting group claims that the cruise industry is causing a climatic crisis and should end. The police were called by afternoon to clear the protestors from the port. The activists were released without being arrested. The Extinction Rebellion group is also planning to conduct a mass protest on August 31. Earlier on August 16, the cruise ship[ AMBITION](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3380256/mmsi:311001141/imo:9172777/vessel:AMBITION) had redirected its course to IJmuiden after being informed about the protest at Amsterdam Port.

headline: Superyacht Bayesian sinks in tornado off the Italian coast
author: Stephanie Duscha
content: ![Bayesian.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Bayesian_8df352c2b7.png) The superyacht [BAYESIAN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:255403/mmsi:235108471/imo:9503392/vessel:BAYESIAN) was caught in a tornado off the coast of Palermo in the early morning hours and, according to eyewitnesses, sank within minutes. According to reports, one person has died, and six others are still missing. A total of 22 people were on board - one of them is the British technology tycoon Mike Lynch. MarineTraffic data shows the 56-meter yacht was last anchored off Panarea, leaving the area on 15 August at 15:05 UTC. It then passed through the Aeolian Islands, and on 18 August, it reportedly underwent turbulence near Cefalù. The tragedy occurred this morning, according to MarineTraffic data, while on its way to Palermo. The BAYESIAN sent its last signal via AIS at 2:06 UTC before sinking. ![Bayesian Sinking 19 August](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Screenshot_2024_08_19_at_17_30_19_1_7a6ad1399a.png) Rescue operations are still ongoing. So far, 15 people have been rescued, including a mother and her one-year-old daughter. Mike Lynch has not yet been found. His wife, Angela Bacares, is among the survivors. The majority of the 22 people on board were from the United Kingdom.

headline: Pacific International Line to introduce new service from China to Bangladesh
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![PIL launch a new service called the China-Chittagong Express.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PIL_58132712fb.png)*PIL new service, image credit: PIL* The Pacific International Lines (PIL) is set to launch a new service called the China-Chittagong Express (CCE), which, as the name implies, connects vital ports in China to those in Bangladesh. This new service will begin operations on August 31. This new service will facilitate direct shipping from the Chinese ports of [NINGBO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1250?name=NINGBO&country=China), [SHANGHAI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1253?name=SHANGHAI&country=China), and [SHEKOU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2710?name=SHEKOU&country=China) to [CHITTAGONG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2743?name=CHITTAGONG&country=Bangladesh) in Bangladesh, with the route being NINGBO- [SHANGHAI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1253?name=SHANGHAI&country=China)- [SHEKOU](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2710?name=SHEKOU&country=China)- [CHITTAGONG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2743?name=CHITTAGONG&country=Bangladesh)- [NINGBO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1250?name=NINGBO&country=China). Ships on the route will offer weekly sailings with transit times between 9 and 14 days from China to Bangladesh. The new service will nearly halve the transit times from China to Bangladesh compared to other routes as they tranship through Singapore. The older services that transport goods from China to [CHITTAGONG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2743?name=CHITTAGONG&country=Bangladesh) in Bangladesh take around 20 to 22 days. Around 70% of raw materials for the ready-made garments industry in Bangladesh are imported from China, and currently, these are transported via transshipment ports. The new shipping service is expected to expedite the process and reduce costs.

headline: CMA CGM BELEM Experiences Significant Cargo Loss Amidst Rough Seas Off South Africa’s East Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![CMA CGM BELEM lost containers near South African coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CMA_CGM_BELEM_a3bc2485ef.png)*Vessel CMA CGM BELEM, iamge credit: SAMSA* The South African Maritime Safety Authority (SAMSA) reported that another CMA CGM vessel had lost containers overboard while sailing off the east coast of South Africa. On August 16, [CMA CGM BELEM ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8829585/mmsi:256909000/imo:9938286/vessel:CMA_CGM_BELEM)encountered adverse weather off the coast of Richard Bay that caused a stow collapse and resulted in the loss of 99 containers in the sea. Initially, in the severe weather, the containership took shelter at Maputo Bay, located southwest of Mozambique. Later, after assessing the situation, the authorities redirected the Malta-flagged containership towards the Qheberha, formerly known as Elizabeth Port. Meanwhile, SAMSA requested the vessels passing through the area to report any sighting of lost containers from [CMA CGM BELEM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8829585/mmsi:256909000/imo:9938286/vessel:CMA_CGM_BELEM) to the appropriate authorities by contacting the Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre. Earlier, on July 09, [CMA CGM BENJAMIN FRANKLIN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3664517/mmsi:215195000/imo:9706891/vessel:CMA_CGM_BENJAMIN_FRANKLIN#overview) lost 40 containers in the same region of the South African and Indian Ocean. The search for the lost containers of the CMA CGM BENJAMIN FRANKLIN is still ongoing.

headline: WADI ALBOSTAN Arrested at Paradip Port Following Orissa High Court Ruling
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Wadi Albostan detained at Paradip port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/WADI_ALBOSTAN_d4eba0a6c6.png)*Bulk carrier WADI ALBOSTAN, image credit: Kenro Oshita* An Egyptian-flagged bulk carrier, [WADI ALBOSTAN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:748386/mmsi:622121410/imo:9460722/vessel:WADI_ALBOSTAN), has been detained at the [PARADIP PORT](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17379?name=PARADIP&country=India), India, over the Orissa High Court orders. The bulk carrier has been detained because of a financial dispute between Elboil GmbH and the vessel owner regarding the delivery of low-sulfur marine gas oil. Elboil GmbH, a German marine gas oil supplier, claimed approximately $4,77,320 from the vessel owner for supplying around 98 metric tonnes of very low-sulfur marine gas oil. A case was filed under the section 4 of Admiralty Act 2017 (jurisdiction and settlement of maritime claims) in the Orissa High Court by the German supplier. Following this, the Admiralty judge of Orissa High Court ordered the arrest of [WADI ALBOSTAN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:748386/mmsi:622121410/imo:9460722/vessel:WADI_ALBOSTAN) on August 14. The civil judge was appointed to execute the High Court order of vessel detention. The order was also conveyed to Paradip Port Authority, its secretary, and the Traffic manager to assist in the vessel's detention. The bulk carrier would remain under detention until further notice from the authorities. The 57,320 dwt vessel departed from [CHITTAGONG Anchorage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/20589?name=CHITTAGONG-ANCH&country=Bangladesh) on August 03. The 2011 built vessel was scheduled for China, carrying 55,000 metric tons of iron ore from Paradip Port.

headline: Adora Cruise Ship Fire at Jeju Port Leaves Three Crew Members Injured
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Fire aboard ADORA MEDITERRANEA.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ADORA_MEDITERRANEA_d1655aadc5.png)*Cruise Ship ADORA MEDITERRANEA, image credit: Hiroshi Miyaji* The South Korean news media reported a machine room fire aboard the Adora Cruise Line ship [ADORA MEDITERRANEA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:275345/mmsi:311001086/imo:9237345/vessel:MEDITERRANEA) docked at the [JEJU Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17611?name=JEJU&country=Korea). On August 14, at around 8:35 AM local time, the Jeju Coast Guard received a report of a smoke rising from the starboard side of the ship. The fire was quickly extinguished by the automatic water spray. The incident caused three crew members breathing problem. The affected crew members were later treated for smoke inhalation. No severe casualties were reported aboard the cruise ship. The fire affected approximately 50 square metres of the machine room area of [ADORA MEDITERRANEA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:275345/mmsi:311001086/imo:9237345/vessel:MEDITERRANEA). The Adora Cruise media issued a letter stating that the fire ignited due to the failure of the air conditioning system. After a thorough safety inspection, [ADORA MEDITERRANEA ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:275345/mmsi:311001086/imo:9237345/vessel:MEDITERRANEA)received clearance for departure and proceeded towards its next port call at [TIANJIN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/309?name=TIANJIN&country=China), China, missing its scheduled destination at Fukuoka, Japan. [ADORA MEDITERRANEA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:275345/mmsi:311001086/imo:9237345/vessel:MEDITERRANEA) is a 7500-det cruise ship sailing under the flag of the Bahamas. The ship is sailing with 2400 passengers and 736 crewmembers onboard.

headline: Viking Line to demonstrate green shipping corridor in the Baltic
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Viking Line to launch green corridor in the Baltic Sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Viking_ship_580eb50baa.png)*Viking Ship, image credit: Viking Line* Viking Line is set to launch the first green corridor in the Baltic Sea between Turku, Finland, and Stockholm, Sweden. This demonstration will involve two Viking ships, [VIKING GLORY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6637578/mmsi:230041000/imo:9827877/vessel:VIKING_GLORY) and[ VIKING GRACE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5547/mmsi:230629000/imo:9606900/vessel:VIKING_GRACE), operating completely on biogas. The ships,[ VIKING GLORY ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6637578/mmsi:230041000/imo:9827877/vessel:VIKING_GLORY)and [VIKING GRACE ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5547/mmsi:230629000/imo:9606900/vessel:VIKING_GRACE)will travel between Turku in Finland and Stockholm in Sweden for one week, running exclusively on biogas. The demonstration is meant to serve as the first green shipping corridor on the Baltic Sea. The demonstration will start on Baltic Sea Day, which is celebrated every year on the last Thursday of August, which is on August 29, and will last for one week until September 4. The project is being achieved with a partnership between Viking Line and the ports of Stockholm and Turku. The three have signed a Memorandum of Understanding for creating a carbon neutral corridor by 2035. The [VIKING GLORY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6637578/mmsi:230041000/imo:9827877/vessel:VIKING_GLORY) and [VIKING GRACE ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5547/mmsi:230629000/imo:9606900/vessel:VIKING_GRACE)are already climate-smart, and Viking Line has invested around 450 million euros in their construction. However, the choice of running the ships on biogas alone will further reduce the CO2 emissions from these ships by 90%. This week-long demonstration with the two vessels will save 2600 tons of CO2. Viking procures its biogas from Gasum, which in turn derives the biogas from food and agricultural waste. The fuel is European in origin, and each batch of fuel can be traced back to its origin.

headline: Stax Engineering contracted by Shell for a 5-year emission capture deal
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![STARX Engineering.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/STARX_Engineering_e84ad92c9c.png)*STARX barge capturing emissions from berthed vessel, image credit: STARX Engineering* Stax Engineering has entered into a 5-year contract with Shell for capturing emissions from berthed vessels at the Mormon Island Terminal in California. The contract will begin on January 1, 2025. The contract has made Stax Engineering the industry's first to have a five-year deal for emission capture. The technology involves a barge arriving by the side of the berthed vessel and connecting to the vessel’s exhaust stack directly using steel pipes and hoses. The emissions are then pulled into the barge’s filtration systems, and the released gas stream is free of 99% diesel particulate matter and 95% nitrogen oxides (NOx). Connecting to the exhaust stack externally makes the approach versatile and applicable to a variety of vessels, including container ships, auto carriers, and tankers. The California Air Resources Board (CARB) has mandated that vessels berthing at California ports adhere to strict emissions regulation standards. Tankers and ro-ro vessels berthing at the Port of [LOS ANGELES](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/87?name=LOS-ANGELES&country=USA) and [LONG BEACH](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2727?name=LONG-BEACH&country=USA) Port will fall within the purview of these laws as of January 1, 2025. These laws are to be applied to all California terminals by 2027.

headline: Fremantle Port Workers to Strike for 48 Hours, Sparking Delays in Vessel Movements
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![Fremantle Port workers to go on a strike.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FREMANTLE_Port_5e788e5340.png)*Fremantle Port, image credit: Graeme Waller* Port workers in the Port of [FREMANTLE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/768?name=FREMANTLE&country=Australia), Australia, are set to go on strike for 48 hours beginning on the morning of Sunday, August 18. The strike will involve Fremantle pilot boat operators and vessel traffic service officers walking off their jobs for 48 hours. They claim that their pay is lower than that of their counterparts in other ports and are demanding that their pay be raised by 33% over three years. The union has claimed that they are prepared to extend the strike should their demands not be taken seriously. Experts have warned that the repercussions of the strike could be felt for weeks even if the strike is not prolonged. The dock workers in charge of loading and unloading are not involved in the strike. So, vessels that are already at berth in the port will continue their operations as per schedule. However, ships that have to be moved to and from the berths will face difficulties. Around 20 vessels are scheduled to arrive in [FREMANTLE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/768?name=FREMANTLE&country=Australia) in the coming days that would be impacted by this strike. The strike will paralyze the port for the duration of the strike and cause delays of weeks in the delivery of goods, including cars and building materials.

headline: Navigating the Complexities of Maritime Sanctions: A July 2024 Overview
author: Dimitris Ampatzidis
content: **Overview** In July 2024, maritime sanctions evolved with the EU renewing measures against Russia and Iran, while OFAC sanctioned 5 new vessels and 2 companies. This contributed to a year-over-year increase of 128 vessels and 70 companies on the sanctions list, reflecting the broadening scope and complexity of global trade. The largest increases were observed in vessels flagged under Panama, Liberia, Comoros, and Swaziland, highlighting the importance of monitoring high-risk activities like AIS manipulation and STS transfers. **Renewal of Sanctions Against Russia and Iran** On July 22, 2024, the EU renewed its economic sanctions against Russia for another six months, extending them until January 31, 2025. These sanctions, initially imposed in 2014 and significantly expanded since February 2022, include a wide range of measures targeting trade, finance, technology, and more. Specific actions include bans on the import of seaborne crude oil and certain petroleum products, de-SWIFTing Russian banks, and suspending broadcasting licences for Kremlin-backed media outlets. The EU continues to maintain these measures in response to Russia’s ongoing aggression against Ukraine ([Lenzu, 2024b](https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2024/07/22/russia-s-war-of-aggression-against-ukraine-council-renews-economic-sanctions-for-a-further-6-months/)). On July 15, 2024, the EU extended sanctions against Iran until July 27, 2025, due to Iran's military support for Russia’s aggression against Ukraine and various armed groups in the Middle East and the Red Sea region. The Council prohibited the export of components used in the development and production of UAVs from the EU to Iran. These measures, reviewed annually, include restrictions on exporting equipment and technology that could bolster Iran's military capabilities, specifically impacting maritime transport and the provision of UAV and missile components ([Lenzu, 2024a](https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2024/07/15/iran-council-prolongs-eu-restrictive-measures-in-view-of-iran-s-military-support-for-russia-s-war-of-aggression-against-ukraine-and-for-armed-groups-and-entities-in-the-middle-east-and-the-red-sea-region/)). **Analysis of Sanctioned Vessels and Companies** ![image6.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image6_5ad1a35de5.png) **Image 1.** _Sanctioned vessels and companies through the years - Kpler._ ![image2.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image2_bc03b6a9c7.png) **Image 2.** _Sanctioned vessels per top 10 flag registry through the years - Kpler._ A year-on-year comparison reveals a substantial rise in sanctioned entities, with 128 new vessels and 70 new companies, reflecting the ongoing enforcement measures and the broader scope of sanctions implemented over the past year. The increase in the diversity of sanctioned entities by country, as illustrated in the second graph, highlights the expanding geographical focus of these sanctions risks - with the biggest increase in vessels flagged under Panama (11), Liberia (12), Comoros (11), and Swaziland (6). The maritime industry continues to navigate a complex web of sanctions and export controls, with July 2024 witnessing developments in enforcement actions by the Office of Foreign Assets Control, while observing a quieter month from OFSI and EU without new sanctions on vessels and shipping companies. The recent updates include notable additions to the list of sanctioned vessels and companies: Sanctioned Vessels - TIREX (9203772): Crude Oil Tanker, Panama-flagged, 25 years old ([OFAC](https://sanctionssearch.ofac.treas.gov/Details.aspx?id=49842)) - WANJI (9215103): Chemical/Oil Products Tanker, Panama-flagged, 25 years old ([OFAC](https://sanctionssearch.ofac.treas.gov/Details.aspx?id=49840)) - MIROVA DYNAMIC (9237618): Crude Oil Tanker, unknown flag, 23 years old ([OFAC](https://sanctionssearch.ofac.treas.gov/Details.aspx?id=49845)) - OCEANIC II (9275995): Oil products Tanker, Hong Kong-flagged, 23 years old ([OFAC](https://sanctionssearch.ofac.treas.gov/Details.aspx?id=49841)) - KASPER (9293143): Crude Oil Tanker, Panama-flagged, 21 years old ([OFAC](https://sanctionssearch.ofac.treas.gov/Details.aspx?id=49850)) Sanctioned Companies - BARCO SHIP MANAGEMENT INC (6389977): UAE-based company, commercial manager for TIREX, WANJI, and OCEANIC II ([OFAC](https://sanctionssearch.ofac.treas.gov/Details.aspx?id=49839)) - SEA KNOT SHIPPING INC (6253546): Registered owner for MIROVA DYNAMIC ([OFAC](https://sanctionssearch.ofac.treas.gov/Details.aspx?id=49844)) Understanding the pre-sanction behaviours of vessels such as WANJI, MIROVA DYNAMIC, and OCEANIC II provides critical insights into the complexities of maritime risk management and due diligence. **Risk & Compliance findings before the applied sanctions** The vessels WANJI, MIROVA DYNAMIC, and OCEANIC II had shown activities that raised compliance concerns before the sanctions were applied. These cases highlight the complexities in assessing risks in maritime operations, particularly with connections to sanctioned cargo, possible manipulation of the Automatic Identification System (AIS), and high-risk ship-to-ship (STS) transfers. WANJI was linked to Iranian cargo (HSFO) as far back as 2023, with suspicions that it manipulated its AIS during a journey between Iran and the UAE during June 2023. This suggests that the vessel might have been trying to hide its true location, a common tactic used to avoid detection and evade sanctions. ![image5.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image5_da45da1937.jpg) **Image 3.** _Cargo with risks for WANJI - Kpler._ ![image8.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image8_911df005c2.jpg) **Image 4.** _AIS spoofing event for WANJI - Kpler._ ![image1.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image1_0a8118b6d5.jpg) **Image 5.** _Start of the spoofing event for WANJI - Kpler._ ![image3.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image3_1736913acb.jpg) **Image 6.** _End of the spoofing event for WANJI - Kpler._ MIROVA DYNAMIC was similarly involved in risky activities, connected to Iranian cargo (HSFO) in 2022 and participating in several high-risk STS transfers. These transfers, where cargo is moved between ships at sea, are often used to conceal the real origin or destination of the cargo, making it harder for regulators to track. ![image10.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image10_a4d60fcefa.jpg) **Image 7.** _Cargo with risks for MIROVA DYNAMIC - Kpler._ ![image9.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image9_01180bff71.jpg) **Image 8.** _High Risk STS transfers for MIROVA DYNAMIC - Kpler._ OCEANIC II had a more complicated risk profile, linked to Iranian cargo (HSFO) in May 2024 and Russian products (LSSRFO) from 2023. The vessel was also involved in high-risk STS transfers, further indicating its potential role in unlawful maritime operations. ![image7.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image7_7dfa85f2fa.jpg) **Image 9.** _Cargo with risks for OCEANIC II - Kpler._ ![image4.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image4_c3a832d3a4.jpg) **Image 10.** _High Risk STS transfers for OCEANIC II - Kpler._ These findings show that pre-existing patterns of behaviour like AIS manipulation and STS transfers are often early signs of future sanction breaches. Stay tuned for more insights and updates as the year progresses, ensuring that you remain informed and compliant amidst these dynamic regulatory changes. Learn more at: [Kpler Risk & Compliance](https://www.kpler.com/product/commodities/risk-compliance). References Lenzu, M.D. (2024a) Iran: Council prolongs EU restrictive measures in view of Iran’s ..., Council of the EU. Available at: https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2024/07/15/iran-council-prolongs-eu-restrictive-measures-in-view-of-iran-s-military-support-for-russia-s-war-of-aggression-against-ukraine-and-for-armed-groups-and-entities-in-the-middle-east-and-the-red-sea-region (Accessed: 14 August 2024). Lenzu, M.D. (2024) Russia’s war of aggression against Ukraine: Council renews ..., Council of the EU. Available at: https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2024/07/22/russia-s-war-of-aggression-against-ukraine-council-renews-economic-sanctions-for-a-further-6-months (Accessed: 14 August 2024).

headline: Multipurpose Vessel, AAL LIMASSOL successfully completes maiden voyage
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![AAL LIMASSOL complete its maiden voyage.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/AAL_LIMASSOL_b49d0d04dc.png)*Cargo vessel AAL LIMASSOL,image credit: AAL Shipping* The multipurpose vessel [AAL LIMASSOL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8575085/mmsi:210232000/imo:9958755/vessel:AAL_LIMASSOL#overview) recently arrived in [CUXHAVEN,](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/173?name=CUXHAVEN&country=Germany) Germany, completing its maiden voyage that started in China. The vessel delivered 89,000 tons of freight cargo on its first voyage, which is a record amount for the carrier AAL. The ship was built and christened at the CSSC Huangpu Wenchong Shipyard in Guangzhou, China. Shortly after the christening ceremony held on April 26, the ship departed on its maiden voyage from Asia to Europe. Departing from China, the ship visited [TUTICORIN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2986?name=TUTICORIN&country=India) in India, transited around the Cape of Good Hope and the English Channel, and reached [KLAIPEDA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/771?name=KLAIPEDA&country=Lithuania). From there, the ship delivered the remaining cargo to [ROTTERDAM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2036?name=ROTTERDAM&country=Netherlands), [ANTWERP](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/117?name=ANTWERP&country=Belgium), and finally [CUXHAVEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/173?name=CUXHAVEN&country=Germany). The ship picked up a variety of cargo, including a dismantled crane, barges, 15 blades of wind turbines weighing around 30 tons each, and so on. The total cargo ended up weighing 89,000 freight tons. The vessel is equipped with three retractable extensions that are called the AAL ECO Deck. These extensions can increase the deck space to 5,200 square meters when needed. The vessel is equipped with MAN engines, which are dual-fuel and capable of running on methanol. The ship is also NOX Tier III compatible and has many environment-friendly features, such as ballast water treatment systems and a hull coating that increase fuel efficiency. The[ AAL LIMASSOL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8575085/mmsi:210232000/imo:9958755/vessel:AAL_LIMASSOL#overview) is the first in a series of eight “Super B Class Vessels” that are to be delivered to AAL by 2026.

headline: Protestors from Extinction Rebellion Targets Cruise Industry in Series of Port Protests
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![SEVEN SEAS MARINER delayed by protestors to arrive at the port of Netherlands. at ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SEVEN_SEAS_MARINER_09278c229d.png)*Cruise Ship SEVEN SEAS MARINER, image credit: Extinction Rebellion* Recently, the group Extinction Rebellion (XR) has resurfaced and begun blocking cruise ships from docking at ports. The group claims that cruising is too taxing an activity on the environment for something that is recreational in nature and, hence, should be ceased. In recent news, XR managed to prevent a cruise ship, the "Jewel of the Seas," from docking in Amsterdam. A small group of protestors chained and glued themselves to the lock gates, obstructing the passage of the ship. The cruise ship had to reroute and head to the nearby IJmuiden on August 10. XR employed the same tactic a day later, on August 11, this time targeting the cruise ship [SEVEN SEAS MARINER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:375209/mmsi:311622000/imo:9210139/vessel:SEVEN_SEAS_MARINER#overview). As negotiations bore no fruit, the Mobile Eenheid (ME), a specialized police unit trained to manage physically restrained protesters, put an end to the protest. This caused the ship to be delayed for around 3 hours entering IJmuiden. The local authorities decided not to arrest anyone to honor the right to protest, as the protestors did not pose a grave threat to anyone but later intervened to restore shipping traffic. Extinction Rebellion claims that presently, there is no emission-free fuel available at scale to sustain shipping. And while they consider logistics to be a necessary evil, they have condemned cruising primarily due to it being recreational in nature.

headline: Plaquemines LNG export plant in Louisiana receives its first LNG vessel
author: Raghib Raza
content: ![QOGIR](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/QOGIR_c3cf81c43d.png)*Vessel QOGIR, image credit: Hannes Van Rijin* The Plaquemines LNG export plant, which is being developed by Venture Global LNG, received its first LNG shipment on the vessel[ QOGIR](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6182784/mmsi:215524000/imo:9851787/vessel:QOGIR#overview). The shipments are imported for the cooldown phase of the plant before it begins operation. The Malta-registered [QOGIR](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6182784/mmsi:215524000/imo:9851787/vessel:QOGIR#overview) arrived at the facility and has been awaiting offloading since August 23. The shipment of LNG was loaded at Equinor’s Hammerfest LNG terminal and departed Norway on August 6, 2024. The shipment of LNG is to be used in the cooldown phase of the LNG plant, which involves reducing the temperature of liquefaction components in the plant shortly before beginning normal operations. LNG marked for use in the cooldown phase may also be used in the testing and purging of the plant, in which any impurities from the components are removed, and the systems are finally tested before starting regular operations. LNG earmarked for such use is usually exported under a special license; in this case, Qogir delivered the cargo under the license issued by the US Department of Energy (DOE). The new Plaquemines facility, once operational, will produce twenty million metric tons of LNG per year, making it the second-largest LNG production facility in the US. The plant is located at a 632-acre site along the Mississippi River, which already has a deep riverbed, not requiring dredging to accommodate larger vessels, which will no doubt be required as the LNG plant begins operation. The new plant will capture a significant share of the LNG supply market, poised to supply Europe, Asia, and South America. The US is currently the largest supplier of LNG in the world, having surpassed Qatar. This is part of a broader strategy of ramping up energy production in response to recent geopolitical events, such as sanctions on Russia.

headline: Bosporus Strait blocked by oil tanker, disrupting Libya’s fuel supply
author: Stephanie Duscha
content: ![Bosporus Strait Sredina.jpeg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Bosporus_Strait_Sredina_7753022cbf.jpeg) Shipping traffic through the Bosporus Strait was temporarily completely blocked in both directions this morning due to an engine malfunction on the 171-meter-long oil tanker [Sredina](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:728411/mmsi:357263000/imo:9236975/vessel:SREDINA). According to MarineTraffic data, the Panama-flagged vessel was en route to Benghazi, Libya, from Novorossiysk, Russia. The incident happened at the northern entrance of the Bosporus Strait, and tugboats were immediately sent to provide assistance. ![Sredina.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Sredina_66a6cbe9cd.png) Viktor Katona, Head of Oil Analysis at Kpler, stated that the Sredina was used as a delivery tanker for Russian gas or naphtha to Libya: "It's a 22-year old vessel, which makes it relatively old by Mediterranean standards, and also explains why the tanker has been used less on other routes as deliveries to Libya usually require less vetting." He also said that the vessel's engine malfunction this morning could have an impact on Libya's fuel supply: "In addition to clogging a crucial waterway, the immediate impact will likely be on Libya's fuel consumption." The Sredina is owned by Srediste Shipping LLC, a shipping company based in the United Arab Emirates, which also owns the product tanker Magni Alexa. So far, in 2024, both ships have exclusively transported goods of Russian origin.

headline: Update: Second Fire Breaks Out on Grimaldi vessel, Crew Safely Evacuated
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire broke out aboard the Grimaldi vessel [GRANDE BRASILE ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:206251/mmsi:215664000/imo:9198123/vessel:GRANDE_BRASILE)on 18th February as it was transiting the English Channel. ![Fire broke aboard vessel GRANDE BRASILE](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GRNADE_BRASILE_c773d147fc.png)*Vessel GRANDE BRASILE, image credit: Manuel Hernández* The vessel issued a distress call around 9:35 AM, which reported the first fire aboard the vessel and the vessel losing steering capabilities and propulsion. The vessel was around 15 nautical miles off of Ramsgate, England, and was traveling from Antwerp, Belgium, to Le Havre, France, at the time of the incident. The UK Maritime and Coastguard Agency (UK MCA) instructed the Royal National Lifeboat Institution (RNLI), and lifeboats were promptly dispatched to the scene. As the lifeboats arrived on site, they discovered that the 28 crew members on board were uninjured and that the fire had already been contained to one deck aboard the vessel. The crew members had also deployed the onboard fire suppression system to combat the fire. In the recent update, a second fire broke out aboard [GRANDE BRASILE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:206251/mmsi:215664000/imo:9198123/vessel:GRANDE_BRASILE) at around 4:25 PM local time affecting another deck of the vessel prompting the evacuation of the crew. The crew abandoned the ship and were transferred to an assisting tug before being taken ashore by the Ramsgate lifeboat, as confirmed by HM Coast Guard. No injuries were reported. The situation remains ongoing, with tugs providing boundary cooling to contain the fire. The Dutch and Belgium Coast Guards are monitoring the incident. Grimaldi’s salvage team Smit Salvage, which was expected to reach the vessel by midday Wednesday to assist in the response.

headline: PIL Welcome KOTA EBONY, its Third LNG Powered Containership
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 20th February, Pacific International Line (PIL) officially took delivery of a 14,000 TEU LNG dual-fuel container vessel named [KOTA EBONY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9282749/mmsi:563248600/imo:9968853/vessel:KOTA_EBONY). The naming ceremony of [KOTA EBONY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9282749/mmsi:563248600/imo:9968853/vessel:KOTA_EBONY) was celebrated in Jiangnan Shipyard, Shanghai. ![KOTA EBONY delivered to PIL](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KOTA_EBONY_ea4d564a9a.png)*Vessel KOTA EBONY, image credit: PIL* The containership is the third in the series of four 14,000 TEUs designed and constructed by Jiangnan Shipyard, China. These series are the largest in the PIL’s fleet and also the first to operate on LNG. The first two vessels, [KOTA EAGLE ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8919841/mmsi:563235800/imo:9963700/vessel:KOTA_EAGLE)and [KOTA EMERALD](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9177674/mmsi:563242600/imo:9963712/vessel:KOTA_EMERALD) were delivered last year and are now operational on PIL’s Latin America Service Network. The fourth vessel is expected to be delivered in the coming months of this year. The 14,000 TEU series vessels are designed with a high reefer capacity, particularly suited for trade routes between China and Latin America. The vessels incorporate several environmentally efficient features, including an optimized hull form to enhance fuel efficiency. These vessels are also equipped with an anti-fouling coating to reduce consumption and an exhaust gas recirculation system to lower main engine methane emissions. Additionally, enhanced data connectivity has been integrated to improve safety and operational efficiency.

headline: Navigator Gas Announces the Acquisition of New Handysize Ethylene Carrier
author: Raghib Raza
content: Marshall Islands-based gas carrier Navigator Gas announced its acquisition of a liquefied ethylene carrier. This is the first of three acquisitions that Navigator Gas announced in January this year to bolster its exports from its Morgan’s Point Ethylene Terminal in the US. ![NAVIGATOR HYPERION](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NAVIGATOR_HYPERION_3507bc1c8a.png)*Vessel NAVIGATOR HYPERION, image credit: Ulf Kornfeld* The new acquisition is a 17,000 cbm German-made vessel, which has been renamed [NAVIGATOR HYPERION](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:758410/mmsi:636091971/imo:9402586/vessel:GASCHEM_ADRIATIC). The vessel is expected to join the spot market shortly. The financing of this acquisition and the other two vessels has been made partly by the company’s own funds and partly by a facility agreement with Nordea Bank Abp. Navigator Gas announced the completion of the terminal expansion plans at Morgan’s Point Ethylene export terminal in the US on 7th January. The company had also announced their commitment to acquire three ethylene gas carriers to be able to carry out the exports from this newly expanded terminal on the same day. The two remaining ethylene carriers are expected to be delivered to Navigator Gas between February and May of this year.

headline: Products Tanker Assists Sail Boat Damaged by Storm Near the Gulf of Antalya
author: Raghib Raza
content: Product tanker [T. CAROLINE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:716166/mmsi:271044409/imo:9418810/vessel:T_CAROLINE) responded to the distress call of a sailboat that had been damaged by a storm at the entrance of the Gulf of Antalya. ![T. CAROLINE rescue crewmembers of the sailboat damaged by a storm.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/T_CAROLINE_306a6c85b7.png)*Vessel T. CAROLINE, image credit:lidergazete.com* The incident occurred on the night of 20th February as the vessel was being transported from Aliağa to Mersin. The distressed sailboat's sail had been torn by the storm, and had also reportedly lost its steering and engine capabilities. The two crewmembers stranded aboard the sailboat were rescued by the tanker [T. CAROLINE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:716166/mmsi:271044409/imo:9418810/vessel:T_CAROLINE) despite challenging weather conditions. By 9:00 AM, the crew members had been rescued as the yacht was left in the inclement weather. The [T. CAROLINE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:716166/mmsi:271044409/imo:9418810/vessel:T_CAROLINE) is a Turkish-flagged products tanker that was built in 2009. It is 131.85 meters long, 18.9 meters wide, and has a gross tonnage of 7,273.

headline: Bulk carrier JIA DE CHANG HE Runs Aground on Embankment of Kiel Canal
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Chinese-flagged Bulk Carrier [JIA DE CHANG HE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:649743/mmsi:414057000/imo:9626546/vessel:JIA_DE_CHANG_HE) ran aground on an embankment of the Kiel Canal on 20th February. ![JIA DE CHNAG HE ran aground in Kiel Canal.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/JIA_DE_CHNAG_HE_49cc5f33ea.png)*Bulk Carrier JIA DE CHANG HE, image credit: Ingo Seidlitz* The incident occurred at 5:30 AM when the vessel was traversing from the Netherlands to Estonia via the Kiel Canal in ballast condition. The vessel ran into the embankment near the switch in Dückerswisch approximately an hour after it had departed from the lock in Brunsbüttel. The pilot of the vessel had reported of rudder problems before the incident. A tugboat was called in for assistance, and at around 8:30 AM, the vessel was pulled out into the fairway. The vessel is currently moored at the Holtenau Anchorage and is awaiting inspections. The JIA DE CHANG HE is a 2011-built bulk carrier that has a length of 189.99 meters, a beam of 32.36 meters, and a gross tonnage of 32,960.

headline: PAVEL GRABOVSKIY Damaged by Ice, Stranded Near Port of Azov
author: Raghib Raza
content: The cargo vessel [PAVEL GRABOVSKIY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:764024/mmsi:372968000/imo:7830911/vessel:PAVEL_GRABOVSKIY) began taking in water as its hull was damaged by ice fragments while traversing the Sea of Azov. ![PAVEL GRABOVSKIY collided with ice and takes in water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PAVEL_GRABOVSKIY_430795f69a.png)*Vessel PAVEL GRABOVSKIY, image credit: S. Melnikov* The incident occurred around the afternoon of 16th February, when the vessel was en route from Rostov-on-Don to Samsun carrying a shipment of 3,000 tons of corn. The collision with ice fragments afloat in the Sea of Azov occurred near the Port of Azov, and the collision ended up punching holes in the hull of the vessel.
