There have been no reports of any injuries among the crew of 11 Azerbaijanis aboard the vessel. Notably, the cargo vessel did not send out an SOS signal following the collision; instead, it merely sought permission to enter the port of [AZON Anchorage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/22877?name=AZOV-ANCH&country=Russia), Russia. Water is being pumped out of the vessel, and two icebreakers, [KAPITAN CHUDINOV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:350956/mmsi:273458320/imo:8027248/vessel:KAPITAN_CHUDINOV) and [KAPITAN DEMIDOV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:347064/mmsi:273332600/imo:8027286/vessel:KAPITAN_DEMIDOV), have arrived on site to assist the distressed vessel. It is reported that due to the low water level, the vessel cannot move forward and has not yet been able to approach the coast

headline: COSCO Shipping Welcomes New Vessel to its Fleet, “GREEN QINGDAO”
author: Raghib Raza
content: COSCO Shipping introduced the newest addition to its fleet, the [GREEN QINGDAO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9349482/mmsi:636023210/imo:9997921/vessel:GREEN_QINGDAO), on 21 February. The vessel, part of the world’s largest professional pulp fleet, aims to enhance sustainable and efficient logistics solutions for global trade. ![GREEN QINGDAO joins the COSCO Fleet.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GREEN_QINGDAO_8d38f5cfa3.png)*Vessel GREEN QINGDAO, image credit: COSCO SHIPPING* The [GREEN QINGDAO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9349482/mmsi:636023210/imo:9997921/vessel:GREEN_QINGDAO) has a length of 225 meters, a width of 32.36 meters, and a deadweight tonnage of 77,000 DWT. Its cargo holds are box-shaped and are equipped with rotary dehumidifiers for efficient storage. The vessel has been designed to haul a diverse variety of cargo including High speed trains, wind power equipment, new energy vehicles, and large machinery and oversized steel structures.

headline: Severe Weather Causes Tanker to Crash into Cargo Vessel in Black Sea
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 21st February, a maritime incident occurred involving a collision between a general cargo vessel, [BEGONIA S](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:702296/mmsi:636022079/imo:9445540/vessel:BEGONIA_S#overview), and an Oil Product Tanker, [NATIG ALIYEV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:997610/mmsi:341453001/imo:9194000/vessel:NATIG_ALIYEV#overview). The accident took place in the Black Sea between the Russian ports of [GELENDZHIK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17916?name=GELENDZHIK&country=Russia) and [NOVOROSSIYSK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/767?name=NOVOROSSIYSK&country=Russia). ![NATIG ALIYEV collided with BEGONIA S in Russian water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NATIG_ALIYEV_f6deca1c1c.png)*Vessel NATIG ALIYEV collided with vessel BEGONIA S, image credit:news.az* The initial report stated that inclement weather conditions and a delay in engine start caused the St. Kitts and Nevis-flagged [NATIG ALIYEV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:997610/mmsi:341453001/imo:9194000/vessel:NATIG_ALIYEV#overview) to drift while at anchor, leading to a collision with the Liberian-flagged [BEGONIA S](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:702296/mmsi:636022079/imo:9445540/vessel:BEGONIA_S#overview). [BEGONIA S](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:702296/mmsi:636022079/imo:9445540/vessel:BEGONIA_S#overview) sustained minor damage to its bow, while [NATIG ALIYEV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:997610/mmsi:341453001/imo:9194000/vessel:NATIG_ALIYEV#overview)’s rudder blade caught in the anchor chain. After the collision, both the vessels remained afloat and eventually navigated away from each other. No injuries or pollution were reported.

headline: Fire Aboard Dutch Inland Freighter; No Casualties Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 24th February, a fire broke out aboard the 80-meter-long inland freighter [KORNELIS JAN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:238202/mmsi:244660942/imo:0/vessel:KORNELIS_JAN#overview). The incident occurred around 6:45 AM local time while the vessel was sailing on New Maas, a river in the Netherlands. ![KORNELIS JAN caught fire in Netherlands river.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KORNELIS_JAN_05b2b198e4.png)*Inland freighter KORNELIS JAN, image credit:pzc.nl* The fire brigade responded swiftly and arrived with multiple units, including four engines and an aerial platform. The firefighter conducted a thorough inspection of the vessel. The initial investigation suggests that a technical malfunction in the electrical system caused a fire aboard the freighter. No injuries were reported in the incident and the fire brigade continued to monitor the situation with a follow-up inspection to ensure freighter's safety.

headline: Bound4Blue Retrofits Rotor Sails on an EPS Tanker During Drydock
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 24th February, Wind propulsion systems provider Bound4Blue announced that it had retrofitted an EPS tanker, the [PACIFIC SENTINEL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5989145/mmsi:636020778/imo:9862932/vessel:PACIFIC_SENTINEL), during a planned drydock at the Besiktas Shipyard in Turkey. The deployment was completed within a single shipyard visit and is expected to reduce fuel consumption by double digits. ![PACIFIC SENTINEL.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PACIFIC_SENTINEL_92b8aa3160.png)*Vessel PACIFIC SENTINEL, image credit: Bound4Blue* The fully autonomous wind propulsion system is estimated to increase energy savings by around 10% on the vessel. The eSails will also reduce emissions, thereby enhancing regulatory compliance. Three eSails, each 22 metres high, were installed aboard the 50,000 dwt tanker. Bound4Blue reported that the installation was carried out in a highly efficient manner, with one rotor sail installation taking only a day. This is the first tanker to be retrofitted by Bound4Blue, and incidentally, it is also the first EPS vessel to be retrofitted with eSail technology. To date, Bound4Blue has completed eSail installations on five vessels, with its order book growing rapidly.

headline: GRANDE CONGO Catches Fire at Sea, Safely Arrives in Newport News
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire broke out aboard the Ro-Ro container carrier [GRANDE CONGO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:281131/mmsi:247302700/imo:9437921/vessel:GRANDE_CONGO#overview), operated by Grimaldi Group. The incident occurred on 21st February while the ship was sailing in the Atlantic Ocean. ![Fire broke aboard GRANDE CONGO.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GRANDE_CONGO_978714831f.png)*Ro-Ro container carrier GRANDE CONGO, image credit: Michael Hatje* The fire was extinguished and safely arrived at Newport News Marine Terminals, USA. This marked the second fire-related accident involving the Grimaldi Ro-Ro vessel in recent days. Earlier, on 18th February, the fire occurred on [GRANDE BRASILE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:206251/mmsi:215664000/imo:9198123/vessel:GRANDE_BRASILE) while it was transiting the English channel. [GRANDE CONGO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:281131/mmsi:247302700/imo:9437921/vessel:GRANDE_CONGO#overview) is an Italian-flagged Ro-Ro container carrier built in 2010. The vessel has a length of 211 meters, width of 32.25 meters, and gross tonnage of 47,658.

headline: Crew of Crude Oil Tanker CAROLINE BEZENGI  Request Inspection After Not Being Paid for Months
author: Raghib Raza
content: The crew of the crude oil tanker [CAROLINE BEZENGI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:753096/mmsi:511101363/imo:9224439/vessel:CAROLINE_BEZENGI) wrote to the port administration of the port of Vostochny, Russia, requesting an investigation to be conducted on their vessel. The sailors have invited the inspection to confirm the violations, such as delayed wages, problems with insurance, and dwindling food supplies. ![Crew of CAROLINE BEZENGI request for vessel inspection.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CAROLINE_BEZENGI_e76efbb60a.png)*Vessel CAROLINE BEZENGI, image credit: GIBFRAN46* The vessel [CAROLINE BEZENGI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:753096/mmsi:511101363/imo:9224439/vessel:CAROLINE_BEZENGI) is owned by Lagosmarine, and the crew aboard is composed of 13 Russian nationals and 12 Indonesians. The Russian Seafarers Union (RSU) has reported that the seafarers aboard the vessel have not been compensated, the Russian sailors for 2.5 months and the Indonesians for 1.5 months, summing up to a total due of 179 thousand euros. The contracts of some of these sailors have already expired, and the contracts for most of the sailors will expire on 28th February. In addition to this, the food supplies on the vessel have been reported to have dwindled to only a couple of days' worth. The owner of the vessel, Lagosmarine, notified the insurance provider of the vessel that the debt had been cleared already. As of now, the vessel is awaiting the requested inspection. If the alleged violations are confirmed in the inspection, the vessel can be detained for the violation of the Maritime Labor Convention.

headline: Russian-flagged Research Vessel Sinks in the Black Sea Near Novorossiysk
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Russian-flagged research vessel [ASHAMBA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4021109/mmsi:273384140/imo:0/vessel:ASHAMBA) sank in the Black Sea near Novorossiysk, Russia, on 22nd February. Initial findings indicate rapidly built icing to be the cause of instability and the subsequent sinking of the vessel. ![ASHAMBA sank in the Black Sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ASHAMBA_c3f89cd9ec.png)*Vessel ASHAMBA, image credit:en.usm.media* The vessel is owned by the Shirshov Institute of Oceanology and was moored near Novorossiysk. The onset of a winter storm caused a rapid buildup of ice that the crew could not keep up with and clear in time. This led to a buildup of ice, leading to the vessel listing and then subsequently capsizing. Reports indicate that the risk of pollution is limited since the vessel was carrying only around 200 liters of diesel. The ship's owner is to deploy booms to contain any oil leak that does happen. The Shirshov Institute has stated that they are drawing out plans to raise the vessel in spring time if the weather is accommodating. Investigations have been opened into the incident by the Transport Prosecutor's Office in Novorossiysk and by the Investigative Committee of Russia's transport division.

headline: Furetank Completes First Bio-LNG Bunkering Operation Off Norway
author: Raghib Raza
content: Swedish Shipping company Furetank has completed its first bunkering of 200 tonnes of ISCC-certified Bio-LNG. ![FURE VIKEN](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FURE_VIKEN_86120df186.png)*Vessel FURE VIKEN, image credit:Furetank* The fueling operation took place off the coast of Mongstad, Norway, where the 17,945 dwt tanker [FURE VIKEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8931239/mmsi:265057000/imo:9980318/vessel:FURE_VIKEN#overview) was supplied with environmentally friendly fuel. This initiative supports compliance with the FuelEU Maritime Regulation compliance, which mandates a 2% reduction in the greenhouse gas intensity of vessel fuel by 2025. Furetank, in partnership with environmental commodity trader STX Group and Molgas, successfully conducted the bunkering operation. STX Group and Molgas handled the sourcing, liquefaction, and delivery of the Bio-LNG, ensuring alignment with the EU Renewable Energy Directive (REDII). This also marked Molga’s first-ever delivery of mass-balanced Bio-LNG to a maritime customer in Norway.

headline: Maritime Incident in Turkey as Two Cargo Vessels Collide
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 27th February, a maritime incident occurred at [GEMLIK ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1684?name=GEMLIK&country=Turkey)Port, Turkey, involving a collision between two general cargo vessels, [FRIENDS RS 1](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:284397/mmsi:511100756/imo:7382665/vessel:FRIENDS_RS_1#overview) and [JESSICA B](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:702298/mmsi:538009853/imo:9262534/vessel:JESSICA_B). The incident took place as [FRIENDS RS 1](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:284397/mmsi:511100756/imo:7382665/vessel:FRIENDS_RS_1#overview) was maneuvering to depart from the port and collided with [JESSICA B](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:702298/mmsi:538009853/imo:9262534/vessel:JESSICA_B), which was docked at the time. ![FREINDS RS 1 collided with JESSICA B in Turkey.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/JESSICA_B_a8cdf6c19d.png)*General cargo vessels FREINDS RS 1 collided with JESSICA B, image credit: Instagram/turkishstraits* As a result of the collision, [JESSICA B](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:702298/mmsi:538009853/imo:9262534/vessel:JESSICA_B) sustained a puncture in its outer section above the waterline, leading to the discharge of ballast water into the sea under pressure. Authorities initiated a damage assessment on [JESSICA B](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:702298/mmsi:538009853/imo:9262534/vessel:JESSICA_B), while [FRIENDS RS 1](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:284397/mmsi:511100756/imo:7382665/vessel:FRIENDS_RS_1#overview) has been anchored off [GEMLIK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1684?name=GEMLIK&country=Turkey). An investigation is also underway to determine the extent of any environmental impact and assess potential pollution in the surrounding waters.

headline: Container Ship Towed to Safety After Mechanical Breakdown in Turkish Waters
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 27th February, Turkey’s Directorate General of Coastal Safety (KEGM) reported that the container ship [OYSTER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:463499/mmsi:372797000/imo:9418884/vessel:OYSTER) suffered an engine failure and had to be towed to safety. ![OYSTER vessel suffer engine failure in Turkish water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/OYSTER_ec5413bf6d.png)*Containership OYSTER, image credit: KEGM* The incident occurred near Kandilli, Turkey, while the vessel was en route from[ AMBARLI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17436?name=AMBARLI&country=Turkey#overview) to [NOVOROSSIYSK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/767?name=NOVOROSSIYSK&country=Russia), Russia. Under the coordination of the IGTH Center, the vessel was successfully anchored in Büyükdere. The operation was carried out with the assistance of a Pilot Captain, along with the tugboats Kurtarma-7 and Kurtarma-12. Authorities have not yet reported any threats to the vessel, its crew, or the surrounding environment. [OYSTER](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:463499/mmsi:372797000/imo:9418884/vessel:OYSTER) is a Panama-flagged container ship built in 2008. The vessel has a carrying capacity of 630 TEU. The overall length is 131.2 meters and width is 18.4 meters.

headline: Fire Breaks Out on Bulk Carrier at Turkish Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: Turkish local news media reported that a fire erupted on the bulk carrier [THOR MONADIC](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:728251/mmsi:564411000/imo:9331220/vessel:THOR_MONADIC#overview) in Adana’s Yumurtalık district, Turkey, in the early morning of 27th February, prompting an immediate emergency response. The incident occurred while the vessel carrying plastic raw materials was docked in the Yumurtalık Free Zone. ![A fire broke out on the bulk carrier THOR MONADIC.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/THOR_MONADIC_1e4c749ae7.png)*Vessel THOR MONADIC, image credit:birgun.net* Upon receiving the alert, firefighting teams were dispatched to the scene. Crews from both land and sea are actively working to contain the blaze. Authorities have not yet determined the cause of the fire, and efforts to extinguish it are ongoing. [THOR MONADIC](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:728251/mmsi:564411000/imo:9331220/vessel:THOR_MONADIC#overview) is a Singapore-flagged bulk carrier built in 2006. The vessel has a carrying capacity of 56,026 tonnes. The overall length of the vessel is 189.9 meters, and the width is 32.26 meters.

headline: Trade Wars at Sea: The Potential Impact of U.S. Penalties on Chinese-Linked Ships
author: Alex Stuart-Grumbar
content: The U.S. government is considering sweeping restrictions and financial penalties on Chinese-linked vessels calling at U.S. ports. These measures are primarily driven by economic and national security concerns, aiming to reduce reliance on Chinese supply chains and revitalise U.S. shipbuilding, which remains uncompetitive. These measures could have far-reaching consequences, as nearly a third of the 57,000 cargo visits to the United States each year involve China—whether through vessel ownership, flag state, or construction. The proposed restrictions have the potential to reshape fleet operations, increase freight costs, and shift global chartering preferences. **Proposed Measures** The Office of the U.S. Trade Representative (USTR) has outlined several measures designed to curb China’s dominance in shipbuilding and logistics. Key proposals include: - Port entry fees of up to $1.5 million per visit for vessels built in Chinese shipyards. - Fees of up to $1 million per entry for Chinese-owned vessels operating in U.S. ports. - Additional surcharges for operators with pending orders from Chinese shipyards, discouraging future procurement. - Stricter regulatory checks and potential restrictions on Chinese-flagged vessels, increasing delays and compliance costs. Currently, a port call for a Chinese bulker or tanker can cost as little as $50,000. With the proposed fees, costs for affected vessels could increase by a staggering 3,000% **Measuring Exposure to U.S. Restrictions Using MarineTraffic Data** MarineTraffic data reveals the extent of Chinese maritime interests in U.S. waters and illustrates the widespread impact of these measures. **Chinese-Built Vessels** MarineTraffic data shows that 2,717 vessels built in Chinese shipyards have called at U.S. ports since January 2024. These vessels have made a total of 16,870 port calls in the U.S. over this period. China has steadily expanded its shipbuilding dominance, leveraging its global steel production supremacy and the cost efficiencies of its shipyards. These factors have positioned China as a near-monopoly in many commercial shipbuilding sectors, accounting for approximately 50% of global shipbuilding output and receiving over 70% of new orders last year. If the $1.5 million per-entry fee is enforced, it would significantly increase operational costs for shipowners using Chinese-built tonnage. The most immediate consequence would be a decline in future orders from Chinese yards, as shipowners seek alternatives in South Korea and Japan despite higher costs. However, the policy highlights a fundamental challenge: U.S. shipyards lack the capacity to meet growing demand. They currently produce only a handful of commercial vessels per year and have not built an LNG carrier since 1980. These measures may be aimed at curbing China's continued expansion in shipbuilding, as its control over steel production and cost-efficient yards enables it to outcompete global rivals. **Chinese-Flagged Vessels** Since the start of 2024, MarineTraffic data shows that 793 Chinese or Hong Kong-flagged vessels have called at U.S. ports, making a total of 4,657 port calls. These ships could face heightened scrutiny, delays, and elevated compliance costs, leading to potential rerouting of cargo flows. A likely response from Chinese operators would be to reflag vessels under alternative jurisdictions to evade restrictions. MarineTraffic continuously monitors flag changes, allowing businesses to track these shifts in real time and assess the regulatory risks associated with different registries. **Chinese-Owned Vessels** MarineTraffic’s ownership data reveals that 1,309 different vessels with some level of Chinese ownership have entered U.S. territorial waters in 2024. These vessels have made 7,186 port calls during this period. If the proposed $1 million port entry fee is implemented, it would impose substantial costs on Chinese-affiliated shipping companies and the charterers relying on these vessels. This financial burden is likely to prompt a shift toward non-Chinese-owned tonnage, as operators seek to minimise expenses and regulatory risks. Companies looking to restructure ownership or divest Chinese holdings can leverage MarineTraffic’s intelligence tools to navigate these changes effectively. **Broader Trade and Financial Implications** Even if implemented in a modified form, these measures will drive higher freight costs globally. Charterers seeking to avoid vessels that attract fees will increasingly favour non-Chinese-flagged, owned, and built tonnage, reshaping global chartering decisions. Financial institutions may also reassess their exposure to Chinese-built assets. Tighter credit terms and risk-averse lending practices could make financing more difficult for companies dependent on Chinese shipyards. Insurers and leasing companies may also adjust their risk models, increasing premiums or limiting coverage for Chinese-built vessels operating in U.S. waters. **What This Means for Global Shipping** While the proposed measures remain uncertain, they are already prompting strategic planning among stakeholders across the shipping industry. The Trump administration adds another layer of unpredictability, but bipartisan concerns over China’s influence in global trade suggest that some level of restriction is likely. Rather than a straightforward revenue-raising mechanism, these regulations may serve a broader strategic purpose—discouraging new orders from Chinese shipyards to curb China’s dominance in shipbuilding. However, given the limited capacity of U.S. shipyards to absorb this demand, the primary beneficiaries are more likely to be South Korean and Japanese builders rather than American ones. And while such stringent policies often begin as extreme proposals—only to be softened after industry pushback—their long-term impact on global trade remains a key concern. In anticipation of these changes, shipping firms may begin restructuring their fleets, segregating Chinese-built vessels from non-Chinese tonnage and assigning them to distinct trade lanes. This could lead to a fragmented global shipping network, potentially driving a shift in global trade routes, with some Chinese-built vessels being used more heavily in regions such as the Far East to Europe trades. If implemented, these policies would impose billions of dollars in additional costs on the shipping industry and global trade. **Key consequences include:** - Higher freight rates, increasing costs for businesses and consumers and contributing to inflation. - Charterers avoiding Chinese-built, owned, and flagged vessels to escape financial penalties. - A decline in Chinese shipyard orders, shifting demand to South Korea and Japan. - Increased pressure on U.S. shipbuilding, which lacks the capacity to meaningfully compete in commercial markets. - A shift of Chinese-linked shipping to Mexican and Canadian ports to bypass U.S. restrictions, with transshipment to U.S. ports. Ultimately, these measures could reshape global shipping, driving up costs, disrupting trade flows, and forcing fleet realignments. A public hearing is scheduled for 24 March 2025, which should shed more light on this topic. MarineTraffic will continue to monitor developments, providing real-time data, analytics, and intelligence to help industry players navigate this evolving regulatory landscape.

headline: Heroic Rescue at Sea: 34 Saved from Burning Vessel by Liberian-flagged Bulker
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Liberian-flagged bulker [ELEEN ARMONIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:414619/mmsi:636022428/imo:9407495/vessel:ELEEN_ARMONIA) rescued 34 crew members from a burning vessel on 26th February. The burning vessel was later identified to be the fishing vessel Hasil Abadi 28. ![ELEEN ARMONIA rescue crew from the burning fishing vessel in Indian Ocean.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ELEEN_ARMONIA_cb47e61b1d.png)*Bulk carrier ELEEN ARMONIA, image credit: Serafettin Aydin* The [ELEEN ARMONIA ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:414619/mmsi:636022428/imo:9407495/vessel:ELEEN_ARMONIA) en route from Port Klang to Durban spotted the burning vessel 800 kilometers south-east of Sri Lanka. The initial distress call was issued by the fishing vessel upon the stern catching fire. The [ELEEN ARMONIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:414619/mmsi:636022428/imo:9407495/vessel:ELEEN_ARMONIA) spotted the thick clouds of smoke rising on the horizon and approached to find the burning vessel with the crew members still onboard waving frantically. The crewmembers had gathered on the bow of the vessel. The[ ELEEN ARMONIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:414619/mmsi:636022428/imo:9407495/vessel:ELEEN_ARMONIA) pulled beside the burning vessel, and the crew aboard tried to extinguish the fire with hoses. Despite the efforts, the fire had been burning for too long, and the ship was reduced to a wreck. The crew of the Hasil Abadi 28 was taken aboard and provided with medical care and food. The rescued crewmembers were then transferred to a sister vessel of the Hasil Abadi 28, which was also operating in the area.

headline: Predicting Sanctions in Maritime Trade: Leveraging Data on Dark Ship-to-Ship Transfers and AIS Spoofing
author: Dimitris Ampatzidis
content: The maritime industry faces increasing challenges in tracking illicit activities such as dark ship-to-ship (STS) transfers and automatic identification system (AIS) spoofing, often linked to sanctions evasion. By analysing these activities, it is possible to assess risk and predict vessels that may be subject to sanctions in the near future. This report provides insights into the latest trends in dark STS transfers, AIS spoofing, and their combined occurrences over 2024, highlighting the involvement of non-sanctioned vessels and the typical timeline of sanctions imposition after deceptive events. **Trends in Dark STS Transfers and AIS Spoofing** Two primary high-risk activities have been identified: - **Dark STS:** transfers conducted with AIS transponders switched off. These events are verified via satellite imagery and pose significant compliance and operational risks. - **AIS Spoofing:** Deliberate manipulation of vessel location data to obscure real movements, making enforcement efforts more challenging. ![3-months rolling average events.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/3_months_rolling_average_events_ace40c84c4.png) **Graph 1.** _3-months rolling average of AIS spoofing and dark STS events within 2024 - Kpler._ Data trends indicate a peak in these activities between July and August 2024. The increase prompted intensified regulatory enforcement, culminating in the U.S. imposing its largest sanctions package by January 10, 2025 ([Wright M., 2025](https://www.kpler.com/blog/us-sanctions-clamp-down-on-russian-oil-exports)). Over time, spoofing tactics have evolved, incorporating more advanced techniques to bypass detection. A three-month rolling average reveals that dark STS events reached approximately 200 occurrences at their peak in August 2024, while AIS spoofing incidents peaked at around 100. Following regulatory crackdowns starting in September 2024, these numbers gradually declined, with dark STS and AIS spoofing falling to 120 and 50 incidents, respectively, by December 2024. **Non-Sanctioned Vessels Engaging in These Events** In 2024: - **242** vessels were involved in dark STS operations. - **280** vessels engaged in AIS spoofing. - **81** vessels were involved in both illicit activities. ![Total vessels engaged in Dark STS and:or AIS Spoofing.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Total_vessels_engaged_in_Dark_STS_and_or_AIS_Spoofing_90cdd26e48.png) **Graph 2.** _Total number of vessels engaged in dark STS and/or AIS spoofing within 2024 - Kpler._ A key finding is that most vessels engaged in dark STS events and AIS spoofing were not under existing sanctions at the time. This highlights a major gap in regulatory frameworks, where operators take advantage of enforcement delays to continue illicit trade. Compliance teams relying solely on sanction lists may miss exposure to high-risk activities. ![Proportion of sanctioned and non-sanctioned vessels per event.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Proportion_of_sanctioned_and_non_sanctioned_vessels_per_event_80ae820386.png) **Graph 3.** _Proportion of sanctioned and non-sanctioned vessels per event within 2024 - Kpler._ Given that more than half of the vessels involved in these activities lacked an official sanctions designation at the time of their operations, proactive monitoring and real-time analytics are essential to mitigate risks. **How Long After a Dark Event Do Sanctions Follow?** Analysis of sanction timelines reveals the following patterns: - **34%** of vessels were sanctioned within **250 days** of their first dark event. - **30%** were sanctioned between **501-750 days** post-event. - **12%** were sanctioned within **251-500 days**. - **25%** of vessels faced sanctions after **750+ days**. ![Sanction after first event.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Sanction_after_first_event_fc4109e3ab.png) **Graph 4.** _Days spent after the first dark event and before sanctioning - Kpler._ This data underscores the enforcement lag, with many vessels operating illicitly for extended periods before facing regulatory action. The prolonged delay in some cases exposes gaps in enforcement, allowing vessels to continue high-risk activities before formal measures are imposed. **Towards a Predictive Approach: Identifying Future Sanctions Risk** On the anniversary of the Russian invasion of Ukraine, February 24th, both the [UK Foreign, Commonwealth & Development Office](https://www.gov.uk/government/news/uk-announces-largest-sanctions-package-against-russia-since-2022) (FCDO) and the [EU](https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2025/02/24/16th-package-of-sanctions-on-russia-s-war-of-aggression-against-ukraine-eu-lists-additional-48-individuals-and-35-entities/) announced new sanctions targeting grey/shadow vessels, including those already sanctioned by OFAC, while OFAC focused on Iranian-affiliated vessels. Notably, all 51 vessels sanctioned were previously flagged by Kpler's Risk and Compliance tool as part of the grey/shadow fleet, with nine of them highlighted as high risk due to dark STS and AIS spoofing activities observed over recent months. While sanctions are often the result of political decisions, our analysis demonstrates that leveraging historical data allows us to make statistically significant predictions about vessels meeting these high-risk criteria, enabling proactive compliance strategies. Predictive analytics can identify potential future sanctions risk by tracking vessel activities over the past twelve months and establishing behavioral patterns that are correlated with eventual sanctions. This method allows for a forward-looking approach to manage compliance risks proactively. Based on current trends, it is estimated that **over 370 vessels are at high risk of inclusion in future sanction lists**. By implementing real-time tracking and predictive modeling, industry stakeholders can better manage compliance risks before formal sanctions are imposed, strengthening risk mitigation efforts and enhancing operational decision-making. Implementing real-time tracking and predictive modeling enables industry stakeholders to proactively manage compliance risks before formal sanctions are imposed. This forward-looking approach strengthens risk mitigation efforts and enhances operational decision-making. For further details, contact [Kpler’s Risk and Compliance](https://www.kpler.com/demos/risk-compliance-demo?utm_source=website&utm_medium=blog&utm_campaign=risk&compliance_commodities_maritime_news_demo_request) team today.

headline: Massive Oil Spill Threatens Elbe River Near Hamburg Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 2nd March, Hamburg authorities responded to a major oil spill in Kattwykhafen, near Hamburg Container Port, after a significant leak was reported. According to the initial reports, 42,000 liters of an oil-water mixture leaked into the Elbe River from a heavy oil tank at Green Port, a company specializing in petroleum residue management. ![Oil spill near Hamburg Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/HAMBURG_PORT_a6f7990c4d.png)*HAMBURG PORT, image credit: HEINER TRAPPMANN* The spill contaminated more than 90,000 cubic meters of water. The firefighters, water police, and environmental authorities deployed floating oil barriers to prevent its further spread. Additionally, a water-air barrier was activated to stop the pollution from reaching the Elbe’s main current, which could impact operations at the [HAMBURG Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/172?name=HAMBURG&country=Germany), Germany. A police aircraft equipped with special cameras was also monitoring the situation. Officials will assess the containment efforts and determine further action by 3rd March.

headline: Collision of a Container Vessels Knocks Off Containers in Hong Kong
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 28th February, the container ship [ONE COLUMBA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5728446/mmsi:431655000/imo:9806055/vessel:ONE_COLUMBA#overview) collided with the berthed [CLIFFORD MAERSK ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:157872/mmsi:219840000/imo:9198575/vessel:CLIFFORD_MAERSK)at Hong Kong’s Kwai Chung No.9 Terminal. The incident occurred around 8:40 PM local time when [ONE COLUMBA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5728446/mmsi:431655000/imo:9806055/vessel:ONE_COLUMBA#overview), arriving from [CHIWAN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2708?name=CHIWAN&country=China), China, collided with the docked vessel [CLIFFORD MAERSK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:157872/mmsi:219840000/imo:9198575/vessel:CLIFFORD_MAERSK). ![ONE COLUMBA collided with CLIFFORD MAERSK in Hong Kong](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ONE_COLUMBA_2529c2d6d7.png)*Image credit:dimsumdaily.hk* A video circulating on social media showed that [ONE COLUMBA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5728446/mmsi:431655000/imo:9806055/vessel:ONE_COLUMBA#overview) container vessel was driving into a [CLIFFORD MAERSK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:157872/mmsi:219840000/imo:9198575/vessel:CLIFFORD_MAERSK) container vessel and then slowly backing away from the accident site. Both the containerships sustained minor damage in the incident. The[ CLIFFORD MAERSK](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:157872/mmsi:219840000/imo:9198575/vessel:CLIFFORD_MAERSK) container ship lost three containers in the collision but was later recovered. The Hong Kong Maritime Department confirmed that no injuries or pollution resulted from the incident.

headline: One of the Largest Southern Indian Ports to Implement Green Methanol Bunkering
author: Raghib Raza
content: Chidambaranar port formerly known as [TUTICORIN Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2986?name=TUTICORIN&country=India) in Tamil Nadu, with the third largest terminal in India, is set to construct green methanol bunkering infrastructure. This move is expected to make the port the first in the country to provide methanol bunkering services. ![Tuticorin Port](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Tuticorin_Port_87606aa418.png)*Tuticorin Port, image credits: V.O Chidambaranar Port Authority* The Italian Marine Classification Society, RINA, collaborated with the Chidambaranar port authority to shortlist green methanol as the fuel of choice in the port. Green methanol was chosen from among green ammonia, green hydrogen, and green methane because it aligned the most with the port’s decarbonization strategy, which is to be implemented by 2030. Following the approval from the Ministry of New and Renewable Energy and the Ministry of Ports, Shipping, and Waterways, the port is set to establish the first green methanol bunkering infrastructure in India.

headline: Netherlands-Flagged Ship Stranded Off Near Welton, England
author: Raghib Raza
content: A Netherland-flagged general cargo vessel, [H&S WISDOM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:259521/mmsi:245339000/imo:9195559/vessel:H_S_WISDOM#overview), ran aground on 2nd March. The vessel became stuck in the flat, muddy seabed off the coast of Brough in the Humber Estuary near Welton, England. ![H&S WISDOM ran aground in England water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/H_and_S_WISDOM_68960e3403.png)*Vessel H&S WISDOM, image credit: steve moody* Built in 2004, [H&S WISDOM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:259521/mmsi:245339000/imo:9195559/vessel:H_S_WISDOM#overview) has an overall length of 82 meters and a width of 11.3 meters. The cargo vessel has a carrying capacity of 1,842 tonnes. Marine traffic data shows [H&S WISDOM](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:259521/mmsi:245339000/imo:9195559/vessel:H_S_WISDOM#overview) departed from [ROTTERDAM WAALHAVEN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2039?name=ROTTERDAM-WAALHAVEN&country=Netherlands), Netherlands, on 1st March and currently remains aground.

headline: Seatrium Completes Landmark CO₂ Capture Retrofit for “Nexus Victoria”
author: Raghib Raza
content: Seatrium announced the successful delivery of oil Products tanker[ NEXUS VICTORIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2095725/mmsi:235108514/imo:9610389/vessel:NEXUS_VICTORIA) on 4th March, marking Japan’s first vessel with a commercially installed CO2 capture system. The retrofit project, undertaken in collaboration with MOL, involved the planning, design, engineering, and system integration, including electrical and automation systems. ![NEXUS VICTORIA](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NEXUS_VICTORIA_5d6978e3f4.png)*Vessel NEZUS VICTORIA, image credit: Seatrium* In April 2024, MOL announced plans to equip [NEXUS VICTORIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2095725/mmsi:235108514/imo:9610389/vessel:NEXUS_VICTORIA) with Value Maritime’s 15 MW Filtree exhaust gas cleaning system (EGCS), which includes an additional carbon capture unit. The plug-and-play Filtree System is capable of filtering sulphur, CO2, and ultra-fine particulate matter from the exhaust stream. The captured CO2 is stored in onboard tanks for offshore discharge and can be repurposed in greenhouse cultivation and methanol production. This retrofit is part of a broader effort to reduce carbon emissions and enhance sustainability in the shipping industry.

headline: Global Fuel Supply expands into West Africa with new physical bunkering operation
author: Stephanie Duscha
content: ![RLO Explorer.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RLO_Explorer_cb450e1b71.png) Global Fuel Supply (GFS), a company specialising in bunker and marine fuel solutions, announced the launch of a new physical supply operation in West Africa on Thursday, 21 February. For this purpose, the company has chartered the 5,498 DWT bunkering tanker [RLO Explorer](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:385727/mmsi:244323000/imo:9148958/vessel:RLO_EXPLORER), which will be stationed at [Luanda](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/805?name=LUANDA&country=Angola) in Angola and will deliver fuel from there. According to GFS, the vessel, built in 1998, is particularly well-suited for these operations due to its relatively short length of approximately 96 metres. Additionally, the stainless steel tanks can be cleaned within 24 hours, enhancing flexibility. The economic reasons behind the expansion into West Africa are the enormous growth and expansion opportunities in the region, explained Bijan Shahbaz, Managing Partner and COO of GFS. “With some of the most dedicated professionals in the industry, we are well-prepared to provide our customers with even greater value by delivering a smooth, seamless service that sets new standards in this region”, he stated.

headline: Bulk Carrier “ERRIKOS” Adrift Off Norwegian Coast After Power Failure
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 4th March, a maritime incident occurred northwest of Tromsø as the cargo ship [ERRIKOS ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:714460/mmsi:538005376/imo:9624500/vessel:ERRIKOS#overview)suffered a power failure and was adrift without propulsion. The incident occurred off the Norwegian coast while the vessel was sailing from [MURMANSK Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2244?name=MURMANSK&country=Russia), Russia. ![ERRIKOS lost power and adrift in Norwegian Water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ERRIKOS_335fc1b2c8.png)*Vessel ERRIKOS, image credit: CapTom* In response to the incident, VTS Nor Maritime Traffic Center in Vardø deployed a Coast Guard vessel, and a tugboat, to the location of the stranded ship, [ERRIKOS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:714460/mmsi:538005376/imo:9624500/vessel:ERRIKOS#overview), to provide assistance. The authorities informed that the bulk carrier is not carrying any hazardous cargo and the situation does not pose any immediate environmental risk. The vessel will be towed to shore outside Vannvag. [ERRIKOS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:714460/mmsi:538005376/imo:9624500/vessel:ERRIKOS#overview) is a 2014-built vessel sailing under the flag of Marshall-Is. It has a carrying capacity of 57,000 tonnes with an overall length of 190 meters and a width of 32 meters.

headline: Cargo Vessel VESTVIND Hits Wall in Kiel Canal, No Injuries Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: A Portugal-flagged cargo vessel, [VESTVIND](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3628841/mmsi:255806433/imo:9750579/vessel:VESTVIND), ran into a wall within the Kiel Canal at Brunsbüttel, Germany, on 2nd March. ![VESTVIND struck the wall in Kiel Canal.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/VESTVIND_a0bd4f584e.png)*Vessel VESTVIND, image credit: Christophe Dedieu* The incident occurred at 9:13 PM local time when the vessel was headed from[ PORTSMOUTH,](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/107?name=PORTSMOUTH&country=United-Kingdom) UK, to[ NAKSHOV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/365?name=NAKSKOV&country=Denmark), Denmark. The vessel struck the wall of the canal and is reported to have sustained minor damage. After the collision, the vessel remained within the canal until two tugboats arrived on the scene to pull the vessel free. The tugboats towed the vessel to the Port of Brunsbüttel, where the vessel remained till 3rd March. The vessel finally arrived at its destination in Nakskov the next day, on 4th March. There have been no reports of any injuries or pollution.

headline: MOL Conducts the First Ship-to-Ship LNG Bunkering in Western North America
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Japanese transport company Mitsui OSK Lines (MOL) successfully conducted its first ship-to-ship bunkering of LNG in English Bay, Western North America, on 1st March. ![MOL conduct first ship-to-ship bunkering of LNG in English Bay](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LAKE_HERMAN_924808b842.png)*Vessel LAKE HERMAN, image credit: MOL* The Seaspan Energy-operated vessel, [SEASPAN GARIBALDI](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8842777/mmsi:352004278/imo:9974319/vessel:SEASPAN_GARIBALDI), provided the LNG to the MOL-operated car carrier, [LAKE HERMAN](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7965109/mmsi:636021536/imo:9953119/vessel:LAKE_HERMAN). The bunkering was carried out as the vessel was moored in English Bay, and the LNG was provided by Seaspan Energy. According to MOL’s Group Environmental Vision, the company is set to achieve net zero emissions by 2050. To this end, MOL has been pushing for expanding the LNG bunkering network around the globe. Yoshikazu Urushitani, the general manager of Marine Fuel GX Division, stated that this successful bunkering has expanded the range of areas in which they can deploy environmentally friendly LNG-powered vessels.

headline: Tanker SAGAR VIOLET Detained in Russia, Over Unpaid Wages and Food Shortages
author: Raghib Raza
content: Russian news media reported that a Palau-flagged crude oil tanker, [SAGAR VIOLET](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:708670/mmsi:511100864/imo:9292981/vessel:SAGAR_VIOLET#overview), was detained in [NAKHODKA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2243?name=NAKHODKA&country=Russia) Port, Russia for overdue salaries of sailors and for supply violations. ![SAGAR VIOLET detained at Russian Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SAGAR_VIOLET_646953cd38.png)*Vessel SAGAR VIOLET, image credit: Geir Vinnes* The sailors onboard the vessel had complained of not having received their salaries for months and of shortages of food on the vessel. The Far Eastern Transport Prosecutor's Office had been conducting an inspection into the allegations and found that the sailors had not received their salaries for three months and that there were food supply problems on the vessel. The ship was then detained at the Nakhodka port. Nikolai Sukhanov, the chairman of the Far Eastern regional organization of the Russian Seafarers Union, has seconded the findings of overdue salaries and supply issues and has stated that the total overdue debt to the sailors has exceeded $200,000. Sukhanov has further stated that the tanker will remain detained until the debts to the sailors are cleared and all violations aboard the vessel are resolved.

headline: Cargo Ship Allides with Moored Oil Tanker at the Port of Chattogram, Bangladesh
author: Raghib Raza
content: The cargo vessel [YONG YUE 11](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7236411/mmsi:352002215/imo:8741026/vessel:YONG_YUE_11) allided with the oil tanker [RHINE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6904284/mmsi:312255000/imo:9356816/vessel:RHINE), which was moored at the port of [CHITTAGONG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2743?name=CHITTAGONG&country=Bangladesh), Bangladesh. The accident was caused by the propeller of the [YONG YUE 11](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7236411/mmsi:352002215/imo:8741026/vessel:YONG_YUE_11) becoming entangled with the anchor chain of the [RHINE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6904284/mmsi:312255000/imo:9356816/vessel:RHINE). ![YONG YUE 11 collided with an oil tanker.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/YONG_YUE_11_d8131254c7.png)*Vessel YONG YUE 11 collided with vessel RHINE in Chittagong Port, image credit: Sergei Skriabin* The incident occurred around 12:20 PM local time on March 4, when the vessel [YONG YUE 11](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7236411/mmsi:352002215/imo:8741026/vessel:YONG_YUE_11) arrived at the [CHITTAGONG](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2743?name=CHITTAGONG&country=Bangladesh) Port from [COLOMBO](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1272?name=COLOMBO&country=Sri-Lanka), Sri Lanka. The propeller of the cargo vessel became entangled with the oil tanker RHINE's anchor chain, resulting in the allision. Neither vessel suffered significant damage, and the oil tanker remained anchored despite the incident. The Chattogram Port authority deployed three tugboats along with a pilot boat to alleviate the situation. The [YONG YUE 11](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7236411/mmsi:352002215/imo:8741026/vessel:YONG_YUE_11)'s propeller was freed, and the container ship was moved by 4:40 PM the same day. Port officials stated that operations at the port were not affected by the incident.

headline: Engine Failures Halt Transit of Oil Tanker "Conga" in Kiel Canal
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 6th March, at around 3:30 AM local time, an oil tanker, [CONGA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:195115/mmsi:538010595/imo:9412000/vessel:CONGA), suffered an engine failure while transiting through the Kiel Canal, Germany. ![CONGA suffered engine failure in Kiel Canal.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CONGA_096a04ff53.png)*Oil tanker CONGA, image credit: Oliver Sesemann* This incident followed an earlier engine failure on 5th March, shortly after the vessel entered the waterway. The vessel experienced mechanical issues and was berthed at Brunsbuttle. Afterward, it resumed its transit, but the tanker faced a second engine failure the next day during its eastbound journey. To assist, two tugboats were dispatched to tow the distressed vessel to Kiel. Subsequently, the inspectors from the shipping company and the classification society boarded to evaluate the condition of the vessel. The tanker, which had previously departed from Libya, will only be allowed to resume its journey once clearance is granted following the inspection. [CONGA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:195115/mmsi:538010595/imo:9412000/vessel:CONGA) is a Marshall-Is flagged oil tanker built in 2010. It has a carrying capacity of 37,874 tonnes, an overall length of 184 meters, and a width of 27 meters.

headline: Containership “SM Portland” Loses 115 Containers in a Storm in the Bering Sea
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Korean-flagged container ship [SM PORTLAND](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:722222/mmsi:441403000/imo:9409027/vessel:SM_PORTLAND#overview) lost a large number of containers due to facing a severe storm in the Bering Sea. According to an alert sent by the operator of the vessel, SM Line, on 5th March, the vessel lost containers while en route to Vancouver. ![SM PORTLAND containers lost in rough sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SM_PORTLAND_2ea9b9c0fd.png)*Containership SM PORTLAND, image credit: Jackie Pritchard* A total of 115 containers were lost, destroyed, or damaged as the vessel faced the storm while traversing the Bering Sea. The storm caused the [SM PORTLAND](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:722222/mmsi:441403000/imo:9409027/vessel:SM_PORTLAND#overview) to begin rolling heavily and tilt to a dangerous degree, leading to the loss of containers. SM Line informed its customers in an issued alert of the delay in the delivery of cargo due to the ship being caught up in a storm. The vessel veered off its course on 4th March and resumed its course the next day. SM Line has clarified that the vessel had adjusted its course for safety. The vessel is set to be inspected when it arrives in Vancouver before it is allowed to berth. SM Line has stated that the Canadian Coast Guard and Transport Canada will be carrying out the inspection.

headline: Oil Tanker Damaged in Collision with Container Ship Near Istanbul
author: Raghib Raza
content: A maritime collision occurred on 7th March off the coast of Beylikdüzü Gürpınar, Istanbul, between the Panama-flagged container ship [ORITA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:124812/mmsi:373184000/imo:9318931/vessel:ORITA#overview) and the Guyana-flagged oil tanker [MIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:756346/mmsi:750276000/imo:9018464/vessel:MIA#overview). The incident took place at approximately 15:00 when [ORITA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:124812/mmsi:373184000/imo:9318931/vessel:ORITA#overview), while drifting into the anchorage area, struck [MIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:756346/mmsi:750276000/imo:9018464/vessel:MIA#overview), which was anchored five miles offshore. ![ORITA vessel collided with MIA in turkish water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ORITA_5e44168536.png)*Containership ORITA struck with Oil tanker MIA, image credit:iha.com.tr* As a result of the collision, [MIA](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:756346/mmsi:750276000/imo:9018464/vessel:MIA#overview) sustained a rupture in one of its ballast tanks, leading to the discharge of contaminated water into the sea. Reports indicate that [ORITA ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:124812/mmsi:373184000/imo:9318931/vessel:ORITA#overview)also sustained visible impact marks in the incident. In response to the situation, the General Directorate of Coastal Safety deployed the tugboat Rescue 2 to assist at the scene. The Coast Guard classified the leakage as pollution but clarified that it was not oil. The Marine traffic data shows that both vessels are currently at [AMARLI Anchorage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/20616?name=AMBARLI-ANCH&country=Turkey), Turkey.

headline: Oil tanker Stena Immaculate collides with container ship Solong in North Sea
author: Stephanie Duscha
content: This morning, the oil tanker Stena Immaculate and the container ship Solong collided in the North Sea. According to MarineTraffic data, the collision was at approximately 9:48 UTC. The 183 metre long oil tanker was at anchor off the coast of Humber Estuary when it was struck by the 140 metre long container ship. ![STENA IMMACULATE.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/STENA_IMMACULATE_7f85c1bb6e.png) Following the collision a fire broke out on the Stena Immaculate. Helicopters, lifeboats and a number of civilian ships are involved in the rescue mission. There are no reports of any injured persons so far. According to the BBC, many sailors abandoned the vessels after the collision. The Stena Immaculate was carrying 18.000 tonnes of Jet A-1 - an environmental disaster is also feared. headline: Israeli-Owned Vessel CAPE LEGACY Damaged After Collision with Chinese Bulker
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Israeli-owned bulk carrier [CAPE LEGACY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:420503/mmsi:538006654/imo:9589401/vessel:CAPE_LEGACY#overview) was damaged and began taking in water after a collision with the Chinese-flagged bulker [FEI DA 138](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6822622/mmsi:413286350/imo:0/vessel:FEI_DA_138). ![CAPY LEGACY collided with FEI DA 138 in Chinese water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CAPE_LEGACY_9da5b31c71.png)*Bulk carrier CAPE LEGACY collided with FEI DA 138, image credit:163.com* The incident occurred at around 4:12 PM local time on 8th March near the mouth of the Yangtze River. The [CAPE LEGACY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:420503/mmsi:538006654/imo:9589401/vessel:CAPE_LEGACY#overview) was inbound from the North Channel, and the [FEI DA 138](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6822622/mmsi:413286350/imo:0/vessel:FEI_DA_138) was arriving from the South Channel when they both collided. The collision caused a hole in the [CAPE LEGACY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:420503/mmsi:538006654/imo:9589401/vessel:CAPE_LEGACY#overview) on the left forepeak of the vessel, which led to water ingress. The [CAPE LEGACY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:420503/mmsi:538006654/imo:9589401/vessel:CAPE_LEGACY#overview), owned by Mano Maritime in Israel, was carrying 90,000 dwt of iron ore fines. Mano Maritime stated that [CAPE LEGACY](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:420503/mmsi:538006654/imo:9589401/vessel:CAPE_LEGACY#overview) refloated on the same day and led to the Beimaodi Anchorage in the Yangtze River. An inspection of the vessel is to be carried out, and the course of action is to be decided by the authorities. The crew of the vessel has been reported to be safe, and no reports of pollution have been released so far.

headline: Bulk Carrier MEGHNA PRINCESS Successfully Refloated in Gulf of Finland
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 7th March, the Marine Rescue Service successfully refloated the grounded bulk carrier [MEGHNA PRINCESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5835195/mmsi:405000306/imo:9805776/vessel:MEGHNA_PRINCESS#overview) from the shore in the Gulf of Finland. ![MEGHNA PRINCESS rescued after running aground in Gulf of Finland.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MEGHNA_PRINCESS_e62fef1972.png)*Vessel MEGHNA PRINCESS refloated after grounding in Gulf of Finland, image credit:morspas.ru* The vessel had run aground on 29th December 2024 with a total cargo of over 32,600 tons of mineral fertilizers. During the rescue operation, 2,300 tons of mineral fertilizers were unloaded to facilitate the rescue. Subsequently, specialists from the Baltic Branch of the Marine Rescue Service washed away the soil beneath the bulk carrier, enabling it to refloat. This extensive rescue operation involved multiple rescue vessels, including MFASS Baltika, MFASS Spasatel Karev, SO Soyuz, and RVC Vodolaz Litvin, a hydrographic team, a diving station, and additional rescue personnel. Authorities confirmed that no oil pollution was observed during the operation. Following the refloat, the vessel arrived at the [PRIMORSK Anchorage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/22093?name=PRIMORSK-ANCH&country=Russia), Russia, for inspection. A diving station aboard the RVC Vodolaz Litvin assessed the vessel’s hull for potential damage. Upon confirmation of its seaworthiness after inspection, [MEGHNA PRINCESS](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5835195/mmsi:405000306/imo:9805776/vessel:MEGHNA_PRINCESS#overview) will be handed over to the ship owner.

headline: French-Flagged Cable Repair Ship Causes Damage in the Kiel Canal
author: Raghib Raza
content: The French cable repair ship [CABLE VIGILANCE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:386285/mmsi:228416900/imo:9329930/vessel:CABLE_VIGILANCE#overview) drove into the tail section on 8th March near the south chamber of the Holtenau Lock in Kiel Canal. The [CABLE VIGILANCE](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:386285/mmsi:228416900/imo:9329930/vessel:CABLE_VIGILANCE#overview) has been tasked with repairing the severed undersea cables beneath the Baltic Sea. ![CABLE VIGILANCE cause damage in Kiel canal.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CABLE_VIGILANCE_9a889e1811.png)*Vessel CABLE VIGILANCE, image credit: Inge Fuhles* The vessel traverses the Kiel Canal frequently, and this was its fifth passage since November last year. The accident was caused due to a coordination error on the bridge of the vessel. The control console on the bridge wing for the systems operating the rudder and propellers was not turned on. This oversight is being attributed to human error on the captain’s part. Officials from the Kiel Canal Waterways and Shipping Authority (WSA) inspected the damage on 10th March. Several wooden floating fenders were reportedly destroyed, splintered, and wedged underwater. A WSA representative stated that the damage is not substantial and can be repaired quickly. The [CABLE VIGILANCE ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:386285/mmsi:228416900/imo:9329930/vessel:CABLE_VIGILANCE#overview)resumed its journey at around 9:00 PM local time the same day after being questioned by the Water Police.

headline: Navigating the Complexities of Maritime Sanctions: A February 2025 Overview
author: Dimitris Ampatzidis
content: Escalating sanctions in February 2025 have intensified the crackdown on illicit oil trade, targeting a record number of vessels and companies linked to Russian, Iranian, and Venezuelan crude exports. As enforcement tightens and shadow fleet operations come under greater scrutiny, traders, insurers, and shipping analysts must navigate a rapidly shifting landscape of supply disruptions, rising compliance risks, and evolving trade routes. Meanwhile, broader geopolitical uncertainty - shifting U.S. policies, unresolved trade agreements, and fragile international alliances - casts a long shadow over what comes next. **Key takeaways** - In February 2025 alone, **51 additional vessels and 19 companies were sanctioned**, bringing the total number of sanctioned vessels to 1,301 and companies to 540. - Newly sanctioned vessels transported over **208.3 million barrels of crude in 2024**, valued at approximately **$15.24 billion**, highlighting the scale of illicit shipments now under restrictions. - The **revocation of Chevron’s Venezuela waiver from 1st of March** is expected to cut production from 900 kbd to 700 kbd by August, tightening supply for U.S. Gulf refiners already struggling with declining Mexican output. - The sharp rise in sanctioned ships, including 183 vessels blacklisted in January 2025 alone, is expected to **push up freight costs**, restrict vessel availability, and intensify compliance risks for insurers and traders. **Market Analysis** In February 2025, the U.S. introduced new sanctions on the shipping industry, targeting vessels involved in illicit oil trade, particularly those linked to Iran and Russia. The U.S. Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control ([OFAC](https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sb0026)) sanctioned over 30 Iranian oil tankers that were part of a “shadow fleet,” moving millions of barrels through ship-to-ship (STS) transfers. Additionally, multiple shipping companies across the UAE, Hong Kong, China, and India were penalised for facilitating these transactions. Some firms, like India-based Marshal Ship Management, were caught providing falsified documents and crew for sanctioned vessels. The [UK followed with its largest sanctions package since 2022](https://www.gov.uk/government/news/uk-announces-largest-sanctions-package-against-russia-since-2022), adding 40 more Russian tankers to its blacklist. These vessels, which had transported over $5 billion worth of oil in six months, are now under asset freezes and trade bans, bringing the total number of UK-sanctioned oil tankers to 133. The [European Union also expanded its restrictions](https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2025/02/24/three-years-of-russia-s-full-scale-invasion-and-war-of-aggression-against-ukraine-eu-adopts-its-16th-package-of-economic-and-individual-measures/), adding 74 vessels to its sanctions list for their role in evading sanctions by moving Russian oil under different flags or through ship-to-ship transfers. At the same time, the U.S. revoked Chevron’s license to operate in Venezuela, cutting off exports of heavy crude that were crucial for U.S. refiners. With Venezuelan production expected to drop from 900 kbd to 700 kbd by August, U.S. Gulf Coast refiners now face a supply gap in heavy crude, which was [already tightening due to declining Mexican output](https://terminal.kpler.com/insight/research/research-updates/trump-cancelling-chevron-s-permit-in-venezuela-hurts-the-us-gulf-the-most). This move is likely to further strain the global heavy crude market, leading to increased demand for alternatives such as [Canadian and Middle Eastern sour crudes](https://terminal.kpler.com/insight/research/reports/chevron-waiver-removal-in-venezuela-will-tighten-heavy-crude-markets-in-the-us). The combination of U.S. sanctions on Russia and Iran, coupled with Venezuela’s supply disruption, is reshaping the global oil and tanker markets, forcing refiners to seek alternative sources to maintain operations. **Implications for the Shipping Industry** Sanctions on vessels and shipping companies have surged over the past year, with a sharp increase in newly blacklisted tankers involved in illicit oil trade. In the last month alone, 51 additional vessels have been targeted, along with 19 shipping companies. In 2024, these newly sanctioned vessels transported a large amount of oil - 208.3 million barrels in total. This included 117.57 million barrels from Russia and 71.45 million barrels from Iran. The flags under which these tankers operate reveal a pattern of convenience, with many shifting registrations to jurisdictions less likely to enforce international sanctions. ![Picture1.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture1_b35f1fcef4.png) **Graph 1.** _Sanctioned vessels and companies through the last five years (February 2020 to February 2025) - Kpler._ The number of ships and companies facing sanctions increased rapidly between late 2024 and early 2025 due to growing political tensions and stricter enforcement of energy trade restrictions. Over the 12 months leading to February 2025, 471 more vessels were sanctioned, bringing the total to 1,301. The biggest increase happened in January 2025, when 183 ships were blacklisted in just one month. The number of sanctioned companies also rose significantly, growing by 213 over the year to reach 540, with the largest jump of 70 in January. These increases were driven by new U.S., UK, and EU sanctions aimed at stopping Russian and Iranian oil trade, particularly through secret ship movements, ship-to-ship transfers, and false registrations. ![Picture2.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture2_f40511abca.png) **Graph 2.** _Sanctioned vessels per top 10 flag registry through the last two years (February 2023 to February 2025) - Kpler._ The number of sanctioned vessels across different flag registries has increased sharply from February 2023 to February 2025, with a notable acceleration in late 2024 and early 2025. Iranian- and Russian-flagged vessels continue to represent the largest share, but the use of alternative flags, such as Panama, Barbados, Guyana, and Curacao, has grown significantly. By February 2025, the total number of sanctioned vessels under these top 10 flag registries had surpassed 600, more than doubling from early 2023 levels. The rapid expansion of sanctions targeting Russian and Iranian oil shipments, along with increased scrutiny of deceptive shipping practices, has driven a diversification of flagged vessels, with new entries such as Djibouti and Sao Tome and Principe playing a more prominent role in recent months. ![Picture3.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture3_e9ddc6632a.png) **Graph 3.** _Total vessels and companies added to sanctions lists over the last twelve months (March 2024 to February 2025) - Kpler._ While the monthly additions remained relatively steady from March to September 2024, with most months seeing fewer than 30 new designations, a sharp rise began in October 2024, when 48 vessels and 30 companies were blacklisted. This trend continued through the end of the year, with December recording 51 sanctioned vessels and 30 companies. However, January 2025 saw an unprecedented increase, with 183 vessels and 70 companies added in a single month, marking the largest wave of sanctions over the period. This surge aligns with intensified geopolitical tensions and expanded U.S., UK, and EU sanctions targeting Russian and Iranian oil networks, reflecting a concerted effort to disrupt illicit shipping activities at the start of the new year. By February 2025, the numbers had moderated, though 51 additional vessels and 19 companies were still sanctioned, indicating that enforcement efforts remain ongoing. In 2024 alone, these newly added vessels exported approximately 117.57 million barrels of crude—71.44 million barrels from Iran and 1.44 million barrels from Venezuela. These tankers have been instrumental in sustaining exports despite restrictions, utilising ship-to-ship (STS) transfers and deceptive shipping tactics. The targeting of these vessels represents a broader effort to disrupt shadow fleet operations, reflecting a tightening enforcement landscape that is reshaping global crude trade flows and increasing risks for market participants engaging with these entities. The total estimated value of these shipments, based on an average crude price of $80 per barrel, is approximately $15.24 billion. **Conclusion** The expansion of sanctions in February 2025 introduces significant risks to oil procurement strategies, particularly for those traders relying on Russian, Iranian, or Venezuelan crude. The growing list of blacklisted vessels increases the difficulty of securing reliable shipping routes, potentially tightening spot market availability and raising freight costs. Refiners, particularly in the U.S. Gulf Coast, face added supply pressures following the revocation of Chevron’s Venezuela waiver, forcing a shift toward alternative heavy crude sources such as Canadian and Middle Eastern grades. The impact of these sanctions extends beyond immediate supply disruptions - traders must now navigate an increasingly complex compliance landscape, where dealing with sanctioned entities, even indirectly, carries heightened legal and financial risks. For insurers and compliance analysts, the sharp rise in sanctioned vessels signals increased exposure to regulatory scrutiny, compliance violations, and operational uncertainty. The growing use of alternative flag registries and deceptive shipping tactics, including dark STS transfers, poses challenges in risk assessment and liability coverage. Insurers will likely tighten underwriting criteria for vessels operating in high-risk corridors, while compliance analysts must closely monitor evolving trade patterns and enforcement trends to anticipate disruptions. The shifting regulatory environment reinforces the need for more sophisticated tracking mechanisms and due diligence to mitigate exposure to sanctioned fleets and maintain supply chain integrity. _To find out more about Kpler’s Risk & Compliance offering, visit [here](https://www.kpler.com/demos/risk-compliance-demo?utm_source=website&utm_medium=blog&utm_campaign=risk&compliance_commodities_maritime_news_demo_request)._

headline: Update: One Dead, Environmental Concerns Rise After Vessel Collision Off East Yorkshire
author: Raghib Raza
content: The collision of a Portuguese-flagged container vessel, [Solong](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:122649/mmsi:255805837/imo:9322554/vessel:SOLONG), with the then-moored oil tanker [Stena Immaculate](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4651569/mmsi:368108000/imo:9693018/vessel:STENA_IMMACULATE), led to an explosion in the North Sea off the coast of East Yorkshire. The incident, which occurred on 10 March, has led to the death of one crew member and is posing a significant risk to the environment due to suspected leaks of aviation and marine fuel. ![STENA IMMACULATE](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/STENA_IMMACULATE_6e1575e6f6.png)*Vessel STENA IMMACULATE, image credits: Instagram/sailor_image* The[ Stena Immaculate](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4651569/mmsi:368108000/imo:9693018/vessel:STENA_IMMACULATE), which was at anchor 21 kilometers off the coast of East Yorkshire, was carrying 220,000 barrels of aviation fuel on charter for the United States Air Force. The [Solong](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:122649/mmsi:255805837/imo:9322554/vessel:SOLONG), which was traveling at a speed of around 18 knots, struck the moored [Stena Immaculate](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4651569/mmsi:368108000/imo:9693018/vessel:STENA_IMMACULATE) at 9:48 AM UTC, leading to a substantial hole in its hull, a ruptured cargo tank, and a fire breaking out along with jet fuel leaking into the sea. The fire aboard the [Stena Immaculate](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4651569/mmsi:368108000/imo:9693018/vessel:STENA_IMMACULATE) was extinguished by the next day; however, the fire on the [Solong](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:122649/mmsi:255805837/imo:9322554/vessel:SOLONG) continued to burn even a day after the collision. 13 crew members from the cargo ship [Solong](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:122649/mmsi:255805837/imo:9322554/vessel:SOLONG) and the 23 crew members of the [Stena Immaculate](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4651569/mmsi:368108000/imo:9693018/vessel:STENA_IMMACULATE) were evacuated. The one missing crewmember from the [Solong](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:122649/mmsi:255805837/imo:9322554/vessel:SOLONG) has been presumed dead after a search and rescue effort was called off on 10 March. Environmental groups continue to warn of disastrous consequences to marine wildlife due to the jet fuel spill from the Stena Immaculate. However, authorities have assured that the impact from the leak remains limited. The Coast Guard has placed a 1 km exclusion zone around the accident site and both vessels. There had been a moment of panic when a Lloyd’s List report revealed that the [Solong](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:122649/mmsi:255805837/imo:9322554/vessel:SOLONG) had been carrying the highly hazardous and toxic sodium cyanide. However, these fears were quelled when the shipowner, Ernst Russ, explained that the containers carrying cyanide had been emptied prior to the collision. They further assured that the four containers that had held sodium cyanide are being actively monitored. Despite the accident, both vessels are expected to remain afloat following the dousing of the fire. Coastguard agencies have stated that the Solong is expected to be towed away from the shore, following which salvage operations on the vessel can be initiated. The captain of the Solong has been identified as a 59-year-old Russian national who has been apprehended under charges of gross negligence and manslaughter. Questions have been raised regarding the incident as to why multiple safety systems on the Solong failed simultaneously and led to the accident. Reports indicate there has been no indication of malicious intent behind the accident; however, foul play has not been ruled out. Poor visibility at the time of the incident is also being claimed to have played a role. Investigations by multiple authorities have been launched into the incident. The British Marine Accident Investigation Branch is to gather preliminary evidence, whereas the US and Portuguese authorities, the states where the vessels are registered, bear the burden of investigating the accident more thoroughly.

headline: Norway-flagged vessel Rotsund pulled free after running aground on the coast of Isle of Skye
author: Raghib Raza
content: A refeer vessel[ Rotsund](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:182272/mmsi:257068010/imo:9333644/vessel:ROTSUND#overview) dragged its anchor and ran aground on the breakish area of the Isle of Skye, Scotland on 10 March, as it was en route from Haugesund to Kyle. ![ROTSUND ran aground off the Scotland Coast](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ROTSUND_c1f0f2fe61.png)*Vessel ROTSUND, image credit: Inverlussa Marine Services* The UK Coastguard summoned help after receiving a distress signal from the vessel. The tugboats, 'Spirit of Fred Olsen' from Kyle of Lochalsh and the Stanley Watson Barker from Portree, were called for help at 2:18 AM local time. The lifeboat Spirit of Fred Olsen arrived on the scene and reported that the Rotsund's stern had run aground while it was continuously being pushed further ashore by winds and choppy waves. The crew of the [Rotsund](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:182272/mmsi:257068010/imo:9333644/vessel:ROTSUND#overview) were trying to free the boat and managed to succeed at 4:15 AM local time. The crew used the vessel's own thrusters and engine when the water level had risen to pull themselves free. The lifeboats Spirit of Fred Olsen and Stanley Watson Barker remained on scene to ensure the crew were uninjured and there was no pollution from the vessel. At around noon, the tugboat Levoly Black and the repair vessel Gina Mary towed the vessel and led it to the Kishorn Port & Dry Dock Ltd.

headline: Ferry Samnoy sustains damage after grounding incident in Norway
author: Raghib Raza
content: On the evening of 9 March, the passenger vessel [Samnoy](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5741310/mmsi:257055860/imo:9825817/vessel:SAMNOY#overview) ran aground while operating on the Halhjem-Sandvikvåg route in Norway. ![Samnoy ran aground in Norway.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Samnoy_d50065b1c9.png)*Passeneger ship SAMNOY, image credit: Stefan Werner* There were 53 passengers on board at the time of the incident. No injuries were reported, and no vehicles were damaged in the incident. Operations Manager Anders Tøsse reported that the ferry struck the seabed while approaching the Halhjem ferry dock. The ferry sustained damage to its thruster but managed to arrive at the dock at its own power. The [Samnoy](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5741310/mmsi:257055860/imo:9825817/vessel:SAMNOY#overview) has since been taken out of service for repairs and is currently moored at Maloy on 12 March. [Samnoy](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5741310/mmsi:257055860/imo:9825817/vessel:SAMNOY#overview) is a 2019-built passenger ship sailing under the flag of Norway. The ship has a length of 134 metres, and 21 metres in width, with a gross tonnage of 7,294.

headline: Update: North Sea collision incident marine insurance payment likely to range between $100 million and $300 million
author: Raghib Raza
