The nature of the accident and the resulting damages, multiple insurance claims from differing parties are expected to be made. Hull and Machinery (H&M) Insurance, which covers damage to the ships, including their hulls, machinery, and equipment, is expected to be significant but still less than claims from liability and environmental cleanups. The combined insurance value of both the vessels is estimated to range between $50 million and $100 million, which includes potential salvage costs. The high cost of environmental cleanup owing to the leaked jet fuel and potential legal liabilities is expected to be the biggest financial contributor to insurance claims. Finally, the Marine Cargo Insurance, which covers the loss of cargo being transported, will also be a significant component of the claims. The jet fuel, which is estimated to be completely lost in the incident, is expected to be claimed for insurance by the owner of the cargo. However, it is important to note that investigations by the US and the Portuguese governments into the incident have not yet been finalized. If malicious actors or sabotage are proven, it can significantly complicate insurance proceedings, with the denial of insurance coverage also becoming a possibility. The total expected losses, including all of these factors, are estimated to range from $100 million to $300 million.

headline: Four missing as massive fire breaks out on tanker engaged in illicit fuel transfer
author: Raghib Raza
content: Four crewmembers of the vessel [Ronggolawe 09](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7899485/mmsi:525501884/imo:0/vessel:RONGGOLAWE_09) are still missing following an explosion and subsequent fire while in the waters near Lamongan, Indonesia, on 13 March. The explosion occurred when the tanker was engaged in an illicit fuel transfer with the vessel [Rosalyn 08](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6578930/mmsi:525700087/imo:0/vessel:ROSALYN_08). ![RONOGGOLAWE 09 caught fire during illicit oil transfer in Indonesian water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RONOGGOLAWE_09_ab87b1595f.png)*Vessel RONGGOLAWE 09, image credit:hubla.dephub.go.id* The [Ronggolawe 09 ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7899485/mmsi:525501884/imo:0/vessel:RONGGOLAWE_09)is reported to have been transferring around 25 tonnes of high-speed diesel fuel to the [Rosalyn 08 ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6578930/mmsi:525700087/imo:0/vessel:ROSALYN_08)at around 5:30 a.m. (WIB). The fuel transfer is reported to have been carried out without official authorization. The explosion occurred at around 6:00 a.m., which led to a fire breaking out on the [Ronggolawe 09](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7899485/mmsi:525501884/imo:0/vessel:RONGGOLAWE_09) and spreading to the [Rosalyn 08](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6578930/mmsi:525700087/imo:0/vessel:ROSALYN_08) as well. All crewmembers from both vessels jumped aboard to avoid the raging fire, while the Ronggolawe 09 drifted away, still engulfed in flames. Firefighting efforts began at around 9:00 a.m., and the fire on the [Rosalyn 08](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6578930/mmsi:525700087/imo:0/vessel:ROSALYN_08) was extinguished by 10:00 a.m. By around 12:30 p.m., the fire on the [Ronggolawe 09](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7899485/mmsi:525501884/imo:0/vessel:RONGGOLAWE_09) was also significantly reduced. An investigation has been opened into the matter, and the search for the missing sailors is still ongoing.

headline: Oil tanker Olavo Bilac collision at Santos port leaves one injured
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Brazilian oil tanker [Olavo Bilac](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5743062/mmsi:710003752/imo:9547697/vessel:OLAVO_BILAC) lost rudder control and collided with three navy patrol boats at [Santos ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/189?name=SANTOS&country=Brazil)on 12 March. Reports indicate that one person suffered minor injuries. ![OLAVO BILAC collided with three navy vessel at Santos port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/OLAVO_BILAC_623e1463b3.png)*Crude oil tanker OLAVO BILAC collided with three navy vessel, image credit:Metrópoles* The incident occurred around 11:20 PM local time when the vessel was manoeuvring at the port of Santos near São Paulo. The [Olavo Bilac ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5743062/mmsi:710003752/imo:9547697/vessel:OLAVO_BILAC)ended up colliding with a navy vessel and pushing it into two others, all three of which were docked in the port at the time. The Navy vessels Gujara, Guapore, and Maracana were reported to be involved in the incident. Online footage shows [Olavo Bilac](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5743062/mmsi:710003752/imo:9547697/vessel:OLAVO_BILAC) running into the pier before colliding with the navy patrol boats. One navy officer is reported to have sustained minor injuries and was released after medical treatment. The tanker was brought back to the Alemoa 1 pier with the assistance of tugboats. Later, on 13 March, the Port Authority inspected the vessel and confirmed a large scrape but no signs of an oil spill or pollution. The [Olavo Bilac](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5743062/mmsi:710003752/imo:9547697/vessel:OLAVO_BILAC) is a 2018-built Brazilian crude oil tanker. It has a length of 249 meters, a beam of 43.9 meters, and a gross tonnage of 61,426. It was reported to carry 50,000 tons of fuel oil during the collision.

headline: Container vessel “MSC Rhiannon” pulled free after running aground in Istanbul
author: Raghib Raza
content: Container vessel [MSC Rhiannon](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5132176/mmsi:636017023/imo:9224051/vessel:MSC_RHIANNON#overview) ran aground in front of Yeşilköy on the Istanbul coast when it was changing anchorage. The vessel was successfully rescued by the Turkish government’s intervention on 15 March. ![MSC Rhiannon ran aground in Turkey.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSC_Rhiannon_8af912fa33.png)*Vessel MSC Rhiannon, image credit: KEGM* The incident occurred in the morning hours when the vessel was headed from Romania to Tekirdağ. According to a statement by the Turkish Ministry of Transport and Infrastructure, the tugboat Kurtarma-9 and the fast rescue boat KEGM-3, along with a diver team, a pilot, and a rescue expert, were dispatched to the distressed vessel’s aid. The [MSC Rhiannon](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5132176/mmsi:636017023/imo:9224051/vessel:MSC_RHIANNON#overview) is a 2012-built container ship that is registered in Liberia. The vessel has a length of 188.1 meters, a width of 30 meters, and a gross tonnage of 23,890.

headline: Tugboat sinks after collision with Containership in the Callao Sea, leaving six injured
author: Raghib Raza
content: A collision between the tugboat[ Westport ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3946086/mmsi:353643000/imo:7810026/vessel:WESTPORT)and the containership [A. Idefix](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:364233/mmsi:256430000/imo:9354662/vessel:A_IDEFIX) on 14th March in the Callao Sea resulted in the sinking of the tugboat. Six crew members have been reported to be injured in the incident. The cause behind the accident is still uncertain and is under investigation. ![A. IDEFIX and a tugboat collided in Callao Sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/A_IDEFIX_96117514f0.png)*Containership A.IDEFIX collided with tugboat in Callao Sea, image credit:panamericana.pe* The incident occurred at 8:30 AM local time when the tugboat collided with the containership. This caused a hole to be punched in the hull of the Westport, and the tugboat listed towards its starboard side. A short while later, it sank stern-first into the water. The incident was reported to the VTS Callao, which arranged for the deployment of a Zodiac boat to the site and the subsequent rescue of the injured individuals. Civil Defence and Disaster Risk Management for the Municipality of Callao responded immediately to the accident and mobilized a response promptly. The injured crew members were transported to a nearby hospital. Containment barriers for the contingency of pollution have been deployed, considering that the tugboat sank completely. Fog prevailing in the area at the time of the incident is suspected of being one possible cause of the collision. Investigations have been launched into the incident, with the National Police and the Navy cooperating.

headline: LNG tanker and Bulk carrier collide in Bay of Gibraltar
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 18th March, the LNG tanker [SM Kestrel](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7879243/mmsi:352002925/imo:9917579/vessel:SM_KESTREL#overview) collided with the anchored bulk carrier[ Diamond Star II ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:688012/mmsi:354570000/imo:9449273/vessel:DIAMOND_STAR_II)in the western anchorage of the Bay of Gibraltar. The incident occurred around 1:00 AM local time when [SM Kestrel](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7879243/mmsi:352002925/imo:9917579/vessel:SM_KESTREL#overview), while maneuvering to depart, came in contact with[ Diamond Star II](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:688012/mmsi:354570000/imo:9449273/vessel:DIAMOND_STAR_II). ![SM KESTREL collided with DIAMOND STAR II off Gibraltar.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SM_KESTREL_6dc24e13cb.png)*LNG tanker SM KESTREL collided with bulk carrier DIAMOND STAR II, image credit:gbc.gi* Both Panama-flagged vessels sustained minor damage and remained anchored. No injuries were reported, and there was no pollution resulting from the collision. Surveyors from the respective Class and Flag authorities are scheduled to assess the vessels at the earliest opportunity. Additionally, Port State Control officials from the Gibraltar Maritime Administration (GMA) will conduct an inspection. [SM Kestrel ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7879243/mmsi:352002925/imo:9917579/vessel:SM_KESTREL#overview)is a Korea-Line-owned LNG Carrier, while [Diamond Star II](linkhttps://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:688012/mmsi:354570000/imo:9449273/vessel:DIAMOND_STAR_II) is a Dubai-controlled bulker. Marine traffic data shows both vessels are currently at Gibraltar West Anchorage.

headline: Minor oil spill in Taiwan’s Keelung port fouls multiple vessels and berths
author: Raghib Raza
content: Around 100 liters of fuel was spilled at the Taiwanese [Keelung port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/191?name=KEELUNG&country=Taiwan) when a bunkering operation went awry on 16th March. Several vessels were contaminated, and cleaning and containment operations are underway. ![Oil spill during bunkering operation from Kanmay Global.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KANMAY_GLOBAL_926660e46d.png)*Vessel KANMAY GLOBAL, image credit: smp* The oil spill occurred at around 5:40 PM local time when the vessel [Kanway Global](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:653390/mmsi:416438000/imo:9167461/vessel:KANWAY_GLOBAL) was being bunkered with fuel, and around 100 liters of fuel leaked out during a connection procedure. The spilled oil contaminated multiple vessels and three pilot boats, which were then cleaned with pressure washers as a temporary solution. Oil containment booms and absorbent materials have been deployed to mitigate pollution and prevent further disruption to the port operations. The vessels [TS Pusan](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6089291/mmsi:538010783/imo:9854844/vessel:TS_PUSAN), [TS Surabaya](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8301305/mmsi:538010946/imo:9955442/vessel:TS_SURABAYA), and [YM Immense](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:753654/mmsi:416492000/imo:9319131/vessel:YM_IMMENSE) were contaminated when their hulls ended up being coated in the floating fuel. In addition to these, three pilot boats’ hulls and mooring lines were also covered in oil. The pilot vessels are to be drydocked for a thorough cleanup, whereas the remaining vessels have postponed their departures.

headline: Engine failure leaves cargo vessel Venture aground near Hamburg
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 18th March, the Antigua Barbuda-flagged cargo vessel [Venture](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:379019/mmsi:305477000/imo:9030503/vessel:VENTURE#overview) experienced engine failure and ran aground in Elbe river near Hamburg. The vessel began to drift before getting stranded in shallow waters. ![Cargo vessel VENTURE ran aground in Germany.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/VENTURE_305f00f9c7.png)*Cargo vessel VENTURE, image credit:mopo.de* Authorities promptly responded and dispatched a tugboat to assist the distressed vessel. The tugboat successfully refloated the vessel and escorted it to the Hamburg Port. There were no reports of injuries or environmental pollution resulting from the incident. [Venture ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:379019/mmsi:305477000/imo:9030503/vessel:VENTURE#overview)is a 1993-built cargo vessel that has a carrying capacity of 2,366 tonnes. The vessel has a length of 74.9 metres and width of 11.4 metres

headline: Container Ship ‘Greta’ towed to safety after engine failure off turkish Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 20th March, a Belize-flagged container ship, [Greta](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:259552/mmsi:312479000/imo:9234422/vessel:GRETA#overview), suffered an engine failure near the southern entrance of the Çanakkale Strait, Turkey. In response, the Çanakkale Ship Traffic Services Center coordinated a successful operation to secure the vessel. ![GRETA suffered engine failure in Turkish water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GRETA_1a8944d1b6.png)*Containeship GRETA, image credit: KEGM* The containership was safely towed to Karanlik Liman by the tugboat Kurtarma-18 under the guidance of a pilot assigned to the operation. No injuries or pollution were reported in the incident. [Greta](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:259552/mmsi:312479000/imo:9234422/vessel:GRETA#overview) is a 2001-built vessel with a carrying capacity of 340 TEU. It is 100.8 metres long and 15.85 metres wide.

headline: Vessel “BGM Oswald Elbe 1” experiences boiler room fire during renovation
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 19th March, a smoldering fire broke out in the boiler room of the German-flagged vessel [BGM Oswald Elbe 1](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:151556/mmsi:218004000/imo:8137548/vessel:BGM_OSWALD_ELBE1). The incident occurred while the vessel was undergoing renovation in the large shipbuilding hall at the Volkswerft maritime industrial and commercial park in Stralsund, Germany. ![Boiler room of BGM OSWALD ELBE 1 caught fire. ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BGM_OSWALD_ELBE_1_5ab7cb3f48.png)*Vessel BGM OSWALD ELBE 1, image credit: Hans-Peter Schroeder* The shipyard's fire department responded swiftly and assisted in evacuating the shipbuilding hall. The fire departments of the Hanseatic City of Stralsund were alerted about the accident. Heavy smoke resulted from the fire in the vessel's boiler room, and a total of 19 firefighters were dispatched to the scene. By the time the emergency team arrived, the fire had already been extinguished by the crew of [BGM Oswald Elbe 1](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:151556/mmsi:218004000/imo:8137548/vessel:BGM_OSWALD_ELBE1). One individual sustained injuries in the incident. Authorities are investigating the cause of the fire and the extent of the damage. There was no risk of nearby buildings or facilities.

headline: Cargo vessel 'Bers' towed to safety after engine failure in Bosphorus
author: Raghib Raza
content: A general cargo vessel, [Bers](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:671382/mmsi:577585000/imo:9044188/vessel:BERS#overview), suffered an engine failure while transiting the Bosphorus near the July 15 Martyrs Bridge in Turkey. The incident occurred on 19th March, prompting a swift response from maritime authorities. ![BERS suffer engine failure in Turkey.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BERS_7fc8a45afd.png)*Vessel BERS, image credit: KEGM* Under the coordination of the Istanbul Vessel Service (VTS) Center, the tugboat Kurtarma 11 was deployed to assist the disabled vessel. A pilot was also dispatched to support the operation. Subsequently, the vessel was towed and safely anchored in Ahırkapı. No pollution and injuries were reported. The [Bers](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:671382/mmsi:577585000/imo:9044188/vessel:BERS#overview) is a 1992-built cargo vessel sailing under the flag of Vanuatu. The vessel was traveling from [Iskenderun](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1686?name=ISKENDERUN&country=Turkey), Turkey, and was scheduled to arrive in [Constanta](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/67?name=CONSTANTA&country=Romania), Romania, by 20th March.

headline: Marshall Islands-flagged bulk carrier stranded in Turkey
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 21st March, the bulk carrier [Xin Hai Tong 37](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713523/mmsi:538004327/imo:9594597/vessel:XIN_HAI_TONG_37) ran aground in the Ahırkapı Anchorage Area, Turkey. In response, Directorate General of Coastal Safety (KEGM) authorities deployed a pilot captain, a salvage specialist, and a diving team to assess the situation. ![XIN HAI TONG 37 ran aground in Turkey.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/XIN_HAI_TONG_37_f1df0456dc.png)*Bulk carrier XIN HAI TONG 37, image credit: KEGM* The KEGM-4 fast boat was dispatched to assist the vessel, while the tugboat Kurtarma-7 was promptly sent to the scene to initiate a salvage operation. Efforts are ongoing to refloat the bulk carrier. No injuries or pollution have been reported in the incident. [Xin Hai Tong 37](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713523/mmsi:538004327/imo:9594597/vessel:XIN_HAI_TONG_37) is a 2012-built bulk carrier sailing under the flag of Marshall Island. The vessel has a carrying capacity of 56,539 tonnes, with a length of 189.9 metres and a width of 32.2 metres.

headline: Flag Risks as a Critical Factor in Maritime Due Diligence and KYC Processes
author: Dimitris Ampatzidis
content: Flag risks are increasingly shaping maritime due diligence, impacting regulatory scrutiny, financial exposure, and operational integrity. The strategic use of high-risk flags in evasive practices, such as flag-hopping and shadow fleet operations, underscores the complexities of compliance in global shipping. Strengthening risk assessment frameworks and integrating systematic flag evaluations are essential for mitigating exposure and ensuring resilience in an evolving regulatory landscape. **Key takeaways** - **High-risk flags pose increasing compliance challenges**: Over 5,000 vessels (14.5% of the global fleet) operate under registries with less than 10% ratification of IMO/ILO conventions, increasing exposure to enforcement actions. - **Sanctioned vessel operations have doubled since early 2023**: Over 600 sanctioned vessels operate under high-risk flags, facilitating the movement of Russian, Iranian, and Venezuelan crude despite restrictions. - **Insurers and financial institutions are tightening policies**: Premiums are rising, detentions are increasing, and financing is being restricted for vessels flagged under jurisdictions with weak compliance records. - **Flag-hopping remains a major enabler of sanctions evasion**: Shadow fleet tankers frequently shift flag registrations to maintain trade flows despite regulatory pressures. **The growing need for flag risks screening** ![Image 13-3-25 at 5.12 PM.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Image_13_3_25_at_5_12_PM_5dbf11afdc.jpg) **Graph 1.** _Countries with weak compliance on IMO and ILO rules - Kpler._ Maritime due diligence frameworks are under increasing strain as **flag state compliance gaps** introduce additional financial and regulatory risk. Vessel registries serve as primary regulatory authorities, yet their **adherence to international safety, environmental, and labour standards remains inconsistent**. A significant proportion of flag states fail to enforce more than 10% of International Maritime Organization (IMO) and International Labor Organization (ILO) regulations, exposing shipowners and charterers to: - Higher risk of sanctions violations - Port State Control (PSC) detentions - Operational disruptions and financial penalties Recent Kpler data analysis highlights critical jurisdictions with compliance gaps, revealing that **14.5% of the global fleet operates under low-ratification flags**. This classification includes nations such as the Marshall Islands, St. Kitts and Nevis, and Palau, where selective ratification creates uncertainty over compliance obligations. _Key Data Point: Afghanistan, Somalia, and South Sudan have not ratified essential IMO frameworks, while Bahrain, Brunei, and Qatar lack adherence to ILO conventions, increasing seafarer risk exposure._ A structured approach to flag risk screening allows stakeholders to quantify non-compliance exposure, integrating these insights into Know Your Customer (KYC) and risk management protocols. Systematic evaluation of flag state governance can mitigate regulatory uncertainty and enhance trading resilience. ![Picture1.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture1_b0b53023da.png) **Graph 2.** _Share of ships registered under flags with weak compliance on IMO and ILO rules - Kpler._ **How flag risks relate to sanctions and the grey/shadow fleet** The [February 2025 surge in sanctions](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/maritime-news/34/risk-and%20compliance/2025/11921/navigating-the-complexities-of-maritime-sanctions-a-february) has exposed the extent to which high-risk flags facilitate evasive shipping practices, with **51 additional vessels blacklisted in a single month**. **Key Trends:** - **Flag-hopping as a primary evasion tool**: Tankers carrying Russian, Iranian, or Venezuelan crude frequently switch flags to obscure ownership structures and evade tracking. - **Rise of alternative registries**: Panama, Barbados, and Curacao continue to attract high-risk fleets. - **STS transfers in high-risk zones**: Weakly regulated flags facilitate ship-to-ship (STS) crude transfers, increasing opacity in global energy flows. The number of sanctioned vessels under the top 10 high-risk flag states has doubled since early 2023, reflecting a shift towards more complex evasion techniques. **Financial and reputational risk** Flag risk exposure directly impacts vessel valuation, operational costs, and market access. Owners operating under low-ratification flags face: - **Tighter underwriting criteria**: Insurers are raising premiums for flagged vessels linked to evasive trade. - **Higher detention risk**: PSC authorities are targeting weak registries with increased enforcement actions. - **Restricted financial access**: Banks are withdrawing financing options from high-risk fleet operators. Recent insurance data suggests that underwriters have increased premiums by 30-40% for vessels flagged under low-ratification jurisdictions. Financial institutions are now integrating flag-based risk scoring models to pre-screen financing applications. **How to integrate flag risk screening** Mitigating exposure to flag risk-driven disruptions requires a proactive compliance framework. Kpler recommends: - Prioritising vessels flagged under high-ratification jurisdictions. - Leveraging real-time tracking to identify high-risk flag-hopping patterns. - Embedding flag risk assessments into sanctions screening protocols to detect evasive shipping tactics. By adopting data-driven flag evaluations, insurers, financiers, and charterers can enhance due diligence and reduce exposure to regulatory and financial penalties. To find out more about Kpler’s Risk & Compliance offering, visit [here](https://www.kpler.com/demos/risk-compliance-demo?utm_source=website&utm_medium=blog&utm_campaign=risk&compliance_commodities_maritime_news_demo_request).

headline: Research vessel runs aground near  Enfola promontory, Italy
author: Raghib Raza
content: A Bahamas-flagged research vessel, [Fugro Mercator](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:206159/mmsi:311000786/imo:9299977/vessel:FUGRO_MERCATOR#overview), ran aground on the reef of the Enfola promontory near Portoferraio, Italy, on 22nd March. The vessel, carrying 11 individuals including crew and technical-scientific personnel of different nationalities was performing seabed monitoring operations. The vessel reportedly approached the coast to seek shelter from adverse weather conditions when it struck a shallow seabed coming close to the rocky cliff in the area. ![FUGRO MERCATOR ran aground off Italian coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FUGRO_MERCATOR_134cffcff6.png)*Research vessel FUGRO MERCATOR, image credit: Guardia Costiera* The vessel sustained damage, leading to water ingress into the hull. The crew initially tried to contain the flooding; however, the water eventually reached and damaged some engine parts, resulting in a complete blackout of onboard equipment. The Livorno Maritime Directorate coordinated a rescue operation and dispatched a patrol boat, CP 805 of the Portoferraio Port Authority, to evacuate all crew members and scientific personnel. All the rescued individuals were reported to be in good health. The transshipment operations were complicated by the blackout, the vessel’s proximity to the rocks, and rough sea conditions. The Italian Coast Guard aerial and maritime monitoring has detected no oil pollution so far. The exact cause of the grounding remains under investigation. The Portoferraio Port Authority has instructed Fugro Mercator’s shipping company to arrange for the vessel’s removal for environmental protection reasons. A specialised company has commenced underwater inspections to develop a recovery plan.

headline: MSC Houston V arrives in Vigo after cargo shift off Portugal
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Portuguese-flagged container ship [MSC Houston V](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:460010/mmsi:255803470/imo:9463281/vessel:MSC_HOUSTON_V#overview) encountered adverse weather conditions off the southern coast of Portugal on 20th March, resulting in a cargo shift. Around 15-20 containers reportedly fell into the sea near Cape St. Vincent, within Portuguese waters. ![MSC HOUSTON V cargo shift in adverse weather off Portugal coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSC_HOUSTON_V_1d27a7c442.png)*Vessel MSC HOUSTON V, image credit:vigoe.es* The large size and deep draft made it difficult for [MSC Houston V](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:460010/mmsi:255803470/imo:9463281/vessel:MSC_HOUSTON_V#overview) to dock at the Portuguese port of Leixoes, prompting its shipping company to seek a berth in Vigo. On 21st March, the vessel arrived at the port of[ Vigo](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/182?name=VIGO&country=Spain), Spain, after requesting permission from the Maritime Authority in Vigo to berth. The cargo shift had prevented it from continuing its voyage. In the image, several containers can be seen hanging over the starboard side near the stern. The President of the Vigo Port Authority, Carlos Botana, confirmed that the containership safely docked at the Guixar Container Terminal in Termavi. Authorities are developing a safety plan to either reposition the displaced containers or remove them as needed. A mobile crane will be used for this operation. The port authority has assured that the cargo on board is not hazardous and does not pose any risk. The duration of MSC Houston V's stay remains uncertain as repositioning the cargo and addressing any damage is expected to be a time-consuming operation. The vessel had departed from [Piraeus](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1?name=PIRAEUS&country=Greece), Greece, and was en route to [Liverpool](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/432?name=LIVERPOOL&country=United-Kingdom), United Kingdom.

headline: Tugboat and Bulk carrier collide off Philippine coast; One crew member missing
author: Raghib Raza
content: A maritime incident occurred on 25th March involving a collision between a Philippine-flagged tugboat, M/TUG Sadong 33, and a Panama-flagged bulk carrier, [Universe Kaisa](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:755431/mmsi:352368000/imo:9283849/vessel:UNIVERSE_KAISA). The incident took place at around 4:20 AM local time in the waters near Maasim, Sarangani Province, Philippines. ![UNIVERSE KAISA and a tug collided off Philippine Coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/UNIVERSE_KAISA_fb2ac77bd8.png)*Image credit: Philippine Coast Guard* Upon receiving the report, the Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) promptly deployed a search and rescue (SAR) team and three floating assets to conduct the rescue operation. According to the initial report, M/TUG Sadong 33 had eight crewmembers onboard at the time of the collision. By 8:00 AM local time, the PCG SAR team successfully rescued six crewmembers, and all were in good health. However, the captain of the tugboat was found dead, while one crew member is still missing. Search operations for the missing crew are ongoing. The PCG is also conducting an oil assessment following the collision. As of now no oil pollution is observed. Authorities have yet to provide any details about the bulk carrier [Universe Kaisa](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:755431/mmsi:352368000/imo:9283849/vessel:UNIVERSE_KAISA).

headline: Six injured in fire aboard refrigerated cargo vessel near South Korean coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire broke out aboard the refrigerated cargo vessel [Crystal Asia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:755566/mmsi:273394490/imo:9053957/vessel:CRYSTAL_ASIA) on 25 March off the South Korean coast near Busan. Although the fire was extinguished, six crewmembers sustained injuries in the fire, two of whom are reported to be in serious medical condition. ![Fire aboard CRYSTAL ASIA near the coast of South Korea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CRYSTAL_ASIA_365fa1a1c5.png)*Vessel CRYSTAL ASIA, image credit: Busan Marine Police* The incident occurred when the vessel was around 8 km off the Port of Gamcheon, Busan. The vessel had a crew of 23, out of which 22 were Russian nationals. Two of the most gravely injured crew members were airlifted via a helicopter and led to a medical facility in Busan. The remaining crewmembers were taken ashore by rescue boats sent by the South Korean authorities. South Korean media has reported that the engine of the vessel is suspected to be the source of the fire. A formal investigation has been opened into the matter by the Coast Guard, which is trying to assess the damage and narrow down the cause of the accident. The [Crystal Asia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:755566/mmsi:273394490/imo:9053957/vessel:CRYSTAL_ASIA) is a Russian-flagged refrigerated cargo vessel that was built in 1993. The vessel has a length of 135.5 meters, a beam of 20.20 meters, and a gross tonnage of 7,534.

headline: Gas tanker 'NP Bangpakong' runs aground on the coast of Koh Larn, Thailand
author: Raghib Raza
content: The gas tanker [NP Bangpakong](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:733681/mmsi:567001650/imo:9020455/vessel:NP_BANGPAKONG) ran aground on the coast of Koh Larn in Thailand early in the morning on 25th March. ![ NP BANGPAKONG](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NP_BANGPAKONG_3341812085.png)*Vessel NP BANGPAKONG, image credit:nationthailand.com* The incident occurred when the vessel was headed from Bang Pakong District, Chachoengsao Province, to Map Ta Phut Port, Rayong Province. The captain of the vessel has defended himself, stating that the accident occurred when they had to steer the ship to avoid collision with a fishing vessel. The local authorities from Koh Larn promptly arrived on the scene, and it was determined that there were no leaks of LPG or marine fuel from the grounded vessel. The owners of the vessel have arranged for the tugboat Map Ta Phut to pull the vessel free from the rocky outcrop upon which it is lodged. Engineers and technicians have also been sent to the scene to more accurately assess the vessel’s condition. An investigation has been launched into the matter, and the locals have been assured that the grounded LPG tanker poses no risk.

headline: Update: Tugboat and Bulk carrier collide off Philippine coast; Two dead, Six rescued
author: Raghib Raza
content: A maritime incident occurred on 25th March involving a collision between a Philippine-flagged tugboat, M/TUG Sadong 33, and a Panama-flagged bulk carrier, [Universe Kaisa](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:755431/mmsi:352368000/imo:9283849/vessel:UNIVERSE_KAISA). The incident took place at around 4:20 AM local time in the waters near Maasim, Sarangani Province, Philippines. ![UNIVERSE KAISA and a tug collided off Philippine Coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/UNIVERSE_KAISA_fb2ac77bd8.png)*Image credit: Philippine Coast Guard* Upon receiving the report, the Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) promptly deployed a search and rescue (SAR) team and three floating assets to conduct the rescue operation. According to the initial report, M/TUG Sadong 33 had eight crewmembers onboard at the time of the collision. By 8:00 AM local time, the PCG SAR team successfully rescued six crewmembers, and all were in good health. According to the latest update, the captain and one crewmember of the tugboat were found dead. The PCG conducted an oil assessment following the collision but oil spill booms were deployed as a precaution. PCG Commandant ordered a Maritime Casualty Investigation and legal action against MV Universe Kiza’s master and crew. The bulk carrier remains anchored at General Santos City to cooperate in the investigation.

headline: Six dead and nine injured in tourist submarine accident in the Red Sea off  Egypt
author: Raghib Raza
content: Six people lost their lives, and nine were injured in a tragic accident involving a tourist submarine “Sindbad,” sinking off the coast of Hurghada, Egypt, on 27th March. The submarine, operated by a company called Sindbad Submarines, had operated in the region for years, and the cause of the accident is yet unknown. ![SINDBAD submarine sank in off Egyptian coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SINDBAD_57ee264ce2.png)*SINDBAD, image credit:Sindbad Marine* The incident is reported to have occurred at around 10:00 AM local time, around 1 km from the shore. The submarine is reported to have been carrying more than 40 passengers, and according to the Russian Embassy in Egypt, all passengers aboard the submarine were Russian nationals. Following the accident, emergency services responded quickly and managed to rescue 29 passengers from the still submerged craft. Latest reports indicate a count of 9 individuals that have been injured, and four reported to be in a grave medical condition and were promptly transported to hospitals. The company Sindbad Submarines has attracted tourists from all over the world for years, offering underwater excursions and a chance to view coral reefs up close. The submarines operated by this company allow tourists to travel up to a depth of 25 meters. Each of these submarines has 44 passenger seats and two pilot seats with a sizable window accompanying each seat. Weather observations from the region indicate that the seas were calm during the time of the incident. An investigation has been launched to gather information on the cause of the accident.

headline: Bulk carrier collides with landing craft off Philippines Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: The bulk carrier [Sangko Uno 66](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7052244/mmsi:548579900/imo:9964534/vessel:ZHU_HAI_STAR) collided with the landing craft [LCT Nicia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:890643/mmsi:-8946016/imo:8946016/vessel:NICIA) on 26th March off the coast of the Philippines near Cavite. ![NICIA collided with bulk carrier in Phillipines](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NICIA_45bcebe662.png)*Vessel NICIA, image credit: Mike Baylon* The incident occurred when the bulk carrier [Sangko Uno 66](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7052244/mmsi:548579900/imo:9964534/vessel:ZHU_HAI_STAR), headed towards Nebu, collided with the landing craft[ LCT Nicia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:890643/mmsi:-8946016/imo:8946016/vessel:NICIA), which was on its way to the Pasay Reclamation project in the Zambales province. The Philippine Coast Guard promptly arrived on the scene and ascertained that both the vessels had only sustained minor damage. No reports of pollution or any injuries aboard either vessel were released. Both the vessels have been directed to head to Manila, where a more thorough assessment and an investigation are to be carried out by the Philippine Coast Guard’s Marine Casualty Investigation.

headline: German Inland gas tanker and Liberian container ship collide near Terneuzen
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 28th March, a collision occurred on the Western Scheldt near Terneuzen, Netherlands. At approximately 2:30 am local time, the German-flagged Inland gas tanker [Gas 85](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3889326/mmsi:211515210/imo:0/vessel:GAS_85) collided with the Liberia-flagged container ship [MSC Mariella](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7769894/mmsi:636022920/imo:9934747/vessel:MSC_MARIELLA). ![GAS 85 involved in a collision with MSC MARIELLA.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GAS_85_a56613937f.png)*Inland Gas Tanker GAS 85, image credit: Lothar Odenthal* Emergency services were immediately alerted, and Rijkswaterstaat personnel boarded the gas tanker, which was moored near the West Buitenhaven, to conduct an inspection that lasted over an hour. The gas tanker sustained minor damage to the railing along its deck, but no structural issues were reported. Following inspections, both ships were cleared and released. No injuries or environmental pollution were reported.

headline: Greenpeace conducts protests trying to block LNG carriers from docking
author: Raghib Raza
content: The environmental activist organization Greenpeace conducted two protests, trying to hinder two LNG carriers from the US and Russia, respectively. The environmental group conducted the protests to urge the EU to expedite their phasing out of Russian fuels, as well as to denounce fossil fuels altogether. ![Greenpeace activist protest blocking LNG Carriers.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GREENPEACE_acc2f44c4d.png)*Image credit: GREENPEACE* One of the protests was conducted on 27th March by eight Greenpeace volunteers who temporarily blocked the incoming LNG carrier, [Marvel Swallow](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8951846/mmsi:538011088/imo:9963449/vessel:MARVEL_SWALLOW), as it was headed to Zebruuge to dock. The vessel was arriving from Louisiana, US, with a shipment of LNG. The group launched out of their mothership, the Arctic Sunrise, and encircled the [Marvel Swallow](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8951846/mmsi:538011088/imo:9963449/vessel:MARVEL_SWALLOW), displaying banners having the likenesses of Vladimir Putin and Donald Trump in addition to slogans such as “Their gas your cash.” Greenpeace claimed that they were conducting the protest to remind the EU that their reliance on fossil fuels was fostering geopolitical instability and hurting households due to skyrocketing fuel prices. Although the protestors hindered the vessel, the [Marvel Swallow](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8951846/mmsi:538011088/imo:9963449/vessel:MARVEL_SWALLOW) managed to dock in Zeebrugge later that same day. An earlier protest on 26th March was carried out against the Cyprus-flagged carrier [Fedor Litke](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5062832/mmsi:212660000/imo:9768370/vessel:FEDOR_LITKE) as it was headed to Sabetta in Russia. The goal behind these protests, according to Greenpeace, was largely the same, namely, trying to stop fuel carriers from transferring fuel to the EU. Greenpeace is urging the EU to completely phase out fossil gas by the year 2035.

headline: Engine failure leaves cargo ship adrift off Norway, resumes voyage after rescue
author: Raghib Raza
content: A cargo vessel experienced an engine breakdown and began drifting towards land near Krossfjord, Norway on 28th March. The Norwegian Coastal Administration’s Nais Service identified the vessel, as [Wilson Rotterdam](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4948498/mmsi:314036000/imo:9557381/vessel:WILSON_ROTTERDAM), which was transporting dry cargo, was en route from [Porsgrunn](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1651?name=PORSGRUNN&country=Norway), Norway, to [Esbjerg](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/377?name=ESBJERG&country=Denmark), Denmark. ![WILSON ROTTERDAM drifted after engine breakdown.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/WILSON_ROTTERDAM_5f2794a38c.png)*Vessel WILSON ROTTERDAM, image credit: Sondre M Pettersen* The Main Rescue Center (HRS) launched a rescue operation around 2:00 PM local time and dispatched helicopters and boats to the scene to ensure the safety of the cardo vessel and its crew. At around 2:40 PM local time, HRS confirmed that the situation was under control, and the vessel had anchored in a shallow water area while the crew members investigated the issue. An ambulance and fire boat were also deployed, though no injuries or overboard incidents were reported. At 4:15 PM local time, [Wilson Rotterdam](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4948498/mmsi:314036000/imo:9557381/vessel:WILSON_ROTTERDAM) resumed its journey under its own power, prompting HRS to conclude its rescue operation.

headline: Crew rescued as cargo ship catches fire near the Philippines
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) reported a fire aboard the cargo vessel MV Castphill XV in the early morning of 30th March. The fire raged while the vessel was sailing in waters northwest of Limbones Island, Nasugbu, Batangas, Philippines. ![Fire aboard the vessel CASTPHILL XV in Philippine water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CASTPHILL_XV_8cce988635.png)*Cargo vessel CASTPHILL XV, image credit: Philippine Coast Guard* At approximately 4:27 AM local time, the PCG patrol vessel BRP Boracay rescued seven crew members, including the captain, who sustained minor injuries in the fire. Later, five more crew members were rescued by Coast Guard Sub-Station (CGSS) Maragondon. Upon arrival at Pier 15, South Harbor, Manila, BRP Boracay handed over the rescued crewmembers to the Coast Guard Medical Dispensary for further evaluation. The PCG has launched an investigation to determine the cause of the fire aboard the vessel. DOTr Secretary Vince Dizon reiterated his commitment to maritime safety, while the PCG reaffirmed its dedication to swift emergency response at sea. This is developing news; updates will follow as more information becomes available.

headline: Cargo vessel blocks waterway after engine failure in the Kiel Canal
author: Raghib Raza
content: The cargo vessel [Frederick ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:300801/mmsi:304374000/imo:9328637/vessel:FREDERIK)blocked a waterway in the Kiel Canal following an engine failure on 27th March. Following days of attempts to repair the vessel, it has been towed to Kiel’s East Shore for a more thorough investigation. ![FREDERIK suffer engine failure.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FREDERIK_7a950e66f5.png)*Vessel FREDERIK, image credit: Nils Junge* The engine failure of the [Frederick](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:300801/mmsi:304374000/imo:9328637/vessel:FREDERIK) happened around 10:30 PM local time on the vessel’s transit from Hamburg to Klaipeda via the Kiel Canal. A problem with the ship’s electronics is being cited as the reason for the engine failure. Following the failure, the vessel veered off course and ended up blocking a waterway near the switch Fischerhütte. The impediment caused the traffic in the canal to be blocked for hours. Two tugboats, the Fairplay-54 and the Fairplay-57, were deployed from Brunsbuttel to assist the distressed vessel. Despite a couple of days of efforts, the vessel could not be repaired, and on 29th March, the vessel was towed to Kiel’s East Shore by the tugboats Stein and OSK Rendsburg. The vessel is to undergo a more thorough investigation for repairs, failing which, its cargo might be transferred to another ship.

headline: Fire engulfs yacht “Ramonda”, vessel sinks off Montenegro Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Yacht [Ramonda](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7934997/mmsi:376357000/imo:0/vessel:RAMONDA) sank after being ravaged by a fire on 27th March in Portonovi, Montenegro. No injuries have been reported thus far and a contingency of pollution from the vessel has been accounted for by placing dams around the site. ![Yacht RAMONDA engulf in fire and sank off Montenegro coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RAMONDA_89e25cad00.png)*Yacht RAMONDA, image credit:boatinternational.com* The incident occurred at around 6:00 PM local time when the vessel was docked at the Porto Novi yacht marina. The Herceg Novi Protection and Rescue Service promptly arrived on the scene with two fire trucks and realized that the fire had spread to the interior of the vessel. After attempts to contain the fire failed, at 7:50 PM local time, the vessel was transported out of the marina so as to combat the fire in the sea. The vessel was left to burn on the seas and sink after it was decided that the damage from the fire had already been so extensive that the vessel could no longer be salvaged. The vessel was also carrying around 8000 litres of fuel and dams have been installed surrounding the site so as to prevent any pollution. An investigation has been opened into the matter, and the cause of the fire is yet unknown.

headline: Speedboat catches fire off Thailand’s coast, six Injured
author: Raghib Raza
content: A speedboat, Tana Marine 555, caught fire following an explosion near Phuket, Thailand. The incident occurred on 1st April and resulted in six injuries, with no fatality reported. ![Tana Marine 555 caught fire off thailand coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Tana_Marine_555_4a2ce9bb3d.png)*Speedboat Tana Marine 555, image credit:laotiantimes.com* According to the Director of the Phuket Marine Office, authorities received a distress report at 9:20 AM local time, prompting an immediate deployment of a rescue team to the site. The Tana Marine 555, with 36 tourists, mostly from Kazakhstan and Russia, had departed from Chalong Pier for Mai Thon Island. Upon arrival, the tourists disembarked for swimming while the captain of the speedboat detected an engine problem. The captain contacted the speedboat owner and requested a replacement boat to ensure the tourist's safety. Before an alternate boat could arrive, a fire broke aboard the speedboat, leading to a powerful explosion just 50 meters from the shore. The fire rapidly spread across the vessel, causing burns and shrapnel injuries to three crew members, including the captain, engine mechanic, and guide. The tourists, who were still in the water, scrambled to safety. Three of the tourists suffered minor injuries while a passing vessel rescued them from the sea. Two of the rescued tourists sustained burns and were transported to Phuket Provincial Administrative Organisation Hospital.

headline: Inland cruise ship “De Zonnebloem” and freighter collided near Germany
author: Raghib Raza
content: An inland cruise ship, [De Zonnebloem](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:236394/mmsi:244650986/imo:8407644/vessel:DE_ZONNEBLOEM#overview), collided with motor freighter [Servia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6390394/mmsi:244185189/imo:0/vessel:SERVIA#overview) on the Rhine River near Wesel, Germany. Fortunately, no injuries were reported. ![De Zonnebloem collided with freighter in German water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/De_Zonnebloem_9f26aff2c3.png)*Vessel DE ZONNEBLOEM, image credit:presseportal.de* The incident occurred on 29th March at around 3:00 AM local time, causing significant damage to [De Zonnebloem](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:236394/mmsi:244650986/imo:8407644/vessel:DE_ZONNEBLOEM#overview) while it was en route from Düsseldorf, Germany, to Arnhem, Netherlands. The inland cruise ship sustained a 20-square-metre hole in the bow above the waterline. [De Zonnebloem](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:236394/mmsi:244650986/imo:8407644/vessel:DE_ZONNEBLOEM#overview), designed to accommodate passengers with physical disabilities, was carrying 69 passengers, 65 volunteers, and 15 crew members at the time of the incident. The German water police directed the ship to the port of Wesel, where passengers disembarked. Arrangements were made for family members and specialized transport services to assist passengers to return to the Netherlands. The [Servia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6390394/mmsi:244185189/imo:0/vessel:SERVIA#overview) also suffered damage to its port-side bow above the waterline. Authorities detained [Servia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6390394/mmsi:244185189/imo:0/vessel:SERVIA#overview) and conducted an alcohol test on its master. Criminal proceedings have been launched, and an investigation is ongoing. [De Zonnebloem](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:236394/mmsi:244650986/imo:8407644/vessel:DE_ZONNEBLOEM#overview) is expected to remain out of service for several months for repairs.

headline: Fatal cargo ship collision off China’s Ningbo Coast: One Dead, Three Injured
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Ningbo Maritime Safety Administration reported a collision between two Chinese-flagged cargo vessels near Yangxiaomao Island, Ningbo, China. The incident resulted in one fatality and three injuries. ![Jianghai Zhida 66 collided with Ningyuan Beilun](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Jianghai_Zhida_66_0dac0a9d32.png)*Vessel JIANGHAI ZHIDA 66, image credit:eworldship.com* The incident occurred on 29th March, approximately at 2:50 AM local time, when the cargo vessel [Ningyuan Beilun](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9364841/mmsi:413609370/imo:0/vessel:NING_YUAN_BEI_LUN) collided with [Jianghai Zhida 66](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7772971/mmsi:413530020/imo:0/vessel:JIANG_HAI_ZHI_DA_66). The impact caused [Jinaghai Zhida 66](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7772971/mmsi:413530020/imo:0/vessel:JIANG_HAI_ZHI_DA_66) to sink with its 13 crew members on board. By 6:50 AM local time all the crew members who fell into the water were rescued. However, one individual was found deceased, while three others were injured and taken to hospital for treatment. The remaining nine crew members were reported safe. [Ningyuan Beilun](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9364841/mmsi:413609370/imo:0/vessel:NING_YUAN_BEI_LUN) was reportedly on a voyage from Ningbo to Zhapu, China, carrying up to 934 TEUs of containerized cargo. The vessel did not sustain any damage in the collision and is currently anchored at Zhoushan Anchorage. The cause of the collision is yet to be determined by the authorities.

headline: Stena Line Designs New Efficient Vessel to Achieve Net Zero Ambitions
author: Raghib Raza
content: Swedish shipping company Stena Line unveiled its concept vessel, the Stena Futuro. The concept vessel has a myriad of eco-friendly features and has been designed with efficiency in mind to contribute to the fulfillment of Stena Line’s aggressive goal of cutting 30% of its CO₂ emissions by 2030. ![STENA FUTURO](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/STENA_FUTURO_bb7ba7f293.png)*Vessel STENA EUTURO, image credit: Stena Line* The Stena Futuro concept details a vessel that is a 240-meter-long Ro-Ro vessel that would be primarily intended for carrying semi-trailers and cars. The vessel’s superstructure and its hull have been designed from the ground up to maximize efficiency and carrying capacity. The weight of the hull has been kept low while increasing the hydrodynamics and aerodynamics of the structure. In addition to the Stena Futuro’s efficient fundamental design, the vessel will also be equipped with technologies to cut back on its emissions. The vessel will feature hybrid propulsion with highly fuel-efficient engines. The vessel will also have batteries connected with solar panels for emission-free operation, such as when the vessel is at ports. A waste heat recovery system will recirculate the residual heat from the engines aboard the vessel for heating needs as well as for power generation. An air lubrication system that uses air bubbles beneath the waterline to reduce the vessel’s friction in water is also present in the vessel to further optimize its performance. Keeping in line with the deadline, the 40-meter-tall retractable wing sails that are to be equipped on the Stena Futuro have already passed the necessary simulations and tests and are projected to enhance the fuel savings of the vessel by 15%. The final design is expected to start production in the coming years, and the new breed of vessels is expected to play a large part in Stena Line’s emission reduction commitments.

headline: U.S. ‘Tariffs’ of Chinese Shipping Threaten 50% of the Vessels In Some Shipping Sectors
author: Alex Stuart-Grumbar
content:
The U.S. is contemplating one of the most significant shifts in maritime trade policy in recent memory. A proposed executive order—currently being developed by the Trump administration and coordinated through the National Security Council—seeks public comment on introducing new port fees of up to $1.5 million per call on vessels connected to China, whether by ownership, flag, or place of construction. These measures are part of a broader strategy to reduce reliance on Chinese maritime infrastructure. If implemented, the fees could increase port call costs for affected vessels by as much as 3,000%, potentially reshaping global shipping dynamics.

Given the structure of the global fleet, the implications are considerable. MarineTraffic data shows that nearly 28% of all commercial vessels worldwide are linked to China in one or more ways. The exposure differs by sector, with MarineTraffic data showing that one in two vessels in some categories will be affected. This reflects China’s longstanding role as a central player in global shipbuilding and maritime logistics—a position built over decades of investment and industrial consolidation. The proposed policy introduces a new variable into global shipping calculations, with potential impacts across key cargo segments and trading routes.

![image5.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image5_8e190d6321.png) _Source: MarineTraffic_ **Measuring Exposure: China's Maritime Reach**

China’s role in global shipping is deeply embedded and highly visible at U.S. ports. MarineTraffic data shows that since January 2024, approximately one in three vessels calling US ports were built in China. That’s a substantial presence in its own right—yet it represents only one part of the broader picture.

When taking into account all vessels linked to China—whether through construction, ownership, or flag (China or Hong Kong) —the exposure rises significantly. In the dry bulk segment, **49% of vessels calling at U.S. ports in 2024 have some form of Chinese link**. For container ships, the figure is 38%; for tankers, 30%. Even among gas carriers and Ro-Ro vessels, exposure stands at 18% and 15%, respectively.

![image3.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image3_b6e10d446d.png) _Source: MarineTraffic_

This reflects China’s dominance in global shipbuilding. Chinese yards account for roughly 50% of global output, and secured over 70% of new commercial ship orders in 2024. Nearly 37% of the global dry bulk fleet and 24% of container ships were built in China. The country’s competitive advantage—driven by scale, cost-efficient production, and control over steel supply—has allowed it to outpace rivals in South Korea and Japan.

This position is no accident. China’s dominance in shipbuilding has been driven by long-term state support, a vast and cost-efficient labour force, and favourable access to domestic steel—often the single largest input cost in ship construction. Yards benefit not only from cheap raw materials but also from integrated supply chains and financing from state-backed lenders, allowing them to offer attractive pricing and terms. Unlike their counterparts in Korea and Japan, Chinese builders have also been more flexible in accommodating bespoke designs, further widening their appeal. Combined with improving quality standards and accelerated delivery timelines, China has positioned itself not just as a shipbuilder, but as the default production base for much of the global fleet.

Should the proposed $1.5 million per-call fee on Chinese-linked vessels be implemented, the impact would be immediate. While future orders may shift to non-Chinese yards, capacity constraints—particularly in the U.S., where commercial shipbuilding is limited—mean that any realignment will be slow and costly. The U.S. has not built an LNG carrier in over four decades and currently produces only a small number of merchant ships each year.

The data makes clear: Chinese-linked vessels are not a marginal presence in U.S. trade—they are a structural feature. Replacing them will take far more than policy—it will require time, global coordination, and substantial industrial investment.

**Dry Bulk: Heavy Exposure to U.S. Fees**

Dry bulk is the most exposed vessel segment to the proposed U.S. port fees targeting Chinese-linked ships. MarineTraffic data shows that 48.7% of the global dry bulk fleet is connected to China through construction, ownership, or flag—the highest level of exposure across all vessel types. This includes standard bulk carriers as well as general cargo vessels and multipurpose (MPP) ships. Notably, the more specialised the dry bulk vessel, the more likely it is to be linked to China, further increasing the risk of disruption in niche shipping segments.

![image6.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image6_7fc33bde31.png) _Source: MarineTraffic_ Since January 2024, more than 8,000 dry bulk carriers with ties to China have called at U.S. ports. Of these, 37.4% were built in Chinese shipyards, 4.75% are owned—at any level—by Chinese entities, and 5.65% sail under a Chinese flag. This deep integration underscores the vulnerability of dry bulk trade flows, which support critical sectors of U.S. industry, from agriculture and energy to construction and manufacturing.

According to Kpler cargo data, the United States exported over 300 million tonnes of dry bulk cargo in 2024, accounting for roughly 6% of global dry bulk flows. While this may seem modest at first glance, it represents a significant share for a single country—highlighting the U.S.'s pivotal role in global commodity supply chains. These exports include vital cargoes such as soybeans, coal, corn, and petcoke. On the import side, the U.S. received around 125 million tonnes of dry bulk goods, with cement, steel, and fertilisers making up the lion’s share. Any disruption to the availability or routing of dry bulk vessels—especially at the scale implied by the proposed port fees—could trigger cascading effects across global supply chains and industrial operations.

The financial impact of these fees is staggering. With the proposed $1.5 million surcharge per port call, voyage costs could rise by as much as 161%—a significant increase that would directly raise freight rates for critical trade routes. For example, coal shipments from the U.S. Gulf to Europe could see voyage costs rise from $12.40 to $32.40 per tonne—a 161% increase. Grain exports from Houston to Rotterdam would jump from $16.15 to $39.23 per tonne, a 143% increase. Petcoke cargoes to Turkey would climb from $23.40 to $53.40 per tonne, up 128%.

    Even under a lower $500,000 fee scenario, the cost implications remain significant: coal shipments to the ARA region would increase by 54%, grain to Rotterdam by 48%, and petcoke to Turkey by 43%. These are not marginal changes—they represent structural cost increases across key routes that underpin U.S. exports.

These cost hikes would make U.S. exports far less competitive on the global market and drive up the price of dry bulk imports that support domestic industries. U.S. manufacturers relying on imported steel, cement, and fertilisers would face higher input costs, with these expenses inevitably passed on to the consumer. In essence, the proposed fees risk acting as a self-imposed tax on both U.S. exporters and industrial buyers.

The ripple effects are already emerging. There are reports that vessel owners are refusing to offer ships for future U.S. coal shipments, citing regulatory uncertainty and cost risk. The agricultural sector alone could face up to over a billion dollars in additional annual freight costs—threatening U.S. competitiveness in an already tight and price-sensitive global market.

**Container Shipping: Navigating Potential Disruption**

In the container sector, the picture is more nuanced. MarineTraffic data shows that 38% of container ships globally are linked to China—whether through construction, ownership, or flag. Of this, 24% are Chinese-built, 18% are Chinese-owned, and nearly 14% sail under the Chinese flag.

While only 22% of container ships calling at U.S. ports are Chinese-built, over 11% fly Chinese or Hong Kong flags—more than any other segment. This suggests that reflagging may be a quick fix for some operators. But even so, China’s presence in newbuild deliveries is only growing. Globally, over 70% of container ship orders in 2024 went to Chinese yards.

The implications for U.S. importers are considerable. Any disruption in Asia–U.S. West Coast traffic could spill over into inventories, port congestion, and freight costs, just as supply chains were beginning to stabilise post-COVID.

**Tankers: A Third of U.S.-Calling Vessels Linked to China**

The tanker segment shows substantial exposure to China across the global fleet. MarineTraffic data indicates that 30.1% of tankers worldwide are linked to China—through construction (21.4%), ownership (14.6%), or flag (7.9%).

These vessels are the backbone of international energy flows, moving crude oil, refined products, and chemicals across long-haul corridors between the U.S., Asia, Europe, and Latin America. China-linked tankers are deeply embedded in these routes, and any disruption to their operations—whether through punitive port fees or regulatory restrictions—would strain the availability of compliant vessels.

The resulting costs go beyond the fee itself. With fewer eligible tankers in the mix, scheduling challenges increase, trade patterns become less efficient, and charterers may need to reroute or delay cargoes. For refiners, traders, and shippers, this means higher freight rates, longer lead times, and reduced flexibility.

Replacing Chinese-linked capacity will take years. Redirecting orders to Korean or Japanese yards, or reshuffling ownership structures, is not a quick fix. In the near term, the proposed U.S. measures introduce not only financial penalties but operational uncertainty. The impact will ripple far beyond shipping desks, affecting fuel costs, delivery timelines, and trade competitiveness worldwide.

**Gas Carriers: Strategically Vulnerable**

Gas carriers—including both LNG and LPG vessels—may have lower direct exposure to China compared to sectors like dry bulk or containers, but their strategic significance is notably higher. MarineTraffic data indicates substantial Chinese involvement in global gas carrier operations: 16.5% of LNG carriers and 19.0% of LPG carriers worldwide have connections to China. Specifically, among LNG carriers, 7.1% are Chinese-built, 13.9% are Chinese-owned, and 4.7% sail under the Chinese flag. For LPG carriers, these figures are slightly different, with 10.5% built in China, 10.5% Chinese-owned, and 3.7% Chinese-flagged.

Energy industry experts caution that imposing restrictions on Chinese-linked gas carriers could disrupt crucial supply routes connecting Asia, Europe, and Latin America. If such measures are strictly enforced, the global market could shift in favour of competitors like Qatar and Australia, nations already benefiting from significant scale advantages in LNG shipping.

**Vehicle Carriers: A Rare Exception** Ro-Ro vessels, which carry vehicles and rolling equipment, are the least exposed segment. Just 13% are Chinese-built and virtually none are flagged or owned in China. These ships may avoid the brunt of new maritime rules, though they could still be affected indirectly by congestion, fleet shortages, or cascading effects from other segments.

That said, the sector is not immune to broader trade frictions. The Trump administration has also proposed new tariffs on Chinese-made vehicles, meaning auto shipping could be hit on multiple fronts. Even if Ro-Ro vessels themselves escape direct penalties, the cargo they carry may soon become entangled in the same geopolitical crossfire.

Looking ahead, the exposure of the vehicle carrier sector is set to rise sharply. China has secured over 80% of the global newbuilding orderbook for Ro-Ro carriers. This orderbook represents just under a third of the existing Ro-Ro fleet, suggesting that China is on course to dominate future capacity in this sector. If port fees are applied to new vessels based on build location, automakers and logistics providers could face significantly higher shipping costs as these ships enter service over the coming years.

The proposed restrictions represent one of the most significant interventions in maritime trade policy in recent decades. As highlighted in this report, MarineTraffic data shows that no segment is entirely insulated. Even sectors like Ro-Ro, which are less exposed, could face ripple effects through vessel availability, pricing pressure, or retaliatory tariffs.

While the policy may succeed in discouraging future procurement from Chinese yards, the reality remains that U.S. shipyards are currently unable to meet global demand, with key capabilities—such as LNG carrier construction—unavailable domestically. In the near term, shipyards in Korea and Japan, already competitively positioned, are more likely to benefit. As the global shipping landscape undergoes this imminent shift, stakeholders must prepare for the far-reaching ramifications of these proposed port fees. headline: Nine Injured as Passenger Ship Collides with Inland vessel in Poland
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 31st March, a collision occurred in the Oder Lagoon near Chełminek Island, Poland, involving a passenger ship Junker Jörg and Inland motor tanker [Argonaut](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5556341/mmsi:205527390/imo:0/vessel:ARGONAUT). ![ARGONAUT collided with passenger ship in Poland.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ARGONAUT_ecfbb2a2c0.png)*Inland vessel ARGONAUT,image credit:rmf24.pl* As a result of the collision, Junker Jörg sustained major bow damage above the waterline, while [Argonaut](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5556341/mmsi:205527390/imo:0/vessel:ARGONAUT) suffered minor damage to its bow. However, no pollution or water ingress was reported aboard either vessel. It was reported that nine out of 97 passengers aboard Junker Jörg were injured, with one individual suffered head injuries and was transported to the hospital for treatment. Following the collision, both vessels continued their journey and docked at [Szczecin](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/396?name=SZCZECIN&country=Poland), Poland. Authorities have launched an investigation to determine the cause of the collision. Alcohol tests were conducted on both crews, but the results were negative. Junker Jörg is scheduled for repairs before resuming operations.

headline: Two Netherlands-Flagged Inland Vessels Collide Near Kreekrak Locks
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 2nd April, a collision occurred between two Netherlands-flagged Inland vessels at the Kreekrak Locks in Zeeland, near the border of the Netherlands and Belgium. At around 2:45 PM local time, the Inland tanker [Nicky](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9007573/mmsi:244690365/imo:9496484/vessel:NICKY) collided with Inland freighter [Volturno](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9043191/mmsi:244660954/imo:0/vessel:VOLTURNO). ![NICKY collided with inland freighter in Zeeland.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NICKY_369a046b93.png)*Inland vessel NICKY, image credit:flows.be* During the collision, Volturno’s bow struck the [Nicky](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9007573/mmsi:244690365/imo:9496484/vessel:NICKY) amidship, causing a breach in the Nicky’s port-side hull above the waterline. [Volturno](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9043191/mmsi:244660954/imo:0/vessel:VOLTURNO) also sustained damage to its bow. No pollution or injuries have been reported as a result of the accident. Authorities have launched an investigation to determine the cause of the collision. Following the collision, the [Nicky](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9007573/mmsi:244690365/imo:9496484/vessel:NICKY) remained moored near the locks while the [Volturno](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9043191/mmsi:244660954/imo:0/vessel:VOLTURNO) continued its journey to Antwerp, where it berthed.

headline: Cleanup Efforts Underway After Oil spill at the Langsat Terminal in Malaysia
author: Raghib Raza
content: An oil spill was confirmed by the Johor Port Authority after an oil patch was spotted near the Eastern Johor strait off the coast of Pulau Ubin in Malaysia on 3rd April. The Johor Port Authority has informed the Maritime and Ports Authority of Singapore (MPA) that the source of the leak has been stopped, and cleanup efforts are already underway. ![Oil spill in Langsat Terminal in Malaysia](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Oil_spill_in_Langsat_Terminal_7242b8f878.png)*Oil spill in Langsat Terminal, image credit: MPA* After the MPA was notified of the possibility of an oil spill, three patrol craft, along with an oil spill response vessel, were deployed to the area. The vessels confirmed the oil spill and started with mitigation efforts on the northeastern coast of Pulau Ubin and along the Changi beach. The National Environment Agency (NEA) has posted a warning against swimming and contact with water at the Changi Beach and the Pasir Ris Beach till further notice. Drones and satellite imagery are being deployed, but fortunately no further oil patches have been spotted thus far. As a precautionary measure, booms are to be deployed near the Chek Jawa wetlands to protect the sensitive biodiverse areas. The Marine Oil Sweeper, an oil recovery system, has been placed on standby if further oil patches are detected.

headline: E&S Tankers Perform their First Bio-LNG Bunkering on the John T. Essberger
author: Raghib Raza
content: E&S Tankers, the joint venture between Essburger Tankers and Stolt Tankers, achieved their first bio-LNG bunkering at the Finnish Hamina LNG Terminal. The bunkering was performed on the chemical tanker [John T. Essberger](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8007580/mmsi:255891000/imo:9939797/vessel:JOHN_T_ESSBERGER). ![JOHN T.ESSBERGER](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/JOHN_T_ESSBERGER_97a065cf57.png)*Vessel JOHN T.ESSBERGER, image credit: T&S Tankers* The [John T. Essberger](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8007580/mmsi:255891000/imo:9939797/vessel:JOHN_T_ESSBERGER) is a 6,600 dwt stainless steel parcel chemical tanker that has dual fuel propulsion and was built at the China Merchants Jinling shipyard in 2023. The Portuguese-flagged vessel has a length of 119.9 meters and a width of 18.1 meters. It also features a Finnish/Swedish 1A Ice Class certification. The [John T. Essberger](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8007580/mmsi:255891000/imo:9939797/vessel:JOHN_T_ESSBERGER) and its class of vessels feature optimized hull design and manage to provide an increased energy efficiency of more than 30%. The vessels are also equipped with shore power connections to reduce pollution while docked at ports. E&S tankers have stated that the bio-LNG used for this bunkering was produced exclusively from European feedstocks and is a viable way for them to further decarbonize their operations while leveraging the old LNG infrastructure.

headline: Ferry Under Maintenance Catches Fire in Indonesia; No Injuries Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Directorate General of Sea Transportation of Indonesia confirmed a fire incident involving the ferry [Mutiara Ferindo 2](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8967029/mmsi:525100865/imo:0/vessel:MUTIARA_FERINDO_2) on 3rd April. The incident occurred in Tarahan Waters, Serang Regency, Indonesia, prompting a swift response from the authorities. ![Mutiara Ferindo 2 caught fire in Indonesian water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MUTIARA_FERINDO_2_53bd45d36e.png)*Ferry MUTIARA_FERINDO_2, image credit:hubla.dephub.go.id* The fire reportedly began around 4:00 WIB while the ferry was anchored and undergoing maintenance. Initial findings suggest that the fire originated on Car Deck D, where a pile of wooden pallets caught fire. Upon discovering the flames, the crew initiated fire suppression efforts. Despite their attempts, the fire quickly intensified, and the ferry’s Chief Officer made a distressed call and sought assistance. At around 4:57, WIB Vessel Traffic Service Officer (VTSO) informed that patrolling vessel KN. Tg Datu successfully evacuated 12 crew members, all of whom were reported to be in stable condition with no injuries. Four other crew members remained on board to assist in extinguishing the fire. The fire was later brought under control. The incident did not affect the operational ferry routes. An investigation has been launched to determine the cause of the fire.
