**Tankers: A Third of U.S.-Calling Vessels Linked to China**

The tanker segment shows substantial exposure to China across the global fleet. MarineTraffic data indicates that 30.1% of tankers worldwide are linked to China—through construction (21.4%), ownership (14.6%), or flag (7.9%).

These vessels are the backbone of international energy flows, moving crude oil, refined products, and chemicals across long-haul corridors between the U.S., Asia, Europe, and Latin America. China-linked tankers are deeply embedded in these routes, and any disruption to their operations—whether through punitive port fees or regulatory restrictions—would strain the availability of compliant vessels.

The resulting costs go beyond the fee itself. With fewer eligible tankers in the mix, scheduling challenges increase, trade patterns become less efficient, and charterers may need to reroute or delay cargoes. For refiners, traders, and shippers, this means higher freight rates, longer lead times, and reduced flexibility.

Replacing Chinese-linked capacity will take years. Redirecting orders to Korean or Japanese yards, or reshuffling ownership structures, is not a quick fix. In the near term, the proposed U.S. measures introduce not only financial penalties but operational uncertainty. The impact will ripple far beyond shipping desks, affecting fuel costs, delivery timelines, and trade competitiveness worldwide.

**Gas Carriers: Strategically Vulnerable**

Gas carriers—including both LNG and LPG vessels—may have lower direct exposure to China compared to sectors like dry bulk or containers, but their strategic significance is notably higher. MarineTraffic data indicates substantial Chinese involvement in global gas carrier operations: 16.5% of LNG carriers and 19.0% of LPG carriers worldwide have connections to China. Specifically, among LNG carriers, 7.1% are Chinese-built, 13.9% are Chinese-owned, and 4.7% sail under the Chinese flag. For LPG carriers, these figures are slightly different, with 10.5% built in China, 10.5% Chinese-owned, and 3.7% Chinese-flagged.

Energy industry experts caution that imposing restrictions on Chinese-linked gas carriers could disrupt crucial supply routes connecting Asia, Europe, and Latin America. If such measures are strictly enforced, the global market could shift in favour of competitors like Qatar and Australia, nations already benefiting from significant scale advantages in LNG shipping.

**Vehicle Carriers: A Rare Exception** Ro-Ro vessels, which carry vehicles and rolling equipment, are the least exposed segment. Just 13% are Chinese-built and virtually none are flagged or owned in China. These ships may avoid the brunt of new maritime rules, though they could still be affected indirectly by congestion, fleet shortages, or cascading effects from other segments.

That said, the sector is not immune to broader trade frictions. The Trump administration has also proposed new tariffs on Chinese-made vehicles, meaning auto shipping could be hit on multiple fronts. Even if Ro-Ro vessels themselves escape direct penalties, the cargo they carry may soon become entangled in the same geopolitical crossfire.

Looking ahead, the exposure of the vehicle carrier sector is set to rise sharply. China has secured over 80% of the global newbuilding orderbook for Ro-Ro carriers. This orderbook represents just under a third of the existing Ro-Ro fleet, suggesting that China is on course to dominate future capacity in this sector. If port fees are applied to new vessels based on build location, automakers and logistics providers could face significantly higher shipping costs as these ships enter service over the coming years.

**The Strategic Trade-Off**

The proposed restrictions represent one of the most significant interventions in maritime trade policy in recent decades. At their core, these measures aim to reduce U.S. reliance on Chinese shipbuilding and logistics. However, with nearly a third of all U.S. port calls involving Chinese-built, owned, or flagged vessels, the fallout will extend far beyond Chinese stakeholders.

Exporters of coal, grain, and energy are already feeling the effects. Shipping availability is tightening, and some operators are preemptively cancelling sailings or reconfiguring trade lanes in anticipation of regulatory enforcement. These disruptions not only risk raising freight rates—undermining the competitiveness of U.S. exports—but also carry direct consequences for American shipowners. MarineTraffic data shows that at least 193 Chinese-built ships are under U.S. beneficial ownership.

The largest exposures include Eagle Bulk Shipping Inc. (39 ships), Genco Shipping & Trading Ltd. (34), and Tidewater Marine Service Inc. (29). Other U.S.-linked owners include MT Maritime Management (7), JP Morgan Chase (6), Sunstone Ships (5), Seabulk Fleet Management (4), and Tropical Shipping (1), with a further 68 ships held by other entities.

![image1.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image1_9d5ab505d3.png) _Source: MarineTraffic_

The exposure spans a wide array of vessel types. Bulk carriers dominate the picture, accounting for 104 of the 193 ships. Offshore supply vessels follow with 27, while container ships number 15. The remainder includes general cargo ships (11), oil/chemical tankers (7), crude oil tankers (6), heavy load carriers (3), drill ships (2), Ro-Ro carriers (2), and a handful of specialised vessels such as anchor handlers, tugs, and passenger ships.

This broad reliance on Chinese shipyards illustrates the depth of integration between U.S. maritime interests and Chinese industrial capacity. The proposed fees may aim to shift future procurement away from China, but in the near term, they risk penalising domestic firms, disrupting trade flows, and raising costs for U.S. exporters.

As highlighted in this report, MarineTraffic data shows that no segment is entirely insulated. Even sectors like Ro-Ro, which are less exposed, could face ripple effects through vessel availability, pricing pressure, or retaliatory tariffs.

While the policy may succeed in discouraging future procurement from Chinese yards, the reality remains that U.S. shipyards are currently unable to meet global demand, with key capabilities—such as LNG carrier construction—unavailable domestically. In the near term, shipyards in Korea and Japan, already competitively positioned, are more likely to benefit. As the global shipping landscape undergoes this imminent shift, stakeholders must prepare for the far-reaching ramifications of these proposed port fees. With MarineTraffic’s advanced maritime intelligence, companies can swiftly adapt to changes in vessel connections, rerouting, and rising costs. Whether you're a shipowner, trader, or policymaker, our platform facilitates smarter, faster decision-making—helping you anticipate disruptions and identify opportunities.

headline: Engine Room Fire Contained on Sea Bus in Turkey, No Injuries Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Bursa Metropolitan Municipality reported a fire aboard [Yildirim Beyazid](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8957121/mmsi:271043572/imo:9086667/vessel:YILDIRIM_BEYAZID#overview), a sea bus operated by Bursa Sea Buses (BUDO), during its scheduled voyage from Eminönü to Mudanya, Turkey. No casualties were reported. ![Fire broke aboard YILDIRIM BEYAZID.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/YILDIRIM_BEYAZID_1f22399210.png)*Vessel YILDIRIM BEYAZID, image credit: Bursa Metropolitan Municipality* The fire broke out on 6th April at approximately 19:50 local time due to a technical fault in one of the vessel’s engines. The crew of the vessel promptly responded to the situation and managed to control the fire. Following the incident, the vessel encountered adverse weather conditions at sea, with waves up to 3 metres. Despite this, the sea bus was able to safely navigate to Mudanya Pier using one functioning engine. All the passengers were safely evacuated upon arrival, and no injuries were reported. A detailed technical investigation into the cause of the fire has been launched. BUDO authorities affirmed their commitment to implementing all necessary safety measures to ensure the continued safety of maritime operations.

headline: Ferry Collides with Dock Structure off U.S. East Coast Near Nantucket
author: Raghib Raza
content: The USA-flagged Ro-Ro/passenger ship [Eagle](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:439185/mmsi:367174060/imo:8705864/vessel:EAGLE#overview) collided with a harbor structure while departing from Nantucket Island en route for Hyannis, USA. No injuries were reported. ![EAGLE collided a harbor structure off USA coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/EAGLE_730d727653.png)*Ro-Ro/passenger ship EAGLE, image credit: Noah Sylvester* The incident occurred on 5th April at approximately 5:30 pm local time when the vessel struck the outer dolphin on its port side, causing the structure to break apart and debris to fall into the sea. Despite the collision, the vessel did not sustain significant damage, and resumed operations with the U.S. Coast Guard's approval. An investigation is currently underway to determine the cause of the collision. [Eagle](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:439185/mmsi:367174060/imo:8705864/vessel:EAGLE#overview) is a 1987-built Ro-Ro/passenger ship with a capacity of 3,269 gross tonnage. It is 71.01 metres long and 18.32 metres wide.

headline: Passenger Ferry “Baltica” Suffers Stern Flooding Off German Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 7th April, a German-flagged passenger ship, [Baltica](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:130695/mmsi:211215210/imo:5302063/vessel:BALTICA), experienced sudden water ingress at the stern while sailing in the Baltic Sea. The incident occurred after the ferry departed [Kuehlungsborn](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1516?name=KUEHLUNGSBORN&country=Germany) en route to Warnemünde, Germany. ![BALTICA suffer water ingress off Germany Coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BALTICA_aa0148c621.png)*Passenger Ship BALTICA, image credit: Bettina Rohbrecht* At around 11:00 a.m. local time, the captain aborted the voyage within ten minutes of departure and returned to Kühlungsborn pier. All the passengers were safely disembarked, and no injuries were reported. However, upon arrival, the ferry’s stern continued submerging, prompting the risk of capsizing. Firefighters from Kühlungsborn and surrounding districts were deployed to pump water from the engine room, successfully stabilising the vessel. Oil barriers were installed around the ferry after a minor marine diesel leak was observed in the water. Later an inspection conducted by the divers found that a loose drive shaft had caused the water ingress in the ferry. On-site repair was initiated, and the authorities confirmed that the situation was under control. However, the water police stated that the ferry will remain moored at the [Kuehlungsborn](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1516?name=KUEHLUNGSBORN&country=Germany) until further notice.

headline: Danish Tanker Group Monjasa Adds New Tanker to its Fleet
author: Raghib Raza
content: Danish tanker group Monjasa added a new tanker, the Hafnia Pegasus, to its fleet, which will now be acting as a floating storage unit in the Middle East. The vessel has also been renamed the [Monjasa Master](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:157211/mmsi:636024552/imo:9461659/vessel:MONJASA_MASTER), reflecting the change in its ownership. ![MONJASA MASTER.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MONJASA_MASTER_ac510af767.png)*Vessel MONJASA MASTER, image credit: Monjasa* The [Monjasa Master](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:157211/mmsi:636024552/imo:9461659/vessel:MONJASA_MASTER) is to serve Monjasa’s bunkering infrastructure in the Middle East, helping in the redistribution of fuel and serving as a floating storage unit. The vessel will be sourcing its fuel from Fujairah, UAE. The [Monjasa Master](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:157211/mmsi:636024552/imo:9461659/vessel:MONJASA_MASTER) is a 2010-built, Liberian-flagged products tanker. The vessel has a length of 183.2 meters, a width of 32.23 meters, and a gross tonnage of 30,261. Monjasa has stated that the vessel is now the largest in its fleet in the Middle East region. Before Monjasa acquired it, the vessel underwent drydocking at the Arab Shipbuilding and Repair Yard in Bahrain to meet specified standards and to change its colors to match Monjasa’s fleet. Monjasa currently has around eight tankers that are operating in the Middle East region, which range from 8000 dwt to 50,000 dwt.

headline: Coral Marine Leads Greece’s First Biofuel Bunkering at Port of Lavrio
author: Raghib Raza
content: Coral Marine announced the first successful biofuel bunkering operation in the country of Greece. This operation was carried out on the cruise vessel [Celestyal Discovery](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:833710/mmsi:256667000/imo:9221566/vessel:CELESTYAL_DISCOVERY#overview) at the port of [Lavrio](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/13?name=LAVRIO&country=Greece) and marks a significant milestone in the country’s path towards sustainable shipping operations. ![CELESTYAL DISCOVERY.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CELESTYAL_DISCOVERY_9187c2b2da.png)*Cruise Ship CELESTYAL DISCOVERY, image credit: Lambros Kakes* The bunkering operation was carried out by Coral Marine, a subsidiary of Coral S.A. which provides integrated solutions for marine operations, in collaboration with the Motor Oil (Hellas) Corinth Refineries S.A. The biofuel used in the bunkering was derived from cooking oil and was supplied by Verd, a subsidiary of the Motor Oil Refinery. This biofuel blend meets the ISO specifications and can reduce emissions of the vessel by up to 21%. The [Celestyal Discovery](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:833710/mmsi:256667000/imo:9221566/vessel:CELESTYAL_DISCOVERY#overview) is a Malta-flagged passenger cruise ship that was built in 2003. The vessel has a length of 202.85 meters, a width of 28.10 meters, and a gross tonnage of 42,489.

headline: Containership ablaze in the North Sea after explosion, rescue mission underway
author: Stephanie Duscha
content: After an explosion on the container ship Victoria L on 9 April, the vessel is currently on fire. A rescue mission is underway. ![Victoria L.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Victoria_L_03245d2bbe.png) The origin of the fire is still unclear. Nineteen crew members were on board the ship when the Dutch coastguard was informed of the fire at 1 p.m. local time. During this time, the [Victoria L](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1365044/mmsi:636091410/imo:9430155/vessel:VICTORIA_L) was travelling through Hoek van Holland near Rotterdam. Victoria L began exhibiting irregular status changes from 09:43 UTC, alternating between “Underway using Engine” and “Not Under Command” multiple times. The last such change was recorded at 12:21 UTC. Currently her navigational status is “Not Under Command”. Victoria L is a 16-year-old, German-owned container ship sailing under the flag of Liberia. According to MarineTraffic data, she was en route from Hamburg to Rotterdam when the accident occurred in the North Sea. In the last 12 months she has been trading mainly in Northwest Africa. Three vessels and a rescue helicopter are involved in the rescue mission, visible on MarineTraffic: [KNRM Dorus Rijkers](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:264435/mmsi:245979000/imo:0/vessel:KNRM_DORUS_RIJKERS), [Multraship Protector](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:363135/mmsi:244830813/imo:9344978/vessel:MULTRASHIP_PROTECTOR), and [KNRM Jeanine Parqui](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5772750/mmsi:246333000/imo:0/vessel:KNRM_JEANINE_PARQUI) operating in close proximity — as well as the [SAR 111244511](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6036435/mmsi:111244511/imo:0/vessel:SAR_111244511). The Pollution Control Vessel Acra is also in the vicinity. According to current reports, no one was injured.

headline: Cargo Ship and Fishing Boat Collision Off Vietnam’s Coast Claims Four Lives
author: Raghib Raza
content: A maritime incident involving a collision between a Panama-flagged cargo vessel [Hosei Crown](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:690548/mmsi:357840000/imo:9543926/vessel:HOSEI_CROWN) and Vietnamese fishing boat TH 92686 TS occurred in the Gulf of Bắc Bộ, Vietnam, resulting in four fatalities. ![SAR Vessel 411 rescued 8 fishermen after the boat collided with cargo vessel Hosei Crown.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SAR_Vessel_411_0f27007fc3.png)*Image credit: VMRCC* The accident took place on 8th April at approximately 06:55 AM local time, when the cargo vessel collided with the fishing vessel, causing it to sink. Upon receiving the distress information, the Vietnam Maritime Search and Rescue Coordination Center (VMRCC) instructed the cargo vessel to deploy buoys and begin the immediate search and rescue of twelve fishermen who had fallen overboard. The Center also dispatched its SAR 411 rescue ship at the scene. Maritime alerts were promptly issued, and nearby vessels were mobilized to assist in the rescue efforts. In addition, the Center informed local forces for coordination and notified the National Civil Defense Steering Committee along with the Vietnam Maritime and Waterways Administration to oversee and direct the ongoing search and rescue operation. By around 9:10 AM local time, the rescue team successfully rescued eight fishermen and recovered the bodies of four deceased individuals. All were transported by SAR 411 to Hai Phong’s Central Pier and handed over to local authorities. VMRCC, in collaboration with relevant agencies, has launched an investigation to determine the cause of the collision. It is to be noted that the area was experiencing southeast winds at level 3–4 and foggy conditions at the time of the incident.

headline: Container Vessel “CMA CGM Pelleas” Briefly Grounds During Departure from Southampton Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Malta-flagged container vessel [CMA CGM Pelleas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3029/mmsi:256548000/imo:9365788/vessel:CMA_CGM_PELLEAS#overview) briefly ran aground in [Southampton](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/106?name=SOUTHAMPTON&country=United-Kingdom), United Kingdom, on 9th April after veering toward a waterfront structure during departure maneuvers. No injuries were reported in the incident. ![CMA CGM PELLEAS ran aground in United Kingdom.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CMA_CGM_PELLEAS_61cd2f3202.png)*Containership CMA CGM PELLEAS, image credit: horst rahmelow* The [CMA CGM Pelleas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3029/mmsi:256548000/imo:9365788/vessel:CMA_CGM_PELLEAS#overview) diverted from its course and approached a wall in front of waterside flats before running aground. The incident took place shortly after the containership left its berth during midday. The tugboats were promptly dispatched and swiftly refloated the containership. Associated British Ports (ABP), operator of the Port of Southampton, confirmed that the situation was quickly resolved and the containership safely returned to its berth. The incident has been referred to the Marine Accident Investigation Branch for inquiry into the circumstances leading to the grounding. The [CMA CGM Pelleas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3029/mmsi:256548000/imo:9365788/vessel:CMA_CGM_PELLEAS#overview) is currently moored at [Southampton Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/106?name=SOUTHAMPTON&country=United-Kingdom) and is scheduled to arrive in [Rotterdam Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2036?name=ROTTERDAM&country=Netherlands), Netherlands, by 12th April.

headline: Fire Breaks Out Aboard Passenger vessel  “RORO Master 2” in Philippine
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Philippine Coast Guard reported a fire aboard the passenger vessel [RORO Master 2](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4649488/mmsi:548793200/imo:0/vessel:RORO_MASTER_2#overview) on 9th April. The blaze broke out during loading operations at the Port of Abra de Ilog, Philippines, prompting a swift response from authorities. ![Fire broke aboard RORO MASTER 2 in Philippine.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RORO_MASTER_2_eb78d6f7e9.png)*Passenger vessel RORO Mater 2, image credit: Philippine Coast Guard* The incident occurred at approximately 9:00 AM local time when the passenger vessel was preparing to depart for Batangas with 34 crew members, 33 passengers, and 21 rolling cargoes on board. According to initial reports, the fire originated in the deck generator area located at the fantail section of the ship. Personnel from the Coast Guard Sub-Station (CGSS) Abra de Ilog promptly responded, coordinating with the vessel’s officer and damage control team to contain the blaze. Additionally, CGSS contacted the Philippine Port Authority (PPA) in Abra de Ilog requesting for extra fire extinguishers as a precautionary measure. At around 9:20 AM local time, the vessel’s Damage Control Officer confirmed the fire was extinguished. No injuries were reported. Following the incident, authorities recommended temporarily suspending the vessel’s documents pending a safety inspection to assess its seaworthiness.

headline: Inland Vessel “Saeftinge” Suffers Engine Room Fire at Terneuzen Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 8th April, a fire broke out aboard the Netherlands-flagged inland motor vessel [Saeftinge](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:243405/mmsi:244700744/imo:0/vessel:SAEFTINGE#overview). The fire originated in the engine room of the vessel while it was berthed on the Western Scheldt in [Terneuzen](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/133?name=TERNEUZEN&country=Netherlands), Netherlands. ![Fire broke aboard Saeftinge in Netherlands.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SAEFTINGE_c8db3d668c.png)*Inland motor vessel SAEFTINGE, image credit: Alexander Kroner* Local emergency services promptly responded to the incident. The fire brigade arrived shortly thereafter and managed to bring the blaze under control. No casualties were reported in the incident. The [Saeftinge ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:243405/mmsi:244700744/imo:0/vessel:SAEFTINGE#overview)remained moored in [Terneuzen ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/133?name=TERNEUZEN&country=Netherlands)following the incident. The extent of the damage has not yet been disclosed.

headline: Greek shipping to expand global share, says industry leader
author: Stephanie Duscha
content:
Greek shipping is on track to boost its share of the global fleet from 21% to 25%, according to Simos Palios, Chairman of Diana Shipping Inc. Speaking at the 10th Delphi Economic Forum, Palios expressed confidence in the industry's momentum, citing consistent new vessel construction across Asia.
![Polaris.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Polaris_dcf5b6f9d0.png)
>Every four days a Greek ship is built in China, every six in South Korea, and every seven in Japan, he said, highlighting the rapid growth. Palios credited Greece’s dominance in global shipping to the expertise of its shipowners and voiced admiration for the new generation entering the field. “They are far better trained than we were, and I envy them,” he said. He believes the younger generation is well-equipped to take Greek shipping to even greater heights. Addressing recent U.S. trade policy developments, Palios urged caution. He suggested waiting to evaluate the real effects of American tariffs, using a gambling metaphor: >We must first see where the roulette ball lands. He also downplayed the impact of recent dips in U.S. stock markets on his company, maintaining that a stock market presence remains advantageous for shipping firms. Palios concluded by urging young Greeks to rediscover their maritime heritage. >The sea is an excellent profession, he said, noting that salaries can start at €2,500 and rise above €14,000. He also called for the reduction of bureaucratic hurdles in Greece to further empower the country’s shipping industry.

headline: Bulk Carrier “KPS Orhan Ali Khan” Strands Off Turkish Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: Turkey’s Directorate General of Coastal Safety (KEGM) reported that the Liberian-flagged bulk carrier[ KPS Orhan Ali Khan](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:721954/mmsi:636017311/imo:9248514/vessel:KPS_ORHAN_ALI_KHAN#overview) ran aground on 11th April. The incident took place in the Yalova Anchorage Field, Turkey prompting an immediate emergency response. ![KPS ORHAN ALI KHAN ran aground off Turkish water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KPS_ORHAN_ALI_KHAN_deedd7d15e.png)*Bulk Carrier KPS ORHAN ALI KHAN, image credit: KEGM* Authorities promptly responded to the situation and dispatched the Nene Hatun Emergency response vessel, Sark Tugboat, and Kiyem-3 fast rescue boat to rescue the distressed vessel. Additionally, a diver team and rescue expert arrived at the scene to assist in the operation. Efforts are underway to assess the situation and ensure the vessel’s safety. No injuries or environmental hazards have been reported in the incident. The [KPS Orhan Ali Khan](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:721954/mmsi:636017311/imo:9248514/vessel:KPS_ORHAN_ALI_KHAN#overview) is a 2001-built vessel with a carrying capacity of 172,517 tonnes. The vessel has a length of 289 metres and a width of 45 metres.

headline: General cargo vessel grounded in UK water, no injuries reported
author: Raghib Raza
content:
The United Kingdom-flagged general cargo vessel [Scot Bay](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:184623/mmsi:232974000/imo:9243930/vessel:SCOT_BAY#overview) ran aground in the River Teign. The incident occurred while the vessel was attempting to enter the [Port of Teignmouth](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/472?name=TEIGNMOUTH&country=United-Kingdom), United Kingdom, on 10 April.

![SCOT BAY ran aground in UK water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SCOT_BAY_10bfadd622.png)*Vessel SCOT BAY, image credit: Teignmouth Harbour Commission* The vessel grounded at around 06:00 BST while en route from [IJmuiden](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/179?name=IJMUIDEN&country=Netherlands), Netherlands, transporting a cargo of animal feed. It developed a slight starboard list following the grounding, but there were no reports of injuries, structural damage, or pollution.

According to the Teignmouth Harbour Master, the vessel was refloated at around 18:00 BST during the evening tide with the assistance of tugboats. The Marine Accident Investigation Branch (MAIB) has launched an investigation to determine the cause of the incident.

[Scot Bay](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:184623/mmsi:232974000/imo:9243930/vessel:SCOT_BAY#overview) is a 2001-built cargo vessel with a carrying capacity of 3,154 tonnes. It has an overall length of 91.25 metres and width of 14.01 metres. The vessel is currently moored at the [Port Teignmouth](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/472?name=TEIGNMOUTH&country=United-Kingdom).

headline: Two Injured After Crane Collapses on Vessel at a Shipyard in the Netherlands
author: Raghib Raza
content: A maritime incident occurred at the Tinnemans Shipbuilding yard on Industrieweg in Maasbracht, Netherlands, after a crane collapsed and partially landed on the vessel named [Rimini](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:226676/mmsi:244218000/imo:9421635/vessel:RIMINI). ![A crane collapsed and partially toppled on RIMINI.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RIMINI_afb7a4ca2b.png)*Vessel RIMINI, image credit:bd.nl* The incident took place on 15th April, at around 11:45 AM local time, during ongoing maintenance work aboard the vessel. Two individuals operating the crane sustained injuries when the structure broke in half and toppled onto the deck of the ship. Emergency services, including fire units, police, and a trauma helicopter, promptly arrived for rescue. The injured individuals were rescued by the firefighters and transported to a hospital. An external contractor is removing and recovering the damaged crane. An investigation has been launched by the Dutch Labour Inspectorate to determine the cause of the accident.

headline: Two Freight Vessels Crash on Oude Maas in the Netherlands
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 13th April, two Netherlands-flagged inland vessels collided on the Oude Maas near Poortugaal, Netherlands. ![CHIMO collided with another inland vessel in Netherlands.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CHIMO_0754a7c81f.png)*Inland vessel CHIMO, image credit:schuttevaer.nl* At approximately 8:48 PM local time, the 150-metre-long [Chimo](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5043939/mmsi:244130477/imo:0/vessel:CHIMO) had a head-on collision with another 135-metre-long inland vessel, [New Jersey](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8971609/mmsi:244927482/imo:0/vessel:NEW_JERSEY). No injuries were reported. [Chimo ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5043939/mmsi:244130477/imo:0/vessel:CHIMO)sustained severe damage to its foreship, with a large hole torn above the waterline on the port side. [New Jersey](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8971609/mmsi:244927482/imo:0/vessel:NEW_JERSEY) also suffered damage to the port side of its bow above the waterline. Following the incident, [New Jersey](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8971609/mmsi:244927482/imo:0/vessel:NEW_JERSEY) proceeded to Shipyard Kooiman Hoebee BV in Dordrecht for ship repair.

headline: Inland Vessel “Alphenaar” Collides with a Bridge in the Netherlands
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 14th April, the inland container vessel [Alphenaar](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5887159/mmsi:244059204/imo:0/vessel:ALPHENAAR#overview) collided with the Algera Bridge in Krimpen aan den IJssel, Netherlands. No injuries were reported. ![ALPHENAAR collided with bridge in Netherlands.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ALPHENAAR_4a202abe1b.png)*Inland vessel ALPHENAAR, image credit: Arnold Pohen* The collision caused a minor damage denting one of the containers onboard, while the bridge structure suffered superficial paint damage. The vessel was able to moor without assistance following the allision. Shipping traffic was temporarily disrupted while the authorities conducted an investigation into the incident. [Alphenaar ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5887159/mmsi:244059204/imo:0/vessel:ALPHENAAR#overview)is a Netherlands-flagged vessel that has an overall length of 90 metres and a width of 10 metres.

headline: The Port of Rotterdam Successfully Conducts Pilot Ammonia Bunkering Project
author: Raghib Raza
content: The port of Rotterdam's first Ammonia bunkering operation was carried out on 12th April, marking a significant milestone in the port's future as an ammonia bunkering hub. Ammonia is expected to play a key role in decarbonization, as the fuel emits no CO2, and infrastructure for ammonia transport is already well established. ![First Pilot bunkering operation at Rotterdam.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GAS_UTOPIA_b9aa2db22b.png)*Ammonia bunkering operation at Rotterdam Port, image credit: Port of Rotterdam* The bunkering operation was conducted at the Maasvlakte 2 APM terminal in the Port of [Rotterdam](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2036?name=ROTTERDAM&country=Netherlands). The operation involved the transfer of around 800 cubic metres of liquid ammonia cooled to -33 degrees celsius. The transfer took around 2.5 hours and was conducted between the tankers, [Gas Utopia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4824471/mmsi:373225000/imo:9770531/vessel:GAS_UTOPIA) and [Oceanic Moon](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713331/mmsi:636023107/imo:9447809/vessel:OCEANIC_MOON). This pilot demonstration involved the transfer of grey ammonia, which is chemically identical to green ammonia. The operation was conducted under heightened security protocols and with the collaboration of multiple entities. The stakeholders involved in the operation included OCI, the owner of the terminal; Trammo, the owner of the tankers involved in the bunkering; James Fisher Fendercare, which provided equipment and expertise; and the Port of Rotterdam Authority.

headline: Vessel Capsizes Off Philippines; 1 Confirmed Dead, 10 Crew Members Missing
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) reported that on 15th April, at approximately 5:20 PM local time, the aggregates carrier vessel [Hong Hai 16](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:421084/mmsi:357588000/imo:8665870/vessel:CAI_JUN_2) capsized off the Philippines coast. The incident resulted in one confirmed fatality, while 10 crew members remain missing. ![HONG TAI 16 capsized off Philippine coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/HONG_TAI_16_58bd8bcc5c.png)*Vessel HONG TAI 16, image credit: PCG* The [Hong Tai 16](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:421084/mmsi:357588000/imo:8665870/vessel:CAI_JUN_2), reportedly operated by Keen Peak Corporation, was carrying 25 crew members, including 12 Chinese and 13 Filipino nationals. Multiple rescue and response units under the Philippine Coast Guard were deployed to search and rescue the crew members. Additional support was dispatched from the PCG station in Sablayan to aid in rescue efforts. 14 crew members, including six Filipinos and eight Chinese, were reportedly rescued. The PCG recovered the body of one deceased Chinese national, while 10 crew members, including seven Filipinos and three Chinese, are still missing. As of today, the search and rescue operation continued by PCG. Initial visual inspections indicate that the vessel is partially submerged but remains upright, with concerns that some personnel may be trapped in the engine room. The PCG has stated deploying oil spill containment booms around the vessel if needed.

headline: Four Crew Members Injured in a Fire Aboard a Coal Ship Near Northern Mozambique
author: Raghib Raza
content: Four crewmembers sustained minor injuries in a fire that broke out aboard the coal-carrying vessel [Altzek](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713843/mmsi:636025041/imo:9621417/vessel:ALTZEK#overview) near the city of Nampula, northern Mozambique, on 13th April. The injured crew members are receiving medical attention, and the fire was reportedly brought under control without further incident. ![ALTZEK caught fire in Mozambique](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ALTZEK_5c483118dd.png)*Vessel ALTZEK, image credit:clubofmozambique.com* The vessel [Altzek](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713843/mmsi:636025041/imo:9621417/vessel:ALTZEK#overview), is said to have detached from the port of [Nacala](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1231?name=NACALA&country=Mozambique), Mozambique after it was done loading coal when the fire broke out. The vessel was bound for Poland, carrying dry bulk cargo at the time of the incident. A note from the Maritime Transport Authority, Itransmar, has stated that they suspect an explosion in the engine room of the vessel caused the accident. Four tugboats with firefighting equipment were quickly dispatched to the scene by CFM-Logistic and Logístico Norte, but upon their arrival, the fire had already been extinguished by the efforts of the crewmembers. The crew members who sustained injuries were sent to a clinic in Nacala, and no reports of any casualties have been made so far.

headline: AD Group Conducts Ship-to-Ship LNG Bunkering in Abu Dhabi
author: Raghib Raza
content: The AD Ports Group conducted its first LNG ship-to-ship bunkering at the Khalifa Port, Abu Dhabi. The operation has cemented the port's position as an up-and-coming center for alternative fuels and sustainable solutions. ![GREEN ZEEBRUGGE conducting bunkering operation in Abu Dhabi.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GREEN_ZEEBRUGGE_6a3392d816.png)*Vessel Green ZEEBRUGGE, image credit: AD PORTS GROUP* The bunkering was carried out, with the LNG bunker vessel [Green Zeebrugge ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4404786/mmsi:205703000/imo:9750024/vessel:GREEN_ZEEBRUGGE)providing the fuel and the vessel [MSC Thais](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8107520/mmsi:636023562/imo:9957347/vessel:MSC_THAIS) receiving it while berthed at the Abu Dhabi terminals. The bunkering operation was carried out during cargo loading operations, ensuring minimal downtime. The bunkering operation was carried out in compliance with international best practices and regulatory standards. These included the guidelines set by the International Maritime Organization (IMO), the International Association for Ports and Harbors, the Society of International Gas Tankers and Terminal Operators, and the International Organization for Standardization. The LNG bunkered was provided by bunker fuel provider Monjasa. AD Ports Group and Monjasa are expected to continue and expand their partnership and provide similar bunkering services across all of the ports managed by the AD Ports Group in Abu Dhabi.

headline: Fire Erupts on Liberian-Flagged Bulk Carrier Docked in Amsterdam
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 17th April, a fire broke in the wiring of the bulk carrier [Syros Trader](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3111/mmsi:636020397/imo:9395214/vessel:SYROS_TRADER#overview) while it was docked at the West Poortweg quay in [Amsterdam](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1766?name=AMSTERDAM&country=Netherlands), Netherlands. All the crewmembers were reported safe and did not require evacuation. ![Fire aboard SYROS TRADER in Amsterdam Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SYROS_TRADER_5e74207e62.png)*Vessel SYROS TRADER, image credit: Bill Kerrigan* Emergency service responded promptly, with three fire engines and a cherry picker deployed to the scene. The fire brigade was able to extinguish the flames efficiently, preventing further damage to the vessel. A patrol boat, Kokmeeuw, with the police, arrived at the scene, likely to assist with any potential safety concerns in the area. [Syros Trader](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3111/mmsi:636020397/imo:9395214/vessel:SYROS_TRADER#overview) is a 2008-built bulk carrier sailing the Liberian flag. The vessel has a carrying capacity of 53,408 tonnes, an overall length of 189.94 metres, and a width of 32.29 metres.

headline: Maltese-Flagged Ro-Ro Ship Catches Fire in Belgium Port, Blaze Under Control
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 16th April, a fire broke out aboard the Maltese-flagged Ro-Ro cargo vessel [Delphine](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5298549/mmsi:248189000/imo:9789245/vessel:DELPHINE). The incident took place when the ship was moored at the CLdN terminal in [Zeebrugge](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/265?name=ZEEBRUGGE&country=Belgium), Belgium. ![Fire aboard Ro-Ro vessel DELPHINE in Belgium Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/DELPHINE_9ae254f93e.png)*Vessel DELPHINE, image credit:demorgen.be* At around 15:00 local time, the fire erupted on one of the vehicle decks. Promptly, the firefighting teams responded in large numbers, supported by three tugboats. The ship’s carbon dioxide-based extinguishing system was activated, effectively cutting off the oxygen supply and containing the fire. Fortunately, all the crew members were safely evacuated, and no injuries were reported. The captain of the vessel remained on board to assist the firefighting team in monitoring the situation. According to the Port Authority of Zeebrugge, the ship’s internal fire suppression system successfully contained the blaze. Firefighting teams were assessing the next steps to prevent the re-ignition of fire once the hatches were open. The extent of damage has yet to be determined. Despite the incident, port operations continued with minimal disruption. Vessel traffic remained active, although a ship at the nearby LNG terminal was temporarily delayed due to safety perimeters around the affected area.

headline: Update: Vessel Capsizes Off Philippines; 2 Confirmed Dead, 9 Crew Members Missing
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) reported that on 15th April, at approximately 5:20 PM local time, the aggregates carrier vessel [Hong Hai 16](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:421084/mmsi:357588000/imo:8665870/vessel:CAI_JUN_2) capsized off the Philippines coast. The incident resulted in fatalities, and crewmembers missing. ![HONG TAI 16 capsized off Philippine coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/HONG_TAI_16_58bd8bcc5c.png)*Vessel HONG TAI 16, image credit: PCG* The [Hong Tai 16](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:421084/mmsi:357588000/imo:8665870/vessel:CAI_JUN_2), reportedly operated by Keen Peak Corporation, was carrying 25 crew members, including 12 Chinese and 13 Filipino nationals. Multiple rescue and response units under the Philippine Coast Guard were deployed to search and rescue the crew members. Additional support was dispatched from the PCG station in Sablayan to aid in rescue efforts. 14 crew members, including six Filipinos and eight Chinese, were reportedly rescued. In the latest update the PCG recovered the bodies of two deceased Chinese and Filipino nationals. With this recovery, the official death toll stands at two, and nine crew members remain missing. A light oil sheen and the odor of marine diesel were reported near the vessel, prompting the deployment of five segments—approximately 250 meters—of oil spill containment booms to prevent the spread of possible fuel contamination. The search and rescue operation remained intensified by PCG while environmental surveillance in the area. Initial visual inspections indicate that the vessel is partially submerged but remains upright, with concerns that some personnel may be trapped in the engine room.

headline: Passenger Ferry “Frisia E I” Damaged in Collision at German Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 16th April, the German-flagged passenger ship [Frisia E I ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8910407/mmsi:218055770/imo:1013250/vessel:FRISIA_E_I#overview)collided with another ferry while departing from [Norddeich port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/392?name=NORDDEICH&country=Germany), Germany. The operator of the ship, Norden-Frisia Shipping, confirmed that no crewmembers or passengers were injured in the incident. ![FRISIA E I collided with a ferry in German Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FRISIA_E_I_ead97f8ad7.png)*Passenger ship FRISIA E I, image credit: Bas de Jager* During the collision, [Frisia E I](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8910407/mmsi:218055770/imo:1013250/vessel:FRISIA_E_I#overview) sustained damage, resulting in a hole approximately 30 by 30 centimetres on the port side above the waterline. The German police confirmed the damage and reported no pollution in the water. The authorities have launched an investigation into the accident. The ferry was successfully repaired, allowing it to return to service.

headline: QatarEnergy Unveils New LNG Carrier at Naming Ceremony in China
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 17th April, QatarEnergy celebrated the naming ceremony of its newly built liquefied natural gas (LNG) carrier “Al Tuwar.” The event was organized by a joint venture company formed by NYK, Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha, Ltd., MISC Berhad, and China LNG Shipping (Holdings) Limited. ![AL TUWAR named by QatarEnergy in China.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/AL_TUWAR_e6b4d9a55b.png)*Vessel AL TUWAR, image credit: NYK Line* Al Tuwar was built by Hudong-Zhonghua Shipbuilding (Group) Co., Ltd. in China. The vessel is the first in a series of 12 LNG carriers constructed for QatarEnergy. The vessel has a length of 299 metres, a beam of 46.4 metres, depth of 26.25 metres, and a cargo holding capacity of 174,000 cubic metres. The vessel is equipped with the X-DF 2.1 iCER dual-fuel engine and a reliquefaction device to utilize surplus boil-off gas, enhancing fuel efficiency and reducing greenhouse gas emissions. It is scheduled to begin global LNG transport operations in May.

headline: Fire Breaks Out on a Petrobras Oil Platform in Campos Basin, No Fatalities Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire broke out at [Petrobras' Cherne 1](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:775812/mmsi:710991000/imo:8753952/vessel:PETROBRAS_I) platform (PCH-1) in the Campos Basin, Brazil, on 21st April. The fire was brought under control with intervention. No fatalities have been reported, and an investigation has been launched into the incident. ![PETROBRAS I on fire.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PETROBRAS_I_ab6e07e1bb.png)*Platform PETROBRAS, image credit: Sindicato dos Petroleiros do Norte Fluminense* According to the Norte Fluminense Oil Workers' Union (Sindicato dos Petroleiros do Norte Fluminense), a labor union representing oil workers in the region, the fire broke out at 7:25 AM local time on the Chern-1 platform. This was followed by a plume of smoke that was visible from nearby platforms. While reports suggest an explosion may have occurred, it is unclear if this was the case. Emergency vessels battled the fire for around four hours, and by 11:25 AM, the fire was brought under control. The gas flow of the platform was stopped at the time for safety reasons. In the chaos of the operation, one worker fell into the ocean but was quickly rescued by present vessels and was alive and conscious. All 176 non-essential workers from the platform were then evacuated, and 32 of these were taken to hospitals for medical attention. Of these 32, fourteen workers have been reported to have suffered burns, while the others have been admitted to hospitals for smoke inhalation. The Brazilian state-owned gas giant Petrobras has stated that the Chern-1 platform has not produced oil since 2020 and was sold to Perenco Oil and Gas of Brazil Ltd., an independent oil and gas company, in April 2024. However, the handover of the platform to its new owner has not been completed yet, and it still remains under Petrobras's management. Petrobras has revealed that they are forming a commission to thoroughly investigate the incident and determine its cause.

headline: Engine Failure Leaves MSC Talia F Adrift Off Spanish Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Portugal-flagged container ship [MSC Talia F](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713950/mmsi:255805965/imo:9308601/vessel:MSC_TALIA_F#overview) experienced engine failure approximately eight nautical miles east-northeast of Punta Melenara, Spain, on 19th April. ![MSC TALIA F suffered engine problem off Spain Coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSC_TALIA_F_87fb470dee.png)*Vessel MSC TALIA F, image credit: Salvamento Marítimo* The container ship, carrying a load of containers, some with hazardous materials, began drifting south at a speed of about two knots. The vessel navigated through challenging weather conditions, with north-easterly winds of 25–30 knots and swells reaching two meters. In response to the situation, Spain's maritime safety agency, Salvamento Marítimo, promptly dispatched the tugboat Heroínas de Sálvora to assist the disabled vessel. The tug successfully secured the vessel and was towed to Port La Palmas for assessment. Following the inspection and clearance, [MSC Talia F](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713950/mmsi:255805965/imo:9308601/vessel:MSC_TALIA_F#overview) departed from [Port La Palmas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/221?name=LAS-PALMAS&country=Spain) on 21st April and is scheduled to arrive in [Nouakchott](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1120?name=NOUAKCHOTT&country=Mauritania), Mauritania, by 23rd April.

headline: Two Injured After Off-Shore Vessel Hits Wind Turbine off Dutch Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Panama-flagged offshore supply vessel [Glomar Venture](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:413501/mmsi:354008000/imo:8822648/vessel:GLOMAR_VENTURE) collided with a windmill on the North Sea off the coast of North Holland, Netherlands. Two of eight crewmembers were injured in the accident. ![GLOMAR VENTURE struck to windmill in North Sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GLOMAR_VENTURE_590bad50a8.png)*Off-Shore vessel GLOMAR VENTURE, image credit:nltimes.nl* The collision occurred on 20th April, at around 7 AM local time, approximately 24 kilometers off the coast near Callantsoog. Emergency response teams from the Royal Netherlands Sea Rescue Institution (KNRM) and the Coastguard were dispatched to the scene. The injured crew members were initially treated onboard before being transferred to shore by a KNRM rescue vessel. Upon arrival in Den Helder, both were transported to a hospital for further medical attention. Despite the collision, [Glomar Venture](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:413501/mmsi:354008000/imo:8822648/vessel:GLOMAR_VENTURE) continued the journey under its own power and safely arrived at the port of [Den Helder](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/120?name=DEN-HELDER&country=Netherlands), Netherlands. An investigation has been launched by the authorities to determine the cause of the incident.

headline: Osaka Gas Introduces Japan's First Shore-to-Ship LNG Bunkering Service
author: Raghib Raza
content: Japanese gas company Osaka Gas kicked off Japan's first shore-to-ship LNG bunkering service at an event on April 21 in Japan. The bunkering service was inaugurated with the bunkering of the vessel [Verde Heraldo](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9241901/mmsi:636024759/imo:9991161/vessel:VERDE_HERALDO). ![VERDE HERALDO conducted shore-to-ship LNG bunkering service.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/VERDE_HERALDO_a9d41289b9.png)*Vessel VERDE HERALDO,image credit: Osaka Gas* The bunkering process with which the new shore-to-ship service was started off was carried out at the Senboku LNG Terminal in Takaishi City, Osaka Prefecture. The vessel itself is operated by Mitsui O.S.K. Lines and makes deliveries to JFE Steel Corporation of raw materials required in steel production. The vessel is a 2024-built bulk carrier registered in Liberia. It has a length of 299 meters, a width of 50 meters, and a gross tonnage of 111,000. The new shore-to-ship bunkering service is an addition to the truck-to-ship bunkering services that Osaka Gas has been offering since 2019. Osaka Gas has also announced an upcoming ship-to-ship bunkering service, which will be available from the 2026 fiscal year. The new bunkering vessel is expected to have a capacity of 1500 tons and is currently under construction under the Shitanoe Shipbuilding Co., Ltd, that is situated in the Oita prefecture in Japan. LNG bunkering methods are being welcomed in Japan due to a lack of LNG bunkering infrastructure. The global decarbonization trends, driven by the net-zero emission goals set by the International Maritime Organization of achieving 50% of the level of emissions in 2008 by 2050, have also led to an increase in demand for LNG in the global market. Osaka Gas is also exploring the production of synthetic or e-methane that would be chemically identical to LNG but have an improved carbon footprint.

headline: Fire Erupts in Cargo Hold of Bulk Carrier in Amsterdam Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire broke out in a cargo hold aboard the bulk carrier [Federal Tweed](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713916/mmsi:538004749/imo:9658898/vessel:FEDERAL_TWEED) on 24th April. The incident occurred at around 6 AM local time when the vessel was berthed along Amerikahaven Way in Amsterdam’s Western Port Area, Netherlands. ![FEDERAL TWEED's cargo hold on fire in Amsterdam Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FEDERAL_TWEED_cc7f735d33.png)*FEDERAL TWEED, image credit:at5.nl* The blaze, erupted by scrap metal stored in the hold, produced dense smoke that drifted across the port and nearby regions. In response, the Amsterdam’s fire department issued a precautionary advisory urging nearby residents to keep windows and doors closed. A crane is being used to lift smoldering scrap from the cargo hold of the vessel and deposit it onto the quay. The fire department is expected to remain engaged in suppression efforts for an extended period while continuously monitoring smoke levels. [Federal Tweed](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713916/mmsi:538004749/imo:9658898/vessel:FEDERAL_TWEED) is a 2013-built bulk carrier sailing under the flag of the Marshall Islands. The carrier has a length overall of 189.99 metres, width of 32.27 metres and a carrying capacity of 55,317 tonnes.

headline: Singapore-Flagged Vessels Allide at Savannah Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 22nd April, Singapore-flagged container ships [Ever Memo](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9092471/mmsi:563237800/imo:9935272/vessel:EVER_MEMO#overview) and [Wai Hai A09](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7582629/mmsi:563182200/imo:9555113/vessel:WAN_HAI_A09) allided in [Port Savannah](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/200?name=SAVANNAH&country=USA), USA. Neither of the vessels sustained damage, and no injuries were reported during the incident. ![EVER MEMO allided with WAN HAI A09 in USA.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/EVER_MEMO_6f07a0d837.png)*Vessel EVER MEMO, image credit:Instagram/salvage_and_wreck* The [Ever Memo ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9092471/mmsi:563237800/imo:9935272/vessel:EVER_MEMO#overview)made contact with [Wan Hai A09](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7582629/mmsi:563182200/imo:9555113/vessel:WAN_HAI_A09) while being maneuvered by tugs in the Port of Savannah turning basin. The allision occurred amid active cargo operations, with five quay cranes engaged on the Wan Hai A09. After the allision, [Ever Memo](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9092471/mmsi:563237800/imo:9935272/vessel:EVER_MEMO#overview) remained moored at Savannah while [Wan Hai A09](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7582629/mmsi:563182200/imo:9555113/vessel:WAN_HAI_A09) departed from the port on 23rd April en route for [Cristobal,](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/796?name=CRISTOBAL&country=Panama) Panama.

headline: Oil Tanker ”Invictus” Battles Fire, Left Adrift Off Somalia
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Marshall Island-flagged oil products tanker [Invictus](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713719/mmsi:538004539/imo:9536820/vessel:INVICTUS) caught fire on 22nd April. The fire broke out in the engine room of the tanker at approximately 508 nautical miles east of Mogadishu, Somalia. ![INVICTUS caught fire and adrift off Somalia.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/INVICTUS_89555c9d52.png)*Oil Products Tanker INVICTUS, image credit: Bridge Valley* The 180-meter-long tanker departed from [Beira Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1228?name=BEIRA&country=Mozambique), Mozambique, for[ Fujairah](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/790?name=FUJAIRAH&country=United-Arab-Emirates), UAE, when the incident occurred. The crewmembers aboard the tanker were able to extinguish the flame by the next day on 23rd April. However, flooding in the engine compartment left the condition of the main propulsion system unknown, rendering the vessel adrift. One Filipino crew member was reported to have sustained burns during the incident. An Indian Navy vessel operating nearby provided first‑aid to the injured crew member. Although treated aboard the vessel, the injured seafarer was not evacuated; the tanker's management is exploring options to transfer him ashore. The remainder of the crew have stayed on board. According to the MarineTraffic data, [Invictus](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713719/mmsi:538004539/imo:9536820/vessel:INVICTUS)'s navigational status states that the vessel is currently not under command.

headline: Utopia IV Crew Wins $2.9 M in Damages After 2021 Tanker Collision
author: Raghib Raza
content: A Miami court awarded the crew of the 63-metre superyacht [Utopia IV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5567834/mmsi:303455000/imo:9851050/vessel:UTOPIA_IV) a total of $2.8 million. The crew members had sued their employer for not providing adequate maintenance, cure, and wages following an accident in which the yacht was involved. ![Crew of Utopia VI win $2.9 M in Damages After 2021 Tanker Collision ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/TROPIC_BREEZE_20b3856c54.png)*Vessel TROPIC BREEZE, image credit: NTSB* The incident in question occurred on 23rd December 2021, when the [Utopia IV ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5567834/mmsi:303455000/imo:9851050/vessel:UTOPIA_IV)ended up colliding with the 49-metres tank vessel [Tropic Breeze](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:377797/mmsi:312815000/imo:8906315/vessel:TROPIC_BREEZE) around 20 miles off the coast of Nassau, Bahamas. The collision punched a hole in the hull of the Tropic Breeze, and the tanker, which was transporting around 156,500 gallons of fuel, sank to a depth of 2000 meters. The estimated damages from the incident, including damages to both vessels and the cost of the lost fuel, ended up being around $7.9 million. Ensuing investigations into the incident revealed the crews of both vessels to be at fault. The captain of the [Utopia IV ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5567834/mmsi:303455000/imo:9851050/vessel:UTOPIA_IV)had departed from the bridge around 12 minutes before the incident to tend to the guests aboard the yacht, leaving behind the bosun, who was unqualified for keeping watch. Conversely, the captain of the [Tropic Breeze](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:377797/mmsi:312815000/imo:8906315/vessel:TROPIC_BREEZE) reportedly left the bridge to utilize the restroom. Neither vessel reported seeing the other vessel on the radar before the collision. All seven crew members of the [Tropic Breeze](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:377797/mmsi:312815000/imo:8906315/vessel:TROPIC_BREEZE) abandoned the ship and were rescued. Three crewmembers from the [Utopia IV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5567834/mmsi:303455000/imo:9851050/vessel:UTOPIA_IV) reportedly suffered injuries and later sued the yacht’s owner, Utopia Yachting LLC, for allegations of negligence, for unseaworthiness of the vessel, and for the failure of the company to provide maintenance, cure, and wages to the three crew members following the incident under the Jones Act. The crew members claimed injuries such as PTSD, whiplash, and fractured bones due to the accident and alleged that their employer did not provide them with medical care or compensation as required by maritime law. The trial took place in Miami, where a jury found the crew eligible for receiving both compensatory and punitive damages, awarding a total of $2.8 million to all three crew members.

headline: Axpo Expands its LNG Bunkering Operations to its Second Port in Spain
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Swiss-based energy company Axpo expanded its LNG bunkering network to the port of [Algeciras](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/185?name=ALGECIRAS&country=Spain). This marks the second port in the Spanish market where the company has introduced its LNG bunkering services. ![Axpo conduct LNG bunkering in second port of Spain ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSC_MARIACRISTINA_a3d16b473b.png)*Vessel MSC MARIACRISTINA, image credit:elmercantil.com* The inauguration involved bunkering around 5,000 cubic meters of LNG from the 7,500 cubic metre LNG bunker vessel [Avenir Aspiration ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6704730/mmsi:215902000/imo:9868962/vessel:AVENIR_ASPIRATION)to the MSC container ship [Mariacristina](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8880594/mmsi:636024272/imo:9968279/vessel:MSC_MARIACRISTINA#overview). The introduction of Axpo’s services in the port of Algeciras was followed closely by the introduction of the company’s services in the port of [Malaga](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/275?name=MALAGA&country=Spain). The introduction followed a similar pattern to the one in the port of Algeciras, with LNG being bunkered from Axpo’s bunker vessel to an MSC vessel. Approximately 2,800 metric tons of LNG were transferred in what also turned out to be Spain’s first SimOps operation, as cargo was loaded concurrently with the LNG bunkering. Axpo has also expressed its future plans of expanding LNG bunkering to the Spanish ports of [Valencia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/74?name=VALENCIA&country=Spain) and [Barcelona](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/236?name=BARCELONA&country=Spain). Axpo has stated that expanding its services to the port of Algeciras is yet another milestone for the company as it aims to become a reliable LNG partner in the Mediterranean.

headline: Engine Failure in Dardanelles Strait Prompts Emergency Response in Turkey
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 26th April, Turkey’s Directorate General of Coastal Safety reported that the containership [MSC Prosperity II](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9541298/mmsi:636025074/imo:9256418/vessel:HONG_PROSPERITY) suffered an engine failure while transiting south of Kepez in the Dardanelles Strait. The incident occurred when the vessel was en route from Egypt to Tuzla, Turkey. ![MSC PROSPERITY II suffered engine failure in Turkey.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSC_PROSPERITY_II_aae49da01e.png)*Vessel MSC PROSPERITY II, image credit: KEGM* Under the coordination of the Çanakkale Ship Traffic Services Center, the vessel was successfully relocated to ensure the safety of navigation and avoid disruption to maritime traffic. No injuries or pollution were reported. [MSC Prosperity II](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9541298/mmsi:636025074/imo:9256418/vessel:HONG_PROSPERITY) is a 2003-built vessel sailing under the flag of Liberia. The vessel has a length of 172.2 metres, a width of 25.26 metres, and a carrying capacity of 1,541 TEU.

headline: Fire Breaks Out on Freighter near Key Rhine Lock in Germany
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire broke out aboard the inland freighter [Lena](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4611297/mmsi:211743670/imo:0/vessel:LENA), anchored near the Friedrichsfeld lock on the Rhine, Germany, on 25th April. ![Fire aboard LENA.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/LENA_6d8fdba86d.png)*Inland vessel LENA, image credit:rp-online.de* At around 1:52 am local time, the fire erupted in the lounge area of the vessel. The captain and a crew member initially attempted to control the blaze before the emergency service arrived. The crewmember subsequently received medical treatment for suspected smoke inhalation. Local firefighters responded to the emergency with special equipment, including a turntable ladder and a command vehicle, to coordinate the operation and extinguish the fire. The vessel was positioned approximately 10 metres below the pier, and access was difficult, prompting the deployment of a multi-purpose boat to transport firefighters and equipment to the site. Upon arriving, the firefighting team discovered smoldering embers hidden behind the cabin’s wall paneling. Equipped with breathing apparatus, the team dismantled the paneling and insulation to fully extinguish the concealed fire. At around 4:30 am local time, the firefighters successfully extinguished the fire. No further injuries were reported.

headline: Boat Strikes Clearwater Ferry, Leaves One Dead and Multiple Injured
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 27th April, Clearwater Police and Clearwater Fire & Rescue reported a collision between a ferry and a boat near the Memorial Causeway Bridge, Florida, in the USA. One fatality and multiple injuries were reported. ![A boat and a Clearwater ferry collided in Florida, USA.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Clearwater_Ferry_a780a311a8.png)*Image credit:news.az* At around 8:40 pm local time, the Clearwater Ferry, carrying 45 passengers, was struck by a boat with six people onboard. The spokesperson of Clearwater Police stated that the boat responsible for collision with the ferry fled the scene after the incident. Six individuals were classified as trauma alerts, with two airlifted to nearby hospitals for urgent care. One person later succumbed to injuries sustained in the crash. The Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission (FWC) will lead the investigation into the incident, with support from the U.S. Coast Guard Sector St. Petersburg.

headline: Massive Explosion Bandar Abbas Port, Around 40 killed and 1200 Injured
author: Raghib Raza
content: An explosion rocked the [Port of Bandar Abbas ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1614?name=BANDAR-ABBAS&country=Iran)in Iran on April 26. The incident has caused the loss of around 40 lives and injuries to more than 1,200 people, as reported by various Iranian state media. ![BANDAR ABBAS explosion.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BANDAR_ABBAS_PORT_75c5e0b629.png)*Port BANDAR ABBAS, image credit:PressTV Extra* While initial reports suggested a death count of 14 and injuries to 750 people, the count rose to 40 dead and over 1,200 injured overnight as the fire continued to burn. The explosion and the resulting fire have been reported to have originated at the Shahid Rajaee section, which is the largest container terminal at the Bandar Abbas port and handles millions of tons of cargo annually. It handles around 85% of Iran's non-oil and gas exports and imports. The initial explosion is said to have rocked the area and damaged the windows of buildings several kilometers from the source. Additional explosions continued to occur hours after the initial one. Firefighting efforts were quickly underway, supported by helicopters and other aircraft. By the afternoon of April 27, the Red Crescent Society in Iran reported that the fire had been mostly extinguished and that regular activities had resumed in some parts of the port. It is believed that the explosions and fire occurred in a container storage site north of the port's container loading quays. Although the exact cause of the explosions is still uncertain, it is being conjectured that the chemicals stored within the port fueled the fire and the explosions. Reports indicate that the port had received a shipment of sodium perchlorate, which is then converted to ammonium perchlorate and used as a propellant in ballistic missiles. A shipment of sodium perchlorate from China was tracked to this port, and it is being conjectured that this chemical could be the cause of the explosions and the fire.

headline: Ship Collision Causes Oil Spill on Vietnam’s Long Tau River
author: Raghib Raza
content: A major maritime incident occurred after the Panama-flagged container ship [KMTC Surabaya](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5485917/mmsi:354467000/imo:9821081/vessel:KMTC_SURABAYA) and Hong Kong-flagged bulk carrier [Glengyle](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2903909/mmsi:477066200/imo:9727285/vessel:GLENGYLE) collided near Long Tau River, Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, on 25th April. No injuries or cargo loss were initially reported. ![KMTC SURABAYA and GLENGYLE collided in Vietnam water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KMTC_SURABAYA_9717a06f78.png)*Vessel GLENGYLE, image credit:baoxaydung.vn* At around 22:40, the collision occurred, resulting in severe damage to both vessels. KMTC Surabaya's bow was damaged, while Glengyle sustained a breach at the stern, leading to an oil spill into the river. In response, the Ho Chi Minh City Maritime Port Authority, in coordination with the Vietnam Maritime Administration, was diverting traffic on the Saigon Vung Tau maritime channel. The authorities have issued warnings and advised against approaching the affected area. A maritime notice has been issued restricting traffic in the section surrounding the damaged vessels. Cleanup and containment efforts are underway, with teams from the City Maritime Port Authority, SOS Oil Response Center, and other agencies working together to contain the oil spill. Rescue vessels are currently separating the two vessels and deploying equipment to control the spill.

headline: ITF Brings Relief to Languishing Crew Members of General Cargo Vessel Abandoned by Owners
author: Raghib Raza
content: Crew members of the general cargo vessel BURHAM C (formerly known as the [Jetmax 2](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:386666/mmsi:577505000/imo:9006447/vessel:JETMAX_2)) were brought food and water by the International Transport Workers' Federation (ITF) Seafarers. The vessel has been anchored near Turkey since October of last year. ![ITF provide relief products to the abandon crew of JETMAX 2](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/JETMAX_2_1e49a075c2.png)*Vessel JETMAX 2, image credit: ITF* The all-Indian crew had been left without food or water after the vessel was abandoned by its owners. The crew members had resorted to drinking boiled seawater. With the support of ITF inspector Kenan Dinc, the ITF team delivered food, water, and other vital provisions to the crew. ITF Seafarers' support is actively involved in cases such as the BURHAM C, working to protect the rights of the crew and ensuring that their needs are met. The ITF also reports these cases to the International Labour Organization's Abandonment of Seafarers database. The BURHAM C is a 1992-built general cargo vessel. The vessel has a length of 77.8 meters, a beam of 11.1 meters, and a gross tonnage of 1,201.

headline: Parallels Between Trump’s Trade War and Sanctions in Global Shipping
author: Dimitris Ampatzidis
content: # Introduction Recent U.S. tariffs imposed under President Trump’s trade policies are poised to reshape the global shipping industry in ways uncannily similar to the effects of international sanctions. As seen with sanctions on Russia, such interventions drive traders toward opaque logistics workarounds—creating grey fleets, obscured cargo origins, and fragmented trade routes. When sanctions hit Russian oil in 2022, Kpler tracked a doubling in dark tanker activity, with over 1,000 vessels - 10% of the global fleet - engaging in deceptive practices by 2024. Tariff regimes, although legalistic rather than punitive, introduce comparable incentives for circumvention. As traders face mounting compliance burdens and rising costs, the risk of a parallel, grey logistics system extending beyond oil into dry bulk and container markets is growing. # Key Takeaways 1. Around 10% of the global oil tanker fleet turned grey within 24 months post-sanctions; dry bulk and container segments may follow, with **400–600 dry bulkers** and **40–60 container ships projected to try to evade tariffs by 2026**. 2. **Trade route manipulation is accelerating**, with Vietnam, Mexico, and Panama emerging as key masking hubs for Chinese cargo bound for the US - often involving short transshipment port calls under 48 hours. 3. 18,000 dry bulkers and 6,000 container ships globally, over 7,000 and 1,500 respectively are over 15 years old. 4. **Freight volatility and compliance costs are intensifying**, with insurers already raising premiums **4–10%** on high-risk trades; similar surcharges are now expected for tariff-exposed cargos. 5. Repeated loops between China and Southeast Asia, followed by long-haul U.S.-bound legs, are increasing among small, reflagged operators. # A Sanctions-Style Disruption, Triggered by Tariffs Trump’s expanded tariffs are shaking up logistics much like sanctions have in the energy sector. In both cases, trade faces structural friction - rerouting, regulatory complexity, and a growing divide between legitimate and grey practices. With sanctions, oil traders responded by deploying aged, poorly tracked tankers under shell ownership. Tariffs are triggering similar behaviours in container and dry bulk segments. In the short term, tariff announcements induce cargo front-loading. During the 2018–2019 US–China trade war, transpacific container volumes surged just before each tariff deadline, only to drop off immediately afterward. Today’s tariff cycle is producing similar effects: sudden port congestion, delayed clearance, and temporary overbooking of vessels ahead of policy changes. Shipping lines are once again warning clients to remain agile. But operational clarity is scarce. Importers must now determine tariff applicability based on intricate rules of origin. Legitimate traders are forced to dedicate resources to documentation and customs compliance, while regulators worldwide intensify inspections for circumvention. The result is logistical friction - longer lead times, higher cost, and widespread uncertainty. Over the medium term, evasion strategies start taking root. Indirect routing through third countries for Chinese-origin products because of 145% tariffs - such as Vietnam, Malaysia, or Mexico, as these ones have considerably lower ones (46%, 24%, and 25% respectively, after the buffering period of 90 days started at 10th of April) - is already being used to mask origin. In the last tariff cycle, U.S. authorities discovered that dozens of Chinese-origin goods were illegally relabelled as “Made in Vietnam.” Similar practices are accelerating, now layered with repackaging, partial assembly, or bonded storage stops to create the façade of compliant trade. A parallel network is emerging. Feeder vessels move cargo from Chinese ports to low-scrutiny hubs like Haiphong or Manzanillo, where containers are transshipped onto larger vessels bound for U.S. ports. These short stops - often less than 48 hours - facilitate origin laundering. In some cases, AIS tracking goes dark en route, before the vessel reappears in known tariff-evasion transit zones such as the UAE or Caribbean. As major carriers avoid legal exposure, the vacuum is filled by small, loosely regulated operators. These firms often use older ships, shell companies, and flags of convenience. Some already mirror sanction-era oil trade practices, such as operator switching, misdeclared paperwork, and unusual routing patterns. # A Structural Shift in Motion Drawing on post-sanction trends in oil, where ~10% of the global tanker fleet pivoted into grey operations within 24 months, Kpler forecasts that: **Dry bulk shipping** (mainly steel and aluminium) - with moderate financial incentives and medium traceability - could see 5–8% of the fleet shift into a trade focusing on bypassing the tariffs by 2026. This equates to 400–600 vessels, particularly among 7,000+ bulkers aged 15 years or older. **Container shipping**, with higher traceability but vulnerable feeder segments, could see 2–4% of its fleet trying to avoid the tariffs, 40–60 vessels, primarily older feeder ships below Panamax class. These vessels often share key traits: older build (15+ years), private or shell ownership, and registry under flags of convenience. # Long-Term Impacts: Fragmentation of the Maritime System Persistent tariffs encourage permanent structural changes. Trade routes evolve. Direct China–U.S.volumes fall, while Vietnam, Mexico, and other rerouting hubs register disproportionate US-bound export growth - well beyond their domestic production capacity. This is a red flag for origin laundering, and Kpler already detects surges in cargo traffic from these nodes. Ultimately, global shipping risks a bifurcation: a regulated, high-cost fleet adhering to tariff rules, and a grey network leveraging opacity to remain profitable. While container and dry bulk markets are structurally different from oil, the growth drivers - financial arbitrage, enforcement asymmetry, and low-traceability routes - are already present. # Conclusion The structural parallels between sanctions and tariffs are no longer theoretical. They’re materializing in vessel behaviour, port patterns, and fleet segmentation. With tariff scope expanding and enforcement intensifying, grey trade dynamics are no longer confined to tankers. Dry bulk and container markets are next. Stakeholders should monitor grey fleet indicators closely - fleet age, flag switching, port call anomalies, and rising traffic from non-producing intermediaries. _To find out more about Kpler’s Risk & Compliance offering, visit [here](https://www.kpler.com/demos/risk-compliance-demo?utm_source=website&utm_medium=blog&utm_campaign=risk&compliance_commodities_maritime_news_demo_request)._

headline: Cargo Ship “Gem Star” Suffers Mechanical Breakdown Off Portuguese Coast
author: Raghib Raza
