content: A global marine and aviation claims management company reported that on 26th April, the Panama-flagged general cargo vessel [Gem Star](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:462683/mmsi:372371000/imo:9496173/vessel:GEM_STAR#overview) suffered engine failure off the coast of Portugal. No injuries or pollution were reported. ![GEM STAR suffered engine failure off Portugal Coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GEM_STAR_ef0232fffe.png)*Vessel GEM STAR, image credit: J E T Byrne* Despite the crew's efforts, the mechanical issue could not be solved onboard. As a result, tugboat Roma was contracted to provide towage assistance. [Gem Star](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:462683/mmsi:372371000/imo:9496173/vessel:GEM_STAR#overview) is a 2011-built vessel with an overall length of 177 metres, a width of 28.6 metres and a carrying capacity of 33,171 tonnes. According to the MarineTraffic data the vessel departed from [Gulluk](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/953?name=GULLUK&country=Turkey), Türkiye on 9th April and is scheduled to arrive at [Gdansk](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/234?name=GDANSK&country=Poland), Poland by 3rd May.

headline: Panamanian Tanker Hits Towboat Barges on Mississippi, Prompting Temporary Channel Closure
author: Raghib Raza
content: The tanker [Isla De Bioko](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3842086/mmsi:374402000/imo:9767235/vessel:ISLA_DE_BIOKO#overview) collided with the barges in tow of the towboat Ginny Rose on 27th April. The collision led to one barge sinking and six others going adrift. No injuries were reported in the incident. ![ISLA DE BIOKO collided with tow boat in USA.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ISLA_DE_BIOKO_8e8b1456bc.png)*Vessel ISA DE BIOKO, image credit: Roland Delhaxhe* The incident occurred around 21:20 when the two vessels collided downstream in the Mississippi River from St. Rose, Louisiana.The tanker [Isla De Bioko ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3842086/mmsi:374402000/imo:9767235/vessel:ISLA_DE_BIOKO)collided with one of the barges of the Ginny Rose, which was carrying urea, causing it to sink in the river and sending six other barges adrift. The Coast Guard reported that conditions on the river were harsh and challenging at the time of the collision. After receiving news of the collision, the Coast Guard immediately mobilized. Local assisting tugboats managed to successfully gather four of the barges, but two of them became fouled in the chains of the vessels [Red Fin](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:302198/mmsi:256610000/imo:9607306/vessel:RED_FIN) and [Bulker Bee 30](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:365362/mmsi:246863000/imo:9489986/vessel:BULKER_BEE_30). The section near the collision site was temporarily closed off by the Coast Guard while they assessed whether it was safe to traverse given the sunken barge. On 28th April, after the depth of the sunken barge was deemed safe for other vessels and the last two barges were recovered, the channel was reopened, albeit with restrictions. An investigation has been opened into the matter, and salvage plans are being drawn up for the sunken cargo. The [Isla De Bioko](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3842086/mmsi:374402000/imo:9767235/vessel:ISLA_DE_BIOKO#overview) is a Panamanian-flagged products tanker built in 2016. The vessel has a length of 186 metres, a beam of 32.2 metres, and a gross tonnage of 30,480.

headline: Passenger Vessel FCN Adventure Runs Aground in Vestland County, Norway
author: Raghib Raza
content: The passenger vessel [FCN Adventure](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:314238/mmsi:259560000/imo:9196723/vessel:AURORA_OF_THE_FJORDS) ran aground on a sandbank at Nordfjordeid in Vestland County, Norway, on 29th April. The vessel was later pulled free with the help of another vessel, and no injuries were reported in the incident. ![FNC ADVENTURE ran aground in Norway.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FNC_ADVENTTURE_1e5e030000.png)*Vessel FNC ADVENTURE, image credit: Trygve Tonnessen* The incident occurred at around 6:00 PM local time when the vessel ran aground on the sandbank at Nordfjordeid. The owners of the FCN Adventure believe that the current generated by the propellers of an Aida cruise vessel drove the vessel into the sandbank. The[ FCN Adventure ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:314238/mmsi:259560000/imo:9196723/vessel:AURORA_OF_THE_FJORDS)was carrying only its crew, with no passengers on board, at the time of the incident. No injuries were reported, and the vessel awaited high tide to be able to steer free. However, it was towed free by a small vessel after remaining grounded for a few hours. The [FCN Adventure](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:314238/mmsi:259560000/imo:9196723/vessel:AURORA_OF_THE_FJORDS) is a Norwegian-flagged passenger vessel that was built in 1999. It has a length of 23.99 metres, a beam of 10 metres, and a gross tonnage of 177.

headline: Product Tanker “Seven Pearls” Damaged in US Strike; Three Injured
author: Raghib Raza
content: Three Russian crew members were injured in a US strike conducted on Yemen's [Ras Isa Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/26103?name=RAS-ISA&country=Yemen) on 25th April. ![SEVEN PEARLS three crew member injured after US Strike at Ras Isa Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SEVEN_PEARLS_18c7bfb5ba.png)*Vessel SEVEN REARLS, image credit: Nektarios Papadakis* The injured crew members belonged to the product tanker [Seven Pearls](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1872/mmsi:341157001/imo:9343986/vessel:SEVEN_PEARLS#overview), which was docked at the Ras Isa port and was preparing to offload oil when the strike occurred. Both Houthi and Russian officials confirmed the attack. Yevgeny Kudrov, Russian chargé d'affaires in Yemen, stated on 30th April that one of the crew members is in need of eye surgery following his injuries, but none of the sailors' lives are at risk. The remaining 19 crew members of the Seven Pearls are reported to be safe. The [Seven Pearls](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:1872/mmsi:341157001/imo:9343986/vessel:SEVEN_PEARLS#overview) is a Saint Kitts and Nevis-flagged product tanker that was built in 2007. The vessel has a length of 185.93 metres, a beam of 32.20 metres, and a gross tonnage of 31,433. As of now, the vessel has been moored at a distance from the Yemeni coast. In what is being considered a retaliatory move, Houthi forces are not allowing commercial vessels to depart from the port of Ras Isa. An unspecified number of commercial vessels are currently at the Ras Isa anchorages. The UKMTO has confirmed that vessels are not being permitted to leave the anchorages despite having obtained the proper clearance to depart. Reports indicate that vessels are being escorted into port and that the crew are being threatened with violence if they do not comply. Security consultants are speculating that these commercial vessels will likely be used as a deterrent to reduce the likelihood of US, UK, and Israeli airstrikes against the port.

headline: Three Crew Members Injured in an Incident aboard "Maersk Sana"
author: Raghib Raza
content: An incident aboard the vessel [Maersk Sana](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:757653/mmsi:563000400/imo:9289922/vessel:MAERSK_SANA) on 28th April left three injured. The vessel [Maersk Nomazwe](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:688040/mmsi:477552800/imo:9294381/vessel:MAERSK_NOMAZWE) diverted for assistance and managed to rescue the crew members, dropping them off in Bermuda. ![MAERSK SANA adrift after engine room incident, ](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MAERSK_SANA_8edb4ae35b.png)*Vessel MAERSK SANA, image credit: Geir Vinnes* According to a Maersk spokesperson, the incident occurred in the engine room of the [Maersk Sana](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:757653/mmsi:563000400/imo:9289922/vessel:MAERSK_SANA), and they are still in the process of identifying the cause. The vessel Maersk Nomazwe, which had departed from Algeciras on 22nd April and was en route to Newark, was diverted to assist the distressed vessel. One of the most grievously injured crew members was given first aid on the vessel itself while the others were evacuated. The injured crew were then dropped off at Bermuda, where one crewmember is still in a critical but stable condition. Although Maersk did not specify the nature of the incident, unconfirmed reports state that an explosion occurred in the engine room of the Maersk Sana leading to the injuries of the crewmembers as well as the vessel being disabled. The [Maersk Sana](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:757653/mmsi:563000400/imo:9289922/vessel:MAERSK_SANA) is currently adrift in the Atlantic Ocean near the coast of Bermuda, while the [Maersk Nomazwe](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:688040/mmsi:477552800/imo:9294381/vessel:MAERSK_NOMAZWE), which had stopped to provide assistance, has resumed its journey.

headline: Cement Carrier Refloated After Grounding Near Terneuzen
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 1st May, the Antigua Barbuda-flagged vessel [Cement Trader](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:299990/mmsi:304048000/imo:7716763/vessel:CEMENT_TRADER#overview) ran aground near the Western foreport of Terneuzen. The incident occurred when the vessel was en route from Setúbal to Terneuzen. ![CEMENT TRADER ran aground near Terneuzen.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CEMENT_TRADER_426cc0b954.png)*Vessel CEMENT TRADER, image credit: francisco correia* In response, tugs Multratug 16, Multratug 13, VB Triumphe, and the vessel Patrol arrived at the scene and successfully refloated the grounded vessel. The vessel was secured at the mooring poles within the Western foreport for further inspection. No injuries or pollution were reported. Authorities are expected to assess the circumstances surrounding the incident. [Cement Trader](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:299990/mmsi:304048000/imo:7716763/vessel:CEMENT_TRADER#overview) is a cement carrier built in 1980. It has a length of 106.18 metres, a width of 14.91 metres and a carrying capacity of 6,392 tonnes.

headline: Nine Dead as Two Boats Capsize in China Under Harsh Weather Conditions
author: Raghib Raza
content: Nine people have been found dead, and a search is ongoing for still-missing passengers who were traveling on two boats that capsized in sudden harsh weather conditions in the Liuchong River in Guizhou Province, China. ![Riverboats capsized in China.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Riverboats_923cbbc4e6.png)*River Boats capsized in China, image credit:orientaldaily.com.my* The incident occurred in the late afternoon of 4th May, at around 4:40 PM local time. A thunderstorm, accompanied by powerful winds and heavy rains, overtook several passenger boats that were transporting sightseeing passengers. Passengers reported that the weather was normal as the vessels set off, but it quickly devolved into a situation with high waves and heavy rain. Reports indicate that visibility was reduced to around one meter. Due to the severe weather conditions, two boats reportedly overturned, leading to around 84 passengers falling into the water. The response was quick, and first responders, along with nearby vessels, arrived to help. Chinese personnel arrived soon after, and more than 500 responders have been mobilized, including 80 divers, along with 16 small underwater remotely operated vehicles, which are working to find the missing passengers. As of the night of 4th May, 70 people have been rescued and provided with medical attention.

headline: Fire Erupts on Moored Freighter Roadrunner in Dutch Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 3rd May, a fire broke out aboard the motor freighter [Roadrunner ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6687654/mmsi:244000039/imo:0/vessel:ROADRUNNER)moored in the harbor of Dintelmond, Netherlands. At around 1:10 a.m. local time, the fire erupted in the vessel's gallery. ![ROADRUNNER engulfed in fire at Dutch Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ROADRUNNER_7e4e7d92d1.png)*Freighter ROADRUNNER, image credit:bndestem.nl* Initially, two crewmembers attempted to extinguish the flames but were unsuccessful, prompting an emergency response. The fire brigade responded with the fireboat Furie 4, while additional fire engines from Dinteloord and Willemstad provided support from the shore. The blaze was eventually brought under control and extinguished. The captain of the vessel was transported to the hospital after he sustained burns on his upper arm and suffered smoke inhalation. Authorities have not yet released details on the extent of the damage or the cause of the fire. [Roadrunner](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6687654/mmsi:244000039/imo:0/vessel:ROADRUNNER) is a Netherlands-flagged vessel with a length of 51 metres and width of 6 metres.

headline: Inland Cargo Barge and Motor Tanker Involved in Kiel Canal Collision
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 4th May, the inland cargo barge [Tor Elbe](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3368261/mmsi:211505920/imo:0/vessel:TOR_ELBE#overview), en route from [Hamburg](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/172?name=HAMBURG&country=Germany) to [Brunsbüttel](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1497?name=BRUNSBUETTEL&country=Germany), collided with inland motor tanker [Daniel Deymann](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9228985/mmsi:211888330/imo:0/vessel:DANIEL_DEYMANN). The incident occurred within the Brunsbüttel lock on the Kiel Canal, Germany. ![TOR ELBE collided with inland tanker in Germany.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/TOR_ELBE_3113baa9b4.png)*Inland Vessel TOR ELBE, image credit:Instagram/salvage_and_wreck* Preliminary reports indicate that both the German-flagged vessels sustained minor injuries in the incident. The cause of the incident remained under investigation. No injuries or pollution were reported. Tor Elbe is a 90 metres long and 9 metres board cargo barge currently moored at [Brunsbüttel](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1497?name=BRUNSBUETTEL&country=Germany).

headline: Towboat Accidents Disrupt Traffic on Mississippi River Bridge
author: Raghib Raza
content: Two towboats collided with the Old Highway 80 Bridge over the Mississippi River, USA, in separate incidents within five days, prompting inspection and temporary closure. ![MYRA ECKSTEIN collided with old bridge in Mississippi.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MYRA_ECKSTEIN_1ec27a8617.png)*Vessel MYRA ECKSTEIN, image credit: Arthur Netteler* The latest incident occurred on 5th May. The towboat [Myra Eckstein](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:448048/mmsi:367505510/imo:0/vessel:MYRA_ECKSTEIN) collided with pier number 4 of the Old Highway 80 Bridge while pushing 25 barges loaded with grain downstream. Local news reports stated that the lead barge hit the pier and subsequently broke free, along with four additional barges. Of these, three barges drifted downstream, while another struck pier number 5 before also floating away. One barge sustained hull damage and sank shortly thereafter. Authorities confirmed no barges impacted the nearby interstate bridge. This followed a similar incident that took place on 1st May involving [Rickey Hughes](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:435705/mmsi:367057330/imo:0/vessel:RICKEY_HUGHES), which lost its steering after a mechanical failure while navigating downstream. The lead barge struck pier number 4 of the same bridge, resulting in the tow breaking apart. Several barges drifted downstream, while one remained lodged against the pier. The bridge was temporarily closed and reopened the same day after inspections confirmed no structural damage. No injuries were reported in either of the incidents. Following the 5th May collision, the traffic on the bridge has been suspended pending a structural assessment. An investigation into the incident has been launched by the Coast Guard.

headline: One Dead and One Missing as Passenger Ship Sinks in Indonesia
author: Raghib Raza
content: One crew member has been declared dead, and one is still missing in an accident involving the sinking of the passenger vessel [KMP.Muchlisa](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6698363/mmsi:525004042/imo:7930462/vessel:KMP_MUCHLISA) is in the East Kalimantan province in Indonesia. The incident occurred at around 12:00 AM WITA on 5th May. ![KMP.MUCHLISA sank after engine problem in Indonesia.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KMP_MUCHLISA_ecd572de3f.png)*Vessel KMP.MUCHLISA, image credit: husni* The [KMP.Muchlisa](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6698363/mmsi:525004042/imo:7930462/vessel:KMP_MUCHLISA) had managed to sail for around 30 minutes from the port of Kariangau when the crew realized that there were engine problems on the vessel, in addition to there being a leak letting in water. As the vessel continued to take in water, it tilted to the starboard side and ended up sinking to a depth of around 20 meters. A total of 44 people were on the vessel at the time of its sinking, including 21 crew members and 23 passengers. Forty-two people have been rescued, one crew member has been confirmed to be dead, and another crew member is still missing. The search and rescue effort is still ongoing. The [KMP.Muchlisa](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6698363/mmsi:525004042/imo:7930462/vessel:KMP_MUCHLISA) is an Indonesian-flagged passenger vessel that was built in 1980. The vessel has a length of 44.4 meters and a gross tonnage of 725.

headline: Norway-flagged Tanker Allides with Brunsbuttel Lock Wall in Kiel Canal
author: Raghib Raza
content: The CO2 tanker [Embla](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:304144/mmsi:257082000/imo:9279446/vessel:EMBLA) allided with the center wall of a Brunsbüttel lock in the Kiel Canal, Germany. The collision is reported to have caused minor damage to the lock wall, and no injuries or pollution have been reported in the incident. ![EMBLA allided with the center wall of a Brunsbüttel lock in Germany.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/EMBLA_15cdc181bb.png)*Vessel EMBLA, image credit: Trevor Bruford* The incident occurred on May 5th at around 1:25 PM local time. The vessel Embla was sailing from Kiel to Hamburg when it allided with a wall on the new southern lock in Brunsbüttel as it was traversing the Kiel Canal. The wall of the lock is said to have sustained minor damage, and the vessel itself suffered scraped paint. Fortunately, the damage was minor, and there were no reports of any injuries, pollution, or water ingress on the vessel. The Brunsbüttel water police have launched an investigation into the incident. The [Embla](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:304144/mmsi:257082000/imo:9279446/vessel:EMBLA) is a Norwegian-flagged CO2 tanker that was built in 2005. The vessel has a length of 82.5 meters, a beam of 12.6 meters, and a gross tonnage of 2,506.

headline: Fire Aboard the Passenger Ship at Norway Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire broke out in the engine room of the passenger ship [Vollsøy](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:311426/mmsi:258226000/imo:9237993/vessel:VOLLSOY) on the afternoon of 6th May. The fire was quickly brought under control, and there have been no injuries reported in the incident. ![Fire aboard VOLLSOY at Norway Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/VOLLSOY_54bff508a2.png)*Vessel VOLLSOY, image credit: Geir Vinnes* The incident took place when the vessel was at the Mekjarvik port. The source of the fire is reported to be a generator situated in the engine room of the vessel. The emergency services responded quickly. The police arrived on the scene at around 2:00 PM local time, shortly after the fire department. The fire was extinguished by 2:30 PM local time. Although a large amount of smoke was seen emanating from the engine room of the vessel, fortunately, there were no injuries in the incident. The ferry was reportedly docked for maintenance at the time of the fire, and the extent of the damage is still unclear. An investigation has been launched into the incident, and it is currently being speculated that a technical failure is the likely cause of the fire.

headline: Inland Freighter Hits Moored River Cruise Ships on Rhine River
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 8th May, the inland motor freighter [Carisma](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:220205/mmsi:244010927/imo:0/vessel:CARISMA) allided with two Viking river cruise ships on the Rhine River in Cologne, Germany. No injuries or pollution were reported. ![CARISMA allided with moored river cruise ships in Germany.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CARISMA_1d14b8ba88.png)*Inland Freighter CARISMA, image credit: Ewout Jager* The incident occurred at around 08:00 UTC, when the vessel [Carisma](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:220205/mmsi:244010927/imo:0/vessel:CARISMA), operating in combination with another unit, became disconnected and collided with the moored cruise vessels. The force of the impact caused several mooring lines on the berthed ships to part. No significant structural damage was reported in the incident. [Carisma](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:220205/mmsi:244010927/imo:0/vessel:CARISMA) is a 1998-built freighter sailing under the flag of the Netherlands.

headline: Gasum's LNG Bunker Vessel “Kairos” to Offset Emissions of Other Vessels in Pooling Service
author: Raghib Raza
content: Gasum's LNG bunker vessel [Kairos](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5625363/mmsi:209275000/imo:9819882/vessel:KAIROS) will act as an emissions offset for other vessels in Gasum's FuelEU maritime pooling service. The vessel will run on waste-based bio-LNG and generate compliance for vessels that are unable to meet the EU's stringent emission reduction standards. ![KAIROS.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KAIROS_e3c52b164c.png)*Vessel KAIROS, image credit: Gasum* Gasum's FuelEU maritime pooling service is designed to help shipowners comply with the new FuelEU Maritime regulation, which mandates that vessels limit their greenhouse gas emissions. The regulations require vessels to reduce the carbon intensity of fuel purchased by two percent starting from 2025, with the reduction increasing to 80% by 2050. FuelEU Maritime allows vessels to voluntarily pool their emissions, allowing emissions to be assessed collectively rather than individually. This enables highly compliant vessels like [Kairos](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5625363/mmsi:209275000/imo:9819882/vessel:KAIROS) to offset the emissions of less efficient ships, effectively providing compliance as a service. The Kairos is an LNG bunker vessel with a dual-fuel engine that is able to operate on conventional fuel as well as LNG. In addition, using bio-LNG grants the vessel the ability to guarantee emission reductions to the pool. The[ Kairos](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5625363/mmsi:209275000/imo:9819882/vessel:KAIROS) is a Cyprus-flagged bunker tanker that was built in 2018. It has a length of 117.07 metres, a beam of 20 metres, and a gross tonnage of 8,070.

headline: Malta-Flagged Containership Damages Quay and Crane in Hamburg
author: Raghib Raza
content: The containership [CMA CGM Ermitage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8790576/mmsi:256800000/imo:9961295/vessel:CMA_CGM_ERMITAGE) collided with the quay wall while traversing the Elbe River in Hamburg, Germany, on 11th May. No pollution or injuries were reported. ![CMA CGM ERMITAGE collided with the quay wall in Germany.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CMA_CGM_ERMITAGE_a4f8013966.png)*Vessel CMA CGM ERMITAGE, image credit: S.Seelemann* The incident occurred at around midday when the [CMA CGM Ermitage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8790576/mmsi:256800000/imo:9961295/vessel:CMA_CGM_ERMITAGE) was en route from Bremerhaven to Hamburg. The vessel had to steer hard to avoid a collision with a small motor yacht and ended up colliding with the quay wall. The vessel damaged the quay wall and a gantry crane in the collision. The [CMA CGM Ermitage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8790576/mmsi:256800000/imo:9961295/vessel:CMA_CGM_ERMITAGE) is a Malta-flagged container ship built in 2024. The vessel has a length of 204.2 metres, a beam of 29.6 metres, and a gross tonnage of 32,245.

headline: First Cruise Ship bunkering with LNG carried out in Vancouver Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Vancouver Port Authority has reached a historic milestone with the first-ever LNG (liquefied natural gas) bunkering of a cruise ship. ![SILVER NOVA bunkered at Vancouver Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SILVER_NOVA_b973d1471b.png)*Vessel SEASPAN GARIBALDI, image credit: Seaspan* The bunker vessel [Seaspan Garibaldi](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8842777/mmsi:352004278/imo:9974319/vessel:SEASPAN_GARIBALDI) carried out the bunkering, and the fuel was provided via a ship-to-ship transfer to Silversea Cruises' vessel, [Silver Nova](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7752116/mmsi:311001189/imo:9886213/vessel:SILVER_NOVA#overview) at [Vancouver Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/682?name=VANCOUVER&country=Canada), Canada. The bunkering was carried out as the cruise vessel was set to depart for Alaska. The Vancouver Port Authority played a central role in accrediting Seaspan Energy to operate within the port in 2024 and in facilitating the transfer. The accreditation was granted after a rigorous safety and risk assessment. Seaspan Energy currently operates three ship-to-ship LNG bunkering vessels on North America's West Coast. The port has had biofuels available for vessels for a long time, but this particular bunkering of LNG marks the introduction of a possible replacement for diesel and other traditional fuels used aboard vessels. The milestone is expected to pave the way for the adoption of other alternative fuels, such as methanol and ammonia.

headline: River Cruise Ship Bijou du Rhône Collides with Barge in France
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 10th May, a major collision occurred on the Rhone River involving the river cruise ship [Bijou Du Rhône](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3842284/mmsi:249358000/imo:0/vessel:BIJOU_DU_RHONE#overview) and a barge. ![BIJOU DU RHONE collided with a barge in France river.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BIJOU_DU_RHONE_56ac553262.png)*River cruise ship BIJOU DU RHONE, image credit:ledauphine.com* At approximately 1:30 Am local time, [Bijou Du Rhône](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3842284/mmsi:249358000/imo:0/vessel:BIJOU_DU_RHONE#overview), carrying 127 German tourist passengers and 39 crewmembers, collided with the barge near the commune of Sablons, about fifty kilometers south of Lyon, France. No injuries were reported among the passengers or the crew onboard. The impact above the waterline caused a significant hole in the ship’s hull but did not pose an immediate risk of sinking. The barge also sustained damage in the incident. Following the collision, the [Bijou Du Rhône](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3842284/mmsi:249358000/imo:0/vessel:BIJOU_DU_RHONE#overview) was immobilized over the weekend for inspection and safety assessments. The passengers and crew of the ship were expected to be evacuated and transported to their destination by bus on Sunday.

headline: Inland Vessel Suffers Fire Damage During Welding Works
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 12th May, a fire broke out aboard the Inland vessel [Gulf Stream](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:112198/mmsi:205364690/imo:0/vessel:GULF_STREAM) moored at the Kalkhaven in [Dordrecht](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1826?name=DORDRECHT&country=Netherlands), Netherlands. The incident occurred at around 7:30 AM local time when the welding operation was being carried out on the vessel. ![GULF STREAM experienced fire in Netherlands.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GULF_STREAM_26a12e5f12.png)*Inland vessel GULF STREAM, image credit: Rene te Pas* Emergency services promptly responded, with the fire brigade arriving at the scene with two fire engines. The fire was extinguished, and no injuries were reported. However, the vessel did sustain damage as a result of the fire. [Gulf Stream](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:112198/mmsi:205364690/imo:0/vessel:GULF_STREAM) is a Belgium-flagged vessel with an overall length of 85 metres and a width of 8 metres.

headline: Container Vessel MSC Antonia Grounded in Red Sea; GPS spoofing Suspected
author: Raghib Raza
content: The container vessel [MSC Antonia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:686442/mmsi:636018660/imo:9398216/vessel:MSC_ANTONIA#overview) ran aground in the Red Sea off Jeddah and has remained stationary since 10th May. Although MSC has not made any statement regarding the damage to the vessel or how it deviated from its charted path, GPS spoofing is suspected to be the cause of the incident. ![MSC ANTONIA grounded near Jeddah.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSC_ANTONIA_adfe866138.png)*Vessel MSC ANTONIA, image credit: Hannes Van Rijn* The vessel made a port call in [Port Sudan ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1679?name=PORT-SUDAN&country=Sudan)and was bound for [Jeddah](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/807?name=JEDDAH&country=Saudi-Arabia), Saudi Arabia at the time of the incident. As of now, the vessel remains grounded approximately 100 nautical miles off the coast of Jeddah. GPS spoofing is a cyberattack technique in which false GPS signals are sent to receivers, leading them to misinterpret their location. Such manipulation can disrupt navigation and mislead vessels off their course. It is being speculated that the vessel was a victim of GPS spoofing, which caused it to lose its charted path and run aground. Further cementing the possibility of a GPS spoofing attack is the fact that the UK Maritime Trade Operations (UKMTO) posted a warning on May 9th regarding incidents of multiple vessels experiencing electronic interference and disruptions while traveling in the Red Sea around the areas of Jeddah, Saudi Arabia, and Port Sudan.

headline: NYK Group Takes Delivery of Methanol Dual-Fuel Bulk Carrier
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 13th May, Japanese shipping company NYK Group took delivery and celebrated the naming ceremony of a new methanol dual-fuel bulk carrier “[Green Future](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9437111/mmsi:636024911/imo:9993224/vessel:GREEN_FUTURE#overview)”. The cargo vessel was delivered by Tsuneishi Shipbuilding Co., Ltd. at its Tsuneishi Factory in Japan. ![GREEN FUTURE delivered to NYK Line.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GREEN_FUTURE_02a207561d.png)*Vessel GREEN FUTURE, image credit: NYK Line* [Green Future](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9437111/mmsi:636024911/imo:9993224/vessel:GREEN_FUTURE#overview) is chartered by NYK Bulk & Projects Carriers Ltd., a subsidiary of the NYK Group. It is the first carrier in the NYK Group fleet to be equipped with a dual-fuel engine capable of operating on both conventional fuel oil and methanol. It is also equipped with Tsuneishi’s proprietary Aeroline technology, which is designed to reduce wind resistance. This new ship marks a step forward in NYK’s efforts to reduce its environmental impact and move toward more sustainable shipping solutions. The Liberian-flagged cargo vessel measures 200 metres in length and 32 metres in width. Its deadweight is approximately 35,700 metric tons, and it can carry about 81,500 cubic metres of cargo.

headline: Navigating the Complexities of Maritime Sanctions: An April 2025 Overview
author: Dimitris Ampatzidis
content: # Overview April 2025 marked a strategic escalation in maritime sanctions enforcement, as regulators transitioned from asset-focused actions to dismantling broader ownership and logistics networks. The month saw over $1.7billion in crude flows tied to newly sanctioned vessels and companies, most with links to Iranian commodity trades. Authorities intensified scrutiny of reflagging practices and ship management firms, with emerging registries like Curacao and Guyana becoming central vectors of risk. Kpler’s proprietary data highlighted these shifts in advance, flagging 63 operational and 51 management-related risk events tied to sanctioned entities. # Key takeaways $1.7billion in sanctioned cargo moved in 2025 alone, tied to 41 vessels blacklisted in April. US, UK, and EU actions expanded to penalize ship operators and ownership networks, not just flagged vessels. Flags of convenience surged, with Panama, Barbados, and Guyana accounting for a growing share of sanctioned ships. Kpler flagged 114 high-risk behaviors across sanctioned entities before regulatory actions - reinforcing the value of predictive risk intelligence. Over 12% of the ships we identified back in February ([MarineTraffic](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/maritime-news/34/risk-and%20compliance/2025/11896/predicting-sanctions-in-maritime-trade-leveraging-data-on-da)) as likely to be sanctioned in 2025 have already been sanctioned by the authorities. # Market Analysis April 2025 saw sanctions enforcement tighten around maritime trade and strategic commodities. In the U.S., OFAC updated its maritime sanctions advisory, sharpening guidance to detect Iranian oil evasion across a growing “shadow fleet” of tankers ([U.S. Department of the Treasury](https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sb0113#:~:text=subsequently%20re,mitigating%20Iranian%20oil%20sanctions%20evasion)). The month also brought new OFAC designations targeting vessels that delivered refined petroleum to Yemen’s Houthi-controlled ports after a humanitarian exemption lapsed ([U.S. Department of the Treasury](https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sb0113#:~:text=In%20conjunction%20with%20the%20re,license%20on%20April%204%2C%202025)). Three tankers and their owners were blacklisted for supporting the Houthis – an Iranian-aligned group known to deploy mines and drones against Red Sea shipping, threatening global navigation ([U.S. Department of the Treasury](https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sb0113#:~:text=to%20Ansarallah%2C%20commonly%20known%20as,discharge%20of%20refined%20petroleum%20products)). These actions underscore heightened compliance risks for shippers, as even post-conflict relief shipments (like fuel into Yemen) face scrutiny once licenses expire. UK and EU authorities similarly advanced measures targeting illicit maritime networks and commodity flows. In late April, the UK implemented a new sanctions package that not only added tech export bans (including oil & gas exploration software) but also intensified pressure on Russia’s energy exports ([Gov UK](https://www.legislation.gov.uk/uksi/2025/504/made)). London has now specified dozens of “shadow fleet” oil tankers for sanctions – bringing the total number of Russian-linked tankers under UK sanctions to 133, the most in Europe ([Gov UK](https://www.gov.uk/government/news/uk-announces-largest-sanctions-package-against-russia-since-2022?utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=govuk-notifications-topic&utm_source=0a23ba4c-3ee7-47fb-99a6-eafd6be6fa2a&utm_content=immediately#:~:text=The%20new%20sanctions%20will%20put,of%20any%20nation%20in%20Europe)). Brussels’ parallel 16th sanctions package (effective late February) banned EU port access and services for an additional 74 vessels involved in covert Russian oil shipments ([European Council](https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/policies/sanctions-against-russia/timeline-sanctions-against-russia/)). These coordinated UK/EU steps are reshaping global shipping patterns, forcing sanctioned or high-risk ships to rely on non-Western ports and insurers. While the United Nations did not announce new sanctions in April, UN-backed embargoes (for example on arms and oil transfers in conflicts like Yemen and North Korea) continue to influence the maritime domain. Overall, regulators on both sides of the Atlantic are signaling zero tolerance for sanctions evasion at sea, tightening the compliance screws on oil, gas, grain, metals and other key trade flows going into Q2 2025. Implications for the Shipping Industry In April 2025, 41 new vessels and 20 new companies were added to official sanctions lists. These 41 vessels were involved in over 79 million barrels of oil transfers in 2024, and more than 21 million barrels just in the first four months of the year. The 20 companies were directly or indirectly linked to more than 43 vessels that already showed serious risk signs before the sanctions — including over 63 operational risks (like turning off tracking systems, spoofing, or dark ship-to-ship transfers) and 51 management risks. ![Picture1.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture1_28eb3d6dbe.png) **Graph 1.** _Sanctioned vessels and companies through the last five years (April 2020 to April 2025) - Kpler._ The graph illustrates a steady rise in the number of sanctioned vessels and companies since 2020, with a particularly sharp uptick visible in April 2025. This coincides with OFAC’s April 2025 designations targeting vessels involved in transporting Iranian-origin bitumen and HSFO, as well as the associated ship management firms, including GLORY INTERNATIONAL FZLLC and PRIME TANKERS LLC. The surge reflects a regulatory shift toward targeting operational networks - rather than just individual ships - by penalizing beneficial owners, ISM managers, and technical operators. The pronounced increase in April suggests a sweeping enforcement round, which aligns with broader Western efforts to dismantle opaque maritime networks engaged in sanctions evasion, especially those supporting Iran’s shadow exports. This escalation reinforces the mounting compliance burden on industry actors as due diligence requirements now extend beyond vessel activity to the full management and ownership chain. ![Picture2.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture2_8432caf522.png) **Graph 2.** _Sanctioned vessels per top 10 flag registry through the last two years (April 2023 to April 2025) - Kpler._ The stacked area chart illustrates a sharp increase in the number of sanctioned vessels by flag state, with a notable acceleration starting in late 2024 and peaking in April 2025. While Iran and Russia continue to account for the largest share, the most significant growth in April stems from a broader proliferation of other flags - including Panama, Barbados, Guyana, Curacao, and Sao Tome and Principe. This reflects a clear shift in evasion tactics, where sanctioned or high-risk vessels increasingly reflag to less scrutinized registries. The spike aligns with April 2025 designations by OFAC and aligned regulators, which targeted shadow fleet operators engaged in dark ship-to-ship (STS) transfers, sanctioned cargo movements (notably Iranian bitumen and Russian petroleum products), and vessels managed by blacklisted entities like GLORY INTERNATIONAL FZLLC. The diversification in flags also signals the need for enhanced due diligence, as risk exposure is no longer confined to traditionally sanctioned registries but is now diffused across a wider geopolitical landscape. ![Picture3.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture3_e3f72cfa94.png) **Graph 3.** _Total vessels and companies added to sanctions lists over the last twelve months (May 2024 to April 2025) - Kpler._ The bar chart shows monthly designations of sanctioned vessels and companies between May 2024 and April 2025. April 2025 reflects a modest resurgence in vessel designations following a relative dip in March, with over 40 vessels and around 15 companies sanctioned. This uptick aligns with OFAC’s April actions that targeted maritime actors linked to Iranian oil and bitumen exports, as well as new compliance risks related to STS transfers and AIS manipulation. While the peak of enforcement was observed in January 2025 - driven by sweeping sanctions packages related to Russian petroleum logistics and Iranian dark fleet operators - the activity in April demonstrates that regulators remain active in scrutinizing deceptive maritime practices. The sustained designation of companies, including ship managers and operators, underscores the ongoing trend of targeting the organizational structures enabling sanctions evasion, a pattern that has intensified since Q4 2024 and is expected to persist. The 41 vessels sanctioned in April 2025 had transported over 79 million barrels of oil in 2024 and more than 21 million barrels in just the first four months of 2025. At an average Brent crude price of $83/bbl in 2024 and $82/bbl in Q1 2025, these flows equate to a total cargo value exceeding $6.5 billion for 2024 and an additional $1.7 billion so far in 2025 - bringing the combined value of sanctioned flows to approximately $8.2 billion in just over 16 months. # Conclusion Throughout April 2025, enforcement actions by OFAC continued to target entities linked to Iranian oil and bitumen exports. Several vessels - Global Eagle, Global Maharani, and Global Genesis - remained under OFAC sanctions for their involvement in transporting sanctioned cargo, including items classified under HS code 271490 (bitumen/asphalt), with multiple voyages originating in Iran. These cargo movements are explicitly restricted under measures imposed by OFAC, the UK’s OFSI, and the EU Commission’s sanctions framework against Iran. Moreover, there is notable evidence of increased high-risk activity through ship-to-ship (STS) operations. Global Eagle alone engaged in multiple high-risk STS transfers during April, including an STS with Global Maharani on April 22 off the coast of Mormugao, involving over 11,700 tonnes of suspected sanctioned product. While no dark STS events were recorded during this month, such frequent and high-volume STS pairings - particularly when coupled with AIS gaps - highlight elevated compliance concerns. Vessels such as Glory Star 1 and Global Genesis also exhibited AIS manipulation patterns or extended offline periods, particularly near high-risk jurisdictions such as Iran and the United Arab Emirates, suggesting potential spoofing or obfuscation of location data. The repeated involvement of sanctioned ship management entities - most notably GLORY INTERNATIONAL FZLLC - as ISM, commercial, and technical managers across several vessels reaffirms coordinated attempts to circumvent maritime sanctions enforcement. These findings coincide with OFAC’s April 2025 listings that targeted vessels and operators engaging in deceptive practices designed to support Iranian commodity flows. While enforcement bodies did not announce additional sanctions programs during April, the expansion of existing designations to vessel operators underlines the shift in regulatory scrutiny from assets to networks. For insurers and compliance analysts, April 2025 highlights the growing complexity of sanctions evasion and the rising risk exposure tied to vessel and company networks. With over $1.7 billion in sanctioned cargo moved in just the first four months of the year - much of it linked to Iranian and Russian flows - traditional due diligence is no longer sufficient. Kpler’s Risk & Compliance platform empowers users to stay ahead of enforcement by surfacing high-risk behaviors such as AIS spoofing, repeated dark STS activity, and ties to sanctioned management firms. As regulators broaden their focus to include entire operational ecosystems, early detection is essential to safeguarding portfolios, clients, and reputations across the maritime supply chain. To find out more about Kpler’s Risk & Compliance offering, visit [here](https://www.kpler.com/demos/risk-compliance-demo?utm_source=website&utm_medium=blog&utm_campaign=risk&compliance_commodities_maritime_news_demo_request).

headline: Port of Gothenburg Leads in Decarbonizing Shipping with First Local Biomethane Bunkering
author: Raghib Raza
content: The [Port of Gothenburg](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/350?name=GOTEBORG&country=Sweden) in Sweden announced on 15th May the successful completion of a bunkering operation involving domestically produced liquefied biomethane. This pioneering initiative is the outcome of a collaboration between key players in the energy and transport sectors, including St1 Sverige AB, St1 Biokraft, Nordion Energi, Terntank, and Litra AS. ![Gothenburg Port Pioneers Domestic Maritime Biofuel Supply Chain.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/GOTHENBURG_PORT_45aad175a8.png)*Port GOTHENBURG, image credit: Port of Gothenburg* The [Tern Ocean](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4838608/mmsi:219008000/imo:9747986/vessel:TERN_OCEAN), an oil/chemical tanker operated by Terntank, became the first vessel to receive the locally produced liquefied biomethane at the port of Gothenburg. The energy companies St, St1 and Nordion Energi supplied liquefied biomethane to the vessel making a successful pilot operation and a milestone for decarbonizing shipping in Northern Europe. St1 and St1 Biokraft plan to become large-scale suppliers of liquefied biomethane by 2026 and are planning to build new production facilities in different parts of Sweden. Additionally, Nordion Energi intends to develop a biomethane liquefaction facility at the port, linked to the West Sweden gas grid, expanding access to maritime biofuel solutions.

headline: Spain’s First Triple LNG Bunkering Completed by Balearia in Barcelona
author: Raghib Raza
content: In a first for Spain, a shipping company bunkered three of its vessels with LNG on the same day at the same port. The shipping company Balearia made the announcement on 14th May of having successfully completed the ambitious operation and reiterated their commitment to reducing the carbon footprint of their company. ![MARTIN I SOLER and other two vessel bunkered simultaneously at Spain Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MARTIN_I_SOLER_d34c34d31c.png)*Vessel MARTIN I SOLER, image credit: Balearia* The operation involved eight bunker tankers providing fuel to three of Balearia's vessels at the port of [Barcelona](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/236?name=BARCELONA&country=Spain). The three vessels, namely the Fast Ferry [Margarita Salas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8839048/mmsi:210012000/imo:9969730/vessel:MARGARITA_SALAS#overview), the Ferry [Martin I Soler](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:167746/mmsi:224637000/imo:9390367/vessel:MARTIN_I_SOLER), and the Ferry [Bahama Mama](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:167486/mmsi:210567000/imo:9441142/vessel:BAHAMA_MAMA), were supplied with a total of 2,320 MWh worth of LNG. The bunkering operation involved three tankers simultaneously supplying fuel to the [Margarita Salas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8839048/mmsi:210012000/imo:9969730/vessel:MARGARITA_SALAS#overview), two tankers supplying fuel to the [Martin I Soler](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:167746/mmsi:224637000/imo:9390367/vessel:MARTIN_I_SOLER), and finally, the last three tankers supplying fuel to the [Bahama Mama](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:167486/mmsi:210567000/imo:9441142/vessel:BAHAMA_MAMA). Balearia stated that this operation marked the first time in Spain's history when three separate bunkering operations were conducted on the same day within the same port. Balearia further stated that they have grown their commitment to LNG by 184% in 2024 alone and have managed to reduce their carbon footprint by 10% per passenger thus far.

headline: Engine Room Fire Destroys Tugboat “Julie” in Paraguay; No Injuries Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: A severe fire engulfed the tugboat [Julie](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:14464/mmsi:755241000/imo:0/vessel:JULIE) near the Remanso Bridge over the Paraguay River on 15th May, prompting a quick response from the emergency service. ![Tugboat JULIE caught fire in Paraguay water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/JULIE_4e920cf26c.png)*Tugboat JULIE, image credit:ultimahora.com* [Julie](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:14464/mmsi:755241000/imo:0/vessel:JULIE), a Paraguayan-flagged push tugboat owned by Brazilian company LHG Mining, was completely destroyed in the blaze. All the 10 crewmembers were safely evacuated by Paraguayan Volunteer Firefighters. No injuries were reported in the incident. The fire reportedly erupted from the engine room and quickly spread throughout the tugboat, triggering multiple explosions due to the presence of flammable materials on board. The tugboat had oil drums, electronic equipment, and approximately 250,000 liters of fuel for its own consumption. Firefighters managed to bring the blaze under control while the cooling efforts continued to prevent the risk of re-ignition from the remaining cargo onboard. Authorities have launched an investigation to determine the cause of the fire.

headline: Cargo Ship “FWN Sun” Rescues Crew from Burning Trawler Off France
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 13th May, the France-flagged trawler [Ablette](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9233105/mmsi:227309000/imo:8884892/vessel:ABLETTE) caught fire approximately 222 kilometres west of Gironde, France. Two crewmembers were reportedly injured in the incident. ![FWN SUN rescued two crewmembers from burning trawler in French water.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/FWN_SUN_2af625390d.png)*Vessel FWN SUN, image credit: Jan Scheurwater* The 24.9-metre-long trawler reportedly suffered water ingress, which subsequently caused fire onboard. French authorities promptly responded to the distress call and dispatched multiple aircraft to the scene. Nearby vessels were also requested to assist the distressed trawler. A general cargo vessel, [FWN Sun](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4138782/mmsi:244770393/imo:9721669/vessel:FWN_SUN), sailing in the vicinity, responded to the call and successfully rescued the two crew members from the trawler. The rescued crew were later transferred to a Search and Rescue (SAR) helicopter. The injured crew was then taken to the hospital for medical treatment. No further details regarding the condition of the vessel or the nature of the fire have been released.

headline: Bulk Carrier ‘Trade’ Engulfed in Fire at Amsterdam’s Western Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: A major fire broke out aboard the bulk carrier [Trade](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5025327/mmsi:538008236/imo:9425942/vessel:TRADE#overview) in the Western Port Area of[ Amsterdam](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1766?name=AMSTERDAM&country=Netherlands), the Netherlands, in the afternoon of 15th May. The incident occurred while the vessel was carrying scrap metal. ![Fire aboard the vessel TRADE in Amsterdam.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/TRADE_59d634b07f.png)*Bulk carreir TRADE, image credit:at5.nl* At around 17:00 local time, the fire brigade was notified about the fire, prompting the deployment of heavy firefighting equipment and issuing four emergency alerts urging residents to close windows, doors, and switch off ventilation systems. A thick black smoke plume was visible over the part of the city. Although no harmful substances have been detected, authorities have reported widespread smoke, soot particles, and strong odors in the area. Specialized units from the Rotterdam region joined in the efforts. They used cranes to unload the scrap metal from the vessel's fire-raging compartment and extinguished it onshore. The remaining scrap in the hold was extinguished by the fire boat and ladder trucks. According to a fire department spokesperson, the fire's source lies deep within the ship, making it difficult to reach and allowing flames to reignite as more material is removed. The operation is expected to continue for several more hours. No casualties have been reported so far, and the cause of the fire remains unknown.

headline: Chimbusco Pan Nation Establishes New Record for Supplying the Largest Quantity of B24 Bunker Fuel
author: Raghib Raza
content: A leading bunkering supplier in Hong Kong, Chimbusco Pan Nation Petro-Chemical Co.,Ltd (CPN) broke the record for the largest supply of B24 biofuel bunkering in Hong Kong on 15th May. ![XIN LOS ANGELES bunkered with B24 biofuel in China](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/XIN_LOS_ANGELES_b8480232ee.png)*Vessel XIN LOS ANGELES, image credit: CPN* This bunkering involved the transfer of 6,300 tons of B24-VLSFO biofuel oil to the container vessel [Xin Los Angeles](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6677264/mmsi:477158700/imo:9307217/vessel:XIN_LOS_ANGELES). The Xin Los Angeles is a 2006-built container vessel registered in Hong Kong, operated by COSCO, with a length of 336.7 meters, a beam of 45.64 meters, and a gross tonnage of 108,069. This record-breaking operation surpasses the company’s previous benchmark of 5,500 metric tonnes, set in February 2025. B24 is a marine biofuel blend made up of 24% waste cooking oil derivative and 76% Very Low Sulfur Fuel Oil (VLSFO). The blend significantly reduces greenhouse gas emissions compared to conventional VLSFO. It also enables shipowners and operators to comply with international regulations, including the IMO decarbonization targets, the EU Emissions Trading System (EU ETS), and the Fuel EU Maritime requirements.

headline: MSV Salamath Sinks off India’s West Coast; Indian Coast Guard Rescues Six
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Indian-flagged vessel [MSV Salamath](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:656597/mmsi:419801370/imo:0/vessel:MSV_SALAMATH) sank approximately 60 nautical miles southwest off the coast of India, in the Arabian Sea, on 14th May. All six crew members were rescued successfully by the Indian Coast Guard (ICG). ![MSV SALAMATH crew rescued by Indian Coast Guard.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSV_SALAMATH_6fb5cf9e9b.png)*Vessel MSV SALAMATH, image credit: Indian Coast Guard* On 14th May at around 5:30 am IST, [MSV Salamath](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:656597/mmsi:419801370/imo:0/vessel:MSV_SALAMATH) encountered rough seas and was struck by a powerful wave, causing the vessel to sink. However, the exact cause of the incident is yet to be confirmed by the authorities. Following the sinking of the 28-metre-long [MSV Salamath](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:656597/mmsi:419801370/imo:0/vessel:MSV_SALAMATH), the crew abandoned the vessel and took refuge in a small boat. At around 12:15 pm IST, the same day, the ICG received a distressed alert from the transiting LPG Tanker[ Epic Susui ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3623600/mmsi:566481000/imo:9713612/vessel:EPIC_SUSUI)reporting that a small boat with six individuals aboard was drifting in the sea. The ICG ship Vikram, which was patrolling the region, promptly arrived at the area and rescued all the crewmembers from the small boat. First aid was administered on board. On 15th May, all the rescued crewmembers were safely transported to the Mangalore port. [MSV Salamath](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:656597/mmsi:419801370/imo:0/vessel:MSV_SALAMATH), carrying a cargo of cement and construction materials, departed New Mangalore Port on 12th May, en route to Kadmat Island in Lakshadweep on 18th May.

headline: Engine Room Fires Break Out on Two Docked Vessels in Puerto Rico
author: Raghib Raza
content: Two consecutive fires on vessels docked in Puerto Rico are being investigated by the US Coast Guard. A fire broke out in the engine room of the passenger vessel [Breezy Point](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5576776/mmsi:368037610/imo:0/vessel:BREEZY_POINT) on 17th May as it was docked at a pier, and in a separate incident, the next day, on 18th May, a fire broke out in the engine room of the product tanker [Scot Stuttgart](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:758542/mmsi:538011215/imo:9274549/vessel:SCOT_STUTTGART). Fortunately, no injuries or pollution have been reported in either of the incidents. ![Fire aboard SCOT STUTTGART and BREEZY POINT in Puerto Rico](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SCOT_STUTTGART_5e238c58dd.png)*Vessel SCOT STUTTGART, image credit: Wolfgang Berthel* The first incident occurred around 9:15 PM local time at Vieques Pier in Puerto Rico. Watchstanders at Sector San Juan received reports of an engine room fire that broke out in the [Breezy Point](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5576776/mmsi:368037610/imo:0/vessel:BREEZY_POINT)'s port-side engine room. The fire broke out aboard the vessel after its arrival from Ceiba with passengers on board. The initial attempts of the crew of the [Breezy Point ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5576776/mmsi:368037610/imo:0/vessel:BREEZY_POINT)with handheld fire extinguishers failed, but they managed to extinguish the fire with the vessel's built-in fire suppression system. All passengers were evacuated, and no injuries were reported in the incident. The second fire occurred on 18th May within the engine room of the products tanker [Scot Stuttgart](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:758542/mmsi:538011215/imo:9274549/vessel:SCOT_STUTTGART) while it was docked at Puerto Nuevo Channel's N Wharf in Puerto Rico. Sector San Juan watchstanders received a report of a fire breaking out in the port generator within the engine room of the vessel at around 3:43 AM local time. The crew utilized the vessel's fire suppression system to douse the fire. However, at around 5:55 AM, local time dense smoke was reportedly seen rising from the same site. The crew activated the vessel's fire suppression system again and successfully extinguished the fire. In both cases, fire department crews arrived on the scene and conducted a thorough assessment of all spaces aboard the vessels before deeming it safe. No injuries or pollution have been reported in either incident. The US Coast Guard Sector San Juan has opened an investigation into the separate incidents.

headline: Dutch Inland Vessel Ina XL Partially Sinks in Antwerp Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Netherlands-flagged inland vessel[ Ina XL](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6173280/mmsi:244139668/imo:0/vessel:INA_XL#overview) partially sank at the port of [Antwerp](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/117?name=ANTWERP&country=Belgium), Belgium on the evening of 16th May. No injuries were reported in connection with the incident. ![INA XL sank at Antwerp Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/INA_XL_4f4723477e.png)*Inland Vessel INA XL, image credit: Pieter Inpijn* The 22.6-metre-long vessel was moored near the Noordkasteel Bridge when it experienced sudden and uncontrolled water ingress, causing it to sink alongside the quay. The emergency service promptly responded, and divers were deployed to assist in refloating the vessel. The cause of the water ingress is yet to be known by the authorities.

headline: Two Killed and 22 Others Injured as Mexican Navy Training Vessel Allides with the Brooklyn Bridge
author: Raghib Raza
content: Two people were killed and 20 others were injured as the Mexican Navy's training vessel [Cuauhtémoc](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:404383/mmsi:345186001/imo:8107505/vessel:CUAUHTEMOC) allided with the Brooklyn Bridge, USA, on the night of 17th May. The vessel was traveling with recruits on a journey that marked the end of training for the cadets when it lost power. ![CUAUHTEMOC allided with the Brooklyn Bridge, USA](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CUAUHTEMOC_81c10b3030.png)*Vessel CUAUHTEMOC, image credit: NYC Fire Department* The incident occurred on the night of 17th May, at around 8:20 PM. It is believed that the loss of power moments before the incident led to a loss of maneuverability for the vessel, causing it to crash into the bridge. The vessel's 45-metres masts could not pass below the bridge, which only had a clearance of 41.1 metres. All three masts of the vessel broke off, and the cadets who were positioned on the masts are reported to have fallen down to the deck. It is still uncertain if these cadets, who suffered the fall, are among the two dead. Twenty more cadets were injured in the incident, of whom 11 are reported to be in a critical condition. A total of 277 cadets were reported to have been on board at the time of the incident. The Brooklyn Bridge was reopened after a preliminary investigation. The Police believe that a power cut and mechanical issues on the vessel caused the accident. The Mexican Navy's vessel [Cuauhtémoc](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:404383/mmsi:345186001/imo:8107505/vessel:CUAUHTEMOC) sets sail each year on a journey that marks the end of training for naval military school cadets. It has a length of 91 metres and a beam of 12 metres. The vessel first set sail in 1982, and this year, it had sailed off from the Acapulco Port on 6th April and was to make stops in multiple countries in the Caribbean and Europe, and finally dock in Iceland.

headline: Fishing Vessel Sinks Near Pedra Branca; 30 Rescued by Passing Bulk Carrier
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 20th May, the fishing vessel Pacific Memory II capsized approximately 27 kilometers northeast of Pedra Branca of Singapore Strait. Singapore's Maritime and Port Authority (MPA) confirmed that all thirty crewmembers of the fishing vessel were safely rescued. ![ANDROS SPIRIT rescue 30 fishing vessel crew from the Singapore SAR region.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ANDROS_SPIRIT_5ecccbe8af.png)*Bulk Carrier ANDROS SPIRIT, image credit: Turkishstraits Kenan Bulutoglu* At approximately 7:20 a.m. local time, the container ship [Cosco Development](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:690431/mmsi:477950300/imo:9472139/vessel:COSCO_DEVELOPMENT), sailing under the flag of Hong Kong, was en route to [Laem Chabang](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/465?name=LAEM-CHABANG&country=Thailand), Thailand reported the capsizing of the fishing vessel to Singapore's Maritime Rescue Coordination Centre (MRCC). In response, Singapore's MRCC swiftly issued navigational alerts, and requesting assistance from nearby vessels. The bulk carrier [Andros Spirit](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:214610/mmsi:636024445/imo:9592537/vessel:ANDROS_SPIRIT#overview), en route to [Huangpu](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2394?name=HUANGPU&country=China), China, responded to the emergency. The bulk carrier, sailing in the vicinity, shortly arrived at the site and rescued all thirty crewmembers of the fishing vessel from the water. The rescued individual of the fishing vessel will be disembark at Batam, Indonesia.

headline: High Speed Boat Carrying 289 Passengers Collides With Pier at Hong Kong Terminal
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 17th May, the high-speed boat [Universal MK2005](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:687301/mmsi:477385000/imo:9087594/vessel:UNIVERSAL_MK2005) collided with the pier at the Hong Kong-Macau Ferry Terminal in Sheung Wan, Hong Kong. The incident occurred around 3:30 p.m. local time, when the boat, carrying 289 passengers, was about to depart for Macau. ![UNIVERSAL MK2005 allided with pier in Hong Kong.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/UNIVERSAL_MK_2005_cb5aec6d9a.png)*High Speed Boat UNIVERSAL MK2005, image credit:gbcode.rthk.hk* The Hong Kong flagged boat immediately returned to dock after the collision. The boat sustained minor damage at its bow, which was later covered by a cloth. The Macau Marine and Water Bureau was informed about the incident. The Hong Kong Fire Service Department dispatched three ambulances to the scene for precaution. No injuries were reported, and the passengers were transferred to an alternative ferry. Despite the incident, the terminal remained operational. According to the ferry operator, TurboJET, a mechanical failure caused the vessel to lose power while still in Hong Kong waters, leading to a loss of control during berthing. Due to the required maintenance of the damaged boat, TurboJET cancelled three sailings on 18th May, including two from Hong Kong to Macau’s Taipa and Outer Harbour in the morning, and one return trip from Macau to Hong Kong in the afternoon.

headline: The First Ever Successful Methanol Bunkering Conducted at the Port of Amsterdam
author: Raghib Raza
content: The first successful methanol bunkering occurred at the Port of [Amsterdam](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1766?name=AMSTERDAM&country=Netherlands)'s TMA Installation terminal in Amerikahaven. The bunkering involved the offshore vessel [Boreas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9157281/mmsi:244832000/imo:9962304/vessel:BOREAS) receiving approximately 500 tons of green methanol from the Unibarge-operated vessel Chicago. ![BOREAS receive methanol fuel at Amsterdam port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BOREAS_1a357745c7.png)*Vessel BOREAS, image credit: Port of Amsterdam* The recipient of the fuel, [Boreas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9157281/mmsi:244832000/imo:9962304/vessel:BOREAS), is an offshore installation vessel operated by the Dutch offshore installation company Van Oord. It is flagged in the Netherlands and was built in 2024. The vessel is not only the largest offshore installation vessel, with a gross tonnage of 47,017, but it is also the first to be able to operate on methanol and has advanced emission control technologies. The powerful 6,000 kWh battery pack further reduces the vessel's emissions. The methanol used in this landmark bunkering was ISSC-certified green methanol, which has much lower lifecycle emissions than conventional methanol. OCI HyFuels supplied the 500 tons of this fuel. The advent of methanol bunkering has been welcomed at the port of Amsterdam as it synergizes well with their vision of becoming a multi-fuel port and achieving net-zero emissions. There are already a number of LNG suppliers offering their services at the port, and recently, a Hydrogen bunkering was also successfully carried out.

headline: Chevron’s BBLT Platform Hit by Fire During Maintenance; 17 Injured
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 20th May, a fire erupted aboard Chevron’s Benguela Belize Lobito Tomboco (BBLT) oil platform, approximately 97 kilometers offshore from the Cabinda coast. At approximately 0200 GMT, the blaze ignited on the basement deck of the multi-storey drilling and production platform located in the Block 14 concession of the BBLT platform. ![BBLT Oil Platform engulfed in fire off Angola coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BBLT_Oil_Platform_21fb4ad46b.png)*BBLT Oil Platform, image credit: Chevron* Seventeen individuals sustained injuries, including four who were seriously injured, in the fire incident. The U.S oil major, Chevron confirmed that all personnel have been accounted for, and no fatalities were reported. The National Agency for Petroleum, Gas, and Biofuels of Angola reported that all seventeen injured individuals have been brought onshore and are under medical supervision. The incident occurred when the BBLT was undergoing annual maintenance as part of a scheduled shutdown with all production at the site having ceased on 1st May. A joint investigation has been launched by Chevron and Angolan authorities to determine the cause of the fire aboard the oil platform.

headline: Container Ship Runs Aground Near Norwegian Shore, Escapes Hitting Residences
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 22nd May, the Cyprus-flagged container ship[ NCL Salten](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:123015/mmsi:209762000/imo:9252773/vessel:NCL_SALTEN#overview), with 16 crew members, ran aground in the Trondheimsfjord near Lauvset, Norway. ![NCL SALTEN ran aground Near Norwegian Shore.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/NCL_SALTEN_29aace174f.png)*Containership NCL SALTEN, image credit:aftonbladet.se* At 6:30 a.m. local time, the fire department and police arrived at the site and determined that the containership had narrowly missed the houses along the shoreline. The authorities confirmed that no damage occurred to nearby residential properties. No injuries or oil spills were reported in the incident. The Norwegian Coastal Administration attempted to refloat the containership at around 9 a.m. local time, but the effort was unsuccessful. The shipping company is currently arranging tug assistance and plans to make another attempt to free the ship during high tide later tonight. Following the incident, local police questioned the crew and informed them of a criminal suspicion. However, the specific nature of the suspicion has not been disclosed. Authorities continue to monitor the situation closely. [NCL Salten](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:123015/mmsi:209762000/imo:9252773/vessel:NCL_SALTEN#overview) is a 2002-built containership with a carrying capacity of 862 TEU. Marine Traffic data shows that the vessel is partially laden and had departed from [Averoy Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/20686?name=AVEROY&country=Norway), Norway on 21st May.

headline: Container Ship Collides with Russian Rescue Vessel in Neva River
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 20th May, a container ship collided with the Russian-flagged salvage/rescue vessel [Spasatel Karev](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:348698/mmsi:273357360/imo:9497531/vessel:SPASATEL_KAREV) while maneuvering during mooring operations in the waters of the Neva River. The incident occurred at berth No. 94 of OOO Basis Port in St. Petersburg, Russia. ![A containership collided with SPASATEL KAREV in Neva River,Russia.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SPASATEL_KAREV_264352a398.png)*Image credit:seanews.ru* No casualties or pollution were reported in the incident. Preliminary information suggests that adverse weather conditions may have contributed to the collision. Russia’s North-West Transport Prosecutor office launched an official investigation into the incident. The St. Petersburg Transport Prosecutor's Office is also conducting an inspection to assess compliance with water transport safety regulations. The authorities have not yet disclosed the name of the container ship involved in the incident.

headline: Mitsubishi Tests out Methane Slip Reduction Technology on LNG bunker vessel
author: Raghib Raza
content: Mitsubishi Heavy Industries is testing its new methane slip reduction technology, developed in collaboration with Daihatsu Infinearth aboard the LNG bunker vessel [KEYS Azalea](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8300751/mmsi:431023109/imo:9983542/vessel:KEYS_AZALEA). The demonstration is expected to reduce methane slip emissions from LNG-powered vessels by 70%. ![KEYS AZALEA.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KEYS_AZALEA_efac92beff.png)*Vessel KEYS AZALEA, image credit: kenro oshita* Mitsubishi Heavy Industries announced the testing of its new methane catalyst oxidation system on May 20th. The new system is being trialed aboard the LNG bunker vessel [KEYS Azalea](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8300751/mmsi:431023109/imo:9983542/vessel:KEYS_AZALEA), which was built in 2024 and is registered in Japan. The vessel has a length of 83 meters, a beam of 18 meters, and a gross tonnage of 4,744. It was built by Mitsubishi Shipbuilding and is currently operated by KEYS Bunkering West Japan. The new system involves a combination of catalyst design, shipboard integration, and engine optimization, and has yielded up to a 70% reduction in methane emissions in land-based tests. Mitsubishi expects similar success in its tests aboard the [KEYS Azalea](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8300751/mmsi:431023109/imo:9983542/vessel:KEYS_AZALEA), which are expected to continue for a whole year. LNG as a maritime fuel can emit up to 80% less nitrogen oxides and virtually eliminate the emission of sulfur oxides compared to conventional heavy fuel oil. LNG also reduces CO2 emissions by around 23%. However, engines that use LNG as a fuel are notorious for releasing unburned methane into the atmosphere, which is 28 times more potent as a greenhouse gas than CO2. Successful mitigation of the release of this methane into the atmosphere, known as "methane slip," would accelerate the maritime transition to LNG.

headline: Cargo Ship Capsizes at Norwegian Port of Hendvågen; All Crew Safe
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 23rd May, the Norwegian-flagged general cargo vessel [Torvang](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:309734/mmsi:257971000/imo:6902808/vessel:TORVANG) capsized while moored at the Hendvågen quay in Averøy, Norway. Fortunately, no injuries or pollution were reported during the incident. ![TORVANG capsize in Norway.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/TORVANG_91f8f37191.png)*Vessel TORVANG, image credit:tk.no* The incident of the vessel sinking was reported to the police at 11:25 AM. The police clarified that the vessel had five crewmembers, and all five of them had safely made it ashore. Two sailors were reported to have swam to shore after jumping into the sea, while the remaining three disembarked directly onto the quay. An ambulance was deployed at the scene, but no medical assistance was required. The Norwegian Coastal Administration took over the response effort. A fire and rescue service arrived on the scene, and a rescue vessel, RS Bergen Kreds, was dispatched to assist the distressed vessel. Although the vessel is reported to have no leaks, the fire department has laid down booms as a precaution. The cargo vessel had completed loading gravel at the Henda Pukk AS facility when it suddenly listed and tipped onto its side. As of now, the vessel’s cargo hold is believed to be half-filled with water. A sludge suction unit was ordered to pump out the water and help in stabilize the vessel.

headline: Cabin Fire Breaks Out on Cypriot-Flagged Passenger Ship Off Spanish Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: A fire broke out aboard the Ro-Ro/Passenger Ship [Rusadir](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6903141/mmsi:210329000/imo:9832119/vessel:RUSADIR#overview) on 21st May. The fire erupted in a cabin on Deck 9 approximately half an hour after the ship departed from [Melilla Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1125?name=MELILLA&country=Spain), Spain. No injuries or environmental pollution were reported. ![Fire aboard RUSADIR in Spain.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RUSADIR_24ea453a9b.png)*Ro-Ro/Passenger Ship RUSADIR, image credit: Bettina Rohbrecht* Upon activation of the fire alarm, passengers in the affected section were immediately evacuated to Deck 10 as a precaution. Crew members quickly brought the situation under control. Despite the ship being near the [Melilla port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1125?name=MELILLA&country=Spain), the captain opted to continue the journey after informing passengers that the fire had been fully contained and posed no further threat. [Rusadir](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6903141/mmsi:210329000/imo:9832119/vessel:RUSADIR#overview) is a 2022-built ship sailing under the flag of Cyprus. It has a carrying capacity of 43,130 gross tonnage, and measures 187.4 metres in length and 31.52 metres in width.

headline: Motor Freighter runs aground near the port of Stavoren, Netherlands
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Netherland-flagged inland motor freighter [Ilse-Marie](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6880374/mmsi:244750324/imo:0/vessel:ILSE_MARIE) ran aground on a sandbank near the port of [Stavoren](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2066?name=STAVOREN&country=Netherlands). The vessel has not been freed yet, and no injuries or pollution have been reported in the incident. ![ILSE MARIE ran aground in Netherlands.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ILSE_MARIE_df0b9cfb7b.png)*Inland motor Freighter ILSE MARIE, image credit:schuttevaer.nl* The incident occurred on the afternoon of 22nd May in front of the port of [Stavoren](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2066?name=STAVOREN&country=Netherlands). The vessel is reported to have been making efforts to pull itself free but has been unsuccessful so far. The Dutch government agency Rijkswaterstaat has arrived on the scene to monitor the situation and provide support to the distressed vessel. Initial reports suggest that there is no danger to the crew and no risk of pollution from the vessel. Although the exact cause of the vessel's grounding is yet unknown, it is suspected that the vessel ended up outside of its assigned shipping lane.
