Maritime traffic around the port of Stavoren is experiencing minor difficulties due to the vessel being stranded near a bustling port. It is still unclear how long the vessel will remain stranded, and a salvage company will be called if necessary.

headline: Engine Room Explosion Aboard Bulker Docked in Bluff, New Zealand, Injured Three
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 24th May, a major maritime incident occurred involving an explosion in the engine room aboard the bulk carrier [Olivia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2121/mmsi:229266000/imo:9608702/vessel:OLIVIA). Three crew members were injured when the bulk carrier was docked at a port in New Zealand. Two of these crew members are reported to be in a serious medical condition. ![Explosion aboard OLIVIA.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/OLIVIA_171b52731e.png)*Vessel OLIVIA, image credit: TAIC* The incident occurred at around 3:15 am local time when the vessel was docked at Berth 11 of the South Port, situated in Bluff, New Zealand. Three crew members were working on a boiler in the engine room when they were injured. It is yet uncertain if it was an explosion or a flashback (a sudden ignition of gases) in the boiler that led to the injuries. The three injured crew members were provided with medical attention promptly. A small fire was also reported to have broken out, but it was extinguished before the arrival of Fire and Emergency services. The vessel had arrived at the South Port in New Zealand on 22nd April, previously having departed from Bintulu in Malaysia. The Transport Accident Investigation Commission (TAIC) has taken charge of the investigation into the incident. The TAIC is an independent government body in New Zealand and is responsible for investigating significant accidents in transport sectors. The incident is being investigated as a "serious marine casualty, " a classification reserved for incidents involving death, serious injury, loss of ship, or major environmental damage, as mandated by the International Maritime Organization's Casualty Investigation Code. As of now, the commission is collecting evidence and interviewing witnesses to determine the cause and circumstances of the explosion. The [Olivia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2121/mmsi:229266000/imo:9608702/vessel:OLIVIA) is a 2013-built, Malta-flagged bulk carrier. The vessel is 179.9 metres long, has a beam of 28.4 metres, and has a gross tonnage of 20,928.

headline: Bulk Carrier “Ali Aykin” Runs Aground in the Sound Strait, Sweden
author: Raghib Raza
content: The bulk carrier [Ali Aykin](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:335049/mmsi:377772000/imo:9166510/vessel:ALI_AYKIN#overview) ran aground in the Sound Strait, which connects Sweden and Denmark. One crew member has been arrested for being inebriated, which might have caused the accident. ![ALI AYKIN grounded in Sweden.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ALI_AYKIN_f6a99e4c6e.png)*Vessel ALI AYKIN, image credit: Borja Vieira* The incident occurred on 25th May when the vessel was en route from Gdansk to Setubal, primarily transporting a cargo of scrap metal. The tanks of the vessel contained around 69,000 liters of diesel fuel, but fortunately, no leaks have been detected thus far. An aircraft from the Swedish Coast Guard is monitoring the site for any leaks. The vessel strayed from its route near the shipping channel close to Klagshamn. Swedish authorities suspect that the drunkenness of crew members at the helm was the reason behind the vessel going astray from its predetermined route through the shipping channel. As of now, one crew member has been detained for having consumed alcohol. The [Ali Aykin](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:335049/mmsi:377772000/imo:9166510/vessel:ALI_AYKIN#overview) is a general cargo ship that was built in 1999 and is flagged in St. Vincent and the Grenadines. The vessel has a length of 93.72 metres, a beam of 14.85 metres, and a gross tonnage of 2,950.

headline: Container vessel MSC ELSA 3, carrying hazardous cargo, capsizes near Indian coast; crew safe
author: Raghib Raza
content: The container vessel [MSC ELSA 3](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:757923/mmsi:636016814/imo:9123221/vessel:MSC_ELSA_3) capsized around 38 nautical miles off the coast of Kochi in Kerala, India. All 24 crew members were rescued by the Indian Coast Guard (ICG). The vessel was reported to have been transporting hazardous cargo, but fortunately, there have been no reports of pollution thus far. ![MSC Elsa 3.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSC_Elsa_3_d9698f3b5d.jpg) Image Credits: MSC Elsa 3 by Indian Coast Guard The container vessel [MSC ELSA 3](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:757923/mmsi:636016814/imo:9123221/vessel:MSC_ELSA_3) departed from [Vizhinjam Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/18972?name=VIZHINJAM-SEAPORT&country=India), India, on 23rd May and was due to arrive in Kochi at around 1:25 PM on 25th May. The vessel is speculated to have sunk due to flooding of its cargo holds, leading the vessel to list and eventually capsize. Twenty-one crew members were rescued by the ICG, and the last three members - the captain, chief engineer, and second engineer - were rescued by the INS Sujata, which had joined the rescue effort in the evening of May 25. All crew members have been reported to be safe and in good health. During the incident, many containers fell overboard into the ocean due to the vessel's tilt. The vessel was carrying 640 containers, 12 of which were carrying calcium carbide, which poses risks of fire and explosions when exposed to seawater. It is also toxic to marine life and can disrupt sensitive marine ecosystems by increasing the pH of the water. The vessel was also carrying 84.44 metric tons of diesel and around 376.1 tons of furnace oil. The ICG has deployed aircraft capable of mapping oil spills and is closely monitoring the situation. Fortunately, there have been no spills reported thus far. Cleanup teams and emergency responders in the nearby coastal areas of Kochi, Thrissur, and Alappuzha are on standby.

headline: Cargo Vessel Cong Thanh 07 Capsizes Near Son Duong Port; All Crew Safe
author: Raghib Raza
content: Vietnam Maritime Search and Rescue Coordination Center reported that all 10 crew members of the cargo vessel [Cong Thanh 07](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6129326/mmsi:574013703/imo:0/vessel:CONG_THANH_07) were rescued after the vessel capsized near Son Duong Port in Vietnam. Other than suffering from hypothermia and weakness, the crew members are reported to be in good health. ![CONG THANH 07 crew rescued by Vietnam Maritime Administration.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CONG_THANH_07_aec754390c.png)*Crewmembers of CONG THANH rescue by SAR 631, image credit: vmrcc.gov.vn* The Vietnam Maritime Search and Rescue Coordination Center received a distress call from the [Cong Thanh 07](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6129326/mmsi:574013703/imo:0/vessel:CONG_THANH_07) on the night of 25th May at around 9:10 PM local time, stating that the vessel was taking on water. The vessel reportedly sank soon after, approximately six nautical miles off Son Duong Port in Vietnam. After verifying the information from the distress call, rescue vessel SAR 631 was dispatched to the location. The weather in the area at the time of the rescue was also adverse, with waves of around 3 to 4 meters, heavy rain, and poor visibility. The SAR 631 then received three crew members who had been rescued by a nearby good Samaritan vessel at around 11:00 AM local time on 26th May. The SAR 631 rescued six of the crew members by around 11:27 AM local time of the same day. The sailors had been drifting at sea for several hours and were brought on board the vessel in a state of exhaustion, suffering from hypothermia. One of these crew members was reported to have been injured and received first-aid treatment on board. All nine crew members were then delivered to the authorities at Vung Ang Port in Ha Tinh, Vietnam, by 4:30 PM local time. The last of the adrift crew members was rescued approximately 17 nautical miles off the accident location on 26th May by a passing vessel. The search and rescue forces were praised by the Vietnam Maritime Administration and the Ha Tinh Provincial People's Committee for managing to rescue all the distressed sailors despite the adverse conditions.

headline: General Cargo Vessel “Wilson Husum” Safely Berthed in Kiel After Breakdown
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 23rd May, the Barbados-flagged general cargo vessel [Wilson Husum](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:378755/mmsi:314208000/imo:9017379/vessel:WILSON_HUSUM#overview) suffered an engine failure in the Baltic Sea off the coast of Gedser. The crew anchored the vessel and attempted repairs but were unable to restore propulsion. ![WILSON HUSUM stranded in Baltic sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/WILSON_HUSUM_be7196c890.png)*Vessel WILSON HUSUM, image credit: Leif Pape* Assistance was requested the following day, prompting the deployment of the Hamburg-based tug [Fairplay 55](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:130777/mmsi:211216490/imo:9021124/vessel:FAIRPLAY_55), which had been operating in the Kiel and Hohwacht Bay area. On 25th May, the tugboat [Fairplay 55](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:130777/mmsi:211216490/imo:9021124/vessel:FAIRPLAY_55) towed the vessel towards Kiel, Germany. Upon arrival in Kiel Fjord, the local tug [Parat](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:132371/mmsi:211283440/imo:8128212/vessel:PARAT) assisted the cargo vessel with maneuvering. The vessel was safely berthed at the North Jetty in Kiel at 6:20 p.m. UTC for propulsion system repairs. [Wilson Husum](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:378755/mmsi:314208000/imo:9017379/vessel:WILSON_HUSUM#overview) is a 1998-built cargo vessel with a carrying capacity of 4,219 tonnes. The MarineTraffic data shows the laden vessel is currently moored in [Kiel ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/171?name=KIEL&country=Germany)Port.

headline: Portugal-flagged  Vessel Allides with Dolphin in Kiel Canal After Rudder Failure
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 25th May, the Portugal-flagged general cargo vessel [Baltic Wind](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7895872/mmsi:255915582/imo:9953999/vessel:BALTIC_WIND#overview) allided with a dolphin structure on its starboard side after experiencing a rudder failure. The incident occurred during the vessel's westbound transit through the Kiel Canal in Germany. ![BALTIC WIND allided in Kiel Canal.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BALTIC_WIND_06295fd789.png)*Vessel BALTIC WIND, image credit: Juergen Braker* The impact caused a crack approximately two metres above the waterline at the bow. No injuries or pollution were reported. The cargo vessel, with a carrying capacity of 3,850 tonnes, was transporting two newly built coastal defense boats for Greece on its deck. Despite the allison, the cargo remained intact and was not damaged. The vessel continued its journey and berthed at the railway station dolphins in Brunsbüttel. The following day, an inspection was conducted by the representatives from the classification society and the divers to assess the extent of the damage. Local firm Cornels of Brunsbüttel was assigned to weld a plate over the crack. [Baltic Wind](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7895872/mmsi:255915582/imo:9953999/vessel:BALTIC_WIND#overview) is a 2023-built general cargo vessel that has a length of 89 metres and a width of 12 metres. According to MarineTraffic data, the vessel departed from [Brunsbüttel](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1497?name=BRUNSBUETTEL&country=Germany) on 27th May.

headline: Zombie Vessels and the Grey Fleet: Maritime Identity Laundering Reaches New Heights
author: Dimitris Ampatzidis
content: _Contributing author: Dimitris Kotsias, Market Analyst - Dirty Products at Kpler (dkotsias@kpler.com)_ # Overview Maritime identity laundering has evolved from a niche tactic into a systemic enabler of large-scale sanctions evasion. The manipulation of Automatic Identification System (AIS) signals, reuse of scrapped vessel identities, and shadowy ownership structures now underpin the operations of the so-called "Grey Fleet" - a clandestine logistics network facilitating embargoed oil flows from Russia, Iran, and Venezuela. At the extreme edge of this spectrum, zombie vessels - resurrected identities of scrapped ships - represent a growing risk to safety, enforcement, and the credibility of sanctions regimes. # Key takeaways - Zombie vessels are real ships operating under the identity of scrapped vessels, allowing illegal cargoes to masquerade as legitimate. - AIS spoofing and identity hijacking have surged post-2022, coinciding with expanded Western sanctions. - These vessels pose serious safety and environmental risks, often operating without verifiable ownership, insurance, or oversight. - Regulatory bodies like the U.S. Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) have started to intervene but are struggling to keep pace with the tactics employed by the grey fleet. - Kpler estimates show that by now, 10% of the global oil tanker fleet is part of the grey fleet - highlighting the scale of the challenge. # The Mechanics of Identity Laundering at Sea "Identity laundering" in shipping refers to the deliberate falsification or swapping of vessel identities to mask illicit operations. While this method predates the 2022 sanctions surge, it has flourished under the cover of expanding embargoes. Core to this tactic is AIS manipulation. Vessels digitally camouflage their movements by: - Broadcasting false coordinates. - Hijacking IMO/MMSI numbers of legitimate vessels. - Disabling transponders to create blackout periods during high-risk operations. This results in a fleet that operates without clear jurisdiction or visibility - a digital ghost armada transporting sanctioned crude undetected. # Zombie Vessels: The Most Deceptive Evolution A zombie vessel is a ship that pretends to be another one that was legally scrapped. This isn’t just a mistake on paper - it’s a deliberate move to hide illegal activity. In March 2025, we observed the sanctioned VLCC _VERONICA III_ (9326055) begin using the identity of _DS VECTOR_ (9203289), a ship that was dismantled in 2018. It broadcasts fake AIS signals in the Eastern Caribbean Sea. By April 2025, the vessel had arrived at Amuay, Venezuela, where it conducted a dark STS transfer with a non-sanctioned vessel that had picked up high-sulfur fuel oil (HSFO) from El Palito Refinery. ![image1.jpg](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/image1_347dd1b732.jpg) **Image 1.** _Satellite imagery for the STS on 4th of April 2025 - Copernicus._ In April and May 2025, the VLCC received 3 cargoes of HSFO, from three separate smaller vessels, LR1 _TAILWINDS_ (9280354) and LR2s _COLON_ (9503574) and _ORIENTAL PEARL_ (9281011). The STS operations were confirmed by satellite imagery, as AIS coverage outside Venezuela is very limited or in cases like the zombie fleet, extremely misleading. The three cargoes’ origin is the El Palito and Cardon refineries in Venezuela and the pattern exhibited by _VERONICA III_ is very typical for Venezuelan exports. VLCCs (often piggybacking on a dead vessel’s identity), are gradually topping-up with Crude or HSFO from Venezuela, and once fully laden they depart usually to the East. Another recent example that establishes this method of concealing the cargo’s origin, is the Suezmax _APUS_ (9280885). The vessel is pinging as the dead vessel _FREESIA I_ (9159660), adopting its identity even in the port line-ups, making it look like _FREESIA I_ is the one loading ex Jose Oil Terminal. In reality, APUS loaded ~140kt of HSFO from the Port of Jose, but the destination is not currently known. There are also cases that unfortunately, despite the indications of a ‘zombie’ vessel, we cannot confirm who’s the real culprit behind it. For example, vessel _ALANA_ (9172583) was seen in November 2023 at the Chittagong breakyard in Bangladesh. However, recently this name has emerged in the documentation of loadings at Cardon, but so far we do not have a visual confirmation that could link _ALANA_ (dead vessel) to an operational one that is using _ALANA’s_ identity. But this method of employing ‘dead’ vessels for their identity is fairly new, so we are closely monitoring the situation to identify as many of these cases as possible. Kpler's vessel tracking has found many examples of scrapped ships being "brought back to life" to hide illegal operations. So far, we have identified over 20 scrapped ships being used this way, connected to more than 23 active vessels, mostly operating in high-risk export areas. # Operational and Safety Hazards Zombie vessels often sail without legitimate registration, valid insurance, or enforceable safety standards. Their age and mechanical degradation pose heightened risks: - AIS spoofing disrupts collision-avoidance systems, increasing maritime accident potential. - Untraceable ownership means no clear liability in case of environmental disasters. - In conflict zones, ships using false IDs may be misidentified as hostile, leading to tragic consequences. # Sanctions Integrity at Stake Grey fleet vessels enable large-scale circumvention of sanctions: - They facilitate unreported STS (ship-to-ship) transfers, often in international waters. - Kpler estimates from late 2024 indicate that over 10% of the global tanker fleet is engaged in opaque or deceptive activities. These include identity laundering, AIS spoofing, and dark STS transfers - normalizing regulatory evasion as standard practice. # The Regulatory Catch-Up Game Global enforcement bodies are taking note. In April 2025, OFAC banned the reuse of IMO numbers from scrapped vessels and ramped up scrutiny on identity changes ([OFAC](https://ofac.treasury.gov/media/934236/download?inline)). However, enforcement remains slow relative to the speed of evasion tactics. Solutions in development include: - Satellite verification systems with machine learning to detect physical discrepancies. - Cross-border data sharing to flag suspicious activity in near real-time. - AIS signal integrity assessments as part of port-state control procedures. Yet, despite these initiatives, the grey fleet continues to outmaneuver traditional compliance infrastructures. # Conclusion Zombie vessels represent the bleeding edge of maritime deception - combining digital obfuscation with recycled identities to operate beyond the reach of law and oversight. They highlight an urgent need for global enforcement synchronization, advanced verification technologies, and real-time maritime intelligence. As regulatory frameworks slowly adapt, the burden of detection increasingly falls on proprietary tracking tools and robust market surveillance systems - areas where Kpler continues to lead. Without decisive action, identity laundering risks becoming institutionalized within global trade flows, eroding both safety and trust at sea. _To find out more about Kpler’s Risk & Compliance offering, visit [here](https://www.kpler.com/demos/risk-compliance-demo?utm_source=website&utm_medium=blog&utm_campaign=risk&compliance_commodities_maritime_news_demo_request)._

headline: Passenger Ro-Ro Vessel Collides with Tugboat and Runs Aground at the Port of Mykonos
author: Raghib Raza
content: The passenger Ro-Ro vessel [Super Express](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:374093/mmsi:241881000/imo:9176046/vessel:SUPEREXPRESS) collided with a tugboat and then ran aground while attempting to dock at the [Port of Mykonos](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/30?name=MYKONOS&country=Greece). Fortunately, no injuries or pollution have been reported in the incident. ![SUPEREXPRESS ran aground at the Port of Mykonos.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SUPEREXPRESS_a28f9e7e1c.png)*Vessel SUPEREXPRESS, image credit: Sakis Antoniou* The incident occurred in the afternoon of 26th May, when mooring operations for the vessel were underway. Following the accident, the Port of Mykonos authority immediately prohibited the vessel's departure. A technical inspection and a seaworthiness certificate for the vessel were required before its departure would be allowed. The [Super Express](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:374093/mmsi:241881000/imo:9176046/vessel:SUPEREXPRESS) was operating on its route from Rafina to Tinos, Mykonos, Paros, Ios, and Thira and was returning to the Port of Mykonos at the time of the incident. The vessel was carrying 158 passengers, 11 vehicles, and one motorbike. An investigation into the incident has been launched by the Coast Guard. The [Super Express](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:374093/mmsi:241881000/imo:9176046/vessel:SUPEREXPRESS) is a 1998-built Ro-Ro vessel sailing under the Greek flag. It measures 92 metres in length, 26 metres in beam, and has a gross tonnage of 5,819.

headline: Container Ship and Inland Vessel Collide in Western Scheldt Estuary
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 30th May, a major maritime incident occurred involving a collision between the Belgium-flagged inland motor vessel [Beringzee](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:117299/mmsi:205508590/imo:0/vessel:BERINGZEE) and the UK-flagged container ship [Containerships Nord](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5629987/mmsi:232046824/imo:9813993/vessel:CONTAINERSHIPS_NORD). The incident took place at around 14:15 hours in the Western Scheldt, southwestern Netherlands. ![Inland vessel collided with CONTAINERSHIP NORD in Netherlands.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CONTAINERSHIP_NORD_c360b4b800.png)*Vessel CONTAINERSHIP NORD, image credit:flows.be* Emergency response vessels from both Antwerp and the Netherlands were dispatched to the scene. A Coast Guard helicopter was also deployed for assistance. The [Beringzee,](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:117299/mmsi:205508590/imo:0/vessel:BERINGZEE) en route from [Antwerp](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/117?name=ANTWERP&country=Belgium), Belgium to [Vlissingen](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2407?name=VLISSINGEN&country=Netherlands), Netherland had three crew members on board. Two were thrown overboard due to the impact but were successfully rescued by responding emergency teams. One of them sustained minor injuries, while the third crewmember was also examined as a precaution. The[ Beringzee](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:117299/mmsi:205508590/imo:0/vessel:BERINGZEE) sustained significant damage and was being stabilized by two assisting inland vessels, the [Kevalia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:170396/mmsi:226001810/imo:0/vessel:KEVALIA) and the [Verity](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:113100/mmsi:205383490/imo:0/vessel:VERITY). Several tugboats remain on site to support the operation. Oil booms were placed around after a very thin oil layer was observed on the Scheldt. Despite the collision and limited oil spill, the shipping traffic remained in operation. The [Nord](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5629987/mmsi:232046824/imo:9813993/vessel:CONTAINERSHIPS_NORD), of CMA CGM, had departed [Antwerp](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/117?name=ANTWERP&country=Belgium) for [Dunkirk](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/20116?name=DUNKIRK-EAST&country=France) in France, was able to continue its journey but was instructed to anchor Vlissingen Anchorage for inspection. Authorities have launched an inquiry into the cause of the collision.

headline: Cargo Ship ‘Meshka’ Runs Aground Off Landskrona, No Oil Spill Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: The bulk carrier[ Meshka](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713214/mmsi:352004583/imo:9588380/vessel:MESHKA) ran aground on the coast of the city of Landskrona, Sweden on 31st May. Crew members are being suspected of negligence as the vessel was issued a warning that it was on the wrong course before it ran aground. There have been no reports of any leaks from the vessel. ![MESHKA ran aground in Sweden.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MESHKA_b110214fa1.png)*Vessel MESHKA, image credit: Kjell Andersson* The incident occurred as the vessel was traveling from Skagen to Vysotsk, carrying around 938,000 liters of oil. The vessel ran aground shortly after a warning was issued to the ship that it was on the wrong course. Crew members are suspected of negligence, and all 24 of them are being questioned. One crew member has been served with a suspicion notice. The crew, however, is defending themselves, stating that they responded to the warning too late. None of the crew members were found to be under the influence of alcohol. The Swedish Coast Guard is on the scene and is closely monitoring the situation. The [Meshka](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:713214/mmsi:352004583/imo:9588380/vessel:MESHKA) is a Panamanian-flagged bulk carrier that was built in 2011. The vessel has a length of 180 metres, a beam of 31 metres, and a gross tonnage of 23,460.

headline: Greece-flagged Ferry Rescues 75 Migrants in Aegean Sea
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 1st June, the Ro-Ro passenger ship [Blue Star Chios](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:213466/mmsi:240672000/imo:9215555/vessel:BLUE_STAR_CHIOS) successfully rescued 75 migrants aboard the sailboat southeast of the island of Karpathos, Greece. ![BLUE STAR CHIOS rescued migrants in Aegean Sea.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BLUE_STAR_CHIOS_7575e455fc.png)*Ferry BLUE STAR CHIOS, image credit: Lambros Kakes* The incident occurred after the sailboat issued a distress call from approximately 14.4 nautical miles off the southeastern coast of Karpathos in the Aegean Sea, prompting a swift response from Greek Maritime Authorities. The Unified Search and Rescue Coordination Center initiated the rescue operation, and the Hellenic Coast Guard dispatched a rescue boat. Nearby vessels also responded promptly to the distress alert. [Blue Star Chios](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:213466/mmsi:240672000/imo:9215555/vessel:BLUE_STAR_CHIOS), a Greece-flagged ferry carrying approximately 200 passengers, altered its course and successfully rescued all migrants. No injuries were reported in the incident. The authorities are yet to disclosed the nationality of the rescued migrants and their intended destination. [Blue Star Chios](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:213466/mmsi:240672000/imo:9215555/vessel:BLUE_STAR_CHIOS) is a 2007-built passenger ship with a carrying capacity of 13,955 gross tonnage. The ship has a length of 141 metres and a width of 21 metres.

headline: Four Vessels Ran Aground in Inclement Weather in Bay of Bengal
author: Raghib Raza
content: Four vessels ran aground due to powerful winds in the Bay of Bengal on 30th May. All affected vessels were docked along the coast near the Port of [Chittagong](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2743?name=CHITTAGONG&country=Bangladesh). There were no injuries or pollution reported in the incidents. ![Four vessel aground in Chittagong port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CHITTAGONG_PORT_e6f53dd803.png)*Vessels aground in Chittagong Port, image credit:prothomalo.com* The winds, which had speeds of up to 64 km per hour, were accompanied by heavy rain and rough seas. The Bay of Bengal is notorious for strong winds during monsoons that can drive vessels aground. The tugboat Navimar-3, which was docked near Anwara due to unpaid fuel bills, was blown ashore along with the barge Mermaid-3. North of Chittagong Port, the tanker Al Herem was pushed ashore after losing control in the heavy seas. The tanker[ B-LPG Sophia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:372139/mmsi:357668000/imo:9175846/vessel:B_LPG_SOPHIA), which had been at anchor at the Port of Chittagong since an explosion and subsequent fire in October last year, also drifted ashore. Fortunately, none of the incidents resulted in injury to personnel or pollution.

headline: Vehicle Carrier 'Morning Midas' Catches Fire off Alaska; Crew Safely Evacuated
author: Raghib Raza
content: The U.S. Coast Guard of Alaska region reported that the Liberia-flagged vehicle carrier [Morning Midas ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:188801/mmsi:636021856/imo:9289910/vessel:MORNING_MIDAS#overview)caught fire approximately 300 nautical miles southwest of Adak, Alaska, on 3rd June. The incident occurred at midnight when the smoke was detected emanating from a deck storing electric vehicles. ![MORNING MIDAS caught fire off Alaska Coast US.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MORNING_MIDAS_3513d959bf.png)*Vehicle carrier MORNING MIDAS, image credit: Geir Vinnes* Following the fire outbreak, the crew activated the onboard fire suppression systems and undertook emergency firefighting measures. However, the fire could not be contained, prompting 22 crewmembers to evacuate into a lifeboat. They were later transferred to a nearby merchant vessel. On the morning of 4th June, the U.S. Coast Guard deployed an aircraft and a cutter in response to the emergency. In addition, two container ships, including the USA-flagged [Manukai ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5952323/mmsi:369296000/imo:9244130/vessel:MANUKAI)and the Malta-flagged [Cosco Hellas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:213002/mmsi:256932000/imo:9308510/vessel:COSCO_HELLAS), diverted course to assist in the emergency. A tug has also been dispatched to aid in salvage and firefighting operations as authorities continue to monitor the situation. The cause of the fire is under investigation. [Morning Midas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:188801/mmsi:636021856/imo:9289910/vessel:MORNING_MIDAS#overview) is a 2006-built vehicle carrier that was carrying approximately 3,000 vehicles, including 800 electric vehicles, at the time of the incident. According to the MarineTraffic data the vessel departed from [Yantai](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1245?name=YANTAI&country=China), China, on 26th May, scheduled to arrive at [Lázaro Cárdenas,](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/3055?name=LAZARO-CARDENAS&country=Mexico) Mexico, by 15th June.

headline: Russian Fishing Vessel Catches Fire in Sea of Japan; Crew Rescued
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 4th June, the Russian-flagged fishing vessel [Iceberg](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:347208/mmsi:273334490/imo:9520390/vessel:ICEBERG#overview) with 17 crew members caught fire while transiting the Sea of Japan. No casualties were reported. ![ICEBERG caught fire in Sea of Japan.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ICEBERG_0e0a89e9ec.png)*Fishing Vessel ICEBERG, image credit: V. Tonic* The fire broke out at around 06:40 a.m. local time as the vessel was en route from the Port of [Zarubino](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2239?name=ZARUBINO&country=Russia), Russia to South Korea. All the crew members evacuated the vessel using the two life rafts. They were later rescued by the reefer vessel [Ostrov Iony](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:351603/mmsi:273873500/imo:8847052/vessel:OSTROV_IONY#overview), which responded to the distress signal. The reefer, en route to the Port of [Busan](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/793?name=BUSAN&country=Korea), South Korea, will disembark the rescued crew at the port. All 17 sailors are reportedly in good health and did not require medical attention. Following the evacuation, the fishing vessel was left adrift with no visible lights. Russia’s regional Transport Prosecutor’s Office has launched an investigation into the incident to assess compliance with maritime safety regulations. The [Iceberg](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:347208/mmsi:273334490/imo:9520390/vessel:ICEBERG#overview), with a carrying capacity of 450 tons, measures 60.2 metres in length and 9.36 metres in width. It is registered in Korsakov and owned by DV-Flot.

headline: Tanker “Gorizont-1” Involved in Pier Collision at Kazan Port, Russia
author: Raghib Raza
content: On the evening of 2nd June, the tanker [Gorizont-1](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6008441/mmsi:273452790/imo:0/vessel:GORIZONT_1#overview) collided with the Columbia pier at the [Kazan River Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/20569?name=KAZAN&country=Russia), situated along the Volga River in Kazan, Russia. No injuries or oil pollution were reported in the incident. ![Gorizont-1 collided witha pier at the Kazan River Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/KAZAN_PORT_beb6c6bedc.png)*PORT KAZAN, image credit: Alexey Bykov* The vessel sustained damage to its bow section above the waterline. Despite the collision, river traffic was not disrupted, and the vessel remained stable. Authorities have launched an investigation to determine the cause of the incident. Russia's regional Transport Prosecutor's Office is currently inspecting potential violations of navigation safety regulations. Officials stated that appropriate legal measures will be taken if any non-compliance is identified. [Gorizant-1](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6008441/mmsi:273452790/imo:0/vessel:GORIZONT_1#overview) is a tanker sailing under the flag of Russia. The vessel has a length of 41 metres and a width of 7 metres.

headline: Environmental Damage in Thai Marine Park as Vessel Grounds on Coral
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 1st June, the Myanmar-flagged vessel Ayar Linn ran aground on a coral reef in Ao Jak Bay, located within Mu Koh Surin National Park in Thailand. ![AYAR LINN grounded on coral reef in thailand.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/AYAR_LINN_e958c03f31.png)*Vessel AYAR LINN, image credit:khaosodenglish.com* The Director-General of the Department of National Parks, Wildlife and Plant Conservation (DNP) stated that the incident had caused major damage to coral reefs. The initial assessment revealed that around 150 square metres of the coral reef had been damaged, affecting six coral species. Currently, environmental concerns are about the debris that has been found scattered on the reef, including cardboard boxes, rubber hoses, fabric scraps, tires, and other waste materials. Moreover, the vessel also carries 3000 cement bags, further escalating the environmental risk if they fall into the sea. Authorities suspect the vessel may have been avoiding Myanmar officials, although this remains unconfirmed. Thailand’s DNP is seeking compensation of 12 million baht ($366,600) from the vessel owner, who is yet to respond. Recovery efforts have been hampered by ongoing monsoon conditions. The authorities confirmed that the affected areas will be temporarily closed to allow the reef to recover. Multiple government agencies are coordinating efforts to contain potential spills, restore the environment, and initiate legal action.

headline: Passengers Evacuated from Docked Ro-Ro Vessel as Generator Catches Fire
author: Raghib Raza
content: Passengers and crew were evacuated from the Ro-Ro passenger vessel [Splendid](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:276825/mmsi:247136000/imo:9015747/vessel:SPLENDID) after a generator fire broke out when the vessel was docked in [Genoa](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/224?name=GENOVA&country=Italy), Italy. The fire was quickly extinguished, and no injuries were reported. ![Fire erupted aboard SPLENDID in Italy.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SPLENDID_51e4eae6bd.png)*Vessel SPLENDID, image credit: Alessandro Susinno* The fire department reported receiving notification of the fire on the night of 3rd June at around 9:00 PM local time. An operator of the vessel had noticed smoke emanating from one of the generators aboard the vessel and had begun a manual shutdown of the generator. The fire teams responded promptly with two fire trucks and a boat. Crew and passengers were evacuated as a precaution, and the fire was reportedly quickly brought under control. The fire department conducted a thorough inspection of the vessel to ensure that the fire had not spread to other parts of the vessel. The vessel appears to have sustained no structural damage. [Splendid](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:276825/mmsi:247136000/imo:9015747/vessel:SPLENDID) is a Ro-Ro passenger vessel sailing under the flag of Italy and can accommodate 2,200 passengers and 1,000 vehicles. The vessel operates between Genoa and Tunis.

headline: Update: Vehicle Carrier 'Morning Midas' Catches Fire off Alaska; Crew Safely Evacuated
author: Raghib Raza
content: The U.S. Coast Guard (USGC), Alaskan division reported that the Liberian-flagged vehicle carrier [Morning Midas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:188801/mmsi:636021856/imo:9289910/vessel:MORNING_MIDAS) caught fire approximately 300 nautical miles southwest of Adak, Alaska, USA on 3rd June. Smoke was detected emanating from a deck storing electric vehicles, which led to the USGC being alerted. Fortunately, no injuries were reported in the incident. ![MORNING MIDAS caught fire off Alaska Coast US.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MORNING_MIDAS_3513d959bf.png)*Vessel MORNING MIDA, image credit: Geir Vinnes* A distress alert was received by Coast Guard watchstanders at the Seventeenth District command center at approximately 3:15 p.m. local time. Following the fire outbreak, the crew activated the onboard fire suppression systems and undertook emergency firefighting measures. However, the fire could not be contained, prompting the 22 crewmembers to evacuate into a lifeboat. They were later transferred to the vessel [Cosco Hellas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:213002/mmsi:256932000/imo:9308510/vessel:COSCO_HELLAS), which was one of three good samaritan vessels that had diverted to provide assistance to the distressed vessel following USGC’s emergency marine broadcast. The U.S. Coast Guard Cutter Munro was diverted to the scene, and support was deployed in the form of a C-130J Super Hercules from Air Station Kodiak and an MH-60T Jayhawk helicopter stationed in Adak. The 2006-built vessel had 3,048 vehicles, including 70 fully electric and 681 hybrid electric units aboard. The ship is carrying approximately 350 metric tons of gas fuel and 1,530 metric tons of very low sulfur fuel oil (VLSFO). Batteries of electric vehicles can ignite under high temperature, emit toxic fumes, and are particularly difficult to extinguish. As per the latest update,[ Morning Midas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:188801/mmsi:636021856/imo:9289910/vessel:MORNING_MIDAS) remains adrift with smoke still emanating from the vessel. The status of the fire is currently unknown. The USGC is coordinating with the vessel’s manager Zodiac Maritime for the recovery of the vessel. According to MarineTraffic data, the [Morning Midas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:188801/mmsi:636021856/imo:9289910/vessel:MORNING_MIDAS) departed from [Yantai](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1245?name=YANTAI&country=China), China, on 26th May, scheduled to arrive at [Lázaro Cárdenas](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/3055?name=LAZARO-CARDENAS&country=Mexico), Mexico, by 15th June.

headline: Navigating the Complexities of Maritime Sanctions: A May 2025 Overview
author: Dimitris Ampatzidis
content: # Overview From the Arabian Gulf to the Arctic, the shipping routes of sanctioned oil are shifting, and so are the rules. In May 2025, regulators delivered their most aggressive crackdown yet on deceptive maritime practices, targeting everything from shadow fleets to overlooked flag registries. This report unpacks the data, the geopolitics, and the operational signals compliance teams can no longer afford to ignore. # Key takeaways - May 2025 saw the largest one-month spike in vessel designations to date, with 176 ships and 16 companies added. - Over half the sanctioned tankers were flagged to Russia or Iran, but the real story is the quiet rise of Panama, Comoros, and other non-sanctioned flags now on the target. - Despite regulatory pressure, sanctioned oil continues to flow, over $55 billion worth moved by newly listed tankers in the past 17 months, mostly to India, China, and Türkiye. - AIS manipulation, and dark STS transfers are now high-risk markers, not just red flags, regulators are penalizing indirect involvement and third-party facilitation with greater frequency and precision. - The line between commercial operations and geopolitical risk is increasingly blurred; for maritime and energy companies, sanctions compliance is now a frontline priority, not merely a back-office responsibility. # Market Analysis May 2025 marked a significant escalation in maritime sanctions enforcement, with global regulators intensifying efforts to disrupt illicit shipping practices across oil, gas, and even dry bulk trades. In Washington, the [U.S. Treasury’s Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) broadened its crackdown on Iran’s petroleum exports](https://home.treasury.gov/news/press-releases/sb0135), while [London](https://www.gov.uk/government/news/prime-minister-to-announce-largest-ever-sanctions-package-targeting-shadow-fleet-as-uk-ramps-up-pressure-on-russia) and [Brussels](https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2025/05/20/russia-s-war-of-aggression-against-ukraine-eu-agrees-17th-package-of-sanctions/) unveiled sweeping new restrictions targeting Russia’s so-called “shadow fleet” of tankers. Meanwhile, voices at the United Nations echoed these efforts, [calling for greater transparency around North Korea’s covert coal shipments](https://press.un.org/en/2025/250501_sc.doc.htm). On May 8, OFAC imposed sanctions on a Chinese “teapot” refinery, three Shandong-based port logistics firms, and several shipping companies, vessels, and ship captains tied to Iran’s sanctions-evasion networks. A week later, on May 13, OFAC escalated its campaign by blacklisting nearly two dozen additional entities involved in all facets of Iran’s oil smuggling ecosystem, from front companies brokering sales to maritime service providers supporting vessel operations. U.S. officials underscored that third-country facilitators would not be exempt from enforcement actions if found complicit in circumventing sanctions. Despite this aggressive posture, OFAC demonstrated limited regulatory flexibility. On May 20, the agency issued a targeted general license allowing safety and environmental operations on the Iranian tanker MV TINOS I (IMO 9969821), which had been seized and was anchored in U.S. waters. The move reflects a balancing act: pursuing robust sanctions enforcement while mitigating environmental and navigational risks posed by immobilized tankers. Collectively, these developments reflect a coordinated international shift toward more proactive maritime sanctions enforcement, one that prioritizes disruption of illicit logistics networks and sends a strong deterrent signal to actors operating in the grey areas of global trade. The month’s most sweeping actions came on May 20, when the European Union and United Kingdom nearly simultaneously escalated sanctions against the secretive flotilla carrying Russian oil. In Brussels, [EU ministers approved the 17th package of Russia sanctions](https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2025/05/20/russia-s-war-of-aggression-against-ukraine-eu-agrees-17th-package-of-sanctions/?utm_source=brevo&utm_campaign=AUTOMATED%20-%20Alert%20-%20Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_id=3318#:~:text=The%20Council%20adopted%20today%20its,that%20support%20Russia%27s%20war%20economy), described as “the most wide-sweeping since the start of the war,” with a heavy focus on maritime evasion. A staggering 189 additional tankers believed to be part of Russia’s shadow fleet were blacklisted, now doubling the number of vessels banned from EU ports and services. Many of these ships are owned or flagged in third countries and have been engaged in transporting Russian crude via high-risk practices like disabling tracking systems and performing mid-ocean cargo transfers ([MarineTraffic LinkedIn post](https://www.linkedin.com/feed/update/urn:li:activity:7330905018226634752/)). The new [EU list](https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2025/05/20/russia-s-war-of-aggression-against-ukraine-eu-agrees-17th-package-of-sanctions/?utm_source=brevo&utm_campaign=AUTOMATED%20-%20Alert%20-%20Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_id=3318#:~:text=In%20addition%2C%20the%20EU%20imposes,of%20the%20Russian%20oil%20shipping) reaches beyond just ships: it also freezes the assets of several shipping companies in the UAE, Türkiye and Hong Kong that manage or operate the embargoed tankers, as well as one notable insurer of Russian oil cargoes. In a sign of widening scope, the EU package even encompassed three modern LNG carriers which are state of the art ice-class ships owned by Japan’s Mitsui O.S.K. Lines, which had been chartered to transport natural gas from Russia’s Yamal LNG project via ship-to-ship transfers. Brussels had largely shied away from Russian LNG transport until now, so the blacklisting of these high-profile gas carriers sent a potent signal that any vessel facilitating sanctioned energy exports (whether oil or gas) is fair game. EU officials noted that since the introduction of the G7/EU oil price cap and anti-shadow fleet measures, [Russia’s energy revenues have dropped significantly year-over-year](https://www.consilium.europa.eu/en/press/press-releases/2025/05/20/russia-s-war-of-aggression-against-ukraine-eu-agrees-17th-package-of-sanctions/?utm_source=brevo&utm_campaign=AUTOMATED%20-%20Alert%20-%20Newsletter&utm_medium=email&utm_id=3318#:~:text=Since%20the%20EU%20introduced%20the,than%20those%20of%20March%202022), evidence, they argue, that tighter maritime sanctions are biting. London matched the EU’s hard line with its own record-breaking action against the dark tanker fleet. On May 9, Prime Minister Keir Starmer’s government unveiled the [UK’s “largest ever” Russia sanctions package](https://www.gov.uk/government/news/prime-minister-to-announce-largest-ever-sanctions-package-targeting-shadow-fleet-as-uk-ramps-up-pressure-on-russia#:~:text=The%20Government%20will%20today%20sanction,since%20the%20start%20of%202024), built around a mass listing of about 100 oil tankers suspected of covertly carrying Russian crude. British authorities stressed that these aging, poorly insured ships pose not just a sanctions risk but also a direct threat to maritime safety and infrastructure, while noting incidents of “reckless seafaring” and even suggesting shadow tankers may have damaged undersea data cables in European waters. Later in the month, coinciding with the EU’s 17th package, the UK rolled out an additional round of sanctions on May 20 that listed 18 more tankers and dozens of related entities. These included two Russian ship captains and even a UK-based accountant accused of helping Moscow acquire tankers via shell companies. By casting a spotlight on a British national’s role in the shadow fleet’s expansion, the UK underscored that Western participants in these schemes will be held to account. Upping the pressure further, UK officials hinted at tightening the oil price cap mechanism, and potentially lowering the price threshold closer to Russia’s production cost to erode Russian oil profits that slip through the cracks. Taken together, the EU and UK moves in May represent a trans-Atlantic one-two punch against the murky tanker network propping up Russia’s oil exports. # Implications for the Shipping Industry Beyond the headline-grabbing designations, May’s developments also delivered important signals about enforcement and compliance expectations for maritime actors. The UK’s Office of Financial Sanctions Implementation (OFSI) demonstrated a newly aggressive posture by levying its first-ever enforcement fine in the maritime sector. The OFSI issued a £5,000 penalty against Svarog Shipping Company for failing to respond to an information request related to Russia sanctions. While modest in amount, the penalty carries outsized significance: it makes clear that even non-cooperation or lapses in due diligence can trigger sanctions consequences. Meanwhile in Washington, regulators continue to update guidance for shipowners and insurers on best practices ranging from scrutinizing AIS transmission gaps to verifying counterparties – reflecting lessons learned from recent deceptive shipping cases. And at the United Nations, maritime sanctions evasion is drawing increased alarm. In a UN Security Council briefing on May 7, the United States presented evidence of North Korea’s illicit coal exports by sea, spotlighting how Pyongyang uses foreign-flagged bulk carriers to smuggle coal and iron ore to China in defiance of UN embargoes. With hundreds of vessels now banned by Western authorities for sanction-breaking voyages, vetting a ship’s history and ownership has become paramount. No longer can one assume that using an older “off-radar” tanker or engaging in an STS transfer at sea will escape notice. The May designations show that authorities are actively tracking such behavior via satellite data and inter-agency intelligence. In addition to mounting sanctions pressure, vessels are facing increasing real-world threats in key maritime zones. According to the [UK Maritime Trade Operations (UKMTO)](https://www.ukmto.org/ukmto-products/weekly-reports/2025), ships transiting the Strait of Hormuz and southern Red Sea experienced repeated GPS signal interference in May, with disruptions lasting several hours and forcing crews to rely on backup navigation methods ([UKMTO, 24–30 May 2025](https://www.ukmto.org/-/media/ukmto/products/20250530_ukmto_summary_report-30may25.pdf?rev=3d68c75f04d543959242b52e71dcf1d8)). During the same period, vessels anchored off Ras Isa, Yemen, were reportedly denied departure even with UN clearance, with some boarded by armed personnel under threat of force ([UKMTO, 26 April–2 May 2025](https://www.ukmto.org/-/media/ukmto/products/20250502_ukmto_summary_report-02may25.pdf?rev=bcf11e93303f4ca8a68ea37839112291)). Meanwhile, the [U.S. Office of Naval Intelligence (ONI)](https://www.oni.navy.mil/ONI-Reports/Shipping-Threat-Reports/Worldwide-Threat-to-Shipping/) recorded several violent boarding attempts in Southeast Asia and the Gulf of Guinea, including knife-point robberies and armed crew kidnappings ([ONI WTS Report, 30 April–28 May 2025](https://www.oni.navy.mil/Portals/12/Intel%20agencies/piracy/WTS/20250528%20WTS.pdf?ver=McIsu5zoz7IQqx1qxrlbKg%3d%3d)). These developments identify the growing operational and physical risks for vessels, particularly those already flagged for compliance concerns, when operating in or near conflict-affected regions. In May 2025, 176 ships and 16 companies were added to global sanctions lists. These tankers had moved more than 503 million barrels of oil in 2024, and over 242 million barrels in just the first five months of 2025. Most of this oil came from Russia (374 million barrels in 2024 and 193 million in 2025 so far) and Iran (32 million in 2024 and 17 million in 2025). In total, 82% of their oil shipments were linked to Russian or Iranian sources. The oil mainly ended up in India (153 million barrels in 2024 and 74 million in 2025), China (96 million in 2024 and 76 million in 2025), and Türkiye (65 million in 2024 and 26 million in 2025). These three countries received about 55% of all the oil moved by these vessels. The 16 companies added to the global lists were tied to more than 28 ships that had already shown high-risk behavior before the sanctions. This included at least 14 cases of dangerous practices like turning off their tracking systems, faking their location, or doing dark ship-to-ship transfers. They also had 28 risk flags related to management. ![Picture1.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture1_03d28e3e69.png) **Graph 1.** _Sanctioned vessels and companies through the last five years (May 2020 to May 2025) - Kpler._ In the last six months, sanctions designations in the maritime sector have surged at an unprecedented rate, with the number of listed vessels rising from just under 1,100 in November 2024 to around 1,600 by May 2025, a 45% increase, while sanctioned companies climbed from around 460 to nearly 670, marking a 40% rise. This sharp escalation reflects a strategic shift: regulators are moving beyond reactive enforcement toward preemptive disruption of high-risk networks, targeting not only tankers but also the web of operators, insurers, managers, and intermediaries behind them. The data signals that authorities are acting on more sophisticated intelligence and deeper cross-jurisdictional cooperation, rapidly identifying and sanctioning entities linked to deceptive practices. ![Picture2.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture2_12aadcef0d.png) **Graph 2.** _Sanctioned vessels per top 10 flag registry through the last two years (May 2023 to May 2025) - Kpler._ Over the last two years, the flag profile of sanctioned vessels has shifted significantly, with sharp growth in designations tied to non-traditional registries. As of May 2025, Russian- and Iranian-flagged vessels make up more than half of all sanctioned ships. However, Panama has emerged as a major concern, with its sanctioned fleet nearly quadrupling since mid-2023. Comoros, China, and North Korea have also seen steady increases, while newer entries like Guyana, Curacao, Guinea, and Barbados have surged in just the last six months. This trend points to deliberate flag-hopping, as operators seek out jurisdictions with weaker oversight. The implication for compliance teams is clear: flag state alone is no longer a reliable risk filter, what matters now is the broader behavioral and enforcement context behind each registration. ![Picture3.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Picture3_144de6435d.png) **Graph 3.** _Total vessels and companies added to sanctions lists over the last twelve months (June 2024 to May 2025) - Kpler._ Sanctions over the past year have followed a pattern of sharp bursts in numbers rather than steady growth. January and May 2025 alone accounted for nearly 360 vessel designations combined, far exceeding any other months alongside major spikes in company listings. These surges reflect coordinated regulatory campaigns aimed at disrupting entire maritime networks in one sweep. The uneven monthly distribution highlights the need for agile compliance systems that can react quickly to sudden waves of sanctions rather than relying on routine updates. The 176 vessels sanctioned in May 2025 had collectively transported over 503 million barrels of oil in 2024 and more than 242 million barrels in the first five months of 2025. Using the average Brent crude price of $80 per barrel in 2024 and the May 2025 average of $64.45 per barrel , the estimated value of these cargoes exceeds $40.2 billion for 2024 and an additional $15.6 billion for 2025. This brings the combined value of sanctioned oil flows linked to these vessels to approximately $55.8 billion over the past 17 months. # Conclusion Sanctions enforcement is no longer confined to headlines or government statements, it now shapes the day-to-day reality of commercial decision-making. Every fixture, every cargo approval, every port call comes with higher stakes, as the risks hidden in opaque ownership, outdated flag assumptions, or AIS gaps can translate into real exposure. With regulators acting faster and more comprehensively than ever, navigating the space between legitimate operations and illicit networks requires more than just technical checks; it calls for critical judgment, institutional memory, and the willingness to ask uncomfortable questions. And the impact doesn’t stop when the workday ends. Supporting vessels that quietly move sanctioned oil isn’t just a business oversight, it helps sustain global instability, from conflicts abroad to supply chain shocks at home. The decisions made in boardrooms and compliance reviews ripple outward, influencing everything from fuel prices to international security. In that sense, protecting a company’s compliance posture also protects the credibility of the systems we all live within, professional, legal, and moral alike. _To find out more about Kpler’s Risk & Compliance offering, visit [here](lhttps://www.kpler.com/demos/risk-compliance-demo?utm_source=website&utm_medium=blog&utm_campaign=risk&compliance_commodities_maritime_news_demo_request)._

headline: Cargo Vessel Collides with Quay at Aker Solutions Shipyard in Stord
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 5th June, the Portugal-flagged general cargo vessel [Wilson Flex IV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7205077/mmsi:255806463/imo:9911460/vessel:WILSON_FLEX_IV) allided with the quay at Aker Solutions’ shipyard in the port basin at Eldøyane in Stord, Norway. The incident occurred in connection with ongoing project deliveries at the shipyard. ![WILSON FLEX IV allided with quay in Stord , Norway.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/WILSON_FLEX_IV_9bb6e24f70.png)*Vessel WILSON FLEX IV, image credit: Paul Misje* The vessel’s ballast water tank sustained damage during the allision, resulting in a water leak. No injuries or pollution were reported in the incident. An internal investigation has been launched by Aker Solution to assess the extent of the damage. The cause of the allision remains unknown. [Wilson Flex IV](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:7205077/mmsi:255806463/imo:9911460/vessel:WILSON_FLEX_IV) is a cargo vessel built in 2022. It measures 88.5 metres in length and 14.55 metres in width.

headline: Singapore Authorities Respond After Barge Grounds Off Sentosa’s Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 6th June, the container barge Marco Polo 802 ran aground off Tanjong Beach in Sentosa, Singapore. ![MARCO POLO 809 ran aground in Singapore.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MARCO_POLO_809_590910976a.png)*Barge MARCO POLO 809, image credit: Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA)* Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) reported that the incident caused no structural damage to the barge. However, some security barriers were damage in the incident. The barge carrying containers remained structurally intact. No injuries or oil spillage have been reported. Tugboats were deployed and successfully refloated the barge. Meanwhile, operations on the beach remain unaffected, and the area remains open to the public. Investigation into the cause of the grounding is ongoing.

headline: UECC Expands Med-North Europe Route with New Vessel and Turkish Port Call
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Norwegian RoRo transportation company United European Car Carriers (UECC) has expanded its North-South shipping network with the addition of a new vessel and a new port of call to its route. The new vessel, a Pure Truck and Car Carrier (PCTC) named[ Blue Heritage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9264612/mmsi:636023928/imo:9968619/vessel:BLUE_HERITAGE), and the new port of call, the Turkish port of[ Yarimca,](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/18723?name=YARIMCA&country=Turkey) will make transport between the Mediterranean and Northern Europe more sustainable and frequent. ![BLUE HERITAGE join UECC fleet.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BLUE_HERITAGE_b3bb346aa4.png)*Vessel BLUE HERITAGE , image credit: Wim Lannoo* The Liberian-flagged vehicle carrier [Blue Heritage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9264612/mmsi:636023928/imo:9968619/vessel:BLUE_HERITAGE), is powered by a dual-fueled Liquefied Bio Methane (LBM) powered engine, which also boosts the company's sustainability. It has a length of 200 meters, and can carry 7,000 Car Equivalent Units on its 12 decks. Four of these decks are hoistable, which allows for high and heavy cargo and break bulk loads. The addition of this new vessel brings the number of UECC vessels on this route to 7. With this latest addition, UECC will be able to offer a sailing frequency of 4.5 days between Turkey and Northern Europe, which is the highest in the market. The inclusion of the new port of Yarimca means that the UECC service now includes 12 ports across Europe and increases the service regularity of UECC. UECC is also ahead of its goals regarding the EU's FuelEU Maritime and IMO's CII, which allows them to avoid extra surcharges for their customers.

headline: Crude Oil Leak from “Phoenix Jamnagar” Contained Off Sriracha Coast, Thailand
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 5th June, a crude oil spill occurred off the coast of Sriracha in Chonburi Province, Thailand. At approximately 11:54 PM local time, the Singapore-flagged crude oil tanker [Phoenix Jamnagar ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5860707/mmsi:563080600/imo:9828962/vessel:PHOENIX_JAMNAGAR)discharged 20 tons of crude oil following a pipeline rupture during offloading operations. ![PHOENIX JAMNAGAR oil spilled in Thailand.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/PHOENIX_JAMNAGAR_f9eeeec0d2.png)*Crude oil tanker PHOENIX JAMNAGAR, image credit: ThaiMECC* The incident took place at the Single Buoy Mooring 2 (SBM-2) terminal. Severe weather conditions caused a pipeline failure, causing oil to leak for approximately 30 minutes. Thai Oil Public Company Limited, the operator of SBM-2, immediately halted the transfer operation and activated its emergency response protocol. On 6th June at around 6:05 AM local time, Thai Oil notified the Thailand Maritime Enforcement Coordinating Center (ThaiMECC) about the oil slick measuring approximately 10 square metres and was drifting southward. In response, Thai Oil deployed three containment booms and dispersant chemicals to limit the spread of the oil. Additionally, a clean-up vessel, Chonthara Anurak, was dispatched to the site. A multi-agency task force, including the Royal Thai Navy, the Marine Department, the Pollution Control Department, and aerial surveillance teams operating UAVs, helicopters, and Dornier 228 patrol aircraft, was assembled to manage the response. Despite the adverse weather and rough seas, the oil spill was successfully sealed on 6th June. By 5:00 PM local time, the Thai Oil company confirmed that no further signs of crude oil leakage were detected in the sea or nearby areas. No injuries or impacts to marine life have been reported. Authorities are continuing to assess environmental conditions in the affected area. [Phoenix Jamnagar ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5860707/mmsi:563080600/imo:9828962/vessel:PHOENIX_JAMNAGAR)is a 2006-built crude oil tanker operated by MOL Tankship Management and chartered by Reliance Industries. According to MarineTraffic data, the vessel is currently anchored in [Sriracha Anchorage](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/22344?name=SRIRACHA-ANCH&country=Thailand), Thailand.

headline: Tug Runs Aground on Russia’s Yenisei River, Spills 30 Tons of Diesel Fuel
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 8th June, the Russian-flagged Tug [OT 2439 ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:350824/mmsi:273452670/imo:8995184/vessel:OT_2439#overview)sustained hull damage and ran aground on the Kazachinsky rapids of the Yenisei River in central Siberia, Russia. The incident resulted in a spill of approximately 30 tons of diesel fuel into the river. ![30 tons oil spill from grounded vessel OT 2439.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/OT_2439_127882777e.png)*Tug OT 2439, image credit:fontanka.ru* The incident occurred at around 6:00 pm local time while the vessel was towing two empty barges downstream. It struck an underwater obstacle, causing a breach in the hull and partial flooding. Subsequently, an oil leak was reported. Following the incident, emergency containment measures, including barrier and sorbent booms, were deployed to prevent the spread of the oil slick. However, the oil spill has drifted and is affecting the downstream riverbanks. A state of emergency has been declared in Kazachinsky district. There were 14 crew members on board at the time of the incident. Two were evacuated to shore, while the others remained to help contain the spill. Although there is no threat to nearby residents, authorities have expressed concern about the potential environmental impact on local flora and fauna. Russia’s Eastern Regional Transport Investigation Department has launched an investigation into the cause of the incident. [OT 2439](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:350824/mmsi:273452670/imo:8995184/vessel:OT_2439#overview) is a 1986-built tug that has a capacity of 197 tons. The vessel measures 51.56 metres in length and 12.01 metres in width.

headline: Explosion Aboard Singapore-Flagged Vessel Off Kerala Coast: Four Crew Missing
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 9th June, the Indian Coast Guard (ICG) responded to an explosion aboard the Singapore-flagged container ship [Wan Hai 503](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:727091/mmsi:563812000/imo:9294862/vessel:WAN_HAI_503) while it was transiting the Arabian Sea, approximately 130 nautical miles (NM) northwest of the Kerala coast, India. ![Explosion aboard WAN HAI 503 off Indian Coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/WAN_HAI_503_3d93fab849.png)*Containership WAN HAI 503, image credit: Indian Coast Guard (ICG)* The underdeck explosion was first reported at around 10:30 AM local time by the Maritime Operations Centre in Mumbai, which notified its counterpart in Kochi. Responding swiftly, the Indian Navy redirected INS Surat to assist the distressed vessel. The Public Relations Officer of the ICG stated that [Wan Hai 503 ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:727091/mmsi:563812000/imo:9294862/vessel:WAN_HAI_503)was carrying containerized cargo and had 22 crew members on board. Eighteen crew members were rescued from lifeboats, five of whom sustained injuries. Four crew members remain missing. The vessel is currently on fire and adrift at sea, with 40 containers reported to have fallen overboard. Multiple Indian Coast Guard assets including Coast Guard ship Rajdoot, Arnvesh, and Sachet, were diverted from their current duties to support the emergency response. Additionally, a Coast Guard Dornier aircraft was deployed to assess the situation at the scene of the explosion. [Wan Hai 503](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:727091/mmsi:563812000/imo:9294862/vessel:WAN_HAI_503) is a 2005-built containership with a carrying capacity of 4,252 TEU. According to MarineTraffic data, the 268.8-metre-long vessel departed from [Colombo Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1272?name=COLOMBO&country=Sri-Lanka), in Sri Lanka on 7th June and was scheduled to arrive [Nhava Sheva](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2713?name=NHAVA-SHEVA&country=India), India by 10th June.

headline: Update: Explosion Aboard Singapore-Flagged Vessel Off Kerala Coast: Four Crew Missing
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 9th June, the Indian Coast Guard (ICG) responded to an explosion aboard the Singapore-flagged container ship [Wan Hai 503](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:727091/mmsi:563812000/imo:9294862/vessel:WAN_HAI_503) while it was transiting the Arabian Sea, approximately 130 nautical miles (NM) northwest of the Kerala coast, India. ![Explosion aboard WAN HAI 503 off Indian Coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/WAN_HAI_503_3d93fab849.png)*Containership WAN HAI 503, image credit: Indian Coast Guard (ICG)* The underdeck explosion was first reported at around 10:30 AM local time by the Maritime Operations Centre in Mumbai, which notified its counterpart in Kochi. Responding swiftly, the Indian Navy redirected INS Surat to assist the distressed vessel. The Public Relations Officer of the ICG stated that [Wan Hai 503 ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:727091/mmsi:563812000/imo:9294862/vessel:WAN_HAI_503)was carrying containerized cargo and had 22 crew members on board. Eighteen crew members were rescued from lifeboats, five of whom sustained injuries. Four crew members remain missing. The vessel is currently on fire and adrift at sea, with around 40 containers reported to have fallen overboard. In the latest update from ICG, the fires and explosions are reported to persist from midships to the container bay ahead of the accommodation block. The forward-bay fire is now under control, although thick smoke continues to hinder visibility. The vessel is listing approximately 10–15° to port. Additional containers have been reported as lost overboard. Multiple Indian Coast Guard assets including Coast Guard ship Rajdoot, Arnvesh, and Sachet, were diverted from their current duties to support the emergency response. Additionally, a Coast Guard Dornier aircraft was deployed to assess the situation at the scene of the explosion. [Wan Hai 503](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:727091/mmsi:563812000/imo:9294862/vessel:WAN_HAI_503) is a 2005-built containership with a carrying capacity of 4,252 TEU. According to MarineTraffic data, the 268.8-metre-long vessel departed from [Colombo Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1272?name=COLOMBO&country=Sri-Lanka), in Sri Lanka on 7th June and was scheduled to arrive [Nhava Sheva](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2713?name=NHAVA-SHEVA&country=India), India by 10th June.

headline: Cargo Vessel Grounds off Trinidad Coast, Triggers Environmental Concerns
author: Raghib Raza
content: The general cargo vessel [Hein](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:764321/mmsi:750000045/imo:6702284/vessel:HEIN#overview) ran aground and became partially submerged off the southern coast of Monas Island in Chaguaramas, Trinidad and Tobago, on 11th June. ![HEIN partially listed after running aground in Trinidad and Tobago.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/HEIN_899d503d48.png)*Vessel HEIN, image credit:stvincenttimes.com* The incident occurred while the vessel was en route to [Kingstown](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/3027?name=KINGSTOWN&country=St-Vincent-Grenadines), St Vincent Grenadines, carrying bricks. A sudden shift in cargo caused the vessel to list to port, compromising its stability. No injuries were reported in the incident. To avert capsizing after a cargo shift, the crew crew intentionally grounded the vessel. The hull reportedly remained intact; however, hydrocarbons have begun leaking from the bilge into the Gulf of Paria and Chaguaramas basin raising serious environmental concerns. Authorities have confirmed that efforts are underway to refloat [Hein](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:764321/mmsi:750000045/imo:6702284/vessel:HEIN#overview). Meanwhile, the environmental organization Fishermen and Friends of the Sea has called for immediate action. The organization has urged activating Trinidad and Tobago’s National Oil Spill Contingency Plan to contain the spill and protect fragile marine ecosystems and coastal livelihoods. [Hein](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:764321/mmsi:750000045/imo:6702284/vessel:HEIN#overview) is a 1966-built cargo vessel sailing under the flag of Guyana. The vessel measures a length of 61.75 metres, width of 10.04 metres and has a carrying capacity of 1065 tonnes.

headline: Ro-Ro Vessel Towed to Safety After Drifting Off Canary Islands
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 10th June, the Ro-Ro cargo vessel [Canarias Express](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:168980/mmsi:255916246/imo:9331191/vessel:CANARIAS_EXPRESS#overview) experienced engine failure and drifted unsteered for several hours between the Canary Islands of Fuerteventura and Lanzarote, Spain. No injuries or pollution were reported in the incident. ![CANARIAS EXPRESS drifted in Spain.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/CANARIAS_EXPRESS_891af4fb87.png)*Vessel CANARIAS EXPRESS, image credit: F.Rull* The vessel became stranded at approximately 6:50 AM local time, a few miles north of Isla de Lobos. The Spanish Maritime Safety Agency's SAR vessel [Guardamar Polimnia](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:165531/mmsi:224179000/imo:9541679/vessel:GUARDAMAR_POLIMNIA) arrived on the scene around 8:50 AM, preventing the [Canarias Express](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:168980/mmsi:255916246/imo:9331191/vessel:CANARIAS_EXPRESS#overview) from running aground amid strong local currents. Subsequently, tugboat [VB Achaman](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:172509/mmsi:225991741/imo:8615617/vessel:VB_ACHAMAN) arrived to tow the distressed vessel. After five hours of towing, the vessel arrived safely at [Arrecife port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2207?name=ARRECIFE&country=Spain), Spain. Authorities confirmed that the situation was under control throughout the operation. [Canarias Express](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:168980/mmsi:255916246/imo:9331191/vessel:CANARIAS_EXPRESS#overview) is a vessel sailing under the flag of Portugal and operated by OPDR Canarias. The vessel has a length of 145 metres and a width of 22.2 metres.

headline: UK-Based Union Maritime Names Upcoming New Wind-Assisted Product Tanker
author: Raghib Raza
content: UK-based shipping company Union Maritime Limited named its upcoming vessel Brands Hatch in a naming ceremony held in Shanghai on 11th June. The vessel, which is expected to be delivered in the coming weeks, features three 40m wing sails that can reduce its annual CO2 emissions by 12% annually. ![BRANDS HATCH christened by UML.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/BRANDS_HATCH_7f72a0341a.png)*Vessel BRANDS HATCH, image credit: BAR Technologies* The ship is being built at the Shanghai Waigaoqiao Shipbuilding shipyard, a subsidiary of the China State Shipbuilding Corporation. The vessel, christened Brands Hatch, is 249.95 metres long, has a beam of 44 metres, and can carry around 800,000 barrels of crude products. The vessel also features three retractable wing sails that are more than 40 metres in height. The wing sails, developed by BAR Technologies, are fitted alongside hydraulics and digital control systems that allow for their retraction and adjustment when needed. These wingsails are claimed to be able to reduce the vessel's emissions by around 12% per year, preventing the emission of around 5,000 tons of CO2. The vessel has already begun undergoing sea trials.

headline: South Korean Vessel Rescues 23 Sailors After Bulk Carrier “RUN FU 3” Capsizes Near Maldives
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 11th June, the Panama-flagged bulk carrier [Run Fu 3](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:674607/mmsi:374230000/imo:9138903/vessel:RUN_FU_3) capsized approximately 500 nautical miles south of the Maldives in the Indian Ocean, prompting all 23 crew to abandon the vessel. Fortunately, no casualties were reported. ![RUN FU 3 crew rescued from Indian ocean after the vessel capsized.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RUN_FU_3_31ef02f449.png)*Vessel RUN FU 3, image credit: South Korea's Ministry of Oceans and Fisheries* The incident occurred following severe flooding in one of the vessel's cargo holds. After unsuccessful efforts to contain the flooding, the crew evacuated into life rafts. Upon receiving a distress signal at around 7:00 a.m. local time, the South Korean-flagged bulk carrier [Maple Harbor](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:420973/mmsi:440049000/imo:9593323/vessel:MAPLE_HARBOUR#overview), en route to Italy, diverted course to assist the drifting crew in the life rafts. At around 1:20 p.m., [Maple Harbor](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:420973/mmsi:440049000/imo:9593323/vessel:MAPLE_HARBOUR#overview) successfully rescued all crew members of [Run Fu 3](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:674607/mmsi:374230000/imo:9138903/vessel:RUN_FU_3), including 21 Vietnamese nationals and two from Myanmar. Following the rescue, the rescued crew were provided with food, water, and a place to rest aboard the Korean vessel. Arrangements are underway to disembark the rescued crew safely at [Louis port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1441?name=PORT-LOUIS&country=Mauritius) in Mauritius, in coordination with the operator of the sunken ship. [Run Fu 3](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:674607/mmsi:374230000/imo:9138903/vessel:RUN_FU_3) is a 1997-built bulk carrier, measuring 171.6 metres in length and 27 metres in width. According to MarineTraffic data, the bulk carrier departed from [Tianjin Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/309?name=TIANJIN&country=China), China on 20th May and was scheduled to arrive at [Lome](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1158?name=LOME&country=Togo), Togo by 7th July.

headline: Another Fire Involving Singapore-Flagged Vessel Reported in Indian Waters
author: Raghib Raza
