content: On 12th June, a fire was reported aboard the container vessel[ Interasia Tenacity](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9239308/mmsi:563242900/imo:1018145/vessel:INTERASIA_TENACITY) while it was transiting the Arabian Sea off the coast of Kerala, India. ![Fire aboard INTERASIA TENACITY off Indian Coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/INTERASIA_TENACITY_dc8be51f8f.png)*Containership INTERASIA TENACITY, image credit: Fumia* The vessel, with 21 Filipino crew members, departed from[ Port Klang](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/483?name=PORT-KLANG&country=Malaysia), Malaysia, on 8th June, carrying 1,387 containers. It is scheduled to arrive at [Nhava Sheva Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2713?name=NHAVA-SHEVA&country=India), India, on 14th June. Authorities have confirmed that no casualties or environmental pollution occurred in the incident. The fire broke out at approximately 8:40 a.m. local time and was confined to a single container on the container ship's deck. The Indian Coast Guard (ICG) responded swiftly to the distress call and redirected its offshore patrol vessel, ICGS Sachet, to the scene. Additionally, ICG aircraft Dornier was also deployed to provide aerial surveillance of the situation. The ICG reported that the Interasia Tenacity's crew acted swiftly to contain the fire without requiring external firefighting support. However, the ICG continues to monitor the vessel while it continues its voyage. This marks another fire incident involving the containership in Indian water within a week. On 9th June Singapore-flagged containership [Wan Hai 503](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:727091/mmsi:563812000/imo:9294862/vessel:WAN_HAI_503) caught fire after an onboard explosion off the Kerala Coast. [Interasia Tenacity](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9239308/mmsi:563242900/imo:1018145/vessel:INTERASIA_TENACITY) is a 2024-built container ship sailing under the flag of Singapore. The vessel measures a length of 194.50 metres and a width of 34.80 metres.

headline: Grounded Bulk Carrier Offloads Limestone in Ship-to-Ship Operation
author: Raghib Raza
content: The American news outlet reported that the self-discharging bulk carrier [Hon. James L.Oberstar](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:429064/mmsi:366904890/imo:5322518/vessel:HON_JAMES_L_OBERSTAR), which ran aground on 8th June, has begun transferring its cargo to another vessel in a ship-to-ship operation. No injuries were reported in the incident. ![HON.JAMES L.OBERSTAR offload its cargo after running aground.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/HON_JAMES_L_OBERSTAR_1aaa754b99.png)*Vessel HON.JAMES L.OBERSTAR , image credit:sooleader.com* The grounding occurred on 8th June at approximately 3:50 p.m. local time after the vessel experienced unusual vibrations while navigating a turn near Johnson Point on the east end of Neebish Island. The crew promptly anchored the vessel at nearby Hay Lake, USA, and notified the U.S. Coast Guard. The vessel carries 108,000 gallons of fuel and oil products. However, no oil pollution was reported. Anti-pollution equipment has been deployed around the vessel's stern, and the Coast Guard is regularly monitoring for any signs of leakage. On 12th June, the bulk carrier [Kaye E. Barker](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:429065/mmsi:366904910/imo:5097450/vessel:KAYE_E_BARKER) went alongside the US-flagged vessel[ Hon. James L. Oberstar](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:429064/mmsi:366904890/imo:5322518/vessel:HON_JAMES_L_OBERSTAR) to take the cargo of limestone. The 29,000 tonnes of limestone were being offloaded, aided by an on-site crane barge. [Hon. James L. Oberstar](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:429064/mmsi:366904890/imo:5322518/vessel:HON_JAMES_L_OBERSTAR) is a 1956-built vessel with a carrying capacity of 31,204 tonnes. It measures 245.66 metres in length and 22.86 metres in width.

headline: Kerala High Court in India Orders Arrest of MSC Vessel to Recover Damages
author: Raghib Raza
content: A high court in Kerala, India, ordered the conditional arrest of the vessel [MSC Manasa F](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:728756/mmsi:636020949/imo:9238882/vessel:MSC_MANASA_F) on 12th June, as the vessel was docked in [Vizhinjam Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/18972?name=VIZHINJAM-SEAPORT&country=India), Kerala. The order was issued after a local business owner filed a claim to recover damages from the Mediterranean Shipping Corporation (MSC) over the loss of their cargo in the sinking of the [MSC Elsa 3](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:757923/mmsi:636016814/imo:9123221/vessel:MSC_ELSA_3#overview). MSC has agreed to put the funds in security and has requested that the vessel not be detained. ![Indian High order of arrest of MSC MANASA F.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MSC_MANASA_F_389c38d96e.png)*Vessel MSC MASANA F, image credit: Aris Refugio* An arrest order was issued for the detention of the vessel [MSC Manasa F](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:728756/mmsi:636020949/imo:9238882/vessel:MSC_MANASA_F) over a claim of Rs. 1.54 crore (around $180,000) filed by the cargo owner, the business owner of Mangalath Cashews, based in Kerala, India. The cargo owner claims that he lost cargo in the capsizing of the [MSC Elsa 3](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:757923/mmsi:636016814/imo:9123221/vessel:MSC_ELSA_3#overview) and that the accident occurred due to the unseaworthiness of the vessel, lack of proper care, and improper stowage of containers resulting from crew incompetence. The cargo owner further contended that although the vessels [MSC Manasa F ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:728756/mmsi:636020949/imo:9238882/vessel:MSC_MANASA_F)and [MSC Elsa 3](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:757923/mmsi:636016814/imo:9123221/vessel:MSC_ELSA_3#overview) were registered under different companies, both vessels were owned and operated by MSC. He claimed that since MSC does not have any other movable or immovable property in India, the court should detain the vessel until the claimed funds are deposited in security. The counsel for MSC stated that they would submit the required amount in security on the same day, and hence, the detention of the vessel is not required. The court date for the next hearing of this petition has been set for 16th June.

headline: Passenger Ship with 123 Aboard Runs Aground off Sweden’s West Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Sweden-flagged passenger ship [St. Erik](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:323301/mmsi:265625300/imo:5422540/vessel:ST_ERIK), carrying 123 passengers and eight crew members, ran aground on June 13th, shortly after 1:00 p.m. local time, in the Gothenburg archipelago, located off the west coast of Sweden. ![ST. ERIK grounded off Sweden Coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ST_ERIK_d239a024af.png)*Passenger ship ST. ERIK, image credit: Malte Kopfer* Five passengers suffered minor injuries, who reportedly fell during the grounding. However, no medical emergencies were required for injured passengers. Following the incident, [St. Erik](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:323301/mmsi:265625300/imo:5422540/vessel:ST_ERIK) successfully refloated and proceeded under its own power to Fiskebäck harbour, where the rescue personnel conducted a thorough inspection of the vessel. No sign of leak or water ingress was found aboard the ship. The canal company confirmed that the ship will be taken to a shipyard for a detailed inspection. Local police have launched an investigation into the incident on grounds of suspected negligence in maritime traffic and causing bodily harm. [St. Erik](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:323301/mmsi:265625300/imo:5422540/vessel:ST_ERIK) is an 1880-built passenger ship with a carrying capacity of 246 gross tons. It is currently docked at [Ockero](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/692?name=OCKERO&country=Sweden), Sweden.

headline: Norwegian-Flagged Vessel Collides with Moored Vessel; Captain Found Intoxicated
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Norwegian-flagged general cargo vessel [Wilson Nanjing ](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:149099/mmsi:259000000/imo:9431018/vessel:WILSON_NANJING)collided with a moored vessel at [Bremen port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/467?name=BREMEN&country=Germany), Germany on 12th June. No injuries or pollution were reported. ![WILSON NANJING collided with another docked vessel in Germany.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/WILSON_NANJING_7c51b14435.png)*Vessel WILSON NANJING, image credit: Ingo Seidlitz* The collision occurred at approximately 8:15 pm local time when [Wilson Nanjing](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:149099/mmsi:259000000/imo:9431018/vessel:WILSON_NANJING) was departing from Weserport Terminal 1 in Bremen’s industrial port. During the maneuver, the vessel’s port-side struck the bow of a stationary vessel docked at the pier, causing minor damage to both the vessels. In response, Bremen Water Police arrived and detected the smell of alcohol on the 55-year-old Russian captain. A voluntary breathalyzer test revealed a blood alcohol level that exceeded the permitted limit. The captain was immediately barred from continuing the voyage. The blood sample of the captain was collected for further analysis, and a $6000 security deposit was imposed. An investigation has been launched against the captain on suspicion of endangering maritime safety. The 123.04 metres-long vessel has been relocated to another berth at Bremen Port.

headline: Crane Accident at Singapore’s Tuas Port, No Fatalities Reported
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) reported that on the afternoon of June 15th, a major accident occurred when a newly delivered quay crane tipped over at a non-operational berth in [Tuas Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/terminals/3674?name=Tuas-Terminal&port=SINGAPORE&country=Singapore), Singapore. The Port of Singapore Authority (PSA) stated that no injuries or fatalities were reported from the incident. ![Crane collapsed Tuas Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/TUAS_PORT_29bb5149da.png)*TUAS PORT, image credit:X/@anthraxxxx* Despite the accident, adjacent port equipment and facilities sustained no damage. PCA confirmed that port operations and development work remained operational without disruption and that all active berths remained accessible. The incident is currently under investigation. PSA and the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) are coordinating with relevant authorities to determine the cause of the incident. [Tuas Port](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/terminals/3674?name=Tuas-Terminal&port=SINGAPORE&country=Singapore) became operational in 2021 and currently consists of 11 Berths. An additional berth is expected to open later this year, followed by four more in 2026 and two in 2027.The Tuas Port, designed to handle up to 65 million TEUs, is set to be completed by 2040. After completion, the port will be the largest automated container terminal.

headline: Two tankers collided in Gulf of Oman
author: Stephanie Duscha
content:
![Adalynn Front Eagle Collision.png](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/Adalynn_Front_Eagle_Collision_007b8f5cb6.png) Two crude oil tankers, [Adalynn](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:149391/mmsi:305091000/imo:9231767/vessel:ADALYNN) and [Front Eagle](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6078102/mmsi:636021815/imo:9855343/vessel:FRONT_EAGLE), collided near Khor Fakkan anchorage on Monday evening 16 June 2025 at 21:14 UTC.

According to MarineTraffic data, the Libyan-flagged vessel Front Eagle was loaded and bound for Zhousan, China. Adalynn, flagged to Antigua Barbuda and built in 2002, had just departed the anchorage with ballast when the collision occurred a short time later, about 24 miles off the UAE coast. At 01.51 UTC today, Front Eagle changed her status to Not Under Command. Adalynn is stopped at Fujairah anchorage since 21:48 UTC yesterday.

UAE Coast Guard has confirmed the incident. All 24 crew members of the Adalynn were also reported to have been rescued.

Initial reports indicated that a third ship was also involved. MarineTraffic playback shows that only these two vessels were involved in the collision.

headline: Freighter Takes on Water in Germany, Emergency Response Prevents Sinking
author: Raghib Raza
content: An inland freighter, [Esche](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:135499/mmsi:211462010/imo:0/vessel:ESCHE#overview), developed a leak while navigating the Dortmund-Ems Canal near Ibbenbüren-Dörenthe, Germany, late on 15th June. The vessel, carrying 1,300 tons of gravel, was at risk of sinking. ![ESCHE developed leak Dortmund-Ems Canal, Germany.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/ESCHE_c3b6779827.png)*Freighter ESCHE, image credit:wdr.de* The incident prompted an immediate response from local emergency services. Around 50 firefighters were deployed to the scene and worked for several hours to stabilize the vessel. Crews successfully pumped out water from the freighter and began offloading its cargo to prevent further risk. Authorities reported that none of the two crewmembers were injured. No pollution was observed in the incident, and the cause of the leak remains under investigation. [Eshe](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:135499/mmsi:211462010/imo:0/vessel:ESCHE#overview) is a German-flagged inland motor freighter. The 1940-built vessel is currently moored at [Dorenthe](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/4423?name=DORENTHE&country=Germany), Germany.

headline: Engine Room Fire Disables "Industrial Challenger" Off Turkish Coast; Vessel Safely Towed
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 17th June, Turkey’s Directorate General of Coastal Safety (KEGM) reported an maritime incident involving a fire aboard the Antigua Barbuda-flagged heavy lift vessel [Industrial Challenger](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:714395/mmsi:305146000/imo:9213935/vessel:INDUSTRIALCHALLENGER#overview). The incident took place while the vessel was transiting the Çanakkale Strait in Turkey. ![INDUSTRIAL CHALLENGER suffer fire and began drifting off the Turkey's coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/INDUSTRIAL_CHALLENGER_d5bb962a69.png)*Vessel INDUSTRIALCHALLENGER, image credit: KEGM* According to KEGM, the fire broke out in the vessel’s engine room, causing it to lose engine power and begin drifting off the coast of Kumkale. The Çanakkale Vessel Traffic Services (VTS) Center promptly responded to the emergency and dispatched maritime rescue units. The tugboats [Turkeli](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:4934190/mmsi:271044683/imo:9816256/vessel:TURKELI) and [Kurtarma-13](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:6570757/mmsi:271048466/imo:9913573/vessel:KURTARMA_13), along with the rescue boat [KIYEM-1](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:339354/mmsi:271042656/imo:0/vessel:KIYEM_1), were deployed to assist the distressed vessel. Kurtarma-13 successfully towed the 120-metre-long vessel to a safe anchorage in Karanlık Liman. No injuries or pollution were reported. As a precautionary measure, vessel traffic through the Çanakkale Strait was temporarily suspended during the operation. The strait has since been reopened to navigation in both directions. [Industrial Challenger](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:714395/mmsi:305146000/imo:9213935/vessel:INDUSTRIALCHALLENGER#overview) is a 2000-built vessel that was en route from [Marmaris](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/73?name=MARMARIS&country=Turkey) to [Yalova](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17805?name=YALOVA&country=Turkey) at the time of the incident. According to the MarineTraffic data, the vessel is currently anchored at [Çanakkale](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/17451?name=CANAKKALE&country=Turkey), Turkey.

headline: All 43 Rescued After Ferry “Melita” Sinks Off Croatian Coast
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 16th June, the high-speed ferry [Melita](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:208956/mmsi:238125441/imo:8517413/vessel:MELITA), carrying 38 passengers and five crew members, sank off Croatia's coast after being damaged by waves that caused a crack in its hull. The incident occurred shortly before 10 p.m. local time, just minutes before the vessel was scheduled to dock at the Port of[ Zadar](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/1303?name=ZADAR&country=Croatia), Croatia. ![MELITA sank off Croatia coast.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/MELITA_c76e29cad3.png)*Ferry MELITA, image credit:balkaninsight.com* Following the incident, all passengers and crew evacuated into a life raft. In response, the ferry Jadran, operated by the state-owned company Jadrolinija, and a rescue vessel from the Zadar Port Authority were dispatched to assist the distressed passengers. The rescue boat towed the life raft, allowing everyone to board Jadran safely. No injuries or casualties were reported. The rescued crew and passengers were then transported to the nearby port of Gaženica. [Melita](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:208956/mmsi:238125441/imo:8517413/vessel:MELITA) is a 1985-built ferry sailing under the flag of Croatia. It has a length of 27.01 metres and width of 9.1 metres.

headline: Two Killed, Two Injured in Inland Vessel Accident at Port of Rotterdam
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 19th June, a fatal accident occurred aboard an inland motor freighter, [Ronny-O](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3364502/mmsi:205484290/imo:0/vessel:RONNY_O), at [Waalhaven](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/2039?name=ROTTERDAM-WAALHAVEN&country=Netherlands) in the Port of Rotterdam, Netherlands. ![Fatal accident onboard RONNY O in Netherlannds.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RONNY_O_cd8936f893.png)*Vessel RONNY O, image credit: Wolfgang Hamann* At approximately 7:45 am local time, the incident took place in the vessel’s hold while employees of Rotterdam-based transshipment company Steinweg were unloading steel plates at terminal C of the Steinweg-Handelsveem. Two workers were killed, and two others were seriously injured. Emergency services responded swiftly, with the skipper of a nearby vessel reportedly providing first aid. A trauma helicopter, fire brigade, and police also arrived at the scene. Resuscitation efforts were made, and the two injured workers were evacuated from the hold using a crane. It is suspected that the workers might have ended up under the steel plates during the offloading operation. The exact cause of the incident remains unclear. The Dutch Labour Inspectorate has launched an investigation, and the Rotterdam-Rijnmond Safety Region confirmed that the area has been set up as a crime scene to aid in determining the cause of the accident. Waalhaven 6 has been closed until further notice as the inquiry continues. The [Ronny-O](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:3364502/mmsi:205484290/imo:0/vessel:RONNY_O), a 110-metre-long inland vessel sailing under the Belgian flag, had arrived in Waalhaven from Gorinchem on 18th June.

headline: Cyprus-Flagged Vessel Stellamar Refloated After Grounding Near Near Finnish Port
author: Raghib Raza
content: On the morning of 20th June, the cargo vessel [Stellamar](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8460304/mmsi:210546000/imo:9951836/vessel:STELLAMAR#overview) ran aground off the Rauma coast, Finland. The vessel carrying eight crewmembers became stranded while en route from [Kunda](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/5043?name=KUNDA&country=Estonia), Estonia. ![STELLAMAR ran aground off Finish port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/STELLAR_b6df31ff45.png)*Vessel STELLAR, image credit:X/Western Finland Coast Guard* The Western Finland Coast Guard had been notified, and a patrol from the Rauma Coast Guard Station arrived at the scene. According to the Coast Guard, the vessel was later refloated and moved to a nearby pier. No injuries or pollution were reported. [Stellamar](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:8460304/mmsi:210546000/imo:9951836/vessel:STELLAMAR#overview) is a 2024-built cargo vessel sailing under the flag of Cyprus. The vessel measures 89 metres in length and 15 metres in width and has a carrying capacity of 5,350 tonnes. According to MarineTraffic data, the laden vessel is currently moored at [Rauma](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/712?name=RAUMA&country=Finland) Port.

headline: Grounded Cement Carrier Freed in Cleveland with Tug, Coast Guard Aid
author: Raghib Raza
content: The Canada-flagged cement carrier [Sunnanvik](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:319833/mmsi:316018180/imo:7633375/vessel:SUNNANVIK) was successfully refloated after running grounded in the narrow mouth of the Cuyahoga River in Cleveland, USA, on 20th June. No injuries or pollution were reported. ![SUNNANVIK refloated after ground in Cleveland Port.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/SUNNANVIK_711ab802a3.png)*Vessel SUNNANVIK, image credit: M.Bouman* At approximately 12:43 a.m. local time, the vessel carrying 35 tons of cement became stranded between the east and west banks of the river, causing temporarily disrupting river traffic. The incident prompted a coordinated response involving the Great Lakes Towing Company and the U.S. Coast Guard. By 6:00 a.m., the vessel was refloated with the combined efforts of the U.S. Coast Guard and tugboats [New York](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:5841478/mmsi:367793450/imo:9820154/vessel:NEW_YORK) and [Wisconsin](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:9028700/mmsi:368161390/imo:0/vessel:WISCONSIN). Following the operation, river traffic was promptly resumed, and Sunnanvik continued its journey to [Loyalist Cove](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ports/14593?name=LOYALIST-COVE&country=Canada), Canada. The cause of the grounding is under investigation. [Sunnanvik](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:319833/mmsi:316018180/imo:7633375/vessel:SUNNANVIK) is a 1978-built cement carrier measuring 124 metres in length and 18 metres in width.

headline: Heavy Lift Vessel Allides with Quay in Suez Canal Following Steering Failure
author: Raghib Raza
content: On 20th June, the Liberian-flagged heavy lift vessel [Red Zed I](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2260693/mmsi:636016990/imo:9633977/vessel:RED_ZED_I#overview) allided with a quay in the Suez Canal after experiencing a technical failure that caused a loss of steering control. No injuries or pollution were reported. ![RED ZED I allided with quay in Suez Canal.](https://kp-strapi-media-maritime-news-prod-main.s3.eu-west-1.amazonaws.com/RED_ZED_I_9bba65114e.png)*Vessel RED ZED I, image credit: X/@Theseainarabic* The vessel veered off course and struck the quay near the 45-kilometre mark of the Suez, prompting a swift response from the Suez Canal Authority (SCA).Three tugboats were dispatched by SCA to assist and secure the vessel. According to the official reports, the crew of Red Zed I was able to carry out repairs, and the vessel resumed transit under its own power, escorted by the tugs. The SCA confirmed that canal traffic remained unaffected throughout the operation. The extent of damage to the quay or the vessel has not yet been disclosed. [Red Zed I](https://www.marinetraffic.com/en/ais/details/ships/shipid:2260693/mmsi:636016990/imo:9633977/vessel:RED_ZED_I#overview) is a 2015-built heavy lift vessel with a carrying capacity of 51,476 tonnes. According to MarineTraffic data, the laden vessel is currently anchored at the Suez Canal.
